d.crumb: the root of the middle way

f.d: Insight—The Stanzas of the Root of the Middle Way
by Nāgārjuna
rgya gar skad du/ pra dz+nyA nA ma mU la ma d+h+yA ma ka kA ri ka/ bod skad du/ dbu ma rtsa ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa shes rab ces bya/
[phyag]
Homage
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

gang gis rten cing 'brel par 'byung*/ / 'gag pa med pa skye med pa/ / chad pa med pa rtag med pa/ / 'ong ba med pa 'gro med pa/ / tha dad don min don gcig min/ / spros pa nyer zhi zhi bstan pa/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas smra rnams kyi/ / dam pa de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

That which originates dependently Does not cease and does not arise, Does not come and does not go, Is not annihilated and is not permanent, Is not different and not the same. To the true teacher who reveals this peace, The complete pacification of constructs, To the perfect Buddha I bow down.
[rkyen brtag pa zhes bya ba ste/ /rab tu byed pa dang po]
CHAPTER I. Analysis of Conditions
bdag las ma yin gzhan las min/ / gnyis las ma yin rgyu med min/ / dngos po gang dag gang na yang*/ / skye ba nam yang yod ma yin/ /
Not from itself, not from another, Not from both, and not uncaused— Nowhere does anything Ever arise. [I.1]
rkyen rnam bzhi ste rgyu dang ni/ / dmigs pa dang ni de ma thag / bdag po yang ni de bzhin te/ / rkyen lnga pa ni yod ma yin/ /
There are four conditions: Causal, objective, immediately preceding, And, likewise, the ruling. There is no fifth condition. [I.2]
dngos po rnams kyi rang bzhin ni/ / rkyen la sogs la yod ma yin/ / bdag gi dngos po yod min na/ / gzhan dngos yod pa ma yin no/ /
The nature of things is not In conditions and so forth. If there is no thing itself, How could there be anything other? [I.3]
bya ba rkyen dang ldan ma yin/ / rkyen dang mi ldan bya ba med/ / bya ba mi ldan rkyen ma yin/ / bya ba ldan yod 'on te na/ /
Actions do not have conditions, Yet there are no actions without conditions. Without an action there are no conditions, Yet no conditions are involved in an action. [I.4]
'di dag la brten skye bas na/ / de phyir 'di dag rkyen ces grag / ji srid mi skye de srid du/ / 'di dag rkyen min ji ltar min/ /
They are known as conditions Because things arise in dependence on them. Yet as long as nothing arises, Why would they not be nonconditions? [I.5]
med dam yod pa'i don la yang*/ / rkyen ni rung ba ma yin te/ / med na gang gi rkyen du 'gyur/ / yod na rkyen gyis ci zhig bya/ /
Neither for the nonexistent, nor for the existent, Could there possibly be conditions. For the nonexistent, what would be conditioned? For the existent, what role could conditions play? [I.6]
gang tshe chos ni yod pa dang*/ / med dang yod med mi 'grub pa/ / ji ltar sgrub byed rgyu zhes bya/ / de lta yin na mi rigs so/ /
If no existent, nonexistent, or both existent and nonexistent Phenomenon comes into being, How can we speak of “effectuating conditions”? When this is the case, they do not make sense. [I.7]
yod pa'i chos 'di dmigs pa ni/ / med pa kho na nye bar bstan/ / ci ste chos ni dmigs med na/ / dmigs pa yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
It is explained that, with existent phenomena, There are no observations whatsoever. How could a phenomenon for which there is no observation Ever relate to an observation? [I.8]
chos rnams skyes pa ma yin na/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / de phyir de ma thag mi rigs/ / 'gags na rkyen yang gang zhig yin/ /
If phenomena have not arisen, Cessation makes no sense. Hence, an immediately preceding condition is untenable. If it has ceased, how could it be a condition? [I.9]
dngos po rang bzhin med rnams kyi/ / yod pa gang phyir yod min na/ / 'di yod pas na 'di 'byung zhes/ / bya ba 'di ni 'thad ma yin/ /
Since there is no existence Of things that have no nature, Saying, “this occurs because of that” Would not make any sense. [I.10]
rkyen rnams so so 'dus pa la/ / 'bras bu de ni med pa nyid/ / rkyen rnams la ni gang med pa/ / de ni rkyen las ji ltar skye/ /
In separate conditions and their gathering, The effect is entirely absent. How could something that does not exist in the conditions Ever arise from them? [I.11]
ci ste de ni med par yang*/ / rkyen de dag las skye 'gyur na/ / rkyen ma yin pa dag las kyang*/ / ci yi phyir na skye mi 'gyur/ /
If, without being present there, It were still to arise from conditions, Why would it not also arise From that which is not a condition? [I.12]
'bras bu rkyen gyi rang bzhin na/ / rkyen rnams bdag gi rang bzhin min/ / bdag dngos min las 'bras bu gang*/ / de ni ji ltar rkyen rang bzhin/ /

The effect may be of its conditions’ nature, But these conditions have no nature of their own. How could the effect of that which is not an entity itself Be of the nature of that which conditions it? [I.13]
de phyir rkyen gyi rang bzhin min/ / rkyen min rang bzhin 'bras bu ni/ / yod min 'bras bu med pas na/ / rkyen min rkyen du ga la 'gyur/ /
Hence, it is not of the nature of its conditions, Nor of the nature of that which are not its conditions. As there is no effect, how could there be Conditions as well as nonconditions? [I.14]
rkyen brtag pa zhes bya ba ste/ /rab tu byed pa dang po'o/// ! //
['gro ba dang 'ong ba brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gnyis pa]
CHAPTER TWO. Analysis of Going and Coming
re zhig song la mi 'gro ste/ / ma song ba la'ang 'gro ba min/ / song dang ma song ma gtogs par/ / bgom pa shes par mi 'gyur ro/ /

Where there has been going, there is none; Where it has yet to occur, there is no going either. Aside from what has been traversed and what has not, No place where walking occurs can be identified. [II.1]
gang na g.yo ba de na 'gro / de yang gang gi bgom pa la/ / g.yo ba song min ma song min/ / de phyir bgom la 'gro ba yod/ /

Where there is movement, there is going, And movement is found where walking takes place, Not where going has been, nor where it has yet to occur. Hence, going is found where walking takes place. [II.2]
bgom la 'gro ba yin par ni/ / ji lta bur na 'thad par 'gyur/ / gang tshe 'gro ba med pa yi/ / bgom pa 'thad pa med phyir ro/ /
Going where walking takes place, How could that make sense, When, without going, there cannot reasonably be Any place where walking takes place? [II.3]
gang gi bgom pa la 'gro ba/ / de yi bgom la 'gro med par/ / thal bar 'gyur te gang gi phyir/ / bgom la 'gro ba yin phyir ro/ /
For whomever there is going where walking takes place, It then follows That there is no going where walking takes place Because “going is found where walking takes place.” [II.4]
bgom la 'gro ba yod na ni/ / 'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur te/ / gang gis de bgom 'gyur ba dang*/ / de la 'gro ba gang yin pa'o/ /

If going took place where walking takes place, It would follow that there are two acts of going: One due to which tshere is a place with walking And another that is the going that happens there. [II.5]
'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur na/ / 'gro ba po yang gnyis su 'gyur/ / gang phyir 'gro po med par ni/ / 'gro ba 'thad par mi 'gyur phyir/ /
When it follows that there are two acts of going, It follows that there are two agents of going, Because without something that goes, It makes no sense for there to be going. [II.6]
gal te 'gro po med gyur na/ / 'gro ba 'thad par mi 'gyur te/ / 'gro ba med na 'gro ba po/ / yod pa nyid du ga la 'gyur/ /
If there is nothing that goes, Going makes no sense. In the absence of any going, How could there be one who goes? [II.7]
re zhig 'gro po mi 'gro ste/ / 'gro ba po min 'gro ba min/ / 'gro po 'gro po min las gzhan/ / gsum pa gang zhig 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
One who goes does not go, Nor does one who does not go. Other than goers and nongoers, What third party could be going? [II.8]
gang tshe 'gro ba med par ni/ / 'gro po 'thad par mi 'gyur na/ / re zhig 'gro po 'gro'o zhes/ / ji ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
When, in the absence of going, A goer does not make sense, The statement “going is engaged in by the one who goes”— How could that possibly make sense? [II.9]
gang gi phyogs la 'gro ba po/ / 'gro ba de la 'gro med pa/ / 'gro po yin par thal 'gyur te/ / 'gro po 'gro bar 'dod phyir ro/ /

For those who hold that going is engaged in by one who goes It would then follow that there is One who goes in the absence of going, For it is asserted that going is performed by one who goes. [II.10]
gal te 'gro po 'gro gyur na/ / 'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur te/ / gang gis 'gro por mngon pa dang*/ / 'gro por gyur nas gang 'gro ba'o/ /
If going is engaged in by the one who goes, It follows that there are two acts of going: One that characterizes the one who goes, And another going in that capacity. [II.11]
song la 'gro ba'i rtsom med de/ / ma song ba la'ang 'gro rtsom med/ / bgom la rtsom pa yod min na/ / gang du 'gro ba rtsom par byed/ /
Going does not begin where it has been, Nor does it begin where it has yet to occur. Going does not begin where walking takes place, So where does going begin? [II.12]
'gro ba rtsom pa'i snga rol na/ / gang du 'gro ba rtsom 'gyur ba/ / bgom pa med cing song ba med/ / ma song 'gro ba ga la yod/ /
Before going has been initiated, There is no place where walking occurs or has taken place Upon which going could begin. And how could there be going where there is none yet? [II.13]
'gro rtsom rnam pa thams cad du/ / snang ba med pa nyid yin na/ / song ba ci zhig bgom pa ci/ / ma song ci zhig rnam par brtag /
Since we never witness a beginning of going How can we conceive of the traversed, Of what is being traversed, And what has yet to be traversed? [II.14]
re zhig 'gro po mi sdod de/ / 'gro ba po ni sdod pa min/ / 'gro po 'gro po min las gzhan/ / gsum pa gang zhig sdod par 'gyur/ /
The one who goes does not stand still, Nor does one who does not go. Aside from those that do and do not go, What third party could stand still? [II.15]
gang tshe 'gro ba med par ni/ / 'gro po 'thad par mi 'gyur na/ / re zhig 'gro po sdod do zhes/ / ji ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
In the absence of going, There cannot reasonably be anyone who goes. How, then, could it reasonably be said That it is the one who goes who stands still? [II.16]
bgom lam ldog par mi 'gyur te/ / song dang ma song las kyang min/ / 'gro ba dang ni 'jug pa dang*/ / ldog pa yang ni 'gro dang mtshungs/ /
Stopping does not occur where walking takes place, Where going has been, or where it has yet to occur. With going, beginning, and stopping, The case is the same as with going. [II.17]
'gro ba de dang 'gro ba po/ / de nyid ces kyang byar mi rung*/ / 'gro ba dang ni 'gro ba po/ / gzhan nyid ces kyang byar mi rung*/ /
The act of going and the one who goes Cannot rightly be said to be the same. The act of going and the one who goes Cannot rightly be said to be different. [II.18]
gal te 'gro ba gang yin pa/ / de nyid 'gro po yin gyur na/ / byed pa po dang las nyid kyang*/ / gcig pa nyid du thal bar 'gyur/ /
If that which is the going Were also the one who goes, It would follow that agent and act Would be one and the same. [II.19]
gal te 'gro dang 'gro ba po/ / gzhan pa nyid du rnam brtag na/ / 'gro bo med pa'i 'gro ba dag / 'gro ba med pa'i 'gro bor 'gyur/ /
Yet if the going and goer Are thought to be different, There could be going without something that goes And someone who goes in the absence of going. [II.20]
gang dag dngos po gcig pa dang*/ / dngos po gzhan pa nyid du ni/ / grub par gyur pa yod min na/ / de gnyis grub pa ji ltar yod/ /
When two things cannot be Established as identical, Yet not as different things either, How can they be established at all? [II.21]
'gro ba gang gis 'gro bor mngon/ / 'gro ba de ni de 'gro min/ / gang phyir 'gro ba'i snga rol med/ / gang zhig gang du 'gro bar 'gyur/
The one who goes does not engage in the going That characterizes him as someone who goes, Because there is no one who goes before going. Someone goes somewhere. [II.22]
'gro ba gang gi 'gro bor mngon/ / de las gzhan pa de 'gro min/ / gang phyir 'gro bo gcig pu la/ / 'gro ba gnyis su mi 'thad do/ /

The one who goes does not engage in going other than The going that characterizes him as someone who goes, The reason being that for a single agent of going, It does not make sense for there to be two acts. [II.23]
'gro bo yin par gyur pa ni/ / 'gro rnam gsum du 'gro mi bya/ / ma yin par ni gyur de yang*/ / 'gro rnam gsum du 'gro mi byed/ /
Someone who goes does not engage In any of the three kinds of going. Someone who does not go does not engage In any of the three kinds of going. [II.24]
yin dang ma yin gyur pa yang*/ / 'gro rnam gsum du 'gro mi byed/ / de phyir 'gro dang 'gro bo dang*/ / bgrod par bya ba'ang yod ma yin/ /
Someone who does and does not go does not engage In any of the three kinds of going either. There is, therefore, no going, No one who goes, and nothing traversed. [II.25]
'gro ba dang 'ong ba brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gnyis pa'o/// ! //
[dbang po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gsum pa]
CHAPTER THREE. Analysis of the Sense Sources
lta dang nyan dang snom pa dang*/ / myong bar byed dang reg byed yid/ / dbang po drug ste de dag gi / spyod yul blta bar bya la sogs/ /
Sight, hearing, smell, Taste, touch, and cognition— The experiential domain of these six faculties Are the objects that are seen and so forth. [III.1]
lta de rang gi bdag nyid ni/ / de la lta ba ma yin nyid/ / gang zhig bdag la mi lta ba/ / de dag gzhan la ji ltar lta/ /
Sight does indeed not see Its own identity. How can something that does not see itself See anything else either? [III.2]
lta ba rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir/ / me yi dpes ni nus ma yin/ / song dang ma song bsgom pa yis/ / de ni lta bcas lan btab bo/ /
A solid establishment of sight cannot Be provided through the example of fire. With what was, has yet to be, and is being traversed We have replied to that along with sight. [III.3]
gang tshe cung zad mi lta ba/ / lta bar byed pa ma yin no/ / lta bas lta bar byed ces byar/ / de ni ji ltar rigs par 'gyur/ /
When nothing at all is seen, Neither is there one that sees. “Sight is what performs seeing,” How could this be right? [III.4]
lta ba lta nyid ma yin te/ / lta ba min pa mi lta nyid/ / lta ba nyid kyis lta ba po'ang*/ / rnam par bshad par shes par bya/ /
Sight does not see, Yet nonsight does not see either. Know that sight itself Also explains the one that sees. [III.5]
ma spangs lta po yod min te/ / lta ba spangs par gyur kyang ngo*/ / lto po med na blta bya dang*/ / lta ba de dag ga la yod/ /
Whether seeing is involved or not, There is nothing that sees. Without the one that sees, How could there be something seen and seeing? [III.6]
blta bya lta ba med pa'i phyir/ / rnam par shes pa la sogs bzhi/ / yod min nye bar len la sogs/ / ji lta bur na yod par 'gyur/ /
As there is nothing to see and no sight, The four, such as consciousness, do not exist. How could appropriation and other Such factors come into existence? [III.7]
lta bas nyan dang snom pa dang*/ / myong bar byed dang reg byed yid/ / nyan pa po dang mnyan la sogs/ / rnam par bshad par shes par bya/ /
Hearing, smell, Taste, touch, and cognition; The hearer, the heard, and so forth— Know that all are explained through sight. [III.8]
dbang po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gsum pa'o/// ! //
[phung po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bzhi pa]
CHAPTER FOUR. Analysis of the Aggregates
gzugs kyi rgyu ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs ni dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / gzugs zhes bya ba ma gtogs par/ / gzugs kyi rgyu yang mi snang ngo*/ /
Apart from the cause of form, Form is not observed. Likewise, aside from so-called form, No cause of form can be observed either. [IV.1]
gzugs kyi rgyu ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs na gzugs ni rgyu med par/ / thal bar gyur te don gang yang*/ / rgyu med pa ni gang na'ang med/ /
If there were form apart from its causes, It would follow that form has no cause. Yet there are no objects at all That do not have causes. [IV.2]
gal te gzugs ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs kyi rgyu zhig yod na ni/ / 'bras bu med pa'i rgyur 'gyur te/ / 'bras bu med pa'i rgyu med do/ /
If, aside from form, There were a cause of form, There would be a cause with no effect, Yet there are no causes without effects. [IV.3]
gzugs yod na yang gzugs kyi ni/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur nyid/ / gzugs med na yang gzugs kyi ni/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur nyid/ /
When form exists, A cause of form does not make sense, Yet when form does not exist, A cause of form doest not make sense either. [IV.4]
rgyu med pa yi gzugs dag ni/ / 'thad par mi rung rung min nyid/ / de phyir gzugs kyi rnam par rtog / 'ga' yang rnam par brtag mi bya/ /
A form without a cause is impossible, Utterly impossible. Therefore, do not give rise To any thoughts about form at all. [IV.5]
'bras bu rgyu dang 'dra ba zhes/ / bya ba 'thad pa ma yin te/ / 'bras bu rgyu dang mi 'dra zhes/ / bya ba'ang 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
It is not right to say That effects resemble their causes. It is not right to say That effects do not resemble their causes. [IV.6]
tshor dang 'du shes 'du byed dang*/ / sems dang dngos po thams cad kyang*/ / rnam pa dag ni thams cad du/ / gzugs nyid kyis ni rim pa mtshungs/ /
With feeling, identification, formation, Mind, and all things The steps are, in all regards, The same as in the case of form. [IV.7]
stong pa nyid kyis brtsad byas te/ / gang zhig lan 'debs smra byed pa/ / de yis thams cad lan btab min/ / bsgrub par ya dang mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
When a critique is made using emptiness, Whatever may be replied Will not be a reply, But the same as what is still to be proven. [IV.8]
stong pa nyid kyis bshad byas tshe/ / gang zhig skyon 'dogs smra byed pa/ / de yis thams cad skyon btags min/ / bsgrub par bya dang mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
When an explanation is given using emptiness Whatever flaws one may find Will not be found to be flaws, But the same as what is still to be proven. [IV.9]
phung po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bzhi pa'o/// ! //
[khams brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa lnga pa]
CHAPTER FIVE. Analysis of the Elements
nam mkha'i mtshan nyid snga rol na/ / nam mkha' cung zad yod ma yin/ / gal te mtshan las snga gyur na/ / mtshan nyid med par thal bar 'gyur/ /
Before the characteristics of space, There is no space whatsoever. If it existed before its characteristics, It would follow that it has no characteristics. [V.1]
mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos po ni/ / 'ga' yang gang na'ang yod ma yin/ / mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos med na/ / mtshan nyid gang du 'jug par 'gyur/ /
Something without characteristics Does not exist anywhere at all. Since there is no thing without characteristics, To what do the characteristics apply? [V.2]
mtshan nyid med pa mtshan nyid ni/ / mi 'jug mtshan nyid bcas la min/ / mtshan bcas mtshan nyid med pa las/ / gzhan la'ang 'jug par mi 'gyur ro/ /
Characteristics do not apply to what has them, Nor do they apply to what does not. Neither do characteristics apply to something Other than what does or does not have them. [V.3]
mtshan nyid 'jug pa ma yin na/ / mtshan gzhi 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / mtshan gzhi 'thad pa ma yin na/ / mtshan nyid kyang ni yod ma yin/ /
If characteristics have no application, It makes no sense that there should be bearers of them. If the bearers of characteristics are unreasonable, Their characteristics cannot exist either. [V.4]
de phyir mtshan gzhi yod min te/ / mtshan nyid yod pa nyid ma yin/ / mtshan gzhi mtshan nyid ma gtogs pa'i/ / dngos po yang ni yod ma yin/ /
Therefore, the bearers of characteristics do not exist, And characteristics themselves have no existence either. Yet aside from bearers and characteristics There are no entities. [V.5]
dngos po yod pa ma yin na/ / dngos med gang gi yin par 'gyur/ / dngos dang dngos med mi mthun chos/ / gang gis dngos dang dngos med shes/ /
If there is no entity, Of what would there be no entity? What entity, nonentity, or otherwise Would be the knower of entity and nonentity? [V.6]
de phyir nam mkha' dngos po min/ / dngos med ma yin mtshan gzhi min/ / mtshan nyid ma yin khams lnga po/ / gzhan gang dag kyang nam mkha' mtshungs/ /
Space, therefore, is not an entity, not a nonentity, Not a bearer of characteristics, not a characteristic. As for the other five elements, The case is the same as with space. [V.7]
blo chung gang dag dngos rnams la/ / yod pa nyid dang med nyid du/ / lta ba de ni blta bya ba/ / nye bar zhi ba zhi mi mthong*/ /
The feebleminded who see Things in terms of existence and nonexistence Fail to see what is to be seen— The peace of complete pacification. [V.8]
khams brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa lnga pa'o/// ! //
['dod chags dang chags pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa drug pa]
CHAPTER SIX. Analysis of Desire and the Desirous One
gal te 'dod chags snga rol na/ / 'dod chags med pa'i chags yod na/ / de la brtan nas 'dod chags yod/ / chags yod 'dod chags yod par 'gyur/ /
If, before the presence of desire, The desirous one exists without desire, Based on that, there would be desire. When the desirous one exists, so does desire. [VI.1]
chags pa yod par ma gyur na'ang*/ / 'dod chags yod par ga la 'gyur/ / chags pa la yang 'dod chags ni/ / yod dam med kyang rim pa mtshungs/ /
Yet if the desirous one does not exist, How could there possibly be desire? Given the presence or absence of desire, This follows also in the case of the desirous one. [VI.2]
'dod chags dang ni chags pa dag / lhan cig nyid du skye mi rigs/ / 'di ltar 'dod chags chags pa dag / phan tshun ltos pa med par 'gyur/ /
Desire and the desirous one Cannot reasonably arise together. In this case, desire and the desirous one Would not depend on one another. [VI.3]
gcig nyid lhan cig nyid med de/ / de nyid de dang lhan cig min/ / ci ste tha dad nyid yin na/ / lhan cig nyid du ji ltar 'gyur/ /
Identical things are not coexistent, As nothing is coexistent with itself. Yet if they are different, How could they be coexistent? [VI.4]
gal te gcig pu lhan cig na/ / grogs med pa yang de 'gyur ro/ / gal te tha dad lhan cig na/ / grogs med par yang der 'gyur ro/ /
If a single thing were coexistent, This would occur in isolation as well. If the different were coexistent, This would occur in isolation as well. [VI.5]
gal te tha dad lhan cig na/ / ci go 'dod chags chags pa dag / tha dad nyid du grub gyur ram/ / des na de gnyis lhan cig 'gyur/ /
If they are different and coexistent, How could desire and the desirous one Be established as two different things That would then be present together? [VI.6]
gal te 'dod chags chags pa dag / tha dad nyid du grub gyur na/ / de dag lhan cig nyid du ni/ / ci yi phyir na yongs su rtog /
If desire and the desirous one Are established as different, Then why would you think of them As being coexistent? [VI.7]
tha dad grub par ma gyur pas/ / de phyir lhan cig 'dod byed na/ / lhan cig rab tu grub pa'i phyir/ / tha dad nyid du yang 'dod dam/ /
If they are asserted to be coexistent Because their difference lacks establishment, Would you also assert their difference To prove their coexistence? [VI.8]
tha dad dngos po ma grub pas/ / lhan cig dngos po 'grub mi 'gyur/ / tha dad dngos po gang yod na/ / lhan cig dngos por 'dod par byed/ /
When things are not established as different, Neither are they established as coexistent. When there is a thing that is different, It may be claimed that it is coexistent. [VI.9]
de ltar 'dod chags chags pa dag / lhan cig lhan cig min mi 'grub/ / 'dod chags bzhin du chos rnams kun/ / lhan cig lhan cig min mi 'grub/ /

Therefore, desire and the desirous one Are not established as coexistent or otherwise. As is the case with desire and the desirous one, No phenomena are established as coexistent or otherwise. [VI.10]
'dod chags dang chags pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa drug pa'o// ! //
[skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bdun pa]
CHAPTER SEVEN. Analysis of the Characteristics of the Conditioned
gal te skye ba 'dus byas na/ / de la mtshan nyid gsum ldan 'gyur/ / ci ste skye ba 'dus ma byas/ / ji ltar 'dus byas mtshan nyid yin/ /
If arising were conditioned, It would possess these three characteristics. If arising were unconditioned, How could it be a characteristic of the conditioned? [VII.1]
skye la sogs gsum so so yis/ / 'dus byas mtshan nyid bya bar ni/ / nus min gcig la dus gcig tu/ / 'dus pa yang ni ji ltar rung*/ /
Arising and the other two are each Incapable of characterizing the conditioned. But how could they simultaneously Come together anywhere? [VII.2]
skye dang gnas dang 'jig rnams la/ / 'dus byas mtshan nyid gzhan zhig ni/ / gal te yod na thug med 'gyur/ / med na de dag 'dus byas min/ /
If arising, abiding, and cessation themselves Bear further characteristics of the conditioned, There will be an infinite regress. Yet if they do not, they are not conditioned. [VII.3]
skye ba'i skye bas rtsa ba yi/ / skye ba 'ba' zhig skyed par byed/ / rtsa ba'i skye bas skye ba yi/ / skye ba'ang skyed par byed pa yin/ /
Due to the arising of arising, There arises only fundamental arising, Yet fundamental arising is responsible For the arising of arising as well. [VII.4]
gal te khyod kyi skye ba'i skyes/ / rtsa ba'i skye ba skyed byed na/ / khyod kyi rtsa bas ma bskyed des/ / de ni ji ltar skyed par byed/ /
If your “arising of arising” Produces fundamental arising, How could it do so when not produced By this “fundamental arising?” [VII.5]
gal te khyod kyi rtsa ba yis/ / bskyed pa de yis rtsa skyed na/ / des ma bskyed pa'i rtsa ba des/ / de ni ji ltar skyed par byed/ /
If the product of this “fundamental arising” Itself produces fundamental arising, Then how could fundamental arising produce it, When it has not been produced by that? [VII.6]
gal te ma skyes pa de yis/ / de skyed par ni byed nus na/ / khyod kyi skye bzhin pa de yis/ / de skyed par ni 'dod la rag /
If that which has not yet arisen Were capable of production, Your assertion of production by the currently arising Would have been acceptable. [VII.7]
ji ltar mar me rang dang gzhan/ / snang bar byed pa de bzhin du/ / skye ba'ang rang dang gzhan gyi dngos/ / gnyis ka skyed par byed yin na/ /
Just as a light illumines Both itself and other things, Birth produces both itself As well as other things. [VII.8]
mar me dang ni gang dag na/ / de 'dug pa na mun pa med/ / mar mes ci zhig snang bar byed/ / mun pa sel bas snang byed yin/ /
Light itself and the place where it is— Neither of these have any darkness. What does light illuminate? Illumination occurs by dispelling darkness. [VII.9]
gang tshe mar me skye bzhin pa/ / mun pa dang ni phrad med na/ / ji ltar mar me skye bzhin pas/ / mun pa sel bar byed pa yin/ /
When light that is currently arising Does not encounter darkness, How could the currently arising light Illuminate the darkness? [VII.10]
mar me phrad pa med par yang*/ / gal te mun pa sel byed na/ / 'jig rten kun na gnas pa'i mun/ / 'di na gnas pa nges sel 'gyur/ /
If light were to dispel darkness, Even without encountering it, Then the one right here would dispel All the darkness in the world. [VII.11]
mar me rang dang gzhan gyi dngos/ / gal te snang bar byed 'gyur na/ / mun pa'ang rang dang gzhan gyi dngos/ / sgrib par 'gyur bar the tshom med/ /
If light could illumine Both itself and other things, Darkness would undoubtedly conceal Both itself and other things as well. [VII.12]
skye ba 'di ni ma skyes pas/ / rang gi bdag nyid ji ltar skyed/ / ci ste skyes pas skyed byed na/ / skyes na ci zhig bskyed du yod/ /
When it has not arisen itself, How could arising produce its own nature? If it does so having already arisen, Having arisen, what is it that is produced? [VII.13]
skyes dang ma skyes skye bzhin pa/ / ji lta bur yang mi skyed pa/ / de ni song dang ma song dang*/ / bgom pas rnam par bshad pa yin/ /
The arisen, unarisen, and arising Are not produced in any way. This was explained before By what was, will be, and is being traversed. [VII.14]
gang tshe skye ba yod pa na/ / skye bzhin 'di 'byung med pa'i tshe/ / ji ltar skye la brten nas ni/ / skye bzhin zhes ni brjod par bya/ /
When there is arising, Current arising occurs, Yet, when there is none, how can you claim That this current arising is based on arising? [VII.15]
rten cing 'byung ba gang yin pa/ / de ni ngo bo nyid kyis zhi/ / de phyir skye bzhin nyid dang ni/ / skye ba yang ni zhi ba nyid/ /
That which originates dependently Is peace by its very essence. Arising and the currently arising as well Are, therefore, peace itself. [VII.16]
gal te dngos po ma skyes pa/ / 'ga' zhig gang na yod gyur na/ / de ni skye 'gyur dngos po de/ / med na ci zhig skye bar 'gyur/ /
If an unarisen entity were to exist somewhere, Then that could arise. But, when it does not exist, What sort of thing could then arise? [VII.17]
gal te skye ba de yis ni/ / skye bzhin pa ni skyed byed na/ / skye ba de ni skye ba lta/ / gang zhig gis ni skyed par byed/ /
If arising gives rise To the currently arising, Then what, in turn, Gives rise to arising? [VII.18]
gal te skye ba gzhan zhig gis/ / de skyed thug pa med par 'gyur/ / ci ste skye ba med skye na/ / thams cad de bzhin skye bar 'gyur/ /
If arising is due to a separate arising There will be an infinite regress. If it arises without arising, Then so does everything else. [VII. 19]
re zhig yod dang med pa yang*/ / skye bar rigs pa ma yin zhing*/ / yod med nyid kyang ma yin zhes/ / gong du bstan pa nyid yin no/ /
The existent and nonexistent cannot reasonably arise. Something that is both Cannot do so either. Indeed, this has already been explained. [VII.20]
dngos po 'gag bzhin nyid la ni/ / skye ba 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig 'gag bzhin ma yin pa/ / de ni dngos por mi 'thad do/ /
A thing that is currently ceasing Cannot reasonably arise. A thing that is not currently ceasing Cannot reasonably be a thing. [VII.21]
dngos po gnas pa mi gnas te/ / dngos po mi gnas gnas pa min/ / gnas bzhin pa yang mi gnas te/ / ma skyes gang zhig gnas par 'gyur/ /
A thing that has abided does not abide, A thing that has yet to abide does not abide, And no currently abiding thing abides either. What thing abides that does not arise? [VII.22]
dngos po 'gag bzhin nyid la ni/ / gnas pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig 'gag bzhin ma yin pa/ / de ni dngos por mi 'thad do/ /
A thing that is currently ceasing Cannot reasonably abide. A thing that is not currently ceasing Cannot reasonably be a thing. [VII.23]
dngos po thams cad dus kun tu/ / rga dang 'chi ba'i chos yin na/ / gang dag rga dang 'chi med par/ / gnas pa'i dngos po gang zhig yod/ /
All things, at all times, Are subject to aging and death. What thing then remains Free from aging and death? [VII.24]
gnas pa gnas pa gzhan dang ni/ / de nyid kyis kyang gnas mi rigs/ / ji ltar skye ba rang dang ni/ / gzhan gyis bskyed pa ma yin bzhin/ /
Abiding cannot reasonably abide Due to itself, or due to another. The case was the same with arising, Which arises neither by itself nor through another. [VII.25]
'gags pa 'gag par mi 'gyur te/ / ma 'gags pa yang 'gag mi 'gyur/ / 'gag bzhin pa yang de bzhin min/ / ma skyes gang zhig 'gag par 'gyur/ /
A thing that has ceased does not cease, A thing that has yet to cease does not cease, And no currently ceasing thing ceases either. What thing ceases that did not arise? [VII.26]
re zhig dngos po gnas pa la/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / dngos po mi gnas pa la yang*/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
A thing that abides Cannot reasonably cease, Yet a thing that does not abide Cannot reasonably cease either. [VII.27]
gnas skabs de yis gnas skabs ni/ / de nyid 'gag pa nyid mi 'gyur/ / gnas skabs gzhan gyis gnas skabs ni/ / gzhan yang 'gag pa nyid mi 'gyur/ /
The same state does not Bring an end to itself, Nor is it that a different state Makes the initial one cease. [VII.28]
gang tshe chos rnams thams cad kyi/ / skye ba 'thad par mi 'gyur ba/ / de tshe chos rnams thams cad kyi/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
When no phenomenon’s arising Makes any sense, No phenomenon’s cessation, Makes any sense either. [VII.29]
re zhig dngos po yod pa la/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / gcig nyid na ni dngos po dang*/ / dngos po med pa 'thad pa med/ /
A thing that exists Cannot have a cessation, Because the same thing cannot Be both thing and no thing. [VII.30]
dngos po med par gyur pa la'ang*/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / mgo gnyis pa la ji ltar ni/ / gcad du med pa de bzhin no/ /
A thing that does not exist Cannot have a cessation, Just as it is impossible To cut offa second head. [VII.31]
'gag pa rang gi bdag nyid kyis/ / yod min 'gag pa gzhan gyis min/ / ji ltar skye ba rang dang ni/ / gzhan gyis skyed pa ma yin bzhin/ /
Cessation is neither brought about By itself nor by anything else, Just as arising is not produced By itself or something else. [VII.32]
skye dang gnas dang 'jig pa dang*/ / ma grub phyir na 'dus byas med/ / 'dus byas rab tu ma grub pas/ / 'dus ma byas ni ji ltar 'grub/ /
As arising, abiding, and cessation are not established, There is nothing that is conditioned. Since the conditioned lacks any establishment, How could the unconditioned be established? [VII.33]
rmi lam ji bzhin sgyu ma bzhin/ / dri za'i grong khyer ji bzhin du/ / de bzhin skye dang de bzhin gnas/ / de bzhin du ni 'jig pa gsungs/ /
Like a dream, like an illusion, Like a city of scent-eaters— This is how arising, abiding, And cessation are taught to be. [VII.34]
skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bdun pa'o/// ! //
[byed pa po dang las brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa brgyad pa]
CHAPTER EIGHT. Analysis of Action and Agent
byed po yin par gyur pa de/ / las su gyur pa mi byed do/ / byed pa ma yin gyur pa yang*/ / las su ma gyur mi byed do/ /
That which is an agent does not Perform something that is an action. A nonagent does not Perform a nonaction. [VIII.1]
yin par gyur la bya ba med/ / byed po med pa'i las su'ang 'gyur/ / yin par 'gyur la bya ba med/ / las med byed pa por yang 'gyur/ /
That which is an agent would have no activity. There would also be action without an agent. That which is an action is not performed, So the agent would be lacking its action. [VIII.2]
gal te byed por ma gyur pa/ / las su ma gyur byed na ni/ / las la rgyu ni med par 'gyur/ / byed pa po yang rgyu med 'gyur/ /
If a nonagent were to perform That which is not an action, The action would have no cause And the agent would have no cause either. [VIII.3]
rgyu med na ni 'bras bu dang*/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / de med na ni bya ba dang*/ / byed pa po dang byed mi rigs/ /
If there is no cause, Cause and effect become untenable. Without these, action, agent, and activity Will all be nonsensical as well. [VIII.4]
bya ba la sogs mi rigs na/ / chos dang chos min yod ma yin/ / chos dang chos min med na ni/ / de las byung ba'i 'bras bu med/ /
If action and so forth are unreasonable, There can be no Dharma and non-Dharma, And without Dharma and non-Dharma, Their effects do not exist either. [VIII.5]
'bras bu med na thar pa dang*/ / mtho ris 'gyur ba'i lam mi 'thad/ / bya ba dag ni thams cad kyang*/ / don med nyid du thal bar 'gyur/ /
Without such effects, paths to liberation And to the higher realms do not make sense. All activities would indeed End up entirely meaningless. [VIII.6]
byed pa por gyur ma gyur pa/ / gyur ma gyur de mi byed de/ / yin dang ma yin gyur cig la/ / phan tshun 'gal bas ga la yod/ /
That which both is and is not an agent Does not perform something that both is and is not. Since being and not being are incompatible in one thing, How could this ever be the case? [VIII.7]
byed pa por ni gyur pa yis/ / ma gyur las ni mi byed de/ / ma gyur pas kyang gyur mi byed/ / 'dir yang skyon der thal bar 'gyur/ /
One that is an agent does not perform Something that is not an action, Nor does one that is not perform something that is Because the same flaws would ensue. [VIII.8]
byed pa por ni gyur pa dang*/ / bcas pa las ni ma gyur dang*/ / gyur ma gyur pa mi byed de/ / gtan tshigs gong du bstan phyir ro/ /
The agent involved does not Perform any nonaction, Or something that both is and is not an action. The arguments have already been given. [VIII.9]
byed pa por ni ma gyur pas/ / las ni gyur dang bcas pa dang*/ / gyur ma gyur pa mi byed de/ / gtan tshigs gong du bstan phyir ro/ /
That which is not an agent Does not perform any action, Or something that both is and is not an action. The arguments have already been given. [VIII.10]
byed pa por gyur ma gyur ni/ / las su gyur dang ma gyur pa/ / mi byed 'di yang gtan tshigs ni/ / gong du bstan pas shes par bya/ /
One that both is and is not an agent Does not perform an action or a nonaction. Here as well it should be understood That the arguments have already been given. [VIII.11]
byed pa po las brten byas shing*/ / las kyi byed po de nyid la/ / brten nas 'byung ba ma gtogs pa/ / 'grub pa'i rgyu ni ma mthong ngo*/ /
Agent comes about in dependence on action, And action, in turn, in dependence on agent. Apart from that we do not see Any cause of their establishment. [VIII.12]
de bzhin nyer len shes par bya/ / las dang byed po bsal phyir ro/ / byed pa po dang las dag gis/ / dngos po lhag ma shes par bya/ /
Appropriation should be understood in the same way, As here action and agent have been excluded. Agent and action will provide Understanding of the remaining issues. [VIII.13]
byed pa po dang las brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa brgyad pa'o/// ! //
[snga rol na gnas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa dgu pa]
CHAPTER NINE. Analysis of Prior Existence
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang*/ / tshor sogs dang yang dbang byas pa/ / gang gi yin pa de dag gi / snga rol de yod kha cig smra/ /
Some assert that sight, hearing, and the rest, As well as sensation and so forth, Are in the possession of, and belong to, Something that precedes them. [IX.1]
dngos po yod pa ma yin na/ / lta ba la sogs ji ltar 'gyur/ / de phyir de dag snga rol na/ / dngos po gnas pa de yod do/ /
If there was no thing, How could there be sight and so forth? Hence, prior to these factors, There is an abiding entity. [IX.2]
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang*/ / tshor ba la sogs nyid kyi ni/ / snga rol dngos po gang gnas pa/ / de ni gang gis gdags par bya/ /
Before sight, hearing, and the rest, And before sensation and so on, What are your grounds for speaking Of that abiding entity’s existence? [IX.3]
lta ba la sogs med par yang*/ / gal te de ni gnas gyur na/ / de med par yang de dag ni/ / yod par 'gyur bar the tshom med/ /
If this remains in the absence Of sight and these other factors, Then they will undoubtedly be present Even in the absence of that. [IX.4]
ci yis gang zhig gsal bar byed/ / gang gis ci zhig gsal bar byed/ / ci med gang zhig ga la yod/ / gang med ci zhig ga la yod/ /
Something manifests somebody, And somebody manifests something. How could somebody exist in the absence of anything? How could something exist in the absence of anybody? [IX.5]
lta la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / snga rol gang zhig yod pa min/ / lta sogs nang nas gzhan zhig gis/ / gzhan gyi tshe na gsal bar byed/ /
This is not present before The totality of sight and so forth. Yet each factor among sight and the rest Individually makes it manifest. [IX.6]
lta la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / snga rol gal te yod min na/ / lta la sogs pa re re yi/ / snga rol de ni ji ltar yod/ /
Unless it precedes the totality Of sight and the rest, How could it possibly precede Each of them individually? [IX.7]
lta po de nyid nyan po de/ / gal te tshor bo'ang de nyid na/ / re re'i snga rol yod gyur na/ / de ni de ltar mi rigs so/ /
If that which sees were that which hears, And what hears were that which senses, This would exist before every one of them, Yet that does not make sense. [IX.8]
gal te lta po gzhan nyid la/ / nyan pa po gzhan tshor gzhan na/ / lta po yod tshe nyan por 'gyur/ / bdag kyang mang po nyid du 'gyur/ /
If the seer, the hearer, and the one that senses Were all different from each other, The hearer could be present at the time of the seer And there would be multiple selves. [IX.9]
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang*/ / tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang*/ / gang las 'gyur ba'i 'byung de la'ang*/ / de ni yod pa ma yin no/ /
Sight, hearing, and the rest, As well as sensation and so forth— Among the causes from which these emerge, There is no existence of that. [IX.10]
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang*/ / tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang*/ / gang gi yin pa gal te med/ / de dag kyang ni yod ma yin/ /
Sight, hearing, and the rest, As well as sensation and so forth— If there is no one to whom these belong, Then they do not exist either. [IX.11]
gang zhig lta la sogs pa yi/ / snga rol da lta phyi na med/ / de la yod do med do zhes/ / rtog pa dag ni ldog par 'gyur/ /
That which does not exist Before, together with, or after sight and the rest Will no longer be thought about As existent or nonexistent. [IX.12]
snga rol na gnas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa dgu pa'o/// ! //
[me dang bud shing brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu pa]
CHAPTER TEN. Analysis of Fire and Fuel
bud shing gang de ma yin na/ / byed pa po dang las gcig 'gyur/ / gal te shing las me gzhan na/ / shing med par yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
If fuel were the same as fire, Then agent and object would be the same. If fire were different from fuel, Then it would burn even without it. [X.1]
rtag tu 'bar ba nyid du 'gyur/ / 'bar byed rgyu las mi 'byung zhing*/ / rtsom pa don med nyid du 'gyur/ / de lta yin na las kyang med/ /
Fire would burn forever, It would not arise from what causes it to burn, Trying to light it would be pointless, And it would not relate to any object. [X.2]
gzhan la ltos pa med pa'i phyir/ / 'bar bar byed rgyu las mi 'byung*/ / rtag tu 'bar ba yin na ni/ / rtsom pa don med nyid du 'gyur/ /
Because it would not depend on anything else, It would not arise from what causes it to burn. Because it would burn eternally, Lighting it would be pointless. [X.3]
de la gal te 'di snyam du/ / sreg bzhin bud shing yin sems na/ / gang tshe de tsam de yin na/ / gang gis bud shing de sreg byed/ /
It may be thought that the fuel Is that which is burning, But if that is all that it is, What is it that burns the fuel? [X.4]
gzhan phyir mi phrad phrad med na/ / sreg par mi 'gyur mi sreg na/ / 'chi bar mi 'gyur mi 'chi na/ / rang rtags dang yang ldan par gnas/ /
ji ltar bud med skyes pa dang*/ / skyes pa'ang bud med phrad pa bzhin/ / gal te shing las me gzhan na/ / shing dang phrad du rung bar 'gyur/ /
Just as a woman touches a man And a man touches a woman, Fire can be different from fuel, And yet still touch it. [X.6]
gal te me dang shing dag ni/ / gcig gis gcig ni bsal gyur na/ / shing las me gzhan nyid yin yang*/ / shing dang phrad par 'dod la rag /
If fire and fuel, Would exclude each other, Fire would be different from fuel, And so fire could touch fuel. [X.7]
gal te shing ltos me yin la/ / gal te me ltos shing yin na/ / gang ltos med dang shing 'gyur ba/ / dang por grub pa gang zhig yin/ /
If fire depends on fuel And fuel depends on fire, Of fire and fuel, the two dependents, Which is established first? [X.8]
gal te shing ltos me yin na/ / me grub pa la sgrub par 'gyur/ / bud par bya ba'i shing la yang*/ / me med par ni 'gyur ba yin/ /
If fire depended on fuel, An established fire would be reestablished, And fuel would end up Existing without fire. [X.9]
gal te dngos po gang ltos 'grub/ / de nyid la yang ltos nas ni/ / ltos bya gang yin de 'grub na/ / gang la ltos nas gang zhig 'grub/ /
If an entity is established in dependence, And is itself depended on By that upon which it depends, What is established in dependence on what? [X.10]
dngos po ltos grub gang yin pa/ / de ma grub ni ji ltar ltos/ / ci ste grub pa ltos she na/ / de ni ltos par mi rigs so/ /
How could an entity that is established in dependence Depend on something when it is not established? If it is said that it depends while established, Its dependence does not make any sense. [X.11]
shing la ltos pa'i me med de/ / shing la ma ltos me yang med/ / me la ltos pa'i shing med de/ / me la ma ltos shing yang med/ /
There is no fire that depends on fuel, There is no fire that does not depend on fuel. There is no fuel that depends on fire, There is no fuel that does not depend on fire. [X.12]
me ni gzhan las mi 'ong ste/ / shing la'ang me ni yod ma yin/ / de bzhin shing gi lhag ma ni/ / song dang ma song bgom pas bstan/ /
Fire does not come from anything else, Nor is there any fire in the fuel. The rest about fuel has been explained By what was, will be, and is being traversed. [X.13]
shing nyid me ni ma yin te/ / shing las gzhan la me yang med/ / me ni shing dang ldan ma yin/ / me la shing med der de med/ /
Fuel is not the same as fire, Nor is there fire apart from fuel. Fire does not possess fuel. Fuel is not in fire, nor is fire in fuel. [X.14]
me dang shing gis bdag dang ni/ / nye bar len pa'i rim pa kun/ / bum snam sogs dang lhan cig tu/ / ma lus par ni rnam par bshad/ /
Through the treatment of fire and fuel, The self and its appropriation, Along with vases, woolen garments, and so forth, Have all been explained without exception. [X.15]
gang dag bdag dang dngos po rnams/ / de bcas nyid dang tha dad par/ / ston pa de dag bstan don la/ / mkhas so snyam du mi sems so/ /
Those who teach that self and entities Are the same or different I do not consider knowledgeable About the meaning of the teachings. [X.16]
me dang bud shing brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu pa'o/// ! //
[sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gcig pa]
CHAPTER ELEVEN. Analysis of Beginnings and Ends
sngon mtha' mngon nam zhes zhus tshe/ / thub pa chen pos min zhes gsungs/ / 'khor ba thog ma mtha' med de/ / de la sngon med phyi ma med/ /
When asked whether any beginning can be seen, The Able One answered in the negative. Cyclic existence has no beginning or end; There is no before and there is no after. [XI.1]
gang la thog med mtha' med par/ / de la dbus ni ga la yod/ / de phyir de la snga phyi dang*/ / lhan cig rim pa mi 'thad do/ /
When something has neither beginning nor end, How could it possibly have a middle? Therefore, cyclic existence cannot Be either sequential or simultaneous. [XI.2]
gal te skye ba snga gyur la/ / rga shi phyi ma yin na ni/ / skye ba rga shi med pa dang*/ / ma shi bar yang skye bar 'gyur/ /
If birth came first And aging and death followed later, There would be birth without aging and death, As well as birth without anyone having died. [XI.3]
gal te skye ba phyi 'gyur la/ / rga shi snga ba yin na ni/ / skye ba med pa'i rga shi ni/ / rgyu med par ni ji ltar 'gyur/ /
If birth occurred later, And aging and death before, How could this causeless aging and death Happen to someone who was never born? [XI.4]
skye ba dang ni rga shi dag / lhan cig rung ba ma yin te/ / skye bzhin pa na 'chi 'gyur zhing*/ / gnyis ka rgyu med can du 'gyur/ /
Birth, aging, and death Cannot occur simultaneously, For the one being born would then be dying, And both would be lacking their cause. [XI.5]
gang la snga phyi lhan cig gi / rim pa de dag mi srid pa'i/ / skye ba de dang rga shi de/ / ci yi phyir na spro bar byed/ /
As it is impossible for them to occur In sequence or simultaneously, Why would anyone think In terms of birth, aging, and death? [XI.6]
'khor ba 'ba' zhig sngon gyi mtha'/ / yod ma yin par ma zad kyi/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu nyid dang ni/ / mtshan nyid dang ni mtshan gzhi nyid/ /
Not only does cyclic existence Have no beginning, But also cause and effect, Characteristics and their bearers, [XI.7]
tshor dang tshor po nyid dang ni/ / don yod gang dag ci yang rung*/ / dngos rnams thams cad nyid la yang*/ / sngon gyi mtha' ni yod ma yin/ /
Feelings and those that feel— Whatever there may be. The same applies to all things; None have a beginning. [XI.8]
sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gcig pa'o/// ! //
[bdag gis byas pa dang gzhan gyis byas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gnyis pa]
CHAPTER TWELVE. Analysis of Suffering
kha cig sdug bsngal bdag gis byas/ / gzhan gyis byas dang gnyi gas byas/ / rgyu med pa las 'byung bar 'dod/ / de ni bya bar mi rung ngo*/ /
Some say that suffering is produced by itself, By something other, by both, Or that it arises without a cause. Such production is not possible. [XII.1]
gal te bdag gis byas gyur na/ / de phyir brten nas 'byung mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir phung po 'di dag la/ / brten nas phung po de dag 'byung*/ /
If suffering were produced by itself, It could not arise in dependence, Because, based on these aggregates, Those aggregates arise. [XII.2]
gal te 'di las de gzhan zhing*/ / gal te de las 'di gzhan na/ / sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas 'gyur zhing*/ / gzhan de dag gis de byas 'gyur/ /
If those were something other than these, And these were something other than those, Suffering would be produced by something other, And they would produce something other. [XII.3]
gal te gang zag bdag gis ni/ / sdug bsngal byas na gang bdag gis/ / sdug bsngal byas pa'i gang zag ni/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs gang zhig yin/ /
If the person itself Produces suffering, Then what, apart from suffering, Is this person who produces suffering? [XII.4]
gal te gang zag gzhan las ni/ / sdug bsngal 'byung na gzhan zhig gis/ / sdug bsngal de byas gang sbyin de/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs de ltar rung*/ /
If suffering comes from a different person, Then how, when produced by another person, Could it be given to somebody Who is something other than suffering? [XII.5]
gal te gang zag gzhan sdug bsngal/ / 'byung na gang gis de byas nas/ / gzhan la ster ba'i gang zag gzhan/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs gang zhig yin/ /
If suffering occurs because of another person, Then who is this producer, This other who gives suffering to another, Yet who is not that very suffering? [XII.6]
bdag gis byas par ma grub pas/ / sdug bsngal gzhan gyis ga la byas/ / gzhan gyis sdug bsngal gang byed pa/ / de ni de yi bdag byas 'gyur/ /
As it cannot be established to be produced by a self, How could suffering be the product of another? The suffering produced by the other Is the product of that other itself. [XII.7]
re zhig sdug bsngal bdag byas min/ / de nyid kyis ni de ma byas/ / gal te gzhan bdag ma byas na/ / sdug bsngal gzhan byas ga la 'gyur/ /
Suffering is not self-produced; It is not its own product. If the other is not the product of itself, How could suffering be produced by another? [XII.8]
gal te re res byas gyur na/ / sdug bsngal gnyis kas byas par 'gyur/ / bdag gis ma byas gzhan ma byas/ / sdug bsngal rgyu med ga la 'gyur/ /
If suffering were produced by each of these, Then suffering would be the product of both. Neither produced by self nor other, How could suffering be uncaused? [XII.9]
sdug bsngal 'ba' zhig rnam pa bzhi/ / yod ma yin par ma zad kyi/ / phyi rol dngos po dag la yang*/ / rnam pa bzhi po yod ma yin/ /
Not only does suffering Not exist in any of these four ways, External entities as well Do not exist in any of the four ways. [XII.10]
bdag gis byas pa dang gzhan gyis byas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gnyis pa'o/// ! //
['du byed brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gsum pa]
CHAPTER THIRTEEN. Analysis of the Conditioned
bcom ldan 'das kyis chos gang zhig / slu ba de ni brdzun zhes gsungs/ / 'du byed thams cad slu ba'i chos/ / des na de dag brdzun pa yin/ /
The Transcendent Conqueror has taught That all deceptive phenomena are false. All conditioned phenomena are deceptive, And, therefore, they are false. [XIII.1]
gal te slu chos gang yin pa/ / de brdzun de la ci zhig slu/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis de gsungs pa/ / stong nyid yongs su bstan pa yin/ /
If a phenomenon that is deceptive is also false, Then what is it that deceives? With this, the Transcendent Conqueror Has fully revealed emptiness. [XIII.2]
dngos rnams ngo bo nyid med de/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba snang phyir ro/ / dngos po ngo bo nyid med med/ / gang phyir dngos rnams stong pa nyid/ /
Things are devoid of essence Because they are perceived to change. There are no entities without essence Because entities possess emptiness. [XIII.3]
gal te ngo bo nyid med na/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin/ / gal te ngo bo nyid yod na/ / gzhan du 'gyur bar ji ltar rung*/ /
If there is no essence, To what does change pertain? If there were essences, How could there be change? [XIII.4]
de nyid la ni gzhan 'gyur med/ / gzhan nyid la yang yod ma yin/ / gang phyir gzhon nu mi rga ste/ / gang phyir rgas pa'ang mi rga'o/ /
Change is not in that itself, Nor is it in something else, Because the young do not age, And because the aged do not age. [XIII.5]
gal te de nyid gzhan 'gyur na/ / 'o ma nyid ni zhor 'gyur ro/ / 'o ma las gzhan gang zhig ni/ / zho yi dngos po yin par 'gyur/ /
If that itself changes, Then milk itself is yogurt. What, other than milk, Would turn into yogurt? [XIII.6]
gal te stong min cung zad yod/ / stong pa cung zad yod par 'gyur/ / mi stong cung zad yod min na/ / stong pa yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
If there were a bit of something that is not empty, There could be a bit of something that is empty. As there is not a bit that is not empty, How could there be anything that is empty? [XIII.7]
rgyal ba rnams kyis stong pa nyid/ / lta kun nges par 'byung bar gsungs/ / gang dag stong pa nyid lta ba/ / de dag bsgrub tu med par gsungs/ /
The Victorious Ones have taught emptiness As a deliverance from all views. For those whose view is emptiness, they teach, Nothing can be accomplished. [XIII.8]
'du byed brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gsum pa'o/// ! //
[phrad pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bzhi pa]
CHAPTER FOURTEEN. Analysis of Contact
blta bya lta ba lta ba po/ / gsum po de dag gnyis gnyis dang*/ / thams cad kyang ni phan tshun du/ / phrad par 'gyur ba yod ma yin/ /
The seen, sight, and the seer Do not, either in pairs Or as a group, Ever come into contact. [XIV.1]
de bzhin 'dod chags chags pa dang*/ / chags par bya ba nyon mongs pa/ / lhag ma rnams dang skye mched kyi/ / lhag ma'ang rnam pa gsum nyid kyis/ /
The same goes for desire, the desirous one, And the object of desire, the other afflictions, The remaining sense sources, And for all such triads. [XIV.2]
gzhan dang gzhan du phrad 'gyur na/ / gang phyir blta bya la sogs la/ / gzhan de yod pa ma yin pa/ / de phyir phrad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
Contact occurs between different things, So because the seen and so forth Do not exist as different things, They do not come into contact. [XIV.3]
blta bya la sogs 'ba' zhig la/ / gzhan nyid med par ma zad kyi/ / gang yang gang dang lhan cig tu/ / gzhan pa nyid du mi 'thad do/ /
It is not only the seen and the rest That do not differ from each other; Wherever there is coexistence There cannot reasonably be difference. [XIV.4]
gzhan ni gzhan la brten te gzhan/ / gzhan med par gzhan gzhan mi 'gyur/ / gang la brten te gang yin pa/ / de ni de las gzhan mi 'thad/ /

That which is different differs in dependence on something else. It does not differ without that different thing from which it differs. Where something depends on something else, The two cannot reasonably be different. [XIV.5]
gal te gzhan ni gzhan las gzhan/ / de tshe gzhan med par gzhan 'gyur/ / gzhan med par ni gzhan 'gyur ba/ / yod min de yi phyir na med/ /
If the different differed from something different, It would be different even without anything different. But nothing differs without something different, And, hence, this is not the case. [XIV.6]
gzhan nyid gzhan la yod ma yin/ / gzhan ma yin la'ang yod ma yin/ / gzhan nyid yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan nam de nyid yod ma yin/ /
Difference does not exist in the different, Nor does it exist in what is not different. As difference as such does not exist, Nothing is different and nothing is the same. [XIV.7]
de ni de dang phrad pa med/ / gzhan dang gzhan yang phrad mi 'gyur/ / phrad bzhin pa dang phrad pa dang*/ / phrad pa po yang yod ma yin/ /
Nothing comes into contact with itself, Nor do different things come into contact. Contacting, contacted, and contactor Do not exist either. [XIV.8]
phrad pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bzhi pa'o/// ! //
[rang bzhin brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bco lnga pa]
CHAPTER FIFTEEN. Analysis of Nature
rang bzhin rgyu dang rkyen las ni/ / 'byung bar rigs pa ma yin no/ / rgyu dang rkyen las byung ba yi/ / rang bzhin byas pa can du 'gyur/ /
Nature cannot reasonably occur Due to causes and conditions. A nature that arises due to causes and conditions Would be a nature that is produced. [XV.1]
rang bzhin byas pa can zhes byar/ / ji lta bur na rung bar 'gyur/ / rang bzhin dag ni bcos min dang*/ / gzhan la ltos pa med pa yin/ /
“A nature that is produced,” How could that be right? The natural is not fabricated, And does not depend on anything else. [XV.2]
rang bzhin yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan gyi dngos po ga la yod/ / gzhan gyi dngos po'i rang bzhin ni/ / gzhan gyi dngos po yin zhes brjod/ /
If nature does not exist, How could there be other-nature? It is the nature of other-nature That is identified as “other-nature.” [XV.3]
rang bzhin dang ni gzhan dngos dag / ma gtogs dngos po ga la yod/ / rang bzhin dang ni dngos po dag / yod na dngos po 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Apart from nature and other-nature, What entity could there possibly be? If there were nature and other-nature, Entities would be established. [XV.4]
gal te dngos po ma grub na/ / dngos med 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / dngos po gzhan du gyur pa ni/ / dngos med yin par skye bo smra/ /
If entity is not established, Then neither is nonentity. It is the transformation of entity That people call nonentity. [XV.5]
gang dag rang bzhin gzhan dngos dang*/ / dngos dang dngos med nyid lta ba/ / de dag sangs rgyas bstan pa la/ / de nyid mthong ba ma yin no/ /
Those who believe in nature or other-nature, In entity or nonentity, Fail to see reality Within the teachings of the Buddha. [XV.6]
bcom ldan dngos dang dngos med pa/ / mkhyen pas ka ta ya na yi/ / gdams ngag las ni yod pa dang*/ / med pa gnyis ka'ang dgag pa mdzad/ /
The Transcendent Conqueror, With knowledge of both entities and nonentities, Refuted, in his Instructions to Kātāyana, Both existence and nonexistence. [XV.7]
gal te rang bzhin gyis yod na/ / de ni med nyid mi 'gyur ro/ / rang bzhin gzhan du 'gyur pa ni/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
If something is existent by nature, It would never become nonexistent. A nature that undergoes change Would never make any sense. [XV.8]
rang bzhin yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin/ / rang bzhin yod pa yin na yang*/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba ji ltar rung*/ /
If no nature exists, To what does change pertain? Even if nature exists, To what could change pertain? [XV.9]
yod ces bya ba rtag par 'dzin/ / med ces bya ba chad par lta/ / de phyir yod dang med pa la/ / mkhas pas gnas par mi bya'o/ /
“Existence” is apprehension of permanence, “Nonexistence” a view of annihilation. The wise, therefore, ought not to adhere To either existence or nonexistence. [XV.10]
gang zhig rang bzhin gyis yod pa/ / de ni med pa min pas rtag / sngon byung da ltar med ces pa/ / des na chad par thal bar 'gyur/ /
That which exists by nature Is not nonexistent—this is permanence. “It existed before, but now it does not”— That implies annihilation. [XV.11]
rang bzhin brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bco lnga pa'o/// ! //
[bcings pa dang thar pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu drug pa]
CHAPTER SIXTEEN. Analysis of Bondage and Liberation
gal te 'du byed 'khor zhe na/ / de dag rtag na mi 'khor te/ / mi rtag na yang 'khor mi 'gyur/ / sems can la yang rim 'di mtshungs/ /
If it is claimed that formations cycle, They cannot do so if permanent, Nor can they if impermanent. In the case of sentient beings, the steps are the same. [XVI.1]
gal te gang zag 'khor zhe na/ / phung po skye mched khams rnams pa/ / de ni rnam pa lngas btsal na/ / med na gang zhig 'khor bar 'gyur/ /
It might be said that the person cycles, But when we search the aggregates, elements, and sense sources, Using the five steps and there is nothing, What is it, then, that cycles? [XVI.2]
nye bar len nas nyer len bar/ / 'khor na srid pa med par 'gyur/ / srid med nye bar len med na/ / de gang ci zhig 'khor bar 'gyur/ /
If there is cycling from appropriation to appropriation, Then there cannot be any becoming. Without becoming there can be no appropriation, So what kind of cycling is this? [XVI.3]
'du byed mya ngan 'da' bar ni/ / ji lta bur yang mi 'thad do/ / sems can mya ngan 'da' bar yang*/ / ji lta bur yang 'thad mi 'gyur/ /
Formations that transcend suffering Do not make sense in any way. Sentient beings that transcend suffering Do not make sense in any way either. [XVI.4]
skye 'jig chos can 'du byed rnams/ / mi 'ching grol bar mi 'gyur te/ / snga ma bzhin du sems can yang*/ / mi 'ching grol bar mi 'gyur ro/ /
Formations that are subject to arising and ceasing Are not bound and will not be freed. As before, sentient beings as well Are not bound and will not be freed. [XVI.5]
gal te nye bar len 'ching na/ / nye bar len bcas 'ching mi 'gyur/ / nye bar len med mi 'ching ste/ / gnas skabs gang zhig 'ching bar 'gyur/ /
If bondage is due to appropriation, Since nothing is bound in the presence of appropriation, And there is no bondage in the absence of appropriation, When, then, is it that bondage occurs? [XVI.6]
gal te bcing bya'i snga rol na/ / 'ching ba yod na 'ching la rag / de yang med de lhag ma ni/ / song dang ma song bgom pas bstan/ /
If the bond existed prior to the bound, There could be bondage, yet it does not. The rest has already been explained By what was, will be, and is being traversed. [XVI.7]
re zhig bcings pa mi grol te/ / ma bcings pa yang grol mi 'gyur/ / bcings pa grol bzhin yin 'gyur na/ / bcings dang grol ba dus gcig 'gyur/ /
That which is bound is not freed, Yet the unbound is not freed either. If the bound were being liberated, Bondage and liberation would be simultaneous. [XVI.8]
bdag ni len med mya ngan 'da'/ / myang 'das bdag gir 'gyur ro zhes/ / de ltar gang dag 'dzin de yi/ / nyer len 'dzin pa chen po yin/ /
“Without appropriation, I shall transcend suffering; The transcendence of suffering, that shall be mine!” Those who grasp in this way Are engaged in severe appropriation. [XVI.9]
gang la mya ngan 'das bskyed med/ / 'khor ba bsal ba'ang yod min pa/ / de la 'khor ba ci zhig yin/ / mya ngan 'das pa'ang ci zhig brtag /
Where the transcendence of suffering is not produced And cyclic existence is not dispelled, How to conceive of cyclic existence, And how of the transcendence of suffering? [XVI.10]
bcings pa dang thar pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu drug pa'o/// ! //
[las brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bdun pa]
CHAPTER SEVENTEEN. Analysis of Action and Its Results
bdag nyid legs par sdom pa dang*/ / gzhan la phan 'dogs byams sems gang*/ / de chos de ni 'di gzhan du/ / 'bras bu dag gi sa bon yin/ /
Restraining oneself properly, Helping others, and a loving mind— These are Dharma, seeds that bear fruit Both here and hereafter. [XVII.1]
drang srong mchog gis las rnams ni/ / sems pa dang ni bsam par gsungs/ / las de bdag gi bye brag ni/ / rnam pa du mar yongs su bsgrags/ /
The Supreme Sage has taught That action is volition and the willed. The subdivisions of these actions Are set forth in great detail. [XVII.2]
de la las gang sems pa zhes/ / gsungs pa de ni yid kyir 'dod/ / bsams pa zhes ni gang gsungs pa/ / de ni lus dang ngag gir yin/ /
That which is taught as “actions of volition” Is asserted to be mental, While the so-called “intended actions” Are physical and verbal. [XVII.3]
ngag dang bskyod dang mi spong ba'i/ / rnam rig byed min zhes bya gang*/ / spong ba'i rnam rig byed min pa/ / gzhan dag kyang ni de bzhin 'dor/ /
Speech and movement; Imperceptible nonabstinence And imperceptible abstinence— These are similarly asserted. [XVII.4]
longs spyod las byung bsod nams dang*/ / bsod nams ma yin tshul de bzhin/ / sems pa dang ni chos de bdun/ / las su mngon par 'dod pa yin/ /
The merit that arises from enjoyment And the demerit, in a similar manner, Along with volition— These seven principles are held to be action. [XVII.5]
gal te smin pa'i dus bar du/ / gnas na las de rtag par 'gyur/ / gal te 'gags na 'gag gyur pa/ / ji ltar 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur/ /
If an action would remain until ripening, Then it would be permanent. If it ceases, then having ceased, How could it produce an effect? [XVII.6]
myu gu la sogs rgyun gang ni/ / sa bon las ni mngon par 'byung*/ / de las 'bras bu sa bon ni/ / med na de yang 'byung mi 'gyur/ /
The continuum of the sprout and so forth Manifests from the seed, Due to which the fruit comes about; Without the seed, it would not arise. [XVII.7]
gang phyir sa bon las rgyun dang*/ / rgyun las 'bras bu 'byung 'gyur zhing*/ / sa bon 'bras bu'i sngon 'gro ba/ / de phyir chad min rtag ma yin/ /
The continuum arises from the seed, And from the continuum comes the fruit. Therefore, the seed precedes the fruit. Hence, there is no annihilation or permanence. [XVII.8]
sems kyi rgyun ni gang yin pa/ / sems las mngon par 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de las 'bras bu sems lta zhig / med na de yang 'byung mi 'gyur/ /
That which is the continuum of mind Manifests from the mind, And from that emerges the effect. Without this mind, it would not occur. [XVII.9]
gang phyir sems las rgyun dang ni/ / rgyun las 'bras bu 'byung 'gyur zhing*/ / las ni 'bras bu'i sngon 'gro ba/ / de phyir chad min rtag ma yin/ /
The continuum arises from the mind, And from the continuum comes the effect. Therefore, the action precedes the effect And there is no annihilation or permanence. [XVII.10]
dkar po'i las kyi lam bcu po/ / chos sgrub pa yi thabs yin te/ / chos kyi 'bras bu 'di gzhan du/ / 'dod pa'i yon tan rnam lnga'o/ /
The ten avenues of wholesome action Are the means for performing Dharma. Here and hereafter, the fruits of Dharma Are the five sense pleasures. [XVII.11]
gal te brtag pa der 'gyur na/ / nyes pa chen po mang por 'gyur/ / de lta bas na brtag pa de/ / 'dir ni 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
When it comes to this account, There are numerous and significant flaws. Hence, this account Is untenable here. [XVII.12]
sangs rgyas rnams dang rang rgyal dang*/ / nyan thos rnams kyi gang gsungs pa'i/ / brtag pa gang zhig 'dir 'thad pa/ / de ni rab tu brjod par bya/ /
The account given by the Buddhas, The self-realized buddhas, and the listeners Is the one that is tenable here. That, then, shall be set forth. [XVII.13]
ji ltar dbang rgya de bzhin chud/ / mi zad las ni bu lon bzhin/ / de ni khams las rnam pa bzhi/ / de yang rang bzhin lung ma bstan/ /
Nondissipation resembles a promissory note. The action then is the debt. It is fourfold with reference to the realms And its nature is neutral. [XVII.14]
spong bas spang ba ma yin te/ / bsgom pas spang ba nyid kyang yin/ / de phyir chud mi za ba yis/ / las kyi 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur/ /
It is not eliminated by elimination, Yet it is eliminated through cultivation. Therefore, it is due to nondissipation That the effects of action are produced. [XVII.15]
gal te spong bas spang ba dang*/ / las 'pho ba yis 'jig 'gyur na/ / de la las 'jig la sogs pa'i/ / skyon rnams su ni thal bar 'gyur/ /
If it were eliminated by elimination Or destroyed by a transference of action, Various flaws would ensue, Such as the destruction of action. [XVII.16]
khams mtshungs las ni cha mtshungs dang*/ / cha mi mtshungs pa thams cad kyi/ / de ni nying mtshams sbyor ba'i tshe/ / gcig po kho na skye bar 'gyur/ /
All those associated with realm-specific actions, Whether congruent or incongruent, Manifest as only one When linking takes place. [XVII.17]
mthong ba'i chos la rnam gnyis po/ / kun gyi las dang las kyi de/ / tha dad par ni skye 'gyur zhing*/ / rnam par smin kyang gnas pa yin/ /
During the present life it arises Separately with each instance Of the two types of action, Remaining even after the ripening. [XVII.18]
de ni 'bras bu 'pho ba dang*/ / shi bar gyur na 'gag par 'gyur/ / de yi rnam dbye zag med dang*/ / zag dang bcas par shes par bya/ /
It ceases at transference To the fruition or at death. It should be understood that it is divided In terms of the defiling and undefiling. [XVII.19]
stong pa nyid dang tshad med dang*/ / 'khor ba dang ni rtag pa min/ / las rnams chud mi za ba'i chos/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni bstan pa yin/ /
Emptiness and absence of annihilation, Cyclic existence and absence of permanence— The phenomenon of nondissipation Is the teaching of the Buddha. [XVII.20]
gang phyir las ni skye ba med/ / 'di ltar rang bzhin med de'i phyir/ / gang phyir de ni ma skyes pa/ / de phyir chud zar mi 'gyur ro/ /
Why does action not arise? Because it has no nature. Because it does not arise, Action does not dissipate. [XVII.21]
gal te las la rang bzhin yod/ / rtag par 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / las ni byas pa ma yin 'gyur/ / rtag la bya ba med phyir ro/ /
If action had a nature, It would, undoubtedly, be permanent. Action would not be created Because the permanent cannot be active. [XVII.22]
ci ste las ni ma byas na/ / ma byas pa dang phrad 'jigs 'gyur/ / tshangs spyod gnas pa ma yin pa'ang*/ / de la skyon du thal bar 'gyur/ /
If action were uncreated, there would be fear Of encountering that which had not been done. A lack of pure conduct Would follow as a flaw as well. [XVII.23]
tha snyad thams cad nyid dang yang*/ / 'gal bar 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / bsod nams dang ni sdig byed pa'i/ / rnam par dbye ba'ang 'thad mi 'byung*/ /
Undoubtedly, this would Contradict all conventions. The distinction between virtuous persons and sinners Would no longer make sense. [XVII.24]
de ni rnam smin smin gyur pa/ / yang dang yang du rnam smin 'gyur/ / gal te rang bzhin yod na ni/ / gang phyir las gnas de yi phyir/ /
The ripening that has already ripened Would go on ripening again and again. For if it possessed a nature, Action would remain present. [XVII.25]
las 'di nyon mongs bdag nyid la/ / nyon mongs de dag yang dag min/ / gal te nyon mongs yang dag min/ / las ni yang dag ji ltar yin/ /
Action is constituted by the afflictions, But the afflictions are not real. If afflictions are not real, How could action be so? [XVII.26]
las dang nyon mongs pa dag ni/ / lus rnams kyi ni rkyen du bstan/ / gal te las dang nyon mongs pa/ / de stong lus la ji ltar brjod/ /
Action and affliction are taught To be conditions for the body. If action and affliction are empty, Then what can be said of the body? [XVII.27]
ma rig bsgribs pa'i skye bo gang*/ / sred ldan de mi za ba po/ / de yang byed las gzhan min zhing*/ / de nyid de yang ma yin no/ /
The consumer is that being Who is obscured by ignorance and has craving. This being is not different from the agent, Yet neither are these two identical. [XVII.28]
gang gi phyir na las 'di ni/ / rkyen las byung ba ma yin zhing*/ / rkyen min las byung yod min pa/ / de phyir byed pa po yang med/ /
Because action does not arise Based on conditions Or based on nonconditions, There is no agent either. [XVII.29]
gal te las dang byed med na/ / las skyes 'bras bu ga la yod/ / ci ste 'bras bu yod min na/ / za ba po lta ga la yod/ /
If there is no action and no agent, How could there be a result produced by action? If there is no result, How could there be a consumer? [XVII.30]
ji ltar ston pas sprul pa ni/ / rdzu 'phrul phun tshogs kyis sprul zhing*/ / sprul pa de yang sprul pa na/ / slar yang gzhan ni sprul pa ltar/ /
The Teacher, in a perfect miracle, Creates emanations, And these emanations again Create further emanations. [XVII.31]
de bzhin byed po de las gang*/ / byas pa'ang sprul pa'i rnam pa bzhin/ / dper na sprul pas sprul gzhan zhig / sprul pa mdzad pa de bzhin no/ /
Likewise, the act performed by the agent Resembles an emanation, Just as when one emanation Gives rise to another. [XVII.32]
nyon mongs las dang lus rnams dang*/ / byed pa po dang 'bras bu dang*/ / dri za'i grong khyer lta bu dang*/ / smig rgyu rmi lam 'dra ba yin/ /
Affliction, action, the body, The agent, and the result Are all like a city of scent-eaters, Like an illusion, and like a dream. [XVII.33]
las brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bdun pa'o/// ! //
[bdag dang chos brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bco brgyad pa]
CHAPTER EIGHTEEN. Analysis of Self and Phenomena
gal te phung po bdag yin na/ / skye dang 'jig pa can du 'gyur/ / gal te phung po rnams las gzhan/ / phung po'i mtshan nyid med par 'gyur/ /
If the self were the aggregates, It would arise and cease. If it were different from the aggregates, It would have none of their characteristics. [XVIII.1]
bdag nyid yod pa ma yin na/ / bdag gi yod par ga la 'gyur/ / bdag dang bdag gi zhi ba'i phyir/ / ngar 'dzin nga yir 'dzin med 'gyur/ /
When the self does not exist, How could that which belongs to it? Due to the pacification of self and that which belongs to it, The belief in an “I” and a “mine” will cease. [XVIII.2]
ngar 'dzin nga yir 'dzin med gang*/ / de yang yod pa ma yin te/ / ngar 'dzin nga yir 'dzin med par/ / gang gis mthong bas mi mthong ngo*/ /
The one who does not grasp at “I” or “mine” Does not exist either. The one who sees what lacks the grasping of “I” and “mine,” That one does not see. [XVIII.3]
nang dang phyi rol nyid dag la/ / bdag dang bdag gi snyam zad na/ / nye bar len pa 'gag 'gyur zhing*/ / de zad pas na skye ba zad/ /
When the sense of “I” and “mine” that is based On the inner and outer is exhausted, Appropriation comes to an end. As that is exhausted, so is birth. [XVIII.4]
las dang nyon mongs zad pas thar/ / las dang nyon mongs rnam rtog las/ / de dag spros las spros pa ni/ / stong pa nyid kyis 'gag par 'gyur/ /

Liberation follows from the exhaustion of action and affliction. Action and affliction are due to thought, And thoughts proliferate due to mental construction. They are brought to an end by emptiness. [XVIII.5]
bdag go zhes kyang btags gyur cing*/ / bdag med ces kyang bstan par gyur/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis bdag dang ni/ / bdag med 'ga' med ces kyang bstan/ /
“Self” is stated And also “no self” is taught. The Buddhas even teach that there is neither Self nor absence of self. [XVIII.6]
brjod par bya ba ldog pa ste/ / sems kyi spyod yul ldog pas so/ / ma skyes pa dang ma 'gags pa/ / chos nyid mya ngan 'das dang mtshungs/ /
The expressible is annulled Because the domain of the mind is annulled. The intrinsic nature, unarisen and unceasing, Equals the transcendence of suffering. [XVIII.7]
thams cad yang dag yang dag min/ / yang dag yang dag ma yin nyid/ / yang dag min min yang dag min/ / de ni sangs rgyas rjes bstan pa'o/ /
Everything is real and unreal, Real and indeed not real, Not unreal and not real— That is the thorough teaching of the Buddha. [XVIII.8]
gzhan las shes min zhi ba dang*/ / spros pa rnams kyis ma spros pa/ / rnam rtog med don tha dad med/ / de ni de nyid mtshan nyid do/ /
Not known by anything else, peace, Not constructed through constructs, Absence of concepts, and absence of a different meaning— These are the characteristics of reality. [XVIII.9]
gang la brten te gang 'byung ba/ / de ni re zhig de nyid min/ / de las gzhan pa'ang ma yin phyir/ / de phyir chad min rtag ma yin/ /
That which arises in dependence on something else Is not identical with it, Nor is it something other. Hence, it is neither annihilated nor permanent. [XVIII.10]
sangs rgyas 'jig rten mgon rnams kyi/ / bstan pa bdud rtsir gyur pa de/ / don gcig ma yin tha dad min/ / chad pa ma yin rtag ma yin/ /
The Buddhas, protectors of the world, Grant the elixir of teaching Without sameness or difference of meaning, Without annihilation and without permanence. [XVIII.11]
rdzogs sangs rgyas rnams ma byung zhing*/ / nyan thos rnams ni zad gyur kyang*/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi ye shes ni/ / ston pa med las rab tu skye/ /
Where a perfect Buddha has not appeared And the listeners have disappeared, The wakefulness of self-realized buddhas Will, in the absence of a teacher, arise in full. [XVIII.12]
bdag dang chos brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bco brgyad pa'o/// ! //
[dus brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu dgu pa]
CHAPTER NINETEEN. Analysis of Time
da ltar byung dang ma 'ongs pa/ / gal te 'das la ltos gyur na/ / da ltar byung dang ma 'ongs pa/ / 'das pa'i dus na yod par 'gyur/ /
If the present and the future Depend on the past, The present and the future Exist in the past. [XIX.1]
da ltar byung dang ma 'ongs pa/ / gal te de na med gyur na/ / da ltar byung dang ma 'ongs pa/ / ji ltar de la ltos par 'gyur/ /
If the present and the future Do not exist in the past, How can the present and future Be dependent on it? [XIX.2]
'das pa la ni ma ltos par/ / de gnyis grub pa yod ma yin/ / de phyir da ltar byung ba dang*/ / ma 'ongs dus kyang yod ma yin/ /
If the two do not depend on the past, Then they are not established. The present and future Therefore, do not exist. [XIX.3]
rim pa'i tshul ni 'di nyid kyis/ / lhag ma gnyis po bsnor ba dang*/ / mchog dang tha ma 'bring la sogs/ / gcig la sogs pa'ang shes par bya/ /
By these very same steps, the other two, The supreme, the middling, and the inferior, and so forth; As well as singularity and so on Can also be understood. [XIX.4]
mi gnas dus ni 'dzin mi byed/ / gang zhig gzung bar bya ba'i dus/ / gnas pa yod pa ma yin pas/ / ma bzung dus ni ji ltar gdags/ /
A time that does not endure is not apprehended. Since a time apprehended as enduring Does not exist, how can one speak Of a time that is not apprehended? [XIX.5]
gal te dus ni dngos brten te/ / dngos med dus ni ga la yod/ / dngos po 'ga' yang yod min na/ / dus lta yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
If time is based on entities, And there are none, how could there be time? When there are no entities at all, How could there be any time? [XIX.6]
dus brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu dgu pa'o/// ! //
[tshogs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY. Analysis of the Assembly
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs pa nyid las skye 'gyur zhing*/ / tshogs la 'bras bu yod na ni/ / ji ltar tshogs pa nyid las skye/ /
If effects are produced by an assembly Of causes and conditions And are present in those assemblies, How could they be produced by those assemblies? [XX.1]
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs pa nyid las skye 'gyur zhing*/ / tshogs la 'bras bu med na ni/ / ji ltar tshogs pa nyid las skye/ /
If effects are produced by the very assembly Of causes and conditions, And are not present in those assemblies, How could they be produced by those assemblies? [XX.2]
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs la 'bras bu yod na ni/ / tshogs la gzung du yod rigs na/ / tshogs pa nyid la gzung du med/ /
If effects are present in the assemblies Of their causes and conditions, They should be perceptible in those assemblies, And yet they are not perceptible in those assemblies. [XX.3]
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs la 'bras bu med na ni/ / rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag kyang*/ / rgyu rkyen ma yin mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
If effects are not present in the assemblies Of their causes and conditions, Then the causes and conditions Equal what are not causes and conditions. [XX.4]
gal te rgyus ni 'bras bu la/ / rgyu byin nas ni 'gag 'gyur na/ / gang byin pa dang gang 'gags pa'i/ / rgyu yi bdag nyid gnyis su 'gyur/ /
If the cause ceases to be, Having been supplied to its effect, It follows that the cause has two identities, One supplied and another that ceases. [XX.5]
gal te rgyus ni 'bras bu la/ / rgyu ma byin par 'gag 'gyur na/ / rgyu 'gags nas ni skyes pa yi/ / 'bras bu de dag rgyu med 'gyur/ /
If a cause ceases to be, Without having been supplied to its effect, The effects that arise when it has ceased Do not have any cause. [XX.6]
gal te tshogs dang lhan cig tu/ / 'bras bu yang ni skye 'gyur na/ / skyed par byed dang bskyed bya gang*/ / dus gcig par ni thal bar 'gyur/ /
If effects arise together With their assemblies, The producer and produced Will then be simultaneous. [XX.7]
gal te tshogs pa'i snga rol tu/ / 'bras bu skyes par gyur na ni/ / rgyu dang rkyen rnams med pa yi/ / 'bras bu rgyu med 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
If effects arise Before their assemblies, The absence of causes and conditions Implies that effects are uncaused. [XX.8]
