gal te rgyu 'gags 'bras bu na/ / rgyu ni kun tu 'pho bar 'gyur/ / sngon skyes pa yi rgyu yang ni/ / yang skye bar ni thal bar 'gyur/ /
If a cause ceases, Yet is transferred to its effect, It follows that a cause already arisen Would arise once more. [XX.9]
'gags pa nub par gyur pa yis/ / 'bras bu skyes pa ji ltar skyed/ / 'bras bu dang ni 'bral ba'i rgyu/ / gnas pas kyang ni ji ltar skyed/ /
How could that which has ceased and disappeared Be the producer of an arisen effect? An enduring cause that is connected to its effect, How could that produce it? [XX.10]
ci ste rgyu 'bras ma 'brel na/ / 'bras bu gang zhig skyed par byed/ / rgyus ni mthong dang ma mthong bar/ / 'bras bu skyed par mi byed do/ /
If cause and effect are not connected, What effect would then be produced? Whether seen or unseen by the cause, No effect is produced. [XX.11]
'bras bu 'das pa rgyu 'das dang*/ / ma skyes pa dang skyes pa dang*/ / lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
A past effect is never in contact With a cause that has passed, Nor with one that has not arisen, Or one that has already arisen. [XX.12]
'bras bu skyes pa rgyu ma skyes/ / 'das pa dang ni skyes pa dang*/ / lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
An effect that has arisen Is never in contact With a cause that has not arisen, That has passed, or that has arisen. [XX.13]
'bras bu ma skyes rgyu skyes dang*/ / ma skyes pa dang 'das pa dang*/ / lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
An effect that has not arisen Is never in contact With a cause that has arisen, Has not arisen, or that has passed. [XX.14]
phrad pa yod pa ma yin na/ / rgyus ni 'bras bu ji ltar skyed/ / phrad pa yod pa yin na yang*/ / rgyus ni 'bras bu ji ltar skyed/ /
If there is no contact, How could a cause produce its effect? Even if there is contact, How could a cause produce its effect? [XX.15]
gal te 'bras bus stong pa'i rgyus/ / ji ltar 'bras bu skyed par byed/ / gal te 'bras bus mi stong rgyus/ / ji ltar 'bras bu skyed par byed/ /
If empty of an effect, How can a cause produce its effect? If not empty of an effect, How can a cause produce its effect? [XX.16]
'bras bu mi stong skye mi 'gyur/ / mi stong 'gag par mi 'gyur ro/ / mi stong de ni ma 'gags dang*/ / ma skyes par yang 'gyur ba yin/ /
An effect that is not empty does not arise. An effect that is not empty does not cease. It follows that what is not empty Has not ceased and has not arisen. [XX.17]
stong pa ji ltar skye 'gyur zhing*/ / stong pa ji ltar 'gag par 'gyur/ / stong pa de yang ma 'gags dang*/ / ma skyes par yang thal bar 'gyur/ /
How can the empty arise? How can the empty cease? It follows that the empty Has not ceased and not arisen. [XX.18]
rgyu dang 'bras bu gcig nyid du/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gzhan nyid du/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
Cause and effect being identical Will never make sense. Cause and effect being different Will never make sense. [XX.19]
rgyu dang 'bras bu gcig nyid na/ / bskyed bya skyed byed gcig tu 'gyur/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gzhan nyid na/ / rgyu dang rgyu min mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
If cause and effect were identical, Produced and producer would be the same. If cause and effect were different, Cause and noncause would be equal. [XX.20]
'bras bu ngo bo nyid yod na/ / rgyus ni ci zhig skyed par byed/ / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid med na/ / rgyus ni ci zhig skyed par byed/ /
If an effect is existent by nature, Then what could its cause produce? If an effect is nonexistent by nature, Then what could its cause produce? [XX.21]
skyed par byed pa ma yin na/ / rgyu nyid 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu nyid 'thad pa yod min na/ / 'bras bu gang gi yin par 'gyur/ /
If it does not produce any effect, The cause does not make sense. If the cause does not make sense, Of what, then, is the effect? [XX.22]
rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag gi / tshogs pa gang yin de yis ni/ / bdag gis bdag nyid mi skyed na/ / 'bras bu ji ltar skyed par byed/ /
If the assembly of causes and conditions Does not itself Produce its own identity, How could it produce an effect? [XX.23]
de phyir tshogs pas byas pa med/ / tshogs min byas pa'i 'bras bu med/ / 'bras bu yod pa ma yin na/ / rkyen gyi tshogs pa ga la yod/ /
Therefore, nothing is produced by an assembly, And yet there is no effect made by anything else. When no effect exists, How can there be an assembly of conditions? [XX.24]
tshogs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu pa'o/// ! //
['byung ba dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gcig pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE. Analysis of Arising and Disintegration
'jig pa 'byung ba med par ram/ / lhan cig yod pa nyid ma yin/ / 'byung ba 'jig pa med par ram/ / lhan cig yod pa nyid ma yin/ /
Disintegration occurs neither apart from Nor together with arising. Arising occurs neither apart from Nor together with disintegration. [XXI.1]
'jig pa 'byung ba med par ni/ / ji lta bur na yod par 'gyur/ / skye ba med par 'chi bar 'gyur/ / 'jig pa 'byung ba med par med/ /
Disintegration without arising, How could this occur? There would be dying without birth. Without arising, there is no disintegration. [XXI.2]
'jig pa 'byung dang lhan cig tu/ / ji ltar yod pa nyid du 'gyur/ / 'chi ba skye dang dus gcig tu/ / yod pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
Disintegration together with arising How could this occur? Death does not take place At the very same time as birth. [XXI.3]
'byung ba 'jig pa med par ni/ / ji lta bur na yod par 'gyur/ / dngos po rnams la mi rtag nyid/ / nam yang med pa ma yin no/ /
Arising without disintegration, How could this occur? It is not that things Ever lack impermanence. [XXI.4]
'byung ba 'jig dang lhan cig tu/ / ji ltar yod pa nyid du 'gyur/ / skye ba 'chi dang dus gcig tu/ / yod pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
Arising together with disintegration, How could this occur? Birth does not occur At the very same time as death. [XXI.5]
gang dag phan tshun lhan cig gam/ / phan tshun lhan cig ma yin par/ / grub pa yod pa ma yin pa/ / de dag grub pa ji ltar yod/ /
When two things are neither Established as coexistent, Nor as not coexistent, How can they be established? [XXI.6]
zad la 'byung ba yod ma yin/ / ma zad pa la'ang 'byung ba med/ / zad la 'jig pa yod ma yin/ / ma zad pa la'ang 'jig pa med/ /
There is no arising of the ceased, Nor is there arising of the not ceased. There is no disintegration of the ceased, Nor is there disintegration of the not ceased. [XXI.7]
dngos po yod pa ma yin par/ / 'byung dang 'jig pa yod ma yin/ / 'byung dang 'jig pa med par ni/ / dngos po yod pa ma yin no/ /
Where there is no thing, There is no arising and no disintegration. Without arising and disintegration, There is no thing. [XXI.8]
stong la 'byung dang 'jig pa dag / 'thad pa nyid ni ma yin no/ / mi stong pa la'ang 'byung 'jig dag / 'thad pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
With respect to the empty, Arising and disintegration make no sense. With respect to the not empty, Arising and disintegration make no sense either. [XXI.9]
'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / gcig pa nyid du mi 'thad do/ / 'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / gzhan nyid du yang mi 'thad do/ /
Arising and disintegration Do not make sense if the same. Arising and disintegration Do not make sense if different. [XXI.10]
'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / mthong ngo snyam du khyod sems na/ / 'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / gti mug nyid kyis mthong ba yin/ /
If you think, “I see arising and disintegration,” Then know that what you see Is due to ignorance. [XXI.11]
dngos po dngos las mi skye ste/ / dngos po dngos med las mi skye/ / dngos med dngos med mi skye ste/ / dngos med dngos las mi skye'o/ /
Things do not arise from things. Things do not arise from nonthings. Nonthings do not arise from nonthings. Nonthings do not arise from things. [XXI.12]
dngos po bdag las mi skye ste/ / gzhan las skye ba nyid ma yin/ / bdag dang gzhan las skye ba ni/ / yod min ji ltar skye bar 'gyur/ /
Things do not arise from themselves Nor from something other than themselves. When nothing arises from either self or other, How could there be arising? [XXI.13]
dngos po yod par khas blangs na/ / rtag dang chad par lta bar ni/ / thal bar 'gyur te dngos de ni/ / rtag dang mi rtag 'gyur phyir ro/ /
If the existence of things is claimed, Views of permanence and annihilation follow Because these things must then Be permanent or annihilated. [XXI.14]
dngos po yod par khas blangs kyang*/ / chad par mi 'gyur rtag mi 'gyur/ / 'bras bu rgyu yi 'byung 'jig gi / rgyun de srid pa yin phyir ro/ /
Although the existence of things is claimed, Permanence and annihilation do not follow Because existence is the continuum of effects and causes That arise and disintegrate. [XXI.15]
'bras bu rgyu yi 'byung 'jig gi / rgyun de srid pa yin 'gyur na/ / 'jig la yang skye med pa'i phyir/ / rgyu ni chad par thal bar 'gyur/ /
If a continuum of arising and ceasing Causes and effects constitutes existence, That which is destroyed does not arise again And so causes are annihilated. [XXI.16]
dngos po ngo bo nyid yod na/ / dngos med 'gyur bar mi rigs so/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i dus na chad/ / srid rgyun rab tu zhi phyir ro/ /
If things have an essential nature, They cannot reasonably become nonexistent. When suffering is transcended there is annihilation, For the continuum of existence is then entirely pacified. [XXI.17]
tha ma 'gags par gyur pa na/ / srid pa dang po rigs mi 'gyur/ / tha ma 'gags par ma gyur tshe/ / srid pa dang po rigs mi 'gyur/ /
If the last ceases, The first existence does not make sense. When the last does not cease, The first existence does not make sense. [XXI.18]
gal te tha ma 'gag bzhin na/ / dang po skye bar 'gyur na ni/ / 'gag bzhin pa ni gcig 'gyur zhing*/ / skye bzhin pa yang gzhan du 'gyur/ /
If the last is in the process of ceasing While the first arises, There is one that is ceasing And another that arises. [XXI.19]
gal te 'gag bzhin skye bzhin dag / lhan cig tu yang rigs min na/ / phung po gang la 'chi 'gyur ba/ / de la skye ba 'byung 'gyur ram/ /
Hence, it does not make sense either For ceasing and arising to occur together. Could the aggregates with which one dies Be the ones with which one is born as well? [XXI.20]
de ltar dus gsum dag tu yang*/ / srid pa'i rgyun ni mi rigs na/ / dus gsum dag tu gang med pa/ / de ni ji ltar srid pa'i rgyun/ /
Therefore, nowhere in the three times, Could there reasonably be any continuum of existence. How could something outside of the three times Be the continuum of existence? [XXI.21]
'byung ba dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gcig pa'o/// ! //
[de bzhin gshegs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gnyis pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO. Analysis of the Thus-Gone
phung min phung po las gzhan min/ / de la phung med de der med/ / de bzhin gshegs pa phung ldan min/ / de bzhin gshegs pa gang zhig yin/ /
He is not the aggregates, nor is he different from them. He is not in them, nor are they in him. Neither does the Thus-Gone possess the aggregates. Who, then, is the Thus-Gone? [XXII.1]
gal te sangs rgyas phung po la/ / brten nas rang bzhin las yod min/ / rang bzhin las ni gang med pa/ / de gzhan dngos las ga la yod/ /
If the Buddha exists dependent on the aggregates, And thus not by his own nature, How could that which does not exist in terms of its own nature Exist through the nature of another? [XXII.2]
gang zhig gzhan gyi dngos brten nas/ / de bdag nyid du mi 'thad do/ / gang zhig bdag nyid med pa de/ / ji ltar de bzhin gshegs par 'gyur/ /
That which depends on the nature of another Cannot reasonably have an identity of its own. How could something lacking an identity Turn out to be the Thus-Gone? [XXII.3]
gal te rang bzhin yod min na/ / gzhan dngos yod par ji ltar 'gyur/ / rang bzhin dang ni gzhan dngos dag / ma gtogs de bzhin gshegs de gang*/ /
If he does not exist by his own nature, How could there be the nature of something else? Apart from what is of the nature of self and other, What sort of Thus-Gone could there be? [XXII.4]
gal te phung po ma brten par/ / de bzhin gshegs pa 'ga' yod na/ / de ni da gdod rten 'gyur zhing*/ / brten nas de nas 'gyur la rag /
If, independent of the aggregates, There were a Thus-Gone, Then he could now rely on the aggregates And, based on them, become that. [XXII.5]
phung po rnams la ma brten par/ / de bzhin gshegs pa 'ga' yang med/ / gang zhig ma brten yod min na/ / des ni ji ltar nyer len 'gyur/ /
Yet, independent of the aggregates, There is no Thus-Gone at all. When there is no one who exists independently, How could there be any appropriation? [XXII.6]
nye bar blangs pa ma yin pa/ / nye bar len par cis mi 'gyur/ / nye bar len pa med pa yi/ / de bzhin gshegs pa ci yang med/ /
Without any appropriation, There cannot be something appropriated. Not involved in appropriation— Such a Thus-Gone does not exist at all. [XXII.7]
rnam pa lngas ni btsal byas na/ / gang zhig de nyid gzhan nyid du/ / med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa de/ / nye bar len pas ji ltar gdags/ /
When examined in the five ways, He exists neither as identical nor different. How, then, could a Thus-Gone who does not exist like that Be spoken of by virtue of appropriation? [XXII.8]
gang zhig nye bar blang ba de/ / de ni rang bzhin las yod min/ / bdag gi dngos las gang med pa/ / de gzhan dngos las yod re skan/ /
That which is appropriated Does not exist by its own nature. That which does not exist by itself, Can definitely not exist due to other things. [XXII.9]
de ltar nyer blang nyer len po/ / rnam pa kun gyis stong pa yin/ / stong pas de bzhin gshegs stong pa/ / ji lta bur na 'dogs par 'gyur/ /
Thus, the appropriated and the appropriator Are empty in all regards. Given their emptiness, how to speak Of an empty Thus-Gone? [XXII.10]
stong ngo zhes kyang mi brjod de/ / mi stong zhes kyang mi bya zhing*/ / gnyis dang gnyis min mi bya ste/ / gdags pa'i don du brjod par bya/ /
Do not say “empty,” And do not say “not empty” either. Do not say “both” and do not say “neither. ” These are to be stated for the sake of designation. [XXII.11]
rtag dang mi rtag la sogs bzhi/ / zhi ba 'di la ga la yod/ / mtha' dang mtha' med la sogs bzhi/ / zhi ba 'di la ga la yod/ /
Permanence, impermanence, and the other two— How could they pertain to this peace? Limited, limitless, and the other two— How could they pertain to this peace? [XXII.12]
gang gis de bzhin gshegs yod ces/ / 'dzin pa stug po bzung gyur pa/ / de ni mya ngan 'das pa la/ / med ces rnam rtog rtog par byed/ /
One seized by the dense fixation That the Thus-Gone exists Will think that, upon his transcendence, The Thus-Gone no longer exists. [XXII.13]
rang bzhin gyis ni stong de la/ / sangs rgyas mya ngan 'das nas ni/ / yod do zhe'am med do zhes/ / bsam pa 'thad pa nyid mi 'gyur/ /
As for a Buddha empty of nature, To declare that, upon transcendence, He exists or does not exist Would not make any sense. [XII.14]
gang dag sangs rgyas spros 'das shing*/ / zad pa med la spros byed pa/ / spros pas nyams pa de kun gyis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong mi 'gyur/ /
Those who create constructs about the Buddha, Who is beyond construction and without exhaustion, Are thereby damaged by their constructs; They fail to see the Thus-Gone. [XXII.15]
de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gang*/ / de ni 'gro 'di'i rang bzhin yin/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin med/ / 'gro ba 'di yi rang bzhin med/ /
That which is the nature of the Thus-Gone Is also the nature of this world. There is no nature of the Thus-Gone. There is no nature of the world. [XXII.16]
de bzhin gshegs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gnyis pa'o// ! //
[phyin ci log brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gsum pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE. Analysis of Error
'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug rnams/ / kun tu rtog las 'byung bar gsungs/ / sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / brten pa nyid las kun tu 'byung*/ /
It is taught that desire, anger, and stupor Originate in dependence on thought. Their arising depends On the attractive, unattractive, and mistaken. [XXIII.1]
gang dag sdug dang mi sdug dang*/ / phyin ci log las brtan 'byung ba/ / de dag rang bzhin las med de/ / de phyir nyon mongs yang dag med/ /
That which originates in dependence On the attractive, unattractive, and mistaken Cannot be due to its own nature. Hence, the afflictions are not real. [XXIII.2]
bdag gi yod nyid med nyid ni/ / ji lta bur yang grub pa med/ / de med nyon mongs rnams kyi ni/ / yod nyid med nyid ji ltar 'grub/ /
The existence or nonexistence of the self Is not established in any way. How can the existence or nonexistence Of the afflictions be established without it? [XXIII.3]
nyon mongs de dag gang gi yin/ / de yang grub pa yod ma yin/ / 'ga' med par ni gang gi yang*/ / nyon mongs pa dag yod ma yin/ /
The one to which the afflictions belong Is not in any way established. When they do not pertain to anything at all, The afflictions cannot exist in any way either. [XXIII.4]
rang lus lta bzhin nyon mongs rnams/ / nyon mongs can la rnam lngar med/ / rang lus lta bzhin nyon mongs can/ / nyon mongs pa la rnam lngar med/ /

As in the case of the view regarding one’s body, The afflictions are absent in the afflicted in five ways. As in the case of the view of one’s body, The afflicted is absent in the afflictions in five ways. [XXIII.5]
sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / rang bzhin las ni yod min na/ / sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / brten nas nyon mongs gang dag yin/ /
If the attractive, unattractive, and mistaken Are not due to their own nature, Then what are those afflictions that depend On the attractive, unattractive, and mistaken? [XXIII.6]
gzugs sgra ro dang reg pa dang*/ / dri dang chos dag rnam drug ni/ / gzhi ste 'dod chags zhe sdang dang*/ / gti mug gi ni yin par brtags/ /
Form, sound, taste, tactility, smell, And phenomena—these six Are believed to be the bases For desire, anger, and stupor. [XXIII.7]
gzugs sgra ro dang reg pa dang*/ / dri dang chos dag 'ba' zhig ste/ / dri za'i grong khyer lta bu dang*/ / smig rgyu rmi lam 'dra ba yin/ /
Form, sound, taste, tactility, smell, And phenomena are all without exception Like a city of scent-eaters, Like an optical illusion, like a dream. [XXIII.8]
sgyu ma'i skyes bu lta bu dang*/ / gzugs brnyan 'dra ba de dag la/ / sdug pa dang ni mi sdug pa/ / 'byung bar yang ni ga la 'gyur/ /
They resemble an illusory person And are similar to reflections. How could there be any real element Of the attractive or unattractive in them? [XXIII.9]
gang la brten nas sdug pa zhes/ / gdags par bya ba mi sdug pa/ / sdug la mi ltos yod min pas/ / de phyir sdug pa 'thad ma yin/ /
The unattractive upon which The designation “attractive” depends Does not exist independently of the attractive. Hence, the attractive does not make sense. [XXIII.10]
gang la brten nas mi sdug par/ / gdags par bya ba sdug pa ni/ / mi sdug mi ltos yod min pas/ / de phyir mi sdug 'thad ma yin/ /
The attractive upon which The designation “unattractive” depends Does not exist independently of the unattractive. Hence, the unattractive does not make sense. [XXIII.11]
sdug pa yod pa ma yin na/ / 'dod chags yod par ga la 'gyur/ / mi sdug yod pa ma yin na/ / zhe sdang yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
When there is nothing attractive, How could there possibly be desire? When there is nothing unattractive, How could there possibly be anger? [XXIII.12]
gal te mi rtag rtag pa zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la mi rtag yod min pas/ / 'dzin pa ji ltar log pa yin/ /
If thinking the impermanent To be permanent is an error, Then why, since the empty is not impermanent, Would that thought be in error? [XXIII.13]
gal te mi rtag rtag go zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la mi rtag pa'o zhes/ / 'dzin pa'ang ji ltar log ma yin/ /
If thinking that which is not permanent To be permanent is an error, Then why would thinking the empty To be impermanent not also be in error? [XXIII.14]
gang gis 'dzin dang 'dzin gang dang*/ / 'dzin pa po dang gang gzung ba/ / thams cad nye bar zhi ba ste/ / de phyir 'dzin pa yod ma yin/ /
The means for apprehending, the apprehension, That which apprehends, and what is apprehended Are all completely pacified. Hence, there is no apprehending. [XXIII.15]
log pa'am yang dag nyid du ni/ / 'dzin pa yod pa ma yin na/ / gang la phyin ci log yod cing*/ / gang la phyin ci ma log yod/ /
Given that there is neither mistaken Nor unmistaken apprehension, Who could be in error? Who could be correct? [XXIII.16]
phyin ci log tu gyur pa la/ / phyin ci log dag mi srid de/ / phyin ci log tu ma gyur la/ / phyin ci log dag mi srid de/ /
The mistaken cannot Become mistaken, Nor can the unmistaken Become mistaken. [XXIII.17]
phyin ci log tu gyur bzhin la/ / phyin ci log dag mi srid de/ / gang la phyin ci log srid pa/ / bdag nyid kyis ni rnam par dpyod/ /
That which is becoming mistaken Cannot become mistaken either. Where is error possible? Investigate that. [XXIII.18]
phyin ci log rnams ma skyes na/ / ji lta bur na yod par 'gyur/ / phyin ci log rnams skye med na/ / phyin ci log can ga la yod/ /
Since they have not arisen, How could there be errors? Given that no error has occurred, How could there be one that is mistaken? [XXIII.19]
dngos po bdag las mi skye ste/ / gzhan las skye ba nyid ma yin/ / bdag dang gzhan las kyang min na/ / phyin ci log can ga la yod/ /
Things do not arise from themselves, Nor do they arise from anything else. As things do not arise from self and not from other either, How could there be one that is mistaken? [XXIII.20]
gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang*/ / rtag dang bde ba yod na ni/ / bdag dang gtsang dang rtag pa dang*/ / bde ba phyin ci log ma yin/ /
If there is a self, something clean, Something permanent, and something delightful, The apprehending of self, clean, permanent, and delightful Are not mistakes. [XXIII.21]
gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang*/ / rtag dang bde ba med na ni/ / bdag med mi gtsang mi rtag dang*/ / sdug bsngal yod pa ma yin no/ /
If there is no self, nothing clean, Nothing permanent, and nothing delightful, There cannot be any absence of self, anything unclean, impermanent, and painful. [XXIII.22]
de ltar phyin ci log 'gags pas/ / ma rig pa ni 'gag par 'gyur/ / ma rig 'gags par gyur na ni/ / 'du byed la sogs 'gag par 'gyur/ /
As error in this way ceases, Ignorance comes to an end. As ignorance ceases, Formations and so forth end. [XXIII.23]
gal te la la'i nyon mongs pa/ / gang dag rang bzhin gyis yod na/ / ji lta bur na spong bar 'gyur/ / yod pa su zhig spong bar byed/ /
If someone’s afflictions Are existent by nature, How can they be eliminated? Who can eliminate the existent? [XXIII.24]
gal te la la'i nyon mongs pa/ / gang dag rang bzhin gyis med na/ / ji lta bur na spong bar 'gyur/ / med pa su zhig spong bar byed/ /
If someone’s afflictions Are nonexistent by nature, How can they be eliminated? Who can eliminate the nonexistent? [XXIII.25]
phyin ci log brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gsum pa'o/// ! //
['phags pa'i bden pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu bzhi pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR. Analysis of the Noble Truths
gal te 'di dag kun stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi po rnams/ / khyod la med par thal bar 'gyur/ /
If all of this were empty, Nothing would arise or be destroyed. For you it follows that There are no four noble truths. [XXIV.1]
'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi med pas/ / yongs su shes dang spong ba dang*/ / sgom dang mngon du bya ba dag / 'thad par 'gyur ba ma yin no/ /
Since there are no four noble truths, Complete understanding and elimination, As well as familiarization and actualization, Do not make any sense. [XXIV.2]
de dag yod pa ma yin pas/ / 'bras bu bzhi yang yod ma yin/ / 'bras bu med na 'bras gnas med/ / zhugs pa dag kyang yod ma yin/ /
Without these, The four fruitions do not exist either. Without fruition, there is no one abiding in that, Nor anyone who has gained entry. [XXIV.3]
gal te skyes bu gang zag brgyad/ / de dag med na dge 'dun med/ / 'phags pa'i bden rnams med pa'i phyir/ / dam pa'i chos kyang yod ma yin/ /
If the eight persons do not exist, Then there is no Sangha. Because there are no noble truths, There is no sacred Dharma. [XXIV.4]
chos dang dge 'dun yod min na/ / sangs rgyas ji ltar yod par 'gyur/ / de skad stong pa nyid smra na/ / dkon mchog gsum la gnod pa ni/ /
If there is no Dharma and no Sangha, How could there be any Buddha? This teaching of emptiness Invalidates the three jewels. [XXIV.5]
byed cing 'bras bu yod pa dang*/ / chos ma yin pa chos nyid dang*/ / 'jig rten pa yi tha snyad ni/ / kun la'ang gnod pa byed pa yin/ /
Likewise, the existence of results, Non-Dharma and Dharma, And all the conventions of the world Would likewise be invalidated thereby. [XXIV.6]
de la bshad pa khyod kyis ni/ / stong nyid dgos dang stong nyid dang*/ / stong nyid don ni ma rtogs pas/ / de phyir de ltar gnod pa yin/ /
To explain, you have not understood The purpose of emptiness, Emptiness itself, or its meaning. Therefore this is damaging to you. [XXIV.7]
sangs rgyas rnams kyis chos bstan pa/ / bden pa gnyis la yang dag brten/ / 'jig rten kun rdzob bden pa dang*/ / dam pa'i don gyi bden pa'o/ /
The Dharma taught by the Buddhas Is genuinely based on the two truths: The relative truth of the world And the truth of the ultimate meaning. [XXIV.8]
gang dag bden pa de gnyis kyi/ / rnam dbye rnam par mi shes pa/ / de dag sangs rgyas bstan pa ni/ / zab mo'i de nyid rnam mi shes/ /
Those who do not understand The distinction between these two truths, Fail to comprehend the profound reality Of the Buddha’s teaching. [XXIV.9]
tha snyad la ni ma brten par/ / dam pa'i don ni bstan mi nus/ / dam pa'i don ni ma rtogs par/ / mya ngan 'das pa thob mi 'gyur/ /
Without relying on convention, The ultimate cannot be shown. Without realizing the ultimate, Suffering cannot be transcended. [XXIV.10]
stong pa nyid la blta nyes na/ / shes rab chung rnams phung bar 'gyur/ / ji ltar sbrul la gzung nyes dang*/ / rig sngags nyes par bsgrubs pa bzhin/ /
When viewing emptiness incorrectly, Those with little insight will be ruined, As when a snake is caught in the wrong way, Or a knowledge mantra is used incorrectly. [XXIV.11]
de phyir zhan pas chos 'di yi/ / gting rtogs dka' bar mkhyen gyur nas/ / thub pa'i thugs ni chos bstan las/ / rab tu log par gyur pa yin/ /
Hence, knowing that the depth of this Dharma Would be hard for the feebleminded to understand, The realized mind of the Able one Turned entirely away from teaching the Dharma. [XXIV.12]
skyon du thal bar 'gyur ba ni/ / stong la 'thad pa ma yin pas/ / khyod ni stong nyid spong byed pa/ / gang de nga la mi 'thad do/ /
The flaws that ensue in consequence Are not reasonable with respect to emptiness. Hence, your discarding emptiness Is not reasonable to me. [XXIV.13]
gang la stong pa nyid rung ba/ / de la thams cad rung bar 'gyur/ / gang la stong nyid mi rung ba/ / de la thams cad rung mi 'gyur/ /
Everything is possible For those for whom emptiness is possible. Nothing is possible For those for whom emptiness is impossible. [XXIV.14]
khyod ni rang gi skyon rnams ni/ / nga la yongs su sgyur byed pa/ / rta la mngon par zhon bzhin du/ / rta nyid brjed par gyur pa bzhin/ /
All your own faults You project onto me, As if, while riding your horse, You had forgotten all about it. [XXIV.15]
gal te dngos rnams rang bzhin las/ / yod par rjes su lta byed na/ / de lta yin na dngos po rnams/ / rgyu rkyen med par khyod lta'o/ /
If you view things As existent by nature, Then for you there are No causes and conditions. [XXIV.16]
'bras bu dang ni rgyu nyid dang*/ / byed pa po dang byed dang bya/ / skye ba dang ni 'gag pa dang*/ / 'bras bu la yang gnod pa byed/ /
rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba gang*/ / de ni stong pa nyid du bshad/ / de ni brten nas gdags pa ste/ / de nyid dbu ma'i lam yin no/ /
That which originates in dependence Is taught to be emptiness. This itself is dependent imputation And so the path of the Middle Way. [XXIV.18]
gang phyir rten 'byung ma yin pa'i/ / chos 'ga' yod pa ma yin pa/ / de phyir stong pa ma yin pa'i/ / chos 'ga' yod pa ma yin no/ /
Apart from what originates dependently, There are no phenomena at all. Therefore, apart from emptiness, There are no phenomena at all. [XXIV.19]
gal te 'di kun mi stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi po rnams/ / khyod la med par thal bar 'gyur/ /
If all of this were not empty, Nothing would arise or be destroyed. For you it follows that There are no four noble truths. [XXIV.20]
rten cing 'brel 'byung ma yin na/ / sdug bsngal yod par ga la 'gyur/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal gsungs pa de/ / rang bzhin nyid la yod ma yin/ /
As it would not originate dependently, How could there be suffering? The teaching that the impermanent is suffering Cannot be relevant where nature exists. [XXIV.21]
rang bzhin las ni yod yin na/ / ci zhig kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de phyir stong nyid gnod byed la/ / kun 'byung yod pa ma yin no/ /
Given natural existence, What could originate? Hence, for those who deny emptiness, There cannot be any origin. [XXIV.22]
sdug bsngal rang bzhin gyis yod na/ / 'gog pa yod pa ma yin no/ / rang bzhin gyis ni yongs gnas phyir/ / 'gog la gnod pa byed pa yin/ /
If suffering exists by nature, There can be no cessation. As it would remain completely, Cessation would be invalidated. [XXIV.23]
lam la rang bzhin yod na ni/ / sgom pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / ci ste lam de bsgom bya na/ / khyod kyi rang bzhin yod ma yin/ /
If there were a nature of the path, It could not reasonably be cultivated. If the path is to be cultivated, Then this nature of yours does not exist. [XXIV.24]
gang tshe sdug bsngal kun 'byung dang*/ / 'gog pa yod pa ma yin na/ / lam gyi sdug bsngal 'gog pa ni/ / gang zhig thob par 'gyur bar 'dod/ /
If there is neither suffering Nor its origin and cessation, What cessation of suffering Do you assert is achieved by the path? [XXIV.25]
gal te rang bzhin nyid kyis ni/ / yongs su shes pa ma yin na/ / de ni ji ltar yongs shes 'gyur/ / rang bzhin gnas pa ma yin nam/ /
If complete understanding Were absent by nature, How could complete understanding occur? Does nature not remain? [XXIV.26]
de bzhin du ni khyod nyid kyi/ / spang dang mngon du bya ba dang*/ / bsgom dang 'bras bu bzhi dag kyang*/ / yongs shes bzhin du mi rung ngo*/ /
The same with your elimination, Actualization, familiarization, Cultivation, and four fruitions— They are as impossible as complete understanding. [XXIV.27]
rang bzhin yongs su 'dzin pa yis/ / 'bras bu rang bzhin nyid kyis ni/ / thob pa min pa gang yin de/ / ji ltar 'thob par nus par 'gyur/ /
Since they retain their own nature, How could fruitions that are By nature unachieved Ever be achieved? [XXIV.28]
'bras bu med na 'bras gnas med/ / zhugs pa dag kyang yod ma yin/ / gal te skyes bu gang zag brgyad/ / de dag med na dge 'dun med/ /
Without fruition, there is no one abiding in it, Nor anyone who has gained entry. If the eight persons do not exist, Then there is no Sangha. [XXIV.29]
'phags pa'i bden rnams med pa'i phyir/ / dam pa'i chos kyang yod ma yin/ / chos dang dge 'dun yod min na/ / sangs rgyas ji ltar yod par 'gyur/ /
Because there are no noble truths, There is no Dharma either. If there are no Dharma and Sangha, How could there be any Buddha? [XXIV.30]
khyod kyis sangs rgyas byang chub la/ / ma brten par yang thal bar 'gyur/ / khyod kyis byang chub sangs rgyas la/ / ma brten par yang thal bar 'gyur/ /
For you it follows that the Buddha Does not depend on enlightenment. For you it follows that enlightenment Does not depend on the Buddha. [XXIV.31]
khyod kyi rang bzhin nyid kyis ni/ / sangs rgyas min pa gang yin des/ / byang chub spyod la byang chub phyir/ / brtsal kyang byang chub thob mi 'gyur/ /
For you, the one who by nature is no Buddha May pursue the conduct of enlightenment In order to attain enlightenment, Yet all such efforts will be in vain. [XXIV.32]
'ga' yang chos dang chos min pa/ / nam yang byed par mi 'gyur te/ / mi stong ba la ci zhig bya/ / rang bzhin la ni bya ba med/ /
Nobody would ever perform Dharma or non-Dharma. What can be done to the not empty? There can be no action in relation to nature. [XXIV.33]
chos dang chos min med par yang*/ / 'bras bu khyod la yod par 'gyur/ / chos dang chos min rgyus byung ba'i/ / 'bras bu khyod la yod ma yin/ /
In the absence of Dharma and non-Dharma, For you, there are still effects. Effects caused by Dharma and non-Dharma For you, do not exist. [XXIV.34]
chos dang chos min rgyus byung ba'i/ / 'bras bu gal te khyod la yod/ / chos dang chos min las byung ba'i/ / 'bras bu ci phyir stong ma yin/ /
If, for you, there are effects That arise from Dharma and non-Dharma, Why, then, would these effects Of Dharma and non-Dharma not be empty? [XXIV.35]
rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yi/ / stong pa nyid la gnod byed gang*/ / 'jig rten pa yi tha snyad ni/ / kun la gnod pa byed pa yin/ /
The one who denies The emptiness of dependent origination Will, likewise, be denying All conventions of the world. [XXIV.36]
stong pa nyid la gnod byed na/ / bya ba ci yang med 'gyur zhing*/ / rtsom pa med pa bya bar 'gyur/ / mi byed pa yang byed por 'gyur/ /
A denial of emptiness Will preclude all action. There will be actions without initiation, As well as agents without anything done. [XXIV.37]
rang bzhin yod na 'gro ba rnams/ / ma skyes pa dang ma 'gags dang*/ / ther zug tu ni gnas 'gyur zhing*/ / gnas skabs sna tshogs bral bar 'gyur/ /
If beings had any nature, They would not be born or die. Indeed, they would remain immutable And would not know a variety of states. [XXIV.38]
gal te stong pa yod min na/ / ma thob thob par bya ba dang*/ / sdug bsngal mthar byed las dang ni/ / nyon mongs thams cad spong ba'ang med/ /
Were it not for emptiness, The unattained could not be attained, There would be no liberation from suffering, And no elimination of action and affliction. [XXIV.39]
gang gis rten cing 'brel par 'byung*/ / mthong ba de ni sdug bsngal dang*/ / kun 'byung dang ni 'gog pa dang*/ / lam nyid de dag mthong ba yin/ /
The one who sees Dependent origination Sees suffering, its origin, Cessation, and the path. [XXIV.40]
'phags pa'i bden pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu bzhi pa'o// ! //
[mya ngan las 'das pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu lnga pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE. Analysis of the Transcendence of Suffering
gal te 'di dag kun stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / gang zhig spong dang 'gags pa las/ / mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur bar 'dod/ /
If all of this were empty, Nothing would arise or be destroyed. Which elimination and cessation is it That you assert leads to the transcendence of suffering? [XXV.1]
gal te 'di kun mi stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / gang zhig spong dang 'gags pa las/ / mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur bar 'dod/ /
If all of this were not empty, Nothing would arise or be destroyed. Which elimination and cessation is it That you assert leads to the transcendence of suffering? [XXV.2]
spangs pa med pa thob med pa/ / chad pa med pa rtag med pa/ / 'gag pa med pa skye med pa/ / de ni mya ngan 'das par brjod/ /
No elimination and no attainment, No annihilation and no permanence, No cessation and no arising— This is termed the transcendence of suffering. [XXV.3]
re zhig mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / rga shi'i mtshan nyid thal bar 'gyur/ / rga dang 'chi ba med pa yi/ / dngos po yod pa ma yin no/ /
Now, the transcendence of suffering is not an entity, For it would then be characterized by aging and death. There is no entity that is free From aging and death. [XXV.4]
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos na/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'dus byas 'gyur/ / dngos po 'dus byas ma yin pa/ / 'ga' yang gang na yod ma yin/ /
If the transcendence of suffering were an entity, The transcendence of suffering would be conditioned. An entity that is not conditioned Does not exist anywhere at all. [XXV.5]
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos na/ / ji ltar myang 'das de brten min/ / dngos po brten nas ma yin pa/ / 'ga' yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
If the transcendence of suffering were an entity, Why would it not be dependent? An entity that is not dependent Does not exist at all. [XXV.6]
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / dngos med ji ltar rung bar 'gyur/ / gang la mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / de la dngos med yod ma yin/ /
If the transcendence of suffering is not an entity, How could it be a nonentity? When the transcendence of suffering is not an entity, Neither is it a nonentity. [XXV.7]
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / ji ltar myang 'das de brten min/ / gang zhig brten nas ma yin pa'i/ / dngos med yod pa ma yin no/ /
If the transcendence of suffering is not an entity, Why would it not be dependent? Indeed, there is no nonentity at all That is not dependent. [XXV.8]
'ong ba dang ni 'gro ba'i dngos/ / brten tam rgyur byas gang yin pa/ / de ni brten min rgyur byas min/ / mya ngan 'das pa yin par bstan/ /
Entities that come and go Are dependent and caused. Their being independent and not caused Is taught to be the transcendence of suffering. [XXV.9]
'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / spang bar ston pas bka' stsal to/ / de phyir mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos min dngos med min par rigs/ /
The Teacher has declared The abandonment of arising and disintegration. Thus, it makes sense that the transcendence of suffering Is not an entity or a nonentity. [XXV.10]
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yin na/ / dngos dang dngos po med pa dag / thal bar 'gyur na de mi rigs/ /
If the transcendence of suffering Were both entity and nonentity, Entity and nonentity would be liberation, Yet this does not make sense. [XXV.11]
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yin na/ / mya ngan 'das pa ma brten min/ / de gnyis brten nas yin phyir ro/ /
If the transcendence of suffering Were both entity and nonentity, The transcendence of suffering would not be independent, Because these two are dependent. [XXV.12]
ji ltar mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dbang dngos med gnyis yin te/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'dus ma byas/ / dngos dang dngos med 'dus byas yin/ /
How could the transcendence of suffering Be both entity and nonentity? The transcendence of suffering is unconditioned, Entity and nonentity are conditioned. [XXV.13]
ji ltar mya ngan 'das pa la/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yod de/ / de gnyis gcig la yod min te/ / snang ba dang ni mun pa bzhin/ /
How could the transcendence of suffering Possess both entity and nonentity? These two cannot coexist, Just like light and darkness. [XXV.14]
dngos min dngos po med min pa/ / mya ngan 'das par gang ston pa/ / dngos po med dang dngos po dag / grub na de ni grub par 'gyur/ /
The teaching that the transcendence of suffering Is neither entity nor nonentity Would be established If entity and nonentity were established. [XXV.15]
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos min dngos po med min na/ / dngos min dngos po med min zhes/ / gang zhig gis ni de mngon byed/ /
If the transcendence of suffering Were neither entity nor nonentity, Who would perceive that “It is neither entity nor nonentity”? [XXV.16]
bcom ldan mya ngan 'das gyur nas/ / yod par mi mngon de bzhin du/ / med do zhe 'am gnyis pa dang*/ / gis min zhes kyang mi mngon no/ /
When the Transcendent Conqueror has gone beyond, He is not perceived as “existent,” Nor as “nonexistent,” As “both,” or as “neither.” [XXV.17]
bcom ldan bzhugs par gyur na yang*/ / yod par mi mngon de bzhin du/ / med do zhe 'am gnyis ka dang*/ / gnyis min zhes kyang mi mngon no/ /
Even as the Transcendent Conqueror remains, He is not perceived as “existent,” Nor as “nonexistent,” As “both” or as “neither.” [XXV.18]
'khor ba mya ngan 'das pa las/ / khyad par cung zad yod ma yin/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'khor ba las/ / khyad par cung zad yod ma yin/ /
Cyclic existence is not the slightest bit Different from the transcendence of suffering Transcendence of suffering is not the slightest bit Different from cyclic existence. [XXV.19]
mya ngan 'das mtha' gang yin pa/ / de ni 'khor ba'i mtha' yin te/ / de gnyis khyad par cung zad ni/ / shin tu phra ba'ang yod ma yin/ /
That which is the condition of transcendence Is the condition of cyclic existence as well. Between these two there is not The slightest bit of difference. [XXV.20]
gang 'das phan chad mtha' sogs dang*/ / rtag la sogs par lta ba dag / mya ngan 'das dang phyi mtha' dang*/ / sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa yin/ /

Views of what follows the passing, of the finite and so on, Along with those on permanence and so forth, Are based on the transcendence of suffering, The limit of the future, and the limit of the past. [XXV.21]
dngos po thams cad stong pa la/ / mtha' yod ci zhig mtha' med ci/ / mtha' dang mtha' med ci zhig yin/ / mtha' dang mtha' med min pa ci/ /
When all things are empty, What is finite and what is infinite? What is both finite and infinite? What is neither finite nor infinite? [XXV.22]
de nyid ci zhig gzhan ci yin/ / rtag pa ci zhig mi rtag ci/ / rtag dang mi rtag gnyis ka ci/ / gnyis pa min pa ci zhig yin/ /
What is identical and what is different? What is permanent, what is impermanent? What is both permanent and impermanent? What is neither permanent nor impermanent? [XXV.23]
dmigs pa thams cad nyer zhi zhing*/ / spros pa nyer zhi zhi ba ste/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni gang du yang*/ / su la'ang chos 'ga' ma bstan to/ /
Complete pacification of all observations, The complete pacification of constructs, peace— Nowhere did the Buddha Teach any Dharma to anyone at all. [XXV.24]
mya ngan las 'das pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu lnga pa'o// ! //
[srid pa'i yan lag bcu gnyis brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu drug pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-SIX. Analysis of Dependent Origination
ma rig bsgribs pas yang srid phyir/ / 'du byed rnam pa gsum po dag / mngon par 'du byed gang yin pa'i/ / las de dag gis 'gro bar 'gro /
Due to the obscuration of ignorance, there occurs, directed at rebirth The conditioning of the action Of the three types of formation. Thus, there is migration between the realms. [XXVI.1]
'du byed rkyen can rnam par shes/ / 'gro ba rnams su 'jug par 'gyur/ / rnam par shes pa zhugs 'gyur na/ / ming dang gzugs ni chags par 'gyur/ /
Consciousness, conditioned by formation, Enters the realms. Once consciousness has entered, Name and form will manifest. [XXVI.2]
ming dang gzugs ni chags gyur na/ / skye mched drug ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / skye mched drug la brten nas ni/ / rig pa yang dag 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
When name and form have manifested, The six sense sources will develop. Dependent on the six sense sources, Contact comes into being. [XXVI.3]
ming dang gzugs dang dran byed la/ / brten nas skye ba kho na ste/ / de ltar ming dang gzugs brten nas/ / rnam par shes pa skye bar 'gyur/ /
It arises exclusively in dependence On eye, form, and consciousness. Thus, dependent on eye and form, Consciousness will occur. [XXVI.4]
mig dang gzugs dang rnam par shes/ / gsum po 'dus pa gang yin pa/ / de ni reg pa'o reg de las/ / tshor ba kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Contact is the meeting Of eye, form, and consciousness. Out of this meeting Arises sensation. [XXVI.5]
tshor ba'i rkyen gyis sred pa ste/ / tshor ba'i don du sred par 'gyur/ / sred par gyur na nye bar len/ / rnam pa bzhi po nyer len 'gyur/ /
Conditioned by sensation, there is craving, Craving with respect to sensation. When there is craving, there will be grasping, Grasping in the fourfold way. [XXVI.6]
nyer len yod na len pa po'i/ / srid pa rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ / gal te nye bar len med na/ / grol bar 'gyur te srid mi 'gyur/ /
Grasping will initiate The becoming of the grasper. Absence of grasping will result In liberation free from becoming. [XXVI.7]
srid pa de yang phung po lnga/ / srid pa las ni skye bar 'gyur/ / rga shi dang ni mya ngan dang*/ / smre sngags 'don bcas sdug bsngal dang*/ /
Becoming is the five aggregates. From becoming follows birth. Aging and death, grief, Lamentation, pain, [XXVI.8]
yid mi bde dang 'khrug pa rnams/ / de dag skye las rab tu 'byung*/ / de ltar sdug bsngal phung po ni/ / 'ba' zhig pa 'di 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Mental unrest, disturbance— All of this occurs due to birth. Thus arises this mass Of nothing but suffering. [XXVI.9]
'khor ba'i rtsa ba 'du byed de/ / de phyir mkhas rnams 'du mi byed/ / de phyir mi mkhas byed po yin/ / mkhas min de nyid mthong phyir ro/ /
Formation is the root of cyclic existence, Therefore, the wise do not form. The agents of that are the unwise; Not the wise, for they see reality. [XXVI.10]
ma rig 'gags par gyur na ni/ / 'du byed rnams kyang 'byung mi 'gyur/ / ma rig 'gag par 'gyur ba ni/ / shes pas de nyid bsgoms pas so/ /
When ignorance has ceased, Formation does not arise either. The cessation of ignorance is accomplished By meditating on reality through insight. [XXVI.11]
de dang de ni 'gags gyur pas/ / de dang de ni mngon mi 'byung*/ / sdug bsngal phung po 'ba' zhig pa/ / de ni de ltar yang dag 'gag /
As each of them ceases, None of them will occur. Thus, this mass of nothing but suffering Will actually come to an end. [XXVI.12]
srid pa'i yan lag bcu gnyis brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu drug pa'o// ! //
[lta ba brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu bdun pa]
CHAPTER TWENTY-SEVEN. Analysis of Views
'das dus byung ma byung zhes dang*/ / 'jig rten rtag pa la sogs par/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa yin/ /
Past existence and nonexistence, A permanent world, and so forth— These views depend On the extreme of the past. [XXVII.1]
ma 'ongs dus gzhan 'byung 'gyur dang*/ / mi 'byung 'jig rten mtha' sogs par/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa yin/ /
The views of existence and nonexistence At a different time in the future, Of the end of the world, and so forth Depend on the extreme of the future. [XXVII.2]
'das pa'i dus na byung gyur ces/ / bya ba de ni mi 'thad do/ / sngon tshe rnams su gang byung ba/ / de nyid 'di ni ma yin no/ /
Saying “It existed in the past” Indeed, does not make sense. Whatever occurred in past lives Is not the same as this. [XXVII.3]
de nyid bdag tu 'gyur snyam na/ / nye bar len pa tha dad 'gyur/ / nye bar len pa ma gtogs par/ / khyod kyi bdag ni gang zhig yin/ /
If you think, “That itself is the self,” The appropriated would be different. Apart from appropriated, What is this self of yours? [XXVII.4]
nye bar len pa ma gtogs pa'i/ / bdag yod ma yin byas pa'i tshe/ / nye bar len nyid bdag yin na/ / khyod kyi bdag ni med pa yin/ /
When it is held that there is no self Apart from the appropriated, If the appropriated is itself the self, Your self does not exist. [XXVII.5]
nye bar len nyid bdag ma yin/ / de 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yin/ / nye bar blang ba ji lta bur/ / nye bar len po yin par 'gyur/ /
The appropriated is not the self, For it arises and disintegrates. How could the appropriated Ever be the appropriator? [XXVII.6]
bdag ni nye bar len pa las/ / gzhan du 'thad pa nyid ma yin/ / gal te gzhan na len med par/ / gzung yod rigs na gzung du med/ /
It does not make sense for there to be A self that is different from the appropriated. If different, it could reasonably be perceived In the absence of appropriation, yet it cannot. [XXVII.7]
de ltar len las gzhan ma yin/ / de ni nyer len nyid kyang min/ / bdag ni nye bar len med min/ / med pa nyid du'ang de ma nges/ /
Thus, it is not other than appropriation, Nor are these two the same. The self does not exist without appropriation, Yet neither can it be ascertained as nonexistent. [XXVII.8]
'das pa'i dus na ma byung zhes/ / bya ba de yang mi 'thad do/ / sngon tshe rnams su gang byung ba/ / de las 'di gzhan ma yin no/ /
Saying “It did not exist in the past,” Does not make sense either. Whatever was there in past lives Is not different from this. [XXVII.9]
gal te 'di ni gzhan gyur na/ / de med par yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin de ni gnas 'gyur zhing*/ / der ma shi bar skye bar 'gyur/ /
If it were something other, It could arise even in its absence. Likewise, that would remain And there could be birth without death there. [XXVII.10]
chad dang las rnams chud za dang*/ / gzhan gyis byas pa'i las rnams ni/ / gzhan gyis so sor myong ba dang*/ / de la sogs par thal bar 'gyur/ /
There would be annihilation, action would be wasted, The action done by one Would be experienced by another— These and other flaws would ensue. [XXVII.11]
ma byung ba las 'byung min te/ / 'di la skyon du thal bar 'gyur/ / bdag ni byas par 'gyur ba dang*/ / 'byung ba'am rgyu med can du 'gyur/ /
Something previously nonexistent does not arise Because flaws would follow: The self would be a product And its arising would lack a cause. [XXVII.12]
de ltar bdag byung bdag ma byung*/ / gnyis ka gnyis ka ma yin par/ / 'das la lta ba gang yin pa/ / de dag 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
Thus, that the self existed, did not exist, That it both existed and did not, Or neither existed nor did not exist— These views on the past are untenable. [XXVII.13]
ma 'ongs dus gzhan 'byung 'gyur dang*/ / 'byung bar mi 'gyur zhes bya bar/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / 'das pa'i dus dang mtshungs pa yin/ /
The views that “it will exist At a different time in the future,” Or that, “it will not exist in the future,” Are equal to those about the past. [XXVII.14]
gal te lha de mi de na/ / de lta na ni rtag par 'gyur/ / lha ni ma skyes nyid 'gyur te/ / rtag la skye ba med phyir ro/ /
If the god were the human, It would be permanent. The god would be unborn, For the permanent has no birth. [XXVII.15]
gal te lha las mi gzhan na/ / de lta na ni mi rtag 'gyur/ / gal te lha mi gzhan yin na/ / rgyud ni 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
If the god were different from the human, It would be impermanent. If god and human were different, There could not reasonably be one stream of being. [XXVII.16]
gal te phyogs gcig lha yin la/ / phyogs gcig mi ni yin gyur na/ / rtag dang mi rtag 'gyur ba yin/ / de yang rigs pa ma yin no/ /
If one part were divine And another part human, It would be permanent and impermanent. That is not reasonable either. [XXVII.17]
gal te rtag dang mi rtag pa/ / gnyis ka grub par gyur na ni/ / rtag pa ma yin mi rtag min/ / 'grub par 'gyur bar 'dod la rag /
If permanent and impermanent Were both established, It would be possible to establish The neither permanent nor impermanent. [XXVII.18]
gal te gang zhig gang nas gang*/ / 'ong zhing gang du'ang 'gro 'gyur na/ / de phyir 'khor ba thog med par/ / 'gyur na de ni yod ma yin/ /
If something came somewhere from somewhere And then would go somewhere else, Then cyclic existence would have no beginning, Yet that is not the case. [XXVII.19]
gal te rtag pa 'ga' med na/ / mi rtag gang zhig yin par 'gyur/ / rtag pa dang ni mi rtag dang*/ / de gnyis bsal bar gyur pa'o/ /
When nothing is permanent, What could be impermanent? Permanence, impermanence, And both have been dismissed. [XXVII.20]
gal te 'jig rten mtha' yod na/ / 'jig rten pha rol ji ltar 'gyur/ / gal te 'jig rten mtha' med na/ / 'jig rten pha rol ji ltar 'gyur/ /
If the world had an end, How could there be another world? If the world had no end, How could there be another world? [XXVII.21]
gang phyir phung po rnams kyi rgyun/ / 'di ni mar me'i 'od dang mtshungs/ / de phyir mtha' yod nyid dang ni/ / mtha' med nyid kyang mi rigs so/ /
This continuity of the aggregates Is just like an oil lamp’s light. Hence, neither finitude Nor infinitude makes sense. [XXVII.22]
gal te snga ma 'jig 'gyur zhing*/ / phung po 'di la brten byas nas/ / phung po de ni mi 'byung na/ / des na 'jig rten mtha' yod 'gyur/ /
If the previous were to cease, And if, based on these aggregates, Those aggregates would not arise, The world would have an end. [XXVII.23]
gal te snga ma mi 'jig cing*/ / phung po 'di la brten byas nas/ / phung po de ni mi 'byung na/ / des na 'jig rten mtha' med 'gyur/ /
If the previous were not to cease, And if, based on these aggregates, Those aggregates would not arise, The world would be endless. [XXVII.24]
gal te phyogs gcig mtha' yod la/ / phyogs gcig mtha' ni med 'gyur na/ / 'jig rten mtha' yod mtha' med 'gyur/ / de yang rigs pa ma yin no/ /
If one part were finite And another part infinite, The world would and would not have an end. This does not make sense either. [XXVII.25]
ji lta bur na nyer len po'i/ / phyogs gcig rnam par 'jig 'gyur la/ / phyogs gcig rnam par 'jig mi 'gyur/ / de ltar de ni mi rigs so/ /
How could one part Of the appropriator be destroyed And another part not be destroyed? This does not make sense. [XXVII.26]
ji lta bur na nyer blang ba/ / phyogs gcig rnam par 'jig 'gyur la/ / phyogs gcig rnam par 'jig mi 'gyur/ / de ltar de yang mi rigs so/ /
How could one part Of the appropriated be destroyed And another part not be destroyed? That does not make sense either. [XXVII.27]
gal te mtha' yod mtha' med pa/ / gnyis ka grub par gyur na ni/ / mtha' yod ma yin mtha' med min/ / 'grub par 'gyur bar 'dod la rag /
If the finite and infinite Were both established, It would be possible to establish The neither finite nor infinite. [XXVII.28]
yang na dngos po thams cad dag / stong phyir rtag la sogs lta ba/ / gang dag gang du gang la ni/ / ci las kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Alternately, because all things are empty, How could views of permanence and so on, Occur in any form, anywhere, And to anyone at all? [XXVII.29]
lta ba brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu bdun pa'o// ! //
gang gis thugs brtse nyer bzung nas/ / lta ba thams cad spang ba'i phyir/ / dam pa'i chos ni ston mdzad pa/ / gau tam de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
By the love of his heart, he accepts us And, so that all views may be relinquished, Reveals the sacred Dharma. To the teacher, Gautama, I prostrate. [XXVII.30]
[mjug don]
Colophon to the Tibetan Translation

dbu ma rtsa ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa shes rab ces bya ba theg pa chen po'i chos mngon pa rnam par gzhag pa/ don dam pa'i de kho na yang dag par ston pa/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i tshul gsal bar byed pa/ slob dpon bdag nyid chen po 'phags pa klu sgrub mi 'phrogs pa'i mkhyen rab dang thugs rjer ldan pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i theg pa bla na med pa'i tshul gsal bar byed pa/ rab tu dga' ba'i sa bsgrubs nas/ bde ba can gyi zhing du gshegs pa/ 'jig rten gyi khams dang ba'i 'od ces bya bar/ de bzhin gshegs pa ye shes 'byung gnas 'od ces bya bar 'gyur bas mdzad pa rdzogs so// //

This completes the root stanzas of the Middle Way, entitled “Insight,” which belong to the Abhidharma of the Great Vehicle and which truly reveal ultimate reality. This elucidation of the way of transcendent insight was composed by the great being and noble Master Nāgārjuna, possessor of inalienable knowledge and compassion. Illuminating the way of the supreme vehicle of the Thus-Gone One, he accomplished the ground of great joy and departed for the Realm of Bliss. In the world called Clear Light, he will become a Thus-Gone One, known by the name “Light of the Source of Wakefulness.”

dbang phyug dam pa'i mnga' bdag rgyal po chen po dpal lha btsan po'i bka' lung gis/ rgya gar gyi mkhan po chen po dbu ma pa/ dz+nyA na gar+b+ha dang*/ zhu chen gyi lots+tsha ba dge slong cog ro klu'i rgyal mtshan gyis bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa/ 'di la rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa bdun/ sh+lo ka bzhi brgya bzhi bcu rtsa dgu yod/ bam po ni phyed dang gnyis su byas so/

As instructed by the great king, Pal-lha Tsenpo, Lord of Perfect Majesty, this translation was prepared, revised, and established by the great Indian preceptor and representative of the Middle Way, Jñānagarbha, and the lotsāwa and editor, the monk Chokru Lui Gyaltsen. The twenty-seven chapters and 449 ślokas are contained in one and a half bampo.

slad kyis kha che'i grong khyer dpe med kyi dbus/ gtsug lag khang rin chen sbas pa'i dbus su/ kha che'i mkhan po ha su ma ti dang*/ bod kyi sgra bsgyur gyi lo ts+tsha ba pa tshab nyi ma grags kyis mi'i bdag po 'phags pa lha'i sku ring la 'grel pa tshig gsal ba dang bstun nas bcos pa'o// // slad kyis ra sa 'phrul snang gi gtsug lag khang du/ rgya gar gyi mkhan po ka na ka dang*/ lo ts+tsha ba de nyid kyis zhu chen bgyis pa'o// // ! //

Subsequently, the translation was revised based on the Clear Words commentary during the reign of Āryadeva, Lord of Men, in the Temple of Hidden Jewels, a monastic college situated in the center of the city of Anupamanagara in Kashmir. This revision was undertaken by the Kashmiri preceptor Hasumati and the Tibetan lotsāwa, the translator Patsab Nyima Drakpa. The Indian preceptor Kanaka and the same lotsāwa later prepared a final revision in the Temple of Rasa Trülnang.
bal yul nas rgyal yongs sa chen zhes pa las gu rus spel// //
NAMO BUDDHĀYA
@#/ /dbu ma rtsa ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa shes rab ces bya ba'i rnam bshad rigs pa'i rgya mtsho zhes bya ba bzhugs so/ /
An Ocean of Reasoning. Commentary to Mūlamadhyamakakārikā, the Text Known as “Wisdom”
rje btsun 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyi zhabs kyi pad+mo la gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ /
[I] I prostrate with veneration to the lotus feet of the Lord Mañjuśrī.

gang zhig gsungs pas smra ba'i gtsug rgyan zhes/ / rab 'byams zhing gi mkhas pas rab bsngags pa/ // rang bzhin stong pa rten 'byung don nyid du/ / gsung ba'i rgyal ba de yis rtag skyongs shig / gtam de gsung rab kun gyi snying por ni/ / gzigs nas rab 'byams zhing gi rgyal sras 'khor/ / zab mo'i gtam gyis rtag tu tshim mdzad pa/ / rje btsun mkhyen pa'i gter la skyabs su mchi/ /

May I be sustained by the Victor Who is universally praised by the wise As the crown of all teachers For teaching emptiness of essence as the meaning of dependent arising. I take refuge in the Lord of the treasure of wisdom Who, seeing that discourse as the heart of all of the scriptures, Through this profound discourse, exhilarates The universal assembly of bodhisattvas.

nges pa'i don de ji ltar gsungs pa las/ / rnam pa gzhan du 'dren pa'i dogs pa'i gnas/ / dpag yas bkod nas legs par sun phyung ste/ / tshul der nges pa bla med ster ba'i sgo/ / sgrub dang sun 'byin lam ni mi 'dra ba'i/ / rigs lam stong gi 'od zer spros pa yis/ / mthar 'dzin snying gi mun stug 'joms mdzad pa/ / klu sgrub smra ba'i nyi ma rgyal gyur cig /

May Nāgārjuna, the sun among teachers, be victorious, Who, having identified countless areas of perplexity, Which could divert one from the definitive meaning of the teachings, Then refutes them eloquently; And, who, providing unsurpassed ascertainment of that system Through countless shining beams of argument— Various proofs and refutations— Dispels the thick darkness at the heart of grasping the extremes.

lugs kyi mchog de tshul bzhin rab bzung nas/ / thub mchog bstan pa ring du gsal mdzad pa/ // dpal ldan 'phags pa lha dang dpa' bo sogs/ / shing rta chen po'i srol 'dzin rnams la 'dud/ / skar tshogs dbus na mtshan mo'i mgon po bzhin/ / 'grel mdzad kun gyi khrod na lham me ba/ / grub mchog sangs rgyas bskyangs dang zla ba'i lugs/ / dran pa yis kyang dad pa'i spu long g.yo/ /

I venerate the upholders of the traditions of the great charioteer, The noble Āryadeva and Āryaśūra, and the rest, Who have properly preserved the supreme system And who have extensively illuminated the doctrine of the sage. Just like the savior in the night—the moon—among the constellations, The system of the masters Buddhapālita and Candrakīrti Shines most radiantly of all the commentators’. Even when I recollect them my hairs stand on end.

gang gi zhabs pad bsten pas rab rmongs dgra/ / rab tu 'joms mdzad rigs lam gsal mdzad pa/ / 'dren mchog bla ma'i rmad byung mdzad pa yis/ / da dung srid mtha'i bar du skyong gyur cig / nges don don gnyer bshes gnyen mang po dang*/ / grags ldan yangs pa'i srid la mnga' mdzad pa'i/ / gsung gis bskul tshe zab mo dbu ma'i lam/ / rnam par 'byed la bdag blo spro ba skyes/ /

By relying on the lotus feet, my enemy—ignorance—is completely [2] Vanquished through his illumination of the path of reason. May I still be sustained until the end of cyclic existence Through the marvelous acts of the supreme guide, the teacher. I am pleased to comment on this profound middle path Having been requested to do so by many spiritual friends Who aspire to ascertain the definitive meaning And by the illustrious ruler of the kingdom.

nges don zhes pa'i ming gis tshim pa dang */ // che long don tsam mthong bas chog shes rnyed/ / snying nas sgrub pa lhur len skyes pa'i tshe/ / gzhung mchog 'dor ba rnams la mi dgos kyang / / nges don gsung rab snying po sher phyin don/ / rnal 'byor dbang phyug bye bas bgrod pa'i lam/ / ma rtogs log rtog the tshom mun pa'i tshogs/ / yang dag rigs pa'i sgron mes legs bsal nas/ / yin lugs phu thag chod pa'i lta ba yis/ / klu sgrub dgongs pa ji bzhin sgom 'dod pa'i/ / blo ldan de la dbu ma'i rtsa ba ni/ // bdag gis legs par bshad kyis gus pas nyon/ /

Although those who are satisfied by the mere term “definitive meaning,” And those who are contented just by a glimpse of partial meaning, And those in whom the desire for practice arises from the heart, But who relinquish these important treatises, may not want this, Having eloquently dispelled the darkness of confusion By the lamp of perfect reasoning, and having resolved all misconceptions Regarding the meaning of the Prajñāpāramitā, the heart of the definitive scriptures, Which is the path on which countless yogis tread, For those wise ones who wish to contemplate Nāgārjuna’s purport as it is, By means of decisive views regarding how things stand, I will now eloquently comment on Mūlamadhyamakakārikā. So, listen with veneration!
[sngon gleng]
Preliminary Explanations
'dir gang bshad par bya ba'i chos ni dbu ma'i rtsa ba yin la de 'chad pa la gnyis/ bshad pa'i sngon du 'gro ba dang*/ bshad pa dngos la 'jug pa'o/ /
The preliminary explanation is the first of two parts of this commentary, the second of which is the principal explanation.
dang po [bshad pa'i sngon du 'gro ba]
[Preliminary Explanations]

['di] la lnga/ de kho na nyid btsal dgos shing 'tshol ba'i tshul/ bstan bcos mdzad pa po'i che ba/ des mdzad pa'i bstan bcos kyi rnam gzhag / chos zab mo la mos pa'i phan yon/ de gang la bshad pa'i snod bstan pa'o/ /

This chapter has five parts: the necessity and manner of investigating the way things really are, the greatness of the author of the text, the articulation of his treatises, the benefits of aspiring to the profound Dharma, and identifying the vessel into which the profound Dharma can be introduced./1/
dang po [de kho na nyid btsal dgos shing 'tshol ba'i tshul] ni/
1. Necessity and Manner of Investigating the Way Things Really Are

rgyal ba rnams kyis sbyin pa la sogs pa'i spyod pa gzhan ji snyed cig gsungs pa thams cad ni de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i shes rab ma skyes pa skye ba dang skyes zin gnas pa dang gong nas gong du 'phel ba'i thabs yin te/ spyod 'jug las/ yan lag 'di dag thams cad ni/ / thub pas shes rab don du gsungs/ / de yi phyir na sdug bsngal dag / zhi bar 'dod pas shes rab bskyed/ / ces gsungs pa ltar ro/ //

Everything the buddhas have said about generosity and other similar virtues is a means to cultivate the wisdom that comprehends the way things really are for those who have not cultivated it and to stabilize and continue its development for those who have already cultivated it. Therefore, Bodhicāryāvatāra says: All the branches of the teachings are taught by the Sage For the cultivation of wisdom. [3] Therefore, those who wish to pacify suffering Should cultivate wisdom. [IX: 1]

de yi phyir gsung rab thams cad kyang dngos dang brgyud pas de kho na nyid la 'bab cing gzhol ba sha stag yin pas long ba'i tshogs rnams long khrid pa mkhas pas 'dod pa'i yul du 'khrid pa bzhin du/ sbyin pa la sogs pa thar pa'i grong khyer du 'khrid par byed pa rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i de kho na nyid mthong ba'i shes rab kyi mig yongs su btsal ba ni blo gros dang ldan pa rnams kyi las su bya ba dam pa'o/ / de yang don de nyid ston par lung bstan pas legs par bkral ba dang 'grel tshul yang / gdul bya'i dbang gis drang nges kyi sgo mi 'dra ba du ma zhig gsungs pa la gang ni sgra ji bzhin pa yin la gang ni min snyam du the tshom za ba na/ 'di ltar ston pa'i gsung rab kyi don ni de kho na ltar gzung gi gzhan du drang bar mi bya'o zhes sgra ji bzhin pa'i don la sgrub byed yod lugs dang / de las gzhan du 'dren pa la gnod byed yod lugs rnams rigs pas mtha' dag par gtan la phab pa zhig gi rjes su zhugs nas 'tshol dgos pa ni shing rta chen po thams cad kyi man ngag bgrod pa gcig pa'o/ /

Therefore, since all the teachings are directly or indirectly devoted to establishing the way things are, the highest obligation of the wise person is to seek the absolutely clear eye of wisdom which ascertains the way things really are, viz., dependent origination. Such things as generosity lead to the city of liberation, just as a group of blind people are led to their destination by a skillful guide. This is how this profound meaning is elegantly interpreted by the masters who have been prophesied to expound it. Their hermeneutical methods are these: In virtue of the fact that many different teachings—some definitive and some requiring interpretations—are provided in accordance with the abilities of different disciples, doubts arise regarding which of these teachings are to be taken literally and which are not. So the meaning of the Buddha’s teaching should be investigated following a system completely justified by arguments that literally demonstrate how the scriptures of the teacher are to be taken, that they are not to be taken otherwise, that undermine alternative interpretations, and also through arguments against other interpretations. This is the instruction given unanimously by all the great charioteers.
gnyis pa [bstan bcos mdzad pa po'i che ba] ni/
2. Greatness of the Author of the Text

de lta yin dang 'phags pa lang kar gshegs pa las/ so so rang rig theg pa ni/ / rtog ge pa yi spyod yul min/ / mgon po 'das pa'i 'og tu ni/ / 'dzin par su 'gyur bshad du gsol/ / zhes mnyam bzhag so so rang gis rig pa'i ye shes kyi yul sgra rtog gi spros pa zhi ba'i theg pa/ ston pa mya ngan las 'das nas su zhig gis 'dzin zhus pa'i lan du/ bde gshegs mya ngan 'das pa'i 'og / tshul rnams 'dzin par 'gyur ba de/ / dus dag 'das nas 'byung ba ni/ / blo gros chen po khyod shes byos/ / lho phyogs be da'i yul du ni/ / dge slong dpal ldan cher grags pa/ / de ming klu zhes 'bod pa ste/ / yod dang med pa'i phyogs 'jig pa/ / nga yi theg pa 'jig rten du/ / bla med theg chen rab bshad nas/ / rab tu dga' ba'i sa bsgrubs te/ / bde ba can du de 'gro'o/ / zhes nges pa'i don gyi theg pa yod med kyi mtha' gnyis dang bral ba klu sgrub kyis 'grel par gsungs so/ /

As it is said in the Lankāvatāra-sūtra: The vehicle of discriminative wisdom Is not subject to the comprehension of sophists. After the passing away of the protector, Please tell, who would hold the tradition thereafter? [m Do sde ca, 165b] Thus the Buddha was asked who, after his demise, would maintain the vehicle—the object of the discriminative wisdom of meditative equipoise—that is free from verbal and conceptual elaboration. The Buddha replies: You, the wise man, should know That after the parinirvāṇa of the Buddha, The holder of the system will come After some time has passed. In the land of Vidarbha in the South, One widely renowned as “the monk Śrī,” [4] Who will be named “Nāga,” Destroying the positions of nihilism and reificationism. He will propound my vehicle in the world, The supreme Mahāyāna, Will achieve the ground of joyfulness and He will than ascend to the Blissful Land. [m Do sde ca, 165b] Thus the Buddha said that the definitive vehicle, free from both nihilism and reificationism, would be propounded by Nāgārjuna.

'di ni gser 'od dam pa nas bshad pa ston pa zhal bzhugs dus kyi li tsa byi gzhon nu 'jig rten thams cad kyis mthong na dga' ba zhes bya ba de nyid skye ba bzhes pa yin te/ sprin chen las/ gzhon nu 'di nga mya ngan las 'das nas lo bzhi brgya lon pa na klu zhes bya ba'i dge slong du gyur nas nga yi bstan pa rgyas par byas te mthar rab tu dad pa'i 'od ces bya ba'i zhing du ye shes 'byung gnas 'od ces bya ba'i rgyal bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ //

This, as said in the Suvarṇaprabhās-sūtra, is the reincarnation of the Licchavī, who was, during the Buddha’s time, called Sarvalokapriyadarśana because in the Mahāmegha the Buddha says: Four hundred years after my passing away, this boy will become a monk named “Nāga” and will disseminate my doctrine; eventually he will become the Victor named Jñānākāraprabhā in the land called Prasāda Prabhā. [rGyud Pa, 159a, Pha 4b–5a]

bya ba'i rgyud 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las kyang 'byung ba'i dus dang mtshan de dang 'dra la lo drug brgya bzhugs par bshad do / rnga bo che'i mdo las li tsa byi gzhon nu 'jig rten thams cad kyis mthong na dga' ba 'di ston pa 'das nas lo brgyad cu pa la bstan pa nyams pa'i tshe/ ston pa'i mtshan 'chang ba'i dge slong du gyur nas bstan pa rgyas par byas te lo brgya lon pa'i 'og tu 'das nas bde ba can du skye bar gsungs so/ /

In Mañjuśrīmūlakalpa of the Action Tantric School, the time of advent and the name are the same but it is said that he would live for six hundred years. The Mahābherihārakaparivarta-sūtra says: After the teacher’s passing away, when the human life span becomes eighty years and his doctrine declines, this Licchavī boy Sarvalokapriyadarśana will become a monk holding the teacher’s name and will disseminate the doctrine. He will die after completing one hundred years, and will be born in the Blissful Land. [mDo sde dza, 100b]

'di yang slob dpon 'di yi lung bstan du gnas brtan byang bzang dang jo bo chen po bzhed de li tsa byi mthong na dga' ba klu sgrub dang rgyud gcig tu bshad pa la brten pa'o/ // rnga bo che las de ltar lung bstan pa de lho phyogs su 'byung ba'i tha ma gcig yin par gsungs pas lo bzhi brgya na byon pa ni lho phyogs su 'byung ba'i tshul gnyis pa'o/ / lang gshegs dang 'jam dpal gyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las sa dang po bsgrubs nas bde ba can du 'byon par bshad cing / rnga bo che las dge slong de sa bdun pa bar bshad do/ /

Atiśa Dīpaṅkara and Bodhibhadra also maintain that this passage is a prediction of the master, which is based on the traditional belief that the Licchavī boy and Nāgārjuna are of same personal continuum. It is said that the prediction in Mahādundubhi is for his final appearance in the South. Therefore, his emergence after four hundred years is his second appearance in the South. The Lankāvatāra-sūtra and Mañjuśrīmūlakalpa say that he would proceed to the Blissful Land after attaining the first ground. [5] But in the Mahādundubhi the monk is said to be of the seventh ground.

sprin chen dang rnga bo che las ma 'ongs pa na 'tshang rgya bar gsungs pa ni 'dod pa khams su sprul sku'i 'tshang rgya tshul yin pas/ sgron gsal las rnal 'byor bla med kyi lam gyis klu sgrub kyi sku tshe de nyid la rdo rje 'chang gi go 'phang thob par gsungs pa dang mi 'gal te/ ston pa shAkya thub pa tshe lo brgya pa'i dus su 'tshang rgya bar gsungs pa dang sngon bskal pa du ma'i sngon nas sangs rgyas par gsungs pa mi 'gal ba bzhin no/ / mgon po 'di 'dra ba'i rlabs po che'i gang zag rnal 'byor bla med kyi theg pa pas lo drug brgya bzhugs kyang 'tshang rgya mi nus na bla med kyi rgyud nas gdul bya rab kyis tshe gcig la rdo rje 'dzin pa'i go 'phang thob par gsungs pa ltar khas blangs kyang tshig tsam du zad do/ // des na rigs pa drug cu pa'i 'grel pa las/ mgon po 'di mdzad pa mthar ma phyin par bshad pa ni phar phyin gyi theg pa rkyang pas lam bgrod pa'i dbang du byas pa'o/ /

The predictions in Mahāmegha and Mahādundubhi that he would be enlightened in the future are for the enlightenment of the manifested body in the desire realm. But this does not contradict the statement in the Pradīpodyotana-ṭīkā [rGyud ha 200a] that Nāgārjuna attained the status of Vajradhara in that very life through the path of supreme yoga, because these are similar to the statements that the teacher Śākyamuni would achieve enlightenment when the human life span would be one hundred, and that he achieved enlightenment several eons back, which do not contradict each other. If a great person like this teacher, who lived six hundred years, could not be enlightened through the supreme yoga, then the claim in the supreme tantra that a superior practitioner can achieve the status of Vajradhara would be idle words. Thus, the statement in the Yuktiṣaṣṭikāvṛtti [dBu ma ya 2b] that this teacher had not completed his activity is in accordance with the path of Prajñāpāramitā vehicle alone.
gsum pa [des mdzad pa'i bstan bcos kyi rnam gzhag] ni/
3. The Articulation of His Treatises

de lta bu'i mgon po 'dis sbyor ba brgya pa la sogs pa rig pa'i gnas thun mong ba'i bstan bcos dang nang rig pa la yang sngags dang pha rol tu phyin pa la brten pa mang du mdzad do/ / zab mo dbu ma'i lam nges pa'i don lung gis bstan pa ni mdo kun las btus las sher phyin 'bum pa dang byang sems kyi sde snod la sogs pa'i mdo mang po drangs nas bshad do/ // rigs pas bstan pa ni rtsa ba shes rab stong nyid bdun cu pa rtsod zlog rigs pa drug cu pa zhib mo rnam 'thag rin chen phreng ba ste drug tu rigs pa mang pos gtan la phab bo/ / bstod pa 'ga' zhig las kyang stong nyid bstan mod kyang rigs pas bsgrubs pa mi mang ngo / / gzhung de dag kyang yod med kyi mtha' spangs pa'i rten 'byung gi de kho na nyid gtso bor ston pa dang / yod med kyi mthar mi lta ba'i lam gyis 'khor ba las grol ba gtso bor ston pa gnyis su 'du'o/ //

This master has written many treatises like Yogaśataka, in secular fields, and on studies of inner phenomena, particularly tantra and the Prajñāpāramitā. He presents the profound middle path as definitive through authoritative sources by citations in Sūtrasamuccaya [dBu ma ki 187a, 193b] of many sūtras like the One Hundred Thousand Verse Prajñāpāramitā and those from the bodhisattva literature, and he establishes it by providing numerous arguments in the six treatises: Mūlamadhyamakakārikā, Śūnyatāsaptati, Vigrahavyāvartanī, Yuktiṣaṣṭikā, Vaidalyasūtra and Ratnāvalī. Some of his paeans discuss emptiness, but not many of them present arguments. These treatises are of two primary kinds: those which demonstrate the way things really are—free from two extremes of existence and nonexistence—and [6] those which demonstrate that the path free from these extreme views leads to liberation.

dang po la gnyis las dngos po'i ngo bo nyid smra ba rnams kyis gang zag dang chos la sgro btags pa'i rang bzhin bsgrub bya 'gog pa ni rtsa ba shes rab yin la/ de'i sgrub byed tshad ma la sogs pa rtog ge'i tshig gi don bcu drug 'gog pa ni zhib mo rnam 'thag go / dngos po rnams kyi rang bzhin ni/ / rkyen la sogs la yod ma yin/ / zhes gsungs pa la/ gal te dngos po thams cad kyi/ / rang bzhin kun la yod min na/ / khyod kyi tshig kyang rang bzhin med/ / rang bzhin bzlog par mi nus so/ / zhes brgal ba'i lan du byung ba'i phyir rtsod zlog ni rab byed dang po'i gzhung de'i lhag ma'o/ /

The former is demonstrated in two ways: Mūlamadhyamakakārikā refutes the thesis concocted by the reificationists, viz., that persons and phenomena have essences; Vaidalyasūtra refutes the Nyāiyayika’s use of their sixteen categories, such as authoritative cognition, to prove that they do. Vigrahavyāvartanaī responds to the following argument: If all phenomena lacked essence Your words also would lack essence. Thus the essence of all things Cannot be rejected. [I: 1] which is offered against The essence of phenomena Does not exist in conditions, etc. [MMK I: 3ab] Therefore, it is a supplement to the first chapter of Mūlamadhyamakakārikā.

'dis tshig rang bzhin gyis stong pa rten 'byung gi don du bshad nas rang bzhin med kyang des bsgrub bya sgrub pa dang dgag bya 'gog nus par gsungs pas rang bzhin med pa'i phyogs la tshad ma dang gzhal bya'i dgag sgrub kyi bya byed kyang 'thad par ston zhing / rang bzhin yod par smra ba la tshad ma dang gzhal bya mi 'thad pa la sogs pa rnams ston no/ // rtsa sher rang bzhin med pa la bya byed thams cad 'thad par bstan mod kyang dmigs kyis phye nas dgag sgrub kyi bya byed 'thad par bstan na lugs 'di la rang phyogs sgrub pa sogs mi rung ngo snyam pa ldog pa'i phyir ro/ /

This shows that the meaning of words being empty of essence is that they are dependently originated, and it states that despite lacking essence words can prove a thesis and refute that which is to be refuted. Thus it demonstrates that the agent and action of establishing and denying authoritative cognition and object make sense in the system asserting essencelessness. Moreover, it shows that for a school positing essence, such things as authoritative cognition do not make any sense. Mūlamadhyamakakārikā demonstrates that without essence agency and action make complete sense. Nevertheless, in Vigrahavyāvartanī, having shown emphatically that agent and action of proof and refutation make sense, the idea that in this system one cannot establish one’s own position is dismissed.

stong nyid bdun cu pa ni rab byed bdun pa las/ rmi lam ji bzhin sgyu ma bzhin/ / dri za'i grong khyer ji bzhin du/ / de bzhin skye dang de bzhin gnas/ // de bzhin du ni 'jig pa gsungs/ // zhes pa 'di la brgal ba'i lan du byung bas gzhung de'i lhag ma'o// // de yang skye gnas 'jig pa'i rang bzhin bkag pa na lung las de dag gsungs pa mi 'thad do zhes rgol ba 'byung la/

Śūnyatāsaptati is composed in response to an argument against the statement in the seventh chapter of Mūlamadhyamakakārikā: Like a dream, like an illusion, Like a city of Gandharvas, So have arising, enduring And ceasing been explained. [VII: 34] Hence, that text is a supplement to the treatise. It is argued by some that the refutation of the essence of arising, endurance, and destruction is incorrect since authoritative sources mention these things.

stong nyid bdun cu pa las/ / gnas pa'am skye 'jig yod med dam/ / dman pa'am mnyam pa'am khyad par can/ / sangs rgyas 'jig rten snyad dbang gis/ / gsungs kyi yang dag dbang gis min/ / zhes skye 'jig la sogs pa thams cad sangs rgyas kyis 'jig rten gyi tha snyad kyi dbang gis gsungs kyi yang dag par grub pa'i dbang gis gsungs pa min par bshad pas de la brgal ba'i lan no/ / gzhung der skye ba la sogs pa la rang bzhin 'gog pa mang du gsungs pa'i mthar/ dngos po thams cad rang bzhin gyis/ / stong pa yin pas dngos rnams kyi/ / rten 'byung 'di ni de bzhin gshegs/ / mtshungs pa med pas nye bar bstan/ / dam pa'i don ni der zad do/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis ni/ / 'jig rten tha snyad brten nas su/ // sna tshogs thams cad yang dag btags/ / zhes dngos po'i gnas tshul gyi don dam ni rten 'byung rang bzhin gyis stong pa de tsam du zad pas/ skye ba la sogs pa thams cad tha snyad kyi dbang gis btags nas bzhag par gsungs so/ /

[7] Śūnyatāsaptati says: The Buddha asserts that there is or is not arising, endurance, and destruction; And that things are lower, equal, or higher In accordance with worldly convention; But not in accordance with reality. [1] Thus it responds that the Buddha presents arising, destruction, etc., all in concordance with ordinary people, but not as existing in reality. After extensively refuting essence in such things as arising, that treatise says: All things are Empty by nature. Therefore, the unexcelled Tathāgata Taught the dependent origination of phenomena. That is the supreme meaning. The Buddha, relying on worldly conventions, States that all the various phenomena are In reality designated. [68–69] The ultimate mode of existence of things is nothing but their emptiness of essence—that is, their being dependently originated. Hence, it is explained that all such things as arising are established as imputed through the power of convention.
