[Ibid., 285b] Thus it is said that the Victor has stated and argued that the effects are empty—that they do not have the nature of being essentially produced.

thams cad chos kyang mi g.yo brtan par gnas/ / mi 'gyur 'tshe ba med cing zhi ba ste/ / ji ltar nam mkha' shes pa med pa bzhin/ / de la mi shes 'gro ba rmongs par 'gyur/ / zhes pas ni chos rnams kyi de kho na nyid de mi g.yo ba sogs su bstan cing de yang nam mkha' ri bo la sogs pa'i thogs bcas bkag tsam 'jog pa min pa gzhan du shes par bya med pa bzhin du g.yo ba dang brtan pa sogs kyi spros pa bcad tsam du shes par bya ba dang / don de ma rtogs pas 'khor bar gsungs so/ / ji ltar ri bo dag ni mi sgul pa/ / de bzhin chos rnams rtag tu bskyod mi nus/ / 'chi 'pho med cing skye ba med pa yi/ / chos rnams de ltar rgyal bas rab tu bstan/ / ces pas ni chos rnams rang bzhin gyis stong pa rnam pa gzhan du drang du mi nus pa dang 'chi / 'pho sogs med par bstan to/ / chos gang skye ba med cing 'byung ba med/ 'chi 'pho med cing rga bar mi 'gyur ba/ / mi yi seng+ge yis ni der ston zhing / / sems can brgya phrag dag ni de la bkod/ / ces pas ni rang bzhin gyis skye 'chi med pa'i don de gdul bya gzhan du ma zhig kyang 'dzin du bcug ces dngos su bstan pa'i shugs kyis gzhan dag gis kyang de la sems can rnams dgod par bya'o zhes bstan to/ /

All phenomena are immutable and stable; Unchangeable, without turmoil and peaceful, Just as empty space is not seen./40/ The ignorant are confused about this. [Ibid., 285b] This statement shows that the way phenomena really are is immutable, etc. Just as space is not understood as anything but the mere absence of obstructions, such as mountains, reality should be understood as the mere absence of fabrications, such as mutability and instability./41/ Unless they realize this point, beings wander in cyclic existence. Just as mountains are unshakable. Phenomena are unshakable, Without death, transformation or birth: So the Victor has presented all phenomena. [Ibid., 285b] This statement shows that the essential emptiness of phenomena cannot be interpreted in any other way; phenomena are without death, transformation, etc. Phenomena are neither born nor come into existence; Nor die, nor transform, nor age. The lion among men has shown this And has led hundreds of sentient beings to see this. [Ibid., 261b] This passage shows that he has enabled his disciples to grasp the fact of being essentially birthless and deathless. Showing this explicitly implies that others also should lead sentient beings to see that.

gang la ngo bo nyid ni gang yang med/ / gzhan yang ma yin sus kyang mi rnyed pa/ / nang na ma yin phyi rol dag na yang / / mi rnyed de dag la ni mgon pos bkod/ / ces pas ni chos gang la tshol ba po sus gnas skabs gang du btsal kyang rang dang gzhan gyi ngo bo nyid mi rnyed pa'i don de la sems can rnams bkod ces bstan te gdul bya la nges don gyi go ba skyed lugs bstan to/ /

That, the entitihood of which does not exist anywhere, Is also not any other thing, and cannot be found. It is not internal; nor can it be found externally. The protector has led them to see this. [Ibid., 262a]/42/ This passage shows that any phenomena, no matter who seeks them, [88] will be found to have neither their own nor any other’s entity. He led sentient beings to see this fact. This shows how disciples should develop their understanding of the definitive meaning.

bde bar gshegs pas zhi ba'i 'gro gsungs kyang / / 'gro ba gang yang rnyed par mi 'gyur de/ / de dag 'gro las grol bar rnam par gsungs/ / grol nas sems can mang po grol bar mdzad/ / ces pas ni zhi bar 'gro mkhan de yang btsal na mi rnyed pa dang / de lta na'ang de dag 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor ba las grol ba dang rang grol nas gzhan mang po sgrol bar gsungs te rigs pas dpyad na mi rnyed pas thar pa dang de thob mkhan dang des de thob pa sogs thams cad mi 'gog pa'i don no/ /

The Tathāgata has said of those who go towards pacification That no goer can be found. They are proclaimed to be free from going. Through their liberation, many sentient beings are liberated. [Ibid., 262a] The meaning of this passage is as follows: If the ones who proceed towards pacification are sought they are not found. However, they are free from the cycle of five transmigrations, and, having liberated themselves, are said to be able to liberate many others. Just because when they are analyzed rationally, they are not found, this does not mean that such things as liberation, those who achieve it, or their achievement are thereby refuted.
de ltar na rab byed dang po'i rigs pa 'di rnams ni 'di dang 'di 'dra ba'i skye med ston pa'i gsung rab thams cad lta ba'i mig tu shes par gyis shig /
So, these arguments in the first chapter should be understood as the eye through which all of the scriptures that present non-arising in this and similar ways can be seen.
gsum pa [don bsdus te rab byed kyi mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

rab byed 'dis gang 'gog pa'i dgag bya 'dzin lugs dang de rigs pas bkag pa'i 'og tu ji 'dra zhig tu grub pa dang / de nyid la rgyu rkyen dang 'bras su 'jog tshul gsum mdor bsdus te brjod na/ sa bon dang bud shing la sogs pas myu gu dang me la sogs pa skyed pa'i bya ba byed pa mthong ba dang de ltar byed ces thos pa na/ rgyu 'bras gnyis ka yang ming du btags pa tsam min par tha snyad btags pa'i btags sa'i don de rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i bskyed bya dang skyed byed du yod par 'dzin pa ni dgag bya 'dzin pa yin no/ / de ltar bzung ba'i don de yod par khas len na 'bras bu skye ba de rgyu rkyen dang rang bzhin gcig pa dang tha dad pa'i skye ba gang yin zhes dpyad nas 'bras bu'i ngos nas bskyed bya'i rang bzhin dang / rkyen gyis kyang 'bras bu rgyu dus na yod med gang sgrub ces sogs kyis rgyu'i ngos nas skyed byed kyi rang bzhin 'gog ste/ rang gi ngo bos yod pa de la rgyu rkyen dang 'bras bu gang yang gzhag sa med par dgag pa'i phyogs nyid gtso bor mdzad nas ston to/ / de ltar mdzad dgos pa ni rgyu 'bras yod pa de rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod par 'dzin pa thog ma med pa nas goms ches pas de bzlog dka' ba'i phyir dang / rang bzhin de khegs na rang bzhin med pa la bya byed 'thad pa bde blag tu 'grub pa'i phyir/ rang lugs la tha snyad du bya byed 'jog lugs rnams gtso bor ma mdzad do/ /

Here are summaries of the following three matters: the way in which the object of negation refuted in this chapter is grasped, what is established after it is refuted through arguments, and in light of that, how to posit causes, conditions, and effects. When such things as seeds and fuel are seen or heard to be performing the action of giving rise to such things as sprouts and fire, respectively, to take both cause and effect not as merely nominally imputed, but as the objects that are the bases of nominal imputation, grasped as inherently existent produced and producer, is to grasp the object of negation. When the object so grasped is maintained to exist in that way, through an analysis asking whether this arisen effect has the same essence as or a different essence from its causes and conditions, with respect to the effect, the essence of the produced is refuted, and when one analyzes the conditions that produce the effect, asking whether they exist or not when the cause occurs, then with respect to the cause the essence of the producers is refuted. [89] This is because Nāgārjuna presents a position, the primary focus of which is refutation, according to which an inherently existent entity cannot be posited as having causes, conditions, or effects. Here is why he does this: Since from beginningless time, we are accustomed to grasping causes and effects as existing inherently, this is difficult to dispel. When that essence is refuted, the tenability of action and agent in the context of essencelessness can easily be established. Nāgārjuna does not focus here primarily on how we set out action and agent conventionally in our own system.

de ltar 'gog pa'i tshe bdag las sam gzhan las zhes sogs kyis tha snyad btags pa'i btags sa'i don de ji ltar yod dpyad nas 'gog pa sha stag 'byung bas btags pa tsam min pa'i skye ba 'gog gi skye ba tsam mi 'gog par shin tu gsal ba la dgongs nas rab byed phal mo cher dgag bya la khyad par ma sbyar zhing / khyad par sbyar ba yang skabs mang du gsungs la skabs gcig tu sbyar na rgyu mtshan mtshungs pas dngos su ma sbyar ba rnams la yang sbyar dgos pa shes sla ba la dgongs nas kyang yin no/ / tshig gsal las ni 'gag pa med pa skye med pa zhes sogs ni 'gag sogs yod par gsungs pa'i lung dang mi 'gal bar ston pa na zag med kyi ye shes kyi yul gyi rang bzhin gyi skye 'gag sogs med pa yin zhes pa dang don dam pa'i skye ba bkag gi kun rdzob pa'i skye ba ma bkag ces stong thun du bshad zin cing / rkyen bzhi las dngos po skye bar gsungs pa'i lung gi dgongs pa yang de yin par bshad la dmigs rkyen bkag pa yang don dam par yin gyi kun rdzob pa min zhes gsungs pas dgag bya la khyad par sbyar ba shin tu yang gsal la grangs kyang mang bas/ tshig don 'chad pa'i skabs su mang du ma byung ba la 'khrul bar mi bya'o/ /

Arguments such as “Neither from itself nor from another” that express refutations always involve analysis of how the objects taken to be the bases of conventional imputation exist. Therefore, they refute any arising that is not merely imputed, but they do not refute mere arising. Having this clearly in mind, in most of the chapters Nāgārjuna does not apply the modifying term to the object of negation. The modifying term is indeed applied in many places. He does not always explicitly apply it, thinking that it is easy to see that when it is applied in any one context, when the grounds are the same, it should be supplied in other cases even where it is not explicitly applied. I have explained in Lam rim chen mo [580, translation by Cutler et al., III, pp. 128-129] that, according to Prasannapadā, when such statements as “Dependent origination is without cessation, without arising” [4a] are shown to be noncontradictory to sūtras where the existence of such things as cessation is asserted, they are taken to express the absence of such things as cessation and arising with respect to the nature of the object of uncontaminated wisdom. They refute ultimate arising, but they do not refute conventional arising. It is also explained that this is the intention behind statements in sūatra that things arise from the four conditions. Even the refutation of the objective condition is said to be with respect to the ultimate and not the conventional [Prasannapadā, 28b]. Therefore, it is crystal clear that the modifying term should be applied to the object of negation, and this kind of case occurs frequently. But one should not be misled by lexical glosses where this is not applied frequently.

brgya pa'i 'grel pa las kyang / gal te rnam par dpyad pa 'dis skye ba rnam pa thams cad du bkag pa las 'dus byas skye ba med par bstan par 'dod na ni/ de yi tshe de sgyu ma lta bu nyid du mi 'gyur gyi mo gsham gyi bu la sogs pa dag gis nye bar gzhal bar 'gyur ba zhig na/ rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba med par thal bar 'gyur ba'i 'jigs pas de dag dang bstun par mi byed kyi de dang mi 'gal ba sgyu ma la sogs pa dag dang ni byed do/ / zhes shin tu gsal bar gsungs shing / lang gshegs las kyang / rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa la dgongs nas ngas chos thams cad ma skyes pa'o zhes gsungs so zhes pa tshig gsal du drangs so/ // rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa la rgyu 'bras khegs pa na rgyu 'bras ming du btags pa tsam dang ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam du 'gyur te bud d+ha pA li ta las rab byed dang po'i mgor skye bar brjod pa tha snyad tsam yin par ston cig ces dang*/ rdzogs pa'i mjug tu skye bar brjod pa tha snyad tsam du grub bo zhes bshad pa bzhin no/ /

The commentary to Catuḥśataka makes this point very clearly: [90] If one maintained that in virtue of the complete refutation of arising via this analysis, compound phenomena are presented as nonarisen, then it would not be like an illusion, but would be like something that is perceived by the son of a barren woman and the like. Lest the absurd consequence follow that there would be no dependent arising, one should not compromise with those who say this. Instead, one should consistently follow the analysis according to which they are illusionlike. [dBu ma ya 225a] Prasannapadā [88b] quotes the following statement in the Lankāvatāra-sūtra: I have said that all things are nonarisen meaning that they are essentially nonarisen. [m Do sde Ca 79b] If cause and effect are refuted in the context of existence through their own characteristic, cause and effect can be taken to be merely nominally imputed, and merely posited through the force of nominal conventions. As the Buddhapālita says, in the beginning of the first chapter, “To say that something arises is merely convention” [161b], and as it says, at the very end of the chapter, “To say that something arises is to say that it merely exists conventionally” [168b].

de ltar rang gi ngo bos grub pa la rgyu 'bras khas blang du mi rung bar mthong na phan gnod byed pa'i rgyu 'bras la ni sus kyang bsnyon du med pas yod la/ rang gi ngo bos yod pa la ni gzhag tu mi rung ba'i phyir ming gi tha snyad gyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la de dag 'thad do zhes khas blang bar bya'o/ bskyed bya skyed byed rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i steng nas 'jog pa la goms ches pas de bkag pa na ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la de dag 'jog pa blo la mi bde yang / 'jog tshul gnyis las ni med la snga ma la mi 'thad na phyi ma la 'jog pa 'os med do snyam du blo de yi phyogs su drang dgos so/ / bskyed bya skyed byed yod na rgyu 'bras kyi don yod pas ming du btags pa tsam mo zhes pa mi 'thad do snyam pa yang mi rigs pa'i rgyu mtshan tsam gyi sgras ming min pa'i don yod pa dang don tshad mas grub pa mi gcod pa dang / ming du btags pa tsam du yod ces pas kyang ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis ma bzhag pa'i yod pa mi srid kyang ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis gang bzhag thams cad yod par ston pa min par bshad zin to//

Thus, when one sees that in the context of inherent existence it does not make any sense to accept cause and effect, since beneficial and harmful causes and effects are undeniable, they exist; and since it makes no sense to posit them in the context of inherent existence, one must accept that they are tenable only when posited as existing merely through the force of nominal convention. Since ordinary people are thoroughly habituated to positing producer and produced as existing through their own characteristics, when this is refuted, they find it awkward to posit them as existing merely through the force of nominal convention. However, since there are only these two modes of positing them, and since the first one is untenable, one should push one’s mind in the direction of the second one, since it is inevitable. It makes no sense to think that it is untenable to say that since producer and produced exist, cause and effect exist; and therefore that they are nominally imputed. [91] The reason that this makes no sense is that, as has been explained, the word “merely” means neither that no objects exist besides names nor that their being cognized by authoritative cognition is precluded. On the other hand, although the phrase “things exist merely in virtue of nominal imputation” means that it is impossible that they exist without being posited by nominal convention, it does not mean that everything posited by nominal convention exists.

de ltar na phyi nang gi rgyu rkyen sa bon dang myu gu la sogs pa dang dbang po dang yul la brten nas rnam shes 'byung ba lta bu gang rnam pa gsal ba zhig gzhir gzung la/ sngar bshad pa ltar gyi 'dzin pas ji ltar bzung ba ltos te de nas 'bras phyogs dang rgyu phyogs gang rung gcig nas rang gi ngo bos yod pa 'gog pa'i rigs pa rnams kyis rang bzhin lhag ma ma lus par dgag ste cung zad ma khegs na'ang de yi 'dzin pas bcings nas grol du mi ster ba'i phyir ro/ / de nas rgyu 'bras de dag ming du btags pa tsam du 'char la phan gnod byed pa'i rgyu 'bras la ni bsnyon sa med pas btags pa tsam gyi rgyus 'bras bu skyed par 'dug pa la/ bdag gis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa kho na la de dag bzung ba ni phyin ci log go snyam du nges par byas la rgyu 'bras rten 'brel gyi nges pa la mi gnod par bya ste/ rang lugs la de dag rgyu 'bras su bzhag sa med par 'khrul ba'i ngor yod pa tsam la kun rdzob tu yod par bzhag na lta ba'i gol sa'i skur 'debs chen po yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

So, taking whichever of the internal and external causes and conditions is clearest as an example—such as seeds and sprouts, or consciousness arising depending on sense faculties and objects—and seeing how it is grasped in the way previously explained, and then focusing either on the cause or on the effect, through the argument refuting their inherent existence, one should refute all of the remaining essence. If even the slightest bit is not refuted, then being bound by that grasping, liberation cannot be attained. Then causes and effects will appear to be merely nominally imputed. Then, since the benefits and harms of causes and effects are undeniable, one should develop ascertainment, thinking as follows: “Although in the context of mere imputation, causes give rise to effects, it is erroneous for me to grasp them in the context of existence through their own characteristics.” One should not allow this to undermine one’s ascertainment of the dependent arising of causes and effects. According to our own system, if these things are posited as existing conventionally in the sense of existing merely from the standpoint of illusion, and are not posited in a framework according to which there are causes and effects, this would be a great error and a great deprecation of reality.
rkyen brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa dang po'o// //
This is the first chapter called “the examination of conditions.”
rkyen brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu bzhi'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa dang po'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the first chapter, having fourteen verses, called “the examination of conditions.”
CHAPTER II. Examination of Motion
gnyis pa 'gro 'ong gi bya byed la brtags nas gang zag la rang bzhin dgag pa
we now turn to the second section, the refutation of the essence of the self through the examination of the action and agent of going and coming
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
This chapter has three parts: the explanation of the the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ gal te skye ba bkag pas 'gag pa med pa sogs 'grub par yang bshad mod kyang rten 'byung la 'gro 'ong med pa grub par bya ba'i phyir de 'gog pa'i rigs pa thun mong ma yin pa brjod dgos so/ / 'dir 'gro 'ong 'gog pa ni zag med kyi ye shes kyi yul gyi rang bzhin gyi 'gro 'ong 'gog par bshad pa dang / rab byed brgyad pa'i 'grel pa las kyang 'gro ba po dang 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis phan tshun ltos nas grub kyi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min par gsungs pas 'gro 'ong ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag bya'o/ /

Here it should be stated that although it has been explained through the refutation of arising [92] that the nonexistence of such things as cessation is established in order to establish that there is no coming or going in dependent origination, it is necessary to provide refutatory arguments specific to that topic. Here the refutation of coming and going should be understood as the refutation of coming and going as the nature of the object of uncontaminated wisdom. The commentary to the eighth chapter explains that since the goer and the action of going exist in mutual dependence, but do not exist inherently, the inherent existence of going and coming is the object of negation.
'di dgag pa la gnyis/ rgyas par bshad/ mjug bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the extensive explanation and drawing conclusions.
dang po [rgyas par bshad]
1.1 Extensive explanation
['di] la gnyis/ las dang byed pa po la bya ba so sor dgag / las dang byed pa po la bya ba thun mong du dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of activity in each of agent and action and the refutation of the activity common to agent and action.
dang po [las dang byed pa po la bya ba so sor dgag pa]
1.1.1 Refutation of activity in each of agent and action
['di] la bzhi/ las la brtags nas dgag / byed pa po la brtags nas dgag / bya ba yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag / bya ba la brtags nas dgag pa'o/ /

This section has four parts: the refutation through the examination of action, the refutation through the examination of the agent, the refutation of the argument for the existence of activity, and the refutation through the examination of activity.
dang po [las la brtags nas dgag pa]
1.1.1.1 Refutation through the examination of action
['di] la gnyis/ lam gsum la thun mong du bya ba dgag / bgom pa la bya ba bye brag tu dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of activity common to the three intervals and the refutation of the activity particular to that which is being gone over.
dang po [lam gsum la thun mong du bya ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of activity common to the three intervals
re zhig song la mi 'gro ste/ / ma song ba la'ang 'gro ba min/ / song dang ma song ma gtogs par/ / bgom pa shes par mi 'gyur ro/ /
1. Now, where one has gone one does not go. Where one has not yet gone one does not go. Apart from where one has gone and where one has not gone, That over which one goes cannot be conceived./1/

de la 'gro ba'i bya ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod na lam gsum gang rung gcig la yod dgos na de yang mi 'thad de/ / sngar song ba'i lam la mi 'gro ba ste 'gro ba'i bya ba med de 'gro ba'i bya ba ni da ltar ba yin la/ lam gyi rnam pa 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gags pa ni song ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / re zhig ni dgag pa'i rim pa ston pa'o/ / da dung ma song ba'i lam la'ang 'gro ba min te ma song ba ni 'gro ba'i bya ba ma skyes pa yin la 'gro ba'i bya ba ni da ltar ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ bgom pa la yang 'gro ba'i bya ba rang bzhin gyis med de 'gro ba pos sngar brgal ba'i yul song ba dang / da dung ma song brgal ba'i yul ma song ba gnyis ma gtogs par te de gnyis gang yang min pa bgom bzhin pa'i lam bden pa ba tshad mas shes par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ // ci ste 'gro bzhin pa'i rkang pas mnan pa'i phyogs de nyid bgom pa yin la/ de yang 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gags pa'i song ba dang bya ba ma skyes pa'i ma song ba min pas song dang ma song ma gtogs zhes pa ma grub bo snyam na/ rkang pa yang rdul phra rab 'dus pa la btags nas bzhag pa'i phyir mdun rgyab kyi cha du ma yod do/ de yi tshe rkang pa'i sor mo la gnas pa'i rdul gyi rgyab kyi phyogs ni de yi song ba'i khongs su gtogs la/ rting pa la gnas pa'i rdul gyi mdun phyogs ni de yi ma song ba'i khongs su gtogs shing rdul rnams las ma gtogs pa'i rkang pa yang med pas song ma song las ma gtogs pa'i bgom pa med do/ /

If the activity of going existed inherently, it would have to be there in any of the three intervals of the path, but this is not tenable. One does not go in the interval of the path over which one has previously gone; there is no activity of going there, because the activity of going is in the present. The aspect of the interval of the path that is the activity of going that has ceased is the gone. The “Now” in the first line indicates the temporal order of the refutations. Nor does one go in the interval of the path over which one has not yet gone, because in that which has not gone the activity of going has not yet arisen. The activity of going is in the present. Nor does the activity of going belong to that over which one goes essentially./2/This is because, having excluded both the place the goer has already traversed and that which he has yet to traverse, there is no further truly existent interval of a path that can be discerned authoritatively in which the process of going is occurring. [93] One might think that the place where the goer is putting his foot down is that which is being gone over, and that it is neither where the activity of going has ceased in the gone, nor is it where the activity will be which has not yet arisen in the not-yet-gone; therefore the claim that there is nothing apart from that over which one has gone and that over which one has not gone is not accurate. However, since the foot is also imputed on the basis of an assemblage of particles, it has many front and back parts. When the goer is putting his foot down, the rear of the particles in the toes are regarded as on the interval of the path over which he has gone. The front of the particles in the heel are regarded as on the interval of the path over which he has not yet gone. Apart from the particles, there is no foot. Therefore, apart from the gone over and the not-gone over, there is nothing that is being gone over./3/

tshig gsal las de bzhin du bshad pa la des gnyis ma yin phung gsum 'gog pa mi 'thad de 'thad na ni/ rkang pas rting pa nas bzung ste sor mo'i rtse mo'i bar gyi yul non pa yang mi srid par 'gyur te mdun rgyab kyi cha re res ni ma non la de dag las ma gtogs pa'i rkang pa yang med pa'i phyir ro/ / sor mo dang rting pa'i rgyab mdun gyi phyogs ni de gnyis kyi song ma song gi khongs su gtogs kyang / de gnyis kyis non pa'i yul de gnyis ma yin gyi phung gsum du 'dzin pa'i dogs pa mi chod pa rkang pa dang 'dra'o/ /

Suppose one argued as follows: While Prasannapadā explains it this way [31a-b], it is not tenable that the third alternative—that is, neither—is refuted by this explanation. If it were tenable, it would follow that it would be impossible for the foot to step on the place stretching from the heel to the toe, because it would not be stepped on by each part of the front and back; and apart from these parts there is no foot. Although where the front and back of the heel and toes, respectively are placed, are regarded as upon that over which he has gone and that over which he has not yet gone, respectively, this does not eliminate the suspicion that the place on which the toes and heels are stepping is the third alternative. This is like the example of the foot.

gzhan yang bgom bzhin pa'i lam med na ni lam da ltar ba med la de lta na bya ba zhig pa'i 'das pa dang bya ba ma skyes pa'i ma 'ongs pa'i lam yang med par 'gyur ro zhe na/ song ma song ni tshig gsal las bya ba zhig pa dang ma skyes pa la bshad la de gnyis gang yang min pa'i bgom pa'i lam med na ni ji skad bshad pa'i skyon du 'gyur yang / 'dir de gnyis gang yang min pa'i bgom pa'i lam med par mi smra yi/ bgom pa'i lam ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag nas de la 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gog go /

Moreover, if there were no interval of the path over which there is going, there would be no present interval of the path. In that case there would be neither past nor future intervals of the path—those in which activity has disintegrated or not yet arisen. However, according to Prasannapadā [31a], the gone over and the not-yet-gone over are explained to be the intervals of the path where activity which has disintegrated and that which has yet to arise occur, respectively. But to say that there is no interval of the path other than these two, over which there is going, would be erroneous, as has been charged. Here we do not say that there is no interval of the path other than these two over which there is going; rather, we refute the inherent existence of the interval of the path over which there is going, and thus we refute the activity of going in that interval.

de yang rkang pas non pa'i lam rkang pa'i sor mos non pa'i rgyab ni cha de yi 'gro ba'i bya ba zhig pa dang / rting pas non pa'i mdun ni cha de yi 'gro ba'i bya ba ma skyes pa yin pas de gnyis la ltos nas ni bar gyi lam de bya ba zhig pa dang ma skyes pa gang yang min pa'i phung gsum du med do/ /

[94] Since the part of the path on which the foot is put down—the part where the back of the toes is being put down—is where the disintegration of the activity of going occurs; and since where the front of the heel is being put down is where the activity of going has not yet arisen, the part of the path in between these would have to be defined in relation to these two, but apart from the disintegrated activity and the activity that has yet to arise, it does not exist as a third alternative.

cha de gnyis gang yang min pa'i rkang pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa zhig yod na/ cha la ltos nas bar gyi lam de gnyis ma yin du med kyang cha can rkang pa la ltos te gnyis ma yin gyi phung gsum du yod na'ang / cha de gnyis gang yang min pa'i rkang pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa med pas de la ltos nas lam de bgom bzhin par ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no/ / gal te bar gyi lam de mdun rgyab kyi cha gnyis la ltos nas phung gsum du med kyang / mdun rgyab kyi chas non pa de rang rang la ltos nas phung gsum mo snyam na/ 'grel pa las rkang pa'i mdun rgyab kyi cha la bshad pa bzhin du sor mo dang rting pa'i rdul la yang / shar nub kyi phyogs kyi cha dang 'brel ba'i sgo nas dpyad pa bya bar gsungs pas de dag la yang de bzhin du dpyad par bya'o/ /

If there were a foot that existed through its own characteristic apart from these two parts, then although the middle part of the path defined in relation to them is neither of these two, there would, in terms of the whole foot, be a third alternative that would be neither of these two. However, since there is not an inherently existent foot apart from these parts, the path on which going occurs, which depends on this, does not exist inherently either. One might think that although the middle part of the path, defined in relation to the front and back parts, is not a third alternative, there is a third alternative: the places where the front and back parts are being placed down, depending only on themselves. But according to the Commentary, just as the front and back parts of the foot are explained, so the particles of the heel and the toe should be examined in terms of the relation between their eastern and western parts [31b]. Therefore, they also should be so examined.

sngar bshad pa'i skye bzhin pa 'gog pa'i rigs pas kyang dgag ste/ 'di ltar skyes pa dang ma skyes pa gnyis mi skye yang myu gu skye bzhin pa skye'o zhes smra ba la yang phung gsum ldog mi ldog gi tshul ni snga ma dad 'dra la/ gzhan yang myu gu'i cha gang yang ma skyes na ni ma skyes pa nyid yin pas cha 'ga' zhig ni skyes la cha 'ga' zhig ma skyes pa skye bzhin par 'dod dgos so/ / de yi tshe phyed skyes phyed ma skyes su song la cha de gnyis las ma gtogs pa'i myu gu yang med pas skyes ma skyes gang yang min pa'i skye bzhin pa med do/ /

This can also be refuted through the argument presented earlier refuting the existence of that which is in the process of arising. There, with respect to the statement, “Although neither the arisen nor the non-arisen arises, the sprout in the process of arising arises,” the way of determining whether or not the third alternative is eliminated is similar to what we have just explained. Moreover, if any part of the sprout is not arisen, then since it would be simply non-arisen, one would have to assert that something, part of which is arisen and part of which is non-arisen, is arising. In that case, it would be half arisen, half non-arisen; and since apart from these two halves there is no sprout, apart from the arisen and the non-arisen, there is nothing in the process of arising.

de bzhin du rkang pa'i mdun rgyab kyi cha gnyis la ltos nas song ma song nyid yin la/ cha de gnyis gang yang min pa'i rkang pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis med pas phyed song phyed ma song gi bgom bzhin pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / rkang pa'i cha rnams rkang pa min la de dag las don gzhan na yang rkang pa med pas ni/ / rkang pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa 'gog nus kyi rkang pa 'gog mi nus pa ni bshad zin cing 'chad par yang 'gyur bas 'dir ma gsungs so/ //

Similarly that over which one has gone and not gone can be understood in terms of the front and the back parts of the foot. [95] Since there is no inherently existent foot apart from these two parts, there is no inherently existent process of going occurring partly in that over which one has gone and partly in that over which one has not gone. The parts of the foot are not the foot; but neither is the foot a separate object distinct from those. Thus the existence of the foot through its own characteristic is refuted, but the existence of the foot is not refuted. This has been explained before, and it will be explained later, so we will not discuss it any further here.

des na rigs pa des rkang pas mnan pa'i lam de cha can rkang pa la ltos nas phung gsum du ngo bos yod pa 'gog gi / song ma song dngos 'gal yin pas phung gsum 'gog pa min te/ 'grel pa nyid las 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gags pa dang ma skyes pa gnyis song ma song dang 'gro ba'i bya ba da ltar bas zin pa bgom par bshad pa'i phyir ro/ //

Thus, these arguments refute the inherent existence of the part of the foot that is being placed on the path as a third alternative with respect to the whole foot. But the third alternative with respect to the path is not refuted simply on the grounds that that over which one has gone and that over which one has not gone are mutually exclusive. This is because, as the Commentary itself says, the two activities—the activity of going that has ceased and that which has yet to arise—occur in that over which one has gone and that over which one has not gone, and the presently occurring activity of going is explained to be where one is going [31a].

'dir kha cig rkang pa'i cha rnams ni rkang pa min la de dag las don gzhan du yang rkang pa med pas rkang pa med pa dang cha re res ni rting pa nas sor mo'i bar gyis non pa'i lam de ma non la de dag las don gzhan du yang de gnon byed med pas lam de mnan pa mi srid ces smra zhing skabs gzhan du yang de kho na bzhin du smras nas dbu ma'i don bshad par rlom mod kyang rten 'byung dbu ma'i don du 'chad pa'i gol sa chen po la gnas pa'o/ /

Here, some say that the foot is not any of its parts. Nor is the foot anything other than them. Therefore there is no foot. No single part is placed on the whole stretch of path from that on which the heel is placed to that on which the toe is placed. And apart from them, there is nothing that could be placed upon it. Therefore it is not possible for the path to be trodden. In other contexts as well, they say similar things, and pretend to be explaining the meaning of Madhyamaka. However they are persisting in great errors regarding the proper explanation of dependent arising as the middle path./4/
gnyis pa [bgom pa la bya ba bye brag tu dgag pa]
1.1.1.1.2 Refutation of the activity particular to that which is being gone over
['di] la gnyis/ phyogs snga ma dgod pa dang / de 'gog pa'i rigs pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the presentation of the opponent’s position and the argument for its refutation.
dang po [phyogs snga ma dgod pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.1 Presentation of the opponent’s position
gang na g.yo ba de na 'gro / de yang gang phyir bgom pa la/ / g.yo ba song min ma song min/ / de phyir bgom la 'gro ba yod/ /

2. Where there is motion, there is going. Since there is motion in that which is being gone over, But neither where one has gone nor where one has not gone, It follows that going is in that which is being gone over.

khyed kyis song ma song la 'gro ba'i bya ba zhig pa dang ma skyes par bstan pa nyid kyis yul gang na rkang pa 'degs 'jog gi bya ba g.yo ba yod pa de na 'gro ba'i bya ba 'di 'byung ngo*/ / g.yo ba de yang 'gro ba po gang gi bgom pa la dmigs pa de na yod do/ / gang gi phyir g.yo ba ni song ba la yang yod pa min la ma song ba la yang yod pa min gyi bgom pa la yod cing g.yo ba yod pa'i yul de nyid na 'gro ba'i bya ba yod pa de yi phyir bgom pa la 'gro ba yod do zhes smra'o/ /

Some argue as follows: You have presented that over which one has gone and that over which one has not gone as where the activity of going has disintegrated and as where the activity of going has yet to arise, respectively. According to that, wherever there is motion—the activity of raising and setting down a foot occurs—there the activity of going occurs. Moreover, it is a fact that motion is perceived in the going of the goer. Because motion does not occur where one has gone, nor does it occur where one is yet to go, but it does occur where one is going, the activity of going takes place at the very place where the motion occurs. [96] Therefore, going is said to be where one is presently going.

'dir bgom pa zhes pa'i 'gro ba ni yul de bya bas zin par shes pa'i don yin la 'gro ba zhes pa phyi ma ni yul gzhan du phyin pa'i don no/ / gang gi zhes pa sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis 'gro ba po la bshad de zla ba'i dgongs par yang snang ngo / / legs ldan gyis de lta yin na de phyir zhes pa'i sgra'i zla bo med par 'gyur ba dang g.yo ba dang 'gro ba'i bya ba'i gzhi 'gom pa'i lam yin par nges pas gang gi bgom pa la zhes pa la yang byed pa po gzhi yin pa mi rigs pa dang / sngar song ba dang ma song ba la 'gro ba'i bya ba bkag pas 'gro ba po'i bya ba bgom pa la yod par grub zin pa'i phyir gang gi zhes pa 'gro ba po la 'chad pa mi rigs so zhes smra'o/ /

Here the word “going” refers to the interval of the path on which one is going to indicate that activity is occurring there. The later occurrence of the word “going” refers to going to a different location. According to Buddhapālita, the word “his (gang gi) [169a] refers to the goer,/5/ and Candrakīrti seems to agree/6/ [31b]. According to Bhāvaviveka, if that were so, the words “it follows that” would be without a mate/7/ [64b], and since it is certain that the basis of motion and the activity of going is the path over which something is presently going, and the phrase “his path” would refer to the goer as the basis, this would make no sense. The activity of going in the interval of the path over which one has gone and in that over which one is yet to go has been refuted earlier. Thereby, it has been established that the activity of the goer is where one is presently going. Therefore, referring to a person by using the word “his” would make no sense.

sangs rgyas bskyangs ni gang phyir dang gang tshe smos nas de phyir dang de tshe dngos su ma smos pa mang du byung zhing*/ 'gro bzhin pa 'gro ba po la yang yod la song ma song la 'gro ba'i bya ba sngar bkag kyang song ma song la 'gro ba'i rtsom pa slar yang 'gog pa mi zlos pa dang 'dra bar dgongs nas skyon de dag yod par mi sems so/ / 'dir de yang gang phyir bgom pa la zhes bsgyur ba ni mi dag pas 'gyur rnying ltar yin no/ /

Buddhapālita does not commit these errors. This is because he must have had the following considerations in mind: There are many places where the words “since” and “where” are used but “thus” and “there” are not explicitly used; the goer has the activity of going; this is similar to the fact that, although the occurrence of the activity of going in the interval that has been gone over and in that which is yet to be gone over has already been refuted, it would not be redundant to refute the effort involved in going in the intervals that have been gone over and which are yet to be gone over as well. Here the translation of the phrase “Since…in that which is being gone over” is not accurate, and so here the older version is followed./8/

'dir kha cig lam la spyir song ma song dang brgal ma brgal gnyis dngos 'gal yin pas/ de gnyis gang yang min pa'i bgom pa'i lam mi srid par gzhung snga mas bshad la/ gzhung 'dis song ma song dngos 'gal yin pa'i rgyu mtshan bstan par 'dod pa ni mi 'thad de/ phung gsum ldog pa'i song ma song la bya ba zhig pa dang ma skyes pa'i rtags mi 'grub pa'i phyir te/

Here some say that the previous verse explains in general that since the path over which one has gone and over which one has not yet gone—that which one has traversed and that which one has not traversed—are mutually exclusive, a path over which one is going distinct from these two is impossible; and that this verse presents the reason that that over which one has gone and that over which one has not yet gone are mutually exclusive. But this interpretation is not tenable. The premise—that they are the loci of action that has disintegrated and action that has not yet arisen, respectively—cannot be established on the basis of the fact that that over which one has gone and that over which one has yet to go preclude any third alternative.

tshig gsal las/ gal te ma song ba yin na ni ji ltar 'gro ba yin la 'on te 'gro na ni ji ltar ma song ba yin/ zhes 'gro na ma song ba min par bshad pas song bar khas blang dgos la de lta na bya ba zhig pas 'gro ba yin pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir 'gro ba pos yul brgal ba song ba dang ma brgal ba ma song bar bshad pas 'gro bzhin pa'i yul ni spyir brgal ma brgal gnyis las brgal ba yin te chu'i yul la brgal bzhin pa dang 'dra'o// des na lam la spyir rkang pas brgal ma brgal gnyis su kha tshon chod kyang / rang lugs kyis skabs 'di yi song ma song ni sngar bshad pa ltar yin pas lam la de gnyis su kha tshon mi chod do/ / des na song dang ma song ma gtogs zhes pa la yang de gnyis dngos 'gal yin pa rgyu mtshan du byed pa min la/ gzhung 'dis kyang dngos 'gal yin pa'i rgyu mtshan ston pa yang min no/

Prasannapadā says, If it is that over which one has not yet gone, how can there be going? And if there is going, how can it be that over which one has not yet gone? [31a] Since it explains that if there is going it cannot be that over which one has not yet gone, [97] it would have to be accepted that it is that over which one has gone. But in that case, since it is a disintegrated action, it would be contradictory for it to be going either. Therefore, since it has been explained that the place which has been traversed by the goer is that over which he has gone, and the place which has not been traversed is that over which he has not yet gone, generally, he would have to traverse the place where he is going and it can be neither of the two: neither that which has been traversed, nor that which has not been traversed, because this would be like traversing a body of water. Therefore, although in general there would only be two alternatives with respect to the path—one must either traverse or not traverse a path, according to our own system, in this context, that over which one has gone and that over which one has not yet gone are as they have been previously explained. Therefore, it is not necessary for the path to be confined to these two alternatives. Thus, the phrase “apart from that over which one has gone and that over which one has yet to go” is not regarded as providing an argument for these two being mutually exclusive. Nor does the present verse present an argument for their being mutually exclusive.
gnyis pa [de 'gog pa'i rigs pa]
1.1.1.1.2.2 The argument for its refutation
['di] la gnyis/las tshig dang bya tshig gcig don dang bcas na cig shos don gyis stong pa dang / gnyis ka don dang bcas na ha cang thal ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: if either the verb or the noun phrase is meaningful then the other is meaningless and if both verbs are meaningful there are further absurd consequences.
dang po [las tshig dang bya tshig gcig don dang bcas na cig shos don gyis stong pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.2.1 If either the noun phrase or the verb is meaningful then the other is meaningless
bgom pa 'gro ba yin par ni/ / ci lta bur na 'thad par 'gyur/ / gang tshe 'gro ba med pa yi/ / bgom pa 'thad pa med phyir ro/ /
3. How could it be tenable For going to be in that which is being gone over? When there is no going, it is not tenable To say that there is going there.

bgom pa la 'gro ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa yin par ni/ / ji lta bur na 'thad par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu mtshan ni gang gi tshe ste gang gi phyir na 'gro ba'i bya ba tshig gi don du med pa yi bgom pa ste 'gro bzhin pa'i tshig 'thad pa med pa na 'gro ba'i bya ba ni bgom pa'i tshig gi don du yod cing bya ba yang gcig las med pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gi don du 'gro ba med pa yang mi rigs pa de'i phyir ro/ / des na bgom pa la zhes pa tsam zhig srid kyi 'gro'o zhes pa ni mi 'thad do/ /

How could it be tenable that going that does not exist essentially is in that which is being gone over? It could not! The argument is as follows: If “when”—that is, because—the phrase “that which is being gone over” does not refer to the action that is the referent of the word “going.” That is, it is not tenable to use the word “going.” The phrase “that which is being gone over” already contains the meaning of “going.” But there is only one action, and it would make no sense to say that the word “going” does not refer to going. In that case it would be possible that there was merely a place that is being gone over, but that it would not be tenable to say that there is going.
gang gi bgom pa la 'gro ba/ / de yi gsum bgom la 'gro med par/ / thal bar 'gyur te gang gi phyir/ / bgom la 'gro ba yin phyir ro/ /
4. For whomever there is going where one goes, The absurd consequence would follow that There could be a path over which one is going without going; But wherever one goes there is going.

ci ste 'gro zhes pa de tsam dang 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis 'brel bar 'dod na rgol ba gang gi ltar na bgom pa'i tshig gi don du 'gro ba'i bya ba med pa la 'gro ba'i bya ba rten par 'dod pa de yi phyogs la bgom pa'i tshig gi don la ste don du 'gro ba'i bya ba med par thal bar 'gyur te/ gang gi phyir te 'di ltar bya ba ni gcig sa med la de yang bgom pa la 'gro ba zhes pa'i tshig phyi ma'i don du yod pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di la dper na shing mkhan gyis shing bzo byed do zhes pa la shing bzo pa'i bya ba gcig las med kyang shing bzo ba de shing mkhan zhes pa'i don yang yin la shing bzo'o zhes pa'i don yang yin pa bzhin du/ bgom pa la 'gro zhes pa yang de ltar 'dod pas bya tshig dang las tshig gang rung gcig don dang bcas na cig shos don gyis stong par ji ltar 'gyur snyam na/

Suppose one said that the term “going” refers only to the action of going. For any opponent according to whom the phrase “that which is being gone over” does not refer to an action of going, the meaning of “going” still depends on the meaning of that phrase. Such a position would be committed to the absurd consequence that the phrase “that which is being gone over” would not refer to the action of going. This is because [98] there is only one action and “that which is being gone over” must refer to the action indicated by the other, the word “going.” Now, suppose one argued as follows: Consider the following example. When we say that a woodcarver works with wood, there is only one action of working with wood. Nonetheless, even though working with wood is referred to by the word “woodcarver,” it is also referred to by the phrase “working with wood.” It is maintained that it is similar with respect to “going” and “that which is being gone over.” So, how could it be the case that if either the noun phrase or the verb is meaningful, the other is meaningless?

bya byed tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam du 'dod pa la de ltar bzhag pas chog kyang / 'gro ba'i bya ba lta bu rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par 'dod na de mi rung ngo / / 'di ltar spyir rkang pa g.yo ba'i bya ba gcig 'gro bzhin pa'i lam dang gang zag gnyis ka la brten pas bya ba de bgom pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis ka'i don du yang 'gyur bas de dang bya ba gcig las med pa mi 'gal yang / lam dang 'gro ba po rang mtshan gyis so sor grub pa'i don la chos gcig thun mong du brten pa 'gal te/ gang dag rang mtshan nyid kyis so so ba/ / de dag rgyud gcig gtogs par rigs ma yin/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar ro/ / des na rkang pa g.yo ba'i bya ba de 'gro bzhin pa'i lam zhes pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis ka'i don du yod pa dang / 'gro ba'i bya ba gcig las med pa gnyis 'gal bas tshig gcig don dang bcas na cig shos don gyis stong par gsungs so//

If one maintains that agent and action are merely posited through the force of nominal convention, this all fits together. But if one maintains that the action of going exists through its own characteristic, this is impossible. Just as in general, a single action of moving the foot depends on both the person and the path over which he is going, we say “that action is the referent of both ‘going’ and of ‘that which is being gone over.’” Therefore, there is no inconsistency between saying that and there being only one action. However, with respect to a path and goer which existed distinctly through their own characteristics, it would be inconsistent for these two things to depend in common on a single entity, because, as it is said, It makes no sense for any things that are distinct through their own characteristics To belong to the same continuum. [Madhyamakāvatāra, VI:61 cd] Thus the action of moving the foot is the referent of both the phrases “that which is being gone over” and “going.” Therefore, since it would contradictory for the action of going to be the referent of both terms and there to be only a single action of going, it is said that if either term was meaningful, the other would be meaningless.
gnyis pa ni/
1.1.1.1.2.2.2 If both are meaningful there are further absurd consequences
ci ste bgom pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis ka'i don du yang 'gro ba'i bya ba yod do zhe na/
Suppose someone said that the action of going is the referent of both phrases “where one goes” and “going.”
bgom la 'gro ba yod na ni/ / 'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur te/ / gang gis de bgom gyur pa dang / / de la 'gro ba gang yin pa'o/ /
5. If going were where one goes, There would be a twofold going: One by he who goes there, And one in the going that is there.

bgom pa la zhes pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis ka'i don du 'gro ba'i bya ba yod na ni 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis su thal bar 'gyur te/ 'gro ba'i bya ba gang gis lam de bgom pa zhes pa'i tha snyad rnyed par 'gyur ba gcig dang gang zag gang gis lam de la 'gro ba gang yin pa 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis pa'o/ /

If the action of going were the referent of both the phrases “where one goes” and “going,” the absurd consequence would follow that there would be a twofold action of going, because the first one would be the action of going in virtue of which that interval of the path is called “where one goes,” [99] and the second action of going would be that in virtue of which the person goes in that interval of the path.
'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur na/ / 'gro shes rab ba po yang gnyis su 'gyur/ / gang phyir 'gro ba med par ni/ / 'gro ba 'thad par mi 'gyur phyir/ /
6. Since it would follow that there would be a twofold going, The goer would be twofold. For without a goer, It is not tenable that anything goes.

'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis yod mod skyon ci yod ce na/ 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis su thal bar 'gyur na 'gro ba po'i gang zag kyang gnyis su 'gyur ba'i skyon 'di yod do/ // de yi rgyu mtshan ni gang gi phyir rten 'gro ba po med par ni brten pa 'gro ba'i bya ba 'thad par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ bya ba ni las sam byed pa po yang rung ste rang gi sgrub par byed pa la ltos pa yin la 'gro ba'i bya ba 'di yang byed pa po la gnas pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis yod pas 'gro ba po gnyis su 'gyur lugs ni/ lhas byin gyis rkang pa g.yas pa 'jog pa'i tshe lam dang byed pa po la brten pa'i rkang pa 'jog pa'i bya ba gnyis dus mnyam du yod dgos te rgyu mtshan ni sngar bshad pa ltar ro/ / de yi tshe rkang pa g.yas pa yang gnyis yod dgos la g.yon pa 'degs pa la yang de dang 'dra'o/ // de ltar na rkang gnyis pa'i lhas byin gcig 'gro ba na yang lhas byin gnyis yod par 'gyur na de med pas bya ba yang gnyis med do/ / de'i phyir bgom pa la 'gro ba'i bya ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes smra ba 'thad pa ma yin no/ ci ste lhas byin gcig 'dug bzhin du smra ba dang lta bar yang byed pa de yi tshe/ byed pa po gcig bya ba du ma dang ldan par mthong ba bzhin du 'gro ba po gcig la 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis yod pa mi 'gal lo snyam na/

There would be two actions of going, but what is the problem? If the consequence of a twofold action followed, the problem would be that it would also follow that there would be a twofold person as the goer. The reason for this is that without the goer as a basis, it would not be tenable for there to be the action of going, which must be based upon it. This is because the action depends upon that which accomplishes it, either object or agent. This action of going is associated with the agent. Here, the reason that a twofold agent follows from there being two actions of going is as follows: When Lhejin puts his right foot down, there would have to be two simultaneous actions of putting the foot down, one depending on the agent, and one depending on the path, for the reasons explained earlier. In that case, he would have to have two right feet, and we could say the same about lifting his left foot! And if so, when one Lhejin with two feet goes, there would have to be two Lhejins! Since that is not the case, there are not two actions. Therefore it is not tenable to say that there is inherently existent going where one goes. Suppose someone thought as follows: When a single Lhejin speaks and sees while sitting, we see a single agent performing many actions. So it is not contradictory for a single goer to have two actions of going.

'di'i lan du tshig gsal las/ ma yin te gang gi phyir nus pa byed pa po yin gyi rdzas ni ma yin la/ bya ba tha dad pas de'i sgrub byed nus pa yang tha dad par grub pa yin te 'dug pa'i bya bas smra ba por 'gyur ba ni ma yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de yi don ni 'di dang snga ma gnyis mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan snga ma'i bya ba de la rdzas sam gang zag byed pa po yin pas/ rkang pa g.yas pa 'jog pa'i bya ba gnyis dus gcig tu yod na rkang gnyis pa'i gang zag gcig gis de mi nus pas gang zag gnyis dgos la/ phyi ma'i smra ba la sogs pa'i bya ba so so dus mnyam pa rnams la ni lce la sogs pa'i nus pa byed pa po yin pas/ nus pa'i byed pa po mang po dus gcig tu yod kyang gang zag dus gcig tu mang po mi dgos so/ / gal te de lta yin kyang rdzas sam gang zag gcig yin pas byed pa po gcig la bya ba du ma byung ba yin snyam na/ smra ba la sogs pa'i bya ba du ma byung ba bzhin du de'i nus pa'i byed pa po yang du ma yod pas de'i dbang du byas pa'i byed pa po gcig la bya ba du ma byung ba ma yin la/ rdzas sam gang zag gi byed pa po gcig la bya ba du ma byung yang 'dir gang zag byed pa po min pas de la ltos nas byed pa po gcig la bya ba du ma byung ba min no/ / gzhan yang dus gcig tu rkang pa g.yas pa gnyis 'jog pa lta bu'i bya ba 'dra ba gnyis kyi byed pa po yang ma mthong bas 'gro ba po gcig la 'gro ba gnyis med do zhes kyang gsungs so/ / TIka byed kha cig snga ma lngar na 'gro ba po'i gang zag gi rdzas gcig la 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis dgag mi nus pas phyi ma ltar legs zhes smra ba ni/ 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis kyis 'gro ba po gnyis su 'gyur lugs dang rdzas byed pa po min la nus pa yin pa'i tshul rnams ma go bzhin du shing rta chen po la dgag pa smra ba yin no/ / de ltar na re zhig song la zhes sogs kyis gang du 'gro sa'i lam la 'gro ba'i bya ba yod pa bkag go /

In response to this, Prasannapadā says: It is not like that, because while the capacity is the agent, the substance is not. Because there are different actions, there are different capacities relevant to accomplishing them. That is, in virtue of performing the action of sitting, one does not become a speaker. [32b] This means that the reason that this and the previous case are not similar is that the previous action had either a substance [100] or a person as its agent. Two simultaneous actions of putting down the right foot are impossible for one person with two feet; therefore, in such a case there would have to be two persons. In the latter case, the capacities of such things as the tongue are the agents for each of the distinct simultaneous actions such as speaking. Therefore, although there are many capacities as agents at the same time, there is no need to have many persons at the same time. Suppose one replied that even though this is the case, since the substance or person is identical, these many actions are performed by one agent. We reply that just as many actions are performed, such as speaking, there are many capacities as agents. Therefore, from this perspective, it is not the case that there are many actions performed by a single agent. Although a single substance or person as an agent may perform many actions, here this person is not the agent. Therefore, just on that ground it does not follow that a single agent performs many actions. Moreover, it is also explained that since it never happens that a single agent performs an action twice, such as placing the right foot down twice simultaneously, a single goer does not go twice. According to some other commentator/9/ since on the previous interpretation it is not possible to refute a single substantial person performing two actions of going, the latter interpretation is preferable. But such a claim is made without understanding why, if one accepts two actions of going, one would have to accept two goers, or why the substance is not the agent but the capacities are. So they disagree with the position of the great charioteers. Thus, “Where one has gone…” [II: 1] refutes the existence of any action of going on the path that is the locus of going.
gnyis pa [byed pa po la brtags nas dgag]
1.1.1.2 Refutation through the examination of the agent
['di] la gsum/ 'gro ba po 'gro ba'i rten du yod pa dgag / rnam grangs gsum gyi gang zag la 'gro ba spyir dgag / 'gro ba po la 'gro ba bye brag tu dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the goer existing as the basis of going, the general refutation of going in terms of the three kinds of person, and particular refutations of the goer going.
dang po ['gro ba po 'gro ba'i rten du yod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of the goer existing as the basis of going

gal te gang du 'gro sa'i lam la 'gro ba'i bya ba mi 'thad kyang lhas byin 'gro'o zhes brjod pa las na 'gro ba po lhas byin la 'gro ba'i bya ba dmigs so/ // de'i phyir 'gro ba ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod de rten 'gro ba po yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: [101] Although it is not tenable that the action of going is in the path over which one goes, since one says, “Lhejin goes,” the action of going must be observed in Lhejin. Therefore, going exists inherently, because its basis, the goer, exists.
gal te 'gro po med gyur na/ / 'gro ba 'thad par mi 'gyur te/ / 'gro ba med na 'gro ba po/ / yod pa nyid du ga la 'gyur/ /
7. If without a goer, It is not tenable that there is going, Then if there were no going, How could there be a goer?

gal te 'gro ba po med par gyur na ste bsal na 'gro ba yod pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te de ni sngar gang phyir 'gro ba po med par ni/ zhes par bshad zin to/ / de ltar yin na gang 'gro ba po la brten pa'i 'gro ba de gang yin/ smras pa 'gro ba po la 'jug pa'i bya ba 'gro ba po las don gzhan du yod de zhes ni mi smra'i 'gro ba gang dang ldan pas 'gro ba por bslad pa'i 'gro de yod de zhes smra'o/ / dpyad pa'i tshe 'gro ba po las don gzhan du gyur pa'i 'gro ba med na 'gro ba'i bya ba rang mtshan pa dang ldan pas 'gro ba po yod pa nyid du ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / 'dis mi 'gro ba'i bya ba rang gi ngo bos yod na 'gro ba po las ngo bos tha dad du rnyed dgos na/ / de lta na 'gro ba po la ltos pa dgag nus pas 'gro ba po med pa'i 'gro bar 'gyur na de sngar bkag pa'i phyir de'i rten 'gro ba po med de brten pa 'gro ba med pa'i phyir zhes 'gro ba po bya ba'i rten yin pa bkag go /

If there were no goer—that is, if it were eliminated—it would not be tenable that there is going, for the reasons previously explained in the context of “For without a goer…” [6c]. In that case, what is that going based on a goer? The answer is as follows: It is not said with respect to the goer that the action in which the goer engages is a different entity from the goer; rather, it is said that that going exists in virtue of being that which makes the goer so-called. Since on analysis, the going does not exist as a different entity from the goer, how could there be a goer having an action of going with its own characteristic? There could not be! The refutation goes as follows: If the action of going existed inherently, one would have to be able to find it as a different entity from the goer. In that case, one could refute its dependence on the goer. Then there could be going without a goer. Since that has been refuted earlier, because there is no going based upon it, there is no goer as a basis. Thus the goer is refuted as the basis of action.
gnyis pa [rnam grangs gsum gyi gang zag la 'gro ba spyir dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2 General refutation of going in terms of the three kinds of person

gal te 'gro ba ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod de de'i sgo nas de dang ldan pa'i gang zag 'gro'o zhes brjod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba med na de dang ldan pa'i lhas byin la 'gro'o zhes mi brjod de/ 'khar ba med na 'khar ba can du mi brjod pa bzhin no zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Going exists inherently, because in virtue of that it can be said that the person who has this property goes. If there were no going, it could not be said that in virtue of having that property, Lhejin goes, just as if there were no stick, one could not say that someone has a stick./10/
re zhig 'gro po mi 'gro ste/ / 'gro ba po min 'gro ba min/ / 'gro po 'gro po min las gzhan/ / gsum pa gang zhig 'gro par 'gyur/ /
8. Now, inasmuch as a goer does not go, And a non-goer does not go, Apart from a goer and a non-goer What third thing could go?

'gro'o zhes pa'i don de rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni rnam pa gsum las mi 'da' la de yang 'gro ba po yin pa ni mi 'gro ste de ni 'chad par 'gyur ro/ / re zhig ni sngon la 'gro ba po bkag nas de nas gzhan 'gog pa'i rim pa ston pa'o/ / 'gro ba po min pa yang 'gro ba min te de ni 'gro ba'i bya ba dang bral ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba po las gzhan dang 'gro ba po min pa las kyang gzhan pa'i gsum pa gang zhig 'gro bar 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te de mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the referent of the word “going” existed inherently, you cannot escape three alternatives. That which is a goer does not go, as will be explained. “Now” shows that after first refuting the goer going, the others are refuted in order. The non-goer also does not go because he is devoid of the action of going. [102] What third alternative—that which is neither a goer nor a non-goer—could go? None could, because such a thing is impossible.
gsum pa ['gro ba po la 'gro ba bye brag tu dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.3 Particular refutations of the goer going
gal te 'gro ba po min pa dang yin min las gzhan pa mi 'gro yang 'gro ba po 'gro'o snyam na/
One might think that even though neither that which is not a goer, nor that which is neither a goer nor not a goer goes, a goer still goes.
gang tshe 'gro ba med par ni/ / 'gro ba 'thad par mi 'gyur na/ / re shig 'gro po 'gro'o zhes/ / ji ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
9. Now, when without going, It is untenable to call something a goer, How could it be tenable To say that a goer goes?

gang gi tshe lhas byin gcig 'gro ba na 'gro ba'i bya ba la ni gcig las med la de yang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gi don du yod cing 'gro ba'i bya ba tshig gi don du med par ni 'gro ba po zhes pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ba de yi tshe re zhig 'gro ba po 'gro'o zhes pa'i don rang gi ngo bos yod pa ji ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / de ni byed tshig don dang bcas na byed pa po'i tshig don gyis stong pa'o/ / ci ste 'gro ba po'i tshig gi don du 'gro ba'i bya ba yod do zhe na/

When a single Lhejin goes, there is only a single action of going, and that is the referent of the word “goes.” Without the action of going as the referent of that term, it would be untenable to call him a goer. In that case, how could it be tenable that the referent of the phrase “the goer goes” exists inherently? It could not be! Then if the verb phrase is meaningful, the subject phrase is meaningless. Now suppose one said that the phrase “the goer” refers to the action of going.
gang gi phyogs la 'gro ba po/ / 'gro ba de la 'gro med pa'i / / 'gro po yin par thal 'gyur te/ / 'gro po 'gro bar 'dod phyir ro/ /
10. For him according to whose position a goer goes, The absurd consequence would follow that There could be a goer who does not go; Because it is maintained that that a goer goes.

rgol ba gang gi phyogs la 'gro ba po'i tshig gi don du 'gro ba'i bya ba yod pa de la/ 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gi don du 'gro ba'i bya ba med pa'i 'gro ba po 'gro ba yin par thal bar 'gyur te/ 'gro ba'i bya ba ni gcig las med la de yang 'gro ba po'i tshig gi don du yod pa'i sgo nas 'gro ba po 'gro bar 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / de ni byed pa po'i tshig don dang bcas na byed tshig don gyis stong pa'o/ / 'di yang 'gro ba'i bya ba gcig las med cing bya ba de rang mtshan gyis grub na tshig gcig don dang bcas na cig shos don gyis stong par sngar bshad pa bzhin no/ / ci ste 'gro ba po zhes pa dang 'gro'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis ka'i don du 'gro ba'i bya ba yod par 'dod do zhe na/

For that opponent whose position is that the referent of the phrase “the goer” is the action of going, the absurd consequence follows that the referent of the word “goes” is not the action of going, and so the goer would be the going. This is because there is only a single action of going, and in virtue of that being the referent of the phrase “the goer” it is asserted that the goer itself is the going. This shows that if the subject phrase is meaningful, the verb phrase would be meaningless. Here also, as there is only a single action of going, if it existed through its own characteristic, and if it were the referent of one word, the other would have no referent, as was previously explained. Now, suppose one said that both the phrases “the goer” and “goes” refer to the action of going.
gal te 'gro po 'gro 'gyur na/ / 'gro ba gnyis su thal 'gyur te/ / gang gi 'gro por mngon pa dang / / 'gro por gyur nas gang 'gro ba'o/ /
11. If a goer were going, There would be the absurd consequence of a twofold going: One in virtue of which he is manifest as a goer, And one in virtue of which, having become a goer, he goes.

gal te 'gro ba po 'gro'o zhes pa'i ngag 'di gnyis ka'i don du 'gro ba'i bya ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod par gyur na ni/ rkang pa'i 'degs 'jog gi 'gro ba'i bya ba rigs mthun gnyis gnyis dus re re yod par thal bar 'gyur te/ 'gro ba'i bya ba gang gis 'gro ba por mngon pa ste brjod pa'i 'gro ba de dang / 'gro ba por gyur nas 'gro ba'i bya ba gang zhig byed pa'i 'gro ba gnyis por 'gyur ro/ / de 'dod na 'gro ba po yang gnyis su 'gyur ba snga ma bzhin brjod par bya'o/ /

If the inherently existent action of going were the referent of both of the phrases in the sentence “the goer goes,” the absurd consequence would follow that in each moment there would be two sets of actions of going, each comprising picking up and putting down the foot, because there would be two goings: the going of the goer which is manifest as—that is, called—a goer in virtue of the action of going, [103] and the going which is the action that the goer—having become a goer—performs. And if one maintained that, the goer would have to be twofold as was explained earlier.

gal te de lta na'ang lhas byin 'gro'o zhes pa'i tha snyad yod pas 'gro ba yod do zhe na/ tha snyad yod pa la yang 'gro ba po yin min gang la yod brtags na mi 'thad par dpyad zin pas de ni gyi na'o/ / re zhig ces sogs de rnams kyis ni 'di 'gro zhes pa'i gang 'gro ba'i 'gro mkhan ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag go /

Now, suppose one said that although this is the case, since we say conventionally that Lhejin goes, there is going. Although there is such a convention, when one analyzes to determine whether or not he is a goer, and in what context, we have already shown that neither is tenable. Therefore, this would be pointless. Thus, the verses “Now, when without going…” [II:9] refute the inherent existence of the goer who goes referred to by the phrase “he goes.”
gsum pa [bya ba yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag]
1.1.1.3 Refutation of the argument for the existence of activity
['di] la lnga/ dang po'i rtsom pa yod pa dgag / 'gro sa'i lam yod pa dgag / 'gro ba'i gnyen po yod pa dgag / tha ma'i ldog pa yod pa dgag / gnas pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /

This section has five parts: the refutation of initial beginning, the refutation of the path on which one goes, the refutation of the opposite of going, the refutation of stopping at the end of going, and the refutation of the argument for staying.
dang po [dang po'i rtsom pa yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.3.1 Refutation of initial beginning
'gro ba ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod de lhas byin sdod pa btang nas 'gro ba rtsom pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one said that going exists inherently because Lhejin begins to go having giving up sitting.
song la 'gro ba'i rtsom med de/ / ma song ba la'ang 'go rtsom med/ / bgom la rtsom pa yod min na/ / gang du 'gro ba rtsom par byed/ /

de yod na'ang yong sa gsum las mi 'da' bas 'gro ba mthar phyin pa'i song ba la 'gro ba'i rtsom pa med de de la 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gags pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba'i bya ba ma son pa'i ma song ba la'ang 'gro ba'i rtsom pa med de ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar ba gnyis 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba'i bya ba dang ldan pa'i bgom pa la yang 'gro ba'i rtsom pa yod par min te 'das ma 'ongs kyi song ma song ma yin pa'i bgom pa ngo bo nyid kyis med pa'i phyir dang / de la 'gro ba'i bya ba yod na bya ba de gnyis su 'gyur ba'i phyir dang de lta na 'gro ba po gnyis su 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de lta yin na thams cad du 'gro ba'i rtsom pa ma gzigs nas gang du 'gro ba rtsom par byed ces gsungs so/ / de dag ni lam yod du chug kyang 'gro rtsom mi 'thad pa'i rigs pa'o/ // da ni 'gro ba rtsom pa'i lam nyid dgag par bya ste/

Even though that is the case, since there are only three possible ways it could exist, there is no beginning of going for one who has finished going—that is, where he has already gone—because his action of going has ceased. Nor is there any beginning of going where one has not yet gone—that is, for one who has not yet performed the action of going—because the future and the present are mutually exclusive. Nor is there a beginning of going in that which is being gone over—that is, for one who is performing the action of going—because apart from where one has gone and where one has not yet gone, which are, respectively, the past and the future, there is no inherently existent place where one goes. Not only that, but if there were an action of going, since this action would have to be twofold, the goer would have to be twofold. Since this is the case, and since the beginning of going is never found, it says, “Where then does going begin?” These are the arguments that demonstrate the untenability of the beginning of going even though the path is taken to exist. Now, the path where the beginning of going occurs is to be refuted.
'gro ba rtsom pa'i snga rol na/ gang du 'gro ba rtsom 'gyur ba'i/ / bgom pa med cing song ba med/ / ma song 'gro ba ga la yod/ /
13. Prior to the beginning of going, There is a beginning of going neither Where one is going nor where one has gone. How could there be going where one has not yet gone?

'gro ba'i bya ba rtsom pa'i snga rol lhas byin bsdad pa'i skabs na gang du 'gro ba rtsom par 'gyur ba bgom pa'i lam med cing song ba yang med pa'i phyir de gnyis la 'gro ba'i rtsom pa med do/ / gal te de yi tshe de gnyis med kyang ma song ba yod la der 'gro ba rtsom mo zhe na/ ma song ba ni 'gro ba'i bya ba ma brtsams pa yin na de la 'gro ba'i rtsom pa ga la yod de med do/ /

Prior to the beginning of the action of going [104], Lhejin, having been sitting, begins going neither on the path where he is going nor where he has gone, because there is no beginning of going in these two. Suppose one said that although at that time these two do not exist, he will begin to go in that over which he has yet to go. But since that over which he has yet to go is where he has not begun the action of going, how could there be the beginning of action there? There could not!
gnyis pa ['gro sa'i lam yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.3.2 Refutation of the path on which one goes
gal te lam gsum la 'gro ba'i rtsom pa med mod kyang lam gsum ni yod la 'gro ba med na 'di rnams mi rung ngo zhe na/

Now suppose one said that although there is no beginning of going in any of the three intervals of the path, there are three intervals of the path. It would not be possible for them to exist without any going.
'gro rtsom rnam pa thams cad du/ bzhi snang ba med pa nyid yin na/ / song ba ci zhig bgom pa ni/ / ma song ci zhig rnam par brtag /
14. Since the beginning of going Cannot be perceived in any way, What over which one has gone, what over which one is going, And what over which one has yet to go, can be conceived?

'gro ba'i rtsom pa yod na ni gang du 'gro ba'i bya ba 'gags pa de song ba dang / gang du da ltar bar gyur pa ni bgom pa dang gang du ma skyes pa de ni ma song ba yin no zhes bya bar brtag na/ gang gi tshe rnam pa thams cad kyis brtags pa na 'gro ba'i rtsom pa rnam pa thams cad du snang ba ste dmigs pa med pa nyid yin pa de'i tshe na/ song ba ni ci zhig bgom pa yang ci zhig ma song ba yang ci zhig rnam par brtag par bya ste mi 'grub pas phyin ci log tu dus gsum rtog par ci ste byed des na de brjod pa'i rgyu 'gro ba yang rang bzhin gyis med do/ /

If there were a beginning of going, then it could be conceived that the beginning of going is where the action of going has ceased—that is, in what one has gone over or in that where it is currently occurring—that is, in that over which one is going, or in that where it has not yet arisen—that is, that over which one has yet to go. However, upon thorough analysis, it cannot be perceived in any way—that is, it cannot be seen. Therefore, one should inquire analytically into what that which has been gone over, that over which one is going, and that over which one is yet to go each are. Since they do not exist in any way, why erroneously conceive of the three temporal periods? Therefore, the ground for positing them—that is going—does not exist essentially.
gsum pa ['gro ba'i gnyen po yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.3.3 Refutation of the opposite of going
gal te gang la gnyen po yod pa ni yod de snang mun dang pha rol tshu rol dang the tshom dang nges pa bzhin no/ / 'gro ba la yang gnyen po gnas pa yod pas yod do zhe na/

Now, suppose one argued as follows: Whatever thing whose opposite exists, exists as well, such as light and dark, here and there, doubt and certainty. Since staying—the opposite of going—exists, going exists as well.
re shig 'gro po mi sdod de/ / 'gro ba po min sdod pa min/ / 'gro po 'gro po min las gzhan/ / gsum pa gang zhig sdod par 'gyur/ /
15. The goer does not stand. The non-goer does not stand. Apart from the goer and the non-goer, What third thing stands?

gnas pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na 'gro ba yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'gyur ba zhig de ni med do/ / 'di ltar de yod na rnam pa gsum las mi 'da' la de yang re zhig 'gro ba po mi sdod de de ni 'chad par 'gyur ro/ // 'gro ba po min pa yang sdod pa min te lhas byin 'gro ba po min pa ni sdod pa yin na de la sdod pa gzhan gyis ci zhig bya/ 'di yang bya ba rang mtshan gyis grub na sdod pa por grub zin nas slar yang sdod par 'gyur dgos pa'i skyon no/ / 'gro ba po dang 'gro ba po min pa las don gzhan gsum pa gang zhig sdod par 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te de ni mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te 'gro ba po min pa dang yin min las gzhan pa mi sdod kyang 'gro ba po nyid sdod do zhe na/

If staying existed inherently, going would exist inherently as well. But it does not. If it existed, it would have to exist in one of three ways. The goer does not stand, as will be explained later. Nor does a non-goer stand, because if Lhejin, who is a non-goer, were to stand, then what would the point be in another standing? If that activity existed through its own characteristic, then the error would ensue that having achieved the status of being a stander, one would have to stand once again. [105] “Apart from the goer and the non-goer, what third thing stands?” There is none, because such a thing is impossible. Now, suppose one said that although neither a non-goer nor something different from the goer and non-goer stands, the goer himself stands.
gang tshe 'gro ba med par ni/ / 'gro po shes rab 'thad par mi 'gyur na/ / re shig 'gro po sdod do zhes/ / ci ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
16. When without going It is not tenable that something is a goer, How could it be tenable That a goer stands?

re zhig 'gro ba po sdod do zhes smra ba ji ltar 'thad pa nyid du 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te/ gang tshe ste gang gi phyir 'gro ba'i bya ba tshig gi don du med par ni 'gro ba po zhes pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ba de'i phyir ro/ / des na 'di sdod do zhes brjod pa'i tshe de la gnas pa dang 'gal ba'i 'gro ba med do/ /

How could it be tenable to say that a goer stands? It could not, because when—that is, since—without the activity of going as the referent of a word, it is not tenable to call something a goer, and to say that something stands is to say that it does not have the activity of going, which is the opposite of standing.
bzhi pa [tha ma'i ldog pa yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.3.4 Refutation of stopping at the end of going
'gro ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod de 'gro ba las ldog pa yod pa'i phyir te 'gro ba las ldog pa na gnas pa rtsom pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one argued as follows: Going exists inherently because there is halting from going, since when one halts from going, one begins staying.
bgom las ldog par mi 'gyur te/ / song dang ma song las kyang min/ /
17. One does not halt/11/ where one is going; Nor where one has gone; nor where one has not yet gone.

ldog pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni ldog sa gsum las mi 'da' la de yang bgom pa las ldog par mi 'gyur te/ bgom pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dmigs pa'i phyir dang bgom pa tsam du yod du chug kyang de la sngar ltar bya ba mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / song ba'i lam las ni 'gro ba ldog pa min te der yang 'gro ba'i bya ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / ma song ba'i lam las kyang ldog pa min te der yang 'gro ba'i bya ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / de yi phyir 'gro ba ldog pa ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / lam gzhan gnyis la 'gro ba'i bya ba ldog pa tha snyad du yang med la bgom pa la ni don dam par med do/ //

If halting existed inherently, there would be only three alternatives with respect to its site. One does not halt where one is going, because since where one is going is not seen to exist essentially and when the mere place where one is going exists, as it has been explained earlier, action is not tenable. One does not halt from going in the path over which one has already gone because there is no action of going there. Nor does one halt in the path over which one has not yet gone because there is no action of going there either. Therefore, halting from going does not exist inherently. While halting from going in the other two intervals of the path does not even exist conventionally, halting from going where one is going does not exist ultimately.
lnga pa [gnas pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.3.5 Refutation of the argument for staying

gal te 'gro ba'i 'gran zla gnas pa med pas 'gro ba med na 'o na 'gro ba grub par bya ba'i phyir te gnas pa bsgrub par bya ste de grub pas 'gro ba grub pa yin no/ / de'i phyir gnas pa ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod de de'i 'gran zla yod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gran zla yang 'gro ba yin no zhe na/

Now suppose one argued as follows: Since without staying—the opposite of going—there is no going, in order to establish going, staying must be established. This is because by establishing the latter we can establish the former. Therefore, staying exists inherently because its opposite exists, and the opposite is going.
'gro ba dang ni 'jug pa dang*/ / ldog pa yang ni 'gro dang mtshungs/ /
17cd. Going and starting And halting are similar.
