gnas pa sgrub pa'i phyir du bkod pa'i 'gro ba ni 'gro ba bsgrub pa'i phyir du bkod pa'i gnas pa la/ re zhig 'gro ba po mi sdod de/ / zhes pa la sogs pas sun 'byin brjod pa dang mtshungs par re zhig gnas po mi 'gro ste/ /zhes sogs kyis tshigs bcad gnyis 'don pa bsgyur te sun dbyung ngo*/ / ci ste 'gro ba btang nas gnas pa rtsom la de yod pa'i phyir gnas pa yod do zhe na/ gnas pa'i 'jug pa ste rtsom pa yang ni 'gro ba'i rtsom pa 'gog pa la/ song la 'gro ba'i rtsom med de/ / zhes sogs kyis sun 'byin brjod pa dang mtshungs par/ gnas la gnas pa'i rtsom med de/ /zhes sogs kyis tshigs bcad gsum 'don pa bsgyur te sun dbyung ngo / / ci ste lhas byin gnas par gyur nas gnas pa las log pa na 'gro ba rtsom pas gnas pa las ldog pa yod pa'i phyir gnas pa yod do snyam na/ gnas pa las ldog pa yang ni 'gro ba las ldog pa 'gog pa la/ bgom las ldog par mi 'gyur te/ / zhes sogs kyis sun 'byin brjod pa dang mtshungs par/ gnas bzhin pa las mi ldog ste/ / zhes sogs kyis rkang pa gnyis 'don pa bsgyur te sun dbyung ngo / / de yi phyir gnas pa ngo bo nyid kyis med pas 'gro ba 'grub par ga la 'gyur/

Just as “the goer does not stay…” [II: 15–16] refutes the presentation of staying as a proof of the existence of going, [106] rearranging those two verses to say “The stayer does not go” would refute presenting going as a proof of the existence of staying. Now suppose one said that having relinquished going, staying begins and therefore that staying exists. Just as “there is no beginning of going where one has gone” [II: 12] refutes the beginning of going, rearranging these three verses to say “there is beginning of staying where one has stayed” would refute the beginning—that is, the start—of staying. Now suppose one thought that when Lhejin, having stayed for a while, stops staying, he begins going, and therefore that since he stops staying, staying exists. Just as “one does not halt where one is going” refutes stopping from going, one could rearrange these two lines to say “one does not stop staying” to refute stopping staying. Therefore, since staying does not exist inherently, how could going?
bzhi pa [bya ba la brtags nas dgag pa]
1.1.1.4 Refutation through the examination of activity
['di] la gnyis/ 'gro ba po dang 'gro ba la gcig dang tha dad brtags te dgag pa dang / 'gro ba por 'jog pa'i bya ba la bya ba gnyis pa yod med brtags nas dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: the refutation through examination of whether the goer and going are identical or different and the refutation through examination of whether or not positing activity in the goer involves two actions.
dang po ['gro ba po dang 'gro ba la gcig dang tha dad brtags te dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.4.1 Refutation through examination of whether the goer and going are identical or different

'gro ba dang 'jug pa dang ldog pa rnams lam gsum mam 'gro ba po yin min gnyis dang de las gzhan pa la yod ces brjod mi nus kyang lhas byin gom pa 'dor ba mthong nas de 'gro ba po zhes bya bar 'gyur bas 'gro ba po dang 'gro ba'i bya ba rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: Although one cannot say that that starting, halting, and going are in the three intervals of the path, or in that which is or is not a goer, or in anything other than these two, Lhejin is seen walking. Therefore, since he is called a goer, the goer and the action of going exist essentially.
'gro ba de dang 'gro ba po/ / de nyid ces kyang byar mi rung / / 'gro ba dang ni 'gro ba po/ / gzhan nyid ces kyang byar mi rung / /
18. That going just is the goer Makes no sense. Nor does it make sense that They are completely different.

lhas byin gom pa 'dor ba'i 'gro ba'i bya ba dang gom pa 'dor mkhan gyi lhas byin gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod na rang bzhin gcig dang tha dad gang rung du grub dgos na/ / 'gro ba'i bya ba de dang 'gro ba po gnyis de nyid de rang bzhin gcig ces kyang byar mi rung la 'gro ba dang 'gro ba po gnyis rang bzhin gzhan nyid ces kyang byar mi rung ngo / / yang ji ltar mi rung zhe na/

If walking Lhejin’s action of going by taking steps and Lhejin the walker both existed essentially then they would have to be either essentially identical or essentially different. But it makes no sense that that action of going [107] and that goer are essentially identical, nor does it make sense that that action of going and that goer are essentially different. “So,” one might ask, “why does it not make sense?”
gal te 'gro ba gang yin pa/ / de nyid 'gro po yin gyur na/ / byed pa po dang las nyid kyang / / gcig pa nyid du thal bar 'gyur/ /
19. If the goer were identical with going The absurd consequence would follow That agent and action Are identical.

gal te 'gro ba'i bya ba gang yin pa de nyid dang 'gro ba po gnyis rang bzhin gcig yin par 'gyur na byed pa po dang las nyid kyang ste bya ba yang gcig pa nyid du thal bar 'gyur bas 'di ni bya ba dang 'di ni byed pa po'o zhes khyad par dbye mi nus par 'gyur na gcod pa'i bya ba dang gcod pa po ni gcig pa yang ma yin no/ / de yi phyir de gnyis rang bzhin gcig tu ma grub bo zhes bzlog pa 'phen no/ /

If the action of going and the goer were essentially identical, then the absurd consequence would follow that agent and action—that is the act—are identical. Then it would follow that you could not draw a distinction by saying “this is the action” and “that is the agent.” However, the action of cutting and the cutter are not identical. Therefore, by modus tollens, these two are not essentially identical.
gal te 'gro dang 'gro ba po/ / gzhan pa nyid du rnam brtag na/ / 'gro po med pa'i 'gro ba dang / / 'gro ba med pa'i 'gro por 'gyur/ /
20. If going and the goer were thought of as completely different, The absurd consequence would follow That there could be going without a goer And a goer without going.

gal te yang 'gro ba'i bya ba dang 'gro ba po ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan pa nyid du rnam par brtag na/ de'i tshe 'gro ba po la ltos pa med pa'i 'gro ba dang 'gro ba'i bya ba la ltos pa med pa'i 'gro ba po yod par gzung du yod par 'gyur na de ltar 'dzin pa yang min pas de gnyis rang bzhin tha dad du med do zhes thal ba bzlog pa 'phen no/ / rang mtshan gyis so sor grub na rag las pa mi 'thad pa'i bum snam bzhin du 'brel med du 'gro ba'i rigs pa'o/ / gal te kho bo ni byed pa po dang bya ba gnyis don tha dad du grub pa med pas gzhan du yang mi 'dod la de gnyis brjod pa tha dad pa'i phyir gcig tu yang mi 'dod pas de gnyis ka med par yang de gnyis grub bo zhe na/

Suppose, on the other hand, one thought that the action of going and the goer were inherently different. In that case, one would see an action of going that did not depend on a goer, and a goer that did not depend upon an action of going. But since this is not observed, it follows by modus tollens that these two are not essentially different. This argument demonstrates that if they existed distinctly through their own characteristics, they would be unconnected, and so it would not be tenable for them to be dependent upon one another, like a pot and a cloth. Suppose someone argued as follows: Since action and agent cannot be established as different entities, as far as I am concerned, they are not different. But since they are the referents of different expressions, nor are they identical. Therefore they exist despite the fact that they are neither identical nor different!
gang dag dngos po gcig pa dang / / dngos po gzhan pa nyid du ni/ / grub par gyur pa yod min na/ / de gnyis grub pa ci ltar yod/ /
21. When neither in identity Nor in difference Can they exist, How can these two exist at all?

byed pa po dang bya ba gang dag dngos po ste rang bzhin gcig pa dang dngos po ste rang bzhin gzhan pa nyid du ni grub par gyur pa yod pa min na de gnyis rang gi ngo bos grub pa ji ltar yod pa de smros shig de lta bas na de ni btags pa tsam du zad do/ / rang bzhin gcig dang tha dad tshad mas rnam par bcad na rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phung gsum blo ngor yang ldog dgos pa la 'dir de gnyis su ma grub kyang rang bzhin gyis yod ces 'dzin pa 'di ji ltar yin snyam na/ dngos ming so sos go bya tha dad du med pa gcig pa'i don dang 'brel med don gzhan du yod pa tha dad pa'i don du bzung nas de gnyis su ma grub kyang rang bzhin gyis yod snyam pa yin la/ rang bzhin gcig pa dang rang bzhin tha dad tshad mas khegs nas dogs pa de byung ba min no/ / gnas ma bu pas gang zag rtag mi rtag gang yang min par smra ba yang de la dpags nas shes par bya'o/ /

Action and agent are not a single entity—that is, have a single essence—nor are they two entities—that is, have two essences. So, how can they exist inherently? You explain it! Since they cannot, they are merely fabricated! If authoritative cognition eliminates their essential identity and essential difference, any third alternative with respect to their essential existence is banished from thought as well. So, one might wonder, how are they are grasped as existing essentially, although they do not exist in these two ways? [108] Here is why one might think that: Taking “identity” to mean that there are not distinct referents for distinct names and “difference” to mean that things exist as unrelated objects, they think that although they do not exist in these two ways, they still exist essentially. But this doubt does not arise after authoritative cognition has eliminated their being essentially identical or essentially different. The Vatsiputrīyas assertion that the person is neither permanent nor impermanent can also be understood analogously.
gnyis pa ['gro ba por 'jog pa'i bya ba la bya ba gnyis pa yod med brtags nas dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.4.2 Refutation through examination of whether or not positing activity in the goer involves two actions

'dir 'gro ba po lhas byin 'gro'o zhes bya bar ni 'jig rten na grags so/ / de la smra ba po tshig smra'o/ / byed pa po bya ba byed do zhes pa la smra ba po yin pas tshig nyid smra ba yin pa de bzhin du 'gro ba po yin pas 'gro ba gang gis 'gro ba por 'jog pa'i 'gro ba de nyid 'gro ba yin pas ji skad brjod pa'i skyon du mi 'gyur ro zhe na/

Now, suppose someone argues as follows: In everyday life one says, “Lhejin, the goer, goes.” When one says things such as “that speaker speaks” or “that agent acts,” one means that because of being a speaker he utters words; and because of being a goer, he goes by that very going in virtue of which he is called a goer. Therefore there is no error in talking this way.
'gro ba gang gis 'gro por mngon/ / 'gro ba de ni de 'gro min/ / gang phyir 'gro ba'i snga rol med/ / gang zhig gang du 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
22. The going in virtue of which a goer is manifest/12/ Cannot be the going in virtue of which he goes Because he does not exist before that going. So who goes and where does he go?

'gro ba'i bya ba gang gis 'gro ba por mngon par gsal bar byed pa'i 'gro ba de ni 'gro ba por gyur pa de 'gro ba min pa ste 'gro ba yin par mi 'gyur ba'am 'gro bar byed pa min te/ gang gi phyir te 'di ltar 'gro ba'i bya ba'i snga rol du 'gro ba po yod na 'gro ba po de lam der 'gro bar 'gyur na/ lhas byin gang zhig don gzhan pa'i grong ngam grong khyer gang zhig tu 'gro bar mthong ba bzhin du 'gro ba'i bya ba'i snga rol du de la mi ltos pa'i 'gro ba po med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba por rnam par 'jog pa'i bya ba de nyid 'gro ba po 'gro bar byed pa'i byed pa yin na de gnyis la snga phyi ba dgos pa 'di ni 'gro ba'i bya ba rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa la yin gyi tha snyad du de ltar 'dod pa la min no/ / ji ltar zhe na/ dper na myu gu skye'o zhes pa la skye rgyu'i myu gu skyes pa'i snga rol na med na skye ba mi 'thad la yod na slar skye mi dgos so zhes skye ba rang mtshan gyis grub pa 'gog pa bzhin du/'gro ba por 'jog rgyu'i lhas byin 'gro ba'i bya ba skyes pa'i snga rol du med na de 'gro bar mi 'thad la yod na 'gro ba por grub zin pas slar 'gro mi dgos shing gal te 'gro ba por grub zin nas kyang 'gro dgos na 'gro ba por 'jog pa'i bya ba de nyid kyis de 'gro bar byed pa min pas snga phyir grub dgos so/ /

He who is clearly manifest as a goer in virtue of the action of going, being a goer, does not go, that is, he is not going—he is not performing the action of going. This is because if there were a goer prior to the activity of going, that goer would have to go on a path. In that case, just as Lhejin is seen going to a city or a town, which is a different entity from him, prior to the activity of going, and independent of it, there is no goer. Since the very activity that determines that something is a goer is itself the instrument by means of which the goer goes, the necessity of the going and the goer being sequential arises in the system according to which the activity of going exists inherently, but not in that according to which it exists coventionally. Why is that? Consider, for instance, saying that a sprout arises. If the sprout which is to be arisen does not exist prior to its having arisen, its arising is not tenable; if it does, it does not need to arise again. Thus the existence of arising through its own characteristic is refuted. In the same way, [109] if Lhejin, who is to be characterized as a goer, did not exist in that way prior to the arising of the activity of going, it would be not be tenable for him to be going; and if he did, then having achieved the status of a goer, there would be no need for him to go again. However if, even after having achieved the status of a goer, he has to go, he cannot go in virtue of the very activity that determines that he is a goer. Therefore, they must be sequential.

slob dpon gnyis kas sngar ltar bshad pa la shes rab sgron ma las de ltar yin na/ gang tshe 'gro ba med par ni/ / zhes pa'i skabs su 'gro ba po 'gro ba bkag pa dang zlos so zhes 'chad mod kyang / de ni 'gro ba'i bya ba byed pa'i tshig gi don du yod la byed pa po'i tshig gi don du med pa 'gog pas 'di dang khyad par che'o/ / ci ste 'gro ba por 'jog pa'i bya ba de nyid 'gro ba ma yin yang de las gzhan pa'i bya ba gnyis pa zhig 'gro'o snyam na/

Both of the masters have explained this as we present it above. However, according to Prajñāpradīpa [74a], this would be redundant to the refutation of the goer’s going in the context of “now, when there is not-going” [II: 9]. But because that is a refutation of the thesis that if the activity of going is the referent of the verb phrase then the phrase “the goer” is meaningless, there is a big difference between these. Now, suppose one thought that one does not go by performing the action in virtue of which one is a goer. Rather, there is a second action in virtue of which one goes.
'gro ba gang gis 'gro por mngon/ rtsa ba de las gzhan pa de 'gro min/ / gang phyir 'gro po gcig pu la/ / 'gro ba gnyis su mi 'thad do/ /
23. The going in virtue of which a goer is manifest Cannot be different from the going in virtue of which he goes, Since in one goer A twofold going is untenable.

'gro ba'i bya ba gang gis 'gro ba por mngon par gsal bar byed pa'i bya ba de las gzhan pa'i bya ba gnyis pa yang 'gro ba po de 'gro bar byed pa'i byed pa min te/ gang gi phyir 'gro ba po gcig pu zhig la 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis su yod pa mi 'thad pa de yi phyir ro/ / 'di la yang sngar bzhin zlos pa'i skyon dang bya ba gzhan ma bkag pa dang 'gro ba'i bya ba gcig kho na yod par khas blangs pas de dang ldan pa'i phyir 'gro ba po 'gro bar 'grub pa'i skyon yod ces 'chad mod kyang / skyon dang po med pa ni sngar dang 'dra la bya ba don gzhan la thal ba'i gnod pa bstan cing / 'gro ba po gcig la 'gro ba'i bya ba gnyis yod par 'gyur ro zhes pha rol po mi 'dod pa 'phen pa tsam yin pa'i phyir skyon de dag med do/ // snga ma rnams gzhung gong 'og gnyis kas 'gro ba bya bar khas mi len par 'gro ba pos bsgrub par bya ba'i las su khas blangs pa 'gog pa yin zhes pa yang mi 'thad de/ 'gro ba por rnam 'jog gi bya ba nyid 'gro bar byed pa yin min brtags nas 'gog par shin tu gsal ba'i phyir ro/ // smra ba po tshig smra ba dang gcod pa po shing gcod pa'i bya ba byed do zhes pa sogs kyang de ltar du dgag par bya'o/ /

A second action, different from the action of going in virtue of which the goer is clearly manifest, is not the action that the goer performs, because it is not tenable that a single goer performs a twofold action of going. Here also, as above, Bhāvaviveka charges Buddhapālita with being redundant: He also charges that since another action is not refuted, and since he maintains that there is only one action of going, the error is committed of asserting that the goer goes in virtue of performing that action [74b]. However, the first error is not committed. It is just as above. Since this merely presents the consequences unacceptable to the opponent—showing that problems follow from their being separate entities, and that a single goer would perform two actions of going—these errors are not committed. Earlier commentators explain that both of these sections of the text refute the assertion that going is not an action; instead, they say, it is an object to be accomplished by a goer. But this is not tenable [110], because it is absolutely clear that this is a refutation through examination of whether or not the very action in virtue of which something is called a goer is going. Such assertions as that the speaker utters words and that the woodcutter cuts wood are refuted similarly.
gnyis pa [las dang byed pa po la bya ba thun mong du dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation of the activity common to agent and action
'gro po yin par gyur pa ni/ / 'gro rnams gsum du 'gro mi byed/ / ma yin par ni gyur de yang / / 'gro rnams gsum du 'gro mi byed/ / yin dang ma yin gyur pa yang / 'gro rnam gsum du 'gro mi byed/ /

24. That which is a goer Does not go in any of the three ways. That which is not a goer Does not go in any of the three ways. 25. One that both is and is not a goer Does not go in any of the three ways.

'gro bo yin pa dang ma yin par gyur pa ni sngar bshad la yin dang ma yin gyur pa ni cha 'ga' zhig la ltos nas 'gro ba po dang 'ga' zhig la ltos nas min par 'dod pa yin la de nyid gong du gnyis ma yin du yang bshad de don 'dra'o/ / 'gro ba ni 'dir 'gro ba ste bgrod par bya ba'o/ / rnam pa gsum ni song ma song bgom pa la bud d+ha pA li ta las bshad do/ / de ltar na 'gro ba po yin par gyur pa ni bgrod par bya ba song ba dang ma song ba dang bgom pa'i lam rnam pa gsum du 'gro bar mi byed pa ste gzhan gnyis la'ang de ltar sbyar ro/ / tshig gsal las 'gro ba yin pa dang ma yin pa dang yin min du gyur pa gsum du byas nas der 'gro bar mi byed pa ni rab byed brgyad pa nas ston par gsungs / /

That which is a goer and that which is not a goer have been already explained. That which is both a goer and a non-goer is maintained to be a goer in dependence on some of its aspects and to be a non-goer in dependence on other aspects. This is similar to the earlier explanation in the context of the discussion of something that is neither. Here, going is to go to where one is to go. Buddhapālita explains that the three ways are to do so in that over which one has gone; that over which one is going; and that over which one has yet to go [174b]. Thus, he who is a goer does not perform going to where he has to go in any of the three intervals of the path: neither in that over which he has gone, nor in that over which he has yet to go, nor in that over which is going. And this can be applied to the other two cases. Prasannapadā, on the other hand, explains that the three ways are being that which is, that which is not, and that which both is and is not a goer [37a]. He says that the eighth chapter explains their nonperformance of going.
gnyis pa [mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.2 Drawing conclusions
de phyir 'gro dang 'gro po dang / / bgrod par bya ba'ang yod ma yin/ /
25c. Therefore, going, goer And that which is to be gone over are non-existent.

gang gi phyir de ltar dpyad pa na 'gro ba po dang bgrod par bya ba dang 'gro ba rnams mi rnyed pa de'i phyir 'gro ba'i bya ba dang 'gro ba po dang bgrod par bya ba gsum rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no/ / 'jig rten ni shas cher bya ba mang po'i tha snyad kyi dbang gis dngos po la mngon par zhen la bya ba rnams kyi nang na 'gro ba'i bya ba gtso bo yin pas/ de la ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag na bya byed lhag ma thams cad kyang de bzhin du rtogs par 'gyur bas 'gro 'ong la rang bzhin 'gog pa gsungs so/ / yul 'di nas phar la 'gro ba de nyid yul de na gnas pa ltos te 'ong ba yin pas de la rang bzhin 'gog pa'i rigs pa logs su ma gsungs so/ /

Therefore, upon analysis, neither the goer, nor where one is to go, nor going are found. Therefore none of these three—neither the goer, nor where one is to go, nor the going—exist essentially. Ordinary people are fixated on things due to conventions, including, primarily, varieties of actions. Among these actions, the action of going is most salient. Therefore, when its inherent existence is refuted, all of the remaining actions and agents can be understood similarly. That is why he has refuted the essence of coming and going. To go from this very place to the other is to come in relation to the one who is staying at that other place. Therefore, he does not present an argument refuting the essence of coming.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar 'gro 'ong rang bzhin gyis stong pa'i zab mo'i don rtog ge nyi tshes bsgrubs so snyam pa dgag pa'i phyir dang / 'gro 'ong med par gsungs pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya ba yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba phyogs tsam smros na/ rgya cher rol pa las/ sa bon yod na myu gu ji bzhin te/ / sa bon gang yin myu gu de nyid min/ / de las gzhan min de yang ma yin te/ / de ltar rtag min chad min chos nyid do/ / zhes gsungs te/

[111] A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to refute the idea that the profound fact of the emptiness of essence of going and coming is established by mere sophistry and to show that all of the scriptures that present the nonexistence of coming and going are explained by this chapter. The Lalitavistara-sātra says, Just as when there is a seed there is a sprout, Whatever is a seed is not a sprout. It is neither anything other than that nor that itself. It is neither permanent nor annihilated in reality. [m Do sde kha 89b]

'dis ni sa bon nyid myu gur phar 'pho zhing 'gro ba dang myu gu sa bon las gzhan zhig nas tshur 'ong ba bkag ste/ snga ma ltar na rtag par 'gyur ba las de ltar min pas myu gu'i dus na'ang mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rtag pa min la/ phyi ma ltar na sa bon gyi rgyu la mi ltos par 'byung bas sa bon rgyun chad par 'gyur ba las de ltar min pas sa bon rgyun chad pa yang min no/ / rgya las rgya yi 'bur ni snang mod kyi/ / rgya de 'phos par dmigs pa'ang yod ma yin/ / de la de med gzhan la ma yin te/ / de ltar 'dus byas rtag med chad pa med/ / ces pas ni/

This refutes both the seed itself passing into and going on to become the sprout and the sprout coming from something that is other than the seed. In the first case it would be permanent. But since that is not the case, that which exists, having not yet disintegrated at the time when the sprout exists, is not permanent. In the latter case, its having arisen without depending on the seed as a cause, the continuum of the seed would have been terminated. But since that is not the case either, the continuum of the seed is not terminated. It continues, Although the impression appears to have come from the seal, One does not see the seal itself pass into it. It is neither in that nor in anything other than that. Thus produced phenomena are neither permanent nor annihilated. [Ibid.]

rgya las rgya yi 'bur gyi rnam pa rgyas btab pa'i gzhi la snang ba na rgya de der 'pho zhing 'gro ba dang rgya las gzhan nas kyang de 'ongs pa min pa dper byas nas/ 'dus byas thams cad kyang 'bras bu skye ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ba dang rgyu 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro bar rtag chad dang bral bar gsungs so/ / me long ngos dang 'bru mar snod rnams la/ / bud med kha bzhin brgyan pas bltas pa na/ / byis pa de ni de la chags bskyed nas/ / 'dod pa tshol ba'i phyir yang shin tu rgyug / bzhin ni der yang 'pho ba ma yin te/ / gzugs brnyan la ni nam yang bzhin mi rnyed/ / rmongs pa de dag 'dod pa skyed pa ltar/ / chos rnams thams cad de bzhin shes par gyis/ / zhes pas ni byad kyi gzugs brnyan me long la sogs pa la shar ba na byad nyid der 'pho zhing mi 'gro la/ las gzhan zhig nas gzugs brnyan 'ong ba yang min pa dper byas nas snga ma bzhin shes par bya bar gsungs te/ sngar gzhung nas 'gro 'ong bkag pa ni rkang pa 'degs 'jog gi 'gro 'ong bkag pa yin mod kyang de mtshon pa tsam yin pas 'dus byas thams cad la 'gro 'ong bkag pa'i don yang rigs pa 'di dag gis shes par bya'o zhes bo go ba'i ched du lung sbyor mdzad do/ /

When the actual contours of the seal are seen in that which is sealed, neither does that seal pass into it nor does it come from anything other than the seal. This example shows that no produced phenomena, when they arise, come from anywhere, and that when causes cease, they do not go anywhere. Thus they are said to be free from permanence and from annihilation. The Samādhirāja-sūtra says, When they see a woman’s ornamented face On the surface of a mirror or a pot of oil, Childish ones develop attachment to it; Then develop desire and pursue it avidly. The face does not pass on to them. Nor is the face ever found in the image. Just as that for which these fools develop desire, So all phenomena should be known. [m Do sde da 26a] [112] This says that when the image of the face is reflected in the mirror, the face itself does not pass or go into it. Nor does the image come from anything other than the face. Taking this as an example, it should be understood according to the previous explanations. The refutation of coming and going in the text above is the refutation of going and coming by picking up and putting down the foot. But that is merely an illustration: one should understand that the point of these arguments is to refute the coming and going of all produced phenomena.

ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang / de tshe sdig med stobs bcu ldan pa yi/ / rgyal ba de ni ting 'dzin mchog 'di 'chad/ / srid pa'i 'gro ba rmi lam lta bu ste/ / 'di la mi skye su yang 'chi ba med/ / sems can mi dang srog kyang mi rnyed de/ / chos 'di rnams ni dbu ba chu shing 'dra/ sgyu ma lta bu nam mkha'i glog 'dra ste/ / chu yi zla ba 'dra zhing smig rgyu bzhin/ / mi 'ga' 'jig rten 'dir yang shi nas ni/ / 'jig rten gzhan du 'pho zhing 'gro med kyang / / zhes gsungs te 'dis ni sems can la 'jig rten snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba dang 'di nas pha rol tu 'gro ba'i rang bzhin bkag ste btsal na de dag mi rnyed pa'i phyir ro/ / de yi tshe las byed mkhan dang 'bras bu myong mkhan med pas las 'bras mi rung ngam snyam pa bzlog pa'i phyir du/ las byas rnams ni nam yang chud mi za/ / 'khor ba na yang dkar nag 'bras bu smin/ / rtag par ma yin chad par mi 'gyur te/ / las bsags med cing gnas pa dag kyang med/ / de yang byas nas reg par mi 'gyur minan/ / gzhan gyis byas pa tshor bar 'gyur ba'ang med/ / 'pho ba med cing phyir yang 'ong ba med/ / thams cad yod pa ma yin med pa'ang min/ / 'di na lta gnas 'jug pa dag pa min/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The following quotations from the Samādhirāja-sūtra are provided to illustrate this: The Victor who lacks all vices and who is endowed with the ten powers Has the taught the supreme meditative absorption. Beings in cyclic existence are like dreams. They are unborn and undying. Sentient beings, humans, and life are not found. These phenomena are like foam, plantain trees, Illusions, flashes of lightning, The moon in the water and mirages. No person who has died in this world Passes or goes to any other world. [m Do sde da 96a] This says that sentient beings essentially coming from a previous life or going to a next life has been refuted, because when they are sought they are not found. When they are not found, one might think that that it is not possible for there to be any agent of action or experiencer of its effect, and therefore that there is no karma. In order to forestall this idea arising, this sūtra continues: Actions that have been performed are never wasted. When one transmigrates, both positive and negative effects ripen. They are neither permanent nor annihilated; There is neither accumulation of karma nor its endurance. But it is not that having performed them there is no contact. Nor will the effect of something done by someone else will be experienced. Neither is anything transferred; nor is it returned. Neither does everything exist nor not exist. Thus engaging with of views is impure. [Ibid.]

las byas zhes pa ni 'khor ba zhes pas bshad la/ 'bras bu phyung gi bar du gnas pa med pas ni rtag pa 'gog go / de yang zhes pas byas pa chud mi za bar bstan te chad pa 'gog go / gzhan gyis zhes pa ni ma byas pa dang phrad pa 'gog pa'o/ / phyir yang 'ong ba med pa ni rnam smin phyung zin nas slar yang mi 'byin pa'o/ rang bzhin gyis ma grub cing tha snyad du yod pas na yod med min pa'o/ / 'jig rten 'di na yod med kyi mthar lta ba'i gnas la 'jug pa ni dag pa ste grol ba min no/ / dkon mchog brtsegs pa las kyang / tshe dang ldan pa dag gar dong gang nas lhags/ de dag gis smras pa btsun pa rab 'byor gang du yang 'gro ba med pa dang gang nas kyang 'ong ba med pa'i phyir bcom ldan 'das kyis chos bstan to/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar na rab byed 'di yi rigs pa rnams ni 'di 'dra ba'i gsung rab gang zag dang chos la 'gro 'ong med par ston pa thams cad lta ba'i mig yin pas/ sngon la 'di'i rigs pa la mkhas par byas nas de yi 'og tu man ngag des gsung rab de dag thams cad kyi don bshad par bya'o/ /

[113] “Actions that have been performed” is explained by “When one transmigrates.” Saying that they do not endure until ripening refutes their permanence. “But it is not” shows that they are not wasted, and thereby refutes nihilism. “Nor will the effect of” refutes encountering the effects of that which one has not done. “Nor is it returned” shows that after ripening has occurred there is no further effect. Since they do not exist essentially, but do exist conventionally, they are neither existent nor nonexistent. In life, to engage with extreme views regarding existence and nonexistence is impure—that is, not conducive to liberation. The Ratnakūṭa-sūtra says, “O worthy ones, where are you going and whence have you come?” They replied, “Ven Subhūti, the Transcendent Lord has explained things as follows: nothing goes anywhere or comes from anywhere.” [dKon brtsegs cha 148a] So the arguments in this chapter are the eyes with which to see such sūtras that show that no phenomena or persons come or go. Therefore, after having first mastered these arguments, one should explain the meanings of all of these texts through that understanding.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

'gro ba po gang yin dang 'gro sa'i yul dang der 'gro ba'i bya ba rnams ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis yod par bzhag pa tsam min par don rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod par 'dzin pa'i 'dzin pa legs par ngos zin par byas la/ de nas ji ltar bzung ba de ltar yod dam med btsal ba'i tshe na de ltar yod pa la sngar bshad pa'i rigs pa rnams kyis sgo du ma nas gnod pa 'bab pa'i tshul rnams nges par bya'o/ / de yang rnam pa du mar dpyad nas rigs pas 'gog pa ni/ rang gi ngo bos yod pa la las bya ba byed pa po'i rnam gzhag gang yang mi 'thad par rtogs su gzhug pa'i ched yin gyi 'gro 'ong sogs med par ston pa'i ched min no/ / de ltar rtogs pa na sngar 'gro 'ong sogs kyi tha snyad thams cad rang gi ngo bos yod pa la byed pa'i blo de gnas 'phos nas/ rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin gyis stong pa kho na la bya byed de dag 'thad do snyam du nges pa 'drongs pa dgos so/ de ni/ byed pa po dang las dag gis/ / dngos po lhag ma shes par bya/ / zhes pa'i tshig gsal las/ 'gro ba dang 'gro ba po ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag ste phan tshun ltos pa'i grub pa nyid yin par shes par bya'o zhes gsungs pa bzhin yin no/ / de yang*/ 'gro po 'gro la brten byas shing / / 'gro ba nyid kyang 'gro po la/ / brten nas 'byung ba ma gtogs pa/ / 'grub pa'i rgyu ni ma mthong ngo / / zhes sbyar ba 'di'i don no/ /

One should understand clearly the grasping by means of which one grasps the goer, the place where he goes, and the going not as posited as existing merely through the force of nominal convention, but as existing inherently. Having understood that, one should ascertain that when one searches to determine whether or not they exist in the way that they are grasped, their existence is undermined in various ways through the arguments explained above. The refutations through various analytic arguments are for the purpose of leading one to realize the untenability of the framework of action and agent in the context of inherent existence, [114] but not for the purpose of demonstrating the nonexistence of coming and going. By understanding that, one should transform the mind which previously took all conventional things such as coming and going to exist inherently. One should then ascertain that agent and action is tenable only in the context of emptiness of inherent existence or essence. Thus, Prasannapadā, commenting on Through action and agent All remaining things should be understood. [VIII: 13cd] says, Having refuted the inherent existence of going and the goer, one should understand that they merely exist in mutual dependence. [64b] This can be understood through the following rearrangement:/13/ The goer depends upon going. Going depends on the goer as well. Apart from depending arising One cannot see any cause for their existence.

dang po mngon du gyur pa'i 'gro 'ong rags pa dang de nas 'jig rten snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba dang 'di nas pha rol tu 'gro ba rnams la yang sbyar nas rang bzhin med pa'i tshul nges par bya/ de nas chos kyi dbang du byas pa'i dngos po rnams la yang skye ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ba dang*/ 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro ba la rigs pa 'don pa spos nas sbyang zhing bya byed gzhan thams cad la yang de ltar bya'o/ // des ni de kho na nyid la dpyod pa'i shes rab shin tu rgyas par 'gyur zhing 'gro 'chag nyal 'dug gi spyod lam thams cad sgyu ma bzhin du 'char bar yang 'gyur ro/ /

First, one should ascertain the manner in which coarse manifest phenomena such as coming and going are essenceless. Thereafter one should ascertain how this applies to the case of a person coming from a previous life to this one and going to the next. With respect to the phenomena as well, one should practice by applying these arguments to that which, while arising, does not come from anywhere and which, while ceasing, does not go anywhere. One should also apply this in the same way to all cases of action and agent. Thereby one will develop profound analytic wisdom with regard to the way things really are, and all activities such as going, walking, sleeping, sitting, etc., will appear to be illusionlike.
'gro ba dang 'ong ba brtag pa shes rab zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gnyis pa'o/ /
the second chapter called “the examination of coming and going.”
'gro ba dang 'ong ba brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa nyer lnga'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa gnyis pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the second chapter, having twenty-five verses, called “the examination of coming and going.”
CHAPTER III. Examination of the Senses
gnyis pa bdag med gnyis rgyas par bshad pa
The second major portion of the text is the extensive explanation of the two selflessnesses.

['di] la lnga/ chos dang gang zag so sor phye ste bshad pa dang / dngos po tsam gyi rang bzhin gyis stong par bstan pa dang / bdag med pa'i de kho na nyid la 'jug pa'i tshul dang / dus kyi rang bzhin gyis stong par bstan pa dang / srid pa'i rgyun gyi rang bzhin gyis stong par bstan pa'o/ /

It comprises five sections: the distinct explanation of the selflessness of phenomena and the selflessness of the person, the presentation of the emptiness of essence of mere phenomena, [115] the mode of engaging with the selflessness of things as they really are, the presentation of the emptiness of essence of time, and the presentation of the emptiness of essence of the continuum of life.
dang po [chos dang gang zag so sor phye ste bshad pa]
We now begin the first of these sections—the extensive explanation of the selflessness of phenomena and the selflessness of the person—
['di] la gnyis/ / chos kyi bdag med bshad pa dang / gang zag gi bdag med bshad pa'o/ /
which has two parts: the explanation of the selflessness of phenomena and the explanation of the selflessness of the person.
dang po [chos kyi bdag med bshad pa]
The first of these
['di] la gnyis/ chos gsum bdag med par bshad pa dang / de la bdag yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
has two sections: the explanation that the three kinds of phenomena are selfless and the refutation of the argument that they have a self.
[chos gsum bdag med par bshad pa]
[the three kinds of phenomena]
dang po la gsum/ skye mched la chos bdag dgag / phung po la chos bdag dgag / khams la chos bdag dgag pa'o/ /

The first of these sections has three parts: the refutation of the phenomenal self of the faculties, the refutation of the phenomenal self of the aggregates, and the refutation of the phenomenal self of the elements.
dang po [skye mched la chos bdag dgag]
[Refutation of the phenomenal self of the faculties]
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
it itself has three parts: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gnyis/ phyogs snga ma dgod pa dang / de sun dbyung ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: advancing the opponent’s argument and its refutation.
dang po [phyogs snga ma dgod pa] ni/
1.1 Advancing the opponent’s argument
lta dang nyan dang sgom pa dang / / myang bar byed dang reg byed yid/ / dbang po drug ste de dag gi / spyod yul blta bar bya la sogs/ /
1. Seeing, hearing, smelling, Tasting, touching, and mind Are the six faculties. Their spheres are the visible objects, etc.

'dir smras pa gal te yang 'gro ba la sogs pa gsum yod pa min mod kyi de lta na'ang gsung rab nas 'byung ba la ltos nas lta ba po la sogs pa rnams khas blang dgos te chos mngon pa las/ / lta ba dang nyan pa dang snom pa dang myang bar byed pa dang reg par byed pa dang yid ni go rim bzhin du mig gi dbang po nas yid kyi dbang po'i bar drug tu bstan la/ de dag gi spyod yul ni rim pa bzhin du blta bar bya ba dang sogs kyis bsdus pa mnyan par bya ba dang bsnam par bya ba dang myang bar bya ba dang reg par bya ba dang bsam par bya ba ste gzugs sgra sogs drug tu gsungs so/ / des na gzugs la lta bar byed pas na lta bar bstan te gzhan rnams kyang rang rang gi yul 'dzin par byed pas bstan to/ / lta dang zhes re re nas ming smos pas grangs grub mod kyang drug ces smos pa ni tha snyad du yang de dag las don gzhan pa gzugs sogs la dmigs byed kyi byed pa po med par shes pa'i don du nges gzung du mdzad do zhes bshad do/ / rang bzhin gyis med na lta ba la sogs par mi 'gyur bas lta ba la sogs pa ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa yin no zhes rang sde 'ga' zhig smra'o/ /

Now, according to some of our schools, even if such things as going do not exist, such things as the seer have to be affirmed, since they are found in the scriptures. In the Abhidharma, seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, touching, and introspection are presented as the six, in that order, from the visual sense to the introspective sense. Their six spheres are presented in that order from the object of sight and those indicated by the “etc.”: from the object of hearing, the object of smell, the object of taste, and the object of touch to the object of introspection, viz., form, sound, etc. To the extent that something sees form it is called “seeing”; and the others are also presented insofar as they grasp their respective objects. Although when he says “seeing” and mentioning each the number is understood, nevertheless, “six” is stated explicitly in order to emphasize that, even conventionally, there is no agent other than these by means of which to observe form such things as form. [116] These schools also maintain that if nothing exists essentially, such things as seeing would not be possible, and therefore that such things as seeing do exist essentially.
gnyis pa [de sun dbyung ba]
1.2 Its refutation
['di] la gnyis/ lta ba'i chos gsum rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of the essential existence of the three phenomena involved in seeing and applying this argument to the other faculties.
dang po [lta ba'i chos gsum rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.2.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the three phenomena involved in seeing
['di] la gnyis/ lta ba'i byed pa po dgag / lta ba'i las dang bya ba dgag pa'o/ /
This part has two sections: the refutation of the eye as the agent of seeing and the refutation of the object and action of seeing.
dang po [lta ba'i byed pa po dgag]
1.2.1.1 Refutation of the eye as the agent of seeing
['di] la gnyis/ mig lta ba'i byed pa po yin pa dgag / bdag gam rnam shes lta ba'i byed pa po yin pa dgag pa'o/
This section has two parts: the refutation of the thesis that the eye is the agent of seeing and the refutation of the thesis that the self or consciousness is the agent of seeing.
dang po [mig lta ba'i byed pa po yin pa dgag]
1.2.1.1.1 Refutation of the thesis that the eye is the agent of seeing
['di] la gnyis/ /rang la mi lta ba'i rtags kyis dgag / lta ba'i bya ba dang 'brel ma 'brel brtags la dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation using the premise that it does not see itself; and the refutation through examining whether or not the seer is or is not related to the action of seeing.
dang po [rang la mi lta ba'i rtags kyis dgag]
1.2.1.1.1.1 Refutation using the premise that it does not see itself
['di] la gsum/ rtags dgod pa/ ma nges pa spang ba/ / don bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has three parts: advancing the argument, disposing of the charge that it commits the fallacy of accident, and the conclusion.
dang po [rtags dgod pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1.1 Advancing the argument
lta de rang gi bdag nyid ni/ / de la lta ba ma yin nyid/ / gang zhig bdag la mi lta ba/ / de gzhan dag la ji ltar lta/ /
2. That very seeing does not see Itself at all. How can something that cannot see itself See another?

rab byed brgyad pa'i 'grel par blta bya dang lta byed ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag ste phan tshun ltos pa'i yod par bshad pa ltar lta ba po la sogs pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag bya yin gyi yod tsam min no/ / gzugs la lta ba'i mig de rang gi bdag nyid de la ni lta ba ma yin pa nyid de kho na ste/ rang nyid rang gi blta bya yin pa'i rang la bya byed 'gal ba'iphyir ro/ / de ltar gang zhig bdag la mi lta ba de la ni sngon po la sogs pa gzhan dag la yang ji ltar na lta ba yod de lta ba ngo bo nyid kyis med de/ dper na rna ba la sogs pa bzhin no/ / 'di ni lta ba ngo bo nyid kyis grub na rgyu la rag las pa 'gal bas rang la mi lta bar mtshungs bzhin du mig gzugs la lta la rna ba la sogs pa de la mi lta ba'i khyad par med de 'brel med don gzhan la lta mi lta mtshungs pa'i rigs pa'o/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las/ chu la rlan dang me la tsha ba dang sna ma'i me tog la dri zhim pa mthong na de dag dang ldan pa las sa dang chu dang gos la rlan la sogs pa dmigs pa bzhin du/ lta ba rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na thog mar mig la dmigs nas de nas gzugs la yang dmigs par 'gyur ba las de med pa'i phyir gzugs la yang mi lta'o zhes 'gog ste/

In the commentary on the eighth chapter the inherent existence of the visual object and visual subject is rejected and it is explained that they exist interdependently. So, the object of negation is the inherent existence of the seer, etc., but not their mere existence. The eye that sees form “does not see itself at all,” because, since it would be its own visual object, this would be an instance of the inconsistency of reflexive action. And then how can something that cannot see itself see others such as blueness? So, there is no inherently existent seeing and the same applies to the ear, etc. This is an argument showing that if seeing existed inherently its dependence on causes would be contradictory. Therefore, since they are comparable in that they do not perceive themselves, one should not distinguish between them by saying that the eye sees form and ear does not. This is because for either of them, as unrelated things, it makes just as much sense to perceive as not to perceive. According to the Buddhapālita, the refutation goes as follows: while moisture is found with water, heat with fire, and fragrance with jasmine, when these are conjoined with them, such things as humidity are observed in such things as soil, water, and cloth. [117] Similarly, if seeing existed inherently, first the eye would be observed, and form would only be observed thereafter. But since this is not found to be the case, vision could not see even form./1/ [175a].

de yang brgya pa las/ dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin ni/ / thog mar bdag la snang 'gyur na/ / mig nyid la yang mig gis ni/ / ci yi phyir na 'dzin mi 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs pa'i rigs pa dang don gcig tu bzhed do/ /

Buddhapālita then quotes the Catuḥśataka: If the natures of all things First appear in themselves, Then why then do we not find That the eye is perceived by the eye itself? [XIII: 16] Buddhapālita’s argument is the same as Āryadeva’s.
gnyis pa [ma nges pa spang ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1.2 Disposing of the charge that it commits the fallacy of accident
lta ba rab tu bsgrub ba'i phyir/ / me yi dpes ni nus ma yin/ / song dang ma song bgom pa yis/ / de ni ltar bcas lan btab bo/ /
3. The example of fire Cannot elucidate seeing. That, along with seeing has been dealt with Through the analysis of the gone, the not-gone, and the going.

gal te me ni rang mi sreg kyang gzhan sreg pa bzhin du rang la mi lta yang gzhan la lta ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa yang mi 'gal lo snyam na/ lta ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir du me yi dpe bkod pas ni sgrub par nus pa ma yin te/ me'i dpe de ni dngos kyi don lta ba dang bcas pa ste lhan cig tu sngar lan btab pa ste sun phyung ba'i phyir ro/ / gang gis she na/ song dang ma song bgom pa yis te de gsum la 'gro ba bkag pa bzhin du bsregs pa la mi sreg ces pa dang bltas pa la mi lta zhes sogs dang re zhig sreg po mi sreg ces pa dang re zhig lta po mi lta zhes sogs kyang mtshungs par brjod par bya'o/ / des na rang la mi lta ba la gzhan la lta ba ngo bo nyid kyis med do zhes pa 'di grub bo/ /

Suppose one thought “Just as, even though the fire does not burn itself, it burns others, it is not contradictory to say that even though seeing does not see itself its seeing others exists essentially.” It is not possible to prove the inherent existence of seeing by supplying the example of fire. The analogy of fire, “along with”—that is, together with—the actual object, seeing, has been “dealt with”—that is, refuted earlier. How? Just as going is rejected in each of these three by “The gone, not-gone and going,” it should be understood that the burned is not burned and the seen is not seen, etc. and “the burner does not burn” and “the seer does not see” should be understood similarly./2/ Thus this establishes that that which does not see itself does not see another inherently.
gsum pa [don bsdu ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1.3 Conclusion
gang tshe cung zad mi lta bar/ / lta bar byed pa ma yin no/ / blta bas lta bar byed ces bur/ / de ni ci ltar rigs par 'gyur/ /
4. When there is not the slightest seeing, There is no seer. How could it makes sense to say That in virtue of seeing, it sees?

gang gi tshe rang dang gzhan la cung zad kyang mi lta ba lta bar byed pa ma yin pa de yi tshe mi lta ba la lta bar byed pa nyid mi rigs pa'i phyir gzugs la lta bas na mig ni lta bar byed pa yin zhes bya bar brjod pa de ni ji ltar rigs par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

Since it does not see itself or another even the least bit, it makes no sense for that which does not see to be seeing. Therefore, how could it make sense to say that just because the eye sees form, the eye is the agent of seeing?
gnyis pa [lta ba'i bya ba dang 'brel ma 'brel brtags la dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.2 Refutation through examining whether or not the seer is related to the action of seeing
lta ba lta nyid ma yin te/ / lta ba min pa mi lta nyid/ /
5. Seeing does not see. Nonseeing does not see.

gzhan yang 'dir mig ni gzugs la lta bas na lta bar byed pa'o zhes brjod pa na mig lta ba'i byed pa po'o/ / de yi tshe byed pa po mig lta ba'i bya ba dang 'brel dgos pas mig lta ba'i rang bzhin yin min gang bya ba dang 'brel brtag grang / dang po ltar na/ mig lta ba'i rang bzhin can ni slar yang gzugs la lta bas na zhes pa'i bya ba dang 'brel ba nyid ni ma yin te lta ba'i bya ba gnyis su 'gyur ba dang de lta na lta bar byed pa po yang gnyis su 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / gnyis pa ltar na mig lta ba'i rang bzhin min pa yang gzugs la mi lta ba nyid de lta ba'i bya ba dang bral ba'i phyir sor mo'i rtse mo bzhin no/ / gang gi tshe lta ba'i rang bzhin can yin min gnyis gzugs la lta bar mi 'thad pa de yi tshe lta bas lta bar byed ces byar de ni ji ltar rigs par 'gyur zhes bya ba 'di nyid dang sbyar ro/ /

Moreover, here it is said that the eye—since the eye sees just in virtue of seeing form—is therefore the agent of seeing. Given this, since the agent eye has to be related to the action of seeing, it must be analytically determined whether the eye is related to the action in virtue of having the nature of seeing or in virtue of lacking the nature of seeing. In the first case, [118] an eye whose nature is seeing cannot be related once again to the action denoted by “since it sees”; it would have to perform two actions of seeing, and consequently there would be two agents of action. In the second case, the eye whose nature is not seeing does not see form, since it is devoid of the action of seeing, just like the tip of a finger. Since neither one having nor one lacking the nature of seeing can see form, the phrase How could it makes sense to say That in virtue of seeing, it sees? [4cd] must be applied here.

gang tshe zhes pa bzhi sngar bkag pa'i don bsdur zla bas bshad la sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis ni 'di ltar 'chad de/ gzhan yang khyod kyis gzugs la lta bar byed pas lta ba'o zhes smras pa ni byed pa po mig la bya ba'i rkyen brjod nas lta bar byed pas lta ba yin no/ / des na yul la lta ba na lta ba yin gyi mi lta na min no/ / gang gi tshe yul la lta na lta ba yin gyi cung zad kyang mi lta ba lta ba ma yin pa de yi tshe lta bar byed pas mig lta ba'o zhes pa de ni ji ltar rigs par 'gyur te/ lta ba'o zhes pa'i tshig don du lta ba'i bya ba yod kyang lta bar byed pas zhes pa'i tshig de'i don du bya ba gnyis pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste bya ba gnyis pa med bzhin du yang yod par rtog na lta ba'i bya ba dang lta ba po gnyis gnyis yod par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste skyon de spong bar 'dod nas lta ba'o zhes pa'i tshig gi don du lta ba'i bya ba 'dod kyi snga ma la mi 'dod na lta bas lta bar byed pa nyid do zhes rtog pa de yang mi rigs te lta bar byed do zhes pa'i don du lta ba'i bya ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / de spang bar 'dod nas lta bar byed do zhes pa de nyid kyi don du lta ba'i bya ba 'dod na/ lta ba zhes pa'i don du bya ba med pas lta ba min pa lta ba'i bya ba dang bral ba ni lta bar byed pa mi rung ba'i phyir ro zhes rkang pa drug ka sbrel nas bshad do/ /

Candrakīrti construes the four lines beginning “When there is not” as the conclusion of the earlier refutation [39a]. However, Buddhapālita explains them in this way: Moreover, your statement: “just in virtue of seeing form, it sees” has an active verbal affix indicating that the eye is the agent;/3/ thus since it sees, there is seeing./4/ Therefore, when an object is seen, there is seeing; but when it is not, there is not. Since when an object is seen there is seeing, and when it is not seen even the least bit there is no seeing, how could it make sense to say that in virtue of seeing, the eye sees? The word “sees” refers to the action of seeing, but “in virtue of seeing” does not refer to a second action. Even though there is no second action, one might think that there is, in which case there would have to be two agents and two actions. If, with the intention of rebutting this error, anyone maintained that the word “sees” refers to an action of seeing, but the earlier occurrence of the word does not, then the phrase “in virtue of seeing, it sees” would not make sense, because the word “sees” would not refer to the action of seeing. If instead, in order to rebut this, it is maintained that “seeing” itself refers to the action of seeing, then again, since “sees” would not refer to an action, it would make no sense for [119] that which does not see—which is devoid of the action of seeing—to be seeing. Thus Buddhapālita comments, combining all six lines into a single argument [176a–176b]./5/

'dir gzugs la lta bar byed pas na lta ba'o zhes pa'i tshig gnyis kyi don du gzugs lta ba'i bya ba gcig mi rung ba'i rgyu mtshan ni/ lta ba'o zhes pa'i tshig gi don gyi bya ba de mig la yod la gzugs la lta bar byed ces pa'i don gyi bya ba de las la yang yod pas/ de gnyis rang mtshan gyis grub na rang mtshan gyis grub pa'i don so so la so sor yod dgos shing thun mong du bya ba gcig rten pa 'gal bar sngar bshad pa bzhin du shes par bya'o/ rang sde kha cig skye bzhin pa'i chos tsam zhig bya ba med par skye bas byab dang 'brel ba'i sgo nas 'gas kyang yul cung zad kyang mi lta ste bya ba med pa'i phyir ro/ // des na lta ba'i rang bzhin gyi mig bya ba dang 'brel bas yul mi lta'o zhes sgrub pa ni grub zin sgrub pa'o snyam du sems so/ / gal te tha snyad kyi yan lag tu gyur pa'i bya ba med na ni de'i tshe chos tsam yang med par 'gyur te bya ba dang bral ba'i phyir nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ // des na tha snyad du yod med yin na ni chos tsam po khas len pa bzhin du bya ba yang khas long la/ 'on te de kho nar yod med sems na ni bya ba khas blang du mi rung ba bzhin du chos tsam po yang med de/

Here, the reason why there can not be a single action of seeing as the referent of these two words in “In virtue of seeing form, it sees”/6/ is as follows: the action to which the word “sees” refers is associated with the eye, and the action to which the phrase “In virtue of seeing form” refers is associated with the object as well. It should, therefore, be noted that if these two existed through their own characteristics, they could exist distinctly through their own characteristics as the referents of individual words, and, as was said earlier, it would then be contradictory for them both to be associated with a single action. Some Buddhist schools maintain that a phenomenon that is merely arising is without action. Therefore, they argue, no one characterized by action sees an object even the least bit, because there is no action. Therefore, they think that to prove that the eye characterized by action, and which has the nature of seeing, does not see an object is to prove that which has already been proven. But without action—which is part of convention—there would be no mere phenomena, since they would be devoid of action, like a sky flower. Thus, if it is a matter of whether or not it exists conventionally, they should accept action, just as they accept mere phenomena. However, if this is an enquiry into whether or not it exists as things really are, then mere phenomena also do not exist, just as action is not acceptable./7/

brgya pa las/ bya ba dang ldan rtag pa med/ / kun tu 'gro la bya ba med/ / bya ba med pa med dang mtshungs/ / bdag med la khyod cis mi dga'/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de yi phyir gzhan gyi lugs 'di dbu ma pa la gnod byed du mi 'gyur la kho bo cag la grub zin sgrub pa'i skyon yang med do zhes tshig gsal las 'chad do/ / 'dir bya ba med ces pa ni gzugs mthong ba dang lhas byin 'gro ba la sogs pa'i bya ba med pa min gyi mig dang lhas byin la sogs pa'i chos tsam zhig min pa'i gzuT mthong ba dang 'gro ba la sogs pa'i bya ba med ces 'dod pa yin no/ // rang lugs ni de gnyis don dam par med mnyam dang tha snyad du yod mnyam yin pas yod med kyi khyad par mi 'byed do/ //

It is said in the Catuḥśataka: That which is active is not permanent. The omnipresent is without action. That which is without action is as though it is nonexistent. Why do you not prefer selflessness? [X: 17] Thus it is explained in Prasannapadā [39b] that this other system does not undermine the mādhyamikas, and that we do not commit the error of proving that which has already been proven. In this context the assertion that “there is no action” does not mean that there is no action such as seeing form and Lhejin’s going, etc. Instead, they assert that apart from mere phenomena, such as form and Lhejin, [120] there is no seeing or going. In our own system, there is no distinction between these two, as they are equally nonexistent ultimately, and equally conventionally existent.

pha rol pos mig bya ba dang 'brel ba'i sgo nas gzugs lta ba min par 'dod kyang de ltar sgrub pa grub zin sgrub pa'i skyon du mi 'gyur ba'i rgyu mtshan du de'i phyir zhes pa'i don tha snyad du bya ba yod pa bkod pas na/ pha rol po la grub pa'i don de'i khas blangs kyis grub pa 'di yi dgongs par 'dod pa ni shin tu mi rigs shing / kho bo cag dgag bya 'gog pa tsam yin gyi bsgrub bya mi sgrub pas zhes pa'i rgyu mtshan yang mi 'god pas sngar gyi bkag pa'i don de mi sgrub pa min no/ // des na gzhan grags kyi rtags dpe pha rol po la grub pas chog ces pa yang de'i tshad mas grub pa dgos kyi khas blangs tsam gyis mi chog go /

Others assert that the word “therefore”/8/ shows that action exists conventionally, as a premise for the claim that although it is maintained that an eye characterized by action does not see form, this is not to commit the error of proving that which has already been proven. Nevertheless, to take the thesis that is the consequence of his assertion as his intention makes absolutely no sense. Since they do not provide as a reason the assertion that we merely refute the object of negation but do not prove a thesis, it is not the case that the point of the previous refutation was not established. Therefore, to say that it is sufficient that the premises and example are accepted by others is to say that they must be established by their authoritative cognition, but not to say that they merely assert them.
gnyis pa [bdag gam rnam shes lta ba'i byed pa po yin pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.2 Refutation of the thesis that the self or consciousness is the agent of seeing
lta ba nyid kyis lta ba po'ang / / rnam par bshad par shes par bya/ /
5cd. Through seeing itself The analysis of the seer is understood.

lta bas na lta bar byed pa'o zhes lta bar byed ces pa 'dis mig lta ba'i byed pa por sgrub pa ni khas mi len no/ / 'o na ci zhe / 'dis lta bar byed pas na lta ba'o zhes lta bar byed ces pa 'dis mig lta ba'i byed par sgrub pa yin te des na mig byed pa por bzhag nas lta ba'i bya ba dang 'brel ma 'brel brtags pa'i skyon du mi 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig byed par 'gyur ba'i lta ba mig 'dis lta bar byed pa de ni byed pa po yin la 'di yang rang sde ltar rnam shes sam gzhan sde ltar bdag yin yang rung ste de yod pas lta ba'i byed pa po yod na lta ba yang grub pa yin no/ / de la sngar ni dper na shing 'di sus gcod na sta res gcod ces sta re gcod pa por smra ba bzhin du gzugs la sus lta na mig gis lta zhes mig lta ba por khas blangs la 'dir ni lhas byin gyis sta res shing gcod ces lhas byin gcod pa po dang sta re byed par smra ba bzhin du bdag gam rnam shes gang yang rung bas mig 'dis gzugs la lta'o zhes bdag gam rnam shes lta ba po dang mig lta ba'i byed par 'dod pa'o/ /

We do not accept that the fact that the words “it sees” are in the phrase “in virtue of seeing it sees” [4d] proves that the eye is the agent of seeing. Then what is the point? Saying “since it sees by means of this, it sees” [Prasannapadā 39b] establishes that the eye is the instrument of seeing. Thus, there is no error in pursuing an analysis to determine whether or not the eye is related to seeing and accepting it as the agent. That which sees by means of this instrument—seeing, viz., the eye/9/—is the agent. And this is either consciousness according to our schools, or the self according to other schools. Since this does exist, when the agent of seeing is established, seeing is also thereby established. Just as in a previous example the axe is taken as the cutter in the context of the question, “Who cuts this log?” when someone responds, “The axe cuts it”/10/ the eye is taken as the seer in the context of the question, “Who sees form?” when someone responds, “The eye sees.” Here, just as in “Lhejin cuts the log with the axe,” Lhejin is taken as the agent and [121] the axe is taken as the instrument, when it is said “either the self or consciousness sees form with the eye,” either the self or consciousness is taken as the agent and the eye is taken as the instrument.

de la sngar mig lta bar smra ba 'gog pa'i tshe/ lta de rang gi bdag nyid ni/ / zhes sogs kyis sun phyung ba de bzhin du rigs pa de nyid kyis lta ba po gnyis po'ang rnam par bshad pa ste sun phyung bar shes par bya ste/ de yang / lta po rang gi bdag nyid ni/ / lta bas lta ba ma yin nyid/ / gang zhig bdag la mi lta ba/ / de gzhan dag la ji ltar lta/ / zhes 'don pa bsgyur ro/ / 'dir mig lta ba po yin no zhes pa bzhag nas bdag gam rnam shes lta ba po yin no zhes pa de tsam zhig smras pa yin pas sun 'byin mtshungs so/ // skyon gzhan 'di yang yod de lta ba pos lta bar byed na lta ba gsum du thal ba'o/ / gal te lta ba po ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i las gzugs dang byed pa lta ba yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Earlier, at the time of the refutation of the assertion that the eye sees, “That very seeing does not see” [III: 2a] rebutted it. Similarly, it should be noted that the two seers should be explained, or more properly, refuted by the same reasoning. Thus we can rearrange the text: The seer does not see itself Through seeing. How can something that cannot see itself See another?/11/ Here, it is shown that only the self or consciousness is posited as the seer, replacing the eye as seer, and thus the refutation is similarly applicable. Further, there would be another error—the absurdity of having three seeings if a seer sees. Now, suppose someone argued as follows: the seer exists essentially because its object, material form, and its action, seeing, exist.
ma spang lta po yod min te/ / lta ba spangs par gyur kyang ngo*/ /
6. Without detachment from vision there is no seer. Nor is there a seer detached from it.

de gnyis rang bzhin gyis med pa'i phyir lta ba po rang bzhin gyis yod par ga la 'gyur/ de la lta ba po rang bzhin gyis yod na gnyis la mi 'da' bas lta ba ma spangs pa ste de la ltos pa dang bcas pa'i lta ba po 'dod na de rang bzhin gyis yod pa min te grub pa zhig ltos sam ma grub pa zhig ltos dang po ltar na de'i mi rigs te grub zin ni slar yang bsgrub par bya ba min pas yang ltos par mi rigs so/ / 'di yang rang mtshan gyis grub pa la ltos pa 'gog pa yin pas de la ni grub zin slar yang pasgrub dgos pa'i skyon 'ong ste sngar bshad zin to/ /

How could the seer exist essentially when neither of them exists essentially? If the seer existed essentially one could not escape the two alternatives: Even if the seer were posited without detachment, that is to say, in dependence on seeing, it would not exist essentially because it would exist either in dependence as an existent, or in dependence as a nonexistent. The first case makes no sense, because that which is already existent does not need to arise again; therefore, it does not make any sense for it to be dependent. This is also a refutation of the possibility that a thing existing through its own characteristic is dependent, showing that that would commit the error—which has been explained earlier—of requiring the arising of one that has already arisen.

gnyis pa ltar na ltos par 'gal te ri bong gi rwa bzhin no/ / gal te lta ba spangs par gyur pa ste lta ba la ma ltos pa'i lta ba po yod do zhe na/ kyang ngo zhes pas lta ba la ltos pa yod pa min par ma zad ma ltos pa'i lta ba po yang yod pa min te gzhan la mi ltos pa'i phyir nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis ni lta ba po lta ba'i bya ba dang ldan na bya ba gnyis med pa dang mi ldan na lta ba'i bya ba dang bral bas 'gog ste/ lta ba lta nyid ma yin te/ / zhes pa dang don 'dra bar 'chad do/ /

In the second case, it is contradictory for it to be dependent, just like the horn of rabbit. Suppose someone says that it is detached, that is, that the seer exists as a seer without depending on seeing. The “nor” indicates that not only is there no seer dependent on seeing, but also there is no seer independent of seeing, [122] because it is not dependent on another, just like a sky flower. However, Buddhapālita refutes this saying that if the seer performs the action of seeing, then there would be two actions but that there cannot be; and if it does not, then it would be devoid of action. Thus he explains that this verse has a meaning similar to that of “Seeing does not see” [III: 5a] [176b–177a].
gnyis pa [lta ba'i las dang bya ba dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.2 Refutation of the object and action of seeing
lta po med na blta bya dang / / lta ba de dag ga la yod/ /
6cd. Without a seer How can there be seeing or the seen?

gang gi tshe lta ba la ltos ma ltos kyi lta ba po rang bzhin gyis med pa de'i tshe lta ba po med na rgyu med pa'i blta bya dang lta ba de dag ga la yod de rang bzhin gyis med pas de dag yod pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis lta ba po rang bzhin gyis yod par ga la 'grub/

Since there is no seer existing essentially, either dependent on or independent of seeing, how can the seen and seeing exist—since they do not exist essentially—without a cause, the seer? Therefore, how can the seer be established as existing essentially on the ground of their existence?
ci ltar pha dang ma dag las/ / brten nas bu ni 'byung bshad pa/ / de bzhin mig dang gzugs brten nas/ / rnam par shes pa 'byung bar bshad/ /
blta bya lta ba med pa'i phyir/ / rnam par shes la sogs pa bzhi/ / yod min nye bar len la sogs/ / rtsi lta bur na yod par 'gyur/ /
7. From the nonexistence of seeing and the seen it follows that The four—consciousness, etc.—do not exist. Since this is the case, how could such things as The appropriator exist?

'dir smras pa gal te blta bya dang lta ba ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de gnyis kyi 'bras bu yod pa'i phyir ro/ / de la lta ba dang blta bya la brten nas rnam par shes pa 'byung la gsum 'dus pa las reg pa zag pa dang bcas pa 'byung zhing reg pa dang lhan cig 'byung ba ni tshor ba yin la de'i rkyen gyis sred pa yin no/ / 'dir/ ji ltar pha dang ma dag la/ / zhes pa'i tshig sa ba ca da ga ci ga 'a byung ba ni rgya 'grel gzhan gsum la med cing / 'grel pa 'dir yang de la bshad pa ma mdzad la spyan ras gzigs brtul zhugs kyis rtsa she la tshigs bcad bzhi brgya dang zhe dgu yod par bshad pa dang mi 'grig pas dpe ma dag pa las bsgyur bar gsal lo/ /

Here, one might propose that the seen and seeing do exist because their effects exist. Depending on seeing and the seen, consciousness arises; combining these three, contaminated contact arises; that which arises with contact is feeling, and because of that craving arises. We note here that the verse “Just as the birth of a son”/12/ is not found in the other three commentaries/13/ and this commentary/14/ also does not comment on it. And also it is not consistent with Avalokitavata’s statement that Mūlamadhyamakakārikā contains 449 verses. Therefore, it appears that it was translated from a corrupted version.

rnam shes la sogs pa bzhi rang bzhin gyis yod na de gnyis kyang rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur na'ang yod pa ni min te/ lta ba po rang bzhin gyis med pas blta bya dang lta ba gnyis kyang rang bzhin gyis med pa'i phyir rnam par shes pa dang sogs kyis bsdus pa reg pa dang tshor ba dang sred pa bzhi po rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no/ / 'dir sred pa'i rkyen gyis len pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pas rnam shes la sogs pa ni yod de len pa dang srid pa dang skye ba dang rga shi la sogs pa ni de dag las skye ba'i phyir ro zhe na/ gang gi tshe blta bya dang lta ba rang bzhin gyis med pas rnam shes la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis med pa de'i tshe nye bar len pa dang sogs kyis bsdus pa srid pa dang skye rga sogs ji lta bur na rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ //

If the four—consciousness, etc.—did exist essentially, the two could also exist essentially. But that is not the case. Since the seer does not exist essentially, neither do the two—the seen and seeing—exist essentially. Consequently, the four—consciousness and those indicated by “etc.,” viz., contact, feeling, and craving—do not exist essentially. Here one might argue further that since such things are said in sūtra as, “Grasping arises through being caused by craving,” consciousness, etc, exist, because grasping, becoming, rebirth, aging, death, and so forth arise [123] from them. But since the seen and seeing do not exist essentially, consciousness, etc., do not exist essentially. Therefore, how could the appropriator, and the others that are indicated by “such things as”—such things as becoming, rebirth, and aging—exist essentially? It is not possible.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba] ni/
1.2.2 Applying the argument to the other faculties
gal te khyod kyis lta ba ni bkag na nyan pa la sogs pa ni ma bkag pas de rnams yod pa'i phyir dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/
Suppose one argued as follows: You have refuted seeing; however, hearing and so forth are not refuted. Therefore, since they exist, things exist essentially.
lta bas nyan dang sgom pa dang / / myang bar byed dang reg byed yid/ / nyan pa po dang mnyan la sogs/ / rnam par bshad par shes par bya/ /
8. Through the explanation of seeing, Hearing, smelling, tasting, touching, and mind, Hearer and sound, etc., Should also be understood.

nyan pa dang snom pa dang myang bar byed pa dang reg par byed pa dang yid kyis sems par byed pa dang / nyan pa po dang mnyan par bya ba dang sogs kyis bsdus pa snom pa po dang bsnam par bya ba dang myong ba po dang myang bar bya ba dang reg pa po dang reg par bya ba dang sems pa po dang bsam par bya ba rnams rnam par bshad par shes par bya'o/ / gang gis rnam par bshad ce na/ lta ba nyid kyis te ji ltar lta ba bkag pa bzhin du nyan pa sogs lnga dang lta ba po bkag pa bzhin du nyan pa po la sogs pa lnga dang blta bar bya ba bkag pa bzhin du mnyan par bya ba la sogs pa lnga bkag pa yang shes par bya'o/ / de yang / nyan pa rang gi bdag nyid ni/ / de la nyan pa ma yin nyid/ / ces dang snom pa rang gi dang myang byed rang gi dang reg byed rang gi dang sems byed rang gi zhes sogs 'don pa bsgyur ro/ /

Hearing, smelling, tasting, touching, and introspection; the hearer and sound; and those indicated by “etc.,”—viz., the smeller and smell; the taster and taste; the toucher and the tangible; and the thinker and thought—should be understood to have been explained. How have they been explained? Just by “seeing.” Just as seeing is refuted, hearing and the other five should be understood; just as the seer is refuted, the hearer and the others should be understood; and just as the seen is refuted, sound and the other five should be understood. Thus we could rearrange the text: That very hearing does not hear Itself at all. Likewise, smelling does not smell itself, tasting does not taste itself, touching does not touch itself, and thinking does not introspect itself.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar las dang byed pa dang byed pa po drug tshan gsum rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag pa de yang rtog ge tsam gyis bsgrubs so snyam pa dgag pa dang*/ mig gis gzugs mthong ba sogs bkag pa'i gsung rab thams cad kyang rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis/ de la 'phags pa nyan thos ni mig gis rnam par shes par bya ba'i gzugs gang dag 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar byung ba 'di dag la/ rtag pa nyid dam brtan pa nyid dam de bzhin nyid dam gzhan ma yin pa de bzhin nyid dam ma nor ba de bzhin nyid ni 'ga' yang med kyi sgyu ma de ni yod do/ / sgyu mar byas pa de ni yod do/ / sems rmongs par byed pa de ni yod do/ / de ni gyi na zhig yod de snyam du de ltar so sor rtog par byed do zhes gsungs te gzhan lnga yang de dang 'dra'o/

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to rebut the idea that the refutation of the thesis that the three sets of six agents, objects, and actions exist inherently is merely an enterprise of sophists and to demonstrate that all the scriptures—which refute the claim that eye sees form, etc.—are explained by this chapter. The Transcendent Lord has said, The exalted hearers analytically determine that the material form apprehended by the eye [124] in the past, present, and future is without any of these: permanence, stability, reality, immutable reality, and nonerroneous reality. Nonetheless the illusion exists. That which is created as an illusion exists. That which creates mental obscuration exists. How else could it be?/15/ The other five should be understood in the same way.

srid pa 'pho ba'i mdo las kyang*/ mig gis gzugs rnams mi mthong zhing / / yid kyis chos rnams mi shes te/ / gang du 'jig rten mi 'jug pa/ / 'di ni bden pa'i mchog yin no/ / gang du rkyen tshogs pas mthong bar/ / 'dren pa rab tu ston mdzad pa'i/ / sa de don dam 'dzin pa ni/ / nye bar btags pa chub par 'gyur/ / zhes pas ni mig nas yid kyi bar drug gis yul 'dzin pa'i byed pa dang las dang byed pa po rang bzhin gyis stong pa gang la 'jig rten gyi blo mi 'jug pa de ni don dam pa'i bden pa yin te 'gyur gzhan las/ de ni dam pa'i bden pa'o/ / zhes bsgyur ba ltar ro/ / dbang po dang yul la sogs pa'i rkyen tshogs pa'i dbang gis rang rang gi yul 'dzin par bstan pa'i sa de don dam par yod par 'dzin pa ni nye bar btags pa tsam mo zhes bstan to/ / de bzhin du/ mig dang gzugs la brten nas ni/ / mig gi rnam shes 'dir skye yang / / gzugs ni mig la brten ma yin/ / gzugs ni mig la 'pho ba'ang min/ / bdag med mi sdug chos 'di dag / slar yang bdag dang sdug ces brtags/ / med la log par btags pa ste/ / de las mig gi rnam shes 'byung / / rnam shes 'gag dang 'byung ba las/ / rnam shes zad dang 'phel bar mthong / / 'gar yang 'gro 'ong med stong dang / rgyu 'dra rnal 'byor pa yis mthong / / zhes pas ni dbang po dang yul la brten nas rnam shes skye yang dbang po dang yul phan tshun du mi 'pho ba dang skye 'gag byed pa'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong la gang du yang mi 'gro ba sgyu ma bzhin du blta bar gsungs so/ /

According to the Bhava-saṁkrānti-sūtra, Since the eye does not see material form And the mind does not know phenomena, Where there is no mundane engagement There is the supreme truth, [m Do sde dza 176b] and When the conditions are assembled there is seeing, As the teacher has explained. To grasp this ground as ultimate Is to fabricate [Ibid.] According to this, the six from the eye to the mind, the action of grasping of the object, the object, and the agent are empty of essence. Where there is no mundane engagement, this is the ultimate truth. An alternate translation reads, “This is the ultimate truth.”/16/ This all shows that to grasp the demonstrated ground—that agents grasp their respective objects through the power of the assembly of the conditions [125], viz., the sense faculties and their objects—as truly existent is fabrication. Similarly, in Lalitavistara-sūtra, it says, Depending on eye and material form The visual consciousness arises here. However, material form does not depend upon the eye. Material form does not enter the eye. These phenomena are selfless and without beauty Nonetheless, people imagine them to have both self and beauty. They erroneously imagine them to have that which they lack. From this arises the visual consciousness. Through the cessation and arising of consciousness, respectively, The elimination of consciousness and its development are observed. Yogis see nothing as coming and going; Rather as empty and illusionlike./17/ [m Do sde kha 89b] [125] This means that although consciousness depends on the sense faculties and objects, the sense faculties and objects do not replace each other; and arising and ceasing neither come from anywhere nor go anywhere, and should be seen as illusionlike.

nye bar 'khor gyis zhus pa las kyang / mig ni thams cad ldan na mthong 'gyur te/ / mig gis gzugs rnams mthong ba gang yin pa'ang / / mtshan mo rkyen rnams med na mthong mi 'gyur/ / de phyir ldan dang bral ba rnam rtog yin/ / zhes rkyen tshogs pa la brten nas mthong la tshogs pa de bral na mi mthong bas yul mthong mi mthong ni rnam rtog gi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam yin gyi rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis med par bstan to/ / mig ni snang la brten te yid 'ong dang / / yid du mi 'ong sna tshogs gzugs mthong bas/ / de ltar ldan la brten te mthong bas na/ / de phyir mig gis nam yang mthong ba med/ / ces rkyen tshogs pa la brten te mthong bas na mig la rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis gzugs mthong ba nam yang med do zhes 'di dang snga ma gnyis kas rten 'brel gyi rtags kyis rang bzhin bkag go /

It is said in Upālipaṛiprcchā-sūtra, The eye sees when everything is assembled. The material forms that are seen by the eye Are not seen at night in the absence of the conditions. Therefore, assembly and disassembly are conceptual. [dKon brtsegs ca 129a] This shows that the agent sees depending on the assemblage of the conditions and does not see when they are not assembled. Therefore, seeing and not seeing the object are merely conceptually posited, but they do not exist inherently. The eye, depending on light, sees various material forms, Pleasant and unpleasant. It sees in assemblage with these. Therefore, the eye never sees. [Ibid.] Since the eye sees depending on the assemblage of conditions, the eye never sees material form inherently. Thus both this and the previous verse refute essence by reasoning from dependent origination.

yid du 'ong ba'i sgra grag gang yin pa/ / de yang nam yang nang du zhugs pa med/ / de 'gro dmigs su yod pa ma yin te/ / rtog pa'i dbang gis sgra rnams 'byung ba yin/ / zhes yul dbang po'i drung du 'ongs pa dang yul 'dzin gyi sar 'gro ba min kyang yul rnams dbang pos longs spyod pa ni rnam rtog gi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam du bstan to/ / de bzhin du/ glu dang gar dang rol mo'i sgra yang gzung bya min/ / rmi lam lta bu mi mkhas rmongs dang chags pa'i rgyu/ / mi mkhas kun tu rtog la zhen rnams brlag 'gyur zhing / / skye bo byis pa nyon mongs bran bzhin bdag gyur tam/ / zhes gsungs te/

Whatever pleasant sound occurs Never penetrates inside; Nor is the (ear) seen going towards it. Sound appears only out of conceptual thought. [Ibid.] Neither does the object come to the sense faculty, nor does the sense faculty go to the object. Instead, the experience of the object by the sense faculty is shown to be merely conceptually posited. The sound of song, music and dance are not to be grasped. Dreamlike objects are causes of desire for unwise fools. The unwise who are obsessed and conceptualize ruin themselves. Am I going to be like the childish beings, who are slaves of afflictive emotions? [Rāṣṭrapālapaṛipṛccha-sūtra, dKon brtsegs nga 248a]
