'dis ni rang gi sems yul la bden par 'dzin pa'i mtshan 'dzin gyis bcings nas nyon mongs pa'i gzhan dbang du gyur pa mthong ba na/ bdag ni mkhas pa'i riT pas chos 'di dag la rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa rdul tsam yang med par rtogs pa yin na/ byis pa rigs pa'i de kho na nyid la mi mkhas pa nyon mongs kyi bran du gyur pa bzhin du spyod du ga la rung snyam du bsams nas mnyam bzhag tu nam mkha' lta bu'i stong pa nyid dang rjes thob tu sgyu ma lta bu'i stong pa la rnal 'byor du bya bar bstan to/ / de ltar na rab byed 'di yi rigs pa rnams ni gzung bar bya ba dang 'dzin par byed pa dang 'dzin pa po rang bzhin med par ston pa'i gsung rab thams cad lta ba'i mig tu 'phags pas bstsal pa yin pas/mig de rnyed par byas la gsung rab de dag gi de kho na nyid bltas pa las byung ba'i dga' ston nyams su myong bar bya'o/ /

This shows that when one sees that one’s own mind is bound by grasping representations—that it is grasping true existence—[126] one sees that one is under the power of afflictive emotions. One should then think as follows: since I understand through skillful analysis that these phenomena do not have even an iota of inherent existence, how could I behave like a child who lacks skill in analyzing the way things really are and is a slave of afflictive emotions? Thinking like this, one should practice realizing spacelike emptiness in meditative equipoise and illusionlike emptiness in the subsequent state. And so, the arguments of this chapter are the eyes provided by the master to see all of the scriptures presenting the object to be grasped, the means of grasping and the grasper as empty of essence. Therefore, having found this eye, one should experience the joy of seeing the way things really are through those texts.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

yul drug gzung bya dang dbang po drug 'dzin byed dang gang zag drug 'dzin pa por 'jog pa na ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam min par chos de dag gi rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod par 'dzin pa'i 'dzin tshul ngos zin par byas la/ ji ltar bzung ba de ltar yin na ni las dang byed pa dang byed pa po gang yang bzhag sa med par rigs pas gtan la phab pa bzhin nges par bya/ de nas ni chos bco brgyad po thams cad rang gi ngo bos ma grub bzhin du de dang der snang ba'i sgyu ma lta bu'i byed pa dang las dang byed pa por 'bad med du 'chad par 'gyur ro/ // de yi tshe mig lta ba sogs su 'jog pa thams cad ni sgyu ma lta bu'i don de kho na la ches shin tu 'thad do snyam du nges pa drang bar bya ste/ rigs pas dpyod pa ni mig la sogs pa la rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin yod med 'tshol ba yin gyi yod med tsam 'tshol ba min pas dpyad nas ma rnyed pa na rang bzhin yod pa khegs kyi mig la sogs pa khegs pa gtan ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

When the six objects are posited as that which is to be grasped, the six sense faculties are posited as the means by which they are grasped, and the six kinds of person are posited as the graspers, one should recognize that the mode of grasping of these phenomena is not as merely posited through the power of nominal convention, but that they are grasped as existing inherently. One should ascertain, as established by arguments, that there would be no grounds for positing agent, object, and instrument if they existed in the way that they are grasped. Thereafter, it will spontaneously become apparent that all of these eighteen phenomena, although they do not exist inherently, appear respectively as illusionlike agent, object, and instrument. Then, it should be ascertained that all that is posited, such as the eye, seeing, etc., are completely tenable only as illusionlike objects. This rational analysis is an investigation into whether or not such things as the eye exist inherently, but not an investigation into whether or not they merely exist. Therefore, when they are not found through the analysis, their essential existence is refuted, but such things as the eye are not refuted at all.

de skad du yang brgya pa'i 'grel pa las/ gal te mig la sogs pa rnams mi srid na de yi phyir ji ltar mig la sogs pa'i dbang po 'di rnams las kyi rnam par smin pa'i ngo bor rnam par bzhag ce na/ ci kho bo cag gis las kyi rnam par smin pa'i ngo bo nyid bkag gam/ gal te mig la sogs pa rnams 'gog pa sgrub pas de ji ltar ma bkag ce na/ kho bo cag gi rnam par dpyod pa ni rang bzhin tshol ba lhur byed pa nyid kyi phyir ro/ kho bo cag ni 'dir dngos po rnams rang gi ngo bos grub pa 'gog gi mig la sogs pa byas shing rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba las kyi rnam par smin pa nyid ni mi 'gog go / de'i phyir de yod pas gang zhig rnam par smin pa nyid du bsnyad pa mig la sogs pa yod pa nyid do/ / zhes 'di tsam zhig 'gog la 'di tsam zhig mi 'gog pa'i sa mtshams shin tu gsal bar gsungs so/ des na 'di'i yod tshul ni lta po lta ba la brten cing / / lta ba nyid kyang lta po la/ / brten nas 'byung ba ma gtogs pa/ / 'grub pa'i rgyu ni ma mthong ngo / / zhes gsungs pa ltar yin la des lhag ma yang shes par bya'o/ / rab byed gong mar bshad pa'i rigs pa rnams kyis skye mched la bden pa 'gog nus mod kyang lta ba la sogs pa'i rang bzhin 'gog pa'i rigs pa thun mong ma yin pa rnams rtogs par bya ba'i phyir du/ rab byed 'di gsungs te de ni rab byed gzhan la yang shes par bya'o/ / de 'dra ba des ni de kho na nyid la dpyod pa'i shes rab kyi khyad par mtha' yas pa 'phel bar 'gyur zhing yul drug la longs spyod pa thams cad sgyu ma'i skyes bu yul la longs spyod pa bzhin du 'char bar 'gyur ro/ /

[127] As the commentary to CatuḥŚataka says, Supposed one asked, “If such things as the eye were impossible, then how could these sensory faculties, like the visual faculties, be posited as the results of karma?” We would reply, “Do we refute the results of karma?” Suppose he then asked, “Since you have proven that such things as the eye are refuted, how can you not have refuted those results?” We would then reply, “This is because our analysis is focused on the investigation of essence. We refute the inherent existence of entities, but we do not refute such things as the eye as functioning, or as dependently originated, or as the effects of karma. Therefore, since they exist, that which is called the result, that is, such things as the eye, indeed exist. [dBu ma ya 201b] This clearly explains the demarcation drawn between what is refuted and what is not refuted. Therefore their mode of existence is as presented here: The seer depends on seeing. Seeing also depends on the seer. Apart from this No cause is seen for their existence./18/ Through this, the rest should be understood. Although the arguments presented in the earlier chapters can refute the true existence of the faculties, this chapter has been composed so that one might understand the specific arguments refuting the essence of such things as seeing. This should be understood in the context of other chapters as well. Through such analysis, one will develop boundless wisdom, particularly with respect to the analysis of the way things really are; and it will be apparent that all experience of the six kinds of object is like that of an illusory person experiencing an illusory object.
dbang po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa gsum pa'o// //
This is the third chapter called “the examination of the sense faculties.”
dbang po brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs bcad brgyad kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa gsum pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the third chapter, having eight verses, called “the examination of the sense faculties.”
CHAPTER IV. Examination of the Aggregates
gnyis pa phung po la chos bdag dgag pa
we now turn to the second part—the refutation of the phenomenal self of the aggregates [128:2].
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
There are three parts to this chapter: explaining the meaning of the chapter; confirmation by citation from definitive sūtras; summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ gal te dbang po rnams bkag mod kyang phung po lnga ma bkag pa'i phyir yod do/ / de yod na dbang po rnams kyang de'i nang du 'dus pa'i phyir rang bzhin gyis yod do/ / 'di dgag pa la gsum/ gzugs phung rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / rigs pa de gzhan la sbyar ba/ rtsod pa dang 'chad pa'i tshe lan gdab tshul lo/ //

In response to this previous analysis one might say, “Even though the sense faculties have been refuted, since the five aggregates have not been refuted, it follows that they exist. If they exist, since the sense faculties are included among them, it follows that they exist essentially.” The refutation of this argument has three parts: refutation of the essential existence of the form aggregate, applying this argument to the other aggregates, the mode of reply to the arguments advanced by others.
dang po [gzugs phung rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the form aggregate
['di] la gnyis/ / don gzhan du yod pa la rgyu 'bras dgag / yod med dang 'dra mi 'dra la rgyu 'bras dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of cause and effect with respect to their being different in entity and refutation of cause and effect being existent or nonexistent and the same or different.
dang po [don gzhan du yod pa la rgyu 'bras dgag] ni/
1.1.1 Refutation of cause and effect with respect to their being different in entity

'dir chos mngon pa las/ gzugs gang yin pa ci yang rung ste de dag thams cad 'byung ba chen po bzhi dag dang 'byung ba chen po bzhi rgyur byas pa'o/ /zhes sa'i khams la sogs pa bzhi ni rgyu'i gzugs 'byung ba bzhi dang */ mig la sogs pa'i dbang po lnga dang gzugs kyi skye mched nas 'bras gzugs kyi reg bya'i bar lnga la sogs pa ni 'bras bu'i gzugs su gsungs la rgyu 'bras rang mtshan par 'dzin pa 'gog pa'i dam bca' ni/

According to the Abhidharma, form, whatever it might be, either is one of the four great elements or is caused by the four great elements. Having said that, the earth principle/1/ and the others of the four are the causal forms, the four elements. The five—the sense faculties, eye, etc., and the five, from the form faculties to tangible resultant form—are described as the resultant form [Śālistambhasūtra, mDo sde tsha 124a]. When it is described like this, cause and effect are grasped as having their own characteristics, and the thesis by means of which we refute this is
gzugs kyi rgyu ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs ni dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / gzugs zhes bya ba ma gtogs par/ / gzugs kyi rgyu yang mi snang ngo / /
1. Apart from the cause of form, Form cannot be conceived. Apart from form, The cause of form is not apparent.

mig la sogs pa'i gzugs kyi rgyu 'byung ba bzhi ni ma gtogs par te de dag las rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'i 'bras bu'i gzugs ni dmigs par mi 'gyur la/ der ma zad 'bras bu'i gzugs zhes bya ba ma gtogs par te de dag las ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'i 'bras bu'i gzugs kyi rgyu yang mi snang ngo*/ // dam bca' de gnyis sgrub pa ni/ /

Apart from the cause of the form of such things as the eye—the four elements—inherently existent distinct resultant form cannot be perceived. Not only that, but apart from what is called resultant form, the cause of resultant form is not apparent as inherently distinct from them. To prove these two theses, it says,
gzugs kyi rgyu ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs na gzugs ni rgyu med par/ / thal bar 'gyur te don gang yang / / rgyu med pa ni gang na'ang med/ /
2. If apart from the cause of form there were form, Form would, absurdly, be without a cause. But nowhere is there a thing Without a cause.

mig la sogs pa'i gzugs kyi rgyu ni ma gtogs par 'bras bu'i gzugs ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gzugs de ni rgyu med par thal bar 'gyur te de la ltos pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / don te dngos po gang zhig rgyu med pa ni gang na'ang med pas rgyu med kyi gzugs yod par mi rung ngo / //

If the resultant form existed inherently apart from the cause of such things as the eye, [129] the absurd consequence would follow that form would be a without a cause, because this contradicts its dependency. Since there cannot be anything—entity—without a cause, form without a cause makes no sense.
gal te gzugs ni ma gtogs par/ / gzugs kyi rgyu zhig yod na ni/ / 'bras bu med pa'i rgyur 'gyur te/ / 'bras bu med pa'i rgyu med do/ /
3. If apart from form There were a cause of form, It would be a cause without an effect. But there are no causes without effects.

gal te 'bras bu'i gzugs ni ma gtogs par gzugs kyi rgyu ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni 'bras bu med pa'i rgyur 'gyur te/ rgyu rgyu nyid du rnam par 'jog pa'i rgyu ni 'bras bu 'jug pa yin na ngo bos tha dad par grub na 'bras bu la mi ltos la de lta na 'bras bu 'jug pa med do/ / 'bras bu med pa'i rgyu ni rgyur med de rgyur rnam 'jog gi rgyu med pa'i phyir nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ // de gnyis kas kyang bzlog pa 'phen pas dam bca' gnyis sgrub par gsungs so/ / rgyu 'bras rang bzhin gcig pa 'gog pa ni rang sde 'gog pa'i skabs yin pas ma gsungs la rang bzhin tha dad yin na ltos pa mi 'thad pas rgyu med du thal ba 'phen pa'i phyir sngar gzhan skye bkag pa'i rigs pa dang mi 'dra'o/ /

If apart from resultant form, a cause of form existed essentially, that would be a cause without an effect because what it is for a cause to have the defining characteristic of a cause is to bring about an effect; but if they were inherently different the effect would not depend on it, and in that case it would not bring about its effect. A cause without an effect is a non-cause; like a sky flower, it does not have the defining characteristic of a cause. These two reductios each project a contrapositive, each of which in turn establishes a thesis. The refutation of cause and effect having the same nature, since it is directed at our own schools, is not mentioned here. If they had different natures, the dependency would make no sense. Thus he demonstrates that the absurd consequence of being without a cause would follow. So this is different from the previous argument refuting arising from another.
gnyis pa [yod med dang 'dra mi 'dra la rgyu 'bras dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation of cause and effect being existent or nonexistent and the same or different
gzugs yod na yang gzugs kyi ni/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur nyid/ / gzugs med na yang gzugs kyi ni/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur nyid/ /
4. When form exists, A cause of form is not tenable. When form is nonexistent, A cause of form is not tenable.

gzhan yang 'byung ba rnams gzugs kyi rgyur rtog na gnyis las mi 'da' bas de la gzugs yod pa na yang gzugs kyi rgyu ni 'thad par mi 'gyur te yod pa la rgyus slar yang ci zhig bya ste dgos pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / gzugs med pa na yang gzugs kyi rgyu ni 'thad par mi 'gyur te med na de gang rgyur 'gyur yang gnyis ni phan tshun bsdu ba'o/ / 'di rkyen brtag tu gsungs zin mod kyang 'dir yang skabs su bab pas gsungs so/ /

Moreover, if the elements are thought to be the cause of form, there are only two alternatives: if form existed, that there is a cause of form could not be tenable. For an existent, what would an additional cause do, as it is not necessary? If form were nonexistent, then a cause of form would be incoherent. If it were nonexistent, of what would the cause be a cause? Cause and effect are mutually implicative. Although this was said in the examination of conditions, since it is relevant, it is mentioned here.
gal te gzugs kyi rgyu mi 'thad kyang 'bras bu'i gzugs ni yod la de yod na rgyu yang yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/
Suppose one argues that, although a cause of form makes no sense, the resultant form exists, and that since it exists, its cause must exist.
rgyu med pa yi gzugs dag ni/ / 'thad par mi rung rung min nyid/ / de phyir gzugs kyi rnam par rtog / 'ga' yang rnam par rtag mi bya/ /
5. Form itself without a cause Is neither possible nor tenable. Therefore, never conceptualize Ideas about form.

gzugs kyi rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pa ni bshad zin la de lta na rgyu med pa'i 'bras bu'i gzugs yod pa ni 'thad par mi rung ngo / // rung min nyid ces brtags nas nges gzung dang bcas pa'i dgag pa gnyis gsungs pas ni dngos po rnams rgyu la mi ltos pa'i rgyu med kyi phyogs shin tu tha chad par ston par mdzad do/ / gang gi phyir gzugs kyi rgyu ma gtogs par gzugs mi dmigs pa dang gzugs yod med gnyis ka la rgyu mi 'thad pa dang rgyu med pa'i gzugs med pa de'i phyir rnal 'byor pa de nyid gzigs pas gzugs kyi rnam par rtog pa thogs bcas thogs med dang bstan yod bstan med sogs 'ga' yang rnam par brtag par mi bya ba ste mi 'os so/ / sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis khyod lta bu de kho na rtogs par 'dod pa mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can gyis gzugs kyi rnam rtog 'ga' yang brtag par mi rigs te gnas med pa la bsam pa ji ltar rigs zhes 'chad do/ /

It has already been explained that the cause of form is essentially nonexistent. Therefore, without a cause, the existence of resultant form does not make sense. Saying “neither possible…” by using two negations so emphatically, [130] the position of causelessness—that no entities depend upon causes—is presented as the stupidest idea ever. Since apart from the cause of form, form cannot be conceived or observed, since it makes no sense for there to be a cause either of existent or of nonexistent form, and since there is no causeless form, a practitioner who realizes the way things really are should never conceptualize ideas such as the solidity, nonsolidity, visibility, or invisibility of form. Buddhapālita says, “Somebody wise like you, who wants to realize the way things really are, should never conceptualize any idea about form. For how can you think about something with no locus?” [178b]/2/
'bras bu rgyu dang 'dra ba zhes/ / bya ba 'thad pa ma yin te/ / 'bras bu rgyu dang mi 'dra zhes/ / bya ba'ang 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
6. The assertion that the cause and effect are similar Makes no sense. The assertion that they are not similar Makes no sense.

gzhan yang 'byung ba rgyur rtog na rang dang 'dra ba'i 'bras bu sgrub pa'am mi 'dra ba'i 'bras bu sgrub grang / 'bras bu'i gzugs rgyu 'byung ba dang 'dra ba zhes bya bar ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'thad pa ma yin te 'byung ba bzhi ni sra gsher dro zhing g.yo ba yin la mig la sogs pa'i dbang po lnga ni mig gi rnam shes la sogs pa'i rten gzugs dang ba dang / phyi rol gzugs la sogs pa'i skye mched ni mig gi shes pa la sogs pas gzung bar bya ba yin gyi 'byung ba rnams kyi rang bzhin can min pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ni rgyu 'bras gnyis 'dra ba de ngo bo nyid kyis yin na 'dra ba de rgyu la rag mi las pas cha gcig gis 'dra na cha thams cad kyis 'dra dgos par ston pa'o/ /

Moreover, if the elements are considered as causes, do they produce effects similar to or different from themselves? It would not make sense to say that there is inherently existent resultant form that is similar to its cause, an element, because the four elements are solid, liquid, hot, and mobile, whereas the five sense faculties such as the eye, are the clear forms that constitute the basis of such things as the visual consciousness. The faculties of external form, etc./3/ are to be grasped by such things as visual consciousness, but they do not have the nature of the elements. This shows that if the cause and effect are inherently similar, that similarity would not be dependent on a cause. Thus, if they were partly similar, they should be completely similar.

'jig rten las 'das par bstod pa las kyang / 'byung rnams mig gzung ma yin na/ / de byung mig gzung ji ltar zhes/ gzugs la de skad gsungs pa na/ / khyod kyis gzugs kyi 'dzin pa bzlog / ces 'byung ba mig gis mi mthong na de las byung ba'i sngo ser sogs kyang mi mthong bar bstan te/ de gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis grub na mig gis mthong mi mthong yang mtshungs dgos pa'i rigs pa'o/ / sa lu'i sa bon la sogs pa sa bon rigs mthun rnams rgyu 'bras su ma mthong bas rgyu mtshan 'dis kyang 'bras bu rgyu dang 'dra ba mi 'thad par gsungs te rigs 'dra gcig rgyu 'bras min par mthong na 'dra ba gzhan yang rgyu 'bras yin pa 'gog pa 'di yang sngar bshad pa'i gnad kyis yin no/ / 'bras bu rgyu dang mi 'dra zhes bya ba'ang 'thad pa ma yin te rgyu dang mi 'dra yang rgyu 'bras su ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa rung na mi 'dra ba thams cad kyang rgyu 'bras su 'gyur ro/

As it says in Nāgārjuna’s Lokātītastava, Since the elements are not perceived by the eye How could that to which they give rise be perceived by the eye? When form is explained in this way, Your grasping of form is undone./4/ [5] This shows that since the elements are not perceived by the eye, the blue, yellow, etc., which are arisen from them are also not perceived. This argument shows that if they existed inherently, they should be similar with respect to whether they are seen or not seen by the eye. [131] Seeds of the same kind, such as rice seeds, are not seen as cause and effect. This argument also shows that it does not make sense for the cause and effect to be similar. When one such pair of things of the same kind are seen not to be causes and effects, this negates other things so related being causes and effects. This is also implied by the earlier explanation. Nor does it make sense to say that the effect is not similar to the cause. This is because if, even though it were not similar to the cause, they could be cause and effect inherently, then any things not similar to one another could be cause and effect.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de gzhan la sbyar ba] ni/
1.2 Applying this argument to the other aggregates
tshor dang 'du shes 'du byed dang / / sems dang dngos po thams cad kyang / / rnam pa dag ni thams cad du/ / gzugs nyid kyi ni rim pa mtshungs/ /
7. Feelings, discriminations, dispositions, Consciousness and all such things Should be thought of in every way In the same way as form.

tshor ba dang 'du shes dang 'du byed dang sems kyang mtshungs pa ste 'dra bar shes par bya'o// / gang dang na gzugs kyi phung po dang ngo / / ji ltar na gzugs phung la rang bzhin 'gog pa nyid kyis ni rim pa ste 'gog pa'i tshul ji lta ba bzhin du rnam pa thams cad du phung po lhag ma bzhi la yang sbyar ro/ / de yang gzugs la rang gi rgyu las de nyid dang gzhan du dpyad nas bkag pa bzhin du tshor ba dang reg pa gnyis dang rnam par shes pa dang lhan cig 'byung ba'i 'du shes dang ma rig pa dang 'du byed gnyis dang 'du byed dang rnam shes gnyis la yang de nyid dang gzhan du dpyad nas dgag par bya'o/ / de bzhin du yod med dang rgyu 'bras 'dra mi 'dra yang sbyar te rnam pa thams cad du zhes gsungs pas so/ / der ma zad dngos po ste mtshan mtshon dang rgyu 'bras dang yan lag dang yan lag can la sogs pa thams cad kyang gzugs la dpyad pa gsum byas pa dang rnam pa thams cad du mtshungs par sbyar ro/ /

Feelings, discriminations, dispositions, and consciousness should be understood in the same way, that is, similarly. To what? To the form aggregate. In what way? In the way the essence of the form aggregate is refuted: exactly the same mode should be applied to the remaining four aggregates. Just as the existence of form is refuted by analyzing to determine whether it is the same as or different from its cause, by thoroughly examining whether the pairs—feeling and sensation, consciousness and the discriminations that arise with it, ignorance and the dispositions, dispositions and consciousness—are the same or different, their existence should be refuted. By saying “in every way,” it indicates that analysis in terms of existence and nonexistence, cause and effect, and similarity and dissimilarity should all be applied. Not only that, but the three analyses of form should be applied in every way to all “things” such as characteristic and characterized, cause and effect, part and whole, and all other such things.
gsum pa [rtsod pa dang 'chad pa'i tshe lan gdab tshul] ni/
1.3 The mode of reply to arguments advanced by others
stong pa nyid kyis brtsad byas tshe/ / gang zhig lan 'debs smra byed pa/ / de yi thams cad lan bdun btab min/ / bsgrub par bya dang mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
8. When an argument is advanced on the grounds of emptiness, If someone were to offer a reply, Any such reply will fail, since it will presuppose Exactly what is to be proven.

gang gi phyir dbu ma pa ni chos gcig rang bzhin gyis stong par ston pa de bzhin du chos gzhan thams cad kyang ston par 'dod pa de'i phyir/ rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid smra ba rgyur byas pa nyid kyis gzhan gyi phyogs sun 'byin pa'i brtsad pa gzugs rang bzhin gyis med do zhes dgag pa byas pa'i tshe/ stong pa nyid ma yin par smra ba gang zhig gal te lan gzhan du re zhig tshor ba la sogs pa ni yod la de bzhin du gzugs kyang yod do zhes smra bar byed na/ de ltar byed pa de yi de lta bu de thams cad ni yang dag pa'i lan btab pa min te/ tshor ba la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa yang gzugs rang bzhin gyis yod pa bsgrub bya yin pa dang bsgrub dgos su mtshungs par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / phyir rgol gyi de 'dra'i tshig de bsgrub bya dang mtshungs pas de'i lan thams cad la dbu ma pas sgrub byed bsgrub bya dang mtshungs pa'i ma grub pa yin no zhes brjod par bya bar slob dpon gyis slob par mdzad do/ //

The mādhyamika maintains that just as he presents one thing as essentially empty, he presents all things in the same way. Thus, just by asserting the thesis that things are essentially empty—by advancing the argument—the [132] opponent’s position is refuted, just by the argument that form is essenceless. Nonetheless, the proponent of nonemptiness “offers a reply” that since other things, such as feeling, exist, form must exist as well. “Any such reply” is inapposite. This is because the essential existence of such things as feeling “need to be proven” just as much as the essential existence of form. The master says this in order to explain that the mādhyamika can respond to any of these oppenents’ arguments by pointing out that they are invalid because they “presuppose what is to be proven.”
stong pa nyid kyis bshad byas tshe/ / gang zhig skyon 'dogs smra byed pa/ / de yi thams cad skyon btags min/ / bsgrub par bya dang mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
9. When an explanation is made through emptiness, Whoever would find fault with it Will find no fault, since any such criticism will presuppose Exactly what is to be proven.

de bzhin du stong pa nyid kyis bshad pa byas pa'i tshe yang slob ma lta bu gang zhig skyon 'dogs pa smra bar byed cing rgol bar byed pa de mi brgal ba de thams cad kyang skyon btaT pa min te/ bsgrub par bya ba dang mtshungs par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / brgya pa las kyang / dngos po gcig gi lta po gang / / de ni kun gyi lta por bshad/ / gcig gi stong nyid gang yin pa/ / de ni kun gyi stong pa nyid/ / ces gsungs so/ / tshigs bcad 'di gnyis ni rab byed thams cad kyi khongs su gtogs par shes par bya'o/ /

In the same way, when an explanation is made through emptiness, if someone such as a student advances a criticism, none of his arguments will locate any error because they presuppose exactly what is to be proven. As it says in the Catuḥśataka: He who sees one thing Sees all things. Since one thing is empty, All things are empty. [VIII: 16] “These two verses should be understood as appended to every chapter” [Buddhapālita 180a].
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar phung po rang bzhin gyis stong par nges pa'i don gyi lung gis kyang grub pa dang de ltar ston pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya bar bstan pa'i phyir nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam ni/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i snying po las/ rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zab mo spyad pa spyod par 'dod pa des 'di ltar rnam par blta bar bya ste phung po lnga po de dag kyang rang bzhin gyis stong par rnam par yang dag par rjes su blta'o/ / zhes gsungs shing /

A briefindication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that definitive sūtras also prove the aggregates to be empty through their very nature, and to show that the explanations of all of these sūtras are contained in this chapter. The Heart Sūtra says, A son or daughter of noble lineage who desires to engage in the profound practice of the perfection of wisdom should do so in this way:…The five aggregates should also be correctly seen to be empty of essence. [Sher phyin ka 145a] [133]

nyan thos la bstan pa'i mdo las kyang / gzugs ni dbu ba rdos pa 'dra/ / tshor ba chu bur dag dang mtshungs/ / 'du shes smig rgyu 'dra ba ste/ / 'du byed rnams ni chu shing bzhin/ / rnam shes sgyu ma lta bu zhes/ / nyi ma'i gnyen gyis bka' stsal to/ / zhes gsungs so/ / khyad par du chos gcig rang bzhin gyis stong pa bzhin du gzhan thams cad kyang de ltar blta ba ni nam mkha' mdzod kyi ting nge 'dzin gyi mdo las/ chos gcig gis ni chos rnams thams cad sgyu ma dang / / smig rgyu dang 'dra gzung byar med cing gsog dang ni/ / rdzun zhing ther zug min par rjes su rtogs 'gyur ba/ / de ni ring por mi thogs byang chub snying por 'gro/ / zhes dang*/

The Sūtra addressed to the Śrāvakas says, Form is like a bubble. Feeling is said to be like an emerging spring. Perception is like mirage. Dispositions are like a plantain. Consciousness is said to be like an illusion. So said the illustrious one./5/ [Mãñjuśrīvikrīḍitasūtra, m Do sde ka 239b and dKon brtsegs ca 272a] In particular, the Gaganagañja-paripṛcchā-sūtra shows that just as any one thing is empty by nature, all other things should be seen in the same way: Whoever understands through one phenomenon that all phenomena are like an illusion, like a mirage, and are ungraspable, unreal, false, and not enduring without delay enters into the essence of enlightenment. [m Do sde pa 281a]/6/

ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang / ji ltar khyod kyis bdag gi 'du shes ni/ / shes pa de bzhin kun la blos sbyar bya/ / chos rnams thams cad de yi ngo bo nyid/ / rnam par dag pa nam mkha' lta bu yin/ / gcig gis kyang ni thams cad shes/ / gcig gis kyang ni thams cad mthong / / ji snyed mang po bshad byas kyang*/ / de la dregs pa skye ba med/ / ces gsungs te/ nga'o snyam pa'i gzhi bdag la rang bzhin btsal bas ma rnyed pa'i gang zag gi bdag med rtogs tshul de nyid chos gzhan kun la yang sbyar bar gsungs pas/ rim pa yang de ltar yin la bdag med tshul yang chos dang gang zag mtshungs par gsungs so/ /

The Samādhirāja-sūtra also says, You should apply your understanding Of the perception of the self to all. That nature of all phenomena Is perfect, just like the sky. [m Do sde da, 44a]/7/ Through one, all are understood. Through one, all are seen. Although many varieties are spoken of, No pride is arisen. [m Do sde da, 41a] This is the order of analysis. The mode of realization of the selflessness of the person that arises after a search that does not find the essence of the self, which is the basis of “I am,” should apply to all phenomena. This is the order of realization, but the mode of selflessness of the person and that of phenomena are explained to be similar.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/ /
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

de ltar phung po'i rgyu 'bras gsungs pa la ming du btags pa tsam min par rang gi ngo bos yod par 'dzin pa'i 'dzin stangs ltar yod na rgyu 'bras gtan mi rung bar rigs pas gtan la dbab la de nas ming du btags pa tsam la 'byung ba 'byung 'gyur dang reg tshor la sogs pa thams cad ches 'thad do snyam du snang phyogs kyi nges pa dang stong phyogs kyi nges pa gnyis phan tshun gcig gcig gi grogs su 'gro ba'i rten 'byung gi rigs pa la blo sbyang bar bya'o/ /

As the causes and effects of the aggregates have been explained, one should establish by reasoning that cause and effect make no sense at all if they exist as they are grasped—as existing inherently, without being merely nominally imputed. Thereafter, one should train one’s mind in reasoning which shows, through dependent origination, by the mutual reinforcement of the ascertainment of their aspects of emptiness and of appearance, that only in the context of nominal imputation do the elements and that which is arisen from elements—such things as contact and feeling—make sense.
phung po brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bzhi pa'o//
This is the fourth chapter called “the examination of the aggregates.”
phung po brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa dgu'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bzhi pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the fourth chapter, having nine verses, called “the examination of the aggregates.”
CHAPTER V. Examination of the Elements
gsum pa khams la chos bdag dgag pa
we now turn to the third part: the refutation of the self of phenomena with respect to the elements. [134:5]
['di] la gsum/ rab tu byed pa'i gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /

This chapter constitutes the third part. There are three parts to this chapter: explanation of the meaning of the chapter, confirmation by citation from definitive sūtras, and summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab tu byed pa'i gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa khams rnams ni ma bkag pa'i phyir dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang rgyal po chen po skyes bu gang zag 'di ni khams drug pa'o/ / zhes sa chu me rlung nam mkha' rnam shes kyi khams drug dang / de dag gi mtshan nyid sra gsher dro zhing g.yo ba mi sgrib pa rnam par shes par byed pa yang bstan la/ rang bzhin med na mtshan nyid bstan pa mi rigs pas mtshan nyid yod pa'i phyir khams rnams rang bzhin gyis yod la de lta na khams bzhin du phung po dang skye mched kyang rang bzhin gyis yod do/ / gal te khams rnams rang bzhin gyis yod na gzhan gnyis kyang de ltar yod na'ang de dag ni rang zhin gyis med do/ / ji ltar med ce na/ 'di la gnyis/ khams drug rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag/yod med kyi mthar lta ba smad pa'o/ /

Here, one might say that since the elements have not been refuted, and since the Transcendent Lord has said, “Great Emperor, this person comprises six elements,” [Pitāputrasamāgama-sūtra, dKon brtsegs nga 127b], and thus demonstrated the six elements—earth, water, air, fire, space, and consciousness—and their characteristics—solidity, liquidity, mobility, heat, unobstructedness, and awareness—that without essence, the presentation of the characteristics does not make sense. Therefore, since the characteristics exist, the elements exist essentially. And so, just as do the elements, the senses and other faculties exist essentially. If indeed the elements existed essentially, the other two could also exist in the same manner, but they do not exist essentially. In what way do they not? This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the six elements and condemning the extreme views of reification and nihilism.
dang po [khams drug rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the six elements
['di] la gnyis/ nam mkha'i khams rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / rigs pa de khams lhag ma la yang sbyar ba'o/ /
The section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of space and applying this argument to the remainder of the elements.
dang po [nam mkha'i khams rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of space
['di] la gsum/ nam mkha'i khams la mtshan mtshon dgag / dngos po dang dngos med du grub pa dgag / bkag pa rnams kyi mjug bsdu ba'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of characteristic and characterized in space, the refutation of the existence of space as an entity and as a nonentity, and drawing conclusions from the refutations.
dang po [nam mkha'i khams la mtshan mtshon dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation of characteristic and characterized in space
['di] la gsum/ mtshan gzhi dgag / mtshan nyid dgag / mjug bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has three parts: the refutation of the basis of characteristics, refutation of characteristics, and drawing of conclusions.
dang po [mtshan gzhi dgag]
1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of the basis of characteristics
['di] la gnyis/ mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag / des mtshan gzhi khegs par bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of characterization and demonstration that thereby the basis of characteristics is refuted. [135]
dang po [mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag]
1.1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of characterization
['di] la gnyis/ snga phyi la brtaT nas mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag / mtshan nyid yod med la brtags nas mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: refutation of characterization through the analysis in terms of priority and posteriority and refutation of characterization through the analysis of characterization in terms of the existence and nonexistence of characteristics.
dang po [snga phyi la brtaT nas mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of characterization through the analysis in terms of priority and posteriority
shes rab nam mkha'i mtshan nyid snga rol na/ / nam mkha' cung zad yod mi yin/ / gal te mtshan las snga gyur na/ / mtshan nyid med pa thal bar 'gyur/ /
1. Prior to a characteristic of space There is not the slightest space. If it existed prior to the characteristic Then it would, absurdly, exist without a characteristic.

mdo las sa'i khams dang por gsungs mod kyang 'dir dang po nam mkha'i khams rang bzhin gyis grub pa bkag pa ni/ 'jig rten na nam mkha' stong par grags shing khams gzhan rnams de ltar ma grags pas grags pa'i don gyis ma grags pa bsgrub pa'i phyir nam mkha'i mtshan nyid snga rol na zhes sogs gsungs so/ / 'dir rang gzhan gyi sde pa su yang mtshan nyid las mtshan gzhi snga bar mi 'dod pas nam mkha'i mtshan nyid kyi snga rol na nam mkha' med par sgrub pa mi rigs so zhe na/ gzhan dag mtshan nyid las mtshan gzhi snga bar mi 'dod pas de med pa tsam zhig ni mi sgrub bo/ /

In sūtra, the earth element is explained first. However, here, the essential existence of space is refuted first, since ordinary people know space to be empty, but the other elements are not so known. So through that commonly known fact, what is not yet known is established, and so it says “Prior to the characteristic of space.” Here, suppose someone were to argue that since neither we, nor those of any other schools, maintain that the characterized is prior to the characteristic, it is therefore inappropriate to establish that space does not exist prior to the characteristic of space. We reply that even though the others do not maintain that the characterized exists prior to the characteristic, its mere nonexistence is not established.

'o na ci zhe na/ 'di ni bud d+ha pA li ta las gal te nam mkha'i mtshan nyid kyi snga rol na nam mkha' zhes bya ba cung zad cig yod na ni/ de la nam mkha' 'di yi mtshan nyid ni 'di yin no zhes bstan pa yang rigs pa zhig na/ zhes snga phyi ba de yod na de ltar ston pa rigs la med na mi rigs zhes phyi ma 'thad na snga ma de'i khyab byed du bstan nas khyab byed 'gog pa'o/ / de yang mdo nas mi sgrib pa nam mkha'i mtshan nyid du gsungs pa tsam zhig rang yang 'dod pas pha rol pos mtshan gzhi nam mkha' la/ mi sgrib pa mtshan nyid du 'jug par gsungs pa de rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis mtshan mtshon yin par 'dod pa ltar na snga phyi de yod dgos zhes ston pa'o/ // de ltar dgos pa'i rgyu mtshan ni mtshan nyid 'jug pa'i dus ni gsum du nges la dus mnyam pa la 'jug pa ni mtshan nyid bcas la min zhes par 'gog cing / mtshan nyid snga zhing mtshan gzhi phyi ba la mtshan nyid 'jug pa dang de las bzlog pa la mtshan nyid 'jug pa gnyis phyi ma 'gog dka' ste/ 'jug gzhi sngar yod pa la 'jug pa po phyis 'jug pa'i dogs pa che la 'jug sa sngar med par nges na sngar zhugs par 'dzin pa chung ba'i phyir ro/ / des na mtshan nyid kyi snga rol du mtshan gzhi yod pa tsam 'gog par mdzad do/ /

So what are we doing here? To quote the Buddhapālita, “If prior to the characteristic of space, even the slightest ‘space,’ were to exist, then it would be possible to demonstrate that this is the characteristic of this space” [180a]. He means that if they existed sequentially, such a demonstration would be possible; but since it is not, it is not be possible. The latter (space and its characteristic not being sequential) is coherent. And since the former (characteristic and characterized in general being sequential) would be its superordinate category, this shows that the coherence of the superordinate category is refuted. We also go as far as accepting the sūtra’s explanation of the characteristic of space as nonobstructiveness. But when others maintain that nonobstruc-tiveness is said to the characteristic of space, they maintain that this means that they are inherently characteristic and characterized. It is being demonstrated that it would follow from this that they would be sequential. Here is why it would follow: There are only three possible moments of characterization. “Nor in the characterized does the characteristic arise” [V:3b] will refute simultaneity. Of the two sequential possibilities—characterization where the characteristic is prior to the characterized [136] and characterization in the reverse order—the latter is more difficult to refute. This is because taking the basis of characterization/1/ to be earlier and its characterization by its characteristic to be later is a more serious issue; when one is sure that the basis of characterization is not earlier, there is less chance of grasping it as characterized earlier. Therefore, Nāgārjuna refutes at least the priority of the characterized over the characteristic.

gal te sgrib thogs med pa nam mkha' la mtshan nyid du 'jug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na dus gzhan gnyis su 'jug pa mi 'thad pas/ mtshan nyid de las snga rol du mtshan gzhi nam mkha' yod pa la 'jug dgos na/ nam mkha'i mtshan nyid sgrib thogs med pa'i snga rol na 'jug gzhi nam mkha' de cung zad kyang yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir mtshan nyid gang du 'jug par 'gyur/

If the characterization by the characteristic of space—nonobstructiveness—existed essentially, it would not make sense for the characterization to be characterizing in the other two temporal periods. So, if the characteristic is to characterize the characterized, (space) which exists prior to its characteristics, then prior to the characteristic of space (nonobstructiveness) the basis of characterization (space) would not exist in the slightest. So, what does the characteristic characterize?
mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos po ni/ / 'ga' yang gang na'ang yod ma yin/ / mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos med na/ / mtshan nyid gang du 'jug par 'gyur/ /
2. A thing without a characteristic Has never existed. If nothing lacks a characteristic, What do characteristics characterize?

gal te mtshan nyid sgrib thogs med pa las nam mkha' snga bar gyur na de'i dus na mtshan nyid de med par thal bar 'gyur la de lta na nam mkha' yang med par 'gyur te/ mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos po ste don 'ga' yang gzhung lugs gang na'ang yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te re zhig mtshan nyid 'jug pa ni yod la 'jug pa de yang mtshan gzhi la yin pas mtshan nyid 'jug pa yod pas mtshan gzhi yang yod mtshan nyid kyi snga rol na mtshan nyid med pa'i dngos po ste don do zhe na/ med do zhes ni bshad zin to/ / de lta yin na mtshan nyid de gang du 'jug par 'gyur ba'i gzhi med pas mtshan nyid 'jug pa med do/ / 'di ni mtshan nyid kyi snga rol na mtshan nyid med kyang mtshan nyid 'jug pa yod snyam pa 'gog pa'o/ /

If space existed prior to the characteristic—nonobstructiveness—the absurd consequence would follow that there would be no characteristic at that time. In that case, space would be nonexistent, since according to no philosophical system does any entity or object without a characteristic exist. Suppose someone says, “Since there is characterization by characteristics, and it characterizes the characterized, that characterization exists, and so the characterized exists.” It has already been explained that prior to the characteristics there is no entity or object without characteristics. And so, since there is no basis of characteristic to be characterized by the characteristic, there is no characterization. This refutes the idea that prior to any characteristic, even without characteristic, there is characterization.
gnyis pa [mtshan nyid yod med la brtags nas mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.1.1.2 Refutation of characterization through the analysis of characterization in terms of the existence and nonexistence of characteristics
mtshan nyid med la mtshan nyid ni/ / mi 'jug mtshan nyid bcas la min/ / mtshan bcas mtshan nyid med pa las/ / gzhan la'ang 'jug par mi 'gyur ro/ /
3. Characteristics do not characterize the uncharacterized. Nor do they characterize the characterized. Nor do they characterize anything other Than the characterized and the uncharacterized.

gzhan yang mtshan nyid 'jug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gsum las mi 'da' la de yang mtshan nyid med pa la mtshan nyid ni mi 'jug ste/ mtshan nyid med pa'i chos tha snyad du yang mi srid pas gzhi med pa la 'jug pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / mtshan nyid dang bcas pa'i don la yang mtshan nyid 'jug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min te/ de la ni mtshan nyid 'jug pa dgos pa med pa'i phyir te rang gi ngo bos mtshan nyid dang bcas par grub pa la slar yang mtshan nyid kyis ci zhig bya/ de ltar grub kyang mtshan nyid 'jug na ni rtag tu mtshan nyid 'jug pas thug pa med par 'gyur ro// //

Moreover, if characterization existed inherently, there are only three possibilities: characteristics do not characterize that which lacks characteristics because even conventionally it does not make sense for phenomena to be without characteristics, and thus without a basis characterization would be contradictory. [137] Characteristics do not inherently characterize an object that has a characteristic because for such a thing characterization is unnecessary: What would an additional characteristic do for that which has a characteristic inherently? If there were characterization of the already characterized, there would be an infinite regress of characterization.

de la mtshan nyid sgrib med la sogs pa de mtshan gzhi nam mkha' la sogs pa'i sgrub byed yin la de tha snyad du yod pa la mi 'gal yang don dam par grub pa la mi rigs pa yin te/ rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i dus mnyam pa la ltos pa mi rigs pa mang du gsungs pas mtshan mtshon rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i dus mnyam pa la 'brel ba med pas mtshan nyid sgrub byed du mi 'thad do/ / 'di yang rang gi ngo bos grub na rang dbang du grub pa dang / rang nyid tshugs thub kyi ngo bor yod dgos pas de lta na gzhan gyi dbang du gyur pa dang gzhan la rag las kyi 'brel ba mi 'thad pa'o/ / des na ngo bos grub pa sgrub byed la rag las na dus nam yang rag mi las pa mi srid dgos pas thug med du 'gyur to/ / mtshan nyid dang bcas pa dang mtshan nyid med pa las gzhan pa la yang mtshan nyid 'jug par mi 'gyur te/ de ni mi srid pa'i phyir te mtshan nyid med pa las log pa ni mtshan nyid yod pa dang / yod pa las log pa ni mtshan nyid med pa yin pas mtshan nyid yod med dngos 'gal yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di la 'os pa las skyes bu ni srog gi rdzas la ltos nas mtshan nyid med la/ lus kyi rdzas la ltos nas mtshan nyid yod ces rnam grangs las mtshan nyid yod med du smra na'ang sngar so so ba sun phyung ba las mi 'da'o/ /

With respect to this, such characteristics as unobstructedness are sufficient reasons/2/ for things being characterized phenomena, such as space. With respect to conventional existence, there is no contradiction. But with respect to ultimate existence, this makes no sense. It has been explained many times that with respect to simultaneous, inherently existent phenomena, dependence does not make sense. Therefore, since inherently existent characteristic and characterized would be unrelated, it makes no sense for the characteristic to be a sufficient reason. This also means that if something existed inherently, then since it would have to exist through its own power and it would have to be an entity that stands on its own, it does not make sense for it to be related to others as dependent on them. Therefore if an inherently existent thing were to depend on a sufficient reason, since it would have to be impossible at each moment be for it to be independent, there would be an infinite regress. The characteristic does not characterize anything other than that which has or that which lacks a characteristic, because that is impossible. This is because having a characteristic is the opposite of lacking a characteristic, and lacking a characteristic is the opposite of having one. Thus, having and lacking a characteristic are mutually exclusive. Concerning this, the Jains say, “With respect to life the person has no characteristic, but with respect to the body it has.” They assert that something has or lacks a characteristic only in context. However, this does not escape from the individual refutations of these respective positions.
gnyis pa [des mtshan gzhi khegs par bstan pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.1.2 Demonstration that thereby the basis of characteristics is refuted
ci ste yang mtshan gzhi la mtshan nyid 'jug pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa bkag kyang tshogs pa bkag pas ya gyal mi khegs pa'i phyir mtshan gzhi ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose someone said, “Although the essential characterization of the basis of characteristics has been refuted, by applying this refutation, the whole does not apply to the parts, [138] and so the basis of characterization exists inherently.”
mtshan nyid 'jug pa ma yin na/ / mtshan gzhi 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
4. When there is no characterization The basis of characteristics makes no sense.

gang gi tshe mtshan nyid 'jug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin na de'i tshe mtshan gzhi rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te/ mtshan nyid 'jug pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis mtshan gzhir gzhag dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir khyod kyis sgrib thogs med pa'i mtshan nyid dang ldan pa'i rtags kyis nam mkha'i khams rang bzhin gyis yod par bstan na/ de yang mtshan nyid mi 'jug pa'i phyir mi 'thad la de lta na khyod kyi mtshan gzhi rang bzhin gyis yod pa gang gis 'grub par 'thad/

Since characterization does not exist inherently, it makes no sense for the basis of characteristics to exist essentially, because the only reason to posit the basis of characteristics is characterization. Here, you have maintained that the space element exists essentially by relying on the premise that it has the characteristic of nonobstructiveness. However, that does not make sense, since there is no characterization. So, how could it make sense for your basis of characterization to exist essentially?
gnyis pa [mtshan nyid dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.2 Refutation of characteristics
gal te khyod kyis mtshan nyid 'jug pa bkag gi mtshan nyid ni ma bkag pas mtshan nyid rang bzhin gyis yod la de lta na mtshan gzhi yang yod do snyam na/
Suppose one thought, “Characterization has been refuted, but since the characteristic has not been refuted, the characteristic exists essentially. So the basis of characterization still exists.”
mtshan gzhi 'thad pa ma yin na/ / mtshan nyid kyang ni yod ma yin/ /
4cd. Since the basis of characteristics makes no sense, There is no characteristic either.

mtshan nyid mi 'jug pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis mtshan gzhi mi 'thad par bstan pa de yi tshe mtshan gzhi rang bzhin gyis yod par 'thad pa ma yin na der ma zad mtshan nyid kyang ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te rten med pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhi med kyi mtshan nyid med pa'i phyir mtshan gzhi bkag kyang mtshan nyid rang bzhin gyis yod par smra ba mi 'thad do/ /

Since it has been demonstrated that it makes no sense for the basis of characteristics to exist on the grounds that there is no characterization, it makes no sense for the basis of characteristics to exist essentially; moreover, since there is no basis, the characteristic does not exist essentially, either. Since there is no characteristic without a basis, it makes no sense to assert that the characteristic exists essentially, even though the basis has been refuted.
gsum pa [mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.1.1.3 Drawing conclusions
de phyir mtshan gzhi yod min te/ / mtshan nyid yod pa nyid ma yin/ /
5. Therefore there is no basis of characteristic Because there is no characteristic.

gang gi phyir rnam pa thams cad du brtags pa na mtshan nyid 'jug par mi 'thad pa de yi phyir mtshan nyid kyi gzhi rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no/ / de'i phyir gzhi med pa'i mtshan nyid kyang yod pa nyid ma yin no zhes sngar bkag pa rnams kyi mjug bsdus so/ /

Through an exhaustive examination, it has been determined that characterization does not makes sense, and therefore that the basis of characteristics does not exist essentially; thus, nor is there any existence of a characteristic without a basis. Thus concludes the foregoing refutations.
gnyis pa [dngos po dang dngos med du grub pa dgag]
1.1.1.2 Refutation of the existence of space as an entity and as a nonentity
['di] la gnyis/ dngos kyi don dang*/ rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the main point and rebutting their refutations.
dang po [dngos kyi don] ni/
1.1.1.2.1 The main point

gal te yang mtshan nyid dang mtshan gzhi rang bzhin gyis med pa de lta na'ang dngos po'i rang bzhin gyi nam mkha' ni yod la de lta na mtshan gzhi'am mtshan nyid du 'gyur bas de gnyis kyang rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose one argued further as follows: Although the characteristic and the basis of characteristic do not exist essentially, space, having the nature of an entity, exists. Since that is the case, these are the characteristic and the basis of characteristic. Consequently, these two exist essentially. [139]
mtshan gzhi mtshan nyid ma gtogs pa'i/ / dngos po yang ni yod ma yin/ /
5cd. Nor is there any entity Other than the basis of characteristic and the characteristic.

de la gzhan sde bye brag pa la sogs pas nam mkha' rdzas su grub par smra la rang sde la ni bye brag tu smra bas nam mkha' dngos por 'dod do/ / de yang sgrib pa ste thogs pa'i reg bya bkag pa la nam mkhar 'dod par ni sangs rgyas pa rnams 'dra mod kyang*/ thogs pa'i reg bya bkag tsam gyi med dgag yin na gzhan la go 'byed pa mi rung bas/nam mkha' ni gzugs can rnams la go 'byed par byed pas don byed nus pa'o snyam du bsams nas bye brag tu smra ba rnams nam mkha' dngos por 'dod do/ / nam mkhas go phye na de ltar yin par gzugs can gzhan la go phye ba ni bum pa lta bu'i gzugs can gcig yul gzhan du go sa 'phos pa'i dbang gis yin gyi nam mkhas phye ba med do/ / go bkag pa yang gzugs can gcig yod pa'i go sar gzugs can gzhan mi tshud pas de nyid kyis go bkag la/ der gzugs can gzhan tshud pa la snga ma gzhan du 'gro dgos pas go phye na 'gro 'ong khas blang dgos so/ // rigs pa de dag dang rtag pa dang dngos po gzhi mthun pa gnod pa ston pa'i rigs pa rnams kyis nam mkha' dngos po yin pa ma bkag par/ nam mkha' mtshan gzhi dang sgrib thogs med pa mtshan nyid du rang gi ngo bos med par ni bstan zin la/ mtshan gzhi dang mtshan nyid du ma gtogs pa'i dngos po yod pa ma yin pas nam mkha' dngos por rang bzhin gyis med do zhes bkag pa ni nam mkha' la bshad pa'i rigs pa rnams khams lhag ma la yang sbyar dgos pa la dgongs so/ /

The other schools, such as the Vaiśeṣikas, maintain that space is substantially existent. Of our schools, the Vaibhāṣikas maintain that space is an entity. Buddhist schools are unanimous in maintaining that space is free from obstructiveness, that is, from being an obstacle to contact. However, the Vaibhāṣikas maintain that space is an entity, thinking that if it were an external negation—merely not being an obstacle to contact—then it would not have the positive quality of being accommodating to others. Since space positively accommodates other material forms, it performs a function./3/ If space positively accommodated others, this would be the case. However, positively accommodating another material object occurs only through a material object, like a pot, moving to another place, but not through space itself positively accommodating it. Exclusion also occurs when one material object occupies a place and another material object is prevented from entering it, being thereby excluded. In order to permit another material object to enter that place, the first one has to move someplace else. Therefore, whenever you accept accommodation, you have to accept going and coming. It has already been demonstrated that these arguments, as well as arguments that undermine the compatibility of permanence and entityhood, without refuting space being an entity, show that neither space as a basis of characteristics nor nonobstructiveness as a characteristic exists inherently. There is no entity apart from basis of characteristic and characteristic, and so the refutation, the argument concerning space—that space does not exist as an entity through its essence—is intended to apply to the all of the other elements as well.
rang sde dngos por smra ba gzhan ni thogs pa'i reg bya bkag tsam gyi med dgag dngos med du 'dod pas de 'dra ba'i dngos med du rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod do snyam na/

Suppose one thought that, according to our other reificationist schools, the external negation—the absence of obstacle to contact—is maintained to be a non entity, and thus to exist inherently as a non entity.
dngos po yod pa ma yin na/ / dngos med gang gi yin par 'gyur/ /
6. If no entity exists, Of what entity would an absence be?

nam mkha' ni thogs bcas kyi gzugs rnam par bcad tsam la bzhag go / gal te gzugs rang gi ngo bos yod na de'i tshe bar snang lta bur thogs bcas kyi gzugs bkag tsam yang rang gi ngo bos yod par 'gyur na yang sngar bshad pa'i rigs pas gzugs kyi dngos po ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin na de'i tshe gang gi dngos po med pa nam mkha' yin par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

Space is posited merely as the absence of obstructive material form. If material form existed inherently, [140] the mere absence of obstructive forms in space would also exist inherently. However, according to the arguments advanced earlier, since material objects do not exist inherently, would space be the absence of what entity? Of none!

gal te ri bong gi rwa'i dngos po yod pa ma yin pa nyid kyis ri bong gi rwa med pa'i dgag pa de ri bong gi rwa'i dngos po med par yod pa ma yin nam/ ji ltar dgag bya'i chos med pa dgag pa med pa'i rgyu mtshan du smra bar rigs snyam na/ de ni mi mtshungs te/ tha snyad du dngos po tsam mi srid na bum pa'i dngos med kyang tha snyad du mi srid pa bzhin du/ don dam par dngos po tsam mi srid na thogs bcas kyi dngos med kyang don dam par mi srid ces pa'i don yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Suppose someone were to offer this argument: On the grounds of the nonexistence of the entity of the rabbit’s horns, is not that negation—the nonexistence of rabbit’s horns—instantiated in the nonentity of the rabbit’s horns? How could you think it reasonable that the absence of an object of negation is the ground for the absence of a negation? Here is what this means: The cases are not similar: If conventionally mere entity were not possible, conventionally the entitylessness of the pot would not be possible. Similarly, since ultimately mere entity is not possible, the ultimate existence of the entitylessness of obstruction is not possible.
gnyis pa [rtsod pa spang ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.2 Rebutting their refutations
gal te dngos po yod med rtog par byed pa po khyod ni yod la de yi phyir brtag bya dngos po yod med kyang yod do zhe na/

Suppose someone says that since you—who are the agent of the investigation into whether entities exist or do not exist—exist, it follows that the object of the investigation into whether entities exist or not must also exist.
dngos dang dngos med mi mthun chos/ / gang gis dngos dang dngos med shes/ /
6cd. Entities and nonentities are mutually exclusive. Who knows entities and nonentities?

de lta na gang gis dngos dang dngos med shes shing dpyod par byed pa po ni gsum las mi 'da' la de yang dngos por rang bzhin gyis yod na ni mtshan gzhi zhes pa dang dngos med du rang bzhin gyis yod na ni dngos po yod pa zhes pa der bkag zin pas mi 'thad do/ / dngos po dang dngos po med pa'i chos mi mthun pa de gnyis gang yang min pa'i phung gsum gyi rtog pa po yang med pas rtog par byed pa po rang bzhin gyi med do/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang / gang zhig dngos rnams dngos med shes pa de/ / nam yang dngos po kun la chags mi 'gyur/ / gang zhig nam yang dngos kun chags med pa/ / de ni ting 'dzin mtshan ma med la reg / ces dngos po rnams rang bzhin med par shes pa de dpyod pa po la sogs pa'i dngos po kun la bden par mi 'dzin par gsungs shing /

Therefore, whoever is the agent of the analysis and knowledge of entities and nonentities cannot escape from the three possibilities: If it exists essentially as an entity, “other than the basis” refutes it; if it exists essentially as a nonentity, “if there is no existent entity” refutes it; and since these have already been refuted, they make no sense. There is no third alternative for the agent—neither an entity nor an nonentity—since these are mutually exclusive and exhaustive. And since there is not, the agent of investigation does not exist essentially. According to the Transcendent Lord, Whoever understands entities as entityless Will not cling to entities. Whoever does not cling to entities Achieves nonrepresentational meditation. [Samādhirāja sūtra, mDo sde da 152b]/4/ Thus it explains that anyone who understands that all entities are essenceless will not grasp any entity, such as the agent of analysis as truly existing. [141]

gang dag chos rnams stong la sems byed pa'i/ / byis pa de dag lam ngan zhugs pa yin/ / chos rnams stong par yi ges brjod pa yin/ / de dag yi ge med par yi ges bstan/ / gang dag zhi zhing rab zhi'i chos sems pa'i/ sems pa de yang nam yang 'byung ma yin/ / spros kun sems kyi rnam par rtog yin te/ / de phyir chos rnams bsam yas rtogs par gyis/ / zhes gsungs so/ / gang dag chos rnams zhes pa'i rkang pa gnyis kyi don ni stong pa nyid la sems pa lam ngan par zhugs par ston pa min gyi/ gang dag zhi zhing zhes pa gnyis kyis bkag pa'i stong pa la sems par byed mkhan bden par 'dzin pa lam ngan par zhugs par ston no/ / de yang yi ge med par zhes pas ni chos rnams rang bzhin gyis stong par ston mkhan de nyid kyis rang yang bdag med du ston par bshad de dngos med la bden pa 'gog mkhan bden par ma grub pa'i khungs so/ /

Whoever conceptualizes empty phenomena, Such a fool has entered bad paths. Through words, phenomena are asserted to be empty. Through words, they are shown to be wordless. Whoever conceptualizes peace and the thorough pacification of phenomena, One with that kind of mind can never renounce. All fabrications are mental conceptualizations. Therefore phenomena should be understood to be inconceivable. [Upālipariprcchā-sūtra, dKon brtsegs ca 128b] The meaning of the two lines “Whoever conceptualizes empty…” is not that to think about emptiness is to enter into bad paths; the two lines “Whoever conceptualizes peace…” show that whoever conceptualizes emptiness—a negation—grasping it as truly existent, has entered bad paths. The phrase “… wordless” shows that that through which phenomena are shown to be empty of essence shows itself to be selfless. This is canonical authority for the true nonexistence of the agent who refutes the true existence of nonentities.
gsum pa [bkag pa rnams kyi mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.1.3 Drawing conclusions from the refutations
de phyir nam mkha' dngos po min/ / dngos med ma yin mtshan gzhi min/ / mtshan nyid ma yin khams lnga po/ /
7. Therefore space is neither an entity. Nor is it a nonentity. It is neither characterized nor characteristic.

sngar bshad pa ltar brtags na mi 'thad pa de yi phyir nam mkha' ni dngos po dang dngos med dang mtshan gzhi dang mtshan nyid bzhi po gang du yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no zhes sngar bshad pa rnams kyi mjug pa bsdus so/ / bod la grags pa'i mtshon bya la 'di dang rgya gzhung gzhan mang po las mtshan gzhi zhes 'byung la de gnyis kyi skad dod kyang gcig pas mtshan mtshon gyi sbyor ba gcig la mtshan gzhi dang mtshon bya 'gal bar smra ba yang mi 'thad la/ gzhan dag snga ma rgyu mtshan du byas nas mtshan mtshon gzhi gsum du byed pa mi 'thad ces smra ba yang mi rigs te/ rtags kyis bsgrub bya sgrub pa la bsgrub bya sgrub byed sgrub gzhi gsum yod pa ltar mtshan nyid kyis mtshon bya mtshon pa la yang byar rung ba'i phyir ro/ / de lta na brjod bya la yang gsum bya dgos par 'gyur ro zhes pa ni 'dod pa yin no/ / skad dod gcig yin pas don gnyis gcig yin na cig shos yin par sgrub mi nus pa ni du ma zhig snang ngo / /

We can conclude from the previous explanations that, according to such analyses, since it makes no sense that space exists inherently, it cannot so exist in any of these four ways: neither as an entity, nor as a nonentity, nor as the characterized, nor as the characteristic. In place of the word mtshon bya5 commonly used in Tibet, the word mtshan gzhi6 is used in this text and in many other translations of Indian texts. Since these two terms correspond to a single Sanskrit word lakṣya, it makes no sense to treat mtshon bya and mtshan gzhi differently when they occur in the same structure of characterized and characteristic. Nonetheless, it is unreasonable to say on the basis of the argument just presented that the threefold categorization into characteristic, characterized, and basis of characteristic does not make sense:/7/ When proving a thesis through a premise, we need all three, the thesis, the proof, and the basis of the proof; it is the same with the characteristic characterizing the characterized. Since this is the case, I agree that you need a similar triad with respect to the referent./8/[142] When one word has two meanings, if something satisfies one of these meanings, that does not mean that it satisfies the other. There are many cases like this.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de khams lhag ma la yang sbyar ba] ni/
1.1.2 Applying this argument to the remainder of the elements
gzhan gang dag kyang nam mkha' mtshungs/ /
7d. The same is true of the other five elements.

sa la sogs pa'i khams lnga po nam mkha' las gzhan gang dag lhag mar gyur pa de dag kyang nam mkha' dang mtshungs par dngos po dngos med dang mtshan gzhi mtshan nyid kyi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong par shes par bya'o/ / de yang / sa khams mtshan nyid snga rol na/ // sa ni cung zad yod ma yin/ / zhes dang / de phyir sa khams dngos po min/ / zhes sbyar te gzhan la yang de ltar sbyar ro/ / chos mngon pa las phyi nang gi skye mched rnams yul yul can dang phung po rnams rgyu 'bras dang / khams drug gi mtshan nyid bstan pa la ji ltar bstan pa de ltar rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'dzin pa bzlog pa'i phyir du thad ka thad ka'i thun mong ma yin pa'i rigs pa rnams gsungs kyi/ bden 'dzin gsum ga yang chos gsum ga la skye bas de 'gog pa'i rigs pa yang chos gsum ga la ston dgos pa'i phyir nges pa ni min no/ /

Earth and the rest of the five elements other than space also should be understood in the same way: empty of being inherently existent entities, nonentities, characteristics or characterized. And so we can rearrange the text as follows: Prior to a characteristic of the earth element There is not the slightest earth. and Therefore earth is not an entity. And this could be applied to the rest of them as well. When in the Abhidharma the external and internal faculties are presented as subject and object, the aggregates as causes and effects, and the characteristics of the six elements are presented, in order to undo the grasping of them as existing inherently as they are presented, the reasoning specific to each one is explained. However, since each of the three ways of grasping true existence arises with respect to all three kinds of entities, the refutatory argument for each of the three entities must be presented. Therefore, the arguments are not specific to the entities.
gnyis pa [yod med kyi mthar lta ba smad pa] ni/
1.2 Condemning the extreme views of reification and nihilism.
blo chung gang dag dngos rnams la/ / yod pa nyid dang med nyid du/ / blta ba des ni blta bya ba/ / nye bar zhi ba zhi mi mthong / /
8. Those fools who see entities As existent or as nonexistent Do not see that which is to be seen As pacified and peaceful.

chos rnams bzhi po der ngo bo nyidakyis yod pa mi 'thad pa'i phyir ma rig pa'i rab rib kyis blo gros kyi mig nyams pas/ thog ma med pa nas dngos po yod med la sogs par log par lta ba goms pa rang bzhin med pa phyin ci ma log par mthong ba'i lam thar pa dang mthun par 'gro ba las nyams pa'i blo chung gang dag / blo zhan pas rten 'byung mchog tu zab pa ma rtogs pa na dngos po rnams la yod pa ste rtag pa dang med pa ste chad par lta bas blo'i mig bsgribs pa de dag gis ni/ blta bar bya ba'i mya ngan las 'das pa nye bar zhi zhing zhi ba'i mtshan nyid can rtog pa thams cad dang bral ba/ shes pa dang shes bya'i spros pa thams cad las log pa'i ngo bo don dam pa stong pa nyid kyi rang bzhin can mi mthong ngo / / bud d+ha pA li ta las/ phung khams skye mched med na rgyal bas phal cher de dag la brtsams nas chos bstan pa don med du 'gyur bar brtsad pa'i lan du/ / kho bo cag yod med kyi mtha' gnyis bsal ba ston gyi de dag med ces mi smra bas kho bo cag la chos bstan pa don med du mi 'gyur ro/ // gang dag yod med kyi mthar lta ba la ni chos bstan pa don med du 'gyur te lta ba de dag dang ldan na myang 'das mi 'thob pa'i phyir ro zhes 'chad de rab byed gsum ga'i rtsod spang ngo*/ /

Since it makes no sense to say that those four phenomena exist inherently, the fools are those whose wisdom-eye is obscured by the cataracts of ignorance, and so who from beginningless time, are conditioned to see falsely the existence and nonexistence of entities, and so have failed to enter the path conducive to liberation, viz., the path of seeing essencelessness nonerroneously. They, because of their stupidity, do not understand the most profound dependent origination, and therefore, by seeing entities as existent, that is, as reified; or as nonexistent, that is, as nullified, their cognitive perception is obscured. They do not see the object to be perceived—nirvana, the pacified that has the characteristic of peace, free from all conceptual constructions, free from all fabrication of knower and known—the ultimate, [143] which is to have the nature of emptiness. Buddhapālita replies to the following argument: If there were no aggregates, elements or faculties, it would be absurd for the Victor usually to present the Dharma based on these. He replies that though we present them as free from the two extremes of existence and nonexistence, we do not maintain that they do not exist. So it does not follow that for us the teaching of the Dharma is absurd. For those who see them in terms of the extremes of existence and nonexistence, the presentation of the Dharma would be absurd, because with those kinds of views nirvana cannot be achieved [182a]. This rebuts this refutation of all of the three previous chapters.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

khams drug la mtshan mtshon dang dngos po yod med kyi rang bzhin bkag pa yang rtog ge tsam gyis min gyi nges don gyi lung gis grub pa dang / rab byed 'di sa khams la rang bzhin de ltar bkag pa'i gsung rab thams cad bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam brjod na/ yod med kyi mthar lta ba la gnas par mi bya ba ni sngar ting 'dzin rgyal po la sogs pa drangs pa ltar yin la tshangs pa khyad par sems kyis zhus pa las kyang / nang gi sa'i khams gang yin pa dang phyi rol gyi sa'i khams gang yin pa ni gnyis su med pa'i don te/ de yang de bzhin gshegs pas shes rab dang ye shes kyis gnyis su med pa dang gnyis su dbyer med pa dang mtshan nyid gcig pa 'di lta ste mtshan nyid med par mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas so zhes pa dang / 'jig rten nam mkha'i mtshan nyid de/ / nam mkha' la yang mtshan nyid med/ / de phyir de yis de rtogs pas/ / 'jig rten chos kyis mi gos so/ / zhes dang*/ 'jam dpal rnam par rol pa las kyang / bu mo khams dag ji ltar blta bar bya/ bu mos smras pa 'jam dpal 'di lta ste dper na 'jig rten gsum bskal pas bsregs pa na thal ba yang med pa ltar ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar rab byed 'di yi rigs pa rnams ni gsung rab de dag dang khyad par du chos rnams mtshan nyid dang mtshan nyid kyi gzhi dang bral bar gsungs pa thams cad lta ba'i mig tu shes par byas la mig de yongs su dag par bya'o/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the negation of the essence of existent and nonexistent entities and of characteristic and characterized with respect to the six elements is not merely a sophistry, but instead is established by definitive sūtras, and in order to demonstrate that this chapter explains all of the scriptures’ similar refutations of the essence of the elements. The fact that one should not retain the extreme views of existence and nonexistence is confirmed by previous citations from the Samādhirāja-sūtra, etc., as the Brahmaviśeṣacintiparipṛcchā-sūtra says:/9/ Any inner or outer earth element is a non-dual object. Thus the Thatāgata completely comprehended through wisdom and insight that non-duality, the indivisibility into two, and that although things have a single characteristic, they are completely known as characteristicless. [m Do sde kha 223b] While in a mundane sense, space has a characteristic There is no characteristic of space. Therefore when it is so comprehended It is not stained by mundane phenomena. [m Do sde pa 37a] And in the Mañjuśrīvikrīḍitasūtra it says, Daughter, how should space be viewed? The girl said, “Oh Mañjuśrī, here is how, for example: when this triple world is burned at the end of the aeon even the ashes do not remain.” [m Do sde kha 230b] [144] So, the arguments of this chapter should be understood as an eye with which to see the scriptures—particularly all of those that present phenomena as free from characteristics and the bases of characteristics—and that eye should be perfected.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

khams rnams kyi mtshan mtshon dang dngos po yod med gsungs pa la ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam min par rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod na mtshan mtshon la sogs par gzhag tu mi rung bar rigs pas gtan la phab pa'i don nges par bya/ nas ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la mtshan mtshon dang dngos po yod med du 'jog pa ches 'thad pa'i tshul gyis bden pa gnyis kyi don rnams nges par bya'o/ /

One should ascertain the meaning established by these arguments to be that with respect to the elements, if characteristic and characterized and existence and nonexistence of entity as they are presented by the sūtras existed inherently, instead of being merely posited through the force of nominal conventions, then characteristic and characterized cannot be posited. Having ascertained that meaning, one should then ascertain the meanings of the two truths in the following, completely adequate way: Only insofar as they are posited merely through nominal convention are characteristic and characterized and the existence and nonexistence of entities possible.
khams brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa lnga pa'o/ /
This is the fifth chapter called “the examination of the elements.”
khams brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa brgyad kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa lnga pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the fifth chapter, having eight verses, called “the examination of the elements.”

d.crumb: *VI. Examination of Desire and the Desirous One

f.d: CHAPTER VI. Examination of Desire and the Desirous One
gnyis pa [de la bdag yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa]
we now turn to the second part, of that section which is the refutation of the argument that there is a self in phenomena. [144:11]
['di] la gsum/ brten pa kun nas nyon mongs yod pa dgag / mtshan nyid skye 'jig gnas pa yod pa dgag / rgyu las dang byed pa po yod pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: refutation of the defilements—that which depends on the basis; refutation of the existence of the characteristics: arising, ceasing, and enduring; and refutation of the existence of the cause—agent and action.
dang po [brten pa kun nas nyon mongs yod pa dgag]
[Refutation of the defilements—that which depends on the basis]
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
and [it] has three parts: the explanation of the meaning of the chapter, confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ phung po dang khams dang skye mched ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i rten can kun nas nyon mongs dmigs pa'i phyir te bcom ldan 'das kyis/ dge slong dag byis pa so so'i skye bo thos pa dang mi ldan pa btags par lhung ba ni mig gis gzugs rnams mthong nas yid bde ba'i gnas su mngon par zhen par 'gyur ro/ // de mngon par zhen par gyur nas 'dod chags skyed par byed do/ // chags par gyur nas lus dang ngag dang yid kyis 'dod chags las byung ba'i las mngon par 'du byed par 'gyur ro/ / zhes chags sogs kyi nyon mongs pa kun nas nyon mongs pa'i rgyu yod par gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir chags sogs rang bzhin gyis yod na phung po la sogs pa yang rang bzhin gyis yod na'ang de ltar ni med do/ / 'di la gsum/ 'dod chags dang chags pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / bkag pa rnams kyi mjug bsdu ba/ rigs pa de gzhan la yang sbyar ba'o/ /

Here someone might say that the aggregates, the elements, and the faculties exist essentially because the defilements, which depend on them, exist; and this is because the Tathāgata has said, “Oh monks, when some childish, uneducated person, fallen into the extreme of reification, has seen material forms with his eyes, the mind becomes obsessed with them as the locus of pleasure. Having developed that obsession, desire arises. Having become desirous, body speech and mind act out of desire” [Pitāputrasamāgama-Sūtra, mDo sde nga 13b]. [145] Thus it is said that afflictive emotions such as desire—the causes of the afflictions—exist. If such things as desire existed essentially, such things as the aggregates would also exist essentially. However, this is not the case! This section has three parts: the refutation of the essential existence of desire and the desirous, drawing conclusions from these arguments, the application of these arguments to other phenomena.
dang po ['dod chags dang chags pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of desire and the desirous one
['di] la gnyis/ snga phyir byung ba dgag / lhan cig tu 'byung ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of them occurring sequentially and the refutation of them occurring simultaneously.
dang po [snga phyir byung ba dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of them occurring sequentially
['di] la gnyis/ 'dod chags kyi snga rol na chags pa yod med dgag / chags pa'i snga rol na 'dod chags yod med dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the existence or nonexistence of the desirous prior to desire and the refutation of the existence or nonexistence of desire prior to the desirous one.
dang po ['dod chags kyi snga rol na chags pa yod med dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1 Refutation of the existence or nonexistence of the desirous one prior to desire
gal te 'dod chags snga rol na/ / 'dod chags med pa'i shes rab chags yod na/ / de la brten nas 'dod chags yod/ / chags yod 'dod chags yod par 'gyur/ /
1. If prior to desire There were a desirous one without desire, Depending on that, desire would exist. Desire would exist when there is a desirous one.
