gzhan yang 'gag pa rang bzhin gyis yod na gnyis las mi 'da' la de yang re zhig dngos po gnas pa la 'gag pa rang gi ngo bos yod pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te 'gag pa'i bya ba de dang gnas pa'i bya ba gnyis gzhi gcig la 'jug pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ dngos po rang dus su mi gnas pa la yang 'gag pa'i bya ba 'jug pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te de ni yod pa yang ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, if cessation existed through its essence, one could not escape two alternatives. It is not tenable that an enduring entity has cessation inherently because it is contradictory for both the activity of ceasing and the activity of enduring to be instantiated in the same basis. Nor is it tenable for the activity of ceasing to be instantiated in an entity that does not endure during its time of existence, because [184] such a thing is not even existent.
gsum pa [gnas skabs rang gzhan la brtags nas dgag]
1.2.1.1.2.3.1.3 Refutation through examination of the stages of self and others
['di] la gnyis/ dngos kyi don dang / rtsod pa spangs pa'o/ /
This third section has two parts: the main point and the rebuttal of refutations
dang po [dngos kyi don] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.1.3.1 The main point
gnas skabs de yis gnas skabs ni/ / de nyid 'gag pa nyid [23] mi 'gyur/ / gnas skabs gzhan gyis gnas skabs ni/ / gzhan yang 'gag pa nyid mi 'gyur/ /
28. A state does not make That state itself cease. Nor does one state Make another state cease.

gzhan yang gal te 'gag pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gnas skabs gnyis kyis 'gag pa las mi 'da' la/ de yang 'o ma'i gnas skabs de yis ni 'o ma'i gnas skabs ni de nyid 'gag pa nyid du mi 'gyur te/ rang gi bdag nyid la byed pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / 'o ma'i gnas skabs las gzhan zho yi gnas skabs kyis 'o ma'i gnas skabs ni/ zho yi gnas skabs las gzhan pa yang 'gag pa nyid du mi 'a gyur te gzhig bya dang 'jig byed gnyis dus gcig na med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, if cessation existed inherently, it could not escape two alternatives with respect to cessation. The state of being milk does not make the state of being milk itself cease because reflexive action is contradictory. The state of being yoghurt—which is different from the state of being milk—does not cause the state of being milk—which is different from the state of being yoghurt—to cease, because the object of cessation and the agent of cessation do not exist at the same time.
gnyis pa [rtsod pa spangs pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.1.3.2 Rebuttal of refutations
gal te yang gnas skabs de nyid kyis de nyid dang gnas skabs gzhan gyis gzhan 'gag par mi byed kyang/ 'o ma'i gnas skabs la ni 'gag pa yod pas skye ba yang yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/
Suppose someone said that although neither does a state cause itself to cease nor does one state cause another state to cease, since the state of being milk has cessation, it must have arising:
gang tshe chos rnams thams cad kyi/ / shes rab skye ba 'thad par mi 'gyur ba/ / de tshe chos rnams thams cad kyi/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
29. Since for no entity Is arising tenable, For no entity Is ceasing tenable.

gang gi tshe sngar bshad pa'i tshul gyis chos rnams thams cad kyi rang bzhin gyis skye ba 'thad par mi 'gyur bar bshad pa de yi tshe/ chos rnams thams cad kyi rang bzhin gyis 'gag pa yang 'thad par mi 'gyur te zhes ches gsal bar bshad pa ma yin nam/ sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis 'gag pa ni yod de sngar khas blangs pa'i phyir te sngar dngos po 'gag bzhin pa la skye ba mi 'thad do zhes smras pa na 'gag bzhin pa'i rgyu las byung ba'i skye ba la dgag pa byas pa'i phyir ro zhes pa'i lan du gzhung 'di 'chad do/ /

Has this not been made clear already? Since, as it has been previously explained, it is not tenable for any phenomenon to arise essentially, as per this explanation, it is not tenable for any phenomenon to cease essentially. Buddhapālita says that this verse is a reply to the following rebuttal: Cessation does not exist in the way that you have accepted it earlier, because since you have asserted that arising is not tenable for a thing that is in the process of cessation, you have refuted the existence of the arising that is arisen from the cause that is in the process of cessation.
bzhi pa [dngos po yod med la brtags nas dgag] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.1.4 Refutation through examination of whether or not entities exist
re shig dngos po yod pa la/ / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / gcig nyid na ni dngos po dang / / dngos po med pa 'thad pa med/ /
30. For an existent entity Cessation is not tenable. A single thing being an entity and A nonentity is not tenable.

gzhan yang 'gag pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na dngos po yod med gnyis las mi 'da' la de yang re zhig dngos po yod pa la rang bzhin gyis 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te bum pa la sogs pa'i dngos po dang de zhig pa'i dngos po med pa gnyis gcig pa nyid yin na ni 'thad pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir zhig pa ni dngos po la brten pa'i chos yin pa'i phyir 'gag pa rang gi ngo bos yod na bum pa zhig pa'i dus na'ang bum pa la de brten dgos pa'o/ / yang na phan tshun 'gal ba'i snang mun bzhin du dngos po yod pa yang yin la dngos po med pa yang yin pa mi 'thad do/ /

Moreover, if cessation existed inherently, one cannot escape the two possibilities with respect to the existence and nonexistence of an entity. It is not tenable to say that any existent entity ceases essentially because it is not tenable for both entities and nonentities—such things as pots and their disintegration—to be identical. Here, disintegration is a phenomenon grounded in an entity. [185] So, if cessation existed inherently, then even at the time when the disintegration of the pot exists it would have to be grounded on the pot. One could also read this as follows: It is not tenable for an existent entity to be existent and nonexistent, just like light and darkness, which are mutually exclusive.
dngos po med par 'gyur pa la'ang / / 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / mgo gnyis pa la ci ltar ni/ / gcad du med pa de bzhin no/ /
31. Moreover, for a nonexistent entity Cessation would be untenable. Just as a second head Cannot be cut off.

dngos po med par gyur pa la'ang 'gag pa 'thad par mi 'gyur te yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ji ltar te dper na mgo gnyis med pa la de gnyis gcad du med pa de bzhin no/ / mgo gnyis med par rab tu grags pas dngos su med pa ma smos kyang bshad pa tshang bar 'gyur bas med pa zhes ma bkod do/ /

Nor is it tenable for a nonexistent entity to cease, because it does not exist. This is just like, for example, the fact that without two heads, two beheadings cannot be performed. Since the nonexistence of two heads is widely known, although “nonexistent” is not explicitly stated, it does not need to be stated, since the explanation is obvious.
lnga pa ['jig byed gzhan yod med la brtags nas dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.1.5 Refutation through examination of whether or not there is another agent of cessation
'gag pa rang gi bdag nyid kyis/ / yod min 'gag pa gzhan gyis min/ / ci ltar skye ba rang dang ni/ / gzhan gyis bskyed pa ma yin bzhin/ /
32. Cessation does not exist through itself. Nor does it exist through another. Just as arising is given rise to Neither by itself nor by another.

gzhan yang 'gag pas dngos po rnams 'gag par byed na 'gag byed de rang gzhan gnyis las mi 'da' la de yang 'gag pa rang gi bdag nyid kyis 'gag par byed pa yod pa min te/ ji ltar skye ba rang gis skyed pa ma yin pa bzhin du 'di la yang mtshungs pa'i phyir te/ 'gags pa 'di ni ma 'gags pas/ / rang gi bdag nyid ji ltar 'gog / ci ste 'gags pas 'gog byed na/ / 'gag na ci zhig 'gag tu yod/ / ces 'don pa bsgyur ro/ / 'gag pa rang las don gzhan gyis kyang 'gag par byed pa min te ji ltar skye ba rang las gzhan pa'i skye bas mi skyed pa bzhin yin pa'i phyir te/ gal te 'jig pa gzhan zhig gis/ / de 'jig thug pa med par 'gyur/ / ci ste 'jig med de 'jig na/ / thams cad de bzhin 'jig par 'gyur/ / zhes bsgyur ro/ / de ltar brtags shing dpyad na skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'jig pa rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ji ltar yang mi 'thad do/ / mi 'thad na 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid du ngo bo nyid kyis yod par yang ji ltar 'gyur/

Moreover, if cessation makes entities cease, one cannot escape two alternatives with respect to that agent of cessation: It has to be the same or different. Cessation cannot make itself cease, just as arising cannot give rise to itself. This is similar because we could rearrange the text as follows: How could this cessation, being non-ceased, Make itself cease? And if it is caused to cease by something ceased, Having ceased, what is there to cease?/25/ However, nothing other than cessation can make cessation cease, just as nothing other than arising can give rise to arising, because one could rearrange the text as follows: If another cessation caused this one to cease, There would be an infinite regress. If anything could cease without cessation, Then everything could cease in this way./26/ So, having analyzed it in this way, it is untenable in any way for arising, enduring, or ceasing to exist inherently. Since this is untenable, how could they be the characteristics of the produced inherently?
gnyis pa [nyes pa de rang la mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.2 The argument showing that this critique is not applicable to us

ci ste dpyod lugs de ltar rnam par dpyad na khyod kyi lugs la yang 'jig pa mi rigs so/ // des na gang zhig gnyis ka la skyon du 'gyur bas des ni gcig shos la brgal bar bya ba ma yin no snyam na/ 'di yi lan du dbu ma pas 'jig rten pa'i tha snyad khas blangs pa'i phyir pha rol po la bkod pa'i skyon rang la mi mtshungs so zhes bshad do/ / 'jig rten pa'i tha snyad byed tshul ni dngos po rnams ni rang bzhin med pa yin la de nyid kyang byis pa dngos po la bden par zhen pa rnams kyi tha snyad kyi lam du 'gro ba yin no/ / 'gro tshul ni 'jig pa zhes pa'i tha snyad btags pa tsam ma gtogs pa'i btags sa de 'das ma 'ongs la sogs pa gang du yod snyam du btsal nas/ rnyed pa'i don la 'jig par 'jog pa de lta bu'i tshul gyis ma brtags shing ma btsal bar grub pa'i don la 'jig pa'i tha snyad byed pa'o/ / de yang 'jig rten pa'i dngos po rnams ni sgyu ma la sogs pa bzhin du de kho nar grub ma grub dpyod pa'i 'thad pa'am rigs pa'i sgrub byed dang bral zhing / ma rig pa'i rab rib kyis blo gros kyi mig bslad pa'i 'jig rten la grub pa yin pas phan tshun ltos nas grub pa tsam zhig byis pa rnams kyis khas len no/ / de yi phyir bskyed bya yod na skyed byed dang skyed byed yod na bskyed bya yod cing 'gag pa yod na dgag bya ste 'gag rgyu dang dgag bya ste 'gag rgyu yod na 'gag pa yod pa yin te de bzhin du dbu ma pas kyang khas len gyi dpyad nas rnyed pa'i don la 'jig pa sogs 'jog pa min no/ /

Suppose you thought as follows: Since you have analyzed in this way, even in your system cessation makes no sense. If this is so, since we are both subject to the same critique, [186] you should not advance this as an argument against others. The mādhyamika replies to this as follows: Since we accept mundane conventions, the critique leveled against you does not apply to us. As mundane conventions posit things, entities are without essence, and that also follows the convention of ordinary people who are attached to entities as truly existent [See Prasannapadā 58b–59a]. Here is how: It is to designate an object, for instance cessation, without applying the following mode of examination and inquiry: not being content with mere nominal designation, to investigate the basis of designation, asking whether or not it exists in the past or future, etc., and thereby, to posit it as cessation, having found it through analysis. Moreover, the analysis to determine whether or not they exist as they are—as illusionlike—is not appropriate to mundane phenomena. Nonetheless, they exist from the mundane perspective conditioned by the clouding of the wisdom-eye by the mist of ignorance. Therefore, ordinary people accept things as existing just in mutual dependence. Therefore, if the arisen object exists, then the agent of arising exists; and if the agent of arising exists, the arisen object exists. If cessation exists, the object of cessation—that is the thing which is to cease—exists; and if the object of cessation—that is, the thing which is to cease—exists, cessation exists. The mādhyamika maintains this as well, but does not posit such things as cessation with respect to an object found through analysis./27/

mdor bsdu na dngos po rnams la sngar bshad pa ltar dpyad pa na skye 'jig gnas pa gang yang mi rnyed pa ni nged la yang mtshungs mod kyang des nged kyis khas blangs pa'i skye 'jig sogs mi khegs pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/ nged ni skye 'jig sogs sngar bshad pa ltar gyi dpyad bzod du yang mi 'dod la gang khas blangs na dpyad bzod du 'dod dgos pa rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par yang mi 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / des na dpyad bzod dang de'i khyab bya gnyis gang yang khas ma blangs pa la rigs pas dpyad nas ma rnyed pa de gnod byed du ji ltar 'gyur te skye 'jig dang gnas pa tsam zhig yod pa la rigs shes kyis rnyed mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / khyed kyis ni skye 'jig sogs dpyad bzod du yang 'dod la de'i khyab bya yang khas len pas sngar ltar dpyad pa'i tshe ma rnyed na gnod pa yin te de dag khas blangs pa ltar yod na rigs pa de dag gis rnyed dgos pa las ma rnyed pa'i phyir ro/ /

To sum this all up, as was previously explained, we also accept that if entities are analyzed, neither arising nor cessation nor enduring is found. But the reason that this does not refute the arising, cessation, etc., that we accept is that we do not maintain that arising, cessation, etc., withstand analysis, as was explained earlier. Nor do we accept inherent existence, that in virtue of which one has to accept that things withstand analysis. [187] Thus, for those who accept neither that which withstands analysis nor anything in a category that withstands analysis, how would not finding something through rational analysis undermine accepting it? It would not, because the mere existence of arising, cessation, and enduring does not need to be found by a rational mind through analysis. As for you, since you maintain that arising, cessation, etc., withstand analysis, and accept the things in those categories as well, if they are not found through the analysis we considered previously, their existence would be undermined, because if they exist in the way they are accepted, they would have to be found through those reasoning processes, and they are not found.

tshig gsal las phar la bkag pa'i skyon rang la mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan du dpyad bzod khas mi len pa dang ma dpyad pa 'jig rten gyi tha snyad byed pa ltar khas len pa 'god pas/ lan 'debs tshul de ltar bya ba'i dpyod byed kyi rigs pas skye 'jig gnas pa thams cad bkag par bzung nas de nas khas len bzhag na/ phar la bkod pa'i skyon thams cad mtshungs par 'jug pa mthong nas rang lugs med ces smra bar mi bya'o/ / 'di ni rab byed thams cad la go dgos te de yang ci tsam zhig 'gog mi 'gog gis mtshams rig pa dang / rigs pas dpyad mi bzod dang rigs pas gnod pas gnyis so sor byed pa la rag las so/ /

Prasannapadā presents the reason that the critique Candrakīrti leveled against the others does not apply to him as well as follows: We do not accept that things withstand analysis, but we do accept them according to ordinary conventions without analysis [59a]. Therefore, this is the way one should reply: One should not say that one has no position, thinking that since analytic reasoning refutes all arising, enduring, and cessation if one maintained a position, the critique that one levels against others will be seen to apply to oneself as well. This should be understood in the context of every chapter, because it enables one to draw the line between that which is to be refuted and that which is not to be refuted and to draw the distinction between that which does not withstand rational analysis and that which is undermined by rational analysis. Every chapter depends on these distinctions.
gsum pa ['jig pa rgyu med du 'dod pa dgag pa]
1.2.1.1.2.3.3 Refutation of the thesis that cessation is causeless
['di] la gnyis/ tshig gsal las 'byung ba dang / rigs pa drug cu pa'i 'grel pa las 'byung ba'o/ /
The third section has two parts: the arguments presented in Prasannapadā and the arguments presented in Yuktiṣaṣṭikāvṛtti.
dang po [tshig gsal las 'byung ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.3.1 The arguments presented in Prasannapadā

'dir 'grel pa las/ / 'jig pa rgyu med du khas blangs nas 'dus byas skad cig mar smra ba ltar na/ rgyu med pas 'jig pa med pa'i phyir dngos po skad cig dang 'jig pa dang bral ba rnams 'dus byas su ji ltar 'grub de'i phyir de thams cad mi 'grig par 'gyur ro zhes bkag go / de la 'jig pa rgyu med du smra ba rnams ni rang grub pa'i dus las dus gnyis par mi sdod pa'i 'jig pa ni dngos po de'i rgyu nyid las skye bas rgyu de las gzhan phyis byung gi rgyu med par 'dod la/ skad cig gnyis par zhig pa ni dngos med yin pas rgyu gtan med du smra'o/ / de'i phyir zhig pa rgyu med du smra ba la dngos po rnams skad cig gis 'jig pa med pas 'dus byas su mi 'grub pa dang 'dus byas rnams skad cig mar smra ba mi 'thad par ston pa 'di ji ltar rigs snyam na/ 'di la zhig ma zhig gnyis rgyus skyed mi skyed 'og nas mtshungs par gsungs pas dus gnyis par ma bsdad pa la rgyu med na dus gnyis par mi sdod pa la yang rgyu med dgos pas skad cig ma med par 'gyur la/ de lta na 'dus byas su yang mi 'grub cing 'dus byas skad cig mar smra ba yang mi 'thad pa'o/ /

Here the Commentary refutes the view of those who maintain that cessation is causeless and that the produced is momentary by arguing that since they would be without cause, it would follow that they would be without cessation, and how could entities that lack momentariness and cessation be produced? Therefore all of this would be inconsistent. Those who assert the causelessness of cessation maintain that cessation—not remaining for a moment after the moment of coming into existence—arises from the very cause of that thing, [188] and that apart from that cause there is no other subsequent cause. Since the disintegration in the second moment is a nonentity, they maintain that it is utterly causeless. Therefore, suppose someone asked: How does it make sense for you to present the inconsistency of entities not being produced and the produced being momentary to those who maintain that disintegration is causeless on the ground of the absence of momentary cessation? In response to this, as will be explained later, cessation and noncessation are similar with respect to whether or not they are given rise to by causes. Therefore, if that which has not remained for the second moment had no cause, then, since a cause would not be necessary for that which does not remain in existence in the second moment, it would not be momentary. In that case, neither could the thing be established as a produced phenomenon nor would it be tenable to assert that the produced phenomenon is momentary [59a].

de ni rigs pas 'gog pa yin la lung gis 'gog pa ni/ skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes pa dang 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid ston pas rnams 'du byed kyi phung po'i nang du 'du bar gsungs pa na/ 'jig pa rgyu bcas su gsal bar gsungs pa ma yin nam zhes pa yin te/ shi ba ni sems can de zhig pa yin la de skye ba'i rkyen gyis skye bar gsungs pas zhig pa rgyus bskyed par grub bo/ / mtshan nyid skye gnas 'jig pa rga ba bzhi 'du byed kyi phung por gsungs pa ni sngon po la mtshon na/ de'i skye ba'i bya ba la sogs pa'i bya ba bzhi dang ldan pas sngon po 'dus byas su mtshon la/ byed pa po sngon po nyid rang gi bya bar 'gal bas bya ba bzhi gzugs phung min la/ tshor ba dang 'du shes dang rnam shes dang mtshungs ldan 'du byed kyang min pas ldan min 'du byed do/ / 'on kyang sngon po sngar med gsar du skye ba dang rang dus na gnas pa dang rang gi dus las dus gnyis par mi sdod pa'i 'jig pa dang / snga ma las gzhan du 'gyur ba'i rga ba yang yin pas sngon po'i skye ba la sogs pa thams cad ldan min du 'chad pa min no/ /

This was a refutation through argument; now here is a refutation through scripture. When the teacher said that through birth as the condition, aging and death come about, and that the characteristics of the produced are included among the compound aggregates, did he not thereby clearly say that cessation has a cause? He did, because death is the disintegration of the sentient being, and that arises conditioned by birth. Saying this, he established that cessation is given rise to by a cause [Vasubandhu, Pañcaskandhaprakaraṅa, Sems tsam she 15a]. His assertion that the four characteristics—arising, enduring, aging, and ceasing—are dispositional aggregates can be illustrated as follows: If we take the example of a patch of blue, since it has the four activities—the activity of arising, etc.,—blueness is characterized as produced. Since for blueness—as an agent—to be its own activity would be contradictory, the four activities are not form aggregates. Neither are they feeling, nor perception, nor consciousness, nor psychological compounds, and therefore they are non-psychophysical aggregates. Nonetheless, such things as the arising of a patch of blue are not explained to be non-psychophysical aggregates on the grounds that the patch of blue arises where it has been previously absent, endures while it exists, ceases without remaining for the second moment after the moment when it comes into existence, and ages, becoming different from what it was earlier./28/[189]

sngon po'i 'jig pa'i bya ba la ni rang gi dus gnyis par zhig pa yang yod la de ldan min yin na rang gi rgyu rkyen gyis 'du byed dgos pas zhig pa rgyu bcas su grub bo/ // sngon po'i 'jig pa'i bya ba yin pas zhig pa gzhag dgos pa rgyu mtshan ni/ sngon po rang dus kyi ma zhig pa dang dus gnyis par zhig pa gnyis dngos po yin min mtshungs par ston pas de lta na de'i ra 'gyur bas so/ / 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid du zhig pa yang de'i mi rtag par 'gyur bas gsungs pa'i don ni bya ba de dag dang ldan pas 'dus byas su shes par byed pa'i mtshon byed tsam zhig la dgongs kyi/ lto ldir ba bum pa'i mtshan nyid yin pa lta bu'i rnam 'jog ni min te mi rtag pa la skad cig ma'i rnam 'jog med par thal bas so/ / skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes gsungs pa'i rigs pas dus gnyis par zhig pa de dus dang por skyes pa tsam la ltos kyi gzhan la ltos mi dgos pas// dngos po rnams dus gnyis par mi sdod pa'i skad cig mar 'jig pa yang bsgrub sla ste des na phyogs 'di la de thams cad legs par gnas par 'gyur ro/ /

The activity of the ceasing of the blue patch, since it has disintegration at the second moment after the moment of its coming into existence, and since it is a non-psychophysical aggregate, must be produced through its own causes and conditions. Therefore, it is established that disintegration has a cause. The argument that it is necessary to posit disintegration since it is the activity of the cessation of a patch of blue is this: Since it has been shown that the nondisintegration of the blue patch while it exists and its disintegration at the second moment are similar with respect to whether they are entities or not, it follows that its disintegration would be its impermanence. The meaning of the statement that these are the characteristics of the produced is that they are merely indicators—that in virtue of having these activities things are known as the produced. But they are not like characteristics such as the bulbousness of the pot, which are defining characteristics. They are not, because the absurd consequence would follow that impermanence would not have momentariness as its defining characteristic. By reason of the assertion that aging and death are conditioned by birth, disintegration at the second moment depends merely on having arisen at the first moment, and does not need to depend on anything else. Therefore, it is easy to prove that momentary things that do not remain for a second moment cease. So all of this fits together nicely in this system.

gal te myu gu zhig pa ni dngos med yin la de la rgyus ci zhig byed des na de la rgyu med do snyam na/ 'o na myu gu yang yod pa yin la de la ni rgyus dgos pa ci zhig yod de skyes zin pa/ slar yang bskyed du med do/ / 'di ni myu gu zhig pa la rgyus ci yang byed mi nus na ma zhig pa rgyus byed mi dgos zhes mgo mtshungs byas pa'o/ / 'di la ma zhig pa grub zin pas da gzod rgyus bya mi dgos kyang grub pa de nyid rgyus byas pa yin pas rgyu yod do zhes smra ba lan dngos gzhi yin mod kyang des mi phyed pa ni ston par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang sngar sa bon gyi dus na med la phyis yod pas myu gu'i skye ba rgyu dang bcas pa yin pa de bzhin du myu gu'i zhig pa yang sngar myu gu'i dus na med la phyis yod pa'i phyir rgyu yod do/ / gang yang myu gu zhig pa la rgyus ci zhig byed ces pa ni mi rigs te/ kyang de la rgyus da gzod gzhan zhig byed par ni mi 'dod kyi myu gu zhig pa de nyid rgyus byed pa yin no / de lta na de dngos por 'gyur ro zhe na/ 'dod pa yin te de ni rang gi ngo bo la ltos nas dngos po yin la myu gu la ltos nas dngos por med do/ /

Suppose one thought as follows: The disintegration of a sprout is a nonentity, so why would it need to have a cause? So, it does not have a cause. Well, then, the sprout is an existent, and since it is, what is the need for it to have a cause? For what is already arisen does not need anything to give rise to it. This shows that these cases are similar: If there is no need for a cause for a disintegrated sprout, there is no need for a cause for a nondisintegrated sprout. Since that which is nondisintegrated has already come into existence, it does not need a cause now. But its coming into existence was brought about by a cause; therefore, it has a cause. This is the fundamental response. We will demonstrate the invulnerability of this response below. Moreover, the arising of the sprout, which was not there previously at the time of the seed, and exists later, has a cause. Similarly, since [190] the disintegration of the sprout—which does not exist at the time of the sprout, but exists later—exists, it has a cause. Suppose one said that if this were the case, it would be irrational to ask what a cause would do for the disintegration of the sprout. We do not maintain that a cause in the present makes it become something else. But the disintegration of the sprout is indeed brought about by a cause. In that case, he would say, it must be an entity. We agree with this, because with respect to its nature it is an entity, though with respect the sprout it is not an entity.

gzhan yang sa bcu pa las/ 'chi ba yang bya ba gnyis su nye bar gnas pa yin te 'du byed 'jig par yang byed pa dang yongs su mi kho bo cag shes pa rgyun mi 'chad pa'i rgyu yang 'byin pa'o/ / zhes gsungs pas zhig pas bya ba byed nus pas rgyu dang bcas pa'o/ / skabs 'di dag tu tshig gsal las/ 'jig pa zhes gsungs pa ni rang nyid zhig pa yang 'jig par bzhed pa'i dbang du mdzad kyi pha rol po ni zhig 'jig 'gal bar 'dod pas 'dir zhig pa la bshad do/ / myu gus ni dngos po gzhan gyi zhig pa yang shes par bya'o/ /

Moreover, in Daśābhūmi-sūtra it says, Death also involves two activities: It destroys the compounds and it provides the cause for the unbroken continuum of ignorance. [phal chen kha 221b] Since it says this, disintegration can perform a function, and therefore it has a cause. In this context, in Prasannapadā, the usage of the word “destruction” accords with the thesis that disintegration of a thing itself is destruction. But the opponent regards destruction and disintegration as mutually incompatible. Therefore, here we use “disintegration.” Through the example of the sprout the disintegration of other entities should be understood.
gnyis pa [rigs pa drug cu pa'i 'grel pa las 'byung ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.3.3.2 The arguments presented in Yuktiṣaṣṭikāvṛṭti

de la skad cig dang por yod pa gnyis par zhig pa'i rgyu ni bshad zin la/ de las gzhan pa'i rgyun gyi zhig pa'i rgyu ni rigs pa drug cu pa'i 'grel pa las/ mar dang snying po zad pa mar me shi ba'i rgyur bshad pa lta bu rnams yin no/ /

The cause of the disintegration at the second moment of the thing that existed at the first moment has already been explained. Apart from that, the cause of the disintegration of the continuum is like the exhaustion of the butter and the wick as the cause of the extinguishment of the butterlamp as explained in the Yuktiṣáṣṭikāvṛṭti [dBu ma ya 15b].

'di la pha rol pos mar dang sdong bu zad pa mar me shi ba'i rgyu min gyi mar dang sdong bu zad pa ni mar me'i skad cig tha mas de'i rigs 'dra ma 'ongs pa skyed pa'i rkyen ma tshang ba yin la/ ma 'ongs pa yang skye ba'i rkyen ma tshang bas ma skyes so zhes smra ba la de lta na rkyen ma tshang ba ma yin na de nges par skye bas/ rkyen ma tshang ba ma 'ongs pa mi skye ba'i rgyur khas blangs la de'i phyir gnas pa'i rgyu zad pas 'bras bu gnas pa zad par khas blangs par 'gyur ro zhes bshad do/ /

Here, according to the opponent, the exhaustion of the butter and the wick are not the cause of the extinguishment of the butterlamp; instead the exhaustion of the butter and the wick is the incompleteness of the set of conditions for the final moment of the butterlamp to give rise to a similar subsequent moment. They also say that a thing yet to come is also not arisen just because the set of causes for it to arise is not complete. In response to that, it is said that if that were so, then when the set of causes for something is not incomplete that thing must certainly arise. The incompleteness of the set of causes is accepted as the cause of the non-arising of things that are yet to come. Therefore, it would have to be accepted that, because of the exhaustion of the cause of endurance, the effect—the endurance—is exhausted. [191]

myu gu skye 'gyur da lta ma skyes pa'i ma 'ongs pa'i rgyu yang rkyen sngar yod zad nas ma tshang ba la bzhed de myu gu zhig pa dngos por 'jog pa la ma 'ongs pa la yang 'di 'dra zhig bzhed dgos so/ / mar dang sdong bu zad pa rgyur mi rung bar brtsad pa'i lan du/ de dag ma zad pa'i yod pa yang rgyur mi 'thad do zhes mgo mtshungs mdzad nas/ sa bon ni yod pa'i gnas skabs kho nar myu gu'i rgyur mi rtogs zhes sogs bshad pa'i don ni sngar bshad zin to/ // des nas myug la sogs pa'i rgyu 'bras 'di dag ni 'jig rten pas mthong ba ltar gzhag dgos la 'jig rten na ni chu med pas nga yi 'bras nyes so/ / zas med pas nga yi bu shi'o zhes snga ma med pas phyi ma brlag pa byas par smra'o/ / de yang zas dang chu ma zad pa bu 'tsho ba dang 'bras legs pa'i rgyur byed pa bzhin du de dag zad pa yang de rnams zad pa'i rgyur 'jog pa'i phyir/ pa min pa'i de dag med pa dang mi 'dra ste des 'bras bu'i phyogs kyang shes par bya'o/ / 'di ni 'og nas/ dngos dang dngos med 'dus byas yin/ / zhes pa dang / rigs pa drug cu pa las kyang / rgyu zad nyid las zhi ba ni/ / zad ces bya bar dmigs pa ste//zhes gsungs pa'i don yin la

The cause of the sprout that is to arise—not arisen at present, and yet to come—is also regarded as the incompleteness of its conditions due to conditions that existed earlier. This is because one who posits the disintegration of the sprout as an entity must maintain the same thing about that which is yet to come. Candrakīrti responds to the argument that the exhaustion of the butter and the wick cannot be a cause by providing a similar argument to the effect that their nonexhaustion and existence could then also not be a cause: The seed, at that very stage of its existence, cannot be perceived as the cause of the sprout. The explanation of such statements has been presented earlier./29/ Therefore, causes and effects of things such as the sprout should be posited in accordance the way things are seen by ordinary beings. Ordinary people say, “Since there was no water my crops failed, without food, my son died, Without the former, the latter was lost.” Just as the non-exhaustion of water and the non-exhaustion of food, respectively, are regarded as the causes of good crops and the life of the son, their exhaustion is also posited as the cause of the respective losses. Therefore their nonexhaustion is not similar to their nonexistence, which is not exhaustion and thus one should understand this with respect to the effect as well. This is the meaning of the statement, “Both things and non-things are compounded” [XXV: 13], as will be explained below, and of the following statement in Yuktiṣaṣṭikā: From the exhaustion of causes comes peace. Exhaustion is perceived. [20ab]

brgya pa las kyang / 'bras bu yis ni rgyu bshig pa/ / des na med pa skye mi 'gyur/ / zhes rgyu 'gags pa 'bras bu skye bzhin pas byas par bshad pas 'phags pa yab sras kyi bzhed pa'o/ / myu gu zhig pa'i 'das pa dngos por bzhed pa'i gnad kyis myu gu'i ma 'ongs pa yang de dang 'dra ste/ des na med pa skye mi 'gyur gyi yang don no/ / 'das ma 'ongs kyi 'jog tshul 'di ni rang gi ngo bos grub pa la mi 'thad kyang rang bzhin de tha snyad du yang khas mi len pa'i lugs la shin tu 'thad par brgya pa'i 'grel pa las gsung la lugs 'di la shin tu gal che yang grags chung bar 'dug pas zhib tu bshad do/ /

Catuḥśataka also says: The effect destroys the cause. Therefore, the nonexistent does not arise. [XV: 2] The cessation of the cause is brought about by the effect that is in the process of arising, as has been explained, and so is the view of the noble father and son. Because of the fact that they maintain that the past disintegration of the sprout is an entity, the future sprout is treated similarly. And this also means that nonexistents do not arise. This framework for understanding the past and the future is not tenable in the system according to which things exist inherently, but it is completely tenable according to the system in which essence is not acceptable even conventionally. This is explained in the Commentary to Catuḥśataka [dBu ma ya 224a] [192] and is extremely important in this system. However, since it is little known, it has been explained in detail here.
gnyis pa [khyad par gyi mtshan nyid dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.2 Individual refutations of the particular characteristics
gal te 'dus byas kyi spyi'i mtshan nyid skye 'jig gnas pa rnams bkag mod kyang khyad par gyi mtshan nyid sra ba dang lkog shal sogs dang ldan pa'i 'dus byas rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose one argued that although the universal characteristics of the produced—arising, enduring, and ceasing—have been refuted, the produced phenomena which have particular characteristics—solidity, dewlap-possession, etc.—do exist essentially.
skye dang gnas dang 'jig pa dag / ma grub phyir na 'dus byas med/ /
33. Since arising, enduring, and ceasing Do not exist, there are no produced things.
'di ltar skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'jig pa dag rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa'i phyir na 'dus byas rang bzhin gyis med do/ / de'i phyir de'i khyad par rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pa med do/ /

Thus it follows from the fact that arising, enduring, and ceasing are not essentially existent that the produced does not exist essentially. Therefore these particular characteristics do not exist essentially either.
gnyis pa [des 'dus ma byas rang bzhin gyis grub pa yang khegs par bstan] ni/
1.2.2 Showing that thereby the essential existence of the unproduced is also refuted
gal te 'dus byas ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i mi mthun phyogs 'dus ma byas yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one argued that the produced exists essentially because its opposite, the unproduced, exists.
'dus byas rab tu ma grub pas/ / 'dus ma byas ni ci ltar 'grub/ /
33cd. If no produced things exist, How could the unproduced exist?

'dus byas ni sngar bshad pa ltar rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis rab tu ma grub pas 'dus ma byas so sor brtags pa'i 'gog pa dang so sor brtags pa ma yin pa'i 'gog dang / nam mkha' dang de bzhin nyid bzhi po ni ji ltar na ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'grub ste mi grub bo zhes gsal bar bstan to//'dir gzhung las 'dus byas bden pa ba rgyas par bkag pas 'dus ma byas ni bden par ji ltar 'grub ces gsungs pa'i dgongs pa ni/ 'dus ma byas bden par 'dod pas kyang tshad ma'i gzhal byar 'dod dgos la de lta na/ re zhig gzhal bya mi 'jal te/ / zhes sogs kyi rigs pa dang / thob byar 'dod na'ang / re zhig thob pa mi 'thob ste/ / zhes sogs dang gzhi 'di 'dra zhig la gnas zhes 'dod na'ang / re zhig gnas pa mi gnas te/ / zhes sogs kyis dgag go // de bzhin du thob byed kyi rgyu 'dod na'ang phung po brtag par bshad pa bzhin du dgag la/ yang de dag la mtshan mtshon ni 'dod dgos la de lta na khams brtag nas bshad pa bzhin du dgag ste/ des mtshon nas rab byed sngar bshad pa gzhan nas 'byung ba'i rigs pa yang 'don pa bsgyur la dgag go / rigs pa des 'dus ma byas thob bya sogs su bden par 'dod pa mi khegs na 'dus byas bden pa yang dgag mi nus pa rnam pa thams cad du mtshungs so/ / des na 'phags pa'i rab byed re re'i rigs pa legs por shes na'ang de 'dra ba'i log rtog thams cad ldog pas 'dus byas mi bden kyang 'dus ma byas bden par grub bo zhes pa ni rigs pa mi shes pa'i gtam mo/ /

Since, as explained earlier, produced things do not exist inherently in any way, how could these four unproduced phenomena—cessation occasioned by analysis, cessation not occasioned by analysis, space, and reality—exist inherently?/30/ They cannot! This is explained clearly. It follows from the extensive refutation of the true existence of produced things that there is no way that unproduced phenomena can truly exist. The point of asserting this in this text is that even those who maintain that the unproduced truly exists must maintain that it is an object of authoritative cognition. In that case, this argument refutes them: “The object to be measured is not measured.” Even if they maintain them to be objects to be achieved, “Whatever is to be achieved is not achieved” refutes them. Even if they maintain that it abides on a certain ground, “Whatever endures does not endure” refutes them./31/ Even if they posit them as the cause of achievement, they are refuted as it is explained in the “Examination of the Aggregates.” Those who posit them in terms of characteristics and characterized should be refuted as it is explained in the “Examination of the Elements.” Following these examples, the arguments explained in the other previous chapters could be reformulated as refutations. [193] If these arguments could not refute the true existence of the unproduced as objects to be achieved, etc., it would be impossible to refute the true existence of produced things. These cases are completely similar. Thus, if one develops a good understanding of the arguments advanced by the master, in each chapter all such misunderstandings will be eliminated. Therefore, to say that although the produced are not truly existent, the unproduced are truly existent is the statement of a philosophical neophyte.
gsum pa [de ltar bkag pa la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba] ni/
1.2.3 Rebutting the view that this refutation contradicts scriptures
gal te skye 'jig gnas pa ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub na 'dus byas skye bar yang mngon no zhes soT gsungs pa de ji ltar rig par bya zhe na/
If arising, enduring, and ceasing do not exist inherently, how could one make sense of statements such as “the produced are seen to arise” [Saṁyuttanikāya, Khandhavagga, ānandasutta, Vol. II, 792]?
rmi lam ji bzhin sgyu ma bzhin/ / dri za'i grong khyer ji bzhin du/ / de bzhin skye dang de bzhin gnas/ / de bzhin du ni 'jig pa gsungs/ /
34. Like a dream, like an illusion, Like a city of gandharvas, So have arising, enduring, And ceasing been explained.

rmi lam ji bzhin pa dang sgyu ma ji bzhin pa dang dri za'i grong khyer ji bzhin pa de bzhin du skye ba dang de bzhin du gnas pa dang de bzhin du 'jig pa gsungs kyi rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i skye ba sogs gsungs pa min no/ / ji ltar sgyu ma la sogs pa la ji ltar snang ba ltar gyi rang bzhin med kyang de rnams sgra'i tha snyad kyi lam du 'gyur ba bzhin du skye ba la sogs pa yang rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin kyang 'jig rten la grags pa tsam gyi sgo nas bstan to/ / mdor na rang gi ngo bos skye 'jig sogs ma grub kyang der snang ba'i sgyu ma lta bu la de dag 'jog pa yin pas de dag gsungs pa'i lung dang mi 'gal te/ skye 'jig sogs gzhag sa ye ma byung na lung dang 'gal ba yin no/ / skye ba la sogs pa mngon sum gyi blo'i gzung bya yin pa dang / de rnams la byed pa po yod pa dang / sems can mang pos thun mong du gzung bya yin pas/ bden par yod do snyam pa bzlog pa'i phyir rim pa bzhin du rmi lam la sogs pa'i dpe gsum gsungs par shes rab sgron ma las bshad do/ /

It is explained that arising, enduring and ceasing are just like a dream, just like an illusion, just like a city of gandharvas, but it is not said that arising, etc., exist inherently. Just as while such things as a mirage do not exist essentially as they appear, but are nonetheless the objects of our verbal conventions, arising, etc., though they do not exist essentially, are presented from the perspective of how they are known in the ordinary world. In brief, although arising, ceasing, etc., do not exist inherently, they are posited on the basis of that illusionlike appearance. This does not contradict the scriptures where they are presented, because it would only contradict scripture to say that arising, ceasing, etc., cannot be established at all. According to Prajñāpradīpa, in order to eliminate the thought that arising, etc., truly exist because arising, etc., are the objects of direct perception; because they have agents; and because they are commonly perceived by many sentient beings, the three examples, including the dream, are explained in that order [113a].
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar skye gnas 'jig pa ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub par rigs pas gtan la phab pa de nyid nges don gyi lung dang yang ldan par yang bstan pa dang / gzugs la skye ba med do zhes pa'i 'gres dang gzugs la gnas par mi bya'o zhes pa'i 'gres dang gzugs mi 'jig ces pa'i 'gres rnams kyis gsung rab las bshad pa de thams cad rab byed 'di yi rigs pa khyer nas bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ ting nge 'dzin rgyal po las/ lpags rgyus sha rus 'dus pa 'di bdag gi / chung ma yin snyam 'du shes bskyed nas ni/ / byis pa rmongs rnams 'dod chags skyed byed cing / / sgyu ma ji bzhin bud med mi shes so/ / ji ltar bu mo gzhon nu'i rmi lam na/ / bu pho byung zhing shi ba des mthong nas/ / byung na dga' zhing shi nas mi dga' ltar/ / chos rnams thams cad de bzhin shes par gyis/ / ji ltar dri za'i grong khyer smig rgyu dang*/ / sgyu ma ji bzhin rmi lam ji 'dra bar/ / chos rnams thams cad de bzhin shes bya ste/ / mtshan ma sgom pa ngo bo nyid kyis stong / / zhes pa dang / 'dus byas 'dus ma byas kun dben pa ste/ / drang srong de dag la ni rnam rtog med/ / 'gro ba kun tu 'dus ma byas thob pas/ / lta ba dag las 'khor mor rnam par dben/ / gang dag 'di 'dra'i chos rnams shes pa ni/ / rtag tu mi chags mi gtum mi rmongs te/ / de yi sems ni rang bzhin mnyam par bzhag / de ni ting 'dzin stobs can stobs dang ldan/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

In order to show the absence of inherent existence of arising, enduring, and ceasing, which has been shown by all of these arguments and which is corroborated by definitive scriptures, the statement that form does not have arising, [194] the statement that form does not have endurance, and the statement that form does not have ceasing—all of these statements presented in the scriptures—are brought into this chapter and are explained by providing arguments. In order to show this, a brief indication of corroboration by citations from the definitive sūtras is presented. The Samādhirāja-sūtra says: By generating the idea That some assemblage of skin, sinew, flesh, and bone Is my wife, fools develop attachment. They don’t understand that the woman is illusionlike. [Ārya-Vīradattagṛhapatiparipṛcchā-sūtra, dKon brtsegs ca 202a]/32/ and Just as in a young girl’s dream A boy turns up and dies, and thus She becomes happy when he turns up and sad when he dies, All phenomena should be understood in a similar way. [m Do sde da 26b] and Just like a city of gandharvas, a mirage, An illusion, a dream, and the like All phenomena should be understood. Meditation on representations is empty of essence. [m Do sde da 26a] Moreover, it says: All the produced and unproduced are free. Those sages have no conceptual thought. In every realm, since they have achieved the non-produced, They are entirely free from views. Those who understand this kind of phenomenon Are never attached, are never evil and never ignorant. Their minds are thus concentrated on essence. And they are powerful, possessing a powerful samādhi. [m Do sde da 147a]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

skye gnas 'jig pa tha snyad kyi dbang gis yod par bzhag pa tsam min par rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par bzung ba ltar yod na/ de gsum gang yang gzhag tu med par rigs pas gtan la phab pa bzhin nges par bya/ de nas tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la de rnams shin tu 'thad pa dang 'dus byas thams cad ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong yang de dang de'i ngo bor snang ba sgyu ma dang rmi lam ji lta ba de bzhin du 'char ba la bslab bo/ /

It should be ascertained through argument that if arising, enduring and ceasing existed as they are grasped—that is, inherently, without being merely posited through nominal convention—the three could not be posited in any way. Thereafter one should practice as follows: They are completely tenable insofar as they are merely posited by nominal convention, and although all of the produced things are empty of inherent existence, their appearance in their respective guises should be taken like illusions and like dreams.
'dus byas brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa 'dun pa'o// //
This is the seventh chapter called “the examination of arising, enduring, and ceasing.”
skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa so bzhi'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bdun pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the seventh chapter, having thirty-four verses, called “the examination of arising, enduring, and ceasing.”

d.crumb: *VIII. Examination of the Agent and Action

f.d: CHAPTER VIII. Examination of the Agent and Action
gsum pa rgyu las dang byed pa po yod pa dgag pa
we are now in the third part of that section which is the refutation of the existence of the agent and action.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
This section has three parts: the explanation of the chapter, confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ rnam shes la sogs pa 'dus byas kyi chos ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i rgyu las dang las de'i byed pa po yod pa'i phyir ro/ / ston pas kyang ma rig pa dang rjes su 'brel ba'i skyes bu gang zag 'di ni bsod nams mngon par 'du bya ba yang mngon par 'du byed do/ / bsod nams ma yin pa dang mi g.yo ba mngon par 'du bya ba yang 'du byed do/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pas/ las kyi byed pa po dang de'i las dang 'bras bu rnam shes la sogs pa yang nye bar bstan to/ / 'di dgag pa la gsum/ las dang byed pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag / tha snyad du las byed pa po 'jog pa'i tshul/ rigs pa de gzhan la yang sbyar ba'o/ /

Here some argue that produced phenomena such as consciousness exist inherently, because their cause—agent and action—exists. They point out that the teacher also says: The person driven by ignorance assembles meritorious dispositions, nonmeritorious dispositions and unshakable dispositions. [Śālistambha-sūtra, mDo sde tsha 120a]/1/ The agent of action, his action, and its effect—such things as consciousness—are thus presented. The refutation of this statement has three parts: the refutation of agent and action existing inherently, the mode of positing action and agent conventionally, and applying the argument to other phenomena.
dang po [las dang byed pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of agent and action existing inherently
['di] la gnyis/ phyogs mthun gyi bya byed ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag / phyogs mi mthun gyi bya byed ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag pa'o/ /

This first part has two sections: the refutation of the homogeneous position with respect to the inherent existence of agent and action and the refutation of the nonhomogeneous position with respect to the inherent existence of agent and action.
dang po [phyogs mthun gyi bya byed ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of the homogeneous position with respect to the inherent existence of agent and action
['di] la gnyis/ mu dang po gnyis kyi bya byed dgag / mu gsum pa'i bya byed dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the first two alternatives with respect to agent and action and the refutation of the third alternative with respect to agent and action.
dang po [mu dang po gnyis kyi bya byed dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation of the first two alternatives with respect to agent and action
['di] la gnyis/ dam bca' gzhag / sgrub byed bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: stating the conclusion and presenting the argument.
dang po [dam bca' gzhag] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Stating the conclusion
byed po yin par gyur pa de/ / las su gyur pa mi byed do/ / byed po ma yin gyur pa yang / / las su ma gyur mi byed do/ /
1. That which is an agent Does not perform an existent action. Nor does that which is not an agent Perform some nonexistent action.

'dis byed pas na byed pa po ste bya ba cung zad cig byed pa kho na la byed pa por bsnyad kyi mi byed pa ni ma yin la/ bya ba byed pa de yang byed pa po du las dang yin par gyur pa dang yin par ma gyur pa dang ltos sa so so la ltos nas yin pa dang ma yin par gyur pa la rtog pa zhig ste gsum las med do/ / 'di bya bas na las te byed pa po'i 'dod par gyur pa dam pa'o/ / de yang gsum ste las yin par gyur pa dang ma yin par gyur pa dang so so la ltos nas yin min gnyis kar gyur pa'o'o/ / de la byed pa po yin par gyur pa bya ba dang ldan pa de las su gyur pa ste bya ba dang ldan pa mi byed do zhes pa ni dam bca' gcig go / byed pa po ma yin par gyur pa bya ba dang bral ba yang las su ma gyur pa ste bya ba dang bral ba mi byed do zhes pa ni dam bca' gnyis pa'o/ /

Anyone who performs even the slightest action is called an agent, as one says, “since this acts, this is an agent.” And if they do not perform an action they are not. Only three alternatives preconceivable with respect to the performance or nonperformance of action: performance by an agent, by that which is not an agent, or by that which is and is not an agent in relation to that action. “Since this is acted upon it is an object; [196] the object is said to be the final end.” [Pāṇinivyākaraṇasātra, 1/4/49]./2/ With respect to this there are three alternatives: that which is an action; that which is not an action, or that which is and is not, depending on the individual object to which it is related. That which is an agent and has an action does not perform an action that does not have activity. This is the first conclusion. That which is not an agent and has no action does not perform an action that does not have activity. This is the second conclusion.
gnyis pa [sgrub byed bstan pa]
1.1.1.1.2 Presenting the argument
['di] la gnyis/ dam bca' dang po'i sgrub byed dang / dam bca' gnyis pa'i sgrub byed do/ /
This section has two parts: presenting the argument for the first conclusion and presenting the argument for the second conclusion.
dang po [dam bca' dang po'i sgrub byed]
1.1.1.1.2.1 Presenting the argument for the first conclusion
['di] la gnyis/ sus kyang ma byas pa'i las yod par thal bas dgag / ci yang mi byed pa'i byed pa po yod par thal bas dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation by reductio showing that there is an action without an agent and refutation by reductio showing that there is an agent that does not do anything.
dang po [sus kyang ma byas pa'i las yod par thal bas dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.1.1 Refutation by reductio showing that there is an action without an agent
yin par gyur la bya ba med/ / byed po med pa'i las su'ang 'gyur/ /
2. That which is an agent has no activity. There would then be action without an agent.

byed pa por ni bya ba byed pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis 'jog pas bya ba dang ldan pa kho nas byed pa po'i tha snyad 'thob bo/ / de ltar bya ba dang ldan pas byed pa po yin par gyur pa de la ni da gzod gang gis las de byed par 'gyur ba'i bya ba gzhan med do/ / gang gi tshe bya ba gzhan med pas byed pa po las mi byed pa de yi tshe byed pa po la ltos pa med pa'i las su'ang 'gyur na/ byed pa po med pa'i las ni mi srid de mo gsham gyi bus bum pa byed pa bzhin no/ / de ltar thal ba bzlog pa na byed pa po med pa'i las mi srid pa'i gtan tshigs kyis byed pa po yin par gyur pa las yin pa byed pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa med do zhes dam bca' dang po sgrub bo/ /

Since the agent is posited on the ground that it performs an action, only in virtue of having activity does it merit the title “agent.” That which is already an agent in virtue of performing an action now does not have another action to perform in order to become an agent. Since it does not have another action to perform, the agent would not perform an action; then the action would be independent of the agent. It is impossible to have an action without an agent. This would be like the son of a barren woman making a pot. When the reductio is contraposed, we can reason from the impossibility of an action without an agent to the fact that the performance of an action by that which is an agent does not exist inherently. Thus we prove the first conclusion.

gal te rdza bum bzo ba'i bya ba byed pa de nyid kyis rdza mkhan bum pa'i byed pa por yang 'jog la rdza bum bzo ba'i las kyang byas pa ma yin nam/ rdza bum bzo ba'i bya ba byed pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis rdza mkhan bum pa'i byed pa por dang por bzhag nas/ de'i 'og tu bya ba de min pa'i bya ba zhig bya dgos pa la bya ba gzhan med pas/ rdza bum bzo ba'i las de byed pa pos ma byas pa'i las su 'gyur ro zhes pa'i sun 'byin 'di ji ltar rigs she na/ de la byed pa po yin pas las yin pa byed cing de yang bya ba gcig byed pa de nyid kyis byed pa po dang las de byas par yang 'jog pa ni tha snyad du rang yang de ltar 'dod de/ dper na lhas byin phyag 'tshal ba'i bsod nams kyi 'du bya ba 'du byed do zhes pa la lhas byin las de byed pa po yin la phyag 'tshal ba'i las de bsod nams kyi 'du bya bar gsungs pas las so/ // de 'du byed par gsungs pas las su gyur pa zhig byed pa yin no/ / de lta na'ang byed pa po dang las ngo bo nyid kyis grub par smra na las su bya ba gcig byed pa des byed pa po dang las byas pa gnyis kar 'jog mi nus pas sun 'byin de 'jug ste/ 'di ltar bzo ba'i las de rdza mkhan dang 'jim pa gnyis ka la brten la gzhi de gnyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis sos sor grub na bya ba yang ris su chad nas so sor gnas dgos pas thun mong du bya ba gcig rten pa 'gal ba yin te sngar bshad zin pa ltar ro/ //

Merely in virtue of performing the action of making a clay pot, the potter is posited as the agent of the making of the pot./3/ Did he not perform the action of making the pot? Just because he performs the action of making the pot, the potter is first posited as the agent. Thereafter, he would have to be performing an action that was other than that one, but since there is no other action, [197] the action of making a clay pot would become an action that is not performed by an agent. Why does this refutation make sense? We maintain conventionally that that which is an agent performs that which is an action, and just in virtue of performing a single action, one is posited as an agent, and that that action is posited as having been performed. For example, it is said that when Lhejin performs the meritorious action of prostrating, Lhejin is the agent of that action, and it is said that through the action of prostration the merit is accumulated, and thus it is an action. Since that merit is said to be accumulated, action is performed. However, suppose one asserts that the agent and action exist inherently. But when a single action is performed, one cannot posit that as both action and agent. Therefore the refutation succeeds. This is because the action of making is dependent on both the potter and the clay. If both of these bases existed individually through their own characteristics, the action should also exist as a distinct individual. Therefore it would be contradictory to have a single action relying on two bases in common. This is just as it has been explained earlier.

des na byed pa por rnam par 'jog pa'i bya ba de min pa'i bya ba gnyis pa zhig ma byas na/ byed pa po yin pas las yin pa byas par mi 'gyur ba yin te sngar gyi thal ba bzlog pa'i rtags kyi khyab pa yang 'dis 'grub bo/ / byed pa por 'dod pa des rang gis bya rgyu'i las de mi byed na byed pa por yang mi 'grub pas/ 'dir des bya rgyu'i las de sus kyang ma byas pa'i las su thal ba'i skyon brjod mdzad kyi gang zag de ci yang mi byed pa'i byed pa por 'gyur ba'i skyon brjod ma mdzad do/ /

Therefore, if it does not perform a second action, which is not the action in virtue of which it is posited as an agent, that which is an agent would not perform that which is an action. This establishes the relation required in the argument that is the contrapositive of the reductio presented earlier. That which is maintained to be an agent, if it does not perform the action it should be performing, cannot be established as an agent. Here, he charges that the absurd consequence would ensue that an action that is to be performed would not be performed by anyone, but he does not charge that the person who does not perform any action would be an agent.
gnyis pa [ci yang mi byed pa'i byed pa po yod par thal bas dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.1.2 Refutation by reductio showing that there is an agent that does not do anything
yin par gyur ba bya ba med/ / las med byed pa por yang 'gyur/ /
2cd. That which is an action has no activity./4/ There would also be agent without action.

las yin par ni byed pa pos byas pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis 'jog pas bya ba dang ldan pa kho nas las kyi tha snyad 'thob bo/ / de ltar bya ba dang ldan pas las yin par gyur pa de la ni da gzod gang gis las de byed par 'gyur ba'i bya ba gzhan med do/ / gang gi tshe bya ba gzhan med pas byed pa po las mi byed pa de'i tshe las med pa ste las mi byed pa kho nar gang zag de byed pa por yang 'gyur na/ las mi byed pa'i byed pa po ni med de mtshams med pa'i las mi byed pa ni de'i byed pa por ma mthong ba bzhin no/ / zhes thal ba bzlog pa'i rtags kyis las yin pa byed pa po yin pas byed pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa med do zhes sgrub bo/ / sun 'byin 'di 'jug lugs kyang sngar bstan pas shes par bya'o/ / las su 'dod pa de rang byed mkhan gyis ma byas na las yin par yang mi 'grub pas 'dir de byed mkhan de ci yang mi byed pa'i byed pa por 'phangs kyi bya rgyu sus kyang ma byas pa'i las su ma 'phangs so/ /

Since that which is an action is posited on the ground that it is performed by an agent, only that which has activity merits the title “action.” That which is already an action in virtue of having activity [198] now does not need another activity to make it happen. If it were the case that without another activity, the agent does not perform an action then, that very person—who is without an action (that is, who does not perform an action)—would be the agent. But there is no agent without an action. For example, a person who does not perform an action with immediate consequence/5/ is not seen as its agent. Thus, the argument that is the contrapositive of the reductio establishes that that which is an action is not inherently performed by that which is an agent. The way this refutation proceeds should be understood through the previous discussion. That which is maintained to be an action, if it is not performed by an agent, cannot be established as an action. Here, he hurls down the reductio that the agent of the action would be one who does not perform any action, but he does not hurl down a reductio that an action to be performed is not performed by anyone.
gnyis pa [dam bca' gnyis pa'i sgrub byed]
1.1.1.1.2.2 Presenting the argument for the second conclusion
['di] la gnyis/ rgyu med du thal bas dgag / de 'dod pa la gnod pa brjod pa'o/ /
This second section has two parts: refuting through the absurd consequence that there would be no cause and impugning those who maintain that.
dang po [rgyu med du thal bas dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.2.1 Refuting through the absurd consequence that there would be no cause
gal te byed po ma gyur pa/ / las su ma gyur byed na ni/ / las la rgyu ni med par 'gyur/ / byed pa po yang rgyu med 'gyur/ /
3. If that which is not an agent Were to perform that which is not an action, Then the action would be without a cause And the agent would be without a cause.

gal te byed pa por ma gyur pas las su ma gyur pa byed par 'dod na ni las te gang zag des bya rgyu de la ni rgyu ni med par 'gyur te bya ba dang bral ba'i phyir ro/ / der ma zad gang zag de rang gi bya ba byed pa por 'jog pa'i rgyu yang med par 'gyur te bya ba dang bral ba'i phyir ro/ /

If it is maintained that that which is not an agent performed that which is not an action, then the action that is to be performed by that person would be without a cause, because it would be without activity. Moreover, there would be no cause for positing the person as the agent of his action, because he would be without activity.
gnyis pa [de 'dod pa la gnod pa brjod pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.2.2 Impugning those who maintain that
rgyu med na ni 'bras bu dang*/ / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / de med na shes rab ni bya ba dang / / byed pa po dang byed mi rigs/ /
4. Without a cause, the effect and The cause would not be possible. Without this, action, Agent and instrument would not be possible./6/

bya rgyu dang byed mkhan la rgyu med na ni 'bras bu rdza bum med de de'i rgyu med pa'i phyir ro/ / rdza bum med na de'i byed rgyu'am lhan cig byed rkyen 'khor lo la sogs pa yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis po de med na ni 'bras bu bum pa ci zhig byed pa la bya ba yod pa dang bya ba gang zhig la rdza mkhan rang dbang du gyur pas byed pa po dang*/ 'jim pa yang bsgrub bya de'i bdag nyid kyis las sgrub par byed pa dam pa yin pa'i sgo nas byed par mi rigs so/ /

If neither that which is to be performed nor that which performs it has a cause, there would be no effect—no clay pot—because there is no cause. If there were no clay pot, its cause and supporting conditions, such as the wheel, would also not be possible. Without both cause and effect, for the purpose of making what kind of pot as an effect would there be action; would the potter independently become an agent; would the clay, being in its nature the primary cause of making that which is to be made, be the cause? None of this would make any sense.

bya ba la sogs mi rigs na/ / chos dang chos min yod ma yin/ / chos dang chos min med na ni/ / de las byung ba'i 'bras bu med/ / 'bras bu med na thar pa dang*/ / _mtho ris 'gyur ba'i lam mi 'thad/ / bya ba dag ni thams cad kyang / / don med nyid du thal bar 'gyur/ /

5. If such things as action were not possible, The virtuous and vicious would not be possible. If there were neither the virtuous nor the vicious, Effects could not arise from them. 6. If there were no effects, liberation and Paths to higher realms would not be possible. The absurd consequence would follow That all action would be pointless.

bya ba la sogs pa gsum mi rigs na ni chos dge ba bcu la sogs pa dang chos min pa mi dge ba bcu la sogs pa yod pa ma yin par 'gyur te/ spong ba dang bsten pa'i bya ba la rang dbang du gyur pa'i byed pa pos/ lus ngag yid gsum byed par gyur pa'i sgo nas spong ba dang bsten pa'i bya ba byed pa'i tshe chos dang chos ma yin pa skye ba'i phyir ro/ / chos dge ba dang chos min mi dge ba med na ni de gnyis las byung ba'i 'bras bu yid du 'ong ba dang mi 'ong ba med par 'gyur ro/ / 'bras bu de gnyis med na ni thar pa'i ched du der 'gyur ba'i lam yan lag brgyad sgom pa dang / / mtho ris te gzugs gzugs med kyi bde 'gro'i ched du der 'gyur ba'i lam bsam gtan dang gzugs med sgom pa mi 'thad cing / gzhan yang zhing las la sogs pa'i 'jig rten pa'i bya ba rtsom pa thams cad kyang don med pa nyid du thal bar 'gyur na don med pa min no zhes bzlog ste/ rim pa bzhin bzlog pas byed pa por ma gyur pas las su ma gyur pa byed do zhes pa nyes pa kun gyi 'byung gnas su gyur pa khas blang bar mi bya'o/ /

If the three—action, etc.—did not make any sense, [199] then such things as the ten moral virtues and the ten moral vices would not be possible, because the agent who independently acts abandoning or relying on them respectively, through body, speech, and mind as instrumental causes—when he performs the actions of abandoning or relying on them—gives rise to virtue or to vice, respectively. Without virtuous and vicious phenomena, there would be neither happiness nor unhappiness as their respective effects. Without these two effects, obtaining liberation by meditating on the eightfold path that leads to it would not make sense. It would not make sense to attain higher realms—the form and the formless realms—through the path of meditative concentration and formless absorption, which constitute the paths that lead to them. Moreover, the absurd consequence would follow that all mundane activities, such as farming, would be pointless. But since they are not pointless, one should contrapose each of these arguments in reverse order. Thus one should not maintain that that which is not an agent performs that which is not an action. To maintain this is the source of all of these errors.
gnyis pa [mu gsum pa'i bya byed dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2 Refutation of the third alternative with respect to agent and action
byed pa por gyur ma gyur pa/ / gyur ma gyur de mi byed de/ / yin dang ma yin gyur gcig la/ / phan tshun 'gal ba ga la yod/ /
7. That which is and is not an agent Does not perform that which is and is not an action. The same thing cannot both be and not be so. Since they are contradictory, how could it be like that?

rnam grangs kyi tshul smra ba dag rdzas la ltos nas byed pa po dang las yin la byed pa po dang byed pa'i snga rol du de gnyis min par smra ba ltar byed pa por gyur pa dang byed pa por ma gyur pa gnyis kas las su gyur pa dang las su ma gyur pa de gnyis ka'i ngo bo mi byed de de byed pa po dang las yin par gyur pa dang ma yin par gyur pa gnyis gcig la dus gcig tu phan tshun yin pa 'gal bas de 'dra ba de ga la yod de med pa'i phyir ro//gal te rnam grangs la ltos nas 'jog pas skyon med do snyam na/ de lta na'ang rigs pa snga ma gnyis kyis khegs pas mi 'thad do/ /

According to those who maintain that these have different aspects, a thing is an action or an agent depending upon its substance, and prior to their being agent and action, neither has its status. Similarly, some maintain that that which is and which is not an agent performs that which is and which is not an action. This would make no sense, because it would be contradictory for that which is an agent and that which is an action simultaneously to be that which is not an agent and that which is not an action, respectively. Where could such things be? Nowhere! Suppose one thought that since it was posited in accordance with their different aspects, no error is committed. Even that has been refuted by the previous two arguments, so that would not make sense.
gnyis pa [phyogs mi mthun gyi bya byed ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag pa]
1.1.2 Refutation of the nonhomogeneous position with respect to the inherent existence of agent and action
['di] la gnyis/ byed pa po re res las phyogs mi mthun re re byed pa dgag / las phyogs mi mthun gnyis gnyis byed pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of each agent performing each nonhomogeneous action and the refutation of the agent performing two nonhomogeneous actions. [200]
dang po [byed pa po re res las phyogs mi mthun re re byed pa dgag] ni/
1.1.2.1 Refutation of each agent performing each nonhomogeneous action
byed pa por ni gyur pa yis/ / ma gyur las ni mi byed de/ / ma gyur pas kyang gyur mi byed/ / 'dir yang skyon der thal bar 'gyur/ /
8. That which is an agent Does not perform that which is not an action. Nor does that which is not perform that which is./7/ From this all of those errors would follow.

gal te byed pa por ni gyur pa bya ba dang ldan pa yis las su ma gyur pa bya ba dang bral ba ni mi byed de byed pa po yin pas byed pa 'dir yang sngar bshad pa'i byed pa po yin pa la bya ba gzhan med pa dang sus kyang ma byas pa'i las yod pa dang las min pa byed pa 'dir yang sngar bshad pa'i las ma yin pa ni rgyu med du 'gyur ba sogs kyi skyon der thal bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / byed pa por ma gyur pas kyang las su gyur pa mi byed de de'i skyon ni snga mas shes par bya'o/ / 'dir mu gsum pas phyogs mi mthun pa byed pa ma bkag pa ni 'og ma'i skabs dang khyad med pa la dgongs so/ /

That which is an agent—that is, that which has activity—does not perform that which is not an action—that is, that which is free from activity./8/ This is because in this context as well, where that which is an agent is acting, as was previously explained, the absurd consequence would follow that there would be an agent without another action to perform, and there would be an action not performed by anyone. Moreover, as was explained before, in the context of the performance of that which is not an action, errors would ensue, such as the absurd consequence that that which is not an action would be causeless. In addition, that which is not an agent does not perform that which is an action, because of the error that should be understood to have been explained earlier. Here the reason for not refuting nonhomogeneity by considering the third alternative is that it is thought that it is not different from the following contexts.
gnyis pa [las phyogs mi mthun gnyis gnyis byed pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2 Refutation of the agent performing two nonhomogeneous actions
byed pa por ni gyur pa dang*/ / bcas pa las ni ma gyur dang / / gyur ma gyur de mi byed de/ / gtan tshigs gong du bstan phyir ro/ /
9. That which is an agent with activity Does not perform that which is not/9/ Or that which is and is not an action. We have already presented the arguments.

byed pa por ni gyur pa bya ba dang bcas pas las su ni ma gyur pa dang las su gyur pa dang ma gyur pa gnyis ka mi byed de de'i gtan tshigs te rigs pa ni gong du yin pa gyur la bya ba med/ ces sogs kyis byed pa po yin pas byed pa dang / las la rgyu ni med par 'gyur/ /zhes sogs kyis las min pa byed pa la skyon bstan pa dang / yin dang ma yin gyur cig la/ /zhes sogs kyis las yin min gnyis ka byed pa la skyon bstan pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

That which is an agent having activity performs neither that which is not an action nor that which both is and is not an action. This is because of the previous arguments—that is, lines of reasoning: “that which is an agent has no activity….” [VIII: 2a], which shows that saying that that which is already an agent performs an action is erroneous; and because of “… Then the action would be without a cause…” [VIII: 3c], which shows that saying that that which is not an action is performed is erroneous; and because of “The same thing cannot both be and not be so…” [VIII: 7c], which shows that saying that that which both is and is not an action is performed is erroneous.
byed pa por ni ma gyur pa/ / las ni gyur dang bcas pa dang / / gyur ma gyur pa mi byed de/ / gtan tshigs gong du bstan phyir ro/ /
10. That which is not an agent with activity Does not perform that which is an action Or that which is and is not. We have already presented the arguments./10/

byed pa por ni ma gyur pas las su ni gyur pa dang bcas pa ste bya ba dang ldan pa dang las su gyur pa dang ma gyur pa gnyis ka mi byed de/ de'i gtan tshigs te rigs pa ni gong du byed pa po min pas byed pa la rgyu med dang las yin pa byed pa la/ / yin par gyur la bya ba med/ /ces sogs dang / las yin min gnyis ka byed pa la/ yin dang ma yin gyur cig ni/ /zhes sogs kyis skyon bstan pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

That which is not an agent performs neither that which is an action—that is, that which has activity—nor that which both is and is not an action because of the previous arguments: An action without an agent would be causeless; and the lines of reasoning that show that that which is already an action must be performed is erroneous—“… That which is an action has no activity…” [VIII: 2c]; and that show that saying that that which both is an is not an action is performed is erroneous by “… The same thing cannot both be and not be so…”[VIII: 7c].
byed pa por gyur ma gyur ni/ / las su gyur dang ma gyur pa/ / mi byed 'dir yang gtan tshigs ni/ / gong du bstan pas shes par bya/ /
11. That which is and is not an agent Does not perform That which is and is not an action. This also should be understood from what has been presented earlier.

byed pa por gyur pa dang ma gyur pa gnyis ka yin pas ni las su gyur pa dang las su ma gyur pa re re nas mi byed de 'dir yang gtan tshigs te rigs pa ni gong du/byed pa po yin min gnyis ka yin pas byed pa la/ yin dang ma yin gyur cig ni/ /zhes sogs dang*/ las yin pa byed pa la/ yin par gyur la bya ba med/ /ces sogs dang / las min pa byed pa la/ las la rgyu ni med par 'gyur/ /zhes sogs kyis skyon bstan pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir rnam shes la sogs pa'i 'dus byas ni rang bzhin gyis yod de/ de'i rgyu las dang byed pa po rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir zhes smras pa ni rigs pa ma yin no/ /

That which both is and is not an agent performs neither that which is nor that which is not an action, because in this context the argument—that is, the reasoning presented earlier—shows [201] that it is erroneous to say that that which both is and is not an agent acts by “… The same thing cannot both be and not be so…” [VIII: 7c]; that it is erroneous to say that that which is an action is performed by “… that which is an agent has no activity…” [2c]; that it is erroneous to say that that which is not an action is performed by “… Then the action would be without a cause…” [VIII: 3c]. Thus it does not make sense to maintain that the produced, such as consciousness, exists essentially because its causes—actions and agent—exist essentially.
gnyis pa [tha snyad du las byed pa po 'jog pa'i tshul] ni/
1.2 The mode of positing agent and action conventionally

gal te byed pa po dang bya ba'i dngos po rnams med do zhes khyod kyis nges par bzung bas dngos po la skur ba btab par 'gyur la/ bya byed kyi dngos po med pa de kho nar yod do zhes sgro btags par yang 'gyur ro zhe na/

Some one might say: Since you say that such entities as agent and action are nonexistent, by ascertaining them in that way you fall into deprecation, and by saying that the nonentity of action and agent exist in reality, you fall into fabrication.
byed po las la brten byas shing / / las kyang byed po de nyid la/ / brten nas 'byung ba ma gtogs par/ / grub pa'i rgyu ni ma mthong ngo*/ /
12. Agent depends upon action. Action depends on the agent as well. Apart from dependent arising One cannot see any cause for their existence.

dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par smra ba khyod la ni dngos po sngar yod phyis med par smra ba las dngos po thams cad la skur 'debs yod de rang bzhin gyis yod na nam yang med pa mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / kho bos ni brten nas skyes pa'i phyir dngos po thams cad la rang bzhin ma dmigs te/ des na don dam dang kun rdzob tu yod pa gang zhig la skur pa btab par 'gyur te/ don dam par 'ga' yang med pa'i phyir dang kun rdzob tu brten nas skye ba thams cad khas len pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad du yang rin chen phreng ba las/ smig rgyu la ni 'di chu zhes/ / bsams te der ni song ba las/ / gal te chu de med do zhes/ / 'dzin pa de ni blun pa nyid/ / de bzhin smig rgyu lta bu yi/ / 'jig rten yod ce'am med pa zhes/ / 'dzin pa de ni rmongs pa ste/ / rmongs pa yod na mi grol lo/ / mi shes pa las sngar brtags shing / / phyi nas de nyid don nges na/ / gang tshe dngos po mi dmigs pa/ / de tshe dngos med ga la 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs te/

For you, who maintain that entities exist inherently, to say that an entity that existed previously does not exist later is to deprecate all entities, because if they existed essentially it would not be tenable for them ever to be nonexistent. As far as we are concerned, since they are dependently arisen, no entities are seen as having essence. Therefore, how could this deprecate either ultimate or conventional existence, since we maintain that nothing at all is ultimately existent, and that, conventionally, all phenomena arise dependently. As it says in Ratnāvalī, Seeing a mirage one might think that There is water here. If, having gone there, One says, “There is no water here,” Having held this would have been really stupid. Similarly, one says that this miragelike world Exists or does not exist. Having held this would be ignorant. If there is ignorance there is no liberation. [1: 55, 56] That which had been previously fabricated by ignorance Is later correctly ascertained. Then, when an entity is not perceived, How could there be a nonentity? [1: 98]

dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par 'dzin pa bkag pa ni smig rgyu la chur bzung ba bkag pa dang 'dra bas skur 'debs min no/ / dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa mi dmigs pa de'i tshe dngos po med pa ste rang bzhin med pa yang don dam par grub par ga la 'gyur te/ don dam par dngos po gang yang mi srid pas de dag gi dngos med kyang don dam par med do/ / de'i phyir dngos po kun rdzob smig rgyu'i chu dang 'dra ba rnams ni 'jig rten pa'i 'khrul shes khas blangs nas/ rkyen nyid 'di pa tsam du khas blangs pa kho nas 'grub kyi gzhan gyis ni ma yin te 'di ltar/ mi byed cing las la ltos pa med pa ni byed pa por mi rung ba'i phyir lhas byin byed pa po yin pa ni las la brten byas shing ste de la ltos nas 'byung ba ste 'grub la/ byed pa pos mi byed pa ni las su mi 'gyur bas byed pa por ma zad las kyang byed pa po de nyid la brten nas 'byung ba ste 'grub kyi de ma gtogs pa ngo bo nyid kyis 'grub pa'i rgyu ste thabs gzhan ni ma mthong ngo / /

The refutation of grasping things as existing essentially [202] is similar to the refutation of regarding a mirage as water. Therefore there is no deprecation. When entities are not seen as existing essentially, how could nonentities—that is, essencelessness—be ultimately existent? For ultimately, no entity is possible. Therefore their entititlessness also does not exist ultimately. Therefore, only for those who maintain things to be merely conditioned and who accept mundane consciousness to be erroneous, do conventional entities exist like the water in a mirage, but not for anyone else. This is because since that which neither performs nor depends upon action cannot be an agent Lhejin’s being an agent depends on action; that is, it comes into existence depending on that. That which an agent does not perform is not an action. Thus, not only is the agent dependent, but also the action arises—that is, comes into existence—in dependence upon the agent. But apart from that, no inherently existent cause or means is seen.

des ni phan tshun ltos nas yod par khas blang ba dang ngo bo nyid kyis yod par khas ma blang bar bstan te yod ces pa'i yod tshul la dbu ma pa dang dngos por smra ba gnyis kyi khyad par phye la des med tshul gyi khyad par yang bstan to/ /

That shows that the mādhyamika accepts things as existing in mutual dependence and does not maintain that they exist inherently, because this distinguishes between the mādhyamika and the reificationist with regard to their account of their mode of existence, thereby demonstrating their difference with respect to nonexistence as well.
gsum pa [rigs pa de gzhan la yang sbyar ba] ni/
1.3 Applying the argument to other phenomena
de bzhin nyer len shes par bya/ / las dang byed po gsal phyir ro/ / byed pa po dang las dag gis/ / dngos po lhag ma'ang shes par bya/ /
13. One should understand appropriation in the same way, Following the elimination of agent and action. Through action and agent All remaining things should be understood.
