ji ltar las dang byed pa po phan tshun ltos nas grub pa tsam yin gyi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa min pa de bzhin du/ 'di nye bar len pas na nyer len te nye bar blang bya dang 'dis nye bar len pas na nyer len te nye bar len pa po yang phan tshun ltos nas grub pa tsam yin gyi rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa min par shes par bya'o/ / yang ci'i phyir ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ma yin zhe na/ rigs pa gang gis las dang byed pa po ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa bsal ba'i rigs pa de kho nas nye bar blang bya dang len pa po yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i sbyor tshul ni len pa po yin min re re ba dang gnyis kas blang bya yin min re re ba dang gnyis ka mi len pa ste phyogs mi mthun pa la yang sbyar ro/ /

It should also be understood that just as agent and action only exist in mutual dependence and do not exist inherently, since this is appropriated, there is the appropriated—that is, that which is to be appropriated,/11/ and that since this appropriates, there is appropriation—that is, the appropriator; and that these are all merely mutually dependent and not inherently existent. Moreover, suppose one asks: Why do they not exist inherently? The very argument by means of which the inherent existence of the agent and action are eliminated refutes the inherent existence of the appropriator and the appropriated. [203] The mode of applying the argument is to apply it to these nonhomogeneous pairs, each of that which is and is not an appropriator and that which is both, and in each case to consider both that which is and is not appropriated and that which is both and to show that each appropriator does not appropriate.

las dang byed pa po rang bzhin gyis yod pa bkag pas nye bar len pa gnyis phan tshun ltos grub tu nges par bya ba kho nar ma zad kyi/ gzhan yang byed pa po dang las dag gis te de gnyis la rnam par dpyad pa'i rigs pas byed pa dang nyer len zung gnyis kyi lhag ma ste de dag las tha dad pa'i dngos po rnams kyang / ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag ste phan tshun ltos grub nyid du shes rab can gyis shes par bya'o/ // de dag kyang bskyed bya skyed byed dang 'gro ba dang 'gro ba po dang blta bya dang lta byed dang mtshan nyid dang mtshan gzhi dang 'byung bya 'byung byed dang / de bzhin du yan lag dang yan lag can dang yon tan dang yon tan can dang tshad ma dang gzhal bya la sogs pa thams cad do/ /

Through the refutation of the essential existence of action and agent not only should the mutual dependence of the two—appropriator and appropriated—be ascertained, but in addition “through action and agent,” that is through the arguments that analyze these two, “the remaining,” that is all of those entities, except for the action and appropriation pairs, are established as mutually dependent and their inherent existence is refuted. This should be understood by the wise. This also includes all of these: that which gives rise and that which is given rise to, going and the goer, the seen and the seer, characteristics and characterized, that which comes into existence and that which brings it about, and in the same way, part and whole, quality and the qualified; authoritative cognition and cognized, etc.

de'i sbyor tshul ni skyed byed dang 'gro ba po yin min re re ba dang gnyis kas bskyed bya dang 'gro ba yin min re re ba dang gnyis ka mi skyed cing der mi 'gro ba ste/ phyogs mi mthun pa la yang sbyar bar bya la lhag ma yang de ltar ro/ / yan lag dang yon tan yin min re re ba dang gnyis ka yang yan lag can dang yon tan can yin min re re ba dang gnyis ka la mi 'jug ces sbyar te phyogs mi mthun pa la yang sbyar ro/ /

The mode of application is to apply the argument to the following nonhomogenous pairs: to show that that which is, that which is not, and that which both is and is not something that gives rise to others or causes to go, respectively, does not give rise to or cause to go, respectively, that which is given rise to or goes, that which has not been given rise to or does not go, or both; and to apply it to the following nonhomogeneous pairs: to show that that which is and that which is not and that which both is and is not a part, and that which is and that which is not, and that which both is and is not a qualifier do not constitute or qualify, respectively, that which is and that which is not, and that which both is and is not, a whole or a qualified; and the rest can be treated in a similar way.

des na rab byed dang por bskyed bya skyed byed dang gnyis par 'gro 'ong dang gsum par blta bya lta byed dang / lnga par mtshan mtshon la dpyad nas bkag pa rnams kyis ni bskyed bya skyed byed sogs ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa tsam 'gog pas yod pa bkag pa min no/ de bkag pa na de rnams phan tshun ltos nas bzhag pa'i rten 'byung gi yod par 'grub cing tshad ma dang gzhal bya yang de dang 'dra bas/ / phan tshun ltos grub tshad ma dang gzhal bya khas mi len pa min te de ni bsgrub bya sgrub byed la yang khyad par med do/ / rgyu 'bras la sogs pa de dag kyang tha snyad phan tshun ltos pa tsam du ma zad don gnyis kyang phan tshun ltos pa gzhung gi don yin te/ phan tshun ltos pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis bya byed kyi don dang tha snyad thams cad la rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'gog pa'i skabs yin pas so/ / des na me yang du ba bskyed bya yin pa la brten nas 'jog gi ngo bos rang dbang du grub pa med pas lugs gzhan las me du ba la mi ltos par bshad pa sogs dang mi 'dra'o/ /

Thus the analytic refutations of that which gives rise to others and that which is given rise to in the first chapter, of going and coming in the second chapter, of the seer and the seen in the third chapter, and of characteristic and characterized in the fifth chapter only refute the inherent existence of that which gives rise to others and that which is given rise to, etc. but do not refute their existence. When this is refuted these are established as existing as dependently arisen and as posited in mutual dependence. As authoritative cognition and the cognized are also similar, [204] it is not the case that the mutually dependent authoritative cognition and cognized are not accepted, and there is no difference with regard to premises and conclusion as well. It is the purport of the text that with respect to such things as cause and effect as well, not only are the words mutually dependent, but the referents are as well, because this is in the context of the refutation of the essential existence of the words “action” and “agents” and their referents just by reason of mutual dependence. Thus, fire is also posited depending on the smoke to which it gives rise. But since it is not posited as inherently existent, as existing through its own power, this is not similar to other systems in which fire is not explained as dependent on smoke.

rab byed thams cad la de ltar du go dgos la phan tshun ltos nas 'grub dgos pa'i phyir na/de rnams la rang rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod pa'i rang tshugs thub pa med pas rten 'byung gi gtan tshigs nyid kyis rang bzhin med pa 'grub bo/ // de lta na rgyu 'bras kyi nges pa drangs pa nyid la brten nas mtshan mar 'dzin pa'i dmigs gtad thams cad 'jig par byed pas/ yang dag pa'i lta ba'i gol sa rtag chad dang sgro skur gyi mtha' thams cad de nas chod pa yin no/ / de lta bu'i rang bzhin gyis stong pa'i don rten 'byung gi don du ma rtogs bar du yang na bden 'dzin gyi dmigs gtad kyi lhag ma sdud/ yang na rgyu 'di las 'di 'byung gi rten 'byung rang lugs la mi bde bar rten 'brel gyi nges pa rnal ma drang sa med pas rtag chad gang rung gcig gi mthar ltung ba las mi 'da'o/ / gal te/ dngos po lhag ma shes par bya/ / zhes pa nyid kyis blang bya dang len byed kyi don rtogs par 'gyur bas/ de bzhin nyer len shes par bya/ // zhes su bkod mi dgos so zhe na/ de ni bden mod kyang rnam par dpyad pa la 'di gnyis gtso bor gyur par shes par bya ba'i phyir logs su bkod de rab byed phyi ma rnams su yang 'di gnyis kyi brtag pa phal cher 'byung ngo / /

This should be understood to be applicable in all chapters. Since things have to exist in mutual dependence, they cannot stand on their own in virtue of existing inherently. Thus, essencelessness is thus established just by reasoning from dependent origination. Thus, just by ascertaining causality one destroys all apparitions grasped as truly existent. From that point on, reificationism and nihilism, fabrication and deprecation—all of the antitheses of the right view—are cut off. As long as one does not understand the meaning of “dependent origination” as emptiness of essence thus explained, a residue will remain of the apparitions grasped as truly existent, or, on the other hand, one will not be free from any extremes of reificationism and nihilism, as one could not have a genuine ascertainment of dependent origination, being uncomfortable with dependent origination in one’s own system, as in “with this cause, this arises.” Suppose one said that just by “all remaining things should be understood” the meaning of “appropriated” and “appropriator” would be understood; therefore there is no need to state, “One should understand appropriation in the same way.” Although this is true, in order to make it understood that these two constitute the primary focus of the analysis, they are stated separately. [205] In the later chapters as well, the analysis of these two occurs frequently.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar dge mi dge'i las dang de'i byed pa po la sogs pa bya ba dang byed pa po thams cad rang bzhin gyis stong par rigs pas bstan pa de nyid nges don gyi lung dang ldan pa dang / rab byed 'dis bya ba dang byed pa po mi dmigs par gsungs pa thams cad bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ nye bar 'khor gyis zhus pa las/ sems dmyal 'jigs pa nga yis bstan byas te/ // sems can stong phrag du ma skyo byas kyang / / gang dag shi 'phos ngan song dag 'gro ba'i/ / 'gro ba de dag nam yang yod ma yin/ / gang dag ral gri mda' chen mtshon 'byin pa'i/ / gnod pa byed pa yod pa ma yin te/ / rtog pa'i dbang gis ngan song de dag na/ / lus la 'bab mthong de na mtshon cha med/ / sna tshogs yid dga' me tog kha phye zhing / / gser gyi khang mchog 'bar ba yid 'ong ba/ // 'di na de la'ang byed pa 'ga' med de/ / de dag rtog pa'i dbang gis bzhag pa yin/ / rtog pa'i dbang gis 'jig rten rnam brtags te/ / 'du shes 'dzin pas byis pa rnam par phye/ / 'dzin dang 'dzin med de yang 'byung ba min/ / yongs su rtog pa sgyu ma smig rgyu bzhin/ / zhes gsungs te ngan song du 'gro ba dang gnod pa skyel ba'i bya byed dang lha'i yul byed pa'i bya byed rang bzhin gyis stong zhing de dag tha snyad kyi rtog pa'i dbang gis bzhag par bshad do/ /

In order to show that the arguments that have shown that all actions and agents, including such things as moral and immoral actions and their agents, are essentially empty are corroborated by definitive sūtras, and that this chapter explains all the statements that agents and actions are not perceived, brief indications of corroboration by citations from the definitive sūtras are presented. The Upālipariprcchā-sūtra says I have shown fear of hell beings. Though many thousands of sentient beings are dismayed, Those beings never exist Who after death transmigrate to fearful lower realms. The weapons, like swords and arrows, And the harms they cause do not exist. Due to conception, those in these lower realms See these weapons fall upon them, but they do not exist. Varieties of beautiful flowers are blooming And magnificent golden mansions are seen. Here they have no agent Because they are simply posited by conception. The world is fabricated through conception. Through grasping what they perceive, fools are identified. Neither grasping nor non-grasping occurs. They are completely conceptualized, like an illusion or a mirage. [dKon brtsegs ca 129b] Thus it is said that those who transmigrate in lower realms, the actions and the agents who harm them and the actions and agents of the divine realms are essentially empty and are explained as conceptually and verbally posited.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

de ltar bya ba dang byed pa po rnams rtog pa'i dbang gis yod par bzhag pa tsam min par rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod par bzung ba ltar yin na/ byed pa po dang bya ba gang yang mi 'thad par nges par bya la de gnyis phan tshun ltos 'grub tsam du rtogs par bya'o/ /

So it should be ascertained that if actions and agents were not merely conceptually posited as existent, and if instead were inherently existent [206] as they are taken to be, no agent or action would be tenable, and it should be understood that they exist merely in mutual dependence.
las dang byed pa po brtag pa zhes bya ba rab tu byed pa ste brgyad pa'o//
This is the eighth chapter called “the examination of agent and action.”
byed pa po dang las brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu gnyis kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa brgyad pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the eighth chapter, having twelve verses, called “the examination of agent and action.”/12/
CHAPTER IX. Examination of the Prior Entity
gnyis pa gang zag gi bdag med bshad pa
The second part is the explanation of the selflessness of the person.
['di] la gnyis/ gang zag rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / gang zag rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
It has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the person and the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of the person.
dang po [gang zag rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
This chapter is the first of these two parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o// //
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citation of definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gnyis/ phyogs snga ma brjod pa dang / de sun dbyung ba'o/ /
The first section has two parts: presenting the opponent’s position and its refutation.
dang po [phyogs snga ma brjod pa] ni/
1.1 Presenting the opponent’s position
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang / / tshor sogs dang yang dbang byas pa/ / gang gi yin pa de dag gi/ / snga rol de yod kha cig smra/ /
1. Since such things as seeing, hearing, And such things as feeling also exist, In virtue of them, he who has them Also exists prior to them, some say.

'dir/ de bzhin nyer len shes par bya/ / las dang byed po gsal phyir ro/ / zhes smras pa de ni mi rigs te 'di ltar lta ba dang nyan pa la sogs pa dang tshor ba la sogs pa rnams nye bar len pa po gang gi nye bar blang ba yin pa'i nye bar len pa po de ni nye bar blang ba de dag gi snga rol na yod do zhes kha cig ste nyan thos sde pa mang bos bkur ba pa smra ste

Here one might say, One should understand appropriation in the same way, Following the elimination of agent and action, [VIII: 13ab] makes no sense, because someone, such as a śrāvaka-Sammitīya might say, since such things as seeing, hearing, and such things as feeling exist, the appropriator who appropriates that which is to be appropriated—that appropriator—must exist prior to that which is appropriated.
dngos po yod pa ma yin na/ / lta ba la sogs ci ltar 'gyur/ / de phyir de dag snga rol na/ / dngos po gnas pa de yod do/ /
2. If there were no existent thing How could such things as seeing also occur? Therefore, prior to this There must be an enduring thing.

rgyu mtshan ni nor gyi snga rol na lhas byin yod pas nor gsog gi mo gsham gyi bus ma yin pa bzhin du/ dngos po ste gang zag snga rol du yod pa ma yin na lta ba la sogs pa gang zag gis nye bar len par ji ltar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / de'i phyir lta ba la sogs pa de dag gi snga rol na dngos po ste 'di nye bar len byed kyi gang zag gnas pa de yod do zhes 'dzer to/ / sogs snga mas ni dbang po lhag ma bzhi dang phyi mas ni reg pa dang yid byed la sogs pa'i sems byung la sogs pa rnams bsdu'o/ / dang ni smras pa'i lta ba dang nyan pa dang tshor ba gsum dang ma smras pa'i dbang po dang sems sems byung lhag ma kun bsdu ba'i don dang / yang ni lhag ma bsdus pa dag kyang 'dir gtogs par yid ches par bya ba'i don dang / dbang byas pa zhes pa'i sgra ni rkang pa dang po gnyis po 'di dbang po dang sems sems byung thams cad bsdu ba'i dbang du byas pas de la 'jug pa'i don yin no zhes shes rab sgron ma dang de'i 'grel bshad las bshad do/ / gnas ma bu pa dang bzang po'i lam pa dang kun gyis bkur ba dang bla ma pa dang chos sbas pa lngas gang zag rdzas su yod par smra bar rtog ge 'bar ba las bshad do/ /

Their argument is that because Lhejin exists prior to his wealth, he can accumulate wealth, but a barren woman’s son cannot. Similarly, if a thing—that is, the previously existing person—did not exist, then how could such things as seeing—that which the person appropriates—occur? They could not occur. Therefore, they say, prior to these, such things as seeing, this thing—the person, their appropriator—must exist. The first “such things as”/1/ refers to the other four sense faculties and the latter/2/ refers to mental processes such as contact, attention, etc. The “and”/3/ conjoins the three—hearing, seeing, and feeling—with the sense faculties and the rest of the mental processes that are not mentioned. The “also” is there to confirm that the rest referred to by the occurrences of “such things as” are included here. “In virtue of them” [207] refers to the first two lines, which indicate all of the mental processes and mental episodes included there. This is explained in Prajñāpradīpa [124a]. Its commentary [Tarkajvālā, dBu ma dza 148b-149a] says that the five schools, Vātsīputrīya, Bhadrayāṇīya, the Sammitiya, Uttarīya, and the Dharmaguptaka, assert the substantial existence of the person.
gnyis pa [de sun dbyung ba]
1.2 Its refutation
['di] la gsum/ nye bar len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag / des nye bar blang bya yang ngo bos yod pa khegs par bstan/ nye bar len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis med pa la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the inherent existence of the appropriator, showing that thereby the inherent existence of that which is to be appropriated is refuted, and rebutting the argument against the inherent nonexistence of the appropriator.
dang po [nye bar len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag]
1.2.1 Refutation of the inherent existence of the appropriator
['di] la gnyis/ gzhan gyis brtags pa'i bdag dgag / rang gis tha snyad du gang zag 'jog pa'i tshul lo/ /
This first part has two sections: refutation of the self fabricated by others and the way we posit the self conventionally.
dang po [gzhan gyis brtags pa'i bdag dgag]
1.2.1.1 Refutation of the self fabricated by others
['di] la gsum/ len pa po blang bya thams cad kyi snga rol na yod pa dgag / blang bya re re'i snga rol na yod pa dgag / blang bya thams cad kyi snga rol na yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /

This first part has three sections: the refutation of the existence of the appropriator prior to all of that which is to be appropriated, the refutation of the existence of the appropriator prior to each of the appropriated, and the refutation of the argument for the existence of the appropriator prior to the existence of all of that which is to be appropriated.
dang po [len pa po blang bya thams cad kyi snga rol na yod pa dgag]
1.2.1.1.1 Refutation of the existence of the appropriator prior to all of that which is to be appropriated
['di] la gnyis/ blang bya las snga na len pa por gdags pa'i rgyu med pas dgag / len pa po snga na blang bya la gnas pa'i rten med pas dgag pa'o/ /

This first part has two sections: The refutation on the grounds that there would be no reason to designate it as an appropriator prior to that which is appropriated and the refutation on the grounds that if the appropriator existed first, it would lack the appropriated as a basis.
dang po [blang bya las snga na len pa por gdags pa'i rgyu med pas dgag] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1 Refutation on the grounds that there would be no reason to designate it as an appropriator prior to that which is appropriated
gal te len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis yod na blang bya las snga phyi dang dus mnyam pa gsum las mi 'da' la phyi ma gnyis 'og nas 'gog pas 'dir blang bya las snga ba 'gog pa ni/

If the appropriator existed inherently, there are only three alternatives: the appropriator is prior to, simultaneous with, or subsequent to the appropriated. The second and third alternatives will be refuted later. The first—that the appropriator exists prior to that which is to be appropriated—is refuted here.
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang / / tshor ba la sogs nyid kyis ni/ / snga rol dngos po gang gnas pa/ / de ni gang gis gdags par bya/ /
3. If something existed prior to Such things as Seeing, hearing and feeling, How could it be designated?

lta ba dang nyan pa la sogs pa dang tshor ba la sogs pa nyid kyi ni snga rol na gang gnas pa'i dngos po gang zag de ni gang gis gdags par bya ba'i rgyu med pas spyir gang zag dang bye brag tu lta ba po la sogs par gzhag tu med par 'gyur ro// 'di ltar gang zag tu tha snyad gdags pa'i rgyu ni lta ba la sogs pa yin na gang zag de de dag las snga na ni/ de'i tshe bum snam bzhin du lta ba la sogs pa la ltos pa med par 'gyur la/gang zhig rang gi rgyu la mi ltos pa de ni rgyu med pa yin te/ nor la sogs pa la mi ltos pa'i nor can ltar med pa yin no/ / 'dir dus snga phyir yod na snga ma phyi ma la ltos pa mi rung zhes pa min te/ rang lugs kyis kyang rgyu 'bras thams cad phan tshun ltos par bzhed pa'i phyir ro//des na gang zag lta ba po la sogs par 'jog pa la ni lta ba la sogs pa la ltos pas khyab pa/ len pa po lta ba la sogs pa la ltos pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa yin na dus nam yang ltos dgos pas len pa po'i dus na ltos sa lta ba la sogs pa med pas de la ltos pa med pa'i phyir spyir ltos pa yang 'gog nus so/ /

Since there is no ground for calling any entity—that is, a person—an appropriator that exists prior to such things as seeing, hearing, and such things as feeling, no such thing can be designated as a person in general or as a seer or another such thing, in particular. The ground for applying the term “person” to something is something such as seeing. If the person were prior to those, it would not be dependent on such things as seeing, like a pot or cloth. Whatever does not depend on its own cause would be without a cause, because it would be like a rich man [208] not depending on his wealth, etc. Such a thing does not exist. Here, this does not mean that if they are sequential, the earlier one does not depend on the later, because in our own system all causes and effects are maintained to be mutually dependent. Thus, the person presented as a seer, etc., would have to be so categorized in virtue of dependence on such things as seeing. If the appropriator—which depends on such things as seeing—existed inherently, then it would always have to be dependent. At the time when the appropriator exists, without the basis of dependence—such things as seeing—it would follow that that which depends on them would not exist. In general this can refute their dependence as well.
gnyis pa [len pa po snga na blang bya la gnas pa'i rten med pas dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.2 Refutation on the grounds that if the appropriator existed first, it would lack the appropriated as a basis
gal te lta ba la sogs pa med par yang ste de dag gi snga rol na gnas par gyur pa'i gang zag des ni lta ba la sogs pa len par byed do snyam du sems na/
Suppose one thought that even without such things as seeing—that is, prior to them—the person who endures prior to them appropriates such things as seeing.
lta ba la sogs med par yang / / gal te de ni gnas gyur na/ / de med par yang de dag ni/ / yod bar 'gyur par the tshom med/ /
4. If it can endure Without such things as seeing, Then, without a doubt they also Can exist without it.

skyon gzhan 'di yang yod de de lta na ni nor dang 'brel ba'i snga rol na lhas byin nor las tha dad par gnas nas nor don gzhan gsog pa bzhin du/ len pa po la yang gang zag de med par yang ste de las don gzhan du lta ba la sogs pa de dag ni logs shig na yod par 'gyur bar the tshom med do/ /

There is an additional error here. If that were the case, prior to his possession of wealth, Lhejin, remaining separate from the wealth, could accumulate wealth as a separate entity. Similarly, with regard to the appropriator, even without the person, such things as seeing could, without a doubt, exist as separate entites.
ci yis gang zhig gsal bar byed/ / gang gis ci zhig gsal bar byed/ / ci med gang zhig ga la yod/ / gang med ci zhig ga la yod/ /
5. By what is someone disclosed? By whom is something disclosed? Without something, how can someone exist? Without someone, how can something exist?

de 'dod par ni mi nus te gang zag 'di ni mig la sogs pa 'di'i nye bar len pa po'o zhes lta ba la sogs pa nye bar blang bya ci zhig po yis len pa po'i bdag gang zhig po gsal ba dang mngon pa dang shes par byed cing / mig la sogs pa 'di ni gang zag 'di yi nye bar blang bya'o/ / zhes len pa po'i bdag gang zhig gis lta ba la sogs pa nye bar blang bya ci zhig po gsal bar byed do// // de'i tshe blang bya ci zhig po la ltos pa med par len pa po gang zhig po ga la yod de med la/ len pa po la yang ltos pa med par blang bya ci zhig po ga la yod de med pas de gnyis phan tshun ltos nas grub bo/ / gang gi tshe len pa po med par logs shig tu lta ba la sogs pa khas len pa'i tshe ni mig la sogs pa'i rten med pas lta ba la sogs pa med do/ / 'di yang sngar bshad pa ltar ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad na ltos pa mi rung ba'i rigs pa'o/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las de ni gang gis gdags par bya zhes pa'i lan du lta ba la sogs pa med par yang rang nyid kyis rab tu grub bo zhes lta ba la sogs pa zhes pa'i rkang pa gnyis kyi don smras pa na/ lta na gang zag de med par yang lta ba la sogs pa rang nyid kyis rab tu grub par the tshom med do zhes bstan pa la/ de lta yin na skyon ci yod ces dris pa'i lan du ci yis zhes pa'i rkang pa gnyis kyis de gnyis phan tshun du gsal bar byed par bstan nas rgyu mtshan des na de gnyis gcig med par cig shos med ces rkang pa phyi ma gnyis 'chad do/ / de dag gis ni len pa por gdags pa'i rgyu dang blang bya gnas pa'i rten med pas lta ba la sogs pa las tha dad par len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis gnas pa med par bshad do/ /

This cannot be maintained, because just as it is said that this person is the appropriator of such things as these eyes, one can ask “by what”—that is, by the appropriated seeing, etc.—is “someone” (that is, the appropriating person)/4/ “disclosed”—that is, made to appear and be known? Just as it is said that such things as these eyes are that which is to be appropriated by this person, one can ask “by whom”—that is, by which appropriating person—“is something,” that is, the appropriated seeing, etc.—“disclosed?” In that case, without depending on “something”—that is, that which is to be appropriated—“how can someone” (that is, the appropriator) “exist?” It cannot. Without depending on the appropriator, “how could something exist,” that is, that which is to be appropriated? It cannot. Therefore, these two exist in mutual dependence. If without the appropriator, such things as seeing were accepted separately, [209] since there would be nothing such as the eye as the basis, things such as seeing could not exist. This is also, as was explained earlier, an argument showing that it would not make sense for them to be inherently separate. According to the Buddhapālita, in response to “How could you designate it?” [IX: 3d] the meaning of the two lines “If it could endure…” [IX: 4ab] is explained to be that without such things as seeing it would exist entirely by itself. This then demonstrates that in that case, even without the person, such things as seeing could, without a doubt, exist entirely by themselves; and in that case, in response to the question, “so what is the error?” the two lines “By what…” [IX: 5ab] explain that these two disclose each other, and for this reason the next two lines [IX: 5cd] explain that neither of these two can exist without the other. These explain that since, without a ground for designating it as an appropriator, and without the basis of that which is to be appropriated, the appropriator itself cannot exist as inherently separate from such things as the seeing. [203a]
gnyis pa [blang bya re re'i snga rol na yod pa dgag]
1.2.1.1.2 Refutation of the existence of the appropriator prior to each of the appropriated
['di] la gnyis/ phyogs snga ma brjod pa dang / de sun dbyung ba'o/ /
This part has two sections: the presentation of the opponent’s view and its refutation.
dang po [phyogs snga ma brjod pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.1 Presentation of the opponent’s view
lta la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / snga rol gang zhig yod pa min/ / lta sogs nang nas gzhan zhig gis/ / gzhan gyi tshe na gsal bar byed/ /
6. Nothing exists prior to All of such things as seeing. Another one of such things as seeing Discloses another at another time.

gal te lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyi snga rol na gang zag de yod par khas blangs na skyon de dag yod kyang lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyi snga rol na len pa po gang zhig pa de yod pa min gyi re re'i snga rol na yod do/ / de'i phyir blang bya lta ba la sogs pa'i nang nas lta ba'i dbang pos gang zag de gsal bar byed pa'i dus na de las gzhan pa'i dbang po zhig gis dus de las gzhan gyi tshe na gsal bar byed kyi dus de'i tshe na gsal bar mi byed do/ / lta ba la brten nas 'dogs pa'i tshe nyan pa la brten nas mi 'dogs pas rang gi blang bya'i snga rol du yang yod la/ gang zag tu gdags pa'i rgyu med pa'i skyon yang med do zhes zer ro/ / 'dis sngar yang rang gi blang bya'i snga rol na yod ces smras pa ma gtogs pa lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyi snga rol na yod ces ma smras la/ de la gang zag tu gdags pa'i rgyu med par thal ba'i skyon med de thams cad kyi snga rol du yod par mi 'dod pa'i phyir ro snyam du bsams so/ / da ltar gyi gang zag len pa po dang de'i mig la sogs pa blang byar 'dod pa 'gog pa yin pas/ tshe snga ma'i gang zag gis tshe phyi ma'i lus len pa skabs 'di'i len pa po dang blang bya'i don min no/ / 'o na gang zag gis lta ba la sogs pa len zhes pa'i don ci yin zhe na/ gang zag de gzugs la lta ba por song ba'i byed par mig gi dbang po song ba na des de blangs pa yin la/ de'i tshe lta ba'i dbang po dang dus mnyam du yod la nyan pa'i dbang po la sogs pa'i snga rol na yod par 'dod de des gzhan yang shes par bya'o/ /

One might argue as follows: If the person were accepted as existing prior to all of such things as seeing, those errors would ensue; however, although an appropriator that is “prior to all of such things as seeing” does not exist, one that is prior to each does exist. Therefore, when that which is to be appropriated—such as the visual sense faculty among “such things as seeing”—discloses the person, then “at another time” “another” sense faculty “discloses” it, but does not disclose it at this time. When, depending on seeing, it is designated, it is not designated in dependence on hearing. Therefore, it exists even before that which is it to be appropriated. Therefore, there would not be the error that there is no ground for designating it as a person. By this one would mean that earlier it has been said that the appropriator exists prior to the appropriated; [210] but it was not said that it exists prior to all of such things as seeing. Thus the absurd consequence does not follow that something is designated as a person without any ground, because it is not maintained that it exists prior to all of them. This refutes the assertion that the present person is the appropriator and that such things as his eyes are that which is to be appropriated. Therefore, the meaning of “appropriator” and “that which is to be appropriated” in this context is not the person of the previous life appropriating the body of the person in the next life. Well, then, what is the meaning of “the person appropriates such things as seeing?” We maintain that when the person becomes the seer of material form and the visual faculty becomes the instrument, the latter is appropriated by the former, and at that time it exists simultaneously with the visual faculty, and it is prior to such things as the auditory faculty. The others should be understood in the same way.
gnyis pa [de sun dbyung ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.2.2 Its refutation
lta la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / snga rol gal te yod min na/ / lta la sogs pa re re yi/ / snga rol de ni ji ltar yod/ /
7. If it does not exist Prior to all of such things as seeing, How could it exist Prior to each of such things as seeing?

gal te lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyi snga rol na bdag de yod pa min na lta ba la sogs pa re re yi snga rol na bdag de ni ji ltar yod de yod pa mi rigs te/ dper na shing thams cad kyi snga rol na nags med pa'i tshe re re'i snga rol na yang med pa dang*/ bye ma thams cad la til mar 'byin pa'i nus pa med na re re la yang med pa bzhin no/ / gzhan yang re re'i snga rol du yod par smra na thams cad kyi snga rol na'ang yod par khas blangs par 'gyur te/ re re ma gtogs par thams cad med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di dper na der yod pa'i mi re re la smras nas lhag ma ma lus pa na der yod pa'i mi thams cad la smras pa yin pa bzhin du/ gang zag de lta ba la sogs pa re re nas lhag ma ma lus par re re'i snga rol du yod pa zhig byung na mthar lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyis snga rol du yod pa zhig sgrub nus so/ // gal te dus rim can gyis re re nas bgrangs pa'i thams cad kyi snga rol du yod pa yin yang / lta ba'i snga rol na yod pa'i dus su lhag ma thams cad kyi snga rol na yod pa lta bu dus gcig gi tshe thams cad kyi snga rol na yod par mi 'dod pas mi 'gal lo zhe na/

If that person did not exist prior to all of such things as seeing, how could that person exist prior to each of such things as seeing? Its existence would not make any sense because it is just like this: since the forest does not exist prior to all of the trees, it does not exist prior to each of them either; and since all of the grains of sand together do not have the potential to yield mustard oil, nor do each of them. Moreover, if it were maintained that it exists prior to each of them, it would have to be asserted that it exists prior to all of them because apart from each of them, the totality of them does not exist. For example, if you speak to each of the people there, without leaving anyone out, then you have spoken to all of the people there. Similarly, if the person exists prior to each of seeing, etc., without leaving any of them out, then you can conclude that it exists prior to all of them. Suppose someone replies as follows: It exists prior to all of them as they occur in temporal order. [211] However, we do not maintain that when it exists as prior to all of them at a particular time, such as prior to seeing, it exists prior to all of the rest. Therefore, there is no contradiction.
lta po de nyid nyan po de/ / gal te tshor po'ang de nyid na/ / re re'i snga rol yod 'gyur na/ / de ni de ltar mi rigs so/ /
8. If the seer itself is the hearer itself, And the feeler, then For it to exist prior to each of these Would make no sense.

len pa po dang blang bya ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa 'gog pa'i skabs yin pas skyon med do/ / rigs pa 'dis kyang re re'i snga rol na yod par mi rigs te/ 'di ltar gang zag gcig lta ba la sogs pa re re'i snga rol na yod par 'gyur ba la gal te lta bo de nyid nyan pa po yin la tshor ba po'ang de nyid yin pa zhig dgos na/de ni mi rigs te lta ba'i bya ba dang bral ba'i nyan pa po yang lta ba po dang / nyan pa'i bya ba dang bral ba'i lta ba po yang nyan pa por 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / bya ba so so la byed pa po tha dad pa'i phyir lta ba po nyid nyan pa po yang de nyid de zhes pa de ni de ltar yin par mi rigs so/ / lhas byin gcig rim gyis mi bcu'i snga rol du gnas pa tha snyad du 'dod dgos mod kyang mi dang po'i snga rol na bsdad pa'i lhas byin de nyid mi gnyis pa'i snga rol na yang sdod par 'dod na/ sngar gzugs lta dus kyi lta ba po de nyid phyis sgra nyan dus kyi nyan pa po der khas blang dgos so/ / de ltar dgos mod kyang pha rol pos de ltar khas blangs pa med pas sun 'byin 'di ji ltar rigs snyam na/ spyir gnas ma bu ba la/ rnam 'grel las/ gang gi rang bzhin 'jig med pa/ / de la mkhas rnams rtag ces brjod/ / des na ngo tsha'i lta ba 'di/ / spongs la de ni rtag par smros/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin du sngar mig gi snga rol na gnas pa'i gang zag de nyid phyis rna ba'i dbang po'i snga rol na gnas pa'i tshe yang ma zhig par 'dod pas/ de ltar khas blangs pa'i sgo nas kyang skyon de brjod nus mod kyang / 'dir ni gang zag ngo bo nyid kyis grub na lta ba po dang nyan pa po gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis gcig pa dang tha dad pa las mi 'da' la/ tha dad 'og nas 'gog pas gcig yin na sngar chos gcig gi snga rol na gnas pa de nyid phyis chos gnyis pa'i snga rol du yang bsdad dgos pas/ rim gyis re re'i snga rol na yod par 'dod pa la yang lta ba po de nyid ces pa'i skyon brjod mdzad do/ /

There is no error in the context of the refutation of the essential existence of the appropriator and that which is to be appropriated. This argument also shows that it does not make sense for it to exist prior to each of them for the following reason: For one person to be prior to each of such things as seeing, it would have to be that very seer and the hearer as well as the feeler; but this would not make any sense, because a seer which lacks the action of hearing would have to be a hearer and a hearer which lacks the action of seeing would have to be a seer. Since each action must have a separate agent, to say that the seer itself is the hearer itself in that case would make no sense. Although conventionally, it can be accepted that one Lhejin sits in front of ten people who sit in order, if one maintained that the very Lhejin who sits in front of the first person also sits in front of the second person, then one would have to maintain that the very seer, while it saw material form earlier, is the hearer when it hears sound later. You might think that although it has to be like that, since the opponent does not maintain this, the refutation does not make sense. Pramāṇavārtika, addressing the Vātsīputraīya, says, What is by nature not destroyed The wise call permanent. Therefore abandon this embarrassing view And call it permanent. [[11: 205] Tshad ma ce 115a] Similarly, as it says above, since it is maintained that that very person that exists prior to the eye later exists prior to the auditory sense faculty without disintegration, they can be charged with the error of accepting such assertions. However, here, [212] if the person existed inherently, one could not escape two alternatives with respect to the seer and the hearer: They would have to be either inherently identical or different. Their being different will be refuted later. If they were identical, the very entity that existed earlier, before a phenomenon, must endure so as to exist before the second phenomenon as well. Therefore, “if the seer itself is…” is the critique of those who maintain that it exists prior to each in order as well.
gal te lta po gzhan nyid la/ / nyan pa po gzhan tshor gzhan na/ / lta po yod tshe nyan por 'gyur/ / bdag kyang mang po nyid du 'gyur/ /
9. If the seer is distinct, The hearer is distinct, and the feeler is distinct, Then when there is a seer there would also be a hearer, And there would have to be many persons.

'on te lta ba po de nyid nyan pa po yang de nyid du 'dod na sngar bshad pa'i skyon 'ong bar mthong nas gal te lta ba po dang nyan pa po dang tshor ba po rnams ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du 'dod na/ lta ba po yod pa'i tshe na yang cig car du nyan pa po yod par 'gyur na de ltar ni mi 'dod pas ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du med do// gzhan yang sngar ltar 'dod na skyes bu gcig la bdag kyang mang po yod pa nyid du 'gyur te lta ba po la sogs pa rnams ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

If, having seen that the previously explained critique applies to the assertion that the seer itself is the hearer, one maintained that the seer, the hearer and the feeler are inherently different, one would have to maintain that when the seer exists, the hearer would have to exist at the same time. However, since that is not maintained, they do not inherently exist separately. Moreover, if one maintained what was asserted earlier, one person would have to have several selves, because the seers, etc., would inherently exist separately.
gsum pa [blang bya thams cad kyi snga rol na yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.3 Refutation of the argument for the existence of the appropriator prior to the existence of all of that which is to be appropriated

gal te bdag ni lta ba la sogs pa thams cad kyi snga rol na yod do/ / 'on kyang bdag tu gdags pa'i rgyu med pa'i skyon med de lta ba la sogs pa'i snga rol ming dang gzugs kyi gnas skabs na/ ming dang gzugs kyi rkyen gyis skye mched drug go zhes gsungs pa'i lta ba dang nyan pa sogs 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i rgyu 'byung ba bzhi yod do/ / des na lta ba la sogs pa'i snga rol na 'byung ba bzhi'i nye bar len pa can gyi bdag yod do zhe na/

Suppose he continues as follows: The self exists prior to all of such things as seeing. But there is no error of designating it as a self without a ground, because at the time of name and form, which is prior to such things as seeing—as it said that through name and form as its conditions, the six faculties arise—the four elements from which such things as seeing arise must exist. Therefore, prior to such things as seeing, the appropriator of the four elements, that is the self, exists.
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang / / tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang / / gang las 'gyur ba'i 'byung de la'ang / / de ni yod pa ma yin no/ /
10. Such things as seeing, hearing, And feeling, And the elements from which they are arisen: These do not exist.

lta ba dang nyan pa la sogs pa dang tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang gang las 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i 'byung ba bzhi po de la'ang bdag de ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin no/ / gal te bdag de ngo bo nyid kyis yod na 'byung ba las phyi ba dang dus mnyam pas 'byung ba nye bar len pa mi 'thad pas 'byung ba'i snga rol du yod par 'gyur ro/ / de lta na bdag tu gdags pa'i rgyu med pa la sogs pa'i skyon sngar bshad pa bzhin 'jug pas 'dir slar yang skyon brjod ma mdzad do/ /

The self does not exist inherently in such things as seeing, hearing, and feeling nor in that from which they are arisen—that is, the four elements. If the self existed inherently, it would not be tenable for it to be the appropriator of the elements, since it would have to be simultaneous with or subsequent to them. Therefore, it would have to be prior to the elements. In that case, the errors previously explained, [213] such as designating the self without a ground, would be committed. The critique is not presented explicitly here.
gnyis pa [rang gis tha snyad du gang zag 'jog pa'i tshul]
1.2.1.2 The way we posit the self conventionally
['di] la gnyis/ bdag gi 'jog tshul dang / de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This part has two sections: the mode of positing the self and rebutting refutations of that.
dang po [bdag gi 'jog tshul] ni/
1.2.1.2.1 The mode of positing the self
gal te de ltar gang zag ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'gog na mthong ba dang thos pa la sogs pa'i gang zag gi tha snyad 'di mi 'thad par mi 'gyur ram snyam na/
One might ask, if the inherent existence of the person is refuted, then would the conventions regarding the person who sees and hears not be untenable?
lta dang nyan la sogs pa dang / / tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang / / gang gi yin pa gal te med/ / de dag kyang ni yod ma yin/ /
11. Such things as seeing, hearing, And feeling: If that to which they belong does not exist, They themselves do not exist.

mthong thos la sogs pa byed pa'i gang zag ni sus kyang bsnyon du med pas de gtan med pa ni mi rung ngo / / 'di la gzhan sdes mthong ba sogs kyi gang zag ni gdon mi za bar khas blang dgos la/ 'on kyang phung po dang ngo bo gcig pa mi rung bar mthong nas/ phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i gang zag gi bdag 'dod par byed do/ / rang gi sde pa gzhan gyis ni las gsog pa sogs kyi gang zag tsam zhig ni gzhag dgos par mthong zhing / phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i bdag yod pa la gnod byed mthong nas phung po'i tshogs rgyun dang lus 'dor len byed pa'i rnam shes nyid bdag gam gang zag tu smra bar byed do/ /

No one who is not insane would reject the existence of the person who is the agent of such things as seeing and hearing. Therefore its total nonexistence makes no sense. Here, the other schools maintain that the person who sees and hears undoubtedly has to be accepted. However, seeing that it is untenable for it to be the same entity as the aggregates, they maintain that the personal self is a different entity from the aggregates. Other Buddhist schools see the need to posit that mere person who accumulates karma, and so forth. Seeing the error in taking the self to be an entity existing separate from the aggregates, some assert that the continuum of the collection of the aggregates is the person, and some assert that the consciousness that appropriates and abandons the body is the self or the person.

rang gi lugs ni ngar 'dzin lhan skyes kyis gang la dmigs pa'i gzhi dmigs pa ni nga dang bdag dang gang zag tu gzhag dgos la/ phyi rol pas kun brtags pa ltar gyi gang zag yod par mi 'dzin pa'i dud 'gro la sogs pa la yang nga dang nga yi bar 'dzin pa'i 'jig lta 'jug pas/ phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i bdag ni ngar 'dzin lhan skyes kyi dmigs pa'i gzhir yang mi rung la/ de ni kun rdzob tsam du yang med par 'dod de/ 'jug pa las/ / 'di ni ngar 'dzin rten du'ang mi rigs la/ / 'di ni kun rdzob tu yang yod mi 'dod/ / ces dang / 'jig rten ngar 'dzin blo yi rten du yang / / mi 'dod de rig min pa'ang bdag lta'i phyir/ / zhes so/

As far as our own system is concerned, the object that is the basis of the objectification by innate self-grasping should be posited as “I,” or the self or person. Even the animals, who do not hold the view that the person exists as it is imputed by the non-Buddhist schools, have the view of “I” and the transitory aggregates with respect to grasping “being mine.” Therefore, a self which is different from the aggregates cannot the basis of objectification by innate self-grasping, and it is maintained that it does not exist even conventionally. As it is said in Madhyamakāvātāra, It makes no sense for this to be the basis of self-grasping. It is not maintained that this even exists conventionally. [VI: 122cd] and also Ordinary people do not even maintain this as the basis of the self-grasping mind. Because without being aware of that, the self is still seen. [VI: 124 cd] [214]

'jig rten gyi tha snyad la ni nga'i gzugs dang nga'i sems zhes bdag ni phung po'i rje bo dang phung po ni de'i khol ltar 'dzin pas/ bdag gi mtshan gzhir phung po'i rgyun nam tshogs pa'am ya gyal rnams 'jog pa ni gtan mi rung ngo / / 'phags pa'i gzhung du yang de kho na ltar 'chad de/ rab byed 'dir ni lta ba la sogs pa'i ci zhig po rnams kyis gang zhig po'i bdag gsal bar byed par bshad pas/ gsal byed kyi tshogs pa dang ya gyal gang yang gsal byar 'gal ba'i phyir dang /rab byed bcu par phung po dang bdag gcig tha dad kyi tshul me dang bud shing dang 'dra bar gsungs pa'i phyir dang / rab byed tha mar yang / nye bar len pa ma gtogs par/ / bdag yod ma yin byas pa'i tshe/ / nye bar len nyid bdag yin na/ / khyod kyi bdag ni med pa yin/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

According to mundane convention, since everyone says “my body,” or “my mind” the self is held to be the master and the aggregates are seen as its servants. Therefore, it would be unreasonable to posit the continuum of the aggregates, the collection of the aggregates, or any part of it as an instance of a self. In the master’s texts, it is explained in exactly this way. In this chapter it is explained which of such things as the seer discloses which kind of self; therefore, it would be contradictory for any part of, or the whole collection of that which discloses to be that which is disclosed; in the tenth chapter, therefore, the way in which the self is the same as or different from the aggregates is presented as similar to fire and fuel; in the last chapter it says, When it is said that there is no self Other than the appropriator, If the self were the appropriator Your self would be nonexistent. [XXVII: 5]
gnyis pa [de la rtsod pa spang ba] ni/
1.2.1.2.2 Rebutting refutations of that

bdag dang phung po rje khol ltar 'dzin na de gnyis ngo bo tha dad par 'dzin par mi 'gyur ram snyam na/ de gnyis rdzas gzhan du 'dzin pa 'jig rten gyi tha snyad la med de/ gzhan du na lhas byin gyi lag pa na ba dang sos pa la lhas byin na ba dang gsos par mi 'jog par 'gyur te/ nyer sbas na ba dang gsos pas byams pa na ba dang gsos par tha snyad mi byed pa bzhin no/ / rigs pa de ni/ gang phyir 'jig rten sa bon tsam btab nas/ / bdag gis bu 'di bskyed ces smra byed cing / / shing yang btsugs so snyam du rtogs des na/ / gzhan las skye ba 'jig rten las kyang med/ / ces gsungs pa'i 'don pa bsgyur ba yin te/ gang phyir 'jig rten lag pa na ba la/ / bdag ni na'o snyam du rtogs des na/ / de gnyis rdzas gzhan 'jig rten las kyang med/ / ces pa'o/ /

One might ask, “If the self and the aggregates are taken as master and servant, would not these two be grasped as different entities?” Grasping these two as substantially separate is not part of mundane convention. Otherwise, when Lhejin’s hand hurts and then is cured, this would not be regarded as Lhejin hurting and then being cured. This is because when Nyerbey is hurt and then cured there is no convention whereby we say that Jampa is hurt and then cured. This argument represents a rearrangement of this verse from Madhyamakāvatāra: It is known that in everyday life, people say, “By sowing the seed I gave rise to this son,” And that they think, “I have planted the tree.” Therefore arising from another is not even accepted in everyday life. [VI: 32] As presented here: It is known that in everyday life, people say, “This hand hurts,” And that they thereby think “I hurt.” Therefore that these two are substantially different Is not even accepted in everyday life.

des na bdag gam gang zag ni ming du btags pa tsam ma gtogs pa bdag gi tha snyad gang la 'jug pa'i gzhi btsal ba na/ phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa dang ngo bo gcig pa sogs mi rnyed pas phung po la brten nas nga dang bdag tu btags pa tsam mo/ / lag pa na ba dang gsos pas gang zag de na ba dang gsos par tha snyad byed cing / nga'i lag pa na ba dang gsos so zhes kyang tha snyad byed pas lag pa gcig nyid nga dang nga yi ba gnyis kar 'jog pa min nam snyam na/ de ni 'jig rten gyi tha snyad kyi don ma rtogs pa yin te/ de'i don ni lag pa na ba dang bdag de na ba dang gsos par 'jog pa'i don yin gyi lag pa bdag tu 'jog pa min pa'i phyir te/ lag pa la nga'o snyam du mi 'dzin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Therefore, when we search for the basis of designation of the self or person as other than its being merely nominally imputed, [215] since it is neither found to be identical with nor different from the aggregates, etc., it is merely designated as a self depending on the aggregates. Someone might argue as follows: It is said that when one’s hand is hurt and then cured, the person is hurt and then cured, and since that person would also say “my hand was hurt and then cured,” is the same hand not posited both as “I” and as “that which is mine?” This statement arises from not understanding the meaning of “mundane convention” because its meaning is as follows: When the hand is hurt and then cured, the self is regarded as hurt and then cured; but the meaning is not that the hand is regarded as the self, because it is not held that “the hand is me.”

lhas byin gyis dus snga phyi'i bdag so sor ma phye bar nga'o snyam du ma 'dzin pa'i dmigs pa'i gzhir gyur pa'i bdag ni thog ma med pa nas zhugs pa'i nga tsam yin pas/lha la sogs pa'i lus blangs dus kyi 'gro ba so so ba'i bdag rnams ni snga ma'i bye brag re'o/ / lhas byin gyis skye ba so sor phye ba'i bdag la nga'o snyam du bzung ba'i bdag ni tshe re re'i bdag phyogs re ba yin no/ / yul gyi bdag bzhin du yul can gyi ngar 'dzin yang so sor phye ba dang ma phye ba'i 'dzin stangs can du shes par bya'o/ //

The self that is the basis of Lhejin’s holding “I am,” without distinguishing between the temporally successive selves, is the mere self with which one is involved from beginningless time. The selves of each of the transmigrators, when they appropriate the bodies of such things as gods, are instances of the previously explained mere self. The self grasped by Lhejin as the self of each of his lives when he says “I am,” is in part the self of each life. Just as the object (the self), the subject—the self-grasping mind—should also be understood as having a mode of apprehension, whether or not individual distinctions are drawn.

de 'dra ba'i bdag tha snyad btags pa tsam min pa'i btags don btsal ba na gang du yang mi rnyed pas/las gsog pa dang 'bras bu myong ba sogs su mi rung ngo zhe na/ de lta na gzugs la sogs pa rnams kyang tha snyad btags pa tsam min pa'i btags don btsal ba na/bdag dang 'dra bar rang gi cha shas rnams las ngo bo tha dad pa dang gcig pa sogs gang du yang mi rnyed pas bya ba byed nus pa mi srid par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar btsal ba na mi rnyed par bdag btaT yod dang rdzas yod gnyis ka mtshungs mod kyang ma rnyed pas bdag gnyis khegs mi khegs mi mtshungs te/ rdzas yod rigs pas dpyad bzod yin la btags yod de ltar min pa'i phyir ro//

Such a self—one that is not merely nominally imputed—cannot be found at all if the object of imputation is sought. So one might say, it makes no sense that it accumulates actions and experiences their effects, etc. In that case, since when such imputed objects such as material form are sought—which objects are taken to be not merely nominally imputed—they, like the self, cannot be found either as identical to or as different from their respective parts, it would be impossible for them to perform functions. The imputed and the substantially existing self are similar in that when they are sought they are not found. However, they are not similar with respect to whether in virtue of not being found, they are done away with or not. [216] This is because the substantially existent self must be able to withstand rational analysis, but the imputed is not like that.
gnyis pa [des nye bar blang bya yang ngo bos yod pa khegs par bstan] ni/
1.2.2 Showing that thereby the inherent existence of that which is to be appropriated is refuted

gal te yang de ltar bdag bkag mod kyi 'on kyang lta ba la sogs pa ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma bkag pa'i phyir ro/ / de dag yod na bdag gi ngo bo can min pa'i bum pa la sogs la lta ba la sogs pa dang 'brel ba med pas de dag gang dang 'brel ba'i bdag kyang ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhe na/

One might argue as follows: Although the self has been refuted in this way, it might be that such things as seeing exist essentially, because they have not thus been refuted. If they exist, there would be no relation between such things as seeing and such things as pots, and between other such objects and other senses which do not have the nature of self; and therefore the self, which is related to them, would exist inherently.
gang zhig lta la sogs pa yi/ / snga rol da lta phyi na med/ / de la yod do med do zhes/ / rtog pa dag ni ldog par 'gyur/ /
12. That which does not exist prior to, Simultaneous with, or after seeing does not exist. Conceptions such as “it exists” or “it does not exist” Will cease.

gal te lta ba dang nyan pa la sogs pa dang tshor ba dag la sogs pa yang len pa po gang gi blang bya yin pa'i len pa po de ngo bo nyid kyis med par bstan pa de yi tshe/ der ma zad lta ba la sogs pa de dag kyang ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no zhes gsal bar bstan pa ma yin nam de'i phyir lta ba la sogs pa nye bar blang bya ngo bo nyid kyis med pas nye bar len pa po'i bdag kyang ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ /

When it was shown that the appropriator of such things as seeing, hearing and feeling—which are that which is to be appropriated by the appropriator—does not exist inherently, was it not even shown that those things such as seeing do not exist essentially as well? Since those things such as seeing—that which is to be appropriated—do not exist inherently, nor does the self—the appropriator—exist inherently.
gsum pa [nye bar len pa po ngo bo nyid kyis med pa la rtsod pa spang ba] ni/
1.2.3 Rebutting the argument against the inherent nonexistence of the appropriator

'dir pha rol pos gang zag ngo bo nyid kyis med pa de dgag bya de rnam par bcad pa tsam min pa'i ma yin dgag tu bsgrubs so snyam nas ci bdag med do snyam du khyod kyis nges sam zhes 'dri'o/ / de skad du sus smras/ lta ba la sogs pa med pas bdag kyang med do zhes thal ma thag tu ma smras sam zhe na/ de skad du smras mod kyi 'di'i don ni khyod kyis bzung ba ltar kho bo cag mi 'dod do//'di ltar bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes khyod kyis brtags pa yin la/bdag gis kyang 'dzin pa de'i gnyen por bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no zhes de zlog pa'i tshig dgag bya rnam par bcad pa tsam smras pa yin gyi/dgag bya bcad tsam las gzhan pa bdag 'di'i rang bzhin med pa rigs shes kyi yul du brtags pa min te/ dngos po dang dngos med la zhen pa gnyis ka spang dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di lta bu'i rigs rnams ni med dgag dang ma yin dgag gi khyad par 'byed pa yin la thal 'gyur ba'i khyad chos kyang min te sngar mang du bshad zin to/ / des na gang zag ni brgya pa las/ khyod kyi bdag gang nga'i bdag min/ // des de bdag min ma nges phyir/ / dngos po mi rtag pa rnams la/ / rtog pa skye bar 'gyur min nam/ / zhes gsungs pa lta bur 'dod par bya'o/ /

Here the opponent, thinking that the absence of inherent existence of the person is not the mere elimination of the object of negation, but an internal negation, asks, “have you really ascertained that there is no self?” Who would say such a thing? Has not it been said just before this that since there is no thing such as seeing, there is no self? It has been said, but we do not intend the meaning that you ascribe to it. Here you imagine that the self exists inherently. I/5/ also, as an antidote for that grasping, have said “the self does not exist inherently,” using this phrase—which merely eliminates the object of negation—to undo that grasping. But setting aside eliminating the object of negation, the essencelessness of the self is not conceived as the object of the rational mind because both fixation on entity and on nonentity has to be eliminated. [217] These kinds of arguments distinguish between external and internal negations. However, this is not a distinctive feature of the prāsaṅgika, because, as it has been said many times earlier, the person should be maintained to be as it is put in the Catuḥśataka where it says, Your self is not my self Because he does ascertain it as not his self. Does not that conception arise With respect to impermanent phenomena? [X: 3]

de'i don ni bdag de rang gi ngo bo sa yod na ga nga za ga ga cig gis de la nga'o snyam du 'dzin pa bzhin du/ thams cad kyis kyang 'dzin pa'i nges pa dgos pa las khyod kyi ngar 'dzin rigs pa des bdag skye ba'i bdag de la nga la ngar 'dzin mi skye ba'i phyir/ de ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa min te thams cad la ngar 'dzin skye bar ma nges pa'i phyir ro/ / bdag med na ngar 'dzin pa 'di gang la 'gyur snyam na/ phung po mi rtag pa las don gzhan du ngar 'dzin gyi dmigs pa med cing phung po nyid kyang der mi 'thad pas phung po mi rtag pa la brten nas btags pa'i bdag la nga'o snyam pa'i rtog pas bzung ba 'ba' zhig go / de ltar bdag rang gi ngo bos yod pa min la brten nas btags pa tsam med pa min pa'i don 'di gang zhig lta la zhes sogs kyis kyang ston no/ /

This means that if the self existed inherently, just as one person grasps it thinking “I,” all others as well should certainly grasp it. But the self with respect to which your self-grasping arises is not that with respect to which my self-grasping arises. This argument shows that that self does not exist inherently, because it is certainly not the case that everyone’s self-grasping arises with respect to it. Someone might ask, if there is no self, with respect to what does self-grasping arise? Besides the impermanent aggregates there is no object of self-grasping. It is not tenable that that just is the aggregates. Therefore, the very self that is imputed in dependence on impermanent aggregates is grasped by the conception “I am.” Thus, the fact that the self does not exist inherently and that it is not the case that there is no mere dependent designation is also presented by “That which does not…” [IX: 12].

bdag gang zhig yongs su brtags na lta ba la sogs pa'i snga rol na med de gang zag tu gdags pa'i rgyu med par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / da ltar te lta ba la sogs pa dang lhan cig tu yang ngo bo nyid kyis med de so sor ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub pa la lhan cig pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma mthong ba'i phyir dang / so sor ngo bo nyid kyis grub na bdag dang nye bar blang ba gnyis phan tshun ltos med du gyur pas so sor grub pa yang mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / lta ba la sogs pa snga la bdag phyi ba yang med de byed pa po med pa'i las ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar med pa de'i tshe bdag de la ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes pa'i rtog pa dag ni ldog par 'gyur la/ lta ba la sogs pas gsal bar byed pa'i phyir gang zag de med do zhes pa'i rtog pa dag kyang ldog par 'gyur ro// //

When the self is thoroughly examined, it is not that which is prior to such things as seeing, because there is no ground for designating any such thing a self. Similarly, it does not inherently exist simultaneously with such things as seeing, because since they do not each exist inherently, they cannot be seen to exist inherently simultaneously. Moreover, if they each did exist inherently, then since the self and the appropriated would not be mutually dependent, their individual existence would therefore not be tenable. It also cannot be that such things as seeing are prior and the self later, because without an agent [218] there cannot be any action. Thus, since that is not the case, the idea that the self exists inherently is eliminated. Since it is disclosed by such things as seeing, the idea that there is no person is also eliminated.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar gang zag nye bar len pa po dang des blang bya ngo bo nyid kyis med par gtan la phab pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis grub par bstan pa dang / de ltar bshad pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya bar bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba ni/ 'gro 'ong brtag pa'i rab byed lung dang sbyar ba nyid la bshad pas de bzhin du shes par bya'o/ /

In order to show that that which has been established—that the person, the appropriator, and that which is to be appropriated by it do not to exist inherently—is corroborated by the profound scriptures, and in order to show that all of the scriptures on similar subjects are explained by this chapter, corroboration from definitive sūtras can be found in the corroboration section of the chapter “Examination of Motion” (chapter 2), and they should be understood in the same way here.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

lus de'i len pa po ni gang zag 'di'o zhes pa dang gang zag 'di yi blang bya ni chos 'di dag go zhes pa rnams la tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa min par ngo bo nyid kyis grub par 'dzin pa'i bzung ba ltar gnas na/ blang bya dang len pa po'i tha snyad gang yang byar med par nges pa bskyed nas ming du btags pa tsam gyi rten 'byung la de gnyis shin tu 'thad pa'i tshul rnams bsam par bya'o/ /

Having ascertained that if that to which the statements, “the appropriator of this body is this person” and “that which is appropriated by this person are the phenomena,” refer existed as they are grasped—as existing inherently—and were not merely posited by nominal convention, then there could not be any convention with regard to appropriator and appropriated, one should contemplate the consistency of these two in virtue of their being merely nominally imputed and dependently originated.
snga rol na gnas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa dgu pa'o// //
This is the ninth chapter called “the examination of the prior entity.”
snga rol na gnas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu gnyis kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa dgu pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the ninth chapter, having twelve verses, called “the examination of the prior entity.”
CHAPTER X. Examination of Fire and Fuel
gnyis pa gang zag rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa
We are now beginning the second part: the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of the person.
['di] la gnyis/ sgrub byed kyi dpe dgag / sgrub byed kyi gtan tshigs dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: The refutation of the example in the premises and the refutation of the reasoning in the premises.
dang po [sgrub byed kyi dpe dgag]
This chapter is the first of these two parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citation of definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ nye bar len pa dang nye bar len pa po phan tshun ltos pas ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ma yin no zhes smras pa ni mi rigs te/ dngos po ltos pa dang bcas pa la ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar bud shing la brten nas me 'byung mod kyang tsha ba'i rang bzhin dang sreg par byed pa'i 'bras bu mthong ba'i phyir dang / / me la ltos nas bud shing yin mod kyang bsreg bya 'byung ba chen po bzhi'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir me dang bud shing bzhin du nye bar len pa dang nye bar len pa po gnyis kyang ngo bo nyid kyis grub bo/ / 'di dgag pa la gsum/ me dang bud shing ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag / rigs pa de gzhan la yang sbyar ba/ bkag pa'i don du lta ba smad /

Here someone might say it does not make sense to say that the appropriator and appropriated do not exist inherently in virtue of being mutually dependent, [219] because dependent entities are seen to exist inherently. Although fire arises in dependence on fuel, the essences of heat and combustibility are seen as the effect; and although fuel depends upon fire, that which is burned has the essence of the four great elements. Therefore, like fire and fuel, both that which is appropriated and the appropriator also exist inherently. The refutation of this has three parts: the refutation of the inherent existence of fire and fuel, applying this reasoning to other phenomena, and condemnation of their view of the point of the refutation.
dang po [me dang bud shing ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the inherent existence of fire and fuel
['di] la gsum/ sngar ma bshad pa'i rigs pas dgag / sngar bshad pa'i rigs pas dgag / de dag gi mjug bsdu ba'o// //
This section has three parts: refutation through arguments not presented earlier, refutation through arguments presented earlier, and their conclusion.
dang po [sngar ma bshad pa'i rigs pas dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation through arguments not presented earlier
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gcig pa dgag / rang bzhin tha dad pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of their being essentially identical and refutation of their being essentially different.
dang po [rang bzhin gcig pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1 Refutation of their being essentially identical
bud shing gang de me yin na/ / byed pa po dang las gcig 'gyur/ / gal te shing las mi gzhan na/ / shing med par yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
1. If fuel were fire, Agent and object would be one. If fire were different from fuel, Then it could arise without fuel.

gal te me dang shing gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ngo bo nyid kyis pa'o/ gcig pa'am tha dad pa gnyis su nges te/ gcig dang tha dad gnyis gcig rnam par bcad na gcig shos yongs su gcod dgos pas phung gsum ldog pa'i phyir ro/ / bsreg par bya ba shing la sogs pa las su gyur pa'i sreg par byed pa po ni me'o/ / de la bud shing gang yin pa de nyid dang me gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis gcig yin na byed pa po dang las rnams gcig tu 'gyur na/ / rdza mkhan dang bum pa'am gcad bya dang gcod pa po gcig pa nyid du ni ma mthong zhing khas kyang ma blangs pas mi rigs so/ / thal ba 'dis ni bzlog phyogs la las dang byed pa po yin pa'i gtan tshigs kyis me dang shing gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis gcig tu med pa 'phen pa'o/ /

If both fire and fuel existed inherently, they would have to be either identical or different, because if you eliminate one of these two—identical and different—the other one must be affirmed. Therefore the third alternative is eliminated. The agent of the burning of the object—that which is to be burned, such as the fuel—is the fire. With respect to this, if that which is fuel and fire were inherently identical, then the agent and object would be identical. But this makes no sense, because it is neither seen nor accepted that the potter and the pot, or that which is to be cut and the cutter, are identical. Contraposing this reductio yields the argument from the premise that they are agent and object to the conclusion that fire and fuel cannot be inherently identical.
gnyis pa [rang bzhin tha dad pa dgag pa]
1.1.1.2 Refutation of their being essentially different
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin tha dad pa'i bsgrub bya dgag / rang bzhin tha dad kyi sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
The second has two parts: the refutation of the conclusion that they are essentially different and the refutation of the argument for their being essentially different. [220]
dang po [rang bzhin tha dad pa'i bsgrub bya dgag]
1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of the conclusion that they are essentially different
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gyis tha dad na shing la mi ltos pa dang / rang bzhin gyis tha dad na shing dang mi phrad par 'gyur ba'o/ /
The first section has two parts: If they were essentially different it would not depend upon the fuel and if they were essentially different it would not contact the fuel.
dang po [rang bzhin gyis tha dad na shing la mi ltos pa]
1.1.1.2.1.1 If they were essentially different it would not depend upon the fuel
['di] la gnyis/ dgag pa dngos dang*/ ma nges pa spang ba'o/ //
This first section has two parts: the primary refutation and resolving the uncertainties.
dang po [dgag pa dngos]
1.1.1.2.1.1.1 Primary refutation
['di] la gnyis/ shing med bzhin du 'byung ba dang / rtag tu 'bar ba sogs su 'gyur ba'o/ /
This first part has two sections: fire arising without fuel and reductio on fire burning eternally.
dang po [shing med bzhin du 'byung ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.1.1.1 Fire arising without fuel

gal te shing las me ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan yin na bud shing la ltos pa med par me 'byung bar 'gyur te/ dper na bum pa las gzhan du gyur pa'i snam bu ni bum pa la ltos pa med par mthong ba bzhin no/ / 'di ni ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa la ltos pa mi rung la ltos pa med na ltos med du mtshungs bzhin du bum pa med pa'i snam bu mthong du rung la/ bud shing med pa'i me mthong du mi rung ba'i khyad par mi 'thad ces 'gog pa yin zhing gzhan skye 'gog pa ni mi ltos pa'i gzhan las skye na gzhan du du mtshungs pa thams cad la skye mi skye khyad par med par 'gyur ro zhes pa yin pas rigs pa khyad med min no/ /

If fire were inherently different from fuel, then fire would not depend on the fuel because the cloth, for example, which is different from the pot, is seen not to be dependent on the pot. This refutes the untenability of drawing the distinction between the possibility of seeing the cloth without the pot and the impossibility of seeing fire without fuel, on the grounds that they are equally independent, and that it makes no sense for something to depend on that which is inherently different. The refutation of arising from another is that if something arose from another on which it was not dependent, since everything is similar in respect of being different, there would be no distinction between that from which it arises and that from which it does not. Thus it is not the case that there is no difference between the arguments.
gnyis pa [rtag tu 'bar ba sogs su 'gyur ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.1.1.2 Reductio on fire burning eternally

rtag tu 'bar ba nyid du 'gyur/ / 'bar byed rgyu las me 'byung zhing / / rtsom pa don med nyid du 'gyur/ / de lta yin na las kyang med/ / gzhan la ltos pa med pa'i phyir/ / 'bar ba byed rgyu las mi 'byung / / rtag tu 'bar ba nyid yin na/ / rtsom pa don med nyid du 'gyur/ /

2. It would be forever aflame; Ignition could occur without a cause. Effort regarding it would be pointless. In that case, it would also be without any action. 3. Since it would not depend on another, Ignition would be without a cause. If it were eternally in flames, Effort regarding it would be pointless.

gzhan yang me bud shing las ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad na rtag tu 'bar ba nyid du 'gyur zhing 'bar bar byed pa'i rgyu las mi 'byung bar 'gyur la/ rtsom pa don med pa nyid du yang 'gyur zhing de lta yin na las kyang med par 'gyur ro/ / don 'di nyid ston pa ni me bud shing las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod na med gzhan bud shing la ltos pa med pa'i phyir 'dis me 'bar bar byed pas 'bar byed de bud shing ngo / / des na 'bar ba'i rgyu ste de las mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / 'bar byed la ltos pa'i me ni de med na 'chi bar 'gyur na de la ltos pa med pa ni 'chi ba'i rkyen ma tshang bas rtag tu 'bar ba nyid du 'gyur ro//rtag tu 'bar ba yin na ni me mi 'chi bar bya ba'i phyir bud shing len pa dang sbar ba la sogs pa'i rtsom pa thams cad don med pa nyid du 'gyur ro/ / de lta yin na bsreg par bya ba'i las med bzhin du me sreg pa por 'gyur na las med pa'i byed pa po ni med do/ / de'i phyir bud shing las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa mi rigs so/ / 'dir yang thal ba'i bzlog phyogs la rtags kyis gzhan med par sgrub pa shes par bya'o/ /

Moreover, if fire were inherently different from fuel, it would be eternally burning and it would arise without any cause of ignition. Making an effort regarding it would be pointless, and in that case there would be no action either. The meaning is presented as follows: If fire were inherently different from fuel, this fire would not depend on fuel. But here, since the fire is ignited, that which ignites it is the fuel. Therefore, it would not arise from a cause of ignition. Fire depending on that which ignites it would extinguish without that cause. That which does not depend on it would burn eternally, since the conditions for its extinguishing are not complete. If it burned eternally, then all of the effort to prevent its extinguishment, such as collecting fuel, igniting it, etc., would be pointless. [221] In that case, even without the action of burning, fire would be the agent of burning. But there is no agent without an action. Therefore it makes no sense for fire to be inherently different from fuel. Here also it should be understood that the contrapositive of the reductio supplies a premise that proves the nonexistence of otherness.
gnyis pa [ma nges pa spang ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.1.2 Resolving the uncertainties
de la gal te 'di snyam da/ / sreg bzhin bud shing yin sems na/ /
4. So, if one thought that That which is burning is the fuel,

shing las me gzhan yin na shing med par me 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes pa de la gal te 'di snyam du 'bar ba dang ldan pa'i don mes sreg bzhin pa bud shing yin la me yang de la brten nas dmigs kyi yan gar bar med pas shing med par me 'byung ba'i skyon de med do snyam du sems na/

If the fire were different from the fuel, then the fire would arise without fuel. In reply to this one might think that the flaming object is the fuel that is being burned by the fire and that the fire is perceived as depending on it, but not in isolation from it. Therefore the error of saying that fire arises without fuel is not committed.
gang tshe de tsam de yin na/ / gang gis bud shing de sreg byed/ /
4cd. If it is just this, By what is this fuel being burned?

gang gi tshe 'bar ba dang ldan pa sreg bzhin pa de tsam zhig bud shing de yin na de las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du gyur pa'i me med pas/ bud shing las ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'i me gang zhig gis bud shing de sreg par byed de byed pa mi rigs so/ // de'i phyir 'bar ba dang ldan pa'i bud shing ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa yang med pas nyes pa de nyid bzlog tu med do/ / 'di yi rigs pa ni brgya pa las/ mes ni tsha ba nyid sreg ste/ / tsha ba ma yin ji ltar sreg / des na bud shing zhes bya med/ / de ma gtogs par me yang med/ / ces gsungs pa gsal bar snang ngo / /

In that case, if the fuel is just that which is flaming and being burned, then, since there is no fire that is inherently different from it, by what fire inherently different from fuel is this fuel being burned? The burning makes no sense. Therefore, since the flaming fuel does not exist inherently the error is unavoidable. The Catuḥśataka clarifies this argument: Since heat is fire—that which burns,/1/ If it is not hot, how can it burn? Therefore there is no so-called fuel. But apart from that there is no fire./2/ [XIV: 16]
gnyis pa [rang bzhin gyis tha dad na shing dang mi phrad par 'gyur ba]

1.1.1.2.1.2.1 The main point
gzhan phyir mi 'phrad phrad mod na/ / sreg par mi 'gyur mi sreg na/ / 'chi ba mi 'gyur mi 'chi na/ / rang rtags dang yang ldan par gnas/ /

5. Because of difference, they do not touch. If they do not touch, It will not be burned. If it is not burned, It will not be extinguished. If it is not extinguished, It will endure with its own identity as well.

gzhan yang bud shing las me ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa'i phyir mun pa ltar mi phrad par 'gyur la phrad pa med na bskal pa'i yul na gnas pa bzhin bud shing sreg par mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na sreg bzhin pa bud shing ngo zhes pa mi rigs so/ / mi sreg na 'chi bar mi 'gyur te mes bud shing sreg na bsreg bya zad pas 'chi bar 'gyur na mi sreg pa la 'chi ba'i rgyu med pa'i phyir ro/ / mi 'chi na rang gi rtags rab tu 'bar ba dang ldan par gnas par 'gyur ro/ / yang gi sgra ni gsum las nges gzung gi don du byed na rang gi rtags dang ldan pa kho nar gnas zhes pa'am yang na me bud shing las gzhan du gyur pa med pa kho na zhes pa'o//rnam par brtag pa'i don du byas na mi phrad pa la sogs pa gang rung du 'gyur ba'o/ / bsdu ba'i don du byas na mi phrad pa la sogs pa snga ma snga mar ma zad ces pa'i don no/ / de'i phyir bud shing las me gzhan du mi rigs so/ / zhes bshad pa ni thal ba de dag gi bzlog pa ston pa'o/ /

Moreover, it would follow from fire being inherently different from fuel that they do not touch each other, just as it does not touch darkness. If there is no contact, as it will remain distant, it will not burn the fuel. In that case, it would not make sense to say that that which is burning is fuel. If it is not burned, it will not be extinguished, because if the fire burns the fuel, then since that which is burned is extinguished by being exhausted, [222] there would be no cause for extinguishing that which is not burned. If it is not extinguished, it would endure with the identity of that which is flaming. If the words “as well” are taken as meaning ascertaining from the three,3 it would mean that it would endure with its own identity, or it could mean that the fire is not absolutely different from the fuel. If, on the other hand, we take them as indicating an alternative, they could mean any of “does not touch,” etc. If their meaning is taken as inclusive, they mean not only this, but also the previous conditions, such as “does not touch.” Therefore, the statement “it doesn’t make sense for fire to be different from fuel” [Prasannapadā 70A] presents the contrapositive of those reductios.
gnyis pa [de la ma nges pa spang ba] ni/
