ci ltar bud med skyes pa dang / / skyes pa'ang bud med phrad pa bzhin/ / gal te shing las me gzhan na/ / shing dang phud par rung bar 'gyur/ /
6. Just as a man touches a woman And a woman touches a man, So if fire were different from fuel, Fire and fuel would have to be suited to touch.

gal te gzhan phyir mi phrad phrad med na/ / zhes sogs smras pa ni mi rigs te shing ji ltar te las me gzhan yin yang shing dang phrad du rung bar 'gyur te/ dper na bud med skyes pa dang skyes pa'ang bud med dang phrad pa bzhin no/ / 'gyur gsar las tshigs bcad 'di yan du yod par byas mod kyang / cog ros bud d+ha pA li ta dang shes rab sgron ma gnyis kar phyogs snga'i gzhung du bsgyur ba dang / gal te shing las me gzhan yang*/ / shing dang phrad du rung bar 'gyur/ / zhes bsgyur ba shin tu legs so/ /

This says that “Because of difference, they do not touch. If they do not touch,” etc., does not make sense, because although the fire is different from the fuel, it is suited to touch the fuel. This is because it is just as, for instance, a man touches a woman and a woman touches a man. According to the latest translations, this verse is treated as a response. But Cog Ro/4/ translates this in both the Buddhapālita [206b] and the Prajñāpradīpa [33a] as the opponent’s view and his translation, Although fire is different from fuel It would have to be suited to touch fuel, [6cd] Is very felicitous./5/
gal te me dang shing dag ni/ / gcig gis gcig ni bsal gyur na/ / shing dang me gzhan nyid yin yang / / shing dang phrad par 'dod la rag /
7. And, if fire and fuel Preclude each other, Then although fire is different from fuel, It still must be asserted that they touch.

gal te me dang shing dag ni gcig gis gcig ni bsal ba ste skyes pa dang bud med ltar phan tshun ltos pa med par grub par gyur na/ shing las me gzhan pa nyid yin yang shing dang phrad par 'dod la reg na de lta bu mi srid do/ / de'i phyir dpe ni don med de phan tshun ltos pa'i gzhan gnyis phrad pa dper dgod par rigs pa la de ltar ma bkod pa'i phyir ro/ /

If fire and fuel preclude each other—if they are not, like a man and a woman, mutually dependent—then although fire would be different from fuel it would be asserted that it touches the fuel,/6/ but that is not possible. Therefore, the example is senseless: It would make sense to give an example of two things that are mutually dependent and touch each other, but that is not what is presented.
gnyis pa [rang bzhin tha dad kyi sgrub byed dgag pa]
1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of the argument for their being essentially different
['di] la gnyis/ ltos pa'i sgrub byed dgag / mngon sum du mthong ba'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the argument for their dependence and the refutation of the argument that it is directly perceptible.
dang po [ltos pa'i sgrub byed dgag] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.1 Refutation of the argument for their dependence

gal te me dang bud shing ni skyes pa dang bud med ltar phan tshun ltos med min gyi ltos pa yod do/ // de'i phyir de gnyis la rang gi ngo bos grub pa yod de med pa'i mo gsham gyi bu dang bu mo ni phan tshun ltos par ma mthong ngo zhe na/ 'di dgag pa la gsum/ dus gsum du dpyad nas ltos pa dgag / ltos chos yod med la dpyad nas ltos pa dgag / ltos ma ltos gnyis ka dgag pa'o/ /

Someone might say that fire and fuel, like man and woman, are not mutually independent, but are instead dependent. [223] Therefore, they might say, these two do exist inherently, because the nonexistent barren woman’s son and daughter are not seen to be mutually dependent. This section has three parts: the refutation of dependence through analysis with respect to the three temporal periods, the refutation of dependence through analysis of whether or not dependent phenomena exist, and the refutation of both dependence and independence.
dang po [dus gsum du dpyad nas ltos pa dgag]

1.1.1.2.2.1.1.1 Refutation of sequential dependence
gal te shing ltos me yin la/ / gal te me ltos shing yin na/ / gang ltos me dang shing 'gyur ba/ / dang por grub pa gang zhig yin/ /
8. If fire exists in dependence on fuel, And fuel exists in dependence on fire, Depending on what do fire and fuel exist? Which one exists first?

gal te me 'di ni bud shing 'di'i sreg pa po'o zhes bud shing la ltos nas mer 'jog pa yin la/ gal te bud shing ni me 'di'i bsreg bya'o zhes me la ltos te bud shing 'jog pa yin na/ gang la ltos nas me dang shing du 'gyur ba gnyis las dang por grub pa'i ltos sa de gang zhig yin/ gal te dang por bud shing grub pa la ltos nas mer 'gyur bar rtog na de ni mi rigs te/ sreg bzhin pa ma yin pa ni bud shing min pa'i phyir te gzhan du na rtswa la sogs pa thams cad kyang bud shing du thal ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar du gsungs pa ni bud shing ngo bo nyid kyis grub na me dang phrad dgos pa la dgongs kyi bud shing tsam la de ltar 'dod pa min te dus snga phyi ba'i bya byed mang po tha snyad du 'jog pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste dang por me grub pa la ltos nas bud shing du rtog na yang mi rigs te bud shing las sngar grub pa'i me med pa'i phyir dang*/ yod na ni rgyu med du 'gyur ba'i phyir dang phyis bud shing la ltos pa la dgos pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

If one said that the fire is the agent of burning this wood, then the fire is posited as depending on the fuel. And if one said that this fuel is being burned by this fire, then the fuel is posited as depending on the fire. But depending on what do both the fire and the fuel occur? And which of these two is first—that is, the one on which the other depends? Thinking that the fuel exists first and the fire occurs in dependence on that would not make sense, because that which is not burning is not fuel. Otherwise, the absurd consequence would follow that anything, like grass, would be fuel. This whole discussion is intended to show that if fuel existed inherently, then it would have to touch the fire; but we do not maintain that mere fuel is like that because many sequences of agent and action are posited conventionally. To think that the fire exists first and the fuel exists in dependence on that would not make sense either because there is no fire existing prior to the fuel; and if there were, it would arise without a cause, and there would be no need to depend on the fuel later.
gal te shing ltos me yin na/ / me grub pa la 'grub par 'gyur/ / bud par bya ba'i shing la yang / / me med par yang 'gyur ba yin/ /
9. If fire exists in dependence on fuel, It would be the establishment of an established fire, And the fuel would also exist Without there being any fire.

gal te shing dang por grub pa la ltos nas mer 'jog pa yin na/ me ma grub pa ltos par mi rigs pas yod pa ltos dgos so/ / de lta na me grub zin pa la slar yang sgrub dgos par 'gyur na de la ni slar ltos pa dgos pa med do// // gzhan yang bud shing sngar grub pa la ltos nas mer 'jog na bud par bya ba'i shing la yang ste shing ni me med par ni grub par 'gyur ba yin na de ni mi rigs so/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las tshigs bcad dang pos dang por gang grub dris nas shing sngar grub na gal te shing ltos zhes pa gnyis dang me sngar grub na bud par bya ba zhes pa gnyis kyis 'gog ste/ ltos chos su 'dod pa gnyis po med na ltos par mi 'thad pas yod dgos la snga phyir yod na shing med par me 'grub nus pas shing la ltos don med la me med par yang shing 'grub nus pas me la ltos don med ces 'chad do/ / 'dir ltos pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'gog pa yin la de yang dus snga phyi ba dang dus mnyam pa gnyis las mi 'da' ba khyab byed du bstan nas dus snga phyi ba 'gog pa na snga ma'i dus na phyi ma dang phyi ma'i dus na snga ma med pa dang ltos pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na dus nam yang ltos sa ltos chos gnyis ka dus mnyam du yod dgos pa la 'gal ba bstan nas 'gog go /

Suppose fire is posited in dependence on previously existing fuel. Then, since it would not make sense for nonestablished fire to be dependent, only an existent fire can depend. And so, a fire that has already been established would have to be established again, but the fire does not need to depend on anything further. Moreover, suppose fire is posited in dependence on previously existing fuel. “And the fuel would also exist” means the fuel./7/[224] It would have to exist without fire, but this makes no sense. According to Buddhapālita [207a], the previous verse (X: 8) asks which exists first. The first two lines of this verse, “If fire exists in dependence,” [9ab], refute the prior existence of fuel; and the next two lines—“And the fuel would also exist” [9cd]—refute the previous existence of fire. He concludes that if these two phenomena, which are maintained to be dependent, did not exist, it would not be tenable for them to depend and so they must exist. If they existed sequentially, then since fire could exist without fuel, there would be no point in its depending on fuel; and since fuel could exist without fire as well, there would be no point in its depending on fire. Here we have refuted the inherent existence of the dependent. Having shown that one cannot escape the two alternatives of their being simultaneous or sequential as the general point, based on this disjunctive superordinate category, he demonstrates two contradictions: He refutes their being sequential by showing that when the former exists the latter does not, and that when the latter exists, the former does not. He also refutes the inherent existence of the dependent by showing that both the dependent phenomenon and the basis of dependence would always have to exist simultaneously.
gnyis pa [dus mnyam pa la ltos pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.1.1.2 Refutation of simultaneous dependence
gal te dus gcig kho nar bud shing grub pas me 'grub cing me grub pas kyang bud shing 'grub par 'gyur te de'i phyir dang por gcig grub pa khas ma blangs pas de'i skyon gyis mi gnod do zhe na/

Suppose someone says, “The fire exists in virtue of the simultaneous existence of the fuel, and the fuel also exists in virtue of the simultaneous existence of the fire. Therefore since we do not assert that one exists before the other, we do not commit that error.”
gal te dngos po gang ltos 'grub/ / de nyid la yang ltos nas ni/ / ltos bya gang yin de 'grub na/ / gang la ltos nas gang zhig 'grub /
10. If an entity that depends on another Exists in dependence on That on which it depends, What exists in dependence on what?

gal te me'i dngos po gang zhig bud shing gi dngos po la ltos nas 'grub la bud shing gi ltos chos gang yin pa me de nyid la yang ltos nas ni/ ltos bya ste ltos sa bud shing gang yin pa de 'grub na da ni gang la ltos nas gang zhig 'grub par 'gyur ba smros shig / 'di ni dper na chu'i nang gi gru gcig mi 'byam par bya ba'i phyir gru cig shos la brtod kyang gnyis ka 'byam pas phan tshun gcig gcig gi skyabs su mi 'gyur ba de bzhin du/ me rang gi ngo bos gnas pa bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir du shing la ltos par smra la/ shing rang gi ngo bos gnas pa bsgrub pa'i phyir du me la ltos par smra ba na de gnyis gang yang rang gi ngo bos gnas pa med par 'gyur ro/ / rang gi lugs la ni gcig gi yod pa gcig shos la ltos dgos pa nyid kyis rang gi ngo bos grub pa med cing gtan med pa ri bong gi rwa lta bu la ltos pa 'gal bas rang gi ngo bos yod pa dang ye med gnyis ka'i mtha' dang bral bar grub bo/ /

Suppose the entity of fire that exists in dependence on the entity of fuel exists. Since the fuel exists depending on fire itself, which is the phenomenon depending on fuel—“that on which it depends,” that is, the ground of dependence, which is fuel—we now ask, “What exists in dependence on what?” Consider, for example, a boat in the water, that in order not to drift, depends on another boat. But it cannot be that two boats both adrift rely on one another for safety. Similarly, to establish that a fire endures inherently, you say that it depends on fuel. And to establish that fuel exists inherently, you say that it depends on fire. [225] Thus it cannot be that either of these exist inherently. In our own system, precisely because of the necessity that the existence of any one thing is dependent upon that of another, they cannot exist inherently. It would be contradictory for the totally nonexistent horns of a rabbit to be dependent. This thus establishes that all things are free from the two extremes of inherent existence and complete nonexistence.
gnyis pa [ltos chos yod med la dpyad nas ltos pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.1.2 Refutation of dependence through analysis of whether or not dependent phenomena exist
dngos po ltos 'grub gang yin pa/ / de ma grub na ci ltar ltos/ / ci ste grub pa ltos zhe na/ / de ni ltos par mi rigs so/ /
11. If the entity that exists through dependence Does not exist, how could it depend? However, if you say that the existent depends, That dependence makes no sense.

me'i dngos po bud shing gi dngos po la ltos nas grub pa gang yin pa de yang grub ma grub gnyis las mi 'da' bas/ de la ma grub na ni ji ltar na bud shing la ltos te mi ltos te bong bu'i rwa bzhin no/ / ci ste grub pa ltos so zhe na/ de lta na me de ni rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis bud shing la ltos par mi rigs te/ yod pa tsam ltos pa la slar yang de la ltos pa mi dgos kyang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ltos na dus nam yang mi ltos par mi 'gyur bas slar yang ltos dgos na de yang don med do/ // me dang bud shing gi skabs su dngos po zhes spyir smos pa ni/ bum snam la sogs lhan cig tu/ / zhes 'chad par 'gyur ba ltar brtag pa 'dis dngos po kun btags par 'gyur ba la dgongs so/ /

The entity of fire that exists in dependence on the entity of fuel is not free from the two extremes of existence and nonexistence. If it is nonexistent, how could it depend on fuel? It would not depend on it, like the horn of a rabbit. Suppose he said instead that the existent depends. Then it would not make sense for the fire, existing inherently, to depend on the fuel, because, although for a mere existent to be dependent, it does not need to depend on anything once again; if something inherently existent were dependent, it would never be independent. Therefore, there would be no point in its depending on another once again. Discussing entities in general in the context of fire and fuel, it is intended that through this examination all other phenomena are examined, as it is said below “together with such things as the pot and cloth” [X:15c].
gsum pa [ltos ma ltos gnyis ka dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.1.3 Refutation of both dependence and independence
de ltar rigs pa sngon du btang ste yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin brtags na shing la ltos pa'i me ngo bo nyid kyis med de me dang shing grub ma grub ltos par mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ /

By reasoning in this way, if we examine thoroughly how things stand, fire, depending on fuel, does not exist inherently, because it is not tenable for fire and fuel to depend on one another, whether they are existent or nonexistent.
shing la ltos pa'i me med de/ / shing la ma ltos me yang med/ / me la ltos pa'i shing med de/ / me la ma ltos shing yang med/ /
12. Fire is not dependent on fuel Fire is not independent of fuel. Fuel is not dependent on fire. Fuel is not independent of fire.

shing la ma ltos pa'i me yang med de gzhan nyid bkag zin pa dang rgyu med du thal ba'i phyir ro/ / me la ltos pa'i shing yang ngo bo nyid kyis med de me dang bud shing grub ma grub gnyis ltos par mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / me la ma ltos pa'i shing yang med de sreg bzhin pa min pa bud shing du mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, there is no fire that is not dependent on fuel, because its being different has already been refuted,/8/ and the absurd consequence would follow that it would be causeless. Fuel, depending on fire, does not exist inherently, because it is not tenable that fire and fuel depend on one another, whether they are existent or nonexistent. There is also no fuel independent of fire. If something is not burning, it is not tenable that it is fuel.
gnyis pa [mngon sum du mthong ba'i sgrub byed dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.2 Refutation of the argument that it is directly perceptible

gal te dpyad pa shin tu phra mo 'dis kho bo cag la ci dgos te kho bo cag ni mngon sum gyis bud shing mes sreg bzhin pa dmigs pa'i phyir me dang bud shing ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes pa de tsam zhig smra'o zhe na/

Suppose someone asked, “Why do we need these subtle analyses? We simply say that anyone can directly perceive that the fire is burning the fuel, and so it follows that fire and fuel exist inherently.” [226]
me ni gzhan las mi 'ong ste/ / shing la'ang me ni yod ma yin/ /
13. Fire does not come from something else. Nor is fire even in fuel.

'dir me ngo bo nyid kyis yod na shing las gzhan pa'am shing de nyid las 'ong dgos na me ni shing las gzhan pa las mi 'ong ste de ltar 'ong ba ma mthong ba'i phyir dang / 'ong na yang rgyu bud shing med pas rgyu med du 'gyur ba'i phyir dang bud shing dang bcas pa yin na mer 'ong mi dgos pa'i phyir dang / der yang bud shing dang brgal brtag mtshungs pas thug med du thal ba'i phyir ro/ / shing la'ang me ni yod pa ma yin te ma dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Here, if fire existed inherently, then it would have to come from something other than fuel, or from fuel itself. But fire does not come from anything other than fuel because such things are not seen. Even if this did occur, without fuel as a cause it would be causeless, and if it came from the fuel, it would not have to come as fire. Moreover, this case is similar to the critical analysis of the fuel, according to which a vicious infinite regress follows. Nor does the fire exist even in the fuel, because it is not perceived.
gnyis pa [sngar bshad pa'i rigs pas dgag] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation through arguments presented earlier
de bzhin shing gi lhag ma ni/ / song dang ma song bgom pas bstan/ /
13d. Moreover, everything else concerning fuel is presented through Where one has gone, where one has not gone, and where one goes.

bud shing gi skabs su sun 'byin lhag ma ni sngar song dang ma song ba dang bgom pas bstan zin pa'i 'don pa bsgyur ba'i sgo nas song ba la sogs pa'i sun 'byin de bzhin du rig par bya'o/ / yang*/ re zhig bsregs la mi sreg ste/ / zhes pa dang / bsregs la sreg pa'i rtsom med de/ / zhes pa dang*/ re zhig sreg po mi sreg ste/ / zhes sogs thams cad 'don pa bsgyur ro/ /

In the context of fuel, the rest of the refutations should be understood by rearranging the previously presented arguments with respect to where one has gone, where one has not gone, and where one goes: Whatever has been burned is not burning [see II: 1a] and What has been burned needs no effort to burn. [11: 12a] and That which is a burner does not burn. [11: 15a]
gsum pa [de dag gi mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.3 Their conclusion
shing nyid me ni ma yin te/ / shing las gzhan la me yang med/ / me ni shing dang ldan ma yin/ / me la shing med der de med/ /
14. Fuel itself is not fire. Fire is in nothing other than fuel. Fire does not possess fuel. Fuel is not in fire, nor vice versa.

de ltar sngar bshad pa rnams kyi don bsdu na shing nyid me ni ma yin te byed pa po dang las gcig pa nyid du 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / shing las gzhan pa ste gzhan du yang me med de shing med par me 'byung ba sogs kyi skyon yod pa'i phyir ro/ / me ni shing dang ldan pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin te lhas byin blo dang ldan zhes pa ltar ngo bo gcig pa'i phyogs yin na sngar gcig bkag pa'i rigs pa dang*/ lhas byin ba lang dang ldan zhes pa lta bu ngo bo tha dad pa'i phyogs yin na sngar gzhan 'gog pa'i rigs pas khegs pa'i phyir gcig dang tha dad bkag pas de dag kyang don gyis bkag go / me la shing ngo bo nyid kyis brten pa yang med de de ni 'khar gzhong la rgya shug ltar yod dgos la de yang gzhan pa 'gog pas bkag pa'i phyir ro/ // bud shing der me de yang ngo bo nyid kyis med de gzhan nyid bkag pas bkag pa'i phyir ro/ // de ltar na rten dang brten pa'i phyogs gnyis bkag pa yang sngar don gyis bstan to/ /

Here, in brief, is the point of the previous explanations: Fuel itself is not fire, because it would follow that agent and object would be identical. Fire is “in nothing other than”—that is, not in anything else but—fuel, because this would entail errors such as the assertion that fire arises in the absence of fuel. Fire does not possess fuel inherently because if it were a state of affairs in which they had a identical nature, like Lhejin’s possessing a mind, then the previous arguments refuting identity would refute this as well, and if it were a state of affairs in which they had different natures, like Lhejin’s possessing a cow, then the previous arguments refuting difference would refute it. Through those refutations of identity and difference, these are implicitly refuted./9/ The fuel does not inherently depend on fire, because it would have to be like jujube fruit in a basket, and this is also refuted by the refutation of difference. Fire does not inherently exist in fuel [227] because that also has been refuted through the refutation of difference. And so the refutations both of things depending and being dependent have been implicitly presented earlier.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de gzhan la yang sbyar ba] ni/
1.2 Applying this reasoning to other phenomena
me dang shing gis bdag dang ni/ / nye bar len pa'i rim pa kun/ / bum snam sogs dang lhan cig tu/ / ma lus par ni rnam par bshad/ /
15. Through the discussion of fire and fuel, The order of self and appropriation, Together with the pot and cloth, all Without remainder have been explained.

bdag tu 'dzin pa'i yul yin pa'i phyir 'di la bdag tu nga rgyal ba bzhag cing bskyed pas bdag ces bya ba dang nye bar blang bar bya bas nye bar len pa ste de gnyis kyi grub pa'i rim pa kun ma lus pa me dang bud shing dag gis rnam par bshad par khong du chud par bya'o/ / kun dang ma lus pa la khyad par ci yod ce na/ kun smos pa ni bshad ma thag pa'i gcig tha dad la sogs pa'i phyogs snga ma tshang ba med par bdag dang nyer len gnyis la me dang bud shing ltar sbyar ba'i don yin la/ma lus pa smos pa ni lnga po de 'gog pa'i rigs pa sngar bshad pa thams cad kyang bdag dang nyer len gyi phyogs lnga 'gog pa la sbyor ba'i don no/ / de yang bdag de nyid nye bar len pa yin na las dang byed pa po gcig tu 'gyur ba dang don gzhan yin na ltos pa med pa la sogs pa'i skyon du 'gyur ro/ / de gnyis bkag pa nyid kyis ldan pa la sogs pa gsum yang bkag pa'i phyir las dang byed pa po ltar bdag dang nye bar len pa gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub kyi phan tshun ltos grub tsam du shes par bya'o/ / bdag dang nye bar len pa gnyis kyi gnyis kyi rim pa kho nar ma zad kyi bum snam la sogs pa'i dngos po ma lus bdag dang lhan cig tu me dang shing gi brtag pas rnam par bshad par rig par bya'o//bum pa dang snam bu la sogs pa ni rgyu 'bras dang yan lag dang yan lag can dang mtshan nyid dang mtshan gzhi dang yon tan dang yon tan can du gyur pa'o/ / de la 'jim pa dang chu dang 'khor lo dang rdza mkhan la sogs pa ni rgyu dang bum pa ni 'bras bu'o/ // cha shas la sogs pa'am sngon po la sogs pa ni yan lag dang bum pa ni yan lag can no//lto ba yangs pa dang mchu 'phyang ba dang kha g.yel ba dang mgul ba ring ba nyid la sogs pa ni mtshan nyid yin la bum pa ni mtshan gzhi'o/ / sngo bsangs nyid la sogs pa ni yon tan yin la bum pa ni yon tan can no/ / de bzhin du gzhan la yang sbyar ba de rnams la gcig tha dad sogs dang ltos ma ltos dang 'gro 'ong dgag pa'i rigs pa sbyor ba sogs thams cad dang 'dra bar sbyar ro/ /

Since it is the object of self-grasping, the ego is posited and constructed as the self and so it is called the self. Since it is to be appropriated there is “appropriation.” The order in which these two—“All of the process,”/10/ “without remainder”—proceed should be understood to have been explained by the fire and fuel. What is the difference between “all” and “without remainder?” Saying “all” means applying what we said immediately above about the five alternatives with respect to identity and difference, etc. [X: 14], without leaving anything out, to both self and appropriation, just like fire and fuel. Saying “without remainder” means applying all of the arguments explained earlier refuting the five alternatives to the refutation of the five alternatives with respect to self and appropriation. If the self were the appropriation, agent and object would be identical, but if they were different objects, the erroneous consequence of their independence would follow. Just by refuting these two, the three alternatives—possessing, etc.—have all been refuted. Like object and agent, the two—self and appropriation—should be understood not as existing inherently, but rather as merely existing in mutual dependence. Not only the process of the self and appropriation, but also the entities, without remainder, like the pot and cloth, should be understood to have been explained at the same time through the examination of fire and fuel. “The pot and cloth, etc.” indicates cause and effect, part and whole, characteristic and characterized, and quality and qualified. Such things as the clay, water, wheel, and potter are the causes and the pot is the effect. Such things as the portions, or [228] such properties as the blueness, are parts, and the pot is the whole. Such things as the belly, the curved lip, the flared mouth, and the long neck are the characteristics, and the pot is the characterized. Such things as blueness are the qualities, and the pot is the qualified. This is applicable in the same way to other things. The reasoning refuting such things as identity and difference, dependence and independence, going and coming, should be applied and should be applied similarly to all things.
gsum pa [bkag pa'i don du lta ba smad] ni/
1.3 Condemnation of their view of the point of the refutation
gang dag bdag dang dngos po rnams/ / de bcas nyid dang tha dad par/ / ston pa de dag bstan don la/ / mkhas so snyam du mi sems so/ /
16. I do not think that Those who teach that the self And the entities can be identical or different Understand the meaning of the doctrine.

de'i phyir de ltar las dang byed pa po ltar/ / bdag dang nye bar len pa dang bum pa la sogs pa rnams ngo bo nyid kyis med kyi phan tshun ltos pa'i grub pa yin par rnam par bzhag pa la/ rgyal ba'i gsung rab kyi don phyin ci ma log par rlom pa nyid kyis mu stegs kyi gzhung lugs kyis nye bar brtags pa'i don gyi rnam par bzhag pa rgyal ba'i gsung rab las khong du chud pa'i don du gcus nas/ / gang dag nyer len gang gis bdag tu 'dogs pa'i nyer len dang len pa po bdag de gnyis bcas pa ste so so ba min par rang bzhin gcig nyid dang de gnyis rang bzhin tha dad dang /de bzhin du dngos po bum pa la sogs pa rnams 'jim pa la sogs pa'i rgyu gang gis bum par 'dogs pa de dang bum pa der bcas pa ste gcig pa nyid dang tha dad par rtog pa de dag ni/ bstan pa'i don rten 'byung mchog tu zab pa rtag chad dang bral ba brten nas gdags pa'i ming can gyi de kho na nyid la mkhas so snyam du mgon po klu sgrub mi sems so/ / 'dis ni bdag nyid chen po'i gsung rab kyi 'grel tshul 'di 'dra zhig ma rnyed bar du thub pa'i bstan pa'i de kho na nyid rnyed pa min par gsungs pas/ gsung rab mtha' dag gi de kho na nyid kyi don bstan bcos 'dis gtan la phab pa bzhin rtogs dgos par bstan to/ /

Therefore, although we have established that just like the agent and object, neither the self and appropriation nor such things as pots exist inherently, but that all exist in mutual dependence, some arrogant people who think they nonerroneously understand the Buddha’s teachings have misrepresented the system fabricated by the set of treatises of those who hold extreme views as the content of the scriptures of the Victor. Nāgārjuna does not think that those who misrepresent the meaning of the scriptures and who conceive of the appropriation, in virtue of which the self is posited, and the self as having either the same essences as or different essences from each other represent the Victor’s thought. In the same way, he does not think that those who conceive of such entities as the pot, and such things as clay—the grounds on which they are posited—as such things as pots as having either the same essences as, or different essences from each other represent the Victor’s thought. Nāgarjuna does not think that these people are not skilled in presenting the profound meaning of the teaching of dependent origination free from the extremes of reification and nihilism—dependent designation, which is called reality. By means of this verse he says that until one achieves a hermeneutical approach to the sūtras like that of the great master, one will not achieve an understanding of the Sage’s doctrine as it really is taught. He thereby shows that the real meaning of all of the scriptures should be understood as they are established in this treatise.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar rnal 'byor pa me dang bud shing gi brtag pas chos rnams kyi de kho na nyid khong du chud pa'i lus ni/ phyi'i dus mtha'i me'am nang gi dug gsum gyi mes mi 'tshig ste/ting nge 'dzin rgyal po las/ bskal pa brgya phrag mang por rab bsregs kyang / / nam mkha' sngon chad nam yang ma tshig bzhin/ / chos rnams nam mkha' mtshungs par rnam rig pas/ / de ni gzhar yang me nang yong mi 'tshig / gal te sangs rgyas zhing rnams 'bar gyur la/ / 'bar ba 'di dag ma lus zhi shog ces/ / ting 'dzin gnas nas smon lam 'di btab na/ / sa rnams zhig kyang de la 'gyur ba med/ / ces gsungs so/ /

[229] The body of the yogi who has realized the way phenomena really exist through the examination of fire and fuel cannot be burned either by the fire at the end of the aeon or by the fire of the three poisons, as the Samādhirājasūtra says: Just as space is never consumed Although it burns for many aeons, Those who have realized that phenomena are spacelike Are not consumed at all by fire. If one abides in samadhi and offers this prayer— May these burnings be pacified— Then even if the Buddha-fields are burned, Even if the Earth disintegrates, there will be no change. [m Do sde da 45b]

mchod brjod du rten 'byung mtha' brgyad dang bral bar bstan pa'i nang nas rab tu byed pa 'dis gtso cher don gcig pa dang don tha dad pa gnyis kyi mtha' bkag pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub par bstan pa dang*/ de ltar bshad pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na mdo las/ / ji ltar gtsub shing dang ni gtsub stan dang / / lag pa'i rtsol ba 'di gsum 'dus pa yi/ / rkyen 'di dag las me ni 'byung 'gyur zhing*/ / byung ste bya ba byas nas myur du 'gag / de nas 'di ni gang nas 'ongs sam gar/ / song zhes mkhas pa 'ga' zhig tshol bar byed/da/ / phyogs dang phyogs mtshams kun tu btsal ba na/ / 'di yi 'gro dang 'ong ba rnyed min bzhin/ / phung po dag dang skye mched khams rnams ni/ / nang yang stong la phyi rol stong pa ste/ / thams cad bdag gis dben zhing gnas med la/ / chos kyi mtshan nyid nam mkha'i ngo bo nyid/ / chos kyi mtshan nyid 'di 'dra 'di dag ni/ / mar me mdzad pa mthong nas khyod kyis rtogs/ / ji ltar nyid kyis rjes su rtogs pa ltar/ / de bzhin lha mir bcas pas rtogs par gyis/ / log pa yang dag ma yin brtags pa yi/ / 'dod chags zhe sdang dag gis 'gro ba gdungs/ / thugs rje'i sprin las zhi ba bsil ba'i chu/ / 'dren pa bdud rtsi'i rgyun ni rab tu phob/ / ces gsungs so//

In the homage verses, it is shown that the dependently arisen is free from the eight extremes. Out of those, this chapter primarily refutes the two extremes of identity and difference, and in order to show that this is corroborated by profound sūtras and that all of the sūtras explaining these things should be understood through this chapter, a brief indication of confirmation by definitive sūtras is provided. In a sūtra it is said: Through the joint action of these three—the stick that is rubbed, The stick on which it is rubbed, and the effort of the hand— Through these conditions, fire arises. Having arisen, it performs it function and instantly ceases. Thereafter, some wise men investigate: Where did this come from? Where did it go? Having searched in all directions, Its going and coming are not found. Similarly, the aggregates, the faculties, and the elements Are internally and externally empty. Everything is devoid of self and groundless. The characteristic of entities is spacelike nature. These kinds of characteristics of phenomena, On seeing, Dīpankara, you will realize. [230] Just as you have realized them, You shall cause gods and men to realize them, O leader, may your cloud of compassion bestow a continuous Peaceful rain of cool nectar to Beings tormented by desire and hatred, Which are false, thoroughly flawed and fabricated. [Lalitavistara-sūtra, mDo sde kha 89b]

de la tshigs bcad dang po gnyis kyis me ni brtags na cung zad kyang mi rnyed pa dang de nyid rgyu rkyen la brten nas skyes te rang gi bya ba byed pa dper bkod do/ / de nas rkang pa gsum gyis bdag dang bdag gi ba'i chos gnyis ka ngo bo nyid kyis stong par bstan te dpe'i chos gnyis ka sbyar ro/ / de nas gcig gis stong pa nyid kyis dpe bstan to/ / de nas gnyis kyis don de ston pas sngar rtogs pa dang de nas gnyis kyis de ltar du gzhan la ston dgos pa dang / de nas gnyis kyis de ltar bstan dgos pa'i rgyu mtshan dang / de nas gnyis kyis chos char 'bebs tshul bstan to/ /

Here, the first two verses provide an analogy that shows that when fire is examined nothing is found, and that having arisen from causes and conditions it performs its function. Then the next three lines show that both the self and that which is possessed by the self are empty of entity. The characteristics in the analogy apply to both. The next line provides an analogy for emptiness. The next two lines show that first Dīpaṇkara realizes, and then the next two show that he should teach it to others, and the next two lines present the reason that he should teach. The last two show how he should bestow the rain of Dharma./11/
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

de dang bud shing gis mtshon nas bdag dang bdag gi ba dang rgyu 'bras dang yan lag dang yan lag can la sogs pa la gcig dang tha dad pa nyid rnam par bzhag pa na/ ci 'di rnams rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa la bzhag pa yin nam 'on te tha snyad kyi dbang gis yod pa la bzhag pa yin snyam du bsams nas/ sngar bshad pa'i rigs pa rnams kyis dpyad pa na snga ma ltar yin na ni bsreg bya dang sreg byed la sogs pa'i tha snyad gang yang byas med par rtogs nas de dag la bden par 'dzin pa 'gog cing / phyi ma la tha snyad de dag thams cad ches 'thad do snyam du rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i nges pa brtan par bya'o/ /

So, when the self and that which is possessed by the self, and such things as cause and effect and part and whole, are established as identical or different, using the example of fire and fuel, one might ask, “Are these established as existing inherently, or are they established through the power of nominal convention?” Then, if one analyzes using the previously explained arguments in the first case, realizing that there would be no grounds for designating anything as that which is to be burned and the burner, etc., grasping them as truly existent is refuted. But in the latter case, realising that all these conventions are completely tenable, it should be ascertained that they are dependently arisen.
me dang bud shing brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu pa'o/
This is the tenth chapter called “the examination of fire and fuel.”
me dang bud shing brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu drug gi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the tenth chapter, having sixteen verses, called “the examination of fire and fuel.”

d.crumb: *XI. Examination of the Beginning and End

f.d: CHAPTER XI. Examination of the Beginning and End
gnyis pa gang zag rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed kyi rtags dgag pa
We now begin the second part, the refutation of the reasoning in the premises.
['di] la gnyis/ /skye 'chi'i bya ba yod pa'i rtags dgag / rten pa sdug bsngal yod pa'i rtags dgag pa'o/ /
This part has two sections: the refutation of the argument that the activity of birth and death exists and the refutation of the argument that, dependent on the self, suffering exists.
dang po [skye 'chi'i bya ba yod pa'i rtags dgag]
This chapter is the first of these two parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citation of definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ bdag ni rang bzhin gyis yod de 'khor ba yod pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te bdag med na 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor bar 'di nas phyi mar 'gro ba dang snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba'i ngo bo skye ba dang / 'chi ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pas su zhig 'khor/ ston pas kyang skye ba dang rga shi'i 'khor ba ni thog ma dang tha ma med do/ / sems can ma rig pa'i sgrib pa dang ldan pa sred pa'i kun tu sbyor ba can sred pa'i lu gu rgyud kyis bcings pa 'khor zhing rgyug pa rnams kyi sngon gyi mtha' ni mi mngon no/ / zhes skye shi brgyud mar byed pa'i sgo nas 'khor bar gsungs so/ / de lta na 'khor ba po yang yod la de yang bdag yin no/ / 'di dgag pa la gnyis/ 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba'o/ /

Here one might say the self exists essentially because cyclic existence exists. If there were no self, then in this cycle of five transmigrations, of migration proceeding to the next from this one, and coming from the previous one to this one, who would have the nature of transmigrating from one birth and death to another? The teacher has also said that the cycle of birth, aging, and death is without beginning or end. The origin of sentient beings who, clouded by ignorance, completely enmeshed with attachment, and bound by the chain of attachment, transmigrate, hurtling, is not apparent. Here the Buddha says that sentient beings, through continuous birth and death, transmigrate. Thus, the transmigrator exists, and that is the self. The refutation of this has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of cyclic existence and the application of the argument to other phenomena.
dang po ['khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of cyclic existence
['di] la gnyis/ 'khor ba la thog mtha' bar gsum gyi cha dgag / skye 'chi la dus snga phyi dang lhan cig pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of cyclic existence having a beginning, middle, and end and the refutation of birth and death being sequential or simultaneous.
dang po ['khor ba la thog mtha' bar gsum gyi cha dgag] ni/
1.1.1 Refutation of cyclic existence having a beginning, middle, and end
sngon mtha' mngon nam zhes zhus tshe/ / thub pa chen pos min zhes gsungs/ / 'khor ba thog ma tha med de/ / de la sngon med phyi ma med/ /
1. When asked if the beginning is known, The great sage said “no.” Cyclic existence is without origin or terminus. Because there is no beginning or end.

'khor ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod na bum pa la sogs pa bzhin de la sngon dang phyi ma yang yod par 'gyur na/ 'khor ba de la ni sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' med de skye ba dang rga shi'i 'khor ba ni thog ma dang tha ma med do zhes gsungs shing / rdzogs byed la sogs pa'i mu stegs kyi ston pa rnams kyis thub pa la 'khor ba 'di la sngon gyi mtha' mngon mi mngon dri la mngon par smra na des 'khor ba la 'byin pa po med pa dang rgyu med du 'byung ba min par smra ba sun phyin no/ / mi mngon par smra na mi shes par khas blangs pas rang nyid thams cad mkhyen par smra ba kyai gau ta ma 'khor ba'i sngon gyi sun phyin par 'gyur ro zhes bgros nas/ mtha' mngon nam zhes zhus pa'i tshe thub pa chen pos sngon gyi mtha' mngon pa min no zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar 'khor ba thog ma dang tha ma med par gsungs pa'i phyir 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa gyis yod pa min no zhes gsal bar gsungs pa yin la/ de'i phyir sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' mi dmigs pa'i phyir 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis med de mgal me'i 'khor lo 'khor ba bzhin no/ / gal te 'khor ba'i thog mtha' med par gsungs pa ni 'di tsam zhig nas byung zhes pa'i dang po'i mtshams dang phyi'i mtha' 'di tsam nas mi 'byung zhes pa'i tha ma'i mtshams med par ston pa yin la/ / de gnyis med par gsungs pas 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin par gsal bar bstan pa ji ltar 'thad ce na/ 'dir 'khor ba la thog ma dang tha ma med par gsungs pa ni khyed smra ba de kho na min te cha snga ma dang phyi ma yang med par gsungs pa yin la de ni don dam par med pa la dgongs pa yin te/ bud d+ha pA li ta las kyang / don dam pa bstan pa'i dbang gis ni/ de la sngon med phyi ma med ces gsungs so zhes bshad pa bzhin no/ // des na tshig gsal las sngar ltar bshad pa mi 'gal lo/ /

If cyclic existence existed inherently, then like such things as a pot, it would also have a beginning and an end. But it is said that cyclic existence does not have a beginning or end, in that the cycle of birth, aging, and death does not have an origin or a terminus. Various non-Buddhist teachers, including Pūrana, held a discussion and decided to ask the Buddha whether he knew that this cyclic existence has a beginning or end. They said that if he says that he does, this would contradict the many statements that there is no creator and that nothing arises without a cause, but if he says that he does not, [232] he would contradict his statement that he is omniscient. Then they asked him “Hey, Gautama! Do you know that this cyclic existence has a beginning?” The great sage replied, “There is no knowledge of a beginning.” Thus, having said that cyclic existence has no beginning or end, he said clearly that it does not exist essentially. Therefore, since the origin and terminus are not seen, cyclic existence does not exist essentially; cyclic existence is like the circle made by swinging a glowing ember. Someone might say, “The statement that cyclic existence has no origin demonstrates that there is no specific point from which it arises, nor any point after which it does not continue. How could it be tenable that to say that neither of these exists is to say explicitly that cyclic existence does not exist essentially?” But here we reply that the statement, “Cyclic existence has neither origin nor terminus,” does not mean what you say it does, but instead means that he has also said that there is neither a beginning nor an end. This means that they do not exist ultimately. Buddhapālita also says in the same vein, In accordance with the presentation of the ultimate, the Buddha has said “there is neither beginning nor end.” [211a] Thus, this does not contradict Prasannapadā’s earlier explanation [75b].

'o na sngon mtha' mngon nam zhes zhus pa'i lan du mi mngon no zhes gsungs pa ni tha snyad du yin na de 'khor ba rang bzhin med pa'i sgrub byed du ji ltar rung snyam na/ 'di ni rigs pa drug cu pa las/ nyon mongs zad pa'i dge slong gi / 'khor ba gal te rnam ldog na/ / de rtsom rdzogs sangs rgyas rnams kyis/ / gang ma bshad pa'i rgyu ci zhig / ces phung po rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa zad pa'i 'khor ba ldog pa'i tha ma yod na/ dang po'i rtsom pa mi gsungs pa la rgyu mtshan med pas thog ma yod par bshad pa'i rigs pa dang 'dra'o/ /

Suppose someone thought as follows: Responding “I don’t know” to the question, “Do you know that there is a beginning?” is a conventional statement. How could this be a premise for the assertion that cyclic existence is essenceless? Here, consider the similar argument in Yuktiṣaṣṭikā: If through the elimination of afflictions monks depart from cyclic existence, Why have the buddhas not Explained the beginning? [14]/1/ If there were an end of cyclic existence—and of aggregates that exist through their own characteristics—then there would be no reason for saying that there is no initial beginning. [233]

gal te ston pas 'khor ba'i sngon dang phyi ma bkag na dge slong dag de lta bas na 'khor ba zad par bya ba'i phyir nan tan du bya'o snyam du khyed kyis de ltar bslab par bya'o zhes tha mar zad pa yod par gsungs pa dang 'gal lo zhe na/ mi 'gal te sngar mdo drangs pa las sems can ma rig pa dang ldan pa zhes sogs kyis khyad par du byas pa de dag kho na'i 'khor ba tha ma med par ston gyi nyon mongs pa ma lus par spangs pa rnams la ni zad pa'i mtha' yod do/ /

Suppose someone argued as follows: If the teacher had denied that there is a beginning and end of cyclic existence, then this would contradict the following statement in sūtra that there is elimination at the end: Therefore, oh monks, one should make strenuous effort to eliminate cyclic existence. Thinking that, you should begin training immediately. [Saṁyuttanikāya XV Anamataggasaṁyuttam, IX Dandasuttam, Vol. II, 616] There is no contradiction here, because this quotation from sūtra presents only the cyclic existence of those “sentient beings who are ignorant” as having no end, but for those who have completely eliminated the afflictions, there is an end.

gal te thog ma dang bral ba rnams la tha ma yod pa mi 'gal lam snyam na/ mi 'gal te/ brgya pa las/ ji ltar sa bon mtha' mthong zhing / / de la thog ma yod min ltar/ / de bzhin rgyu ni ma tshang phyir/ / skye ba'ang 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes sa bon la thog ma med kyang mes tshig pa las tha ma yod bzhin du/ skye ba la thog ma med kyang nyon mongs pa zad nas rgyu ma tshang ba la phyis nyon mongs kyi dbang gis skye ba zad pa'i tha ma ni yod par bshad do/ / 'dir dngos po'i de kho na nyid sems pa'i dbang du byas na thog mtha' gnyis med par 'dra yang tha snyad du thog mtha' gnyis yod med mi 'dra'o/ /

Suppose one thought, would it not be contradictory for that which lacks an origin to have a terminus? There is no contradiction, because, as Catuḥśataka says, Just as the terminus of the seed is seen, But the origin is not seen, Without completing all of the causes, Nor does birth occur./2/ [VIII: 25] Just as even though the seed does not have an origin, there is a terminus when it is burned by fire, although birth does not have a beginning for those who have not completed the causes through the exhaustion of the afflictions, it is said that there is a terminus—the exhaustion of that birth which occurs due the afflictions. Here, although the origin and terminus are equally nonexistent with respect to the way things really are, conventionally, the origin and terminus are not similar with respect to their existence and nonexistence.
gal te 'khor ba la thog mtha' rang bzhin gyis ma grub mod kyang dbus ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma bkag pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose someone says that although it has neither origin nor terminus essentially it must have a middle essentially, since that has not been refuted.
gang la thog ma tha med pa/ / de la dbus ni ga la yod/ /
2. For that which has neither origin nor terminus, How could there be a middle?

'khor ba gang la thog ma dang tha ma rang bzhin gyis med pa de la dbus rang bzhin gyis grub pa ga la yod de med do/ // de'i phyir 'khor ba ni nam mkha' bzhin du thog mtha' dbus kyi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dang bral ba'i phyir ming tsam du zad de mgal me'i 'khor lo 'khor ba la sogs pa bzhin no/ / 'dir bud d+ha pA li ta las/ thog ma dbus dang tha ma rnams/ / skye ba'i snga rol mi srid de/ / gnyis gnyis dag ni ma gtogs par/ / re res rtsom par ji ltar 'gyur/ zhes brgya pa las gsungs pa drangs pas thog mtha' dbus gsum ni skye 'jig gnas gsum yin la/ skye 'jig ngo bo nyid kyis med pas gnas pa ngo bo nyid kyis med pa ni thog mtha' gnyis med pas dbus med ces pa'i don no/ / de'i phyir 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pas 'khor ba po rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no/ /

How could that cyclic existence which does not have an origin or terminus essentially, have a middle essentially? It could not. Therefore, since cyclic existence is like the sky, without any origin, terminus, or middle existing inherently, these are merely nominal. Cyclic existence is just like such things as the circle made by swinging a glowing ember. Here, Buddhapālita [211b] quotes Catuḥśataka [234] Origin, middle and terminus Are not possible before arising. Without the other two, How could any of them occur? [XV: 5] This means that the three—origin, middle, and terminus—are these three: arising, enduring, and ceasing. Just as since arising and ceasing are not inherently existent, and enduring is not inherently existent, since the two—origin and terminus—do not exist, middle does not exist either. Therefore, it is not the case that since cyclic existence exists essentially, the transmigrator exists essentially.
gnyis pa [skye 'chi la dus snga phyi dang lhan cig pa dgag pa]
1.1.2 Refutation of birth and death being sequential or simultaneous
['di] la gsum/ mdor bstan/ rgyas par bshad/ don bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has three parts: the brief summary, the detailed explanation, and drawing conclusions.
dang po [mdor bstan] ni/
1.1.2.1 Brief summary
de phyir de la snga phyi dang / / lhan cig rim pa mi 'thad do/ /
2cd. Therefore it is not tenable that it is ordered as prior, posterior, or simultaneous.

'khor ba la thog mtha' dbus gsum rang bzhin gyis med pa de'i phyir 'khor ba de la 'khor ba po'i skye ba dang rga shi dag la yang snga phyi dang lhan cig tu ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa'i dus kyi rim pa mi 'thad do/ / rang sdes sems can rnams skye shi bar ma chad du thog ma med pa nas tha ma med pa'i bar du 'khor zhing rgyug par gsungs pa'i lung gis skye 'chi byed mkhan gyi sems can yod par gsungs pa la brten nas gang zag ngo bo nyid kyis yod par smra ba la thog mtha' med par gsungs pa nyid kyis skye 'chi'i 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis grub par mi 'thad ces sngar bsgrubs la/ 'dir ni skye 'chi rang bzhin gyis grub na dus gsum las mi 'da' ba khyab byed du bstan nas de gsum 'gog pa'o/ /

Since cyclic existence does not have an origin, middle, or terminus inherently, it is not tenable for the transmigrator in cyclic existence inherently to have birth, aging, and death, either ordered as sequential or as simultaneous. According to other Buddhist schools who maintain that the person exists inherently, the sūtras that say that sentient beings transmigrate—being born and dying continuously, from beginningless time to endless time—thereby imply that these sentient beings, who are agents of birth and death, exist. It has already been demonstrated to them that it is not tenable that the cycle of birth and death exists essentially simply on the ground of the statement that there is no origin or terminus. Here, if birth and death existed essentially, one cannot escape their being categorized as existing in one of the three temporal periods, and these alternatives are now refuted.

spyir 'dus byas thams cad la skye ba dang rga ba yod la sngar/ dngos po thams cad dus kun tu/ / rga dang 'chi ba'i chos yin na/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar 'gag pa la yang 'chi ba zhes btags pa yod mod kyang / sems can ma yin pa'i rgyu 'bras la sogs pa'i dus kyi rim pa ni rigs pa 'di gzhan la sbyar ba'i skabs su gsungs pas 'dir ni sems can gyi dbang du byas pa'o// // shi ba dang 'chi ba'i tha snyad btags pa yang skabs dang sbyar ro/ / snga phyi dang dus mnyam gang yin dpyod pa'i gzhi ni lhas byin gyi dus dang po dang bar dang tha ma'i skye rga 'chi ba min pas de gsum spyir bzung ba'o/ /

Generally, all produced phenomena arise and age. As it was said previously, Inasmuch as the nature of all entities Is always aging and death … [VII: 24ab] Although sometimes ceasing is called “death,” it has been said in the context of applying this argument to other phenomena that it applies to the temporal order of causes and effects of things other than sentient beings. In this context, though, sentient beings are the issue. The words “death” and “dying” must be understood in context. [235] The basis of the analysis of sequence and simultaneity is not Lhejin’s first being born, then aging, and finally dying; but these three in general are taken as the basis.
gnyis pa [rgyas par bshad]
1.1.2.2 Detailed explanation
['di] la gnyis/ snga phyi ba dgag / dus mnyam pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of sequence and the refutation of simultaneity.
dang po [snga phyi ba dgag]
1.1.2.2.1 Refutation of sequence
['di] la gnyis/ skye ba snga ba dgag / rga shi snga ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the priority of birth and the refutation of the priority of aging and death.
dang po [skye ba snga ba dgag] ni/
1.1.2.2.1.1 Refutation of the priority of birth
gal te skye ba snga gyur la/ / rga shi phyi ma yin na ni/ / skye ba rga shi med pa dang / / ma shi bar yang skye bar 'gyur/ /
3. If birth came first, And then aging and death, Then birth would be ageless and deathless And a deathless one would be born.

gal te 'khor ba po'i skye ba snga bar gyur la de las rga shi phyi ma yin na ni/ de'i tshe de'i skye ba la rga ba dang shi ba ste 'chi ba med par 'gyur ro/ / de 'dod na ni skye ba de 'dus ma byas su 'gyur de gzhan du 'gyur ba'i rga ba dang 'chi ba dang bral ba'i phyir ro/ / sems can skyes pa 'chi ba dang bral na rtag dgos pas 'dus ma byas su 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas bskyangs kyis skye ba la rga shi med na phyis rga shi 'ong ba'i gzhi med par 'gyur la phyis rga shi dang phrad du zin kyang des skye ba la ci yang mi byed par 'gyur te rga shi med par ngo bo nyid kyis gnas pa'i phyir ro zhes 'chad do/ // skye ba snga bar rtog na lhas byin tshe rabs gzhan du ma shi bar yang 'dir dang por skye bar 'gyur bas 'khor ba la thog ma yod par 'gyur zhing rgyu med pa'i skyon du 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang bdag 'das pa'i dus na byung ngo zhes sngon gyi skye ba dran pa mi 'thad par 'gyur zhing sngon ma byung ba'i sems can phyis skye ba'i gsar skye yod par 'gyur ro/

If the transmigrator’s birth came first and later his aging and death, in that case, his birth would be ageless and deathless. If you maintained that, it would follow that the birth would be unproduced, because it would lack transformation into aging and death. If sentient beings who are born lacked death, they would have to be permanent. It would follow that they are unproduced. The Buddhapālita says that if birth were ageless and deathless, later there would be no basis for aging and death. Even though later aging and death are encountered, there would be no effect on birth, because it would endure inherently without aging and death. [211b] If one thought that birth was first, then Lhejin, without ever having died in a previous life, would be born for the first time here. The erroneous consequence would follow that his cyclic existence has a beginning and that it would be causeless. Moreover, it would be not be tenable that one remembers one’s previous lives, saying “I was there in the past.” There would also be new sentient beings who did not exist in the past.

gal te lhas byin skye ba snga mar ma shi bar 'dir skyes na zhes pa'i don gang yin 'dir skyes pa'i lhas byin skye ba snga mar ma shi bar zhes pa'i don yin na ni/ dper na tshe snga mar lha tshe 'phos nas tshe 'dir mir skyes pa'i mi de skye ba snga mar ma shi bar 'dir skyes pa yin kyang / 'khor ba la thog ma yod mi dgos pa bzhin du tshe 'dir skyes pa'i lhas byin la yang mtshungs so/ / tshe 'dir mir skyes pa de tshe snga mar shi bar 'dod na ni shin tu mi rigs te tshe snga mar de med pa'i phyir dang tshe snga mar shi ba de lha shi ba ma yin par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / tshe 'dir skyes pa de nyid snga mar shi ba yin na 'dir shi ba de nyid phyi mar skyes par 'gyur bas 'gro ba gang shi ba de nyid 'gro ba der skye dgos pa 'gyur ro/ /

Suppose one meant, by “Lhejin was born here without having died in a previous life,” that the Lhejin who was born here did not die in a previous life. Consider this, for instance: Although a person who, having left a previous life as a god, is born in this life as a human being, he would have been born in this life without having died in the previous life. However, the life of the Lhejin who is born here, like cyclic existence, must be without beginning. If one maintained that the very person who is born in this life as a human being [236] died in a previous life, this still would make no sense at all, because he does not exist in the previous life; and it would follow that the death in the previous life would not be the death of a god. If the very one born in this life died in the previous life, the very one who dies in this life would be born in the next life. So, the very transmigrator who dies would have to be born as that transmigrator.

ci ste tshe snga mar lhas byin zhes pa'i sems can gcig ma shi bar 'dir sems can gcig skyes na thog ma yod par 'gyur ro zhes pa yin na yang mi rigs te/ lhas byin gcig gi dbang du byas pa'i skye 'chi gnyis kyi skye ba snga ba 'gog pa'i skabs yin gyi/ sems can gcig gi dbang du ma byas pa'i sems can so so ba'i skye 'chi gnyis gang snga dpyod pa'i skabs min pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ 'dir sems can rgyud so so ba gnyis kyi skye 'chi gang snga dpyod pa min gyi sems can rgyud gcig gi yin no/ /

Suppose someone argued as follows: If the one sentient being called “Lhejin,” without having died in a previous life, is born here as one sentient being, there would be a beginning. However, saying this would not make sense, because this occurs in the context of the refutation of birth being the earlier of the two—birth and death—of a single Lhejin; but this is not the context of an analysis of which of the two—birth and death—is earlier for distinct sentient beings, as opposed to a single sentient being.

'di la yang pha rol pos tshe 'di'i lhas byin gyi dang por skye gnas su nying mtshams sbyar ba'i skye ba dang phung po de'i ris mthun dor ba'i 'chi ba gnyis skye ba snga la 'chi ba 'phyi bar 'dod cing / rgyud gcig gi skye 'chi la snga phyi'i nges pa med par 'dod mod kyang / tshe 'di'i lhas byin dang de'i bdag gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa'i phyogs la so so ba mi 'dod pas ngo bo gcig tu 'dod la/ de lta na gcig tu 'gyur bas tshe 'di'i lhas byin gyi skye shi dang de dang rgyud gcig pa'i skye ba dang rga shi gnyis la snga phyi yin min dbye bar mi nus so/ // de'i phyir rgyud gcig pa'i skye ba 'chi ba las snga na lhas byin tshe 'dir skyes pa'i sngon du de dang rgyud gcig pa'i shi ba ma song dgos la/ de lta na lhas byin gyi 'khor ba la thog ma yod pa dang rgyud gcig pa'i sems can sngar med gsar du 'byung ba dang*/ lhas byin gyis bdag 'das pa'i tshe rabs rnams su byung ngo zhes smras pa mi 'thad par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod do/ / des na 'dir skyes pa'i sems can de nyid skye ba snga mar ma shi bar 'dir skyes na zhes pa yang min la tshe snga mar shi ba dang 'dir skyes pa gnyis sems can rgyud so so ba la byed pa yang min pas skyon de dag gang yang med do/

Here, the analysis is not of which of the two—birth and death—is earlier with respect to two sentient beings belonging to different continua, but rather with respect to a single continuum of a sentient being. Here also, the opponent maintains that the Lhejin of this life’s birth (the entry of consciousness into the embryo/3/) and his death (the sloughing off of the homogeneous continuum of aggregates) come first and later, respectively. But he maintains that there is no certainty with respect to a single continuum that birth comes first and death comes later. According to the position that both the Lhejin of this life and his self exist inherently, it is not maintained that they exist distinctly; but instead that they are a single entity. In that case, since they are one, the birth and death of the Lhejin of this life and the birth, aging, and death of the same continuum cannot be distinguished as earlier and later. Therefore, if birth in a single continuum were prior to death, then there would have to have been no death in that continuum before Lhejin was born in this life. Then the following errors would ensue: asserting that there is a beginning of Lhejin’s cyclic existence, asserting that there would be a new emergence of the continuum of a sentient being where none had been there before, and it would not be tenable for Lhejin to say that “I was there in those lives.” [237] Thus, this is neither to say that the very sentient being that is born in this life is born without having died previously, nor that the one who died in the previous life and has been born in this one is a continuum of different sentient beings. Therefore, we do not commit any error.

gal te tshe 'di'i lhas byin gyis nga tshe rabs snga ma rnams su 'di dang 'dir skyes so zhes dran pa yod du chug kyang des dran pa ltar khas blang du mi rung ste/ len na ni tshe 'di yi lhas byin 'di nyid tshe rabs snga ma rnams su yang yod pas rtag par 'gyur ro snyam na/ 'di ni dran tshul ma shes par smra ba'i rtsod pa yin te/dper na rtsod pa'i dus su sgra 'dra ba zhig sngar rtag par khas blangs la phyis sngar gyi khas blangs ma dran par mi rtag par khas blangs pa na/ rtsod zlas 'gal ba bsgrigs pa'i tshe dran par 'gyur la de'i tshe ngas sngar rtag par khas blangs 'dug snyam du dran gyi dus phyi ma'i dus na yod pa'i nga 'dis sngar rtag pa khas blangs so snyam du mi dran no/ / de'i rgyu mtshan gyis 'gal ba sgrig nus kyi de lta ma yin na 'gal ba sgrig mi nus te sngar dus kyi rtag pa khas len mkhan gyis phyi dus su mi rtag par khas ma blangs pa'i phyir ro/ /

One might argue as follows: Although the Lhejin of this life could remember, “I was born in that and other previous lives,” it would be wrong to accept it just as he remembers it. If we did so accept it, the very Lhejin of this life would have to have been in the previous lives as well, and therefore he would be permanent. In response to this, we say this is an argument propounded by someone who does not understand how memory works. For instance, early in the course of a debate, someone accepts that something such as sound is permanent. Later, not remembering what he accepted earlier, he maintains that it is impermanent. When the opponent in the debate demonstrates the contradiction by juxtaposing the two theses, he remembers, thinking “earlier, I maintained that sound was permanent,” but does not remember “The I who exists later maintained earlier that sound was permanent.” For this reason, contradictory theses can be juxtaposed; otherwise, it would be impossible to juxtapose contradictory theses, because the very one who maintained that sound was permanent previously does not maintain that it is impermanent later.

de bzhin du tshe 'di'i mi lhas byin gyis sngon gyi skye ba dran pa na nga sngar de dang der skyes 'dug snyam du dran pa yin gyi tshe 'di'i dus kyis khyad par du byas nas nga sngar de dang der skyes 'dug snyam du mi dran no/ // des na tshe 'di'i lhas byin gyis gang la dmigs nas nga'o snyam pa skye ba'i dmigs par gyur pa'i bdag ni tshe rabs snga ma rnams su yang yod pas de ltar dran pa mi 'gal la/ tshe 'di'i lhas byin tshe snga mar yod na rtag par 'gyur ba dang yang mi 'dra'o/ / de bzhin du ma 'ongs pa'i skye ba la yang tshe 'di'i dus kyi gang zag de nyid skye ba phyi mar mi 'gro yang nga'o snyam pa'i dmigs pa nga tsam zhig der yang rjes su 'gro bas/ rang nyid skye ba phyi mar sdug bsngal gyis dogs nas de'i rgyu mi dge ba 'dir spong ba dang bde bar bya ba'i phyir du 'dir dge ba la brtson pa yang 'thad de/ dper na de ring gi dus kyi mi 'di sang gi dus na med kyang sang bkres skom gyi sdug bsngal byung gis dogs nas de ring nas bza' btung gsog pa dang / rgas pa'i tshe sdug bsngal gyis dogs nas gzhon dus nor gsog pa bzhin no/ /

Similarly, when the man—Lhejin in this life—remembers his previous lives (“I was born in that life and others”) he does not remember, “I, qua being currently existing in this life was born in that life and others.” So, the self objectified by the Lhejin of this life, which is the referent of the “I” in any thought “I am,” does exist in previous lives as well. Therefore there is no inconsistency in remembering. This is not similar to saying that since he—Lhejin of this life—existed earlier, he would be permanent. Similarly, with respect to future lives, the very person who exists currently in this life will not go into future lives. However, the mere self—the object of the thought “I am”—is taken to go there as well. [238] Therefore it is reasonable to perform virtuous deeds in order to achieve benefits in future lives and to abandon vicious deeds out of fear of suffering in future lives. For instance, although the person who exists today will not exist tomorrow, out of fear of suffering hunger tomorrow, he stores food today. To take another example, out of fear of the sufferings of old age, a person accumulates wealth in his youth.

'di thams cad kyang yul dus 'di'i bdag ces so sor mi 'byed par spyir bdag bde ba thob pa dang sdug bsngal dang bral bar 'dod nas byed la/ bdag tsam yang dus de dag tu rjes su 'gro bas des yul la 'khrul ba yang min no/ / des na nga'o snyam du tha snyad 'dogs mkhan gyi mi dang tha snyad btags pa'i gzhi bdag gnyis khyab mnyam du mi gzung bar mi de bdag de'i cha gcig yin pa shes par byos shig / 'di rnams rten 'brel spyi dang khyad par du las dkar nag gi 'bras bu bde sdug 'byung ba'i nges pa la khyad che bar snang bas phyogs tsam brjod pa'o/ / 'dir 'grel pa las shing a mra la sogs pa rnams rga ba dang zhig pa sngon du ma song yang dang por skye ba mthong ba de bzhin du bdag kyang rga shi sngon du ma song yang skye'o zhes smra ba la/de dag kyang rang gi sa bon 'gag pa na skye ba'i phyir gzhan du ma zhig pa skye ba min pas snga ma dang mtshungs so/ / ci ste sa bon las shing gzhan yin pas shing gi skye ba ni gzhan du ma zhig pa'o snyam na/ rgyu 'bras gzhan nyid yin pas bsgrub bya dang mtshungs par gsungs te/ rgyud gcig pa la sngar ltar gtugs na bdag dang mtshungs kyi de lta ma yin na lan gdab par dka'o/ /

In all of these cases in general—without specifying the identity of the self in terms of time and place—the self, because it desires to obtain happiness and to avoid suffering, does such things. The mere self is taken to persist through those times as well. Thus it is not erroneous for these people to take the mere self as the referent of “I.” Therefore, the person who uses the expression “I am,” and the basis of the use of that expression should not be taken to be coextensive; instead, the person should be understood as a segment of that self. Since all of these are important in order to understand dependent arising in general, and in order to ascertain the relation between virtuous and vicious deeds and happiness and suffering in particular, they have been discussed briefly here. Here the Commentary presents the following example: One might say, just as such things as a mango tree are seen first being born without being preceded by aging and death, the self also is born without being preceded by aging and death. But, since even they arise from the cessation of their seeds, they do not arise without the other thing having ceased. So, this is similar to the preceding. One might then think that since the tree that comes from the seed is different from it, the arising of the tree, occurs without previous cessation. But since cause and effect are not different, this is similar to what we are proving. This is because a single continuum, as we saw earlier, is like a self; otherwise it would be difficult to respond [76b].
gnyis pa [rga shi snga ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.1.2 Refutation of the priority of aging and death
gal te skye ba 'chi 'gyur la/ / rga shi snga ma yin na ni/ / skye ba med pa'i rga shi ni/ / rgyu med par ni ci ltar 'gyur/ /
4. If birth were to come after, And aging and death first, How could there be a causeless aging and death Without birth?

gal te sems can gyi skye ba 'phyi bar 'gyur la de las de'i rga shi snga ba yin na ni/ skye ba sngar med pa'i rga shi ni rgyu med par ni yod par ji ltar 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad du/ bong ba bteg par gyur pa na/ / bteg pa la ni rgyu yod kyi/ / bteg pa'i lta zhig rgyu las ni/ / gzhan pa ltung la med pa nyid/ / ces bshad pa de yang bteg pa kho na ltung ba'i rgyu yin gyi gzhan min pa de bzhin du skye ba kho na 'jig pa'i rgyu yin gyi gzhan ni min no/ // des na 'jig pa rgyu med yod pa min no/ / 'jig pa 'di skye ba'i rgyu can yin pas 'byung ba kho na 'jig pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir na/ de ltar 'dus byas chos de dag / rgyu dang bcas par 'byung ba ste/ / skyes pa 'jig pa gang yin pa/ / 'di ni chos rnams rang bzhin no/ / zhes gsungs pa 'di yang legs par drangs par 'gyur ro zhes bshad de dus gnyis par zhig pa dus snga mar skyes pa'i 'bras bur sgrub pa'i khungs so/ //

If the birth of a sentient being came later, and its aging and death came first, then without birth having come first, without a cause, [239] how could its aging and death occur? They could not, because it is said that “conditioned by birth there is aging and death.” As it is said, When a clod is lifted, There is a cause of its lifting. Apart from the cause of lifting, There is no other cause of its falling. [Prasannapadā 76b] As this says, the lifting itself is the cause of the falling, and there is no other cause; similarly arising itself is the cause of cessation, and there is no other. Thus, there is no causeless cessation. Since cessation has arising as a cause, and since coming into existence is the cause of cessation, Thus these produced phenomena Come into existence through having causes. Being that which arises and ceases Is the essence of a phenomenon. [Prasannapadā 77a]/4/ This is a felicitous quotation. It is a scriptural source establishing that disintegration at the second moment is the effect of arising at the previous moment.
gnyis pa [dus mnyam pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.2 Refutation of simultaneity
skye ba dang ni rga shi dag / lhan cig rung ba ma yin te/ / skye bzhin pa ni 'chi 'gyur zhing / / gnyi ga rgyu med can du 'gyur/ /
5. For birth, aging, and death To be simultaneous makes no sense. That which is being born would be dying, And both would be without a cause.

skye ba dang ni rga shi dag lhan cig tu ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa yang rung ba ma yin te/ de rung na ni skye bzhin pa na 'chi 'gyur te 'gag bzhin par 'gyur na de yang mi rigs te/ snang mun ltar phan tshun 'gal ba'i phyir dang skye bzhin pa nyid 'chi bzhin pa'o zhes 'jig rten na yang ma mthong ngo / / spyir skye 'gag gi bya ba yang mi 'gal la skye 'gag gnyis kyang mi 'gal yang skye bzhin pa dang 'gag bzhin pa gnyis dus gcig pa ni gzhi gcig la 'gal bar kun la grags so/ // de la skye 'gag rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub na sngar bshad pa ltar skye bzhin pa'i dus su skye rgyu de yod dgos so/ / de lta na da lta bar 'gyur bas 'gag bzhin par yang 'gyur la de'i tshe skye bzhin pa 'phel bar 'gyur ba dang 'gag bzhin pa zad par 'gyur ba gnyis 'gal lo/ / skye ba dang 'chi ba gnyis ka rgyu med pa can du'ang 'gyur te dus mnyam pa gnyis gcig gcig shos kyi rgyur mi 'thad la/ skye ba'i sngon du 'chi ba ma song ba dang 'chi ba'i sngon du yang skye ba ma song ba'i phyir ro/ /

It also makes no sense for birth, aging, and death to exist inherently simultaneously, because if that were possible, then when something is being born it would be dying—that is, ceasing. This makes no sense, because they are mutually exclusive, like light and dark, and the dying of that which is being born is not seen in the ordinary world. In general, the activities of arising and ceasing are not mutually exclusive, nor are the two—arising and ceasing—inconsistent. It is well known to all that it is contradictory for that which is arising and that which is ceasing to be present at the same time in the same basis. So, if arising and ceasing each existed through their own characteristic, then, as has been previously explained, at the time of the arising, that which is to be arisen would have to exist. In that case, since that which is now existent would also be ceasing, at that time there would be both that which is arising—that is, that which is progressing—and that which is ceasing (that is, that which is being exhausted), which are mutually exclusive. Birth and death would both be causeless as well, because it is not tenable for one of two simultaneous things to be the cause of the other [240] and because neither would death precede birth nor would birth precede death.
gsum pa [don bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.2.3 Drawing conclusions

gal te skye ba la sogs pa la snga phyi dang lhan cig gi rim pa yod kyang rung med kyang rung ste re zhig skye ba dang rga shi ni yod do/ / de dag kyang gzhi med par mi 'thad pas 'ga' zhig gi yin la de yang bdag yin no snyam na/

Suppose someone thought as follows: Whether or not the framework of sequence and simultaneity apply to such things as birth, birth, aging, and death exist. It would not be possible for them to be without a basis; so there must be a basis, and that must be the self.
gang la snga phyi lhan cig gi / rim pa de dag mi srid pa'i/ / skye ba de dang rga shi de/ / ci yi phyir na spros par byed/ /
6. Since the framework of sequence and simultaneity Does not make sense for Birth, aging, and death, Why do you fabricate them?

de ltar rigs pa sngon du btang ste brtags na skye ba dang rga shi gang la snga ba dang phyi ba dang lhan cig gi rim pa de dag mi srid pa de la khyed skye ba ni de dang rga shi ni de'o zhes ci yi phyir na spro ba ste rjod par byed/ yang na de dag ma dmigs pa na 'phags pa rnams ci'i phyir na spro bar byed de spro bar mi mdzad de yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin gzigs pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te skye ba dang rga shi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na snga phyi gnyis dang lhan cig gang rung du 'gyur na snga phyi dang lhan cig gi rim pa gang yang mi 'thad pa'i phyir skye ba dang rga shi ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / de med na skye ba dang rga shi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas skye shi'i bya ba byed mkhan gyi bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes pa de thongs shig /

With the previous arguments in hand, consider the following analysis: Since it is impossible to apply the framework of sequence and simultaneity to birth, aging, and death, why are you fabricating—that is, asserting—that this is birth and those are aging and death? One could also read it this way: So, if they do not objectify them, why do the aryas fabricate them? They do not! Because they see thing just as they are. If birth, aging, and death existed inherently, they would have to be either sequential or simultaneous. But since the framework of sequence and simultaneity is not tenable here, birth, aging, and death do not exist inherently. Since they do not exist, give up your assertion that because birth, aging, and death exist inherently, the self that is the agent of birth and death exists inherently.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba] ni/
1.2 Application of the argument to other phenomena

'khor ba 'ba' zhig sngon gyi mtha'/ / yod ma yin par ma zad kyi/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu nyid dang ni/ / mtshan nyid dang ni mtshan gzhi nyid/ / tshor dang tshor ba nyid dang ni/ / don yod gang dag ci yang rung / / dngos rnams thams cad nyid la yang / / sngon gyi mtha' ni yod ma yin/ /

7. Not only is cyclic existence Without a prior limit—/5/ Neither cause and effect; Nor characteristic and characterized. 8. Nor feeling and the feeler; Whatever there is— All entities Are without a prior limit.

'khor ba ste sems can 'ba' zhig gi skye ba dang rga shi la sngon gyi mtha' ste snga ba dang phyi ba dang lhan cig gi rim pa yod pa ma yinapar ma zad kyi/ rgyu dang 'bras bu dang mtshan nyid dang mtshan gzhi dang tshor ba dang tshor ba po la yang sngon gyi mtha' dang des mtshon nas phyi ba dang lhan cig gi rim pa ni yod pa ma yin par rig par bya'o//de yang rgyu snga bar ngo bo nyid kyis yod na 'bras bu yang de'i dus na yod dgos pa las med pa'i phyir rgyu med par 'gyur la/ 'bras bu snga na yang rgyu med du 'gyur ro/ / rgyu 'bras gnyis gcig car du yod na gnyis ka yang rgyu med par 'gyur te sngar bshad pa ltar ro/ / mtshan nyid snga na ni mtshon rgyu med la mtshan gzhi snga na ni mtshan nyid med par 'gyur ro/ / mtshan mtshon gnyis dus gcig tu ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni phan tshun du mi ltos par grub par 'gyur ro// // tshor ba po snga na ni gang gi tshor ba por 'gyur/ tshor ba snga na yang tshor mkhan med par tshor ba mi rigs so/ / gnyis ka dus mnyam na ni phan tshun mi ltos par grub pa dang rgyu med du 'gyur ro/ / 'khor ba'i bshad pas rgyu 'bras la sogs pa rig par bya bar ma zad don yod pa'i dngos po gzhan gang dag ci yang rung ba tshad ma dang gzhal bya dang / shes pa dang shes bya dang bsgrub bya dang sgrub byed dang / yan lag dang yan lag can la sogs pa thams cad la yang sngon gyi mtha' la sogs pa gsum yod pa ma yin no zhes sbyar bar bya'o/ /

Not only does the birth, aging, and death of cyclic existence (sentient beings) have no beginning—that is, what is prior—nor anything posterior or simultaneous, but cause and effect, characteristic and characterized, and feeler and feeling as well have no beginning. These indicate how one should understand that the framework of posteriority and simultaneity does not apply to them, either. And so, if the cause inherently existed prior to it, then the effect would also be present at that time. But since it is not, it would follow from that assumption that they are causeless. And if the effect were prior, it would also be causeless. If the cause and effect were simultaneous, they would both be causeless, as was previously explained. If the characteristic were prior, [241] there would be nothing to be characterized; if the characterized were prior, it would be without characteristics. If the characteristic and characterized existed inherently simultaneously, they would exist without mutual dependence. If the feeler were prior, then of what would it be the feeler? If the feeling existed first, it would make no sense to call it a feeling without a feeler. If the two existed at the same time, then they would fail to be mutually dependent, and both would be without a cause. Through this explanation of cyclic existence one should understand that not only such things as cause and effect are without these three—beginning and the others—but so are all other entities (“whatever there is”) including such things as cognition and cognized, knower and known, conclusion and premise, and part and whole.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar skye rga dang rgyu 'bras la sogs pa ngo bo nyid kyis med pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang bsgrub pa dang / chos rnams la sngon dang phyi ma'i mthar mi sbyor ba dang 'chi 'pho ba dang skye ba med pa dang 'khor ba mi dmigs pa la sogs par ston pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya bar bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to demonstrate that the fact that birth and aging and cause and effect do not exist inherently can also be established by profound scriptures, and to demonstrate that all of the scriptures that show that all phenomena are beginningless and endless, that they are deathless and birthless, and that cyclic existence should not be objectified are explained by this chapter.

dkon mchog sprin las/ chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba na/ / gzod nas zhi zhing ma skyes pa/ / rang bzhin mya ngan 'das pa yi/ / chos rnams mgon po khyod kyis bstan/ / zhes pa dang de bzhin du/ gzod ma nas ni stong zhing ma 'ongs chos/ / song ba med cing gnas med gnas kyis dben/ / sgyu ma'i rang bzhin rtag tu snying po med/ / thams cad dag cing rnam dag nam mkha' bzhin/ / rgyal ba'i chos ni gang dag rab ston pa/ / de yang mi zad pas na mi mthong ste/ / chos 'di snga nas bdag med sems can med/ / de dag rab tu ston kyang zad mi 'gyur/ / btags pa tsam du brtags nas bstan pa yin/ / 'khor ba la ni tha ma mi rnyed de/ / gang dag sngon byung mtha' ni mtshan nyid med/ / ma 'ongs dus kyang shes par bya ba'i phyir/ / las dang bya ba de ltar zhugs 'gyur te/ / rab dang tha ma dag tu'ang 'byung bar 'gyur/ / chos rnams rtag tu blun zhing rang bzhin stong*/ / thams cad bdag med par yang shes par gyis/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The Ratnamegha-sūtra says, When you turned the wheel of Dharma You, the protector, taught that All phenomena are primordially peaceful and unarisen And are essentially free.
