[m Do sde Wa 9a] And similarly the Samādhirāja-sūtra says, Primordially empty, not coming, Not gone, not enduring and without abode, Having an illusory nature, and always without a core, All things are as pure as the sky. [m Do sde Da 146b] … The dharma that the Victor has taught Is not perceived by those who have not exhausted the obscurations. The dharma that things are primordially selfless and that there are no sentient beings, Although it is completely taught, is never exhausted. [m Do sde Da 147a] [242] … Shown by imputation that it is merely imputed, The terminus of cyclic existence is not found. That which is a prior limit is without characteristic. Therefore in order to understand in the future One engages in such activities and with such objects, And becomes either of high or low status. All phenomenally are eternally and essentially empty./6/ It should be known that all phenomena are selfless. [m Do sde Da 147b]

de la gzod ma dang gdod ma ni dang po'i sgra'o/ / zhi ba ni chos rnams ye shes zhi ba'i yul te/ ma skyes pa'i phyir te rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong pa'i phyir ro/ / de nas bzhis dus gsum gdod nas stong pa sgyu ma dang nam mkha' dang 'dra ba dang / de nas lngas chos rnams gdod ma nas gang zag gi bdag gis stong zhing rgyal bas chos bstan pa yang btags pa tsam du bstan pa de nas lngas chos rnams la sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' med pa dang ma dang / 'ongs pa'i dus su yang de ltar rtogs pa'i phyir du da ltar bya ba la zhugs pas/ ma 'ongs pa na rab dang tha ma'i 'bras bu skal ba dang 'tsham par thob par 'gyur ba dang / de nas gnyis kyis chos rnams shes pa po'i ngo bo bdag gis stong pa'i bdag med kyi don shes par gyis zhes bstan to/ /

Here “primordially” means originally. “Peaceful” denotes the object of peaceful wisdom. It is not arisen because it is essentially free, that is, it is inherently empty. The next four lines present the three temporal periods as primordially empty, as illusory and as sky-like. The next five lines present phenomena as primordially empty of the self of the person, and show that the dharma taught by the Victor, as well, is merely imputed. The next five lines present all phenomena as beginningless and endless, and say that in order to realize those in the future, one must engage in action in the present. In the future, one will thus achieve higher or lower fruits according one’s abilities. The last two lines say that one should know that the meaning of “selflessness” is emptiness of the self, which is the nature of the knower.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

'khor ba po'i gang zag dang de 'khor ba'i bya ba skye ba dang rga shi dang rgyu 'bras la sogs pa rnams rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na skye ba sogs gang gi yang tha snyad byar med pas/ 'khor mkhan dang des skye 'chi brgyud mar byed par gsungs pa ni tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la 'thad do snyam du nges par bya'o/ /

If the transmigrating person and the activity of transmigration—birth, aging, and death—and all things such as cause and effect, existed inherently, there would be no way to call them “birth,” etc. Therefore, it should be ascertained that the statement that the transmigrator is born and dies continuously is only tenable when taken as merely posited through convention.
sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' brtag ba zhes bya ba rab tu byed pa ste bcu gcig pa'o// //
This is the eleventh chapter “the examination of the beginning and end.”
sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa brgyad kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu gcig pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the eleventh chapter, having eight verses called “the examination of the beginning and end.”
CHAPTER XII. Examination of Suffering
gnyis pa rten pa sdug bsngal yod pa'i rtags dgag pa
This chapter is the second of these two parts: the refutation of the argument that that dependent on the self—suffering—exists.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ //
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ bdag ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de dang 'brel ba can gyi sdug bsngal yod pa'i phyir ro/ / lung las nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga la sdug bsngal zhes gsungs pas de yang yod la sdug bsngal de yang rten med par ni med pas rten yod la de yang bdag yin no/ / 'di dgag pa la gnyis/ sdug bsngal ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag / rigs pa de chos gzhan la'ang sbyar ba'o/ /

Here one might say, “The self exists essentially because the suffering with which it is associated exists. According to sūtra, the appropriator’s five aggregates are suffering. Therefore, they exist. Suffering cannot exist without a basis; therefore it must have a basis, and that is the self.” The refutation of this has two parts: the refutation of the inherent existence of suffering and the application of this argument to other phenomena.
dang po [sdug bsngal ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the inherent existence of suffering
['di] la gnyis/ dam bca' bzhag / sgrub byed bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the assertion of the thesis and the presentation of the argument.
dang po [dam bca' bzhag] ni/
1.1.1 Assertion of the thesis
kha cig sdug bsngal bdag gis byas/ / gzhan gyis byas dang gnyi gas byas/ / rgyu med pa las byung bar 'dod/ / de ni bya bar mi rung ngo/ /
1. Some maintain that suffering is self-created. Some maintain that it is created by another; others that it is created by both, Or that it arises without a cause. Such creation is impossible.

de la rgol ba kha cig gis ni sdug bsngal bdag gis byas pa dang kha cig gis ni sdug bsngal rang las don gzhan gyis byas pa dang / zhan dag gis ni rang gzhan gnyis kas byas pa dang 'ga' zhig gis ni sdug bsngal rgyu med pa las 'byung bar 'dod pa'i sdug bsngal de ni rnam pa thams cad du rang bzhin gyis bskyed par bya bar mi rung ngo zhes dam bca' ba bzhag pa'o/ / sdug bsngal sdug bsngal gyi rang pazhin du gyur pas skyed par ni grangs can 'dod la sdug bsngal gang zag gi bdag gis byas par ni bye brag pa la sogs pas 'dod do/ / sdug bsngal rang gi skyed byed dang rang gi mtshan nyid kyis tha dad par ni rang gi sde pa dang gzhan gyis kyang 'dod do/ / gnyis kas byas pa ni gcer bur rgyu bas lus kyis byas pa ni lus sdug bsngal yin pas rang gis byas pa dang srog gis byas pa ni sdug bsngal las gzhan yin pas gzhan gyis byas par smra ba sogs so/ / rgyu med par 'byung bar ni rgyang pan pa rnams 'dod do/ /

Some of our opponents say that suffering is created by itself, some say that something other than it created suffering, some others say that both it and something else created the suffering, whereas some say that suffering occurs without a cause. However, we assert the following thesis: It cannot be the case that the suffering that is to arise essentially is created in any sense. The Sāṁkhya maintain that suffering arises from that which has the essence of suffering. The Vaiśeṣikas and others maintain that suffering is created by the personal self. Others, including other Buddhist schools, maintain that suffering and that which gives rise to it are different through their own characteristics. Creation by both is maintained by the naked Jains: They say that since it is created by the body, the suffering of the body is self-created; and since it is created by life, which is different, suffering is created by another. The Cārvākas say that it is causeless.
gnyis pa [sgrub byed bstan pa]
1.1.2 Presentation of the argument
['di] la gnyis/ sdug bsngal rang gzhan re re bas byas pa dgag / gnyis ka tshogs pas byas pa dang rgyu med du smra ba dgag pa'o/ /

This part has two sections: the refutation of the creation of suffering by each of self and other; [244] and the refutation of the creation of suffering by both self and other together and of the assertion that it is without a cause.
dang po [sdug bsngal rang gzhan re re bas byas pa dgag]
1.1.2.1 Refutation of the creation of suffering by each of self and other
['di] la gsum/ sdug bsngal la ltos te rang gzhan re re bas byas pa dgag / gang zag la ltos te re re bas byas pa dgag / rang gzhan re re bas ma byas pa'i sgrub byed gzhan bstan pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of creation by each of self and other with respect to suffering, refutation of the creation by each of self and other with respect to the person, and the presentation of other arguments showing that it is not created by each of self and others.
dang po [sdug bsngal la ltos te rang gzhan re re bas byas pa dgag]
1.1.2.1.1 Refutation of creation by each of self and other with respect to suffering
['di] la gnyis/ sdug bsngal la ltos te rang gis byas pa dgag / sdug bsngal la ltos te gzhan gyis byas pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of self-creation with respect to suffering and the refutation of the creation by another with respect to suffering.
dang po [sdug bsngal la ltos te rang gis byas pa dgag] ni/
1.1.2.1.1.1 Refutation of self-creation with respect to suffering
gal te bdag gis byas gyur na/ / de phyir brten nas 'byung mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir phung po 'di dag la/ / brten nas phung po de dag 'byung / /
2. If suffering was created by itself, Then it would not arise dependently. For those aggregates Arise in dependence on these aggregates.

gal te sdug bsngal te bdag rang gis byas par gyur na ni sdug bsngal gyi ngo bo nyid kyis de nyid byed par 'gyur ro/ / de'i phyir rgyu rkyen la brten nas 'byung bar mi 'gyur te rang yod na rang gis skyed mi dgos la rang med na skyed byed du mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / rten 'brel ni yin te gang gi phyir 'chi ba'i dus kyi phung po 'di dag la brten nas skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i phung po de dag 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ / des na sdug bsngal bdag gis byas par mi rigs so/ /

If suffering created itself, then suffering would create itself inherently. Therefore it would not depend on causes and conditions because when it already exists, there is no need for it to give rise to itself. And if it does not exist, it cannot give rise to itself. It is dependently arisen because the aggregates associated at the time of birth arise depending on the aggregates at the time of death. Thus, suffering created by itself makes no sense.
gnyis pa [sdug bsngal la ltos te gzhan gyis byas pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.1.1.2 Refutation of the creation by another with respect to suffering
gal te 'di las de gzhan zhing / / gal te de las 'di gzhan na/ / sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas 'gyur zhing / / gzhan de dag gis de byas 'gyur/ /
3. If those were different from these, Or if these were different from those, Suffering could be created by another. These would be created by those others.

gal te 'chi ba'i dus kyi phung po 'di dag las skye ba'i cha'i phung po de dag ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan yin zhing / gal te skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i phung po de dag las kyang 'chi ba'i dus kyi phung po 'di ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan yin na ni/ da ltar gyi phung po gzhan de dag gis ma 'ongs pa'i phung po de byas par 'gyur bas sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas par 'gyur ba zhig na de ni mi 'thad de/ ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod na/ rgyu 'bras kyi 'brel ba mi gnas pa'i phyir dang / gang la brten te gang 'byung ba/ / zhes sogs 'chad par 'gyur ba ltar ro/ //

If these aggregates at the time of death were inherently different from those aggregates associated with birth, and if the aggregates that are associated with birth were inherently different from the aggregates at the time of death, then in that case the present aggregates, which are different, would create the future aggregates. Therefore, the suffering would be created by another; this is not tenable, because if they were inherently different, there would be no causal relation between them as will be explained later in “Whatever comes into being dependent on another …” [XVIII: 10].
rkang pa phyi ma gnyis ni bud d+ha pA li ta dang shes rab sgron mar/ gzhan de dag gis 'di byas pas/ / sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas par 'gyur/ / zhes bsgyur ba ltar bde'o/ /
The two last lines are translated more felicitously in the Buddhapālita [214b] and in Prajñāpradīpa [44b] as Since it is created by something other than itself, Suffering is created by another./1/
gnyis pa [gang zag la ltos te re re bas byas pa dgag]
1.1.2.1.2 Refutation of creation by each of self and other with respect to the person
['di] la gnyis/ gang zag rang gis byas pa dgag / gang zag gzhan gyis byas pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of creation by the person himself [245] and refutation of creation by someone other than the person himself.
dang po [gang zag rang gis byas pa dgag] ni/
1.1.2.1.2.1 Refutation of creation by the person himself

gal te sdug bsngal nyid kyis sdug bsngal byas pa la sdug bsngal bdag gis byas par mi smra'i gang zag rang gis rang gi sdug bsngal de byas pa yin gyi/ gang zag gzhan gyis byas nas 'di la byin pa ni ma yin pas sdug bsngal bdag gis byas par smra'o zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: The suffering created by suffering itself is not said to be suffering created by self, but instead the person himself creates his own suffering. Having been created by another person it would not come to fruition in this person, and so suffering is said to be created by oneself.
gal te gang zag bdag gis ni/ / sdug bsngal byas na gang bdag gis/ / sdug bsngal byas pa'i gang zag de/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs gang zhig yin/ /
4. If suffering were caused by a person himself, Then who is that self who created the suffering— That person— Apart from suffering?

gal te mi'i gang zag bdag gis ni mi'i gang zag der 'dogs pa'i sdug bsngal de byas na ni sdug bsngal de byas pa'i gang zag de byas pa'i sdug bsngal las ma gtogs pa gang zhig yin te/ sdug bsngal de ni 'di yin la sdug bsngal de byed pa po ni 'di yin no zhes so sor phye ste 'dis 'di byas zhes brjod dgos na de ltar brjod du yang med do/ / ci ste yang mi'i sdug bsngal gyi nye bar len pa can gyi gang zag gis lha'i sdug bsngal byas par rtog na gang zag de bdag gis bdag gi sdug bsngal de byas pa min gyi gzhan gyi sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste gang zag de gnyis nye bar len pa phung po tha dad kyang gang zag tha mi dad do zhe na/ de yang mi rigs te nye bar len pa las don gzhan du gang zag bstan par mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the human self/2/ of this man creates the suffering on the basis of which the human self is imputed, then who could that person be who has created that suffering apart from the suffering created? For it would be necessary to be able to distinguish between them by saying “this is the suffering” and “this is the agent of the suffering.” However, this is not possible. Suppose one thought that the person who is the appropriator of a man’s suffering created the suffering of a god. Though that person would not create his own suffering, that would be the creation of the suffering of another. Suppose he argues that although the aggregates to be appropriated by the two persons are different, the persons are not different. This would not make any sense either, because the person cannot be demonstrated to be a different object from that which is to be appropriated.
gnyis pa [gang zag gzhan gyis byas pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.1.2.2 Refutation of creation by someone other than the person himself

gal te mi'i gang zag gis mi'i sdug bsngal mi byed kyi des lhar skye ba'i lha'i sdug bsngal byas nas lha'i gang zag la ster zhing lha'i sdug bsngal des kyang lha'i gang zag tu tha snyad 'dogs par byed do zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: The human person does not create the man’s suffering, but creates a god’s suffering in order to be born as a god and it comes to fruition in the divine person. In virtue of that suffering, he is designated as the divine person.
gal te gang zag gzhan las ni/ / sdug bsngal 'byung na gzhan zhig gis/ / sdug bsngal de byas gang sbyin de/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs ci ltar rung / /
5. If suffering arose from another person, Then that other one would create the suffering. What could that which comes to fruition be Apart from the suffering?

gal te mi'i gang zag lha las gzhan pa de las ni lha'i sdug bsngal 'byung na/ gzhan mi'i gang zag gcig gis sdug bsngal de byas nas gang la sbyin pa'i lha'i gang zag de/ sbyin bya'i sdug bsngal de las ma gtogs pa gzhan zhig ji ltar yod par rung ste de med do/ /

Suppose the suffering of the god arose from the human person who is other than the god. Then, though the self of the human person, who is other, creates this suffering, the fruition of the suffering occurs in the divine person. How could there be something else, apart from the suffering, that is to come to fruition? There could not be!
gal te gang zag gzhan sdug bsngal/ / 'byung na gang gis de byas nas/ / gzhan la ster ba'i gang zag gzhan/ / sdug bsngal ma gtogs gang zhig yin/ /
6. If another person gave rise to suffering, Who would that other person be Who created it and gave that suffering, Other than suffering?

gal te mi'i gang zag gzhan las lha'i sdug bsngal de 'byung na/ gang gis lha'i sdug bsngal de byas nas gzhan lha la ster ba'i gang zag gzhan nye bar len pa'i sdug bsngal gang gis mi'i gang zag tu 'dogs pa de ni/ rang gi nye bar len pa'i sdug bsngal de las ma gtogs pa gang yin te med do/ / gang la ster ba dang gang gis ster ba po ngo bo nyid kyis yod na rang gi nye bar len pa'i sdug bsngal las ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad par rnyed dgos na de ni mi rnyed do/ / ster ba po'i gang zag 'gog pa'i tshigs bcad ni bud d+ha pA li ta dang shes rab sgron mar ma byung yang tshig gsal las gnyis ka la bshad pa so sor mdzad do//

If the human person who is other gave rise to the suffering of the god [246], then that which created the suffering of the god—that person who is other than the god, who gave the suffering to the god, who is the appropriator of the suffering, in virtue of which he is called a human—a person—is nothing other than the appropriator of its own suffering. If that to whom it is given and that by whom it is given existed inherently, it would have be found that someone was inherently different from his own appropriated suffering, but this is not found. The verse that refutes the personal self of the giver is not commented on in the Buddhapālita or Prajñāpradīpa, but Prasannapadā comments on both [79a].
bdag gis byas par ma grub pas/ / sdug bsngal gzhan gyis ga la byas/ / gzhan gyis sdug bsngal gang byas pa/ / de ni de yi bdag byas 'gyur/ /
7. When it does not exist as self-created, How could suffering be created by another? Any suffering created by another Must have been self-created.

gzhan yang gal te sdug bsngal gang zag bdag gis byas pa de ngo bo nyid kyis grub na sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis 'grub na/sdug bsngal bdag gis byas pa ni ngo bo nyid kyis yod par ma grub par sngar bshad pas sdug bsngal de dag gzhan gyis ga la byas te byas par mi 'grub bo/ / de'i rgyu mtshan ni gzhan gyis sdug bsngal gang byed pa de ni gzhan mi de'i bdag gis byas pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste mi des sdug bsngal de bdag gis byas pa min na lha'i sdug bsngal de gzhan gyis byas par ji ltar 'gyur zhes/ bud d+ha pA li ta las bshad de tshig gsal dang don 'dra'o/ /

Moreover, if the suffering created by a person himself existed inherently, then the suffering created by others should also exist inherently. Hence, since, as has been already explained, self-created suffering does not exist inherently, how could that suffering be created by another? It could not be. The reason is that the creation of suffering by another is creation by that other man himself. If this man himself did not create the suffering, then how could you say that that god’s suffering was created by another? Buddhapālita explains it this way [215b] and Prasannapadā explains it similarly [79ab].
gsum pa [rang gzhan re re bas ma byas pa'i sgrub byed gzhan bstan pa] ni/
1.1.2.1.3 Presentation of other arguments showing that it is not created by each of self and others
re zhig sdug bsngal bdag byas min/ / de nyid kyis ni de ma byas/ / gal te gzhan bdag ma byas na/ / sdug bsngal gzhan byas ga la 'gyur/ /
8. No suffering is self-created. Nothing creates itself. If another is not self-created, How could suffering be created by another?

re zhig sdug bsngal bdag gis byas pa ni min te sdug bsngal de nyid kyis ni de nyid ma byas pa'i phyir te rang la byed pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / gal te sdug bsngal de ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa'i gzhan gyis byas par smra na'ang der ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ 'dis byed do zhes brtag pa'i gzhan de bdag ma byas pa ste rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub pas rgyu gzhan la ltos pa'i phyir ro/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las sdug bsngal de gang zag rang gis byas la gang zag kyang sdug bsngal las gzhan min pa la bsams nas sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal byas so/ / zhes smra la/ gang zag des sdug bsngal de byas shing de sdug bsngal ma yin pa la bsams nas sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas so zhes kyang smra ba la/ rkang pa dang pos nye bar len pa med pa'i gang zag 'ba' zhig pa med pas sdug bsngal gang zag rang gis byas pa 'gog go / rkang pa gnyis pas sdug bsngal de nyid kyis de nyid byas pa la phyi ma gnyis kyis sdug bsngal las ma gtogs pa'i bdag med pas sdug bsngal gzhan gyis byas pa 'gog go /

There is no suffering that is self-created, because that suffering does not create itself. This is because that would entail the inconsistency of reflexive action. Suppose one asserted that this suffering is created by an inherently existent other. How could this be? It cannot, because when you say “This creates,” since that supposed other “is not self-created”—it does not exist inherently—it must depend on another cause. Buddhapālita says that suffering is created by the person himself, [247] and thinking that the person is not other than suffering, it is said that suffering is created by suffering. It is also said that that this suffering is created by another, thinking that this person creates suffering and it is not suffering [216a]. On this reading, the first line refutes the creation of suffering by the person himself on the grounds that apart from the appropriation there is no independent person. The second line, on this reading, refutes the creation of suffering by itself; the next two lines refute the creation of suffering by another on the grounds that there is no self apart from suffering.
gnyis pa [gnyis ka tshogs pas byas pa dang rgyu med du smra ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2 Refutation of the creation of suffering by both self and other together and of the assertion that it is without a cause
gal te sdug bsngal so so ba re res byas pa med kyang gnyis ka tshogs pas byas pa ni yod dod snyam na/
Suppose one thought that although this suffering is not created by one of these individually it is created by both of them together.
gal te re re byas gyur na/ / sdug bsngal gnyi gas byas par 'gyur/ / gzhan gyis ma byas bdag ma byas/ / sdug bsngal rgyu med ga la 'gyur/ /
9. If suffering were created by each, Suffering could be created by both. Not created by self or by other, How could uncaused suffering occur?

'khor lo la sogs pa re re ba la shing rta gzhag tu med kyang yan lag tshogs pa la brten nas shing rtar 'jog pa lta bu yin na de skad smra bar rigs kyang / 'di ni srog gcod pa re re nas ma byas na 'di gnyis kas srog gcod byas so zhes 'jog mi nus pa bzhin du yin no/ / des na gal te rang gzhan re res sdug bsngal byas par gyur na sdug bsngal de gnyis ka tshogs pas byas par 'gyur na yang re res byed pa ni min te sngar bkag zin pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad bshad pa'i tshul gyis sdug bsngal de bdag gis ma byas shing gzhan gyis kyang ma byas na/ sdug bsngal rgyu med du 'byung bar ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ nam mkha'i me tog gi dri zhim po bzhin no/ / de ltar sdug bsngal ngo bo nyid kyis med pa'i phyir de'i rten gyi bdag kyang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin no/ /

Although the chariot cannot be posited only on the basis of such things as each individual wheel, the chariot can be posited depending on a complete assembly of the parts. If the case were like this, that thought would make sense. Instead it is like this: If each of them were innocent of the killing, then it cannot be said they both are guilty of the killing. If the suffering were created by each of self and other individually, then the suffering would be created by both of them together. But it is not caused by each, because this has already been refuted before. As it has been explained, suffering is neither created by itself nor by another, and how could it arise causelessly? It cannot, just like the beautiful fragrance of the sky flower. Thus suffering does not exist inherently; nor does its basis, the self, exist inherently.
gnyis pa [rigs pa de chos gzhan la'ang sbyar ba] ni/
1.2 Application of the argument to other phenomena
sdug bsngal 'ba' zhig rnam pa bzhi/ / yod ma yin pa ma zad kyi/ / phyi rol dngos po rnams la yang / / rnam pa bzhi po yod ma yin/ /
10. Not only does suffering not exist In any of the fourfold ways: No external entity exists In any of the fourfold ways.

de ltar nang sems can gyi sdug bsngal 'ba' zhig la bdag gis byas pa la sogs pa rnam pa bzhi yod pa ma yin par ma zad kyi/ phyi rol gyi dngos po sa myug dang bum snam la sogs pa thams cad dag la yang bdag gis byas pa sogs rnam pa bzhi po yod pa ma yin pa sngar bshad pa bzhin du rig par bya'o/ / gal te phyi nang gi dngos po 'di dag la bdag gis byas pa sogs bzhi po med na 'di dag yod ni dgos pas rnam pa gang gis 'grub ce na/ de la 'di dag ngo bo nyid kyis yod med 'tshol ba'i dbang du byed na ni/ sdug bsngal la sogs pa 'di rnams rang bzhin gyis yod na bdag gis byas pa sogs rnam pa bzhi po po gang rung gcig tu grub dgos pa la/ de ni sngar bshad pa ltar med pas sdug bsngal la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin par nges te khyab byed mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ / 'on te phyin ci log tsam gyis bdag nyid yod paRa rnyed pa sdug bsngal la sogs pa kun rdzob pa rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i rnam gzhag 'tshol na ni/ bdag gis byed pa la sogs pa bzhi po dor nas rab byed brgyad par bshad pa'i rnam pas rkyen nyid 'di pa tsam gyi rten 'byung grub pas yod par khas blang bar bya ste/ sdug bsngal bdag gis byas pa dang / / gzhan gyis byas dang gnyis kas byas/ / rgyu med par ni rtog ge 'dod/ / khyod kyis brten nas 'byung bar gsungs/ / zhes bshad pa ltar ro/ /

It should be understood, as explained earlier, that not only does the suffering of the inner world—that of sentient beings—fail to exist in any of the fourfold ways, such as being self-created, but external phenomena such as the seed, the sprout, the pot, and the cloth, fail to exist in any of the fourfold ways, such as being self-created. [248] Although these inner and outer entities fail to exist in any of the fourfold ways, such as being self-created, they still must exist. In what way do they exist? If this is considered in terms of an examination into whether or not they exist inherently, then, if such things as suffering existed essentially, they would have to exist in one of the fourfold ways. But, as was explained earlier, that is not the case. Therefore, it is ascertained that such things as suffering do not exist essentially, because the relevant superordinate category is incoherent./3/ On the other hand, suppose one searches the framework of dependent arising for the self that is found merely by adhering to an erroneous position, and for such things as conventional suffering. If one does so, abandoning the four extremes such as self-creation, one should, as the eighth chapter has explained, accept that they exist in virtue of being merely conditioned, dependently arisen phenomena. As it is said, Sophists maintain that suffering is Self-created, created by others, Created by both and without a cause. But you taught them to be dependently arisen. [Lokādtītastava 21]

bud d+ha pA li ta las kyang*/ gal te sdug bsngal med na ston pas 'od srungs sdug bsngal yod de ngas sdug bsngal shes so mthong ngo zhes gsungs pa ji lta bu zhe na/ sdug bsngal med do zhes de skad su zer/ / kho bos de phyir brten nas 'byung mi 'gyur//zhes ma smras sam de'i phyir kho bo ni sdug bsngal rten 'byung yin par smra'i bdag gis byas pa sogs su mi smra'o zhes bshad do/ /

Buddhapālita raises the question, “If there is no suffering, what would the teacher mean by saying, ‘Oh Kāśyapa, there is suffering. I have seen it and understood it’?” [Saṁyuttanikaya, Nidāna Vagga, Acelakassapasutta, Vol. II, 414] He continues, “who would say, ‘There is no suffering’? He replies, “Have we not said, ‘It would not arise dependently’? [XII: 2b] Therefore we say that suffering is dependently arisen. But we do not say that it is self-created, etc.” [216b–217a]

des na bdag gis byas pa rten 'byung yin pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis dngos su bkag cing gzhan gyis byas pa yang de nyid kyis 'gog par 'grel pa gnyis char gyis bshad cing de'i phyir gnyis kas byas pa yang des 'gog go / rgyu med du 'byung ba ni rgyu mtshan des 'gog pa shin tu gsal bas rten 'brel rgyu 'bras kyi rim pa gdon mi za bar khas blang dgos pa nyid kyis/ // ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag nas rang bzhin med pa nyid la bya byed thams cad 'thad par ston pa 'di mgo mjug thams cad du shes par byed pa shin tu gal che ste/

Both commentaries therefore say that this is a direct refutation of self-creation on grounds of dependent origination, and that this also refutes creation by another. Therefore, creation by both [249] is also thereby refuted. It is clear that arising causelessly is also refuted by this argument. Thus the necessity of accepting, without any doubt, the framework of dependent arising and cause and effect shows, through refuting inherent existence, that everything, such as action and agent, only makes sense from the standpoint of essencelessness. It is extremely important to understand this demonstration in all contexts from the beginning to the end of the text.

rgyu 'bras rten 'brel gyi rim pa de kho nar grub ma grub dpyod pa'i rigs pas bkag par 'dzin na/ rgyu 'bras Rang lugs la khas blangs med pas de la ni phra ba'i bdag med mi ston par rags pa'i bdag med bstan nas bkri dgos par gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

If one held that the framework of dependent arising and cause and effect is refuted by rational analysis regarding whether or not things exist in reality, then one would not accept cause and effect in one’s own system. It is said that such a person should not be taught subtle selflessness right away but should be led to it by teaching coarse selflessness first.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar chos rnams rang dang gzhan dang gnyis kas byas pa dang rgyu med bkag pa de zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub par bstan pa dang / de ltar ston pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ ting nge 'dzin rgyal po las/ kun rdzob tu ni rgyal bas chos bshad de/ / 'dus byas 'dus ma byas yin de ltar ltos/ / yang dag nyid du bdag dang mi med de/ / 'gro ba kun gyi mtshan nyid 'di 'dra'o/ / dge dang nag po'i las rnams mi 'jig ste/ / bdag gis byas pa bdag gis myong bar 'gyur/ / las kyi 'bras bu 'pho bar mi 'gyur te/ / rgyu med par yang myong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / srid pa thams cad sgyu ma dbang med pa/ / gsog dang gsob tu gyur pa dbu ba bzhin/ / sgyu ma smig rgyu lta bur rtag tu stong*/ / sgra yis bshad kyang de dag dben pa yin/ / brag phug ri dang gcong rong klung rnams su/ / rkyen gyis ji ltar brag cha 'byung ba ltar/ / de bzhin 'dus byas 'di kun rig par gyis/ / 'gro ba thams cad sgyu ma smig rgyu bzhin/ / zhes so/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to demonstrate that the refutation of the theses that phenomena are self-created, created by other, created by both, or are causeless is also established by profound scriptures, and to demonstrate that all of the scriptures which show this are explained by this chapter. The Samādhirāja-sūtra says: The Victor explains phenomena to be conventional. The produced and unproduced are equally dependent. In reality there is neither self nor person. All transmigrators are similarly characterized. Virtuous and wicked actions cannot be destroyed, Because whatever is done by the self is experienced by the self. The consequences of action cannot be transferred, And experience cannot be causeless. All of cyclic existence is eternally empty like illusion,/4/ powerless, Like a straw, like a scarecrow, like a bubble, Like an illusion. Although they are referred to by words, they are void. [m Do sde Da 147b] and All produced phenomena should be understood as Just as an echo that arises dependent on conditions such as A cave, a mountain, a cliff, a canyon. All transmigrators are like illusions and mirages. [m Do sde Da 147b]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name
don bsdu ba ni bshad zin to/ /
The summary has already been presented.
bdag gis byas pa dang gzhan gyis byas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gnyis pa'o//
This is the twelfth chapter called the “examination of that which is created by self and that which is created by another.”
bdag gis byas pa dang gzhan gyis byas pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu gnyis pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twelfth chapter, having ten verses, called the “examination of that which is created by self and that which is created by another.”
CHAPTER XIII. Examination of Compounded Phenomena
gnyis pa dngos po tsam gyi rang bzhin gyis stong par bstan pa
We now begin the second part of that section, the demonstration that mere phenomena are essentially empty.
['di] la gnyis/ dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / rang bzhin yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of things and the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of things.
dang po [dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
[Refutation of the essential existence of things]
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gsum/ gzhan la grags pa'i lung gis rang bzhin med pa bshad pa/ de ltar bshad pa mi 'thad pa'i rtsod pa spang ba/ lung de'i don rnam pa gzhan du 'chad pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the explanation of essencelessness through treatises renowned to others, rebutting the refutations claiming that these explanations are not tenable, and refutation of the claim that these treatises have different meanings.
dang po [gzhan la grags pa'i lung gis rang bzhin med pa bshad pa] ni/
1.1 Explanation of essencelessness through sūtras renowned by others
bcom ldan 'das kyis chos gang zhig / bslu ba de ni brdzun zhes gsungs/ / 'du byed thams cad bslu ba'i chos/ / des na de dag brdzun pa yin/ /
1. The Transcendent Lord has said that whatever Is deceptive is false. All compounded phenomena are deceptive. Therefore they are all false.

de ltar bshad ma thag pa'i tshul gyis rnam par dpyad pa na dngos po rnams bdag la sogs pa bzhi las 'byung ba med cing / rang bzhin gyis grub par skyed pa'i rnam pa gzhan yang med la ma rig pa'i rab rib kyis blo gros kyi mig nyams par byas pa rnams la ngo bo nyid kyis skye bar yang snang ba'i phyir sgyu ma'i rta glang la sogs pas sgyu ma mi shes pa slu ba bzhin du byis pa rnams slu bar byed do/ / de'i phyir sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis chos gang zhig slu ba yin pa de ni brdzun no zhes slu ba la brdzun pas khyab par gsungs la/ 'du byed thams cad kyang slu ba'i chos can yin no zhes gsungs pa des na 'du byed de dag thams cad brdzun pa yin no/ / mdo las/ dge slong dag 'dus byas slu ba'i chos can gang yin pa de dag ni brdzun pa yin la mi bslu ba'i chos can mya ngan las 'das pa gang yin pa de ni bden pa dam pa'o/ / zhes pa dang*/ de bzhin du 'dus byas de ni slu ba'i chos kyang yin de ni rab tu 'jig pa'i chos kyang yin no zhes kyang gsungs so/ / de la slu ba'i chos ni 'drid par byed cing phyin ci log tu snang ba ste mgal me'i 'khor lo bzhin no/ / dam pa'i don gyi bden pa ni slu ba ma yin te mya ngan las 'das pa bzhin no/ / de'i phyir ngo bo nyid kyis med kyang yod par snang nas slu bar rigs pas grub pa dang lung las kyang 'du byed slu bar gsungs pa las dngos po rnams rang bzhin med par grub ste/ sher phyin gyi mdo las chos thams cad ni stong pa ste rang bzhin med pa'i tshul gyis so/ / zhes 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ / 'dir mdo sde las myang 'das bden par gsungs pa ni 'du byed rnams mi bden par ston pa na/ slu ba'i chos can du gsungs pa'i gnad kyis mi bslu ba la bden pa dam pa zhes bya'i rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis grub pa'i bden par grub pa min no/ /

According to the mode of analysis just explained, things do not arise from any of the four, such as from self, etc., nor could that which exists essentially arise in any other way. Since things appear to have arisen inherently to those whose wisdom-eye is clouded by the mists of ignorance, fools are deceived just as an illusory horse or elephant conjured by a magician deceives those who do not understand the magic. Therefore, the Buddha, the Transcendent Lord, saying that any deceptive phenomenon is false, says that the deceptive is categorized as false. Since he also said that all compounded phenomena are deceptive pheomena, all of these compounded phenomena are false. As the sūtra says, O monks: As all compounded phenomena whatever are deceptive phenomena, they are false. The nondeceptive phenomenon, which is nirvana, is ultimate truth. Similarly it is also said, These compounded phenomena are deceptive phenomena and are completely disintegrating phenomena. [Majjhimanikāyā Dhātuvib-haṅgasuttam Vol. 5, 23, p. 1355]/1/[251] Deceptive phenomena mislead one. They appear as other than as they are, like the circle made by swinging a glowing ember. The ultimate truth is that which is nondeceptive, just like nirvana. It is established by arguments and by statements in sūtra that, although things do not exist inherently, they appear to do so, and thus are deceptive. And through these statements it is established that entities are essenceless. The Prajñāpāramitā-sūtra says: “All phenomena are empty; that is in virtue of lacking essence.” [Vajracchedikā-prajñāpāramītā-sūtra, Sher phyin sna tshogs kha 136a] Here the statements in sūtra that nirvana is truth mean that since compounded phenomena are presented as not being true, in virtue of the fact that they are said to be deceptive phenomena, the nondeceptive is called “ultimate truth.” But it is not established as true in virtue of existing inherently.
gnyis pa [de ltar bshad pa mi 'thad pa'i rtsod pa spang ba] ni/
1.2 Rebutting the refutations claiming that these explanations are not tenable

gal te de ltar slu ba'i chos can nyid kyis 'du byed thams cad brdzun par bstan na don byed nus pa'i dngos po gang yang med pas dngos po thams cad la skur 'debs kyi log ltar 'gyur ro zhes zer te/ sngar drangs pa'i mdo de nyan thos sde pa la grags pa'i mdo yin la don smra sde gnyis kyis mdo de'i don de ltar mi 'dod pas 'di ltar rtsod do/ / 'di ni brdzun pa gang yin thams cad ri bong gi mgo la rwa yod ces pa lta bur bzung nas de lta yin na rgyu 'bras thams cad med par 'gyur ro snyam pa yin te/ / ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub bzhin du der snang ba la brdzun par 'jog cing snang ba'i don de dag gis kyang bya ba byed nus pa sgyu ma dang 'dra ba mi shes par smra ba'o/ / gang dag da dung du yang khyod slu bar byed pa 'du byed slu ba'i chos can rnams ngo bo nyid kyis yod ces pa ni khyod bden te/ khyod 'dra ba 'dis de ltar ma bslus na 'di byis pa slu bar 'jog pa'i don med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Some contend that if, in virtue of being deceptive, all compounded phenomena are presented as false, then nothing could perform any function, and thus that this view is false and deprecates all phenomena. The previously quoted sūtra is accepted by the Śrāvaka schools/2/ and they advance this argument because these two reificationist schools do not interpret this sūtra as explained above. Here is their idea: Whatever is false is taken to be like the horns on the head of a rabbit. Thus it would follow that there would be no causes or effects. They say this because they do not understand that to be false in this sense is to not exist inherently, but to appear to do so. The appearing objects, however, can perform functions, just as an illusion can. Nonetheless, you are justified to say that the deceptive compound phenomena that deceive you exist inherently, because if a person like you were not deceived by them, it would be incorrect to regard them as that which deceives fools. [252]
gal te bslu chos gang yin pa/ / de brdzun de la ci zhig bslu/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis de gsungs pa/ / stong nyid yongs su bstan pa yi/ /
2. If whatever is a deceptive phenomenon Is false, then what deceives? Saying that, the Transcendent Lord Perfectly presents emptiness.

gal te chos gang slu ba de ni brdzun no zhes bshad pa de'i tshe de la ci zhig slu ba ste ci zhig dngos po med par 'dzin pa'i skur 'debs su 'gyur/ dngos po rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis 'ga' zhig yod na dngos po rnams brdzun par bstan pa na de la skur ba btab pas med ltar 'gyur na/ gang gi tshe dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa cung zad kyang med pa de'i tshe der ci zhig slu ste yod pa 'ga' yang med par mi smra bas klan ka de ni mi rigs so/ /

When it is stated that whatever is deceptive is false, “What deceives?” means What is being deprecated by being taken as a nonexistent entity? If any object existed inherently then when objects are presented as false, this would be to deprecate them, and so would be nihilism. But since entities do not have even the slightest essential existence, “What deceives?” means that we are not saying that anything that in fact exists does not exist, and so your argument does not make any sense.

gal te khyed lung des bden pa bkag pa'i brdzun pa bstan par 'dod pa na/ dngos po don byed nus pa med par mi ston na lung 'dis ci zhig ston zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis de la 'du byed brdzun par de skad gsungs pa des ni dngos po med par mi ston gyi rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa'i stong pa nyid yongs su bstan pa yin te/

Suppose one argued as follows: You maintain that this sūtra demonstrates the falsity of objects, refuting their truth by saying, “In that case, if this sūtra does not demonstrate that things are unable to perform functions, what does it demonstrate?” Through that statement the Transcendent Lord said that compounded things are false. By saying that, he did not demonstrate that entities do not exist, but rather perfectly demonstrated their emptiness—that they are essentially non-arisen.

ma dros pas zhus pa las/ gang zhig rkyen las skyes pa de ma skyes/ / de la skye ba'i rang bzhin yod ma yin/ / rkyen la rag las gang de stong par bshad/ / gang zhig stong nyid shes de bag yod yin/ / zhes rkyen la rag las pa de rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa'i don du gsungs pa ltar 'du byed brdzun par gsungs pa des kyang rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa ston gyi skye ba bkag pa'i dngos med ston pa min no/ / de ltar na rang bzhin gyis ma skyes bzhin du der snang ba ni slu ba dang brdzun par gsungs pa'i lung gi don du bshad do/ /

As it is said in the Anavatapta-sūtra, Whatever arises from conditions is non-arisen; It does not have the essence of being arisen. That which depends on conditions is explained to be empty. Whoever understands emptiness is mindful. [m Do sde pha 230b]/3/ Just as it says that to depend on conditions is what it means to be essentially unarisen, the statement that compounded phenomena are false also demonstrates that they are essentially unarisen; but it does not, by refuting their arising, demonstrate that they are nonentities. Thus, the meaning of this sūtra is explained as follows: It says that although things are essentially unarisen, they appear to be essentially arisen, and so they are deceptive and false.
gsum pa [lung de'i don rnam pa gzhan du 'chad pa dgag pa]
1.3 Refutation of the claim that these sūtras have different meanings
['di] la gnyis/ lung don gzhan du 'chad tshul bstan/ de ltar 'chad pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: presentation of other ways of interpreting these sūtras and the refutation of the argument for those interpretations.
dang po [lung don gzhan du 'chad tshul bstan] ni/
1.3.1 Presentation of other ways of interpreting these sūtras

nyan thos sde pas sngar drangs pa'i mdo des 'jig pa'i chos can du gsungs pa la brten nas/ / dngos po thams cad rang grub pa'i dus las dus gnyis par mi sdod pa yin yang sdod par snang ba slu ba dang brdzun pa'i don du 'dod do/ // de ltar byas na rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa lung gi don min gyi rang bzhin la mi gnas pa rang bzhin med pa'am brdzun pa'am bden pa med par gsungs pa'i don du smra'o/ /

The śrāvaka schools, relying on the sūtra quoted earlier which says that compounded phenomena are disintegating phenomena, maintain that “all things are false and deceptive” means that, although nothing remains for a second moment after the moment when it comes into existence, nonetheless things appear to remain. [253] Having interpreted it this way, they say that essential non-arising is not the meaning of the sūtra, but instead that nonendurance of its essence is the meaning of “essencelessness,” “falsity,” and “unreality.”
dngos rnams ngo bo nyid med de/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba snang phyir ro/ / dngos po ngo bo nyid med med/ / gang phyir dngos rnams stong pa nyid/ /
3. All entities are natureless, Since transformation into something else is perceived. All entities lack naturelessness Because all entities have emptiness.

de'i rgyu mtshan yang gnyis las dang po ni/ dngos po rnams la rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i ngo bo nyid med na 'di rnams gzhan du 'gyur ba snang bar mi 'gyur ba las snang ba'i phyir/ rang gi ngo bos ma grub pa mdo'i don du mi rung gi ngo bo gzhan du 'gyur bas rang bzhin la mi gnas pa mdo'i don no/ / rgyu mtshan gnyis pa ni dngos po rnams ngo bos grub pa'i ngo bo nyid med pa ni med de gang gi phyir na chos can dngos po rnams kyi chos stong pa nyid 'dod dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / yod pa min pa'i mo gsham gyi bu la ni de'i sngo bsangs mi 'thad pas chos can med par de la brten pa'i chos kyang mi 'thad pa'i phyir dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod do/ /

Here is the first of their two arguments: If entities do not have their own inherently existent nature, they would not be seen to transform into something else. But this is seen. It can not be that the meaning of the sūtra is that they do not inherently exist, but instead that since they transform into something else their essence does not endure. Their second argument is that it is not the case that entities do not have their own inherently existent nature, because it must be maintained that all property bearers have emptiness as a property. It is not tenable that the nonexistent barren woman’s son has the property of blueness. Without property bearers it is not tenable that there are the properties that depend upon them. Therefore, all entities exist essentially.
gal te ngo bo nyid med na/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin/ /
4. If they are natureless, What transforms?

gal te dngos po la rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i ngo bo nyid med na gzhan du 'gyur ba 'di chos gang zhig gi ngo bo yin zhes 'dzer to/ / rgol ba 'di dag ni rigs pa'i rnam gzhag la byang ba yin pas rang gis khas blangs pa'i lung 'ga' zhig las rang bzhin med par gsungs pa'i lung don 'chad pa na/ rang gi ngo bo la mi gnas pa'i mi rtag pa la dgongs par smra ba yin gyi/ rang bzhin yod med dang bden par grub ma grub kyi don rtag par yod med la byed pa ni gtan min pas/ gangs ri'i khrod pa'i rgol ba mu cor smra ba 'ga' zhig gis de ltar smra ba dang khyad par che'o/ / rnal 'byor spyod pa pas dngos po bden par smra ba'i bstan bcos kyi rnam gzhag byas pa ni rtsa ba mkhan po'i rjes su byung bas/ 'dir yang rang sde phyogs sngar len pa na don smra gnyis phyogs sngar mdzad la de dag la lung gi gnod pa ston pa na'ang theg dman gyi sde snod nas 'byung ba nyid kyis mdzad do/ // de lta na'ang 'di dag gi 'dod pa bkag na rnal 'byor spyod pa pa'i dngos po bden par 'dod pa yang khegs par 'gyur bas 'gog pa'i rigs pa ni thun mong ba kho na'o/ /

Continuing in this vein they ask, “If entities do not have their own inherently existent nature, then what is the nature of the thing that transforms into something else?” These opponents are skillful in dialectic, and therefore when they interpret the meaning of “essencelessness” in the sūtras they accept, they say that it means impermanence in virtue of the fact that things’ essences do not endure. However, it absolutely does not mean that “having versus lacking essential existence,” or “truly existing versus not truly existing,” means existing permanently versus not existing permanently, as they say. Therefore, this is completely different from some similar assertions by some sophists from the Land of Snows who are just talking nonsense./4/ The set of treatises of the Yogācārins setting out the true existence of things emerged after the time of the master who wrote this root text. Therefore, here when Buddhist schools are taken as opponents, those two reificationist schools/5/ are taken as the opponents. When their views are shown to be inconsistent with scriptures, this is shown with reference to Hīnayāna scriptures. However when their assertions are refuted, the assertions by the Yogācārins that things truly exist are also thereby refuted. [254] Therefore, these refutatory arguments strike against all of them equally.
gnyis pa [de ltar 'chad pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa]
1.3.2 Refutation of the argument for those interpretations
['di] la gnyis/ gzhan 'gyur rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag / stong nyid rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of the argument for the inherent existence of that which is arisen from others and refutation of the argument for the inherent existence of emptiness.
dang po [gzhan 'gyur rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag]
1.3.2.1 Refutation of the argument for the inherent existence of that which is arisen from others
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin dang gzhan 'gyur gnyis 'gal bas dgag / gzhan 'gyur rang bzhin gyis yod pa mi srid pas dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: refutation by showing that essence and transformation into another are inconsistent and refutation by showing that it is impossible for transformation into another to exist inherently.
dang po [rang bzhin dang gzhan 'gyur gnyis 'gal bas dgag] ni/
1.3.2.1.1 Refutation by showing that essence and transformation into another are inconsistent
gal te ngo bo nyid yod na/ / ci lta bur na gzhan du 'gyur/ /
4cd. If there were nature, How could there be transformation?

chos gang zhig dngos po gang la mi 'khrul ba de ni de'i rang bzhin no zhes brjod de gzhan gyis gegs byar med pa'i phyir ro/ / de yang me la mi 'khrul ba'i me'i tsha ba lta bu zhig dgos so/ / gal te dngos po rnams ngo bo nyid de rang bzhin du yod na de gang gi rang bzhin du 'dod pa de las gzhan du 'gyur bar ji ltar rung ste mi rung ngo / / gzhan du 'gyur ba yang mthong ba'i phyir rang bzhin du yod pa min no zhes bzlog pa 'phen no/ / de ni tha snyad pa'i gzhan 'gyur ro/ /

It is said that anything inextricable from a phenomenon is its essence because it cannot be displaced by anything else. This must be like the heat of fire being inextricable from the fire. If the nature of things existed essentially, how could the essence proposed transform into something else? It could not. Transformation into something else is perceived. So there is no essential existence. Thus he contraposes. That is conventional transformation.
gnyis pa [gzhan 'gyur rang bzhin gyis yod pa mi srid pas dgag pa] ni/
1.3.2.1.2 Refutation by showing that it is impossible for transformation into another to exist inherently
de nyid la ni gzhan 'gyur med/ / gzhan nyid la yang yod ma yin/ / gang phyir gzhon nu mi rga ste/ / gang phyir rgas pa'ang mi rga'o/ /
5. A thing itself is without transformation. Nor is transformation in something else, Because a young man does not age, And because an aged man does not age either.

re zhig dngos po sngar gyi gnas skabs na gnas pa de nyid la ni gzhan du 'gyur ba med de/ gang gi phyir te 'di ltar gzhan du 'gyur ba ni rga ba'i rnam grangs yin na lang tsho'i gnas skabs nyid la gnas pa'i gzhon nu la ni mi rga ba ste rga ba yod pa min pa'i phyir te/ gnas skabs de na lang tsho las gzhan du 'gyur ba mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste gzhon nu la rga ba mi 'dod kyi rgas pa nyid rga'o snyam na/ gzhan rgas pa nyid la yang rga ba yod pa ma yin te gang gi phyir rgas pa la'ang rga bar 'gyur mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir tshig gsal las/ rgan gzhon gyi gnas skabs gnyis 'gal ba dang / bud d+ha pA li ta las rgas pa dang gzhon nu'i gnas skabs gnyis gang zag gcig la dus gcig na med pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis gzhon nu rgas par 'gyur ba bkag pa'i rigs pa ni/ lhas byin gyi gzhon nu'i gnas skabs 'gag bzhin pa dang rgas pa'i gnas skabs skye bzhin pa gnyis dus mnyam yang / gnas skabs gnyis dus gcig na med pa ni rang yang tha snyad du 'dod dgos so/ // des na sngar skye ba 'gog pa'i skabs su bshad pa bzhin du gzhan 'gyur ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gnas skabs gnyis dus gcig na gnas pa'i skyon yod pas 'gog pa yin no/ / gal te gzhan rgas par gyur pa rga bar mi 'gyur yang gzhon nu de nyid gzhan rgas par 'gyur ba'i gzhan 'gyur ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes 'dod na ni/ de ltar na 'o ma nyid kyis rang gi gnas skabs ma btang bar ni zhor 'gyur ro/ /

Anything that endures in its previous state cannot transform into something else. This is because “to transform into something else” is a synonym of “to age.” So, the youth who endures in the state of adolesence would not age. That is, he would be without aging, because if he were to endure in that state, it would not be tenable that he transforms from an adolescent into something else. One might say that it is not asserted that aging is present in the youth, but that the aged age. But aging is also not present in some other aged one/6/ because someone who is already aged does not need to age again. Here, according to Prasannapadā, the two states of being aged and remaining young are mutually exclusive. [82b] Buddhapālitī refutes the youth aging on the grounds that the two states of being aged and being young cannot occur [255] in the same person at the same time [218b]. Here is what he means: The ceasing of Lhejin’s state of youth and the arising of his state of aging occur at the same time./7/ However, even we must accept conventionally that the two states in question cannot occur at the same time. Therefore, as was explained earlier in the context of the refutation of arising, the inherent existence of the transformation of something into something else is refuted by showing that this would entail falsely that the two states exist at the same time. If it is asserted that the aged person who is other does not age, but instead that the transformation of the youth himself into an aged person who is other exists inherently, then milk itself, without giving up its own state, would become yoghurt.
gal te de nyid gzhan 'gyur na/ / 'o ma nyid ni zhor 'gyur ro/ / 'o ma las gzhan gang zhig ni/ / zho yi dngos po yin par 'gyur/ /
6. If a thing itself transformed, Milk itself would become yoghurt. But what other than milk Could become the entity that is yoghurt?

ci ste 'o ma'i gnas skabs btang nas zho'i gnas skabs su 'gyur ba'i phyir 'o ma nyid zhor mi 'gyur ro zhe na/ gal te phan tshun 'gal bas 'o ma nyid zhor 'gyur ro zhes mi 'dod na ni 'o ma las don gzhan gang zhig ni zho yi dngos por 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ zho dang chu lta bu gzhan gang yang zhor mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / chos snga ma gcig phyi mar 'gyur ro zhes pa'i tha snyad ni rgan gzhon dang 'o zho lta bu la yod kyi me dang shing lta bu'i rgyu 'bras la ni bud shing mer 'gyur ro zhes pa'i tha snyad 'jig rten na mi byed do/ / de ltar gzhan 'gyur ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa mi srid pa'i phyir mi rtag pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'du byed slu zhing brdzun par gsungs pa'i don ma yin gyi dngos po rnams rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma skyes pa lung gi don yin no/ /

Suppose one said that since the milk, having given up its own state, has transformed into the state of yoghurt, the milk itself does not become yoghurt. If one did not maintain that, since milk and yoghurt are mutually inconsistent, the milk itself becomes yoghurt, then what stuff other than milk would transform into yoghurt? Nothing would, because other stuff like yoghurt itself and water do not transform into yoghurt. The convention of saying that an earlier phenomenon transforms into a later one is relevant to youth and age, and to yoghurt and milk, but with respect to cause and effect like fire and fuel there is no mundane convention of saying that the fuel transforms into fire. Thus, since it is impossible for transformation into another to exist inherently, the inherent existence of impermanent objects is not the meaning of the statement that compounded phenomena are false and deceptive. Instead, the meaning of these sūtras is that entities are not inherently arisen.

ji skad du dkon mchog 'byung gnas kyi mdo las/ chos gang skye ba med cing 'byung ba med/ / ces pa nas/ grol nas sems can mang po grol bar mdzad/ / ces pa'i mjug tu/ bdag med par ni chos kun ston mdzad cing / / sems can 'dzin las 'jig rten rnam par grol/ / bdag nyid 'gro las grol zhing 'gro grol bas/ / de phyir pha rol gshegs kyang brgal ba'ang med/ / drang srong chen po srid pa'i pha rol phyin/ / pha rol gshegs pa gang yang rnyed mi 'gyur/ // pha rol yod ma yin zhing tshu rol med/ / pha rol song ngo zhes kyang tshig tu gsung*/ / gang gis tshig tu smra ba de yang med/ / gang smras de yi tshig kyang yod ma yin/ / gang la smra ba de yang rnyed mi 'gyur/ / gang gis shes pa de yang yod ma yin/ / log par rtog la chags pa'i dbang gis su/ / 'dir ni 'gro ba 'di kun rab tu 'khyam/ / skyes bu gang gis zhi ba'i chos rig pa/ / des ni rang 'byung de bzhin gshegs pa mthong / / chos mchog zhi ba rnams kyang rab tu shes/ // dga' ba rnyed nas sems can tshim par byed/ / nyon mongs rgyal nas de ni rgyal bar 'gyur/ / bdag nyid rgyal bar 'gyur zhing gnas pa med/ / de phyir rgyal ba'i byang chub rab tu mkhyen/ / sangs rgyas nas ni 'gro ba shes par byed/ / ces gsungs te gzhan 'gyur med pa dang ngo bo nyid mi rnyed pa dang de ma rtogs pa'i nyes dmigs dang rtogs pa'i phan yon du sbyor ro/ /

Thus, the Ratnākara-sūtra says; As phenomena are unarisen they do not come into being, [m Do sde tha 261b] and later it says, Having been liberated, he liberates many other sentient beings, [262b] [256] and it also says, All phenomena are presented as selfless. Through guiding sentient beings, the world is liberated. He himself is liberated from transmigration, and transmigrators are liberated. Though he has passed beyond, he has not crossed over. The Great Sage has passed beyond cyclic existence. That which has passed beyond is not found. Neither the other shore nor this shore exists. “Gone beyond” is also said to be mere words. He who expreses words does not exist. The words that are expressed do not exist. They to whom they are expressed are also not found. He by whom this is known also does not exist. Through being wrongly conceived through the power of attachment, All of the transmigrators wander here. Whoever sees the peaceful dharma Sees the self-originated Thathāgata, The peaceful supreme dharma is understood. Obtaining bliss, beings are satisfied. Having conquered the afflictions, he is victorious. Having become victorious, he does not endure. Thus, the Victor’s enlightenment is realized. Having achieved enlightenment he enlightens transmigrators. [262a] This passage shows the disadvantages of not understanding, and the benefits of understanding, that a thing does not transform into another, and that no nature is found.
gnyis pa [stong nyid rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa]
1.3.2.2 Refutation of the argument for the inherent existence of emptiness
['di] la gnyis/ dngos kyi don dang / de la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the main point and the refutation of the claim that this contradicts sūtras.
dang po [dngos kyi don] ni/
1.3.2.2.1 The main point
gal ste stong min cung zad yod/ / stong pa'ang cung zad yod par 'gyur/ / mi stong cung zad yod min na/ / stong pa'ang yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
7. If there were even the slightest bit nonempty, Emptiness itself would be the slightest bit existent. But when not there is not even the slightest nonempty thing, How could emptiness exist?

sngar dngos po ngo bo nyid kyis med pa ni yod pa ma yin te dngos po rnams stong pa nyid du ni 'dod do/ / de'i phyir stong nyid kyi rten du gyur pa'i dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes smras pa de ni mi rigs te/ gal te stong pa nyid rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa cung zad cig yod na ni de'i rten ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa'i stong pa min pa cung zad cig yod na'ang / 'dir stong pa nyid dang bdag med pa ni chos thams cad kyi spyi'i mtshan nyid du khas blangs pas bdag gis mi stong pa cung zad kyang yod pa min na/ stong pa nyid ngo bo nyid kyis yod par ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur te gnyen po la ltos pa dang bral bas nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ / chos thams cad ni bdag med do zhes pa'i lung don smra sde gnyis kyis kyang khas len la/ bdag med kyi med rgyu'i bdag ni slob dpon gnyis kas rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa la bzhed pas tshig gsal las sngar ltar bshad pa yang 'thad do/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las dpyad na mi stong pa cung zad kyang med pas stong pa yod par ga la 'gyur zhes bshad de chos thams cad bdag med pa'i don yang de nyid yin pas don 'dra'o/ /

As was explained earlier, the absence of inherent existence of things does not exist, because all things are maintained to be empty. Therefore, it makes no sense to say that the entities that are the bases of emptiness exist essentially, because if emptiness existed inherently even the slightest bit, then there could be the slightest bit of its basis existing inherently, that is, as nonempty. But since here emptiness and selflessness are asserted to be the universal characteristics of all pheomena, there is not the slightest thing empty of self. [257] Then how could emptiness exist inherently? It could not. The antidote, being free from dependence, would be like a sky flower. The statement in sūtra that all phenomena are selfless is accepted by both reificationist schools. As both masters maintain, inherent existence is the self, absence of which is selflessness. Prasannapadā has already correctly explained this. Buddhapālita asks how emptiness could exist, since analysis shows that there is not the slightest nonempty thing. That is the meaning of “all things are selfless,” and thus their accounts are similar [219b].

stong pa nyid yin pa'i cung zad cig bden par grub par 'dod na de'i rten chos can bden par grub pa cung zad cig kyang gdon mi za bar 'dod dgos te/ rten chos can med par brten pa'i chos gnas pa mi srid pa'i phyir dang / bden par grub pa'i rten brdzun pas byed pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / des na de la ni dbu ma pa dang dngos por smra ba gnyis ka mthun la de lta na'ang dngos por smra bas ni chos can dang stong nyid gnyis ka bden par 'dod la dbu ma pas ni chos can mi bden pas stong nyid kyang bden par ma grub par bzhed do/ /

Suppose it were maintained that emptiness were even the slightest bit truly existent. Then one would undoubtedly have to maintain that that which it qualifies—the basis—is at least the slightest bit truly existent. This is because it is impossible for the quality to exist without the qualified phenomenon on which it is grounded, and it would be contradictory for something truly existent to be grounded in something whose existence is false. Thus, the mādhyamika and the reificationist agree about this point. But the reificationist maintains that both emptiness and its basis are truly existent. The mādhyamika, on the other hand, says that since the basis is not truly existent, emptiness is not truly existent either.

rnal 'byor spyod pa pa'i mkhas pa rnams kyang yongs grub bden par 'grub pa la de'i rten gzhan dbang bden par 'grub dgos par mthong nas gzhan dbang bden par sgrub ste/ de bden par grub na de'i stong nyid bden pa 'bad med du 'grub pa'i phyir dang de bden par ma grub na rgyu mtshan de nyid kyis de'i chos nyid bden med du 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ // des na de dag las bzlog ste smra ba ni rang gi sde pa gong 'og gang gi yang lugs min pas dor bar bya ba kho na'o/ /

The yogācāra masters, seeing that in order for the consummate to truly exist, that on which it depends—the other-dependent nature—must truly exist, argue that the other-dependent truly exists. This is because if it truly existed, the true existence of its emptiness would follow immediately, and if it does not truly exist, just in virtue of that its quality cannot truly exist. Therefore, claims at variance with these assertions would not be in accordance with the systems of either our upper or lower schools, and thus these claims should simply be discarded.

spyod 'jug las/ gang tshe gang zhig med do zhes / / brtag bya'i dngos po mi dmigs pa/ / de tshe dngos med rten bral ba/ / blo yi mdun na de ltar gnas/ / zhes gsungs pas kyang dgag bya dgag pa'i rten du ston pa min gyi dngos po bden pa ma grub na dngos med kyi stong nyid bden pa pa'i rten med ces pa'i don no/ /

Bodhicaryāvatāra says: Whenever anything is said to be nonexistent And the entity to be examined is not observed, [258] Then how could the entitilessness, without a basis, Be present before the mind? [IX: 33] This does not show that the basis of negation of the object of negation exists; but instead it shows that since there are no truly existent entities, nonentity—that is, emptiness, or truth—lacks a basis.
gnyis pa [de la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba]
1.3.2.2.2 Refutation of the claim that this contradicts sūtras
['di] la gnyis gzhung gi don bshad pa dang / de gsungs pa'i khungs bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: explanation of the meaning of the treatises and the presentation of the source treatises.
dang po [gzhung gi don bshad pa] ni/
1.3.2.2.2.1 Explanation of the meaning of the treatises

gal te bcom ldan 'das kyis gdul bya rnams grol bar bya ba'i phyir stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang smon pa med pa'i rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum gsungs pa ni/ mu stegs dang thun mong ma yin pas bde bar gshegs pa'i gsung kho na la dmigs na/ khyod kyis ni da lta gsung rab 'chad pa'i sgyu thabs kyis stong pa nyid spong bar brtsams pa yin pas/ mtho ris dang byang grol gyi lam rgyun gcod par byed pa khyod dang brtsad pas da chog go zhe na/

One might argue as follows: In order to liberate sentient beings the Transcendent Lord taught the three doors of liberation, viz. emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness. This teaching is not common to the non-Buddhist schools. Therefore these statements are found only in the teachings of the Transcendent Lord and you, pretending to be interpreting the teaching, are discarding emptiness. I have argued enough with you who dismantle the continuous path to enlightenment!
rgyal ba rnams kyis stong pa nyid/ / lta kun nges par 'byung bar gsungs/ / gang dag stong pa nyid lta ba/ / de dag bsgrub tu med par gsungs/ /
8. The victorious ones have said That emptiness is the elimination of all views. Anyone for whom emptiness is a view Is incorrigible.

e ma kye hud shin tu phyin ci log tu gyur pas thar pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba'i lam drang po bor nas/ dngos po dang dngos po med pa la bden par zhen pa'i sbrul gyis dkris pa'i 'khor ba'i 'brog dgon par 'gro ba'i lam la thar par 'gro bar 'dzin pa khyod ni/ dam pas smad par bya ba yin bzhin du dam pa la smod pa zhig ste kwa ye sman pa'i rgyal po chen po rgyal ba rnams kyis stong pa nyid ni/ lta ba ste bden 'dzin kun las nges par 'byung ba ste 'byin pa yin par gsungs pas bden par lta ba'i dmigs gtad thams cad log pa tsam mo/ / log pa tsam ni rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa yang min no/ / des na gang dag stong pa nyid de la ngo bo nyid kyi yod par lta ba de dag ni bsgrub tu med pa ste gsor mi rung bar gsungs so/ / 'di ni khyod la zong ci yang ster rgyu med do zhes smras pa na kye bdag la ci yang med pa zhes pa'i zong de byin cig ces smra na pha rol po de rang la zong med par 'dzin du gzhug pa'i thabs med pa dang 'dra bar slob dpon gnyis kas bshad do/ / pha rol pos 'di la ni sbyin rgyu'i zong med par 'dug snyam pa'i blo bskyed pa'i phyir du tshig de smras pas na blo de bskyed du mi rung ba min gyi zong med pa de zong gcig yin par 'dug snyam pa'i blo de bskyed du mi rung ngo / /

You poor man! Having succumbed to seriously deviant views, and having abandoned the direct path that leads to the city of liberation, you are constricted by the serpent of fixation on entitihood and entitilessness as truly existent. Thus you wander in cyclic existence, regarding the path into the forest of cyclic existence as the path to liberation. Subject to condemnation by the noble ones, instead you condemn them! Hey! The great lord of physicians and of the victors has said that emptiness is the view that allows one to abandon and to eliminate all grasping. This is the mere relinquishing of all views regarding things as truly existent. And a mere relinquishing does not exist inherently! Thus it is said that anyone who regards emptiness as inherently existent will accomplish nothing; that is, he is incurable. This is similar to a case where someone says, “I have no goods to give you.” And the other person says, “Give me what you call ‘no goods’!” The two masters say that this opponent is like the one who cannot be convinced that he does not have any goods. [259] When, in order to convince the other person that he has no goods to give, he utters that sentence, it is not that he cannot be convinced; but the idea that he has “no goods” as goods should not arise [Buddhapālita 219b and Prasannapadā 83b].

de bzhin du dngos po rnams ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no zhes ston pa na 'di rnams bden pas stong ngong snyam du bzung du mi rung ba min gyi dngos po bden pas stong pa 'di bden no snyam du bzung du mi rung ba yin no/ / des na chos rnams stong pa'o snyam du bzung na yang gsor mi rung bar gzhung 'dis bstan par 'dod pa ni ma brtags par smra ba chen po'o/ // slob dpon gnyis kas stong pa nyid du lta ba zhes pa'i don stong pa nyid la dngos por zhen pa la gsungs la de ni stong nyid bden par bzung ba'am stong nyid ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'dzin pa yin gyi rang bzhin med pa'o snyam du 'dzin pa tsam ga la yin/ brgya pa'i 'grel pa las kyang gal te stong pa nyid ces bya ba rang gi ngo bos grub pa 'ga' yod na ni dngos po rnams rang bzhin dang bcas par 'gyur na yod pa ni ma yin no/ / zhes bshad pa/ stong min med par stong pa ni/ / gang las 'byung ba nyid du 'gyur/ / ji lta bur na gcig shos ni/ / med par gnyen po 'byung bar 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs la de'i 'grel par gzhung 'di yang drangs so//sngar nyan thos sde pas stong nyid bden par yod par khas blangs pa gzhung snga ma dang 'di gnyis kyis 'gog pa yin pas bdag med yod pa tsam zhig 'gog pa gtan min no/ / de ltar gzhung gi don log par bzung na ni don dam pa'i bden pa mi srid ces skur pa 'debs pa dang / srid kyang de nges pa'i nges shes bskyangs na mtshan 'dzin du 'gro bar bzung nas yang dag pa'i don tshul bzhin du nges pa'i lta ba skyong ba'i gegs chen po byed pa yin no/ /

Similarly, when it is demonstrated that entities do not exist inherently, it is not that one should not take them to be truly empty, but that one should not take the entities’ emptiness of true existence to be truly existent. Therefore, to maintain that this text/8/ shows that if you take phenomena to be empty you will be incurable would be to make a strong claim with no justification. According to both of these masters, to hold emptiness as a view9 means to be fixated on emptiness as an entity—that is, to grasp emptiness as truly existent or as existing inherently. So how could this be to grasp emptiness as mere essencelessness? The Commentary to the Catuḥśataka says, If it were there were anything called emptiness that exists inherently, then there would be objects with essence. But this is not the case. As it is said:/10/ Without that which is not emptiness, How could there be emptiness? Just as without another How could there be the antidote? [dBu ma ya 232b] The commentary quotes this verse. Both this and the earlier texts refute the assertions of the śrāvaka schools that emptiness truly exists. But this does not refute the mere existence of selflessness. So if you misunderstand the meanings of these texts, you would repudiate the truth by saying that the ultimate truth is incoherent. Or even if you say that it is coherent, if you develop an ascertainment that grasps it as truly existent [260] this would be a great hindrance to the the proper ascertainment of the correct meaning and the development the view.
gnyis pa [de gsungs pa'i khungs bstan pa] ni/
1.3.2.2.2.2 Presentation of the source treatises

gzhung des gsungs zhes pa'i mdo'i khungs ni dkon brtsegs kyi 'od srungs kyis zhus pa las/ gang dag stong pa nyid kyis chos rnams stong par mi byed de/ chos rnams nyid stong pa dang / gang mtshan ma med pas chos rnams mtshan ma med par mi byed de/ chos rnams nyid mtshan ma med pa dang / gang smon pa med pas chos rnams smon pa med par mi byed de/ chos rnams nyid smon pa med par gang dag de ltar so sor rtog pa de ni/ 'od srungs dbu ma'i lam chos rnams la yang dag par so sor rtog pa zhes bya'o/ / 'od srungs gang dag stong pa nyid du dmigs pas stong nyid la rtog pa de dag ni/ sa gsung rab 'di las nyams rab tu nyams zhes bshad do/ / zhes gsungs pa'o/ / stong pa nyid la sogs pas chos rnams stong par mi byed par chos rnams nyid stong pa la sogs par gsungs pa ni chos kho rang bden pas mi stong par gzhan zhig bden pas kho stong par mi gzung ba'i don no/ / stong nyid la rtog pa ni rab tu nyams par gsungs pa'i rtog lugs ni gang dag stong pa nyid du dmigs pas zhes gsungs pas bden par dmigs pa la bya'i stong nyid do snyam du rtog pa la mi bya ste/ gzhan du na de ma thag tu stong pa nyid la sogs pa gsum la so sor rtog pa dbu ma'i lam du gsungs pa dang 'gal bar 'gyur ro/ / stong pa nyid du lta ba gsor mi rung ba'i dpe don sbyor tshul yang med de/

The source sūtra we have been explaining is the Ratnakūta-sūatra and from within that it is the Kāśyapa parivarta-sūtra. And it says, That which is emptiness does not empty phenomena, because/11/ phenomena themselves are empty; that which is signlessness does not make phenomena signless, because phenomena themselves are signless; that which is wishlessness does not make phenomena wishless, because phenomena themselves are wishless. To so analyze, oh Kāśyapa, is called the middle path—in the correct analysis of phenomena. Oh, Kāśyapa, I say that whoever analyzes emptiness by objectifying emptiness has fallen, fallen far from my teachings. [dkon brtsegs cha 132a] The statements that such things as emptiness do not empty phenomena but that phenomena themselves are empty etc., means that it should not be taken that phenomena that are not themselves truly empty are truly emptied by something else. When it says that to conceptualize emptiness is to have fallen far, the mode of that conceptualization is, as it is said in “whoever objectifies emptiness,” the objectification of emptiness as truly existent, but it is not just the conceputalization of emptiness as “this is emptiness.” Otherwise, it would be contradictory to say immediately that the analysis of these three, including emptiness, is the middle path. The method of the application of the example to that which it illustrates in the case of “whoever views emptiness is incurable” is,

de nyid las 'od srungs 'di lta ste dper na/mi nad pa zhig yod la sman pas de la sman btang bas sman des de'i nad thams cad bskyod de sman lto na 'dug pa de nyid mi 'byung na/ 'od srungs 'di ji snyam du sems mi de nad de las thar bar 'gyur ram/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni mi 'gyur laT te gang sman des nad thams cad bskyod nas/ sman ltor mchis pa nyid ma byung na mi de'i bro nad shin tu tshabs che bar 'gyur lags / // bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ da srungs/ de bzhin du lta bar gyur pa thams cad las 'byung ba ni stong pa nyid yin na/ 'od srungs gang stong pa nyid kho nar lta ba de ni gsor mi rung ngo zhes ngas bshad do zhes gsungs pa'o/

as the sūtra puts it, Kāśyapa, it is like this, for example: There is a sick man and the physician gives him some medicine, and the medicine cures his illness completely. If that medicine remains in his stomach and is not expelled, what do you think, Kāśyapa? Has the person really been cured? [261] He responds, “Oh, Transcendent Lord, of course not. Even if that medicine has cured his illness completely, if the medicine is not expelled from his stomach, that man’s stomach-ache would be wrenching.” The Transcendent Lord then replied, “Oh, Kāśyapa, in exactly the same way, when emptiness is that which eliminates all views, I call someone incurable who adopts emptiness as a view.” [Kon brtsegs cha 132b]

sman gyis ma zhu ba snga ma dag par byas nas rang nyid ma zhu bas nad skyed pa dper mdzad pa 'di ni rang sde dngos por smra ba sde gnyis kyis bdag med bden par 'dod pa dang gangs can pa snga ma kha cig dngos po rnams mthar thug dpyod pa'i rigs pas dpyad bzod du yod pa bkag nas/ // de ltar bkag pa'i stong pa bden par 'dod pa rnams la sbyar bar bya ste/ dgag bya bkag pa'i stong pa de rtogs pas nyon mongs pa'i nad mngon gyur pa mang po yang ldog la stong pa bden par bzung bas kyang nyon mongs pa'i nad skyed pa'i phyir ro/ / de dag las gzhan du stong pa dang mi stong pa'i tshul gnyis byed pa la ni stong pa'i tshul ni tshad mas kheT pa min gyi skur 'debs yin pa'i phyir dper brjod snga ma'i don med pas mi stong pa'i tshul du 'dzin pas nyon mongs pa'i nad skyed pa tsam mo/ /

The medicine cured his previous indigestion, but then, due to its own indigestibility, gave rise to a new sickness. This example represents the two Buddhist reificationist schools’ thesis that selflessness truly exists and the thesis of several previous scholars from the Land of Snows/12/ that, although the thesis that things can withstand ultimate rational analysis has been refuted, emptiness truly exists. Realizing emptiness as that which refutes the object of negation eliminates many of the manifest illnesses of affliction, but grasping emptiness as truly existent gives rise to the illnesses of afflictions. For those who take either of two other approaches—taking things as empty or taking things as nonempty—while taking things as empty in this way is not refuted by authoritative cognition, it becomes deprecation. Since it does not correspond to the previous example, taking things as nonempty also gives rise to the illnesses of affliction.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar 'du byed thams cad ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa med bzhin du der snang ba dang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa la gzhan 'gyur mi rung ba dang / bden pas stong pa'i stong nyid bden pa med par bstan pa rnams zab mo'i lung gis kyang 'grub pa ni sngar skabs skabs su sbyar zin pas de la dpags nas shes par bya'o/ //

The confirmations by profound sūtras of the demonstrations that, although no compounded phenomena exist inherently, they appear to do so, that it is impossible for anything that exists inherently to transform into anything else, and that emptiness, which is the emptiness of true existence, does not truly exist have been provided in their respective contexts and should so be understood.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name
