brdzun pa'i brdzun lugs ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis ma grub bzhin du der snang ba yin zhing de nyid la bya byed thams cad 'thad pas brdzun pa'i don bya byed kyi dngos po thams cad kyis stong pa la mi gzung ste gzhan 'gyur dang mi rtag pa yang de dang 'dra'o// // brdzun pa la bden grub bkag pa'i stong pa bden par ma grub kyang ma grub pa min pas/ grol ba don du gnyer ba rnams kyis gang la dmigs nas bsgoms pas sgrib pa zad par byed pa'i lam gyi dmigs par shin tu 'thad pa'i tshul rnams nges par bya'o/ /

The sense in which that which is false is false is that although they appear to do so, things do not exist through their own characteristics. Since all agents and actions are tenable in this sense, [262] “false” should not to be taken to mean empty of the phenomena of agent and action. Impermanence and transformation should be understood in the same way. Emptiness, that is, the negation of the true existence of that which is false, does not truly exist. However, it is not the case that it is nonexistent. Those who aspire to liberation must ascertain perfectly the objects of the path on which one should concentrate in meditation in order to eliminate the obscurations.
'du byed brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu gsum pa'o// //
This is the thirteenth chapter called “the examination of compounded phenomena.”
'du byed brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa brgyad kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu gsum pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the thirteenth chapter, having eight verses, called “the examination of compounded phenomena.”
CHAPTER XIV. Examination of Contact
gnyis pa dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa
We now begin the second of those two parts: the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of things.
['di] la gsum/ phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / rgyu rkyen bdag gir byed pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / bcings thar rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /

This part has three sections: the refutation of the essential existence of contact, the refutation of the essential existence of appropriation of causes and conditions, and the refutation of the essential existence of bondage and liberation.
dang po [phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
This chapter is the first of those three parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod de de dag gi phrad pa bstan pa'i phyir te/ mdo sde las/ mig dang gzugs la brten nas mig gi rnam par shes pa 'byung ngo zhes bya ba dang gsum 'dus pa las reg pa'o/ / reg pa dang lhan cig 'byung ba ni tshor ba'i zhes rgya cher 'byung ba dang*/ de bzhin du tshor ba dang 'du shes zhes bya ba'i chos 'di gnyis ni phrad pa yin gyi ma phrad pa ni ma yin no/ / zhes pa dang / rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba dang ma rig pa'i kun tu sbyor ba dag gis kun tu sbyar ro/ / zhes 'du byed rnams la phrad pa gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar 'dod pa dgag pa la gnyis/ phrad pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / des phrad bzhin pa la sogs pa'ang khegs par bstan pa'o/ /

Here someone might argue as follows: Things exist essentially because their contact is presented, because it says frequently in sūtra that, depending on eye and material form, visual consciousness arises. And depending on the assembly of these three, there is contact. That which arises along with contact is feeling./1/ In the same way these two phenomena called “feeling” and “discrimination” are in contact and are not out of contact. Attachment, anger, and ignorance—the three overpowering passions—overpower one. Thus, all compound phenomena involve contact. Refuting this thesis has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of contact and the demonstration that this refutes things being in the process of contact.
dang po [phrad pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of contact
['di] la gnyis/ dam bca' bzhag / sgrub byed bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: setting out the conclusion and the presentation of the argument. [263]
dang po [dam bca' bzhag] ni/
1.1.1 Setting out the conclusion
blta bya lta ba lta ba po/ / gsum po de dag gnyis gnyis dang / / thams cad kyang ni phan tshun du/ / phrad par 'gyur ba yod ma yin/ /
1. The seen, seeing, and the seer; These three—neither pairwise nor All together—do not Exist in contact with each other.

blta bya gzugs dang lta ba mig dang lta ba po rnam shes gsum po de dag las mig dang gzugs sam mig dang rnam par shes pa'am rnam par shes pa dang gzugs te gnyis gnyis dang / der ma zad gsum po thams cad kyang dus gcig tu phan tshun du phrad par 'gyur ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no/ /

The simultaneous contact of the three—the seen material form, the seeing eye, and the consciousness which is the seer—do not exist essentially: neither does their pairwise contact, viz., that of eye and material form, eye and consciousness, consciousness and material form, nor does the joint contact of the three of them all together.
de bzhin 'dod chags chags pa dang / / chags par bya ba nyon mongs pa/ / lhag ma rnams dang skye mched kyi/ / lhag ma'ang rnam pa gsum gyis so/ /
2. Similarly, desire, the desirous, and the desired And the remaining afflictions, And the remaining faculties, Should be regarded in this threefold way.

ji ltar lta ba sogs gsum la bshad pa de bzhin du 'dod chags dang chags pa'am 'dod chags dang chags par bya ba'am chags pa dang chags par bya ba yang gnyis gnyis dang gsum po thams cad kyang phan tshun dus gcig tu phrad par mi 'gyur bar blta bar bya'o/ / de ltar ji skad bshad pa de bzhin du nyon mongs pa lhag ma zhe sdang dang gti mug la sogs pa rnams dang / skye mched kyi lhag ma nyan pa dang nyan pa po dang mnyan par bya ba la sogs pa'ang rnam pa gsum gsum du sbyar ba nyid kyis gnyis gnyis dang gsum char phrad pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no/ /

Just as we explained with reference to the three (seeing, etc.) the simultaneous contact of the three—neither their pairwise contact, viz. that of desire and the desirous, desire and the desired, the desirous and the desired, nor the joint contact of the three of them all together—should be regarded as existing. In exactly the same way, this threefold approach should be understood to apply to the remaining affictions such as aversion and confusion, etc., and the remaining faculties, such as hearing, the hearer, and the heard: Neither when each triad is considered all together nor when its members are considered pairwise does contact exist inherently.
gnyis pa [sgrub byed bstan pa]
1.1.2 Presentation of the argument
['di] la gnyis/ gzhan rang bzhin gyis med pas phrad pa dgag / gcig dang tha dad la dpyad nas phrad pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of contact on the grounds that the other does not exist essentially, and refutation of contact through analysis into whether it is the same or different.
dang po [gzhan rang bzhin gyis med pas phrad pa dgag]
1.1.2.1 Refutation of contact on the grounds that the other does not exist essentially
['di] la gsum/ sbyor ba dgod pa/ tshul de gzhan la yang sbyar ba/ gtan tshigs sgrub pa'o/ /
This section has three parts: presentation of the formal argument, application of this argument to other phenomena, and demonstration that the argument is valid.
dang po [sbyor ba dgod pa] ni/
1.1.2.1.1 Presentation of the formal argument
gzhan dang gzhan du phrad 'gyur na/ / gang phyir blta bya la sogs la/ / gzhan de yod pa ma yin pa/ / de phyir phrad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
3. Since different things contact one another, But in such things as seeing There is no difference, They cannot make contact.

phrad par 'gyur ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod na phan tshun du gzhan dang gzhan du yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod dgos na zhes ldog pa'i khyab pa bsgrubs shing / gang gi phyir blta bya la sogs pa la gzhan de ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin pa de'i phyir zhes rtags bkod nas de dag la phrad pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod par mi 'gyur te zhes dam bca' brjod do/ /

If the occurrence of contact existed inherently, the different things that contact each other would have to exist inherently./2/ Having established the contrapositive categorization, using the premise “the other—such as the seen—does not exist inherently,” one draws the conclusion, “they do not have inherently existent contact.”
gnyis pa [tshul de gzhan la yang sbyar ba] ni/
1.1.2.1.2 Application of this argument to other phenomena
blta bya la sogs 'ba' zhig la/ / gzhan nyid med par ma zad kyi/ / gang yang gang dang lhan cig tu/ / gzhan pa nyid du mi 'thad do/ /
4. Not only with respect to such things as the seen Is there no such difference: When one thing and another are simultaneous, It is also not tenable that there is difference.

gzhan yang blta bar bya ba la sogs pa rgyu 'bras su gnas pa'i dngos po 'ba' zhig la gzhan ngo bo nyid kyis med par ma zad kyi/ bum snam la sogs pa'i dngos po gang yang zla bo gang dang lhan cig tu gzhan pa nyid du ngo bo nyid kyis yod par mi 'thad do/ / de'i phyir de dag la yang phan tshun du phrad pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min zhes don gyis bstan te/ dngos po thams cad la phrad pa ngo bo nyid kyis med par bstan par bzhed pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, not only is it not the case that entities existing as cause and effect, such as the seen, lack inherent difference; it is not tenable that any entity, such as pots or cloth [264] that exist simultaneously are inherently different. Therefore, this implies that their being in contact with each other does not exist inherently because it is intended to show that there is no inherently existent contact between any entities.
gsum pa [gtan tshigs sgrub pa]
1.1.2.1.3 Demonstration that the argument is valid
['di] la gnyis/ rtags bgod pa dang / de la skyon spang ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: presentation of the premise and rebutting charges against it.
dang po [rtags bgod pa] ni/
1.1.2.1.3.1 Presentation of the premise
gzhan ni gzhan la brten te gzhan/ / gzhan med par gzhan gzhan mi 'gyur/ / gang la brten te gang yin pa/ / de ni de las gzhan mi 'thad/ /

5. One different thing depends on another for its difference. Without a different thing, another would not be different. It is not tenable for that which depends on something else To be different from it.

bum pa snam bu las gzhan no zhes brjod pa'i gzhan de ni gzhan snam bu la brten nas gzhan du 'jog go / gzhan pa'i snam bu la ltos pa med par gzhan bum pa ni/ snam bu las gzhan du mi 'gyur ro zhes gzhan du 'jog pa thams cad gzhan de la brten nas 'jog dgos par sngon du bsgrubs nas/ chos gang la brten te gang yin pa de ni rten sa de las gzhan du rang bzhin gyis yod par mi 'thad do zhes khyab pa spyir brjod do/ / de nas bum pa snam bu las gzhan yin pa yang snam bu la brten nas yin pa'i phyir/ snam bu las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa min no zhes bye brag la sbyar ro/ /

The different thing in the statement “the pot is different from the cloth” is posited as different in dependence on another thing, viz., the cloth. Without depending on the other object—the cloth as a ground of difference—the other, the pot, would not be different from the cloth. This first establishes that whatever is posited as different depends for its being posited as another on something different and then thereby establishes the categorical thesis that it is not tenable for any dependent phenomenon to be inherently different from that on which it depends. Thereafter this is applied to the specific case: the pot, being different from the cloth, is also dependent upon the cloth; therefore, it is not inherently different from the cloth.
gnyis pa [de la skyon spang ba]
1.1.2.1.3.2 Rebutting charges against it
['di] la gnyis/ ma nges pa'i skyon spang ba/ ma grub pa'i skyon spang ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: rebutting the charge that it commits the fallacy of accident and rebutting the charge that the premise is not established.
dang po [ma nges pa'i skyon spang ba] ni/
1.1.2.1.3.2.1 Rebutting the charge that it commits the fallacy of accident
gal te bum pa snam bu las gzhan yin pa de snam bu la brten pa dang ltos pa'ang yin la ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa yang yin na skyon ci yod ce na/
Suppose someone says that the pot, being different from the cloth, depends upon the cloth and at the same time is inherently different from it. What would the error be?
gal te gzhan ni gzhan las gzhan/ / de tshe gzhan med par gzhan 'gyur/ / gzhan med par ni gzhan 'gyur ga / yod min de yi phyir na med/ /
6. If one different thing were different from another, Without another, a thing could be different. But without that other, that different thing does not exist. Therefore this is not the case.

gal te gzhan bum pa ni gzhan snam bu las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod na ni/ de'i tshe gzhan pa'i snam bu la ltos pa med par bum pa gcig pu la yang / snam bu las gzhan no zhes tha snyad 'dogs pa yod par 'gyur na de ni ma mthong ngo / / 'dir ni snam bu la ltos mi ltos gnyis dngos 'gal yin la bum pa snam bu las gzhan yin pa de snam bu la ltos shing / gzhan de rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub na rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis rang dbang du grub bas gzhan la rag las pa dang 'gal ba yin no/ / de yang mi rigs te gzhan snam bu la ltos pa med par ni/ bum pa snam bu las gzhan du 'gyur ba yod pa min pa/ de yi phyir na bum pa de snam bu las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du med do zhes bzlog pa 'phen no/ /

If the different thing, the pot, existed as inherently different from the other, the cloth, then without depending on the other—the cloth—as a ground of difference, the pot all by itself could be designated as different from the cloth. But this does not occur. Depending on the cloth and not depending on the cloth are mutually exclusive. The pot’s being different from the cloth is dependent on the cloth. If that other existed inherently, then in virtue of its nature, it would be existent through its own power. Therefore, it would be contradictory for it to depend on the other. [265] This would be unreasonable/3/ because, to contrapose, without depending on the other—the cloth—the pot would not be different from the cloth; so the pot is not inherently different from the cloth.

rigs pa de dag ni brgya pa las/ gang la brten nas 'byung yod pa/ / de ni rang dbang mi 'gyur ro/ / 'di kun rang dbang med pa ste/ / des na bdag ni yod ma yin/ / zhes gsungs te bdag ni rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin la 'grel pas bshad do/ / 'dir 'grel pa las bum pa snam bu las gzhan yin pa de snam bu la ltos la bum pa'i ngo bo 'grub pa snam bu la mi ltos par gsungs pa bzhin ltos grub yin min gyi khyad par rnams phyed par bya'o/ / mgo mjug kun tu 'ong ba'i rigs pa thun mong ma yin pa dka' gnas yin pas yang yang dran par bya'o // gal te khyod gzhan 'ga' zhig kyang mi 'dod na/ gzhan ni gzhan la brten te gzhan/ / zhes smra ba yang ji ltar rung zhe na/ phan tshun ltos nas grub pa'i gzhan yin pas 'jig rten pa'i tha snyad la gnas te gzhan zhes brjod pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las kyang / 'jig rten gyi tha snyad kyi dbang gis gzhan yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

The Catuḥśataka puts this argument this way: Whatever is dependently arisen Cannot be independent. None of this is independent. So all of it is selfless. [XIV: 23] The “self” is explained in the Commentary to the Catuḥśataka as inherently existent essence. [dBu ma ya 20b] Here, as the Commentary says, the pot’s being different from the cloth is dependent upon the cloth, but the existence of the pot as an entity does not depend on the cloth. [85b] A distinction should be drawn between what is and what is not dependent. One should remember that this is a crucial point; this distinctive kind of argument occurs throughout the text. Suppose someone says: If you do not posit any different thing, how could “a different thing depends on another for its difference” [5a] make sense? Since the others are established in mutual dependence according to mundane convention, they are posited as different. Buddhapālita says, Things are different in virtue of mundane convention. [221b]

'dir 'grel pa las/ 'jig rten pa'i kun rdzob tu bum snam gzhan du brjod na sa myug kyang gzhan du ci'i phyir mi smra zhes pa'i lan du/ 'jig rten pas bum snam gzhan du 'dzin pa bzhin du sa myug gzhan du mi 'dzin pa'i khyad par gsungs pa ni/ blo lhan skyes kyis bum snam rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i so so bar 'dzin pa bzhin du sa myug mi 'dzin zhes pa'i don yin gyi/ tha snyad du bum snam gzhan du yod la sa myug gzhan du med ces pa'i don min no/ / nyer len gyi rgyu 'bras la blo lhan skyes kyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i so so bar 'dzin pa'i rgyu mtshan ni sngar bshad zin to/ / bum snam rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa tha snyad du yang med kyang gzhan tsam ni tha snyad du yod de/ bum pa snam bu las gzhan yin pa de rten 'brel du gsungs pa'i phyir dang 'grel pa gnyis kyis kyang tha snyad du yod par gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Here, the Commentary, in response to the question, “If the pot and cloth are posited as different in mundane convention, then why not say that the seed and sprout are also different?” explains the distinction between ordinary people holding the pot and cloth to be different and their not holding the seed and the sprout to be different. [86a] The explanation goes as follows: While an innate mental process grasps the pot and the cloth each as existing through its own characteristic, it does not so grasp the seed and sprout. But, this does not mean that conventionally, although the pot and cloth are different, the seed and sprout are not. The argument that the innate mental process does not grasp each thing as existing distinctly through its own characteristic has been explained earlier with respect to the cause and effect of appropriation. [266] Although even conventionally there is no existence through their characteristic of the pot and cloth, their being merely different exists conventionally. This is because, as has been explained, their being different is dependently originated and both commentaries have also explained that this exists conventionally [Prasannapadā 85b, Buddhapālita 221b].

rnam shes drug dang mig gzugs la sogs pa'i yul dang dbang po drug rnams la/ ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa'i gzhan med pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis phrad pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa 'gog pa gtso bo'i don yin la/ de'i rtags ni/ gal te gzhan ni gzhan las gzhan/ / zhes pa dang /gang la brten nas gang yin pa/ / zhes sogs kyis sgrub pa yin pas rnam shes drug yul dbang las gzhan yin pa de rten 'byung du bstan dgos pas rgyu 'bras rnams kyang gzhan tsam zhig yin no/ / de lta ma yin na de dag gcig pa dang tha dad pa gang yang min pas ma grub par 'gyur te/ yod pa tsam la gcig dang tha dad dngos 'gal ma yin na bden yod la yang bden pa'i gcig dang du ma gang rung du nges pa bsgrub mi nus so/ /

The main point of the argument that the six sensory consciousnesses and the six sense faculties and their objects, such as the eye and material form, do not exist as inherently different is to refute the essential existence of contact. Its premises are provided by “if a different thing were different from another …” [6a] and “it is not tenable for that which depends on something else…” [5c], etc. Therefore the difference between the six sensory consciousnesses and their respective objects and faculties must be demonstrated to be dependently arisen. Thus cause and effect as well are merely different from one another. If that were not the case, since they would be neither identical to nor different from one another, it would follow that they do not exist. This is because, if, for that which merely exists, being different from and being identical to one another were not mutually exclusive, then the certainty that that which truly exists must be truly identical or different could not be established as well.

'o na tha snyad du gzhan skye yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/ 'dir 'jug 'grel las/ rang gi lugs kyis ngo bo nyid gsum gyi rnam gzhag gis mdo 'grel lugs gsungs pas tha snyad du gzhan dbang yang 'dod dgos mod kyang / gzhan skye dang mi mtshungs te gzhan skye'i don dang tha snyad 'dod pa ni/ 'bras bu rang ngam gzhan las skye ba gang yin snyam du grub mtha' smra bas brtags nas byed la/ des kyang 'bras bu rang dang tha dad tsam zhig las skye mi skye'i dpyod pa byed pa min gyi/ rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa yin min dpyad nas rang gi mtshan nyid kyis tha dad pa'i skye ba la gzhan skye'i tha snyad byed pa'i phyir dang /gzhan dbang gi tha snyad ni 'bras bu rang dbang du 'byung ngam snyam pa bzlog pa'i phyir rgyu rkyen gyi dbang du gyur pa tsam la mdzad pa'i phyir dang / gzhan tsam la rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i gzhan gyis ma khyab pa'i phyir ro/

Suppose that one then said, “Then it would follow that arising from another would exist conventionally!” Since Madhyamakāvatāra-bhāṣya says that according to our own system the hermeneutical approach to the sūtras is presented through the framework of the three natures, conventionally, even the other-dependent has to be posited [283a]. However, this is not like arising from another! This is because those who hold the concept of arising from another and who use that language do so on the basis of a philosophical analysis into whether effects are arisen from themselves or from something else. They do not conduct an analysis into whether or not an effect is merely arisen from itself or from another, but by conducting an analysis into whether or not they are inherently different, they use “arising from another” to refer to that which arises from something different through its own characteristic. The term “other-dependent” [267] in order to reject the idea that effects are arisen through their own power, indicates that they are merely dependent on the power of causes and conditions. Being essentially different does not follow from being merely different.
gnyis pa [ma grub pa'i skyon spang ba] ni/
1.1.2.1.3.2.2 Rebutting the charge that the premise is not established

gal te dngos po gzhan dngos po gzhan la ltos nas gzhan gyi blo 'byung na ni de de las rang bzhin gyis gzhan du med pa yin na'ang / de skad du mi smra ste gzhan nyid ces pa spyi yang yin la khyad par yang yin pa zhig yod la de gang la 'du ba yod pa'i dngos po de ni/ dngos po gzhan la ltos pa med kyang gzhan zhes brjod par bya ste de'i phyir kho bo cag la ji skad smras pa'i nyes pa med do zhes gzegs zan pa dag zer ro/ //

The Kaṇāda argue as follows: If the idea of difference came from one different thing depending on another different thing, those would not be essentially different from each other. But we do not say this. Difference is a universal as well as a particular./4/ An entity in which this/5/ is instantiated does not depend on another entity. However, it can be said that it is different. Therefore we do not commit the errors with which we are charged.
gzhan nyid gzhan la yod ma yin/ / gzhan ma yin la'ang yod ma yin/ / gzhan nyid yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan nam de nyid yod ma yin/ /
7. Difference is not in a different thing. Nor is it in a nondifferent thing. If difference does not exist, Neither difference nor identity exists.

'dir gzhan nyid ces pa'i spyi de gsal ba gzhan du grub pa la don du gzhan du yod pa ma yin te/ de la gzhan nyid don gzhan brtags pa dgos pa med pa'i phyir te/ de brtags pa ni gzhan du grub par bya ba'i phyir yin na/ gzhan du grub zin pa'i phyir ro/ / der ma zad gzhan ma yin pa gcig la'ang gzhan nyid kyi spyi don gzhan yod pa ma yin te/ de la ni khyed ltar na gzhan nyid don gzhan yod pa dang 'gal ba gcig nyid yod pa'i phyir ro/ / gcig dang gzhan gnyis gang yang min pa'i phung gsum yang med pas gzhan nyid ces pa'i spyi de ni gang la yang don gzhan du med do/ /

In response to this, we say, this universal of difference instantiated in the particular other does not exist as another object because it is not necessary to posit existent difference as another existing object. This is because to posit it that way is to establish it as other; but the particular already exists as other. Even worse, nor can you claim that a thing which is not other instantiates the universal of difference as a different object, because according to you, identity exists, which is inconsistent with otherness existing as another object. Since there is no third alternative besides identity and difference, the universal of difference is not instantiated in either of them as another object.

gal te gzhan nyid ces pa'i spyi bkag mod kyang gzhan ni re zhig yod la gzhan nyid med par ni gzhan med pas gzhan nyid ces pa'i spyi yang yod do zhe na/ gzhan nyid ces pa'i spyi sngar bshad pa ltar yod pa ma yin na gzhan nam de nyid de gcig pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin no/ / bud d+ha pA li ta las tshigs bcad de la bshad pa mi 'dra ba gnyis mdzad de snga ma dang mi 'dra'o/

Suppose someone says that although we have denied the reality of the universal of difference, the other exists; without difference there is no other; thus, the universal of difference must exist. Since as has been previously explained, the universal of otherness does not exist, neither difference nor identity—sameness—exists inherently. The Buddhapālita provides two different interpretations of this verse, which are not similar to the way it has been just explained. [221b–222b]/6/
gnyis pa [gcig dang tha dad la dpyad nas phrad pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2 Refutation of contact through analysis into whether it is the same or different
gal te lta ba la sogs pa la gzhan med do zhes bstan zin mod kyang reg pa ni gsum 'dus pa'o zhes gsungs pas/ phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod la de'i phyir lta ba la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Although it has already been explained that the other, such as seeing, does not exist, since it is said that contact is the assembly of the three, [268] contact must exist essentially. Therefore, such things as seeing exist essentially.
de ni de dang phrad pa med/ / gzhan dang gzhan yang phrad mi 'gyur/ /
8. Nothing contacts itself. Nor does one different thing contact another.

'dir lta ba la sogs pa la phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod na lta ba la pa de dag ngo bo nyid kyis gcig pa dang tha dad pa gang yin/ dang po ltar na chos de ni de nyid dang phrad pa med de chu la ma ltos pa'i 'o ma gcig pu la chu dang phrad ces mi brjod pa bzhin no/ / ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'i gzhan dang gzhan yang phrad par mi 'gyur te/ chu dang so sor gnas pa'i 'o ma la chu dang phrad pa mi smra ba bzhin no/ /

In response to this we ask: If contact existed essentially in such things as seeing, then would such things as seeing be inherently identical to or different from each other? In the first case, no phenomenon contacts itself, as one cannot say that without depending on water, the milk all by itself can contact water. One different thing that is inherently different does not contact the other, as one cannot say that when water and milk are in different places, the milk contacts the water.
gnyis pa [des phrad bzhin pa la sogs pa'ang khegs par bstan pa] ni/
1.2 Demonstration that this refutes things being in the process of contact
gal te gnyis gcig tu 'dres pa'i tshe gcig yin pas mi phrad la so sor gnas pa'i tshe yang mi phrad pas phrad pa bkag mod kyang gzhan du gyur pa phrad bzhin pa de yod pas phrad pa'ang yod do zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: When two things are combined into one, there is no contact; nor is there contact between things put in different places. Therefore, although you have denied the existence of contact since contacting that which is other exists, contact also exists.
phrad bzhin pa dang phrad pa dag / phrad pa po yang yod ma yin/ /
8c. Neither that which is being contacted, Nor the contact, nor the contactor exists.

phrad bzhin pa'ang ngo bo nyid kyis gcig tu grub na ni de nyid de dang mi phrad la ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan yin na'ang phrad par mi 'thad de ma phrad par mtshungs pa thams cad phrad par 'gyur bas so/ / gal te phyed phrad pa la 'dod na ni phyogs gcig phrad pas bdag nyid thams cad kyis phrad par rtog na gcig pa dang cha gnyis 'dod na tha dad pa la skyon brjod pas bkag go / des na phrad pa'i bya ba'i sgrub byed las su gyur pa/ phrad bzhin pa yod pa ma yin no/ / gal te phrad bzhin pa med kyang sla yi phrad pa yod do zhe na/ phrad bzhin pa med na phrad par rtsom pa med pa de la bya ba rdzogs pa can gyi phrad pa yang ni yod pa ma yin no/ / gal te phrad pa rdzogs pa med kyang sla yi gcig pa nyid kyi snga rol na gzhan du 'gyur ba'i phrad rgyu'i dngos po phrad pa po yod do zhe na/ de med na phrad par byed pa med par phrad pa'i byed pa po bya ba rdzogs par bya ba la rang dbang du gnas pa yang yod pa ma yin no/ /

If that which is being contacted existed inherently as a single thing, it could not contact itself; if on the other hand it existed inherently as something other, it would not be tenable that it makes contact. It would follow that all that is not in contact would be contacted. Suppose it were maintained that a part of it makes contact. Then if by contacting a single part it makes contact with the whole, whether you maintain that it is a single part or two different parts,/7/ this has been refuted by demonstrating the errors concerning difference. Therefore, the obejct that accomplishes the activity of contact—that which is being contacted—does not exist. Suppose one said that although that which is being contacted does not exist, that is all right:/8/ The contact exists. But when there is nothing that is being contacted, when there is no effort to contact, there could be no contact—that is, the completion of the activity. Suppose one said that although there is no completion of the activity of contact, that is all right: prior to the existence of the first one—contact—the other, which is the contactor of the entity to be contacted, exists. But when that does not exist, without the activity of contact, the agent of contact cannot independently exist to accomplish the activity of contact.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar mig dang gzugs la sogs pa'i dbang po dang yul dang rnam shes la sogs pa la phrad pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min par bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang 'grub pa dang / chos rnams la ldan pa dang phrad pa bkag pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya ba'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i mtshon byed tsam ni nye bar 'khor gyis zhus pa las/ mig ni thams cad ldan na mthong 'gyur te/ / zhes pa nas/ de phyir mig gis nam yang mthong ba med// ces pa'i mjug tu/ gang dag rang bzhin med chos 'di shes pa/ / dpa' bo de dag 'jig rten mya ngan 'da'/ / 'dod pa'i yon tan spyad kyang chags med cing / / chags pa rnam spangs sems can 'dul bar byed//'di na sems can 'ga' med srog med kyang / / mi dbang rnams ni sems can phan pa mdzad/ / sems can yod pa min yang don mdzad pa/ / de dag rnams kyi de ni dka' ba che/ / zhes bya ba nas/ de la nam yang chags pa yod ma yin/ // gang dag chos nyid 'di la mos gyur pa/ / de dag yid ni srid la chags mi 'gyur/ / zhes sogs gsungs te/ mig la sogs pa la ldan pa dang phrad pa med pa dang chags pa la sogs pa med par bstan pa dang de ltar rtogs pa'i phan yon ston pa'o/ /

[269] A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the demonstration that the sense faculties, their objects and such things as the sensory consciousnesses, and such things as the eye and material form do not inherently contact each other can also be corroborated by profound scriptures, and to demonstrate that all of the scriptures which refute the contact and possession of phenomena are explained by this chapter. The Upāliparipṛcchā-sūtra says, If the eye is associated with everything, it sees … Therefore, the eye never sees. [dKon brtseg ca 129a] Later, it says, When they understand phenomena to be essenceless, Those courageous ones transcend the world. Although they enjoy the benefits of desire, they are without attachment. Having eliminated attachment they calm sentient beings. Here although there are neither sentient beings nor life, These supreme human beings benefit sentient beings. Although sentient beings do not exist, they benefit them. Their practice is very difficult. [dKon brtseg ca 130a] And after that, it says, Those who aspire to see reality Do not have any attachment. Their minds are not attached to cyclic existence. [dKon brtseg ca 131a] … This demonstrates the benefits of understanding the absence of contact and possession with respect to the such things as the eye and in the context of such things as attachment.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

chos rnams phrad pa dang ldan pa dang 'dus pa dang tshogs pa ni rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod pa la de dag gang yang gzhag tu med pas/ de dag rang bzhin med pa la rnam gzhag de dag thams cad shin tu 'thad pa'i bden pa gnyis kyi tshul la nges pa brtan par bya'o/ /

While if the contact, possession, coalescing, and collection of phenomena existed through their own power they could not be posited, one should be firm in one’s ascertainment, through the framework of the two truths, of the tenability of all of these things when they are posited as essenceless.
phrad pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bzhi pa'o/ /
This is the fourteenth chapter called “the examination of contact.”
phrad pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa brgyad kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu bzhi pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the fourteenth chapter, having eight verses, called “the examination of contact.”
CHAPTER XV. Examination of Essence
gnyis pa rgyu rkyen nye bar len pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa
This chapter comprises the second part: the refutation of the appropriation of causes and conditions as essentially existent./1/[270]
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive Sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa dngos po rnams ni rang bzhin gyis yod de myu gu dang 'du byed la sogs pa rnams skyed par byed pa'i rgyu dang rkyen sa bon dang ma rig pa la sogs pa nye bar len pa yod pa'i phyir ro/ / de ni tshig gsal gyi mtshams sbyor tshul yin la bud d+ha pA li ta las ni smras pa/ khyod dngos po rnams rten cing 'brel bar 'byung bar yang 'dod la ngo bo nyid med par yang smra na ji ltar na dngos po byung ba yang yin la ngo bo nyid med pa yang yin par 'gyur/ gal te rgyu rkyen las dngos po'i ngo bo nyid mi 'byung na de las gzhan ci zhig 'byung ste/ rgyu spun las snam bu'i ngo bo nyid kho na mi 'byung na ci rgyu spun gyi ngo bo nyid kho na 'byung ngam ci ste ci yang mi 'byung na ni 'byung zhes kyang ji skad brjod/ ci khyod rta la zhon bzhin du rta ma mthong ngam khyod dngos po rnams rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba zhes kyang smra la de dag gi ngo bo nyid med pa nyid kyang ma mthong zhes gsungs te/ dngos po rnams la ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa'i ngo bo nyid cung zad kyang mi rung ba dang / 'on kyang rgyu rkyen la brten nas dngos po 'byung bar 'dod pa gnyis 'gal bar 'dzin pa mi 'gal bar rab byed 'dis 'chad par mtshams sbyor te/ de gnyis 'dres pa 'byed pa 'di nyid rigs pa rnams kyi gnad che shos so/ / de ltar rang bzhin gyis grub par smra ba dgag pa la gnyis/ dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / rang bzhin gyis yod par smra na mthar 'dzin las mi 'da' bar bstan pa'o/ /

Here one might say that things exist essentially, because there is appropriation of such things as causes, conditions, seeds, and ignorance, which give rise to such things as sprouts and actions, respectively. This is the motivational introduction to the chapter in Prasannapadā, [87b] but Buddhapālita motivates it as follows: You maintain that all phenomena are dependently arisen and at the same time that they are not inherently existent. But how could things arise and not exist inherently? If the nature of things does not arise from causes and conditions, then what else could arise from them? If the nature of the cloth does not come from the warp and weft, do they simply give rise to warp and weft themselves? If nothing arises from them, why do we say “It arises”? We respond: Are you not the man riding the horse who does not see that horse? While you say that things are dependently arisen, you do not see that they are not inherently existent? [224a] Thus, this provides a motivational introduction to this chapter, which explains that it is not contradictory to say that it is inconsistent for things to have even the slightest nature of inherent existence and to be arisen from causes and conditions. The most important point of this argument is to distinguish rather than to confuse these two. The refutation of essence has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of things and the demonstration that maintaining that things exist essentially cannot avoid the extremes.
dang po [dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of things
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag / rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gnod byed bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the argument for inherent existence and undermining inherent existence.
dang po [dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of the argument for inherent existence
['di] la gsum/ dngos kyi don dang / des mtha' gzhan gsum khegs par bstan/ bkag pa'i don du lta ba smad pa'o/ //

This section has three parts: the main point, the demonstration that thereby the other three extremes are refuted, [271] and condemnation of the reificationist view of the meaning of those refutations.
dang po [dngos kyi don]
1.1.1.1 The main point
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin la rgyu rkyen mi dgos shing 'gal bar bstan pa/ rang tshugs kyi rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid bstan pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: the demonstration that cause and effect are not necessary in the context of essence and that they are inconsistent with it, and the presentation of the defining characteristic of essence in our system.
dang po [rang bzhin la rgyu rkyen mi dgos shing 'gal bar bstan pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Demonstration that cause and effect are not necessary in the context of essential existence and that they are inconsistent with it
rang bzhin rgyu dang rkyen as ni/ / 'byung ba rigs pa ma yin no/ / rgyu dang rkyen las gang 'byung ba'i/ / rang bzhin byas pa can du 'gyur/ /
1. Essence arising from Causes and conditions makes no sense. Essence arisen from causes and conditions Would be created.

gal te 'du byed dang myu gu la sogs pa la rang bzhin yod na ni ma rig pa dang sa bon la sogs pa'i rgyu dang rkyen las ni 'byung bar rigs pa ma yin te/ rang bzhin du yod pa la skyed byed dgos pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste skyes pa'i snga rol du yod na skye ba don med du 'gyur yang snga rol du yod pa min pa'i rang bzhin kho na rgyu rkyen la brten nas 'byung ngo snyam na/ de lta na rgyu dang rkyen las byung ba yi phyir 'bras bu'i rang bzhin de byas pa can du 'gyur ro/ / ci ste byas par thal ba ni 'dod pa kho na yin no snyam na/ byas pa yang yin la rang bzhin yang yin no zhes ji lta bur na smra bar rung bar 'gyur te mi 'gyur te phan tshun 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ // de la bcos ma bcos gnyis ni dngos 'gal yin pas gzhi gcig la gcig rnam par bcad na gcig shos yongs su gcod dgos so/ / byas pa la ni bcos mas khyab la rang bzhin te gshis la ni ma bcos pas khyab pas byas pa yin pa dang gshis yin pa gnyis gzhi gcig la 'dur mi rung ngo / / 'jig rten na'ang chu'i tsha ba dang ke ke ru la sogs pa nor sgyur mkhan gyis bcos ma'i pad+ma rA ga la sogs par bsgyur ba la de dag gi rang bzhin du mi brjod pa bzhin no/ / 'o na 'jig rten na me'i tsha ba dang pad+ma rA ga la sogs pa rigs du ma'i ngo bo ni de dag gi rang bzhin du brjod pas byas pa gang yin gshis min par ji ltar rigs snyam na/

If actions or such things as sprouts had essential existence, then it would make no sense for them to arise from causes and conditions such as ignorance or seeds because that which exists esentially does not need anything to bring it into existence. Suppose someone said: If a thing existed prior to its arising then there would be no point in its arising again; but that very essence which does not exist earlier arises depending on causes and conditions. In that case, since it has arisen in dependence on causes and conditions, that which has the nature of the effect would be created. Suppose one then said that she or he accepts the consequence that it is created. Candrakīrti asks, “How could it make sense that it is an essence and also created?” [88a] It cannot, because they are mutually exclusive. Since the two—being created and being uncreated—are mutually exclusive, if one is eliminated in one basis, the other must be affirmed in that basis. The created is categorized as constructed. Since essence, which is nature, is categorized as unconstructed, being created and being a nature cannot be co-present in the same basis, like the heat of water or, just as in everyday life, when a chemist makes such things as an artificial padma rā ga out of such ingredients as ke ke ru, it is not called their essence./2/ But suppose one argued as follows: In everyday life, since the heat of the fire and such things as the padma rā ga, which have the nature of being naturally developed,/3/ is called their essence, how could it be that everything created is not a nature?

'jig rten na bcos ma la rang bzhin nam gshis kyi tha snyad mi byed pa ni 'dir yang khas len la/ de lta na me'i tsha ba me'i rang bzhin nam gshis su 'jig rten na grags mod kyang de yang me'i gshis ma yin te/ gshis kyi mtshan nyid dang bral ba'i phyir ro zhes smra ba yin te/ me ni me shel la sogs pa'i rgyu rkyen la ltos par dmigs la de'i tsha ba yang de dang 'dra bas/byas pa'i phyir chu'i tsha ba bzhin du rang bzhin ma yin no zhes gsal bar nges so/ / 'dir chu'i tsha ba dang me'i tsha ba gnyis rgyu rkyen gyis byas par mtshungs kyang bcos ma yin min mi mtshungs pas rang bzhin yin min kyang mi mtshungs so snyam du 'jig rten pa la grags mod kyang / dngos por smra ba rnams ni chu tsha bar skyes pa dang me tsha ba ra skyes pa la rang bzhin gyis skyes ma skyes kyi khyad par mi 'dod pas/ 'jig rten na bcos mar 'jog na rang bzhin du tha snyad mi byed pa'i tshul de khas mi len zhing rang lugs la de ltar khas len no/ / byis pa rnams dngos po rang bzhin med pa la rang bzhin yod par zhen nas de chos de kho na la mthong zhing chos gzhan la ma mthong ba na/ me'i rang gi mtshan nyid ni tsha ba'o zhes zhen pa ji lta ba bzhin du mtshan nyid smra ste/ bdag nyid kyi mtshan nyid ni rang gi mtshan nyid do zhes byas pa'i phyir ro/ / de dag la grags pa'i sgo nas ston pas kyang chos mngon par de dag gi rang gi ngo bo kun rdzob pa rnam par bzhag la/ mi rtag pa la sogs pa chos gzhan dang thun mong ba ni spyi'i mtshan nyid do zhes bshad do/ /

In everyday life, when something is constructed, we do not ordinarily say that it is a nature or essence. We also accept this and therefore we assert that, [272] although in everyday life the heat of fire is known as the essence or nature of fire, it is not the nature of fire because it lacks the characteristic of a nature. This is because fire is seen to occur in dependence on such things as a burning glass as causes and conditions, and similarly for its heat. Therefore, it can be clearly ascertained that since it is created, just like the heat of water, it is not an essence. Although the heat of the fire and the heat of the water are similar in that they are both created by causes and conditions, they are not similar with respect to whether or not they are constructed. Thus, although they are also not similar with respect to whether or not they are known as essences in everyday life, reificationists do not draw the distinction between the arisen heat of water and the arisen heat of fire in terms of whether or not they are essentially arisen. Thus, in everyday life, if something is regarded as constructed, it is not accepted that there is no way to call it an essence. In our own system we accept that. Fools, being fixated on the essence of essenceless things, seeing that in those very phenomena, but not seeing it in other phenomena, just as they are fixated on heat being the characteristic of fire, maintain that it is a characteristic because it is said that the characteristic is that in virtue of which one exists through one’s own characteristic. In accordance with their understanding, the teacher, in the Abhidharma, also set out the individual natures of these things as conventional. He explained that such things as impermanence, which are commonly shared with others, are universal characteristics.

de la tsha ba me dang mi rtag pa 'dus byas kyi gshis yin pa tha snyad du yang med kyang thun mong yin min gyi mtshan nyid las/ rang gi mtshan nyid dang spyi'i mtshan nyid du mngon pa las gsungs pa ltar tha snyad du yod pa rang lugs so/ // de'i phyir rang gi mtshan nyid kyis sam rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa dang thun mong ma yin pa'i rang gi mtshan nyid gnyis khyad par shin tu che'o/ /

So neither does heat as the nature of fire nor impermanence as that of the produced exist conventionally. However, it is explained in the Abhidharma that a characteristic is universal or particular in virtue of either being or not being shared. They exist conventionally in our own system exactly as this is presented in the Abhidharma. Therefore there is a big difference between something existing through its own characteristic and existing inherently, on the one hand, and a thing having a particular characteristic that is not shared, on the other. [273]

'grel pa las/ de rnams la grags pa nyid kyi sgo nas chos mngon par rang spyi'i mtshan nyid bshad par gsungs pa ni/ byis pa rnams ni chos gang dang gang gi mtshan nyid yin pa de dang de ni de dag gi gshis su 'dzin pas de ma bkag par de dag la mtshan nyid gnyis bshad pa la bya yi/ me'i tsha ba la sogs pa gshis yin par 'dzin pa bzhin du mngon pa las kyang de dag gi gshis la mtshan nyid gnyis su bzhag ces pa min te/ 'jug pa las / de dag shes rab tshul mdor sangs rgyas kyis/ / mtshungs par spangs shing mngon pa'i chos las gsungs/ / zhes gsungs shing

The statement in the Commentary that “the Abhidharma has explained the particular and universal characteristics of phenomena in accordance with their understanding” [88b] means that fools grasp the characteristics of phenomena as their natures, and therefore that without refuting this, these two natures are explained to them. This does not mean that the Abhidharma also presents the two kinds of characteristics as natures in the way that we grasp such things as the heat of the fire as its nature. According to the Madhyamakāvatāra, Although the Buddha through the approach taken in the Prajñāpāramitā Eliminates them equally, in the Abhidharma they are presented. [VI: 92]

'grel par yang mngon pa las rang spyi'i mtshan nyid la sogs pa'i rab dbye'i sgo nas phung po lnga char mtshungs par bstan cing / yum gyi mdo las lnga char rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid du gsungs pas don dam par med mnyam dang tha snyad du yod mnyam du gsungs pa'i phyir dang / me'i tsha ba me'i gshis yin pa tha snyad du yang mi 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / des na me'i tsha ba lta bu de rang khas mi len pas gzhan grags zer ba min gyi/ me'i tsha ba dang me'i rang bzhin gnyis so sor mi phyed par gcig tu bzung ba de nyid rang la ma grub pas gzhan la grags pa tsam du 'jog go /

The Commentary also demonstrates, in the Abhidharma, through such things as the classification of universal and particular characteristics, the five aggregates are presented as having the same status. But in the “Mother” Sūtra4 [Sher phyin kha 20a] all five are presented as essentially empty [88b]. Therefore, they are explained to be equally ultimately nonexistent and equally conventionally existent. And the heat of the fire being its nature is not accepted even conventionally. The reason that we say that this is accepted by others is not that we don’t accept such things as the heat of fire as its nature. But since we do not accept the heat of the fire and the nature of the fire as identical without distinguishing them, that is presented as merely “accepted by others.”
gnyis pa [rang tshugs kyi rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid bstan pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2 Presentation of the defining characteristic of essence in our system
gal te byas pa yin pas rang bzhin min no zhes smra na rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid ni gang rang bzhin de yang gang zhe na/
Suppose one asked, “Since it is said that if something is created it is not an essence, then what is the characteristic of essence, and what is essence?”
rang bzhin byas pa can zhes byar/ / ci lta bur na rung bar 'gyur/ / rang bzhin dug ni bcos min dang / / gzhan la ltos pa med pa yin/ /
2. How could it be appropriate To call that which is created “essence”? Essence itself is not constructed And does not depend on another.

'di na rang gi ngo bo ni rang bzhin no zhes tha snyad byed pas gang zhig dngos po gang gi bdag gi ba yin pa de ni de'i rang bzhin no zhes brjod do/ / gang zhig gang gi bdag gi ba yin zhe na chos can gang gi chos gang ma bcos pa de ni de'i'o/'o/ / gang zhig bcos ma yin pa de ni de'i bdag gi ba ma yin te dper na chu'i tsha ba lta bu'o/ / gang zhig gzhan la rag ma las pa de ni de'i bdag gi ba yin te/ dper na rang gi khol po dang rang gi nor dag bzhin no/ / gang zhig gzhan la rag las pa de ni de'i bdag gi ba ma yin te/ dper na re zhig brnyan po rang dbang med pa lta bu'o/ / de ltar gsungs pas ni bcos ma dang chos de las gzhan pa la rag las pa thams cad chos de'i bdag gi ba min par ston pa min gyi/ chos de'i rang bzhin nam gshis su 'jog pa'i bdag gi ba de la de'i bcos ma min pa dang de las gzhan la rag las pa'i g.yar po lta bu min pa zhig dgos par ston no/ /

Here, a thing’s nature is called its essence. Therefore, it is said that whatever nature belongs to a thing is its essence. What is that which belongs to it? The unconstructed characteristics of the characterized. That which is constructed is not that which belongs to it like, for example, the heat of the water. Whatever does not depend on another is also that which belongs to it like, for example, [274] one’s servant or one’s wealth. That which depends on another is not that which belongs to the self, just as, for example, a debtor is not a debtor all by himself. By saying this, he does not mean that no phemonema that are constructed and that depend on other phenomena belong to those phenomena; but instead presents that which is regarded as the essence or nature of a phenomenon, which has to belong to it, as having to be nonconstructed and not, like a debtor, dependent on another.

de'i phyir me'i gnyug ma'i ngo bo bcos ma min pa sngar med gsar skyes pa min pa dang dus gsum du yang me la mi 'khrul ba/ chu'i tsha ba'am tshu rol dang pha rol lam ring thung ltar rgyu rkyen gzhan la ltos pa med pa de ni me'i rang bzhin dag ni yin par brjod do/ / ci me'i rang gi ngo bo de lta bur gyur pa yod dam zhe na/ de ni rang gi ngo bos yod pa yang min la med pa yang min zhes gsungs te yod mod kyi rang gi ngo bos yod pa min zhes pa'i don yin te 'jug 'grel las/ de la don dam pa ni yang dag pa gzigs pa rnams kyi ye shes kyi khyad par gyi yul nyid kyis bdag gi rang gi ngo bo rnyed pa yin gyi rang gi bdag nyid kyis grub pa ni ma yin te zhes gsungs pa ltar ro/ /

Therefore, the essence of fire is defined as follows: the intrinsic nature of fire, not constructed, not newly arisen without having existed earlier, and in all three temporal periods inextricable from fire; not—like the heat of water or the far shore and the near shore or the long and short—dependent on other causes and conditions. Suppose someone asked, “If the nature of fire is like that, does it exist?” It is said that it neither exists inherently nor is it nonexistent. This means that, although it exists, it does not exist inherently. As the Madhyamakāvatāra-bhāṣya says, The ultimate, through being the special object of the insight of those who see perfectly, is found to be the self’s own nature, but is not the self’s inherent existence. [253a]

rang gi ngo bos med pa de lta yin mod kyang nyan pa po rnams kyi skrag pa spang ba'i phyir sgro btags nas kun rdzob tu de yod do zhes bya bar smra'o/ / 'dir dgos pa de'i phyir yod par gsungs pas don dam bden pa shes bya min no zhes smra ba ni mi rigs te chos yang dag par sdud pa las/ 'jig rten gyi skrag pa'i gnas yongs su spang ba'i phyir tha snyad kyi dbang gis skye'o 'gag go zhes gsungs kyi/ zhes gsungs pas skye 'gag kyang shes bya ma yin par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / sgro btags nas zhes gsungs pas don dam bden pa shes bya min no zhes pa yang mi rigs te/ sgro btags nas yod par gsungs pa'i shes byed du/ yi ge med pa'i chos la ni/ / nyan pa gang yin ston pa gang*/ / sgro btags pa la yi ge med/ / de ni nyan zhing ston pa'ang yin/ / ba cas bya ba' rnam bshad rigs pa'i rgya mtsho/ zhes ting nge 'dzin rgyal po drangs pa las nyan mkhan dang bshad mkhan dang bshad bya'i chos rnams kyang sgro btags nas byed par gsungs pas de rnams kyang shes bya ma yin par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ // des na blos btags nas ston pa la yang sgro btags nas zhes gsungs pa mang po yod pas bdag gnyis sgro btags pa 'dra ba yin mi dgos so/ /

It is said that even though, as presented here, things do not exist inherently, the claim that things exist conventionally is fabricated in order to allay the anxiety of those who hear this. Here it does not make sense to say that since things are said to exist just for that reason, the ultimate is not knowable. Candrakīrti says, This is because Sañcayagāthā says, In order to allay the anxiety of ordinary beings, things are said to arise and cease through the power of convention. [m Do sde Sha 43a] It would then follow that arising and ceasing as well are not objects of knowledge. Saying that “fabricated” means that the ultimate is not an object of knowledge does not make sense. [275] As a proof that things exist through fabrication the Samādhirāja-sūtra is quoted: Without letters, how could the teaching Be presented and heard, and by what teacher? That which is fabricated is without letters, And can neither be heard nor taught./5/ Therefore, since all these phenomena, including the listener and the speaker and the speech, are said to be fabricated, it would also follow that they are not objects of knowledge. Therefore, since there are many places where “fabricated” refers to that which is presented by mental imputation, it is not necessary that the two selves are similar in the respect that they are both fabricated./6/

gal te sgro btags pa las de yod do zhes brjod na de ji 'dra ba zhig yin zhe na/ de'i rang gi ngo bo ni chos rnams kyi chos nyid ces pa de yin no zhes sogs ni sngar gyi dri ba gnyis pa'i lan no/ // de ni chos rnams kyi ngo bo dang ngo bo ni rang bzhin dang rang bzhin ni stong nyid dang stong nyid ni rang bzhin med pa dang de ni de bzhin nyid dang de yang de bzhin nyid kyi ngo bor 'gyur ba med pa dang rtag tu gnas pa'o/ / ma rig pa'i rab rib kyi mthus dmigs pa 'di rnams de kho na nyid du yod na 'phags pa'i mnyam bzhag zag pa med pa'i ye shes kyis dmigs dgos pa las/ de rnams ci yang ma gzigs pa'i tshul gyis de dag gi de kho na nyid de ye shes de'i yul du 'gyur te/ ye shes des ni dngos po rnams kyi de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i phyir dang dngos po rnams de kho na nyid du ma grub pa de nyid de dag gi de kho na nyid yin pa'i phyir dang / / dgag bya yod na dmigs su rung ba las ma dmigs pa nyid kyis dgag bya bkag pa rtogs par 'jog pa'i phyir ro/ / mthong ba med pa ni mthong ba dam pa'o zhes gsungs pa'i don yang ci yang mi mthong ba mthong bar mi bzhed kyi/ sngar bshad pa ltar spros pa ma mthong ba ni spros bral mthong bar 'jog pas mthong ma mthong gzhi gcig la byed pa min no/ /

Suppose someone asked, “How could it be said that things exist through fabrication?” Here, “Their own nature is that which is the reality of phenomena …” [Prasannapadā 89b] is the response to this second question./7/ That reality is the nature of phenomena, that nature is essence, that essence is emptiness, that emptiness is essencelessness, and that is the way things are and that is the immutable nature of the way things really are, and it is eternally existent. If objects really existed as they are perceived through the mists of ignorance, they would have to be so perceived through the uncontaminated insight of the noble beings in meditative equipoise. But although from that perspective they are not perceived even the slightest bit, the way those things really are is the object of that insight. This is because that insight comprehends the way entities really exist, and because the nonexistence of the entities as things really stand is the very way that things really are. This is also because if the object of negation existed it would have to be perceived. So, just in virtue of its not being perceived, the negation of the object of refutation is taken to be perceived. [276] The meaning of the statement “nonseeing is the most exalted seeing” is not asserted to be that to have not seen anything is to have seen. Instead, as has been previously explained, to have not seen the fabricated is to have seen free from fabrication. Therefore to have seen and not to have seen are not grounded on the same basis.

de ltar yang sdud pa las/ gzugs rnams mi mthong tshor ba dag kyang mi mthong zhing / / 'du shes mthong ba med la sems pa mi mthong zhing*/ / gang la rnam par shes dang sems yid mthong med pa/ / 'di ni chos mthong yin zhes de bzhin gshegs pas bstan/ nam mkha' mthong zhes sems can tshig tu rab brjod pa/ / nam mkha' ji ltar mthong ste des 'di brtag par gyis/ / de ltar chos mthong ba yang de bzhin gshegs pas bstan/ / mthong ba dpe gzhan gyis ni bsnyad par nus ma yin/ // zhes mi mthong ba phung po lnga dang mthong ba ni chos zhes gsungs la de ni de kho na nyid kyi don te sus rten 'brel mthong ba des chos mthong ngo zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / de yang dper na nam mkha' ni thogs pa'i reg bya bcad tsam yin la de mthong ngam rtogs pa ni dgag bya sgrib thogs yod na dmigs su rung ba las ma mthong ba la byed pa dang 'dra ste der yang mthong ba ni nam mkha' dang ma mthong ba ni sgrib thogs so/ // dpe de bzhin du mthong ba min par sngon po mthong ba bzhin du de kho na nyid mthong ba ni rkang pa tha mas bkag go / phung po lnga mi mthong bar gsungs pas ni zag med kyi mnyam bzhag gis chos can mthong ba min par bstan to/ / de ltar na de kho na nyid mthong ba dngos min par btags pa tsam yang min la don dam de rang gi ngo bos grub par yang mi 'gyur ro/ / de 'dra ba'i rang bzhin du chos can thams cad ma grub kyang chos nyid rnams grub la rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin du ni chos gang yang grub pa med do/ /

The Sañcayagāthā says, Neither are physical forms not seen nor are feelings seen. Neither perception nor awareness are seen. Where awareness and consciousness are not seen, There, the Tathāgata has said, the Dharma is seen. Sentient beings express in words that the sky is seen. Examine how the sky is seen! The Thatāgata has said that the Dharma should be seen in the same way. Seeing cannot be explained by any other example. [Sher phyin sna Tshogs ka 8b] What is not seen are the five aggregates; what is seen is the Dharma, and that means the way things really are, as it has been said that whoever sees dependent arising sees the Dharma. For example, space is just the absence of obstruction to contact. To see or to perceive it is not to see the object of negation which, if it existed, would be perceptible. This is similar because in the example, what is seen is space and what is not seen are the obstacles. The last line refutes seeing the way things really are to be just like seeing blue instead of seeing it as presented in this example. By saying that the five aggregates are not seen, it is shown that in uncontaminated meditative equipoise one does not see the characterized. And so, it is not the case that seeing the way things really are is not real seeing, but is merely so-called. But it does not follow that the ultimate exists inherently. No phenomena exist having that kind of essence. Nonetheless, their realities exist. But no phenomena whatever exist with the essence of inherent existence.
gnyis pa [des mtha' gzhan gsum khegs par bstan] ni/
1.1.1.2 Demonstration that thereby the other three extremes are refuted

gal te yang dngos po rnams rang bzhin du yod pa bkag pas rang dngos bkag mod kyang gzhan dngos ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma bkag pa'i phyir de yod na rang bzhin yang rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: although by refuting any entity having essence, you have refuted them having their own nature [277] the nature of being other8 exists essentially, since you have not refuted it. Since it does, essence exists essentially.
rang bzhin yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan gyi dngos po ga la yod/ / gzhan gyi dngos po'i rang bzhin no/ / gzhan gyi dngos po yin zhes brjod/ /
3. Since there is no essence/9/ How can there be the nature of being other? The essence of the nature of being other Is what is called the nature of being other.

gal te tsha ba me'i rang bzhin du grub na gsher ba'i rang bzhin la ltos nas gzhan gyi dngos por 'jog tu rung na/ gang gi tshe rnam par dpyad pa na dngos po gang yang rang bzhin du yod pa ma yin na de'i tshe gzhan gyi dngos po rang bzhin gyis ga la yod ces pa med de/ gzhan gyi dngos po'i rang bzhin te ngo bo rang bzhin gyis grub pa la gzhan gyi dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub pa yin zhes brjod pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te rang gi rang bzhin te ngo bo dang gzhan gyi dngos po ste ngo bo gnyis bkag mod kyang dngos po ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma bkag pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

If heat existed as the essence of fire, then, depending on the essence of liquidity, it could be regarded as having the nature of being other. Since, upon analysis no entity exists essentially, how could the nature of being other exist essentially? It could not, because in the phrase “the essence of the nature of being other” that essence—that is, the entity—that exists essentially is what is called “the essentially existent nature of being other.” Now, suppose one argued as follows: Although you have refuted both its own essence—that is, entity—and the nature—or entity—of being other, things do exist essentially, because this is not refuted.
rang bzhin dang ni gzhan dngos dag / ma gtogs dngos po gang la yod/ / rang bzhin dag ni gzhan dngos dag / yod na dngos po 'grub par 'gyur/ /
4. Without having either essence or the nature of being other, How could things exist? If essence or the nature of being other existed,/10/ Entities would be established.

rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos ma gtogs pa'i dngos po ga la yod de med pas rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos gang rung gcig tu ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'grub par 'gyur yang de gnyis sngar bkag pas med do// gal te yang khyod kyis dngos po bkag mod kyi dngos med ni ma bkag pas rang bzhin gyis yod de de yod na 'gal zla yod pas dngos po yang yod do zhe na/

How could things exist without having either essence or the nature of being other? They could not, because if either essence or the nature of being other existed inherently, entities would be established as existing essentially. But both of them have been refuted earlier, so they do not. Suppose you then argued as follows: Even though entity has been refuted, nonentity has not been refuted. Therefore, it exists essentially, and because if one exists, the opposite member of the pair exists, so entity exists as well.
gal te dngos po ma grub na/ / dngos med 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / dngos po gzhan du 'gyur ba ni/ / dngos med yin par skye bo smra/ /
5. Since entity does not exist, Nonentity does not exist. People say that an entity that transforms into another Is a nonentity.

gal te dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma grub na dngos med rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'grub par mi 'gyur te/ bum pa la sogs pa'i dngos po da ltar ba'i gnas skabs las gzhan du gyur pa ni sngar gyi dngos po de med pa yin par 'jig rten na skye bo dag smra ba'i phyir ro/ / 'dir dgag bya shes bya la mi srid pa'i dngos med la yang bden pa dgag dgos mod kyang / dgag bya yod med la bden 'dzin shas che chung gi gnad kyis dgag bya dngos po yod pa zhig pa de'i dngos med bden med du grub na dngos med gzhan bden med du 'grub sla ba la dgongs so/ /

Since entity does not exist essentially, nonentity does not exist essentially. This is because when an entity such as a pot transforms from its current state into another, it is ordinarily said that the previous entity becomes nonexistent. Here it is necessary to refute the true existence of nonentity—the object of negation—which cannot possibly be an object of knowledge. However, the point is this: since one can grasp the true existence or nonexistence of the object of negation to different degrees, if the nonentity of a disintegration of an existent object of negation is established to be not truly existent, to establish other nonentities to be not truly existent will be easier.
gsum pa [bkag pa'i don du lta ba smad pa] ni/
1.1.1.3 Condemnation of the reificationist view of the meaning of those refutations.
gang dag rang bzhin gzhan dngos dang / / dngos dang dngos med nyid lta ba/ / de dag sangs rgyas bstan pa la/ / de nyid mthong ba ma yin no/ /
6. Those who see essence, the nature of being other And entities and nonentities: They do not see the reality of The Buddha’s doctrine.

de ltar rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos dang dngos po dang dngos med ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ma yin pa la gang dag gsung rab phyin ci ma log par 'chad par rlom pa nyid kyi/ sa'i rang bzhin sra ba dang tshor ba'i rang bzhin yul myong ba zhes sogs kyis rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos gnyis dang / rnam shes la sogs pa da ltar ba ni dngos po dang de dag 'das pa la sogs pa ni dngos po med pa nyid du ngo bo nyid kyis yod par lta ba de dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi bstan pa la rten 'byung mchog tu zab pa'i de kho na nyid mthong ba dang smra ba ma yin no/ / 'di ltar rang bzhin la sogs pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ni rigs pa dang 'gal ba yin la rgyal ba rnams ni dngos po'i rang bzhin rigs pa dang 'gal ba bzhed pa yang ma yin te/ dngos po thams cad kyi de kho na nyid phyin ci ma log par thugs su chud pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir mkhas pa rnams ni rgyal ba kho na'i gsung tshad mar byed de 'thad pa dang bcas pas mi slu ba'i phyir ro/ / lung gi skad dod kyi steng nas bshad pa byas pas nyes pa thams cad zad pa'i yid ches pa las 'ongs pas lung dang / kun tu go bar byed pa ste de kho na nyid kun nas go bar byed pa'i phyir lung dang / mngon du phyogs nas 'gro ba ste 'di la brten nas 'jig rten mya ngan las 'das par 'gro ba'i phyir rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi gsung nyid lung du bzhag la/ de las gzhan gyi gzhung lugs ni 'thad pa dang bral bas lung ma yin par bzhag go /

[278] So neither essence, nor the nature of being other, nor entities nor nonentities exist inherently. However, those who pretend to be interpreting the scriptures nonerronenously, who see “the essence of earth to be solidity and the essence of feeling to be the experience of the object, etc.” [Prasannapadā 90b], as “essence” and “the nature of being other;” “consciousness, etc., which are present” [ibid.], as “entities;” and “the past of that which is present, etc.” [ibid.], as “nonentities,” and see all of them as existing inherently, neither see nor present the profound reality of dependent origination taught in the doctrine of the transcendent Buddha. So the inherent existence of such things as essence is contrary to reason. The victors do not posit that essence of entities which is contrary to reason, because they nonerroneously realize the way all phenomena really are. Therefore, scholars regard only the teachings of the Victor as authentic because, since it is absolutely cogent, it is nondeceptive. The explanations of the etymology of the Sanskrit word āgama [lung]go as follows: It is called āgama because it came through reliable sources who have eliminated all faults;/11/ and it is called āgama because it brings about complete understanding; that is, it brings about understanding of the way things really are;/12/ and it is called āgama because it leads to liberation and, by relying on it, beings depart for nirvana; therefore the teaching of the completely enlightened one is called āgama.13 The teachings other than this lack absolute accuracy, and therefore they are not regarded as āgama.
gnyis pa [rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gnod byed bstan pa]
1.1.2 Undermining inherent existence
['di] la gnyis/ lung gi gnod byed dang / rigs pa'i gnod byed do/ /
This section has two parts: undermining it through sūtra and undermining it through reasoning.
dang po [lung gi gnod byed] ni/
1.1.2.1 Undermining it through Sūtra
bcom ldan dngos dang dngos med pa/ / mkhyen pa ka t+yA ya na yi/ / gdams ngag las ni yod pa dang / / med pa gnyi ga'ang dgag par mdzad/ /
7. The Transcendent Lord, through understanding Entity and nonentity, In the Discourse to Kātyāyana Refuted both existence and nonexistence.

gang gi phyir rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos dang dngos po dang dngos med ngo bo nyid kyis yod par lta ba rigs pa dang bral bas de kho na nyid ma yin pa de'i phyir/ gdul ba'i skye bo thar pa 'dod pa rnams la bcom ldan 'das kyis ka ta ya na yi gdams ngag ces bya ba'i mdo las/ ka ta ya na gang gi phyir 'jig rten 'di ni phal cher yod pa nyid dang med pa nyid la mngon par zhen te/ des na skye ba dang rga ba dang na ba dang 'chi ba dang mya ngan dang smre sngags 'don pa dang sdug bsngal ba dang yid mi bde ba dang / 'khrug pa dag las yongs su grol bar mi 'gyur 'chi ba'i gdung ba'i sdug bsngal las yongs su grol bar mi 'gyur/ zhes yod pa dang med pa'i mtha' gnyis ka'ang dgag par mdzad do/ / mdo sde 'di yang sde pa thams cad kyis 'don pa yin pas lung 'di dang ji skad bshad pa'i rigs pa las ni rang bzhin la sogs pa bzhi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par khas mi blang ngo / / bcom ldan 'das cis khyad par du 'phags pa zhe na/ dngos po dang dngos po med pa'i rang bzhin phyin ci ma log par mkhyen pa'o/ /

Since seeing essence, the nature of being other, entity and nonentity as inherently existent is irrational, it is not the way things really are. [279] Therefore, the Transcendent Lord in the sūtra known as the Discourse to Kātyāyana, says to followers who aspire to liberation, Oh, Kātyāyana, Since in this world, most people are fixated on existence and nonexistence, they are unable completely to escape birth, aging, illness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, anxiety, and conflict.… They are unable completely to escape the sufferings of the agony of death. [Phran tshegs tha 283a] Thus he refutes the two extremes of existence and nonexistence. Since this sūtra is accepted by all schools, they, in accordance with this sūtra and the arguments previously explained, do not accept the inherent existence of the four including such things as essence. In virtue of what is the Transcendent Lord especially exalted? In virtue of his nonerroneous understanding of entity, nonentity, and essence!
gnyis pa [rigs pa'i gnod byed] ni/
1.1.2.2 Undermining it through reasoning
gal te rang bzhin gyis yod na/ / de ni med nyid mi 'gyur ro/ / rang bzhin gzhan du 'gyur ba ni/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
8. If something existed essentially,/14/ Then it could not become nonexistent. Essence transforming into something other Could never be tenable.

gzhan yang gal te me la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod na de'i tshe rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i rang bzhin de ni slar yang gzhan du 'gyur ba'i sgo nas med pa nyid du mi 'gyur ro/ / gang gi phyir rang bzhin gyis yod pa gzhan du 'gyur ba ni nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir te nam mkha'i mi sgrib pa nam yang gzhan du mi 'gyur ba bzhin no/ / rnam par 'gyur ba'i chos can yang yin pa'i phyir chu'i tsha ba ltar rang bzhin ma yin no/ / gal te rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gzhan 'gyur med pa'i phyir dang gzhan 'gyur yang dmigs pa'i phyir/ dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no zhes smra na

Moreover, if such things as fire existed essentially, then the essentially existing essence could not become nonexistent through transforming into something else. Just as the unobstructedness of space could never become something else, it is never tenable for that which is essentially existent to become something other. Things that have transformed, like the heat of the water, are not essences. We can put the point this way: Anything that exists essentially cannot change into something else. So, since things are observed transforming into something else, things do not exist essentially.
rang bzhin yod pa ma yin na/ / gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin/ /
9. If there is no essence, What could transform into something else?

rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin na'ang gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin par 'gyur/ de'i phyir rang bzhin gyis yod pa min pa la gzhan 'gyur mi 'thad la de yang mthong ba'i phyir dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/
Therefore, one might say, if there were no essence, transformation into something else would make no sense; so since this is seen, entities exist essentially.
rang bzhin yod pa yin na yang / / gzhan du 'gyur ba gang gi yin/ /
9cd. If there is essence, on the other hand, How could it be possible for something to transform into something else?

rang bzhin de rang gi ngo bos yod pa yin na'ang gzhan du 'gyur bar ji ltar rung ste mi rung ngo / / bud d+ha pA li ta las rkang pa snga ma gnyis kyis gzhan du 'gyur rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pas gzhan 'gyur gyi dngos po yod pa bkag la/ phyi ma gnyis kyis rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gzhan 'gyur mi 'thad pas dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa bkag ste bzhi kha rang gzhung ngo / / 'dir 'grel pa las gzhan 'gyur mthong ba'i phyir rang bzhin yod pa ma yin no zhes pa yang gzhan la grags pa'i gzhan 'gyur mthong ba'i dbang du byas nas brjod kyi/ kho bo cag gis nam yang gang la yang gzhan 'gyur yod par khas ma blangs so zhes gsungs pa ni/ sngar gong du me la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dag kyang gzhan du 'gyur ba khyed kyis dmigs pa yang yin no zhes/ rang bzhin gzhan du 'gyur ba mthong bas rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no zhes bshad pa la zer ba yin gyi gzhan 'gyur tsam khas mi len par smra ba min no/

[280] If essence did exist inherently, how could it be possible for it to transform into something else? It could not. Buddhapālita says that the first two lines refute the transformation of entities into something else on the grounds that the thing that transforms into something else does not exist inherently and that the last two lines refute the essential existence of things on the grounds that transformation into something else of that which exists essentially is not tenable, reading all four as Nāgārjuna’s own position [325b]. Here the Commentary says, The statement “Since transformation of things into something else is seen, they do not exist essentially” refers to the transformation into another that is accepted by others. But we never maintain that the transformation of anything into another exists. [92a] This refers to the thesis that since transformation into another is seen, there is no essential existence. This is said previously in the statement, “even though such things as fire exist essentially, you perceive them transforming into another thing” [91b]. But it does not mean that we we do not accept mere transformation into another.
gnyis pa [rang bzhin gyis yod par smra na mthar 'dzin las mi 'da' bar bstan pa] ni/
1.2 Demonstration that maintaining that things exist essentially cannot avoid the extremes
yod ces bya ba rtag par 'dzin/ / med ces bya ba chad par lta/ / de phyir yod dang med pa la/ / mkhas pas gnas par mi bya 'o/ /
10. To say “it exists” is to reify. To say “it does not exist” is to adopt the view of nihilism. Therefore a wise person Does not subscribe to “it exists” or “it does not exist.”

de ltar rang bzhin gyis grub pa gtan yod pa ma yin bzhin du gang gis dngos po rnams yod pa dang snga ma zhig nas med par rtog pa de la ni/ nges pa kho nar yod ces bya ba ni rtag par 'dzin pa dang med ces bya ba ni chad par lta bar thal bar 'gyur ro/ / rtag chad du lta ba yang mtho ris dang byang grol la bar du gcod pas don ma yin pa chen po byed pa de'i phyir yod pa dang med pa'i mtha' gnyis la mkhas pas gnas par mi bya'o/ / yang ci'i phyir dngos po dang dngos po med par lta ba yod na rtag chad kyi lta bar 'gyur ba yin zhe na/

Although there is no essential existence whatever, it is certain that whoever conceives of things as existent or as nonexistent—as the disintegration of a previous thing—will fall into absurdity: “to say ‘it exists’ is to reify” and “to say ‘it doesn’t exist’ is to adopt” the view of nihilism. The views of reification and nihilism are obstacles to achieving high status and liberation. Therefore, since they are very destructive “a wise person does not subscribe to the” extremes of existence and nonexistence. Suppose someone said, “Why, when one has a view of entity or nonentity, does that become a view of reification or nihilism?”
gang zhig rang bzhin gyis yod pa/ / de ni med pa min pas rtag / sngon byung da ltar med ces pa/ / des na chad par thal bar 'gyur/ /
11. “Whatever exists essentially Cannot be nonexistent” is reification. “It existed before, but does not now” Entails the error of nihilism.

gang zhig rang bzhin gyis yod par brjod pa de ni rang bzhin la ldog pa med pas nam yang med pa min no/ / de'i phyir na rang bzhin gyis yod par khas blangs pas rtag ltar 'gyur gyi yod pa tsam du khas blangs pas min no/ / dus sngon mar dngos por byung ba rang bzhin gyis grub par khas blangs nas da ltar te phyis zhig nas med ces khas blangs pa des na chad par lta bar thal bar 'gyur gyi/ dus snga mar yod pa dus gnyis par zhig pa tsam zhig khas blangs pas min no/ /

Whatever is said to exist essentially, since there could be no change in its essence, could never become nonexistent. Therefore, to maintain that something exists essentially is to adopt the view of reification. [281] But to maintain mere existence is not to do so. To maintain that a thing, having arisen essentially as an entity in the previous moment and now having subsequently disintegrated, does not exist, is to fall into the absurd view of nihilism. But, to maintain mere existence in the previous moment and disintegration in the second moment is not to do so.

kho bo cag la ni rang bzhin la brten pa'i rtag chad kyi lta bar mi 'gyur te dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa mi 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te khyed la rtag lta med mod chad lta ni yod do snyam na/ chad rgyu'i dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa sngar khas blangs nas phyis med par 'dod na ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa nam yang yod dgos pa la skur pa btab pas chad ltar 'gyur gyi/ rang bzhin gyis grub pa gtan med pa la de med ces brjod pa na de la skur pa btab pa med pas chad ltar mi 'gyur ro/ / ji skad du/ lang kar gshegs pa las/ bcom ldan 'das gang gis sngar 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug dag g.yar gyis blangs nas phyis 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug dngos po yod pa ma yin no zhes smra ba de ni med pa bar 'gyur lags so/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

For us, there is no view of refication or nihilism based on essence, because we do not maintain that entities exist essentially. Suppose one charged, “Although you do not adopt the view of reification, you do adopt the view of nihilism!” We would reply that if one first maintained that the object of annihilation exists essentially and then later maintained that it does not exist, one would thereby repudiate the necessity of the eternal existence of that which exists essentially, and thus would fall into nihilism.
