But to say that that which never existed essentially in the first place does not exist is not deprecation, and therefore is not nihilism. Compare the statement in the Laṅkāvatāra-Sūtra: O Transcendent Lord, whoever first accepts desire and confusion and then says that the entities of desire and confusion do not exist becomes a nihilist! [m Do sde ca 113a]

dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par 'dod na de rtag par mi smra yang rtag ltar 'gyur la/ dus snga mar rang bzhin gyis yod pa zhig dus gnyis par zhig par 'dod na de'i rgyun chad par khas mi len kyang chad ltar 'gyur bas dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dod phyin chad rtag chad kyi lta ba las mi 'da'o/ / dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par khas mi len na rang bzhin la brten pa'i rtag chad gnyis ka'i lta ba med kyang rgyu 'bras gzhag sa med na skur 'debs su 'gyur bas chad lta'o/ /

To maintain that entities exist essentially, even if one does not assert that they are permanent, would entail the view of reification. If one maintains that that which exists essentially in the previous moment is then disintegrated in the second moment, then, even though one does not assert that the continuum is broken, one adopts the view of nihilism. Therefore, as long as one maintains that things exist essentially one cannot escape the views of nihilism and reification. If one does not maintain that things exist essentially, although there is neither the view of reification nor of nihilism grounded in essence, without a ground for positing cause and effect one would repudiate them and fall into the nihilist view.

'di la chad rgyu'i dngos po khas ma blangs pas chad ltar mi 'gyur ro zhes smra mi nus te/ 'jig rten rgyang pan pas kyang skye ba snga phyi dang las 'bras la sogs pa'i chad rgyu sngar khas blangs nas phyis med par ma smras kyang chad ltar 'gyur ba spong mi nus pa bzhin no/ /

Here one should not say that just because the object of annihiliation is not accepted, one has not fallen into nihilism, just as even though it is not the case that the Cārvākas [282] first accept the object of annihilation—rebirth, cause, and effect, etc.—and later say that it does not exist, you cannot avoid saying that they fall into nihilism.

rnal 'byor spyod pa bdag gzhan dbang sems dang sems byung tsam zhig rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pas med lta dang / gzhan dbang la kun btags pa med pas rtag lta spong bar 'dod pa ni/ phyi rol la ltos pa'i gzung 'dzin tha snyad du yod pa la skur pa btab cing gzhan dbang bden par med pa la sgro btags pas rtag chad gnyis ka'i mthar ltung bas/ dbu ma pa'i lta ba kho na la yod med kyi mthar ma lhung ba dang rtag chad kyi skyon dang bral ba yod kyi gzhan la ni ma yin ni/ /

The Yogācāra assert that since the other-dependent—only mind and mental episodes—exists through its own characteristic, they avoid the view of nihilism, and that since the imagined does not exist in the other-dependent, they avoid the view of reification. This assertion deprecates the conventional existence of subject and object with respect to the external world. It reifies the other-dependent, which does not truly exist. Therefore, they fall into both extremes! Thus, the mādhyamika’s view alone does not fall into the extremes of existence and nonexistence and avoids the errors of reification and nihilism. None of the other schools achieve this.

de skad du yang rin chen phreng ba las/ gang zag phung por smra ba yi/ / 'jig rten grangs can 'ug phrug dang*/ / gos med bcas la gal te zhig / yod med 'das pa smra na dris/ / de phyir sangs rgyas rnams kyi ni/ / bstan pa 'chi med yod med las/ / 'das pa zab mo zhes bstan pa/ / chos kyi khud pa yin shes gyis/ / zhes gsungs te gang zag tsam du smra ba ni rang sde gang zag rdzas yod du smra ba'o/ / phung po tsam du smra ba ni rang gi sde pa gang zag rdzas su med la phung po rdzas su yod par smra ba'o/ / mdor na ji srid du rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin med pa la las 'bras dang 'ching grol la sogs pa yod par 'jog mi shes pa de srid du/ rtag chad kyi lta ba spong tshul ji 'dra zhig byas kyang mtha' de gnyis las mi 'da' ste chad lta spong ba na yod mtha' khas blang dgos la rtag lta spong ba na med mtha' khas blang dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir gzugs med la sems yod do zhes pa dang kun btags rang gi mtshan nyid kyis ma grub la ngo bo nyid gzhan gnyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par gsungs pa'i rnam par rig pa tsam gyi tshul ni/ mang pos bkur ba'i gang zag tu smra ba ltar ston pa thugs rje chen po can gyis rim gyis don dam pa rtogs pa'i thabs su bkri ba'i phyir/ gdul bya de lta bu'i ngor gsungs pa'i drang don yin gyi nges don ni ma yin no/ / gsung rab ci 'dra zhig drang don dang ci 'dra zhig nges don du 'jog pa ni ting 'dzin rgyal po dang blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i rjes su 'brang nas shes par bya ste/ 'di dag shin tu rgyas par ni drang nges rnam par 'byed pa legs par bshad pa'i snying po las shes par bya'o/ /

Here the Ratnāvalī says, Ask the Sāṁkhyas and Aulūkyas and the Jains Who say that the person is the aggregates Whether they maintain a view Free from existence and nonexistence. Therefore the nectar—the doctrine Of the buddhas—has been taught; Profound, free from existence and nonexistence. This Dharma should be understood as their legacy. [I: 61–62] Thus those who assert the existence of the mere person are those of our own Buddhist schools who maintain that the person exists substantially. Those who assert the existence of the mere aggregates are those of our own schools who, while they do not assert that the person exists substantially, assert that the aggregates exist substantially. In short, unless one is able to set out cause and effect, samsara and nirvana coherently in the framework of the absence of inherently existent essence, no matter how many ways one attempts to dispel the views of reification and nihilism, one will not get free from the two extremes, because otherwise, when one eliminates nihilism one has to accept reification; and when one eliminates reification, one has to accept nihilism. Thus, the approach of the mind-only school is to say that while material form does not exist, mind does exist; and that while the imagined nature does not exist through its own characteristic, the other two natures do exist through their own characteristic. The great compassionate teacher presented this approach, which is subject to interpretation and not definitive—like that of the Sammitīya who assert the existence of the person—as a method to lead them to an understanding of the ultimate truth. One should follow the Samādhirāja-sūtra and the Akṣayamati-nirdeśa-sūtra in order to understand which scriptures are definitive and which are require interpretation. One can learn this from The Essence of Eloquence (Thurman 1985, Geshe Yeshes Thab-khas 2000), where it is explained extensively.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar dngos po thams cad la rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i rang bzhin med par rigs pas bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / de ltar bstan pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs mtshon ni ting 'dzin rgyal po las/ / thams cad bsam yas thams cad 'byung min pas/ // dngos dang dngos med shes pa rnam par shig / byis pa gang dag sems kyi dbang song ba// de dag srid pa bye ba brgyar sdug bsngal/ / zhes dang / sngon 'das dus kyi bskal pa bsam yas na/ / mi yi gtso bo byung ba ngas dran te/ / drang srong chen po gzings kyis don mdzad pa/ / ming ni dngos po med las byung zhes bya/ / skyes ma thag tu mkha' la rab tu gnas/ / chos rnams thams cad dngos po med par bstan/ / de tshe de dang mthun par mtshan btags te/ / sgras ni 'jig rten kun tu grags par byas/ / lha rnams thams cad rab tu sgra 'byin pa/ / dngos po med ces bya ba'i rgyal bar 'gyur/ / skyes ma thag tu gom pa bdun bor te/ / rgyal bas chos rnams dngos po med par bshad/ / thub pa chos rnams thams cad ston pa yi/ / sangs rgyas chos kyi rgyal por nam gyur tshe/ rtswa shing gel pa sman ri brag rnams las/ / chos rnams dngos po med ces sgra yang byung / / 'jig rten de na ji snyed sgra yod pa/ / thams cad dngos med ci yang med pa zhes/ / de lta bur ni 'jig rten 'dren pa yi/ / sgra dbyangs rnam pa shin tu byung bar gyur/ / zhes gsungs te dngos po med pa'i don ni rang bzhin med pa'i don no/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to to show that the demonstration that all entities are inherently essenceless can also be corroborated by profound scriptures and to demonstrate that all of the scriptures that present this are explained by this chapter. The Samādhirāja-sūtra15 says, Because everything is inconceivable and everything is unarisen The conception of entity and nonentity is destroyed. Those fools who are overpowered by mind Suffer for a billion lifetimes. [Upāliparipṛcchā-sūtra dKon brtsegs ca 128b] And further, it is said, In the inconceivably distant past I remember that I was a supreme human being: The great sage who served as a vessel Who was named after naturelessness. Immediately after birth I floated in space, I taught that all things were natureless. That is why I received that name. Word of this spread to the entire world. All of the gods proclaimed that I would be the victor called “natureless.” Immediately after birth, I took seven steps. The victors declared that all phenomena are natureless. When the sage explains all phenomena, When the Buddha becomes a Dharma king, From the trees, bushes, grasses and mountains The word spread that all phenomena are natureless. The Guide to the world Proclaimed the following words: All of the words that exist in this world Are natureless, and nothing exists. [Samādhirāja-sūtra, mDo sde da, 23b] To be natureless here means to be essenceless.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

spyir dngos po dang dngos med dang bye brag tu rang gi dngos po dang gzhan gyi dngos po dang chos rnams kyi de kho na nyid kyi rang bzhin zhes pa rnams ni rang gi ngo bo'i dbang gis yod pa la gang yang gzhag tu med par dngos su bstan pa'i don nges par bya zhing / de'i tshe shugs kyis na tha snyad kyi dbang gis yod par bzhag pa tsam la de dag thams cad shin tu 'thad do snyam du rten 'byung gi nges pa drang bar bya'o/ /

One should ascertain the explicit meaning of this presentation—that nature and naturelessness in general, one’s own nature and the nature of being other in particular—and the essence of phenomena as they really exist cannot be posited in the framework of inherent existence. One should thereby ascertain the implicit meaning—dependent origination—with the understanding that they are all only tenable when they are merely posited conventionally.
rang bzhin brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bco lnga pa'o// //
This is the fifteenth chapter called “the examination of essence.”
rang bzhin brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu gcig gi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bco lnga pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the fifteenth chapter, having eleven verses, called “the examination of essence.”
CHAPTER XVI. Examination of Bondage
gsum pa bcings thar rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa
The third part of this section, the refutation of the essential existence of bondage,
['di] la gnyis/ dngos kyi don dang / de'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
it has two sections: the main point and the refutation of the argument.
dang po [dngos kyi don]
This chapter comprises the first part.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gsum/ 'khor 'das rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / bcings thar rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / myang 'das kyi don du rtsom pa don med du thal ba spang ba'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the essential existence of samsara and nirvana, the refutation of the essential existence of bondage and liberation, and dispelling the apparent consequence that there is no point in making effort to achieve liberation.
dang po ['khor 'das rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of samsara and nirvana
['di] la gnyis/ 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / myang 'das rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of cyclic existence and refutation of the essential existence of nirvana.
dang po ['khor ba rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of cyclic existence

'dir smras pa dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod de 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'gro ba nas 'gro ba gzhan du 'gro ba la 'khor ba zhes bya na dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis med na de'i tshe su zhig 'gro ba snga ma nas 'gro ba phyi mar 'gro zhing 'khor te mo gsham gyi bu bzhin no/ / 'di dgag pa la gnyis/ blang bya phung po 'khor ba dgag / len pa po sems can 'khor ba dgag pa'o/ /

Here someone might say that things do exist essentially because cyclic existence exists essentially. Since cyclic existence is said to be the transmigration from one life to another/1/ if things did not exist essentially, [285] who would it be who goes from an earlier life to a later life and thus cycles through existence? It would be like the son of a barren woman. The refutation of this has two parts: the refutation of the thesis that the appropriated aggregates cycle and refutation of the thesis that the appropriating sentient being cycles.
dang po [blang bya phung po 'khor ba dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation of the thesis that the appropriated aggregates cycle
['di] la gnyis/ rtag pa 'khor ba dgag / mi rtag pa 'khor ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the thesis that that which is permanent cycles and the refutation of the thesis that that which is impermanent cycles.
dang po [rtag pa 'khor ba dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of the thesis that that which is permanent cycles
gal te 'du byed 'khor zhe na/ / de dag rtag na mi 'khor te/ /
1. Suppose compounded phenomena cycle: If they are permanent, they do not cycle.

gal te 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod na phung po dang sems can gnyis gang rung gcig 'khor dgos na de la gal te 'du byed de phung po 'khor ro zhe na/ de yang rtag pa yin min gnyis su nges la de rtag na ni mi 'khor te/ 'gro 'ong gi bya ba dang bral ba'i phyir dang 'gro ba snga ma nas 'ong zhing phyi mar mi 'gro na 'khor ba por 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ /

Suppose that one said, “Since cyclic existence exists essentially, either the sentient being or the the aggregates must cycle. Thus, the compounded, viz., the aggregates, cycle.” In that case, they must be either permanent or impermanent. If they were permanent, they would not cycle, because they would lack the activity of going and coming, and if they came from the previous life and did not go to the next life, this would contradict their being transmigrators.
gnyis pa [mi rtag pa 'khor ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2 Refutation of the thesis that that which is impermanent cycles
mi rtag na yang 'khor mi 'gyur/ /
1c. Even if they are impermanent, they do not cycle.

gal te 'du byed mi rtag pa 'khor bar smra na mi rtag na'ang 'khor ba por ngo bo nyid kyis yod par mi 'gyur te/ mi rtag pa ni skyes ma thag tu 'jig la zhig pa rnams ni slar mi 'khor ba'i phyir ro/ / 'on te 'du byed rgyu 'bras gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i rim pa rgyun mi 'chad pa'i mi rtag pa kho na 'khor ro snyam na/ / 'di la skad cig snga phyir ma phye bar snga phyi la rjes su 'gro ba'i rgyun 'khor ba dang / snga phyi so so ba'i skad cig 'khor ba gnyis las phyi ma 'gog pa na re zhig snga phyi re re ba 'gog pa ni/ 'bras bu'i skad cig ma phyi ma skye 'gyur ni 'khor ba por mi rung ste/ de ni 'gro ba snga ma gang nas kyang ma 'ongs shing 'gro ba phyi ma gang du yang mi 'gro ba'i phyir dang 'khor mkhan la bya ba de gnyis dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyu snga ma zhig pa yang mi 'khor te 'gro ba snga ma gang nas kyang ma 'ongs pa'i phyir dang phyi ma gang du yang mi 'gro ba'i phyir ro/ / 'du byed snga ma zhig pa dang phyi ma ma skyes pa tsam las ma gtogs pa'i 'du byed 'das ma 'ongs med pa'i phyir dang / de gnyis kyang zhig pa dang ma skyes pa nyid kyis 'khor ba por yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir 'du byed 'das ma 'ongs 'khor ba por yod pa ma yin no/ /

Suppose one said that impermanent compounded phenomena cycle. Even if they were impermanent, they could not inherently be the transmigrator, because an impermanent thing ceases immediately after arising and disintegrated things cannot cycle once again. However, one might think that the impermanent compounded phenomena, linked one to another as cause and effect in an uninterrupted continuum, cycle. To this we reply as follows: Without differentiating between earlier and later moments, the continuum comprising successive moments could cycle, or the individual moments could each cycle. The refutation of the latter of the two—the refutation that each successive moment does—is as follows: The effect at the later moment, which is yet to be arisen, cannot be the transmigrator, because that has neither come from any of the previous lives nor is it going to go to any future life; and these two actions are necessary for something to be a transmigrator. Nor can the previous cause, which has disintegrated, cycle, because that has neither come from any of the previous lives nor is it going to go to any future life. Apart from the previously disintegrated compound phenomena and the future ones which have yet to arise, there are no other compound phenomena, whether past or future; [286] and these two, as well—disintegration and being yet to arise—cannot be the transmigrator. Therefore compound phenomena, whether in the past or the future, cannot be the transmigrator.

gal te de gnyis mi 'khor yang skad cig ma phyi ma skyes pa na snga ma 'khor ba yin pas 'du byed kyi snga phyi gnyis ka la ltos nas 'khor ba por 'jog go snyam na/ skad cig snga phyi rang bzhin gyis gcig gam tha dad pa yin pa rtag grang / dang po ltar na mi rigs te rgyu 'bras dang snga phyi yin pa'i phyir dang snga ma zhig pa dang phyi ma skyes pa'i dus so so yin pa'i phyir ro/ / brtag pa gnyis pa ltar na'ang skad cig ma phyi ma skyes pa na snga ma 'khor bar mi rigs te de gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'i phyir ro/ / ma nges pa min te gzhan du na so so skye bo 'khor bar skye ba yod pas dgra bcom pa rnams kyang 'khor bar 'gyur la/ mar me gzhan 'bar ba na mar me shi ba yang 'bar bar 'gyur te/ 'brel med don gzhan du mtshungs pa la skad cig snga phyi gnyis gcig skyes pas gcig 'khor la gzhan gnyis la de ltar mi 'dod pa'i rgyu mtshan med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Suppose, on the other hand, one thought that although these two cannot cycle, when the later moment is arisen, the earlier moment has cycled. Thus, depending on both the earlier and later stages, a compounded phenomenon can be said to cycle. One must inquire: Are the earlier and later moments essentially identical or essentially different from one another? The first alternative does not make sense because they are cause and effect, because they are sequential, and because the disintegration of the earlier and the arising of the later occur at distinct moments. If, on the other hand, we consider the second alternative, when the later moment has arisen it does not make any sense for the previous moment to have cycled because these two would be inherently different. There is no fallacy of accident here. Otherwise, it would follow from ordinary beings having been born in cyclic existence that arhats would also be in cyclic existence; and it would follow from one butterlamp burning that another that has already been extinguished would nonetheless also be burning. Since these are equally unrelated objects, if when one of two moments arises, the other cycles, there would be no justification for saying that this case is different from these two examples.

gzhan yang skad cig ma phyi ma snga ma las skye na snga ma zhig pa dang ma zhig pa dang 'jig bzhin pa gang las skye zhig pa las skye na ni sa bon tshig pa las kyang myu gu skye bar 'gyur bas rgyu med du 'gyur ro/ / lugs 'dis zhig pa dngos por bzhed kyang skad cig snga ma zhig pa las/ phyi ma skye bar mi bzhed par sngar bshad zin la de'i phyir de ltar 'gag go / snga ma ma zhig pa las skye na sa bon rnam par ma 'gyur bar 'bras bu skye ba dang rgyu 'bras gnyis dus gcig tu 'gyur ro/ / tha snyad du snga ma ma zhig pa phyi ma'i dngos rgyur bzhed mod kyang 'dir ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis skye ba 'gog la de la sngar bshad pa ltar skyon de dag 'jug go / 'jig bzhin pa las skye na zhig ma zhig gnyis gang yang min pa'i 'jig bzhin pa ni med la de gnyis la yang skyon brjod zin to/ //

Moreover, if the later moment arises from the earlier moment, does it arise from one that is already disintegrated, one that is not yet, or from one that is disintegrating? Suppose it arises from a disintegrated one: It would follow that a sprout could arise from a roasted seed! Such a thing would be causeless! According to this system disintegration2 is considered a thing. However, as has already been explained, a later moment is not considered to have arisen from the disintegrated earlier moment. Thus this is how it is refuted. Suppose, on the other hand, that it arises from a previous moment that is not already disintegrated. It would follow that fruit would arise from a seed that had not changed at all, and cause and effect would be simultaneous. Conventionally, an earlier nondisintegrated one is considered to be the direct cause of a later thing. However, in this case, since arising through its own characteristic is being refuted, all of the previously explained errors ensue. Suppose, finally, that it arises from one that is disintegrating. There is no disintegrating that is neither [287] already disintegrated nor yet to be disintegrated. The errors attaching to these two have already been presented.

de ltar skad cig snga phyi phye ba'i re re ba dang gnyis ka bsdoms pa la 'khor ba por 'dod pa bkag cing / snga phyi ba la gcig tha dad dang snga ma las phyi ma skye ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag pa'i phyir/ skad cig snga phyi dang rgyu 'bras ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa gzhag tu med pas/ de la brten pa'i rgyun kyang med pas rgyun la yang 'khor ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min no//

Thus the assertion that sequential moments either jointly or severally constitute the transmigrator has been refuted. The identity and difference of the sequential moments and the inherent existence of the arising of the subsequent moment from the previous moment have been refuted. Therefore, since one cannot posit them as inherently existent as sequential or as cause and effect, the continuum that would depend on them does not exist as well, and therefore cyclic existence does not exist inherently as that continuum.

gzhan sde 'gro ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i 'khor ba po 'dod pa thams cad ni phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i gang zag rdzas yod 'khor bar 'dod do/ / de'i phyir 'du byed dam phung po 'khor bar smra ba rang sde yin la de yang gang zag tu 'jog pa'i gzhi ni phal cher rnam shes la 'dod pas/ kun gzhi la sogs pa'i rnam shes 'khor bar 'dod cing de nyid la gang zag 'khor zhes kyang smra la skad cig snga phyi ma phye ba'i rgyun nyid 'khor bar 'dod do/ /

All of the non-Buddhist schools who maintain that the transmigrator persists from one life to another maintain that a substantially existent person inherently different from the aggregates cycles. Therefore, it is our own schools who maintain that compounded phenomena or the aggregates cycle, and therefore most of them maintain that the basis of positing the person is consciousness. Therefore, it is maintained that a consciousness, such as the foundation consciousness, cycles. The cycling of that is called the cycling of the person as well, and the continuum, without distinguishing the sequential moments, is maintained to be cyclic existence.
gnyis pa [len pa po sems can 'khor ba dgag pa]
1.1.1.2 Refutation of the thesis that the appropriating sentient being cycles
['di] la gnyis/ phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i sems can 'khor ba dgag / phung po las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i gang zag 'khor ba dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: the refutation of the thesis that the sentient being who is different from the aggregates cycles and the refutation of thesis that the inexpressible person, whether it is identical to or different from the aggregates, cycles.
dang po [phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i sems can 'khor ba dgag] ni/
1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of the thesis that the sentient being who is different from the aggregates cycles
gal te rigs pa dang 'gal bas 'du byed mi 'khor ba ni bden mod kyang phung po las ngo bo tha dad pa'i bdag rdzas su yod pa de 'khor ro zhe na/

Suppose one said, “Although you are correct that it is contradictory to reason that compounded phenomena do not cycle, the substantially existent self, which is different from the aggregates, cycles.”
sems can la yang rim 'di mtshungs/ /
1d. The same approach applies to sentient beings.

de 'dra ba'i sems can 'khor ba la yang 'du byed 'khor bar mi 'thad pa'i rim pa 'di thams cad mtshungs pas mi rigs te/ rtag na 'gro 'ong gi bya ba mi byed pas rtag pa mi 'khor la sems can mi rtag pa la yang skad cig dang rgyun gyi dpyad pas 'khor bar mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ /

Since all of these approaches to demonstrating the untenablity of the thesis that uncompounded phenomena cycle also apply to a transmigrating sentient being characterized in that way, that proposal does not make sense either. This is because, since it would be permanent, it would not perform the activities of coming and going, and so as permanent it would not cycle. And analysis to determine whether an impermanent sentient being is momentary or continuous shows that it is untenable for it to cycle.
gnyis pa [phung po las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i gang zag 'khor ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of the thesis that the inexpressible person, whether it is identical to or different from the aggregates, cycles

gal te mang pos bkur ba pa rnams na re 'du byed rtag mi rtag 'khor bar mi 'thad pa'i dpyad pa sems can la mtshungs par smra ba ni mi rigs te/ bdag ni phung po las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa ltar rtag mi rtag gang du yang brjod du med pa'i gang zag 'khor ba'i phyir ro zhe na/

At this point, the Sammitīya might argue as follows: It does not makes sense to apply this analysis showing the untenability of permament or impermanent compounded phenomena transmigrating [288] to sentient beings per se because the self—whether it is identical to, or different from, the aggregates—is inexpressible. Thus, the inexpressible person—whether it is permanent or impermanent—cycles.
gal te gang zag 'khor zhe na/ / phung po skye mched khams rnams la/ / de ni rnam pa lngas btsal na/ / med na gang zhig 'khor bar 'gyur/ /
2. Suppose the person cycles: Since when sought in the fivefold way In the aggregates, in the sense spheres, and in the elements, It is not there, what cycles?

gang zag 'khor ba de ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gang zag de ni phung po dang skye mched dang khams rnams la gcig tha dad la sogs pa sngar bshad pa'i rnam pa lngas btsal ba na rnyed dgos pa las rnyed pa med na bdag ngo bos yod pa gang zhig 'khor bar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

If this person who cycles exists inherently, this person, as was explained before, should be found when sought through the fivefold analysis—that is, an inquiry into whether it is identical to, different from, or bears some other relation to the aggregates, faculties, and elements. Therefore, since it is not found, how could an inherently existent self cycle? It could not!
nye bar len nas nyer len par/ / 'khor na srid pa med par 'gyur/ / srid med nye bar len med na/ / de gang ci zhig 'khor bar 'gyur/ /
3. If one transmigrated from Appropriation to appropriation, there would be no life. If there were neither life nor appropriator, What would transmigrate?

gzhan yang 'dir mi'i nye bar len pa nas lha'i nye bar len par 'khor na/ mi'i nye bar len pa btang nas sam ma btang bar 'gro ba rang bzhin gyis yod/ dang po ltar na snga phyi de gnyis kyi bar du nyer len phung po lnga'i srid pa med par 'gyur te/ nye bar len pa snga ma btang nas phyi ma ma blangs pa'i skabs yod pa'i phyir te/ rang bzhin gyis grub na snga phyi gtong len gyi bya ba gnyis dus gcig pa mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / de gnyis kyi bar na srid pa med cing nye bar len pa'i phung po med na bdag tu tha snyad 'dogs pa'i rgyu med pas gang zag de ni gang ste ci yang med do// // de med na 'byung 'gyur gyi lha'i nye bar len pa po'i gang zag kyang med pa'i phyir/ ci zhig tu 'khor bar 'gyur te gang du 'khor bar 'gyur ba de yang med do/ / yang na len pa po med pas 'khor ba'i bya ba ci zhig byed par 'gyur zhes ci zhig ces pa bya ba 'khor ba'i khyad par du sbyar ro/ //

Moreover, here, when one transmigrates from appropriating a human life to appropriating a god’s life, does the transmigration exist essentially in virtue of giving up the human life or not? In the first case, in between the earlier and later lives, there would not be any life—any set of five aggregates—to appropriate, because there is a time when one has given up the previous aggregates and has not yet appropriated the later ones. This is because if it existed essentially it would not be possible for the two actions—giving up the previous and taking up the next—to occur simultaneously. Since there would be neither life nor aggregates to appropriate in between these two, there would be no grounds for calling it a self. So what would this person be? It would not be anything! Since it would not exist, the future person who appropriates the life of the god would not exist. So, since there is no life into which to cycle, to which life would he cycle? Alternatively, this could be read: Since there is no appropriator, what action of transmigration does it perform? In this case, the “what would” modifies the verb “transmigration.”/3/

gal te phyogs gnyis pa ltar na'ang mi rigs te skye ba snga ma'i srid pa ma btang bzhin du skye ba phyi ma'i srid pa bzung ba'i phyir/ bdag gcig lha dang mi'i bdag gnyis su 'gyur na de ni 'dod pa yang min no/ / gal te lha mi'i srid pa gnyis kyi bar na lha'i bar srid yod pas srid pa med pa'i bdag yod par mi 'gyur ro zhe na/ de yang mi rung ste mi'i srid pa nas lha'i bar srid du 'khor ba la yang*/ srid pa snga ma btang nas 'khor mi 'khor gyi dpyad pa snga ma dang mtshungs pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste mi'i srid pa gtong ba dang lha'i bar srid len par byed pa gnyis dus gcig car du yin pas/ / snga ma btang ba dang phyi ma blangs pa gnyis kyang dus gcig yin pas phyir de gnyis kyi bar skabs su nyer len med pa'i bdag yod pa'i skyon med do zhe na/ ci bdag gi phyogs gcig gis nye bar len pa snga ma gtong zhing / phyogs gzhan gcig gis bar srid du rgyu'am/ 'on te de 'dra'i cha so sor med par bdag nyid thams cad kyis snga ma gtong zhing phyi ma len pa yin pa rtag grang / de la dang po ltar na ni de'i tshe mi'i srid pa gtong ba dang lha'i bar srid len pa'i bdag gnyis yod par 'gyur ro/ / gnyis pa ltar na yang de gnyis kyi bar du srid pa med pa'i bdag yod par 'gyur ro/ /

The second case, on the other hand, does not make any sense, because the next life would be taken up without having given up the previous life. The single self would have to be both a man’s and a god’s, but that cannot be maintained. Suppose somone said that between the two lives—that of man and that of the god—there is a god’s intermediate life./4/ Therefore, there would not be a self without a life. [289] One cannot say this, either, because the earlier analysis in terms of whether or not one transmigrates having given up the previous life applies equally to transmigration from the man’s life to the god’s intermediate life. Suppose one then said that the giving up of the man’s life and the taking up of the god’s life are simultaneous. Therefore, since the giving up of the previous and the taking up of the next lives are simultaneous, we do not commit the error of saying that there would be a self without appropriation in between them. Let us analyze this as follows: One part of the self would have to give up the previous appropriation while the other part enters into the intermediate life. Or, on the other hand, if it were not so divided, the whole self would give up the previous life and take up the next one. In the first case, there would have to be two selves: one of which gives up the man’s life, and one of which takes up the god’s intermediate life. In the second case, there would be one self with no life in between two lives.

snga ma dang khyad par ni bar dor rgyu ba na shin tu nye bas dus thung ngu zhig tu nyer len med par 'gyur ba 'di tsam zhig go 'dir snga phyi gnyis kyi srid pa'i bar na phung po med pa'i bdag yod pa ra pha rol pos khas blang dgos pa'i rigs pa ni/ 'di gtong ba dang len no zhes las la brten pa'i gtong len gyi bya ba gnyis dus snga phyi ba'i phung po so so ba'i yul la brten pa can yin la/ de'i tshe 'dis gtong ba dang len no zhes pa'i bya ba byed pa po la brten pa yang dngos po gcig la dus gcig tu mi rung ste/ de gnyis dus gcig na bya ba'i rten mi dang bar srid kyi phung po gnyis kyang dus gcig tu 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ rang bzhin gyis grub na brten pa rten la dus thams cad du mi 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar gtong len gyi bya ba gnyis dus snga phyi ba yin na srid pa snga ma btang zin pa dang phyi ma blangs pa gnyis kyang snga phyir 'gyur la/ de'i phyir snga ma btang zin nas phyi ma ma blangs pa'i skabs der srid pa med pa'i bdag yod par 'gyur ro/ /

Here is the only difference between this example and the previous one: When entering the intermediate state, since it is so close, there is not supposed to be enough time to appropriate. Here, the reason why the opponent must accept a self without aggregates in between the previous and the next lives is that, having said “that one is given up, and this one is taken up,” the two activities—giving up and taking up—which depend on karma, are based on the two objects—the two consecutive sets of aggregates. Therefore, the activities called “giving up” and “taking up” which must be dependent upon the agent cannot be performed with respect to a single object simultaneously, because if they were simultaneous, the man’s aggregates and the intermediate aggregates, which are the bases of the actions, would have to be simultaneous. This is because, if they were essentially existent, the dependent and that on which it depends would have always to be inextricable. And so, since the two activities of giving up and taking up are sequential, the previous life given up and the next life taken up would be sequential as well. [290] Therefore, after having given up the previous life, at the time when one has not not yet taken up the next one, there would have to be a self without a life.
gnyis pa [myang 'das rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation of the essential existence of nirvana
gal te 'khor ba ni rang bzhin gyis yod de 'gal zla myang 'das rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one said, “Cyclic existence exists essentially, because its opposite, nirvana, exists essentially.”
'du byed mya ngan 'da' bar ni/ / ci lta bur yang mi 'thad do/ / sems can mya ngan 'da' bar yang / / ci lta bur yang 'thad mi 'gyur/ /
4. It is not tenable in any way For compounded phenomena to pass into nirvana. It is not tenable in any way For a sentient being to pass into nirvana./5/

su zhig mya ngan las 'da' ba'i 'da' ba po yang gnyis su nges la de yang 'du byed dam phung po mya ngan las 'da' ba rang bzhin gyis yod par ni ji lta bur yang ste rnam pa gang gis kyang mi 'thad la/ der ma zad sems can phung po las rdzas tha dad pa dang de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i gang zag mya ngan las 'da' ba rang bzhin gyis yod par yang ji lta bur yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / de dag gi rigs pa ni de dag rtag na mi 'da' ste zhes sogs 'don pa bsgyur ro/ / de la phung po'am gang zag kyang rung ste 'khor mkhan bden par grub pa ma khegs na de rnams 'khor bar 'khor ba bden par grub pa yang mi khegs so/ / 'khor mkhan bden grub khegs na mya ngan las 'da' mkhan nam thob mkhan bden grub kyang khegs so/ / de lta na thob mkhan gyis thob bya thob pa bden pa khegs la de'i phyir 'di dag thob byar bden pa yang khegs so/ // des na myang 'das sam chos sku bden par grub pa yang khegs dgos te de dag bden par grub na thob bya bden pa bar grub dgos pas khyab byed khegs pa'i phyir ro/ / rigs pa'i 'gros 'di rnams shes pa'i gnad kyis 'phags pa'i yul gyi rang sde dngos por smra bas kyang 'khor 'das la bden pa grub ma grub kyi khyad par mi 'byed mod phyogs 'di'i rgol ba rigs pa'i 'gros mi shes pa rnams de la khyab par 'byed do/ / de ltar mya ngan las 'das pa yang rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par ma grub pa la dgongs nas bcom ldan 'das ma las/ / tshe dang ldan pa rab 'byor mya ngan las 'das pa yang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o/ / tshe dang ldan pa rab 'byor sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams kyang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes pa la sogs pa nas/ rigs kyi bu gal te mya ngan las 'das pa las ches lhag pa'i chos gzhan zhig yod na'ang de yang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes nga smra'o zhes dang /

Whatever passes into nirvana must be one of two things. And it is not tenable in any way—that is, at all—for the passing into nirvana of compounded phenomena—that is, the aggregates—to exist essentially. Nor is it tenable in any way for a sentient being—that is, a person, whether they are said to be substantially different from aggregates or inexpressible in terms of identity to or difference from the aggregates—to pass into nirvana. These arguments can be rearranged as follows: “If they are permanent, they would not pass into nirvana,” etc./6/ Unless the existence of the agent of transmigration—either the person or the aggregates—is not refuted, the existence of transmigration in cyclic existence cannot be refuted. When the existence of the transmigrator is refuted, the existence of the one who passes into or achieves nirvana is refuted as well. Therefore, the true existence of the achievement by the achievers of what is to be achieved is refuted. Therefore, the true existence of that which is to be achieved is refuted. Thereby, the true existence of nirvana itself, or the dharmakaya/7/ is necessarily refuted, because the category—things to be achieved that are truly existent in virtue of the true existence of their achievers, etc.—has been refuted. Even the reificationist Indian Buddhist schools, because they understand how these arguments go, do not distinguish between cyclic existence and nirvana on the grounds that one is truly existent and the other is not. However, people of this land, who do not understand how these arguments go, draw this distinction. With the intent of showing that nirvana also does not exist inherently, it is said in the Aṣṭasāhasrikā-prajñāpāramitā-sūtra that [291] Worthy Subhuti, nirvana is also like an illusion or a dream; Worthy Subhuti, all of the qualities of the buddha are also like an illusion or like a dream … Oh son of good lineage, even if there were a phenomenon greater than nirvana, I would say that it is also like a dream and like an illusion. [Sher phyin ka 23a–23b]

ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang / don dam bden pa rmi lam 'dra ba dang / / mya ngan 'das pa rmi lam mtshungs par 'gyur/ / gang gis mkhas pa de ltar 'jug pa yang / / de ni yid kyi sdom pa'i mchog tu brjod/ // ces dang*/ 'gog pa'i bden pa rmi lam ji bzhin te/ / mya ngan 'das pa'ang rmi lam rang bzhin du/ / gang la byang chub sems dpa' ngag 'dug pa/ / de ni ngag gi sdom pa de zhes bya/ / zhes rang bzhin med pa'i don yid la byed na yid kyi sdom pa dang ngag tu smra na ngag gi sdom pa'i mchog tu bshad de sdom pa ni spang bya sdom pa yin la des skyon thams cad drungs 'byin pa'i phyir ro snyam du dgongs so/ /

And the Samādhirāja-sūtra says The ultimate truth is like a dream; And nirvana is similarly like a dream. The wise take them that way And this is the supreme discipline of mind. [m Do sde da 161b] and When the bodhisattva addresses these things: The truth of cessation is like a dream; Nirvana also is essentially a dream; That is called the discipline of speech. [m Do sde da 159a] It is said that this is the supreme discipline. Here is what this means: When the meaning of essencelessness is contemplated, this is mental discipline; when it is spoken about, this is the supreme discipline of speech. The discipline is that which subdues that which is to be abandoned and thereby eradicates all of the errors.
gnyis pa [bcings thar rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.2 Refutation of the essential existence of bondage and liberation
['di] la gnyis/ bcings thar rang bzhin gyis yod pa thun mong du dgag / so sor dgag pa'o/ /
The section has two parts: the collective refutation of the essential existence of liberation and bondage and the refutation of each.
dang po [bcings thar rang bzhin gyis yod pa thun mong du dgag] ni/
1.2.1 Collective refutation of the essential existence of liberation and bondage
gal te khyod kyis 'khor 'das gnyis bkag mod kyang bcings pa dang thar pa rang bzhin gyis yod pas dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/
Someone might say, “Although you have refuted cyclic existence and nirvana, since liberation and bondage exist essentially, entities exist essentially.”
skye 'jig chos can 'du byed rnams/ / mi 'ching grol bar mi 'gyur te/ / snga ma bzhin du sems can yang / / mi 'ching grol bar mi 'gyur ro/ /
5. Compounded phenomena that arise and cease Are neither bound nor liberated. And in the same way, sentient beings Are neither bound nor liberated.

'di na 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs rnams bcing bya rang dbang med par byed pas 'ching ba dang des bcings pa'i so so skye bo rnams khams gsum las mi 'da'o zhes bya bar 'jog na/ chags sogs 'ching bar brtags pa'i bcings pa ni rtag pa la/ mi rigs pa sla bas re zhig skye ba dang 'jig pa'i chos can 'du byed skad cig ma rnams la ni mi 'ching ba ste 'ching ba ngo bo nyid kyis med de rgyun dang skad cig ma so so ba la mi 'thad pa sngar ltar ro/ / de rnams la grol bar 'gyur ba yang ngo bo nyid kyis med de rgyu mtshan ni snga ma ltar ro/ / snga ma 'du byed la bcings thar mi 'thad par bshad pa'i rim pa bzhin du sems can yang mi 'ching zhing grol bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yang na rtag mi rtag mi 'khor zhing mi 'da' bar gsungs pa'i rim pa bzhin du'o/ /

It is said that the afflictions—such as desire—render the bound one heteronomous and thus constitute bondage and that ordinary beings, thus bound, cannot escape the three realms. It is easy to see that it is unreasonable to say that those things thought of as the bonds of the bound, such as desire, are permanent. Thus, momentary compounded phenomena which arise and cease are not bound; that is, bondage does not exist inherently, since as we have seen earlier, it is untenable for it to be either continous or momentary. [292] Their liberation also does not exist inherently as per the earlier arguments. As we explained earlier, the bondage and liberation of compounded phenomena are untenable. “And in the same way” means that sentient beings also are neither bound nor liberated. Alternatively, “and in the same way” can refer to the earlier explanation that neither permanent nor impermanent beings transmigrate or liberate./8/
gnyis pa [so sor dgag pa]
1.2.2 Refutation of each of liberation and bondage
['di] la gnyis/ bcings pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / thar pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of bondage and the refutation of the essential existence of liberation.
dang po [bcings pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1 Refutation of the essential existence of bondage
gal te 'du byed dang sems can la bcings thar bkag mod kyang 'dod chags la sogs pa nye bar len pa 'ching bar 'gyur ba ni yod pas bcings pa yang rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose someone said: Although compounded phenomena and sentient beings being bound or liberated have been refuted, since bondage—appropriation, such as desire—exists, the bound one exists essentially./9/
gal te nye bar len 'ching na/ / nye bar len bcas 'ching mi 'gyur/ / nye bar len med mi 'ching ste/ / gnas skabs gang zhig 'ching bar 'gyur/ /
6. If appropriation were bondage, Then the appropriator would not be bound. But without appropriation, there is no bondage. So, in what circumstances would one be bound?

gal te nye bar len pa 'ching byed du ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gnyis las mi 'da' la/ de yang nye bar len pa chags sogs kyi 'ching ba dang bcas pa la ni 'ching mi 'gyur zhes pa 'ching ba rang bzhin gyis med de/ yod na de la slar yang 'ching byed don gzhan yod dgos na slar yang 'ching ba ni don med pa'i phyir ro/ / bcing bya dang 'ching byed rang bzhin gyis grub na 'di bcings zhes pa'i 'ching ba'i bya ba dang 'dis bcings zhes pa'i 'ching ba'i bya ba gnyis rdzas gzhan du bya dgos pas/ bcings zin slar yang 'ching dgos te rab byed brgyad par bshad pa'i rigs pa dang 'dra'o/ / nye bar len pa med pa yang mi 'ching ste 'ching ba dang bral ba'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa bzhin no/ / de ltar na gnas skabs gang zhig tu gyur pa zhig 'ching bar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

If appropriation existed inherently as bondage you cannot escape two alternatives: On the one hand, that which has the appropriation—which is bondage by such things as desire—might “not be bound,” that is, might lack essential bondage, because if it had it, it would need another bond—another object—but there would be no point in another bond. If the bond and the bound existed essentially, the two verbs—“bound” in “this is bound” and the verb “binds” in “this binds”—would have to refer to substantially different actions. Therefore, that which is already bound would have to be bound once again. This is demonstrated by the similar argument in the eighth chapter. But without appropriation there is no bondage, because it would be free from bondage like the Tathāgata. In that case, in what circumstances would one be bound? There are none.
gal te bcing bya'i snga rol na/ / 'ching ba yod na 'ching la rag / de yang med de lhag ma ni/ / song dang ma song bgom pas bstan/ /

7. If bondage existed at all prior to that which is to be bound, It would have to bind the bound, But it could not. The rest has been explained By where one has gone, where one has not yet gone, and where one goes.

gzhan yang lcags sgrog la sogs pa 'ching byed sngar yod pas bcing bya 'ching ba bzhin du gal te bcing bya'i snga rol na 'ching ba chags sogs grub na/ des 'du byed dam gang zag 'ching ba la rag na de yang med de rten med pas chags sogs ma grub pa'i phyir dang sngar 'ching ba grub na phyis 'ching bya dang 'brel mi dgos pa'i phyir dang / 'ching byed las ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad par grub pa'i bcing bya la slar yang 'ching ba dgos pa med pa'i phyir ro//'di'i sun 'byin lhag ma ni song ba dang ma song ba dang bgom pa bkag pa'i 'don pa bsgyur bas bstan to/ / de yang re zhig bcings pa mi 'ching ste/ / zhes sogs sbyar ro/ /

Moreover, just like such things as a chain, the previously existing bond binds the bound. If prior to that which is to be bound, the bond—such as desire—existed, then, though it must bind the compounded phenomena or the person to be bound, they would not be there. This is because in the absence of a basis, such things as desire would not be present. And if the bond existed earlier, [293] then it does not need any connection to the bound later. If there were a bound that existed as inherently different from the bond, there would be no need for an additional binding. All of the other refutations relevant to this case have been presented in the refutation of where one has gone, where one has not gone, and where one goes, and can be applied here by rearranging the text as follows: That which has been bound is not bound./10/
gnyis pa [thar pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of liberation
gal te khyod kyis 'ching ba bkag mod kyang thar pa ni yod la ma bcings pa la thar pa med pas bcings pa yang yod do zhe na/
Suppose someone said, “Although you have refuted bondage, since liberation exists, and without someone bound, there would be nobody to liberate. Therefore bondage exists.”
re zhig bcings pa mi 'grol te/ / ma bcings pa yang grol mi 'gyur/ / bcings pa grol bzhin yin 'gyur na/ / bcings dang grol ba dus gcig 'gyur/ /
8. Whoever is bound would not get liberated. Whoever is not bound would not get liberated. If a bound one were being liberated, Bondage and liberation would occur simultaneously.

grol ba rang bzhin gyis yod na gang la yod re zhig bcings pa la ni mi grol ba ste grol ba rang bzhin gyis med de/ bcings pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste sngar bcings pa la ma bsgoms pa'i thabs la brten nas phyis thar par 'gyur ba'i phyir bcings pa nyid la grol ba rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/ 'o na ni bcings pa grol ba ma yin gyi bcings pa grol bar 'gyur ro zhes pa tsam du 'gyur ro/ / gal te dus snga logs su bcings pa de phyi dus su grol ba'i dus da lta ba dang nye bas de skad du brjod do snyam na/ thar pa rang gi ngo bos yod na de dang nye ba yod du chug na'ang / bcings pa bkag nas thar pa rang gi ngo bos med par bstan par 'dod pa de'i tshe thar pa rang gi ngo bos yod pa'i dus da lta ba dang nye ba med do/ / der ma zad nyon mongs kyis ma bcings pa'i gang zag la yang grol ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod par mi 'gyur te/ de ni grol ba nyid yin na de slar yang thar ci dgos te slar yang thar pa la ltos pa'i phyir/ dgra bcom pa grol zin pa la yang 'ching ba yod pas bcings par 'gyur ro/ / rigs pa 'di ji ltar snyam na grol ba po dang thar pa myang 'das gnyis ka 'khor ba las grol bar gzhag dgos la/ de gnyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub na grol ba'i bya ba gcig gis 'jog mi nus pas so sor dgos na/ de'i tshe grol ba'i bya ba gang dang ldan pas grol ba por bzhag pa las gzhan pa'i bya ba gnyis pa med pas grol ba po grol zhes pa mi 'thad la/ bya ba gnyis pa yod na grol zin nas slar yang grol ba la ltos pas dgra bcom pa la yang slar yang grol ba dgos par 'gyur ro/ / ci ste ma bcings pa la thar pa med pas bcings pa grol bar 'gyur ro snyam na/ bcings pa grol bzhin pa yin par ngo bo nyid kyis grub na bcings pa dang grol bzhin pa gzhi mthun yin pa'i phyir bcings pa dang grol ba dus gcig tu 'gyur na de ni mi srid de snang mun bzhin no/ / 'di ni sngar skye bzhin pa rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na dus der skye rgyu yod par bshad pa dang 'dra'o/ /

If liberation existed essentially, where would it be? Whoever is bound would not get liberated, that is, would be essentially unliberated because of being bound. Suppose one then said, “Since one who was previously bound later achieves liberation by means of meditation on the path, that bound one must be essentially liberated.” That would be merely to say that although the bound one is not yet liberated, he would become liberated. But suppose one thought that that which is bound at an earlier time soon becomes liberated in the future, which is imminent, and that thus this is put that way. If liberation existed inherently, then something could be proximate to it. But the liberation of those who maintain that it does not exist inherently in virtue of having refuted the bound is not proximal to the inherently existent present. Not only that, but a person who was not bound by the afflictions would not attain an inherently existent liberation because he would already be liberated. Why would there be a need for a further liberation? If further liberation were needed, the arhat who is already liberated would have bondage and so would be bound. “How,” one might ask, “does this argument go?” The one who is liberated and liberation must both be regarded as having transcended cyclic existence. If these two existed through their own characteristic, then it would follow that they could not both be accomplished by a single action, and each would need its own action. [294] But in that case, it would not be tenable to say that the liberated one achieved liberation, because there is no second action other than the action in virtue of performing which the liberated one is so-called. If there were a second action, then the arhat would need further liberation, since his being an arhat would depend on further liberation, despite being already liberated. Suppose one now thought, “Since the one who is not bound is not liberated, the one who is bound is liberated.” If the bound one’s being liberated existed inherently, then, since there is a common basis of being the bound one and being liberated, it is impossible for bondage and liberation to occur there simultaneously, just like darkness and light. This is just like the previous explanation that if arising existed inherently, then that which is to be arisen would have to be co-present with its conditions.
gsum pa [myang 'das kyi don du rtsom pa don med du thal ba spang ba] ni/
1.3 Dispelling the apparent consequence that there is no point in making effort to achieve liberation

gal te 'khor 'das dang bcings thar yang ngo bo nyid kyis med na thar 'dod rnams kyis bdag nam zhig na len pa med par mya ngan las 'da' la myang 'das de ni bdag gi bar nam zhig na 'gyur snyam pa de don med du 'gyur zhing / de rnams kyis sbyin pa dang tshul khrims dang thos bsam bsgom pa la sogs pa'i rim pa myang 'das 'thob pa'i dgos pa can rnams kyang don med par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: If neither cyclic existence nor nirvana nor bondage nor liberation exist inherently, it would be pointless for those who aspire to nirvana to think this way: “When, without appropriation, will I attain nirvana, and when will that nirvana be mine?” It would also be pointless for them to engage in all of the practices necessary for attaining liberation, such as generosity, propriety, listening, contemplating, and meditating.
bdag ni len med mya ngan 'da'/ / myang 'das bdag gir 'gyur ro zhes/ / de ltar gang dag 'dzin de yis/ / nyer len 'dzin pa chen po yin/ /
9. “I, without appropriation, will attain nirvana, And nirvana will be mine,” one says. Whoever grasps like this Grasps mightily to appropriation.

dngos po thams cad gzugs brnyan bzhin du rang bzhin med cing bdag dang bdag gi ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong pa la nga dang nga yi ba ngo bo nyid kyis yod par lta ba bskyed nas bdag ni yang srid len pa med par mya ngan las 'da'o// // myang 'das ni bdag gi bar 'gyur ro zhes de ltar thar pa 'dod de gang dag 'dzin par 'gyur ba de yi 'dzin pa de ni nyer len te 'jig tshogs la lta ba chen po yin no/ / de 'dra ba'i 'dzin pa ma dor ba de srid du thar pa'i phyir du rtsom pa rnams don med par 'gyur ro// // myang 'das la dmigs nas de ltar rtog pa thams cad 'jig lta min gyi ngo bos yod pa'i ngas nam myang 'das 'thob snyam pa dang / de 'dra ba'i nga de'i bdag gi bar myang 'das nam zhig na 'gyur snyam du 'dzin na de 'jig lta yin pas de nyid kyis myang 'das 'thob pa la gegs byed par gsungs te/ 'khor ba las grol bar 'dod pas de spang dgos par gsungs pas gang zag dang chos rang bzhin med pa rtogs pa nyan rang la yang yod par bstan to/ /

Although all phenomena are, like a reflection, essenceless, and the self and being mine are empty of inherent existence, some develop the view according to which the self and being mine exist essentially, and they say, “I, without appropriating a further life, will attain nirvana and that nirvana will be mine.” Those who aspire in this way to nirvana grasp it. Their grasping is a mighty view fixated on appropriation—that is, on the transitory assemblage. Until one abandons that gasping, all efforts exerted towards liberation will be pointless. Not all conceptions focused on nirvana are views objectifying the transitory assemblages. [295] But when it is grasped through the thought, “When will I, who exist inherently, attain nirvana, and when will that nirvana be inherently mine in the same sense?”/11/ this is the view of the transitory aggregates. That is explained to be the obstacle to attaining nirvana. Thus, as it said, in order to be liberated from samsara, one must abandon it. Therefore, this shows that both the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas have the realization of the essencelessness of the person and of phenomena.
gang la mya ngan 'das bskyed med/ / 'khor ba bsal ba'ang yod min pa/ / de la 'khor ba ci zhig yin/ / mya ngan 'das pa'ang ci zhig brtag /
10. When one can bring about neither nirvana, Nor the elimination of cyclic existence, What are the cyclic existence And the nirvana one imagines?

de'i phyir thar 'dod rnams kyis sngar bshad pa de thams cad gtang bar bya ste gang gi phyir don dam pa gang la mya ngan las 'das pa bskyed pa ste sgro btags pa med cing / 'khor ba bsal ba ste zad pa yang yod pa min pa de la gang zhig zad par bya ba'i phyir brtags pa 'khor ba ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ci zhig yin la/ gang thob par bya ba'i phyir brtags pa mya ngan las 'das pa'ang ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ci zhig yin par brtag yang na 'khor 'das gang yang ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ma dmigs pa'i phyir sems can 'ga' yang myang 'das gang du 'khor ba nas bsal ba ste bkri ba dang / mya ngan las 'das par bskyed pa 'bad pas kyang bya bar mi nus pa de la myang 'das ci zhig brtag ste brtag par mi rigs so/ / de ltar rtogs nas der mi rtog pa ni nges par 'khor ba'i 'brog dgon pa las 'da' zhing thar pa'i grong khyer du phyin par 'gyur ro/ /

Therefore, those who aspire to nirvana should give up all of the things mentioned earlier. This is because for them, ultimately there is no way to bring about, that is, to fabricate nirvana, nor is there any way to eliminate that is, to extinguish cyclic existence. What is that inherently existent cyclic existence that they imagine to be extinguished and what is that inherently existent nirvana that they imagine to be achieved? There is an alternative reading:/12/ Since neither cyclic existence nor nirvana is seen to exist inherently, it is not possible for any sentient being to detach from or to depart from cyclic existence or to make effort to bring about nirvana. In that case what could you imagine nirvana to be? Imagining it would not make sense! By realizing this, and by not thinking in that way, one will definitely depart the wilderness of cyclic existence and arrive at the city of nirvana.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/

de ltar 'khor 'das dang bcings thar rang bzhin med par rigs pas bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung dang yang ldan par bstan pa dang*/ gzugs ma bcings ma grol zhes sogs gsungs pa thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ bdud btul ba'i mdo las/ de nas de'i tshe 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas ji ltar bdud sdig can sgo mo'i them pa'i 'ching bas bcings pa ltar sa steng du 'gyel nas/ nga ni 'ching ba dam pos bcings so nga ni 'ching ba dam pos bcings so zhes ngu zhing cho nges 'debs par gyur pa de lta bu'i gzugs su bsams so/ / 'jam dpal gyis smras pa/ sdig can gang gis khyod rtag tu bcings shing gzod bcings pa ma yin pa 'ching ba ches dam pa 'ching ba 'di las gzhan pa zhig yod de/ de gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ nga rgyal phyin ci log gi 'ching ba dang srid pa dang lta ba'i 'ching ba ste sdig can 'di ni 'ching ba yin gyi 'ching ba 'di las gzhan pa 'ching ba ches dam por gyur pa ni yod pa ma yin no/ / khyod ni des rtag tu bcings pa yin gyi gzod bcings pa ni ma yin no/ / gzhan yang sdig can ci khyod gal te slar bkrol na dga' bar 'gyur ram/ smras pa dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas lha'i bu rab mtha' bral zhig gis/ 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la 'di skad ces smras so/ / 'jam dpal bdud sdig can thongs shig rang gi gnas su dong la rag go / de nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bdud sdig to can la 'di skad ces smras / / sdig can gang zhig btang ba khyod sus bcings/ smras pa/ 'jam dpal sus bcings pa mi shes so/ / smras pa/ sdig can ji ltar khyod ma bcings pa las bcings par 'du shes pa de bzhin du/ byis pa so so'i skye bo thams cad mi rtag pa la rtag par 'du shes pa sdug bsngal ba la bde bar 'du shes pa bdag med pa la bdag tu 'du shes pa/ mi gtsang ba la gtsang bar 'du shes pa gzugs med pa la gzugs su 'du shes pa tshor ba dag med pa dang 'du shes dag med pa dang 'du byed dag med pa dang rnam par shes pa med pa la tshor ba dang 'du shes dang 'du byed dang rnam par shes par 'du shes pa yin no/ / gzhan yang sdig can gang khyod grol bar 'gyur na gang las grol bar 'gyur/ / smras pa bdag gang las kyang grol bar mi 'gyur ro/ / smras pa/ sdig can de bzhin du gang dag grol bar 'gyur ba de dag kyang yang dag pa ma yin pa'i 'du shes gang yin pa de yongs su shes pa ma gtogs par gang las kyang grol bar 'gyur ba med de de yongs su shes nas grol ba zhes bya'o/ / zhes gsungs te lung 'di las na rmi lam gyi me 'bar ba chus bsad pa bzhin du phyin ci log gi rtog pa'i 'khri shing rnam par chad pa tsam la thar pa zhes bya'o/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to to show that the presentation through arguments of samsara and nirvana, and bondage and liberation, as essenceless can also be corroborated by profound scriptures, and to demonstrate that all of the sūtras that state that material form is neither bound nor liberated are explained by this chapter. The Māradamana-sūtra13 says: Then the youthful Mañjuśrī reflected on the form of an evil demon, [296] being bound by the bonds of the threshold,/14/ falling on the ground, lamenting “I am tightly bound! I am bound! I am tightly bound! I am bound!” Mañjuśrī said, “O demon, that by which you are always bound is not a primordial bond. There is a tighter bond apart from those bonds./15/ What is that? It is like this: ego, the bonds of error, greed, the bonds of views. Oh demon, these are the bonds; there are no bonds tighter than these bonds! You are always bound by these, but you are not primordially bound. [m Do sde ka 253a] It continues, O demon! Would you be happy to be released? He replied, “I would be happy.” One of the sons of the gods, Suyāma,/16/ said to Mañjuśrī: O, Mañjuśrī, release this evil demon, to return to his own place! Thereafter, Mañjuśrī, asked the evil demon: O, demon! Who is to be released and what binds him? He replied: O, Mañjuśrī, I know what binds me! He replied: O, demon! You regard yourselves as bound, even though you are not bound. In the same way, all ordinary beings regard the impermanent as permanent, suffering as happiness, the selfless as having a self, the impure as pure, and the formless as form. They regard that which is without feeling; that which is with out perception, that which is without disposition, that which is without consciousness as having feeling, as having perception, as having dispositions, and as having conciousness, respectively. [253a–253b] [297] It continues, O demon! When you are freed, from what would you be freed? He replied: There is nothing from which I would be freed! Mañjuśrī replied: O demon! in the same way, those who are to be freed also would not be freed from anything unless they completely realize the imperfection of perception. When one completely realizes that, one is said to be freed. [253b]/17/ This sūtra shows that one should understand that just as fire is extinguished by water in a dream, freedom should be understood as the mere cutting off of the vines of erroneous conception.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

'khor bar 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa dang nyon mongs pas bcings pa dang de bcad pa'i grol ba rnams rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod na gang yang mi rung bar rtogs nas de dag la bden par mi 'dzin pa dang / ming gi tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam la de dag thams cad shin tu 'thad pa'i rten 'brel zab mo'i nges pa brtan par bya'o/ //

Realizing that if cycling in cyclic existence, achieving nirvana, being bound by afflictions, and being freed by cutting those bonds existed inherently, none of them would be tenable and they make no sense in the context of inherent existence, one should ascertain the profound dependent origination—that they are all completely tenable when they are merely posited through the force of nominal conventions.
bcings pa dang thar pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu drug pa'o// //
This is the sixteenth chapter called “the examination of bondage and freedom.”
bcings pa dang thar pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu drug pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the sixteenth chapter, having ten verses, called “the examination of bondage and freedom.”
CHAPTER XVII. Examination of Action
gnyis pa bcings thar rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa
This chapter comprises the second part: the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of liberation and bondage.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gnyis/ rtsod pa/ lan no/ /
This section has two parts: the argument and the reply.
dang po [rtsod pa] ni/
1.1 The argument

sngar dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed du 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod par smra ba bkag pa la 'khor ba ni rang bzhin gyis yod de las 'bras kyi 'brel ba'i rten yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar skye 'chi gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i sgo nas 'du byed dam sems can rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'khor na ni 'dir byas pa'i las kyi 'bras bu tshe rabs gzhan du 'byung bas las rnams 'bras bu dang 'brel bar 'gyur la/ de 'dra ba'i 'khor ba med na ni sems ni skyes ma thag tu 'jig pa'i phyir dang las 'phen pa'i dus na rnam smin med pas las dang 'bras bu 'brel ba med pa kho nar 'gyur ro/ // des na las 'bras kyi 'brel ba'i rten yin pa'i phyir 'khor ba rang bzhin gyis yod do/ / las dang 'bras bu yang gang yin zhe na 'di la gnyis / dge mi dge'i rnam gzhag dang / de la rtag chad spong tshul lo/ /

The statement that cyclic existence exists essentially was advanced as a premise for the claim that things exist essentially. In response to the earlier refutation of this assertion, someone might argue as follows: Cyclic existence exists essentially because it is the basis of the relation between actions and their effects. If the essentially existent compounded phenomena or the sentient being transmigrates continuously from one birth and death to another, actions and effects must be related to one another [298], since actions performed in this life come to fruition in other lives. If there were not such cyclic existence, actions and their effects would be completely unrelated, since consciousness ceases immediately after it arises, and at the time when the karma is projected, the effect has not yet occurred. Thus, since it is the basis of the relation between actions and their effects, cyclic existence must exist essentially. What are actions and their effects? There are two parts to this discussion: setting out virtuous and nonvirtuous deeds and the method of dispelling nihilism and reification with respect to them.
dang po [dge mi dge'i rnam gzhag]
1.1.1 Setting out virtuous and nonvirtuous deeds
['di] la gnyis/ sems kyi dge mi dge'i rnam gzhag dang / las kyi rab tu dbye ba'i rnam gzhag go /
This section has two parts: setting out virtuous and nonvirtuous attitudes and setting out the different kinds of divisions of actions.
dang po [sems kyi dge mi dge'i rnam gzhag] ni/
1.1.1.1 Setting out virtuous and nonvirtuous attitudes
bdag nyid legs par sdom pa dang / / gzhan la phan 'dogs byams sems gang / / de chos de ni 'di gzhan du/ / 'bras bu dag gi sa bon yin/ /
1. Self-restraint and benefitting others With lovingkindness is the Dharma. This is the seed for Fruits in this and future lives.

bdag tu nga rgyal ba 'di la bzhag pas na bdag ste phung po la brten nas btags pa'i gang zag go / de nyid chags sogs kyi dbang gis srog gcod pa sogs la 'jug pa zlog par byed pas legs par sdom zhing nye bar gsog la las kyi rnam smin 'byin par nus pa la nges par byed pas sems dang*/ de yang ngan 'gror 'gro ba las 'dzin pas chos zhes bya'o/ / de tsam du zad dam snyam na ma yin te sbyin pa dang snyan par smra ba dang don spyod pa dang don mthun pa ste bsdu ba bzhi dang 'jigs pa las skyob pa sogs la zhugs pa gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i sems gang yin pa de dang / byams pa'i sems ni mdza' bshes la dmigs nas 'byung ba'i sems sam yang na bdag nyid la phan 'dogs pa'i sems gang yin pa de yang chos yin no/ / chos kyi sgra ni gsung rab las gsum la bshad de zag bcas zag med kyi chos thams cad ni rang gi mtshan nyid 'dzin pa'i don dang / dge ba bcu la sogs pa ni ngan 'gror 'gro ba las chos la skyabs su mchi zhes pa der ni mya ngan las 'dzin pa'i don dang / 'das pas 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor bar 'gro ba las 'dzin pa'i don gyis chos zhes gsungs so/ / de gsum las bzlog pa srog gcod sogs la 'jug pa mi sdom pa dang gzhan la gnod pa dang kun nas mnar sems pa'i sems ni chos ma yin par shes par bya'o/ / ji ltar sa lu'i sa bon ni sa lu'i myu gu'i rgyu thun mong ma yin pa dang sa la sogs pa ni thun mong ba'i rgyu yin pa de bzhin du/ sems gsum po de ni rnam smin yid du 'ong ba'i 'bras bu dag gis sa bon yin te skyes bu'i byed pa la sogs pa ni thun mong ba'i rgyu tsam du zad do/ / dus nam gyi tshe snyam na/ mthong ba'i skye ba 'di dang ma mthong ba'i skye ba gzhan du'o/ / mi dge ba la yang de ltar ro/ /

The self is that with respect to which the ego is posited; that is, the person which is imputed in dependence on the aggregates. That which prevents the person from engaging in such acts as killing, induced through the power of such attitudes as attachment with proper restraint/1/ and that which collects/2/ and regulates the ripening of the fruits of karma is mind. And that which holds the person back from falling into lower realms is Dharma./3/ That is not all that it means: It also includes “benefitting others with loving kindness,” including the four grounds of attraction—that is, generosity, gentle speech, beneficence, and integrity/4/—and saving others from such things as fear. The loving kindness one develops towards those who are near and dear or towards oneself is also Dharma. The scriptures give three meanings of the word “Dharma”: the holding (dhārayati) of their own characteristics by all of the contaminated and uncontaminated phenomena (dharmas) holding the person back from falling into lower realms through the ten virtuous actions,/5/ and holding the person back from transmigrating in the five transmigrations—cyclic existence—through nirvana, as expressed in “I take refuge in the Dharma.” [299] It should be understood that the opposites of these three are being unrestrained that is, engaging in such activities as killing, harming others, or antipathy towards others are non-Dharma (adharma). Just as a rice seed is the specific cause of a rice sprout and such things as the soil are the common causes of sprouts, these three kinds of attitudes are the seeds of pleasant ripened effects, because such things as the person’s effort are only the common causes. When would those effects arise? In the life we see, and in those other lives we do not see! The nonvirtues should be understood in the same way.
gnyis pa [las kyi rab tu dbye ba'i rnam gzhag]
1.1.1.2 Setting out the different kinds of divisions of actions
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa/ rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the brief presentation and the detailed explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1 Brief presentation
drang srong mchog gis las rnams ni/ / sems pa dang ni bsams par gsungs/ / las de dag gi bye brag ni/ / rnam pa du mar yongs su bsgrags/ /
2. The Unsurpassed Sage has said That actions are either intention or intentional. The varieties of these actions Have been delineated in many ways.

don dam pa / thugs su chud pas drang srong nyan rang dang byang sems mchog tu gyur pa dag gis las rnams ni rnam pa gnyis te sems pa'i las dang bsams pa'i las so zhes gsungs so/ / las gnyis po de dag gi bye brag ste rnam par dbye ba ni rnam pa du mar yongs su bsgrags pa ste bshad do/ /

Through realization of the ultimate truth, the Unsurpassed Sage, who is superior to the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas, has said that there are two kinds of action: intentions and intentional actions. Many varieties of these two kinds of actions are delineated—that is, explained.
gnyis pa [rgyas par bshad pa]
1.1.1.2.2 Detailed presentation
['di] la gnyis/ las gnyis la las gsum du dbye ba dang / las gsum la las bdun du dbye ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the three varieties of the two kinds of actions and the seven divisions of the three varieties of actions.
dang po [las gnyis la las gsum du dbye ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.1 The three varieties of the two kinds of actions
de la las gang sems pa zhes/ / gsungs pa de ni yid kyir 'dod/ / bsams pa zhes ni gang gsungs pa/ / de ni lus dang ngag gir 'dod/ /
3. Of these, what is called “intention” Is maintained to be mental. What is called “intentional” Comprises the physical and the verbal.

las gnyis gsungs pa de la ste de'i nang nas sems pa'i las zhes sngar gang gsungs pa de ni yid kyi rnam shes dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i sems pa kho na yin te/ yid kyir 'dod pa ste yid la yod pa'i phyir dang yid kyi sgo nas de mthar thug par 'gro zhing lus dang ngag 'jug pa la ltos pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / bsams pa'i las zhes gang gsungs pa de ni lus dang ngag gi yin par rig par bya ste lus dang ngag gi sgo nas de ltar 'jug par bya'o snyam du sems kyis bsams nas byed pa'i phyir ro/ // de gnyis kyang lus dang ngag gir 'dod pa ste lus dang ngag la yod pa'i phyir dang de gnyis kyi sgo nas rdzogs par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Of the two kinds of action mentioned earlier, that which is called “intention” is precisely the intention concomitant with mental consciousness. This is because intention is maintained to be mental; that is, it pertains to the mind and is accomplished by the mind and it does not depend on engaging in physical or verbal action. That which is called “intentional action” should be seen as physical and verbal, because it is done intentionally, with the intention to engage in physical and verbal action. These are also maintained to be physical and verbal because they pertain to the body and speech [300] and are accomplished by means of these two.
gnyis pa [las gsum la las bdun du dbye ba] ni/
1.1.1.2.2.2 The seven divisions of the three varieties of actions

ngag dang bskyod dang mi spong ba'i/ / rnam rig byed min zhes bya gang / / spong ba'i rnam rig byed min pa/ / gzhan dag kyang ni de bzhin 'dod/ / longs spyod las byung bsod nams dang / / bsod nams ma yin tshul de bzhin/ / sems pa dang ni chos de bdun/ / las su mngon par 'dod pa yin/ /

4. Speech and physical action: Unobservable unrejected actions, and Unobservable rejected actions; As well as … 5. Virtuous and nonvirtuous actions Derived from enjoyment; As well as intention: All are maintained to be similar. These seven phenomena are the kinds of action.

dge mi dge'i ngag yi ge gsal por brjod pa dang dge mi dge'i lus kyi bsgul bskyod gnyis dang rig byed kyi dbye ba gnyis yod pa de bzhin du rig byed las gzhan pa rnam par rig byed ma yin pa dag kyang dge mi dge gnyis su 'dod pa dang / yongs su btang ba'i dngos po dge 'dun la sogs pa rnams kyis longs spyad pa las de'i rjes su sbyin pa po'i rgyud byung ba'i bsod nams dge ba 'phel ba dang / dge ba skye ba'i tshul de bzhin du srog chags gsod pa'i lha khang brtsigs par srog chags bsad cing lha khang la sogs pa der longs spyad pa las de'i rjes su byed pa po rnams kyi rgyud la byung ba'i bsod nams ma yin pa sdig pa skye bar 'gyur ba dang / yid kyi las dge mi dge la mngon par 'du byed pa'i sems pa dang chos de bdun ni las su mngon par 'dod pa yin no/ / rnam par rig byed ma yin pa mi dge ba ni mi spong ba'i rnam par rig byed min pa zhes bya ba gang yin pa ste/ deng nas bzung nas sems can bsad cing chom rkun byas la 'tsho bar bya'o zhes khas blangs pa dang nya pa la sogs pa rgya'i las byed pa nas bzung ste bya ba de dag dngos su mi byed pa'i dus su'ang rgyun mi 'chad par mi dge ba'i rig min skye ba'o/ /

Virtuous and nonvirtuous speech—that is, clear verbal expression—and virtuous and nonvirtuous physical action are the two kinds of observables. In the same way, that which is other than the observable—that is, the unobservable—is also maintained to be of two kinds: the virtuous and the nonvirtuous. When the sangha and others enjoy the things that have been completely relinquished to them, then the merit—the virtue—develops in the continuum of the benefactor. Just as that virtue arises, when a temple is built in which animals are sacrificed, when people enjoy the temple where such things as sacrifices are held, thereby the demerit—the vice—develops in their continua. Mental action—intention—initiates virtuous and nonvirtuous action. These seven phenomena are maintained to be actions. The nonvirtuous unobservable is the unobservable subtle substance of nonrejection./6/ That is, when one resolves, “From now on, I will earn my living by killing sentient beings, or by robbery,” or when one adopts a profession such as that of a fisherman or a trapper, from the moment one engages in such activities as trapping, even when one is not actively engaging in these activities, a nonobservable nonvirtuous substance continuously arises in one’s continuum.

de yang mdzod las/ sdom pa min pa bya ba'am/ khas len pa las thob par 'gyur/ / zhes sdom min thob tshul gnyis gsungs pa'i dang po ni nya pa la sogs pa'i rigs su skyes pa rnams ni gsod pa'i sbyor ba byas pa dang / phyi ma ni gzhan gyi rigs su skyes pa rnams ni bdag cag kyang 'tsho ba 'dis 'tsho bar bya'o zhes khas blangs pa las 'thob par rang 'grel las bshad do/ / 'di yang rig min gyi sdom min 'thob tshul yin gyi rig min gyi dge ba tsam la min no/ / dge ba'i rig byed ma yin pa ni spong ba'i rnam par rig byed min pa ste deng nas bzung ste srog gcod pa sogs spong ngo zhes lus ngag gi rigs byed rdzogs pa'i dus nas bzung ste/ dus phyis myos pa la sogs pa'i skabs su yang dge ba'i rig min skye ba'o//'di yang sdom pa dang bar ma'i rig min 'ga' zhig gi skye tshul yin gyi dge ba'i rig min thams cad la min no//gzugs dang bya ba'i rang bzhin yin kyang rig byed bzhin du kun slong gzhan la rig par mi byed pas rig byed ma yin pa'o/ /

The Abhidharmakośa says, Ill-discipline is developed Through action or resolution. [IV: 37ab] The first of the two ways of developing ill-discipline is through engaging in the action of killing, like someone of a caste such as that of a fisherman. The second way is by someone not borne into those castes resolving to earn one’s living in that same way, as it is explained in the autocommentary [mNgon pa khu 168b]. And this how the unobservable ill-discipline develops, but not how mere unobservable vice develops. [301] The virtuous unobservable is the unobservable subtle substance of rejection. That is, one says, “From now onward, I reject such activities as killing.” From the moment one completes those observable physical and verbal actions, later on, even when one is drunk or in some similar state, the virtuous unobservable continues to arise. This is also the way unobservable substances develop in the context of discipline and some morally neutral actions. But it is not the way all virtuous unobservables develop. Although these unobservables have the nature of both material form and action, they are unobservable, because unlike the observables, the intention cannot be observed by others.
gnyis pa [de la rtag chad spong tshul]
1.1.2 The method of dispelling nihilism and reification with respect to virtuous and nonvirtuous deeds
['di] la gnyis/ rtsod pa dgod pa dang / de spong ba'i tshul lo/ /
