This section has two parts: presenting the opponent’s argument and how to refute it.
dang po [rtsod pa dgod pa] ni/
1.1.2.1 Presenting the opponent’s argument
gal te smin pa'i dus bar du/ / gnas na las de rtag par 'gyur/ / gal te 'gags na 'gag gyur pas/ / ci ltar 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur/ /
6. If until the time of ripening Action had to endure, it would be permanent. If it has ceased, then having ceased, How will a fruit arise?

'di la kha cig rgol te gal te las mang po zhig bshad pa de la las de rnam smin phyung ba'i dus kyi bar du mi 'jig par gnas na rtag par 'gyur te/ / de'i bar du 'jig pa dang / bral ba'i phyir dang sngar mi 'jig pa phyis kyang mi 'jig pas 'dus ma byas su 'gyur ba'i phyir dang 'dus ma byas kyis rnam smin mi 'byin pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te las rnams skyes ma thag tu 'gags na ji ltar na 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te 'gags par gyur ba ni yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Here some argue that if those actions—many kinds of which have been explained earlier—endure without cessation until the time ripening, they would be permanent, because they would have to be free of cessation until then; and since those that do not cease earlier also do not cease later, they would therefore be uncompounded, and uncompounded phenomena do not induce ripening. If actions ceased immediately after they arose, how could they give rise to effects? They could not, because that which has ceased does not exist any more.
gnyis pa [de spong ba'i tshul]
1.1.2.2 How to refute it
['di] la gnyis/ rgyun khas blangs nas rtag chad spong ba dang / chud mi za ba khas blangs nas rtag chad spong ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: dispelling reification and nihilism through asserting that there is a continuum and dispelling reification and nihilism through asserting that karma is indestructible.
dang po [rgyun khas blangs nas rtag chad spong ba]
1.1.2.2.1 Dispelling reification and nihilism through asserting that there is a continuum
['di] la gnyis/ rtag chad spong tshul dngos dang / las lam bcu 'bras bu dang bcas pa ngos gzung ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the principal mode of refuting reification and nihilism and identifying the ten paths of action with their respective effects.
dang po [rtag chad spong tshul dngos]
1.1.2.2.1.1 The principal mode of refuting reification and nihilism
['di] la gnyis/ dpe dgod pa/ don la sbyar ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: presenting the example and applying the analogy.
dang po [dpe dgod pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.1.1.1 Presenting the example

myu gu la sogs rgyun gang ni/ / sa bon las ni mngon par 'byung / / de las 'bras bu sa bon ni/ / med na de yang 'byung mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir sa bon las rgyun dang*/ / rgyun las 'bras bu 'byung 'gyur zhing / / sa bon 'bras bu'i sngon 'gro ba/ / de phyir chad min rtag ma yin/ /

7. Any continuum, such as that of a sprout, Comes from a seed. From that arises the fruit. Without a seed, It would not come into being either. 8. Since from the seed comes the continuum, And from the continuum comes the fruit, The seed precedes the fruit. Therefore there is neither nonexistence nor permanence.

de ltar brtag pa gnyis byas pa'i dang po ni khas mi len la/brtag pa gnyis pa ltar 'dod kyang skyon med do/ / sa bon skad cig ma yin kyang myu gu dang la sogs pa'i sgras bsdus pa sdong bu dang sbubs 'chas pa dang lo ma la sogs pa 'bras bu'i rgyun gang yin pa rnams ni sa bon las mngon par 'byung ba ste sa bon de rnams kyi rgyur gyur nas 'gag go / 'bras bu'i rgyun de las ni mtha'i 'bras bu'i tshogs rgya chen po skye'o/ / sa bon de sngon du song ba med na myu gu la sogs pa'i rgyun de yang 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / gang gi phyir sa bon las myu gu la sogs pa'i rgyun dang rgyun las mtha'i 'bras bu 'byung bar 'gyur zhing / sa bon 'bras bu'i sngon du 'gro ba de'i phyir 'bras bu'i rgyun mi 'byung ba'i chad pa dang 'bras bu phyung gi bar du mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rtag pa ma yin no/ /

The first of the opponent’s two analyses is not acceptable. The second analysis is acceptable, but the alleged erroneous consequences do not follow. Although the seed is momentary, the sprout and all that is indicated by “such as,” including such things as the plant, the stem, and the leaves—the continuum of effects—arises subsequently from the seed. [302] That is, the seed ceases after having caused them. Subsequently, from that continuum of effects, a vast array of effects arises. Without the seed preceding them, the continuum of such things as the sprout would not have arisen. Because the continuum of the sprout arises from the seed, and the subsequent effects arise from that continuum, and because the seed precedes the fruit, there is no termination, no non-arising of the continuum of effects; and there is no permanence, no endurance of the seed without cessation until the effect arises.
gnyis pa [don la sbyar ba] ni/
1.1.2.2.1.1.2 Applying the analogy

sems kyi rgyun ni gang yin pa/ / sems las mngon par 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de las 'bras bu sems lta zhig / med na de yang 'byung mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir sems las rgyun dang ni/ / rgyun las 'bras bu 'byung 'gyur zhing / / las ni 'bras bu'i sngon 'gro ba/ / de phyir chad min rtag ma yin/ /

9. So a mental continuum arises From a preceding intention. From this a consequent mental state arises. Without that, it would not arise. 10. Since from the intention comes the continuum, And from that continuum the fruit arises, Action precedes the fruit. Therefore there is neither termination nor permanence.

ji ltar sa bon la smras pa de bzhin du sems pa dge ba dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i sems las sems kyi rgyun phyi ma gang yin pa mngon par 'byung bar 'gyur la/ sems pa dge bas bsgos pa'i sems kyi rgyun de las ni lhan cig byed pa'i rgyu ma tshang ba med pa na 'bras bu rnam smin yid du 'ong ba skye'o/ snga ma'i sems lta zhig med na ni phyi ma'i sems kyi rgyun de yang 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ // gang gi phyir snga ma'i sems las phyi ma'i sems kyi rgyun dang rgyun de las mtha'i 'bras bu yid du 'ong ba 'byung bar 'gyur zhing*/ sems pa'i las ni 'bras bu'i sngon du 'gro ba de yi phyir sems kyi rgyun phyi ma'i rgyur ma gyur par 'gags pa'i las kyis rgyun chad pa dang / rgyun phyi ma'i rgyu byas nas kyang mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rtag pa ma yin pas las skad cig mar khas blangs kyang rtag chad du 'gyur ba ma yin no/ / 'di sde pa gang gis 'dod rtsa she'i 'grel pa 'grel bshad rnams las mi gsal yang mdzod 'grel gyi gnas dgu par bshad pa dang mthun pas mdo sde pa dang kha che ba'i 'dod pa'o/ /

Just as we discussed in the case of the seed, the subsequent mental continuum arises from the mental state concomitant with the virtuous intention. If that mental continuum colored by the virtuous intention meets with all of the requisite auxilliary causes, a pleasant ripened result will occur. If there were no earlier mental state, the later mental continuum would not arise. The later mental continuum comes from the earlier mental state and the subsequent pleasant effects arise from that continuum and intentional action precedes its effect. Therefore, there is no termination of the continuum of action—that is, cessation—without causing the subsequent mental continuum. And there is no permanence—that is, the endurance without cessation of the continuum after being caused. Therefore, even though the action is asserted to be momentary, there is neither permanence nor termination. It is not clear from any of the commentaries on Mūlamadhyamakakārikā which school maintains the view refuted here. However, since it is consistent with what is explained in the ninth chapter of Abhidharmakośa, it is the view of the sautrāntrikas and the Kashmiris.
gnyis pa [las lam bcu 'bras bu dang bcas pa ngos gzung ba] ni/
1.1.2.2.1.2 Identifying the ten paths of action with their respective effects
dkar po'i las kyi lam bcu po/ / chos sgrub pa yi thabs yin te/ / chos kyi 'bras bu 'di gzhan du/ / 'dod pa'i yon tan rnam lnga po/ /
11. The ten pure paths of action Are the method for practicing the Dharma. The fruits of this Dharma in this and other lives Are the five sensual pleasures.

de yi phyir las kyi rab tu dbye ba ji skad bstan pa'i ngag dang bskyod dang zhes pa la sogs par lus kyi gsum dang ngag gi bzhi dang sems pa dang ni zhes par yid kyi gsum ste dkar po'i las kyi lam bcu po yang bshad pa yin la/ de dag kyang chos sgrub pa'i thabs te 'grub pa'i rgyur gyur pa'o/ / 'o na bcu po 'di gang gi thabs su 'gyur ba'i chos de gang yin zhe na sngar bshad pa ltar gyi sems gsum la chos zhes bya ba'am yang na dge ba bcu mthar gtugs pa'i ngo bo ni chos yin la byed bzhin pa'i ngo bo ni dge ba'i las kyi lam gyi sgra'i brjod bya'o/ / chos de'i 'bras bu ni skye ba 'di dang skye ba gzhan du gzugs yid du 'ong ba la sogs pa lnga la nye bar longs spyod pa'o/ / las lam bcu chos sgrub pa'i thabs dang 'di phyir 'dod yon yid du 'ong ba la longs spyod pa chos kyi 'bras bur gsungs pas las dang 'bras bur 'brel ba yang rang bzhin gyis yod do snyam du bsams so/ /

Therefore, the divisions of action have been presented: the three physical and four verbal actions by “speech and physical action,” etc. [XVII: 4], [303] and three mental actions by “as well as intention” [5c]. These are explained to be the ten pure paths of action, and they are the method for practicing the Dharma—that is, the causes of its accomplishment. “Now,” one might ask, “what is that Dharma for the practice of which these ten are the method?” As we explained previously, “Dharma” should be taken to refer to the three attitudes,/7/ or, the state of having completely achieved the ten virtues can be taken to be Dharma. The very engagement in them is the meaning of the phrase “path of virtuous action.” The fruit of this Dharma is the enjoyment of the five kinds of phenomena, such as pleasant material form in this life and in other lives. Some think that since the ten paths are said to be the means of practicing the Dharma and the experience of sensual pleasures are said to be the fruits of Dharma, the relation between the action and the fruit must exist essentially.
gnyis pa [chud mi za ba khas blangs nas rtag chad spong ba]
1.1.2.2.2 Dispelling reification and nihilism through asserting that karma is indestructible
['di] la gnyis/ sde pa gzhan gyi lan dgag / rang gi lan gdab pa'o/ /
The section has two parts: the refutation of responses of other schools and our own response.
dang po [sde pa gzhan gyi lan dgag] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.1 Refutation of responses of other schools
gal te brtag pa der gyur na/ / nyes pa chen por mang por 'gyur/ / de lta bas na brtag pa de/ / 'dir ni 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
12. If it were conceived in this way Many serious errors would follow. Therefore, such a conception Is not tenable here.

gal te sa bon dang myu gu dang chos mthun pa'i sgo nas sems kyi rgyun la rtag chad spong ba'i brtag pa der 'gyur na ni/ phyogs de la mthong ba dang ma mthong ba dang 'gal ba'i nyes pa chen po dang nyes pa grangs mang por 'gyur ro/ / 'di ltar sa lu'i sa bon las sa lu'i myu gu la sogs pa'i rgyun dang sa lu'i myu gu la sogs pa'i rgyun las kyang sa lu'i 'bras bu kho na skye'i rigs mi mthun pa gzhan mi skye ba bzhin du/ dge mi dge lung ma bstan gyi sems dang 'dod pa dang gzugs dang gzugs med dang zag med kyi sems dang mi la sogs pa'i 'gro ba drug gi sems las kyang rang rang dang rigs mthun pa kho na 'byung gi rigs mi mthun pa'i sems mi skye ba dang / lha gang yin pa ni lha kho nar 'gyur la 'gro ba gzhan du mi 'gro ba sogs 'gyur ro/ / de lta na lha dang mi mi dge ba byed pa rnams ngan 'gror 'gro ba med par 'gyur na 'dod pa yang min no/ / skyon de dag yod pa de lta bas na sde pa gzhan gyis smras pa'i brtag pa de las la rtag chad spong ba'i lan gyi skabs 'dir 'thad pa ma yin no/ /

If one thinks that the analysis of the mental continuum as similar to the case of the seed and sprout avoids nihilism and reification, one’s position will suffer from many great errors: Homogeneous cases will not have homeogeneous properties, things with heterogeneous properties will not be heterogeneous cases, and there will be contradictions./8/ The rice seed only gives rise to the continuum of a rice sprout and the continuum of the rice sprout only gives rise to rice as an effect, but these never give rise to anything of a heterogeneous species. One would have to say that in the same way, virtuous, nonvirtuous, or morally neutral mental states, mental states associated with the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm; and uncontaminated mental states and the six kinds of transmigrations, such as the human, give rise only to mental states of a homogeneous kind, but not to mental states of a heterogeneous kind. It would follow that a god would only become a god and would not transmigrate to any other kind of transmigration. In that case, a human being or a god who performs nonvirtuous acts would not experience unfavourable transmigrations. But one can not maintain this! [304] Since these errors ensue, it is not tenable in the context of this response that one avoids the errors of reification and nihilism through the ideas expressed by other schools.
gnyis pa [rang gi lan gdab pa]
1.1.2.2.2.2 Our own response
['di] la gsum/ mdor bstan pa/ rgyas par bshad pa/ don bsdus te rtag chad spang ba'o/ /
This section has three parts: the brief presentation, the detailed explanation, and the concise disimssal of reification and nihilism.
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.1 Brief presentation

sangs rgyas rnams dang rang rgyal dang / / nyan thos rnams kyi gang gsungs pa'i/ / brtag pa gang zhig 'dir 'thad pa/ / de ni rab tu brjod par bya/ / dpang rgya ji ltar de bzhin chud/ / mi za las ni bu lon bzhin/ /
13. I will now explain The analysis advocated by all Buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, and śrāvakas Which is apposite here. 14. Karma is indestructible, like a promissory note And like a debt.

sangs rgyas rnams dang rang rgyal ba dang nyan thos rnams kyis gang gsungs pa'i brtag pa gang zhig lan gyi skabs 'dir ni 'thad pa de ni 'dir rab tu brjod par bya'o/ // brtag pa de yang gang zhe na/ dge mi dge'i las byas ma thag tu 'jig kyang 'bras bu med par mi 'gyur te las skye ba'i tshe byed pa po'i rgyud la las de'i chud mi za ba zhes bya ba ldan min 'du byed du gtogs pa bu lon gyi dpang rgya 'dra ba zhig skye'o/ / dpang rgya ji lta ba de bzhin du chud mi za ba dang de skyed pa'i las ni bu lon bzhin du rig par bya'o// // bu lon gyi dpang rgya bzhag nas nor spyad kyang nor bdag gi nor dus gzhan gyi tshe skyed dang bcas pa 'ong ba bzhin du/ las byas ma thag tu zhig kyang chud mi za ba gnas pas byed pa pos las kyi 'bras bu myong bar byed do// bu lon gyi dpang rgya gtong ba po la nor bkug nas nor gyur pa ni yod dam med kyang rung ste slar yang nor 'gugs mi nus pa bzhin du/ chud mi za ba yang rnam smin phyung nas yod dam med kyang rung ste slar yang byed pa po rnam smin dang 'brel bar byed mi nus so/ / 'di ni bye brag tu smra ba 'dod par spyan ras gzigs brtul zhugs kyis bshad de kha che ba las gzhan no/

Here we demonstrate that the analysis propounded by the buddhas, the pratyekabuddhas, and śrāvakas is apposite in the context of this response. What is that analysis? Although all virtuous and nonvirtuous actions cease immediately upon their completion, they are not without effects, because when the karma arises, a nonmental compound called an indestructible element associated with karma arises in the continuum of the agent like a promissory note. It should be understood that, just like a promissory note, it is indestructible, and the karma to which it gives rise is like the debt. In virtue of executing the promissory note, even though the money has been spent, the creditor will receive the money with interest at a later time. In the same way, even though the action is disintegrated immediately after it is performed, as it endures without destruction, the agent experiences the effect of the action. Once the money is repaid to the creditor—whether or not he still has the money—he cannot claim the money again with the same promissory note. In the same way, when the indestructible karma has ripened—whether or not that effect still remains—it can no longer have anything to do with that agent. Avalokitavrata explains this to be the assertion of the Vaibhāsikas. [Avalokitavrata-vrtti, Vol. III, dBu ma za 34a]. Therefore, it is different from the Kashmiris’ position.
gnyis pa [rgyas par bshad pa]
1.1.2.2.2.2.2 Detailed explanation
['di] la bzhi/ khams kyi dbye ba dang rang bzhin/ spang bya gang yin pa/ skye ba'i tshul/ 'gag pa'i tshul lo/ /
This section has four parts: The divisions of the realms and their natures, what is to be abandoned, the way one takes birth, and the mode of cessation.
dang po [khams kyi dbye ba dang rang bzhin] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.2.1 The divisions of the realms and their natures
de ni khams las rnam pa bzhin/ / de yang rang bzhin lung ma bstan/ /
14dc. Because of the realms, there are four kinds. Moreover, its nature is neutral.

mdo gzhan pas gsungs shing kho bo cag gis smras pa'i chud mi za ba de ni 'dod pa dang gzugs dang gzugs med pa dang zag med kyi khams kyi dbye ba las rnam pa bzhi'o/ khams gsum dang zag med du gtogs pa'i las kyi bye brag gis phye na zag bcas dang zag med du shes par bya bar zad kyi chud mi za ba'i ngo bo ni zag bcas dang zag med du brda mi sprod pas lung ma bstan no zhes spyan ras gzigs brtul zhugs kyis bshad de/ zag bcas min par gsungs pa ni las zag bcas la dgongs kyi zag bcas tsam min pa min te sgom spang du gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / chud mi za ba de yang dge mi dger brda sprad du med pas lung du ma bstan pa ste gal te mi dge ba'i chud mi za ba mi dge ba yin na/ 'dod pa la chags pa dang bral ba la mi dge ba med pa bzhin du de'i chud mi za ba yang med par 'gyur ro/ / dge ba'i chud mi za ba dge ba yin na'ang log ltas dge rtsa bcad pa la de med par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

It is said in other sūtras that the indestructible karmas that we mention here are, because of the desire, form, formless, and uncontaminated realms, of four kinds. [305] Avalokitavrata says that it should be understood that since karma can be categorized as pertaining to either the three realms or to the uncontaminated, it has to be either contaminated or uncontaminated; but its indestructible nature cannot be said to be either contaminated or uncontaminated. Therefore it is said to be neutral [dBu ma za 34b]./9/ When it says that it is not contaminated it refers to contaminated karma. But it does not mean that it is just not contaminated, because it is said to be abandoned through the path of meditation. That indestructible continuum as well can neither be described as virtuous nor nonvirtuous, and thus it is morally neutral. This is because if the indestructibility of the nonvirtuous action were itself nonvirtuous, then since one who is free from attachment to the desire realm does not have any vices, it would follow that he could not have their indestructibility either. If the indestructibility of the virtuous action were itself virtuous on the other hand, then it would follow that the person who has extirpated the roots of virtue through adopting a deviant view would not have its indestructibility.
gnyis pa [spang bya gang yin pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.2.2 What is to be abandoned
spong bas spang ba ma yin te/ / bgom pas spang ba nyid kyang yin/ / de phyir chud mi za ba yi/ / las kyi 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur/ /
15. Abandonment does not occur through abandoning. Abandonment occurs instead through meditation. Therefore, in virtue of indestructibility The effect of action arises.

chud mi za ba de mthong lam gyis mthong spang spong bas spang bar bya ba ma yin te sgom pas spang ba nyid yin no/ / kyang zhes pas khams las 'das pa na der gtogs pa'i las kyi chud mi za ba spong ba bsdu'o/ / so so skye bo'i las mthong lam gyis ma spangs na 'phags pa so so skye bo'i las dang ldan par 'gyur bas spong mod kyang de'i chud mi za ba mthong spang min no/ / las zhig kyang de'i chud mi za ba mi 'jig la las spangs kyang de'i chud mi za ba mi spong ba de'i phyir las de dag gi chud mi za ba de yis las kyi 'bras bu skyed par 'gyur ro/ / gal te las gnyen pos spangs pa dang las 'jig pa na chud mi za ba spangs pa dang 'jig na skyon ci yod snyam na/

The indestructible continuum is not abandoned through the path of seeing in virtue of the abandonment of that which is to be abandoned by the path of seeing; rather, it is to be abandoned by the path of meditation. “Instead” refers to the abandonment of the indestructable continuum of the actions connected with the realms when one transcends them. If the actions of common beings were not abandoned by the path of seeing, the aryas would retain the karma of common beings. Thus although they abandon that karma, its indestructibility is not to be abandoned by the path of seeing. Although an action is disintegrated, its indestructible continuum does not cease. Although the action is abandoned, since its indestructible continuum is not abandoned in virtue of the indestructibility of the karma, the effect of the action arises. Suppose one asked, “What error ensues if you say that when actions are abandoned via the antidote, or cease, one abandons the indestructible continuum, or it ceases?”
gal te spong bas spang ba dang / / las 'pho ba yis 'jig 'gyur na/ / de la las 'jig la sogs pa'i/ / skyon rnams su ni thal bar 'gyur/
16. If abandonment occurred through abandoning, or If action were destroyed in virtue of transformation, Absurd consequences such as The annihilation of karma would follow.

gal te so so skye bo'i las mthong spang spong bas spangs pa dang las 'pho ba ste/ 'jig ya yis de dag gi chud mi za ba 'jig par 'gyur na/ del ste de yi tshe las byas pa 'jig pa ste chud zos pa kho nar 'gyur la de'i phyir/ la sogs pa'i sgras bsdus pa 'phags pa rnams kyis so so skye bo'i dus su bsags pa'i las kyi 'bras bu gnyis gang yang myong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / myong na'ang ma byas pa'i las kyi 'bras bu 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / las dang 'bras bu med par lta ba'i phyir log par lta bar 'gyur ba'i skyon rnams su thal bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du las 'pho ba la yang sbyar ro/ /

If the indestructible continuum ceased through ordinary beings’ actions being abandoned in virtue of the abandonment of that which is to be abandoned by the path of seeing or through transformation of action—its cessation—then the karma that has been produced would be annihilated—that is, rendered nonexistent. [306] Therefore, the words “such as” indicate these additional absurd consequences: In that case the aryas would not experience the two consequences of the karma accumulated when they were ordinary beings; and, even if they did experience them, they would be results of actions that had not been performed; and, since this would be a view according to which there are no effects of actions, this would be a deviant view. This argument applies, mutatis mutandis, to the transformation of karma.
gsum pa [skye ba'i tshul] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.2.3 The way one takes birth
khams mtshungs las ni cha mtshungs dang / / cha mi mtshungs pa thams cad kyi/ / de ni nying mtshams sbyor ba'i tshe/ / gcig bu kho na skye bar 'gyur/ /
17. From all the karma in a realm, Whether congruent or incongruent, At the moment of conception Only one will arise.

nying mtshams sbyor ba'i tshe chud mi za ba ji ltar skye ba ni las ni cha ste rigs mtshungs pa dang cha ste rigs mi mtshungs pa thams cad kyi chud mi za ba de ni khams gsum po gang du nying mtshams sbyor ba'i tshe las thams cad bshig nas gcig kho na skye bar 'gyur ro/ / de yang 'dod pa khams la sogs pa khams mtshungs pa ste khams mnyam pa rnams kyi kho na skye'i mi mtshungs pa rnams kyi ni min no/ / nying mtshams sbyar ba'i 'og tu chud mi za ba'i skye tshul ni

How could indestructibility arise at conception?/10/ When all the other karma is destroyed, only the indestructibility of the karma, whether congruent (that is, of a similar kind) or incongruent (that is, of a dissimilar kind) in whichever of the three realms this conception occurs, arises. Moreover, the indestructible karma corresponding to the congruent realms—such as the desire realm—arises only in those realms, but does not arise in the incongruent realms. After conception, the way the indestructibility arises is as follows:
mthong ba'i chos la rnam gnyis po/ / thams cad las dang las kyi de/ / tha dad par ni skye 'gyur zhing / / rnam par smin kyang gnas pa yin/ /
18. In the here and now, Each karma and that which pertains to that karma Of either of the two kinds, arises separately and Although they ripen, they endure.

chud mi za ba de ni mthong ba'i chos tshe 'di la zag bcas dang zag med rnam pa gnyis po kun gyi ste sems pa dang / bsam pa'am dge ba'am mi dge ba'i las dang las kyi chud mi za ba tha dad pa re re skye bar 'gyur zhing / 'bras bu rnam par smin pa phyung zin kyang gnas pa yin pa ste gdon mi za bar mi 'gag go /

In the here and now—that is, in this life—each karma of either of the two kinds, contaminated or uncontaminated—that is, virtuous or nonvirtuous, whether intention or intentional and that which pertains to it, its indestructibility, arises separately. Although the ripened fruit has already arisen, the indestructibility endures; that is, it undoubtedly does not cease.
bzhi pa ['gag pa'i tshul] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.2.4 The mode of cessation
de ni 'bras bu 'pho ba dang / / shi bar gyur na 'gag par 'gyur/ / de yi rnam dbye zag med dang / / zag dang bcas par shes par bya/ /
19. That ceases when one moves To a stage of fruition or dies. One should understand that it has divisions: The uncontaminated and the contaminated.

chud mi za ba de ni zhig nas 'gro ba'i skabs gnyis te rgyun zhugs la sogs pa'i 'bras bu 'pho ba'i skabs dang / shi bar gyur pa'i tshe na 'gag par 'gyur la de'i dang po ni/ sgom pas spang ba nyid kyang yin zhes pa dang / gnyis pa ni/ de ni nying mtshams sbyor ba'i tshe/ gcig pu kho na skye bar 'gyur/ / zhes par bshad zin pas slar yang 'dir ma smos so/ / chud mi za ba de'i rnam dbye ni rnam pa gnyis su shes par bya ste zag pa med pa'i las kyi ni zag med dang zag pa dang bcas pa'i las kyi ni zag pa dang bcas par ro/ / 'di yang las gnyis kyi dbang gis de ltar tha snyad btags par spyan ras gzigs brtul zhugs kyis bshad do/ /

There are two occasions when the indestructibility disintegrates: At the time when one moves to a stage of fruition, such as that of a stream-enterer, or when one dies, it ceases. The first of these has been explained by “abandonment occurs instead through meditation” [XVII: 15b], and the second has been explained by At the moment of conception Only one will arise. [XVII: 17cd] Therefore they are not repeated here. The indestructability should be understood to have two divisions: That of the uncontaminated karma is uncontaminated, and that of the contaminated karma is contaminated. [307] According to Avalokitavrata [dBu ma za: 38a] they are thus so-called on the basis of the two kinds of karma.
gsum pa [don bsdus te rtag chad spang ba] ni/
1.1.2.2.2.2.3 Concise disimssal of reification and nihilism
stong pa nyid dang chad med dang / / 'khor ba dang ni rtag pa min/ / las rnams chud mi za ba'i chos/ / sangs rgyas kyis ni bstan pa yin/ /
20. Emptiness is not annihiliation; Cyclic existence is not permanent: The doctrine of the indestructability of karma Is taught by the Buddha.

de yi phyir las ni byas ma thag tu 'gag la rang bzhin gyis gnas pa ni ma yin pas stong pa nyid du 'thad do/ / de lta na'ang chad pa med de chud mi za bas yongs su bzung bas las kyi 'bras bu yod pa'i phyir ro/ / chud mi za ba yod pa'i phyir dang sa bon gyi rgyun dang chos mthun pa'i brtag pa med pa'i phyir/ 'gro ba dang rigs dang skye gnas dang khams sna tshogs pa'i dbye bas phye ba 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor ba grub pa yang yin la/ las rang gi ngo bos mi gnas par khas blangs pa'i phyir rtag par smra ba yang min no/ / las rnams chud mi za ba zhes pa'i chos 'di ni ma rig pa'i gnyid ma lus pa dang bral ba'i sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa yin pa'i phyir/ las la rtag chad du thal ba'i skyon med pas kho bo cag gis brjod pa'i brtag pa 'di kho na rigs so zhes 'dzer to/ /

Therefore it is tenable that the cessation of action immediately after its performance and its essential nonexistence is its emptiness. But nonetheless, this is not annihiliation because its indestructability ensures that the action has effects. Because there is indestructiblity and since homogeneity as it is fabricated in the continuum of the seed is nonexistent/11/ cyclic existence, comprising the five transmigrations involving different kinds of transmigrators, different manners of birth, and different kinds of realms, exists. Since karma is not asserted to endure inherently its permanence is not asserted either. This doctrine of the indestructibility of karma is the doctrine taught by the Buddha completely free from the slumber of ignorance. Thus Nāgārjuna says that since it is free from the erroneous extremes of reification and nihilism, the conception of karma that we have presented is tenable.
gnyis pa [lan]
1.2 The reply
['di] la gsum/ las la rang bzhin med pas rtag chad med pa dang / las rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa dang / rang bzhin med pas bya ba byed pa dpes bstan pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: Since karma is essenceless, there is neither nihilism nor reification, the refutation of the essential existence of karma, and demonstrating by examples that, because of essencelessness, things can perform functions.
dang po [las la rang bzhin med pas rtag chad med pa] ni/
1.2.1 Since karma is essenceless, there is neither nihilism nor reification
gang phyir las ni skye ba med/ / 'di ltar rang bzhin med de'i phyir/ / gang phyir de ni ma skyes pa/ / de phyir chud zad mi 'gyur ro/ /
21. Why is karma without arising? Because it is without essence. Because it is not arisen, It follows that it is indestructible.

las rang gi ngo bos skye na de rnam par ma smin gyi bar du gnas na rtag pa dang 'jig na chad par 'gyur na'ang gang gi phyir las ni rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis skye ba med pa'i phyir rang bzhin gyis gnas pa'i rtag pa dang rang bzhin gyis 'jig pa'i chad par ga la 'gyur/ de'i rgyu mtshan 'di ltar las ni rang bzhin gyis grub pa med pa de'i phyir ro/ / gal te las rang bzhin gyis skye ba med na lung las/ lus can rnams kyis las rnams ni/ / bskal pa brgyar yang chud mi za/ / tshogs shing dus la bab pa na/ / 'bras bu nyid du smin par 'gyur/ / zhes de skad du gsungs she na/ bcom ldan 'das kyi dgongs pa ni gang gi phyir las de ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis ma skyes pa de yi phyir chud za bar mi 'gyur ro zhes bya ba de ltar yin te de yi phyir lung de ni kho bo cag la gnod byed min no/ / nyan thos sde pas las rang bzhin gyis skye ba med na las med dgos pas las kyi chud mi za ba gsungs pa dang 'gal lo snyam du brtsad rang bzhin gyis ma skyed pas chud mi za'o zhes gsungs pa ji ltar 'brel te chud mi za ba ni las kyi rnam smin 'byin pa'i don du 'dod pas so zhe na/ skyon med de rgol ba 'di don dam pa la bsams nas yin na ni las don dam par ma skyes pa la de'i 'bras bu chud za rgyu med cing / don dam par skye ba med pa dang tha snyad du rnam smin chud mi za ba 'gal bar rtsod na ni mi 'gal bar mang du bshad cing 'chad par yang 'gyur ba'i pa'i lan du/ phyir ro/ / gal te rang gi mtshan nyid kyis skye ba med pa rgyu mtshan du bkod nas rnam smin chud mi za bar sgrub na/rgyu mtshan des tha snyad du las kyis rnam smin 'byin pa mi 'gal bar ji ltar 'grub snyam na/

If karma were inherently arisen, then, if it endured until ripening, it would be permanent, and if instead it ceased, it would be annihilated. However, since karma does not arise inherently, how could reification, its essential endurance, or nihilism, its essential cessation, follow? The reason that they do not is that karma does not exist essentially. If karma does not essentially arise, then why is the following said in sūtra? Beings’ karma is not destroyed Even after a hundred aeons. When the assemblage is complete, and the time is right The fruit will ripen. [Vinayakṣurakavastu-sūtra’Dul ba tha 153a, 156a and 157a]/12/ [308] The Transcendent Lord’s intent here is as follows: Since no karma is arisen through its own characteristic, no karma is destructible. Therefore, this does not undermine our own position. Suppose one argued as follows: The śrāvakas argue that if karma were not essentially arisen, there would be no karma, and this would contradict what has been said about the indestructibility of karma. Since “indestructiblity” refers to the fruition of the ripening of karma, how could saying “since karma is not essentially arisen it is indestructible” be a coherent reply to these arguments? There is no error here; Suppose this opponent has the ultimate in mind. Then, since that karma would be ultimately non-arisen its fruit could not be destroyed. Suppose, on the other hand, he argues that the ultimate non-arising and conventional nondestruction of ripened fruit are contradictory. As has been said many times already, and as will be reiterated below, these are not contradictory. Now suppose one thought as follows: You have offered its lack of existence through its own characteristic as an argument demonstrating that the ripened fruit is not destroyed. So how could this argument establish that the conventional fruition of the ripening karma is not contradictory?

'jug pa las/ gang phyir rang bzhin gyis de mi 'gag pa/ / de phyir kun gzhi med kyang 'di nus phyir/ // la lar las 'gags yun ring lon las kyang / / 'bras bu yang dag 'byung bar rig par gyis/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar shes par bya ste rtsa she'i tshigs bcad 'di skabs der 'jug 'grel du drangs nas don de bsgrubs pa'i phyir ro/ /

This should be understood as it is presented in the Madhyamakāvatāra: Since it does not cease essentially, Even without the foundation consciousness it is possible That at some time, even long after the action has ceased, Its fruit will arise. [VI: 39] The present verse of Mūlamadhyamakakārikā is quoted in this context in Madhyamakāvatāra-bhāsya and establishes this fact [dBu ma ‘a 260a].

de la sngar bsags pa'i las gnyis kyis ring du lon nam 'bras bu gnyis skyed par ni 'dod dgos la/ las kyang skyes pa'i dus gnyis par zhig nas 'gro bas 'bras bu'i snga logs de ma thag na las med cing las zhig pa yang dngos med yin pas las kyis 'bras bu ji ltar skyed ces brtsad pa'i lan du/ 'gag kha ma'i las kyi nus pa gzhag pa'i phyir rang sde kha cig kun gzhi dang gzhan dag chud mi za ba dang thob pa dang la la las kyi bag chags kyis bsgos pa'i sems rgyun rtog par byed do// // las rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma skyes pa'i ltar na 'gag pa med la ma zhig pa las kyang 'bras bu 'byung ba mi srid pa ma yin pas las rnams mi 'jig pas las 'bras kyi 'brel ba ches 'thad par 'jug 'grel las gsungs so/ / ma 'gags pa ni/ rang bzhin gyis de mi 'gag pa/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis mi 'gag pa yin gyi tha snyad pa'i 'gag pa mi bzhed pa min te/ la lar las 'gags yun ring lon las kyang*/ / zhes pa dang /

Now one might argue as follows: It must be accepted that the two kinds of previously accumulated karma can give rise to the two kinds of fruits after a long time. Since the action disintegrates in the second moment after it has arisen, immediately before the effect there is no action. Since the disintegrated action is a nonentity, how could the action give rise to the effect? In response to this, Madhyamakāvatāra-bhāsya says that some Buddhist schools theorize that since just before cessation the action deposits a potentiality, [309] there must be a foundation consciousness, others propose indestructibility, others propose accrual, and others propose the continuum of mind which is marked by latent potentialities. It also says that according to the view that karma is inherently non-arisen, it is not the case that the effect cannot arise from the unceased and nondisintegrated karma. Therefore, since the effect arises from the unceased karma, the relation between karma and effect is completely coherent [260a]. So this says that “unceased” means essentially unceased; so, it is inherently unceased but this does not assert that there is no conventional cessation, because it says “at some time, even long after the action has ceased” and

de bzhin 'gags shing rang bzhin yod min pa'i/ / las las kyang ni 'bras bu yod pa yin/ / zhes gsungs shing / skabs der 'jug 'grel du mdo drangs pa las kyang / zad pa med ces gang smras dang*/ / las zad ces ni gang smras pa/ / stong pa'i tshul du zad pa med/ / tha snyad tshul du zad par bstan/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i chos tha snyad du yang khas mi len pa'i lugs kyis zhig pa don byed nus par sgrub pa ni sngar bshad zin pa ltar yin pas/ / kun gzhi la sogs pa khas ma blangs kyang las 'bras kyi 'brel ba 'thad pas/ gang phyir rang bzhin gyis de mi 'gag pa/ / de phyir zhes pa'i sgrub byed dang las 'gags pa las 'bras bu 'byung ba mi 'gal bar gsungs so/ / skye 'gag sogs rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par 'dod pa rnams ni zhig pa dngos med du 'dod pas 'gags pa las 'bras bu 'byung ba mi rung ba yin no/ / las zhig pa'i zhig pa rigs 'dra brgyud pa'i rten ni nga'o snyam pa gang la skye ba'i gang zag gi rgyud yin la de nyid las dang 'bras bu 'brel ba'i rten yang yin no/ /

Similarly, an action which is ceased and essenceless Could still produce an effect. [VI: 40cd] In this context, the autocommentary quotes sūtra [260a]: That which is said to be unextinguished and That which is said to be the extinction of karma From the perspective of emptiness are not extinguished; They are extinguished from the conventional perspective. [Pitāputrasamāgama-sūtra, dKon brtsegs dBu ma nga 50b] In the system that does not accept the existence of things through their own characteristic even conventionally, it has been established, as explained earlier, that disintegration is a functioning thing./13/ For this reason, although such things as the foundation consciousness are not accepted, the relation between actions and their effects is coherent. Hence it is said that “Since it does not cease essentially,” this argument and the arising of effects from ceased actions are not contradictory. Those who maintain that such things as arising and ceasing exist through their own characteristic, since they maintain that disintegration is a nonentity, cannot make sense of the arising of an effect from a ceased action. The basis of a homogeneous continuum of the disintegration of disintegrated actions is the continuum of the person in which the thought “I am” occurs. That is the basis of the connection between action and effect.
gnyis pa [las rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa]
1.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of karma
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gnod byed dgod/ rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa'o/ /
[310] This section has two parts: undermining essential existence and refuting the argument for essential existence.
dang po [rang bzhin gyis yod pa la gnod byed dgod]
1.2.2.1 Undermining essential existence
['di] la gnyis/ rtag cing ma byas par thal ba dang / rnam smin thug med du 'byin par thal ba'o/ //
This section has two parts: the absurd consequences of being permanent and nonproduced and the absurd consequence of the endless fruition of ripened effects.
dang po [rtag cing ma byas par thal ba]
1.2.2.1.1 The absurd consequences of being permanent and nonproduced
['di] la gnyis/ thal ba dngos dang / de 'dod pa la gnod pa brjod pa'o/ //
This section has two parts: the principal absurd consequences and undermining such assertions.
dang po [thal ba dngos] ni/ /
1.2.2.1.1.1 Principal absurd consequences
gal te las la rang bzhin yod/ / rtag par 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / las ni byas pa ma yin 'byung / / rtag la bya ba med phyir ro/ /
22. If action had an essence, It would, without doubt, be eternal. Action would be unproduced, because There can be no production of what is eternal.

las rang bzhin gyis med pa ni gdon mi za bar 'dod par bya ste gzhan du na/ gal te las la rang bzhin gyis grub pa yod na the tshom med par rtag par 'gyur te rang bzhin la gzhan du 'gyur ba med pa'i phyir ro/ // de yi phyir las ni byed pa pos byas pa ma yin par 'gyur te rtag pa la byed pa pos bya ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir dge mi dge'i las ma byas par 'jig rten la smin par 'gyur ro/ /

Undoubtedly, one must maintain the essencelessness of action, because, if action did exist essentially, it would without doubt be eternal, since essence cannot be transformed. Therefore, action would not be performed by an agent, because there is no production by an agent of a permanent thing. It would follow that the fruition of effects in the world would occur despite neither virtuous nor nonvirtuous actions being performed.
gnyis pa [de 'dod pa la gnod pa brjod pa]
1.2.2.1.1.2 Undermining such assertions
['di] la gnyis/ bstan bcos dang 'gal ba dang / 'jig rten gyi grags pa dang 'gal ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: showing that it contradicts treatises and showing that it contradicts common sense.
dang po [bstan bcos dang 'gal ba] ni/
1.2.2.1.1.2.1 Showing that it contradicts treatises
ci ste las ni ma byas na/ / ma byas pa dang phrad 'jigs 'gyur/ / tshangs spyod gnas pa ma yin pa'ang / / de la skyon du thal bar 'gyur/ /
23. If action were not produced, One would have to fear encountering something not engendered. And the absurd consequence would ensue That one would nonetheless not keep one’s vows.

ci ste las ni byed pa pos ma byas na srog gcod pa la sogs pa ma byas pa rnams kyang las de dag dang 'brel bas las ma byas pa'i 'bras bu dang phrad pa'i 'jigs par 'gyur ro/ / tshangs spyod dag pa rnams la'ang mi tshangs spyod ma byas par yod pas phyogs de la tshangs par spyod pa la gnas pa ma yin pa'i skyon du yang 'gyur bas 'ga' yang mya ngan las 'da' bar mi 'gyur ro/ /

If action were not produced by an agent, although such things as killing would not have been performed, one would have to fear encountering the effects of those actions, even though those actions had not been performed. So from this view the erroneous consequence would follow that those who strictly keep by their vows nonetheless—even though they have not broken their vows—would not keep their vows. Therefore, nobody would attain liberation.
gnyis pa ['jig rten gyi grags pa dang 'gal ba] ni/
1.2.2.1.1.2.2 Showing that it contradicts common sense
tha snyad thams cad nyid dang yang / / 'gal bar 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / bsod nams dang ni sdig byed pa'i/ / rnam par dbye ba'ang 'thad mi 'gyur/ /
24. All conventions would also Be contradicted, without doubt. It would be impossible to draw a distinction Between virtue and evil.

zhing rmo ba dang tshong la sogs pa'i 'bras bu'i don du rtsom pa de dag kyang ma byas par yod pas rtsom pa don med du 'gyur la/ bum pa gyis shig snam bu thogs shig ces pa la sogs pa'i 'jig rten gyi tha snyad thams cad dang yang 'gal bar 'gyur bar the tshom med de bum pa la sogs pa thams cad ma byas par yod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ni bsod nams byed pa dang 'di ni sdig byed pa'o zhes pa'i rnam par dbye ba'ang 'thad par mi 'gyur te de gnyis ma byas kyang yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Even without making any effort, such as plowing fields and doing business one could achieve the fruits of such activities. So there would be no point in making any effort. This would undoubtedly be in conflict with all worldly conventions such as saying, “make a pot,” or “weave a cloth,” because everything, including such things as pots, would already exist without being made. One could not draw distinctions such as that drawn by saying “he performs virtuous deeds” and “he performs evil deeds,” [311] because these two kinds of deeds would exist even without being performed.
gnyis pa [rnam smin thug med du 'byin par thal ba] ni/
1.2.2.1.2 The absurd consequence of the endless fruition of ripened effects
de ni rnam smin smin gyur pa/ / yang dang yang du rnam smin 'gyur/ / gal te rang bzhin yod na ni/ / gang phyir las gnas de yi phyir/ /
25. Any ripened result would ripen Time and time again. If there were essence this would follow, Because karma would endure.

gzhan yang las de ni rnam smin rnam par smin zin par gyur pas kyang yang dang yang du rnam par smin pa 'byin par 'gyur te/ rnam par ma smin pa'i skabs ltar rang gi ngo bo las ma nyams pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir de ltar gal te las rang bzhin gyis yod do snyam du sems na ni gang gi phyir las dus kun tu mi nyams par gnas pa de yi phyir ji skad bshad pa'i nyes par 'gyur bas las rang bzhin gyis med pas rtag chad du lta ba'i skyon med do/ /

Moreover, that karma having ripened as the result would ripen time and time again because it would be just like the unripened stage, having not lost its identity. So, suppose someone thought that karma existed essentially. Then, since karma would exist eternally, enduring without transformation, all of the errors previously explained would ensue. Therefore, since karma does not exist essentially, we commit neither the error of reification nor that of nihilism.
gnyis pa [rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa]
1.2.2.2 Refuting the argument for essential existence
['di] la gsum/ las rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag / las dang nyon mongs gnyis ka rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag / las rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed gzhan dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of karma, the refutation of the argument for the essential existence of both karma and affliction, and the refutation of another argument for the essential existence of karma.
dang po [las rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag] ni/
1.2.2.2.1 Refutation of the argument for the essential existence of karma
gal te las ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma rig pa'i rkyen gyis 'du byed do zhes dang len pa'i rkyen gyis srid pa'o zhes gsungs pas las kyi rgyu nyon mongs rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: It does exist essentially, because it is said that, conditioned by ignorance, there are actions and, conditioned by grasping, there is existence, and because the afflictions—the cause of karma—exist essentially.
las 'di nyon mongs bdag nyid la/ / nyon mongs de dag yang dag min/ / gal te nyon mongs yang dag min/ / las ni yang dag ci ltar yin/ /
26. While this karma has affliction as its nature This affliction does not exist in reality. Since affliction does not exist in reality, How can karma exist in reality?

zag bcas kyi las 'di nyon mongs pa'i bdag nyid de nyon mongs pa las byung ba yin la/ nyon mongs pa de dag kyang yang dag par yod pa min te rnam par rtog pa'i dbang gis 'byung ba'i phyir ro zhes 'chad par 'gyur ro/ / gal te nyon mongs pa de dag yang dag par yod pa min pa de'i tshe de'i rgyu can gyi las ni yang dag par yod pa ji ltar yin te ma yin no/ /

This contaminated karma has affliction as its nature; that is, it is arisen from affliction, and those afflictions as well do not exist in reality either, because, as will be explained, they have arisen through the power of conception. Since the afflictions do not exist in reality, how can that which they cause—karma—exist in reality? It cannot!
gnyis pa [las dang nyon mongs gnyis ka rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag] ni/
1.2.2.2.2 Refutation of the argument for the essential existence of both karma and affliction
las dang nyon mongs pa ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i 'bras bu lus rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one said that karma and the afflictions exist essentially, because their effect—the body—exists essentially.
las dang nyon mongs pa dag ni/ / lus rnams kyi ni rkyen du bstan/ / gal te las dang nyon mongs pa/ / de stong lus la ci ltar brjod/ /
27. Karma and affliction Are shown to be the conditions that produce bodies. If karma and affliction Are empty, what should one say about bodies?

las dang nyon mongs pa dag ni lus rnams kyi ni rkyen du mdo sde las bstan to/ / gal te las dang nyon mongs pa de dag rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong par sngar bshad zin pas grub zin pa'i phyir/ de dag gi 'bras bu lus rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin pa la brjod pa lhag ma ji ltar te ci zhig yod de med do/ /

It is said in sūtra that karma and the afflictions are the conditions of the arising of the body. Since it has been established by previous explanations that karma and the afflictions are empty of existing essentially, their effect, the body, does not exist inherently. [312] What else could one say about that? Nothing!
gsum pa [las rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed gzhan dgag pa] ni/
1.2.2.2.3 Refutation of another argument for the essential existence of karma
ma rig bsgrib pa'i skye bo gang / / sred ldan de ni za ba po/ / de yang byed las gzhan min zhing / / de nyid de yang ma yin no/ /
28. The person who is clouded by ignorance And overcome by craving—the experiencer— Is neither different from the agent Nor is it itself identical to it.

las ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i 'bras bu bde sdug za ba po rang gi ngo bos yod pa'i phyir ro/ / ma rig pas bsgribs pa ste g.yogs pa 'gro ba lngar yang dang yang du skye bas skye bo gang srid pa'i 'ching ba dang ldan pa de ni las kyi 'bras bu'i za ba po'o/ / 'bras bu'i za pa po de yang rgyu'i byed pa po las gzhan min zhing za ba po de nyid las kyi byed pa po de yang ma yin te de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Karma exists essentially because its effect—the experiencer—exists essentially. Clouded by ignorance, that is, impaired, being reborn again and again in the five kinds of transmigration, the person who is overcome by craving is the experiencer of the effect of karma. This experiencer of the effect of karma is not different from the agent of its cause—the action—but that experiencer itself is also not said to be that agent. So it is ineffable in terms of identity or difference.
gang gi phyir na las 'di ni/ / rkyen las byung ba ma yin zhing / / rkyen min las byung yod min pa/ / de phyir byed pa po yang med/ /
29. Since this action Is not arisen from a condition, Nor arisen from that which is not a condition, It follows that there is no agent.

gang gi phyir na las 'di ni rgyu'i rkyen la sogs pa rkyen bzhi las byung ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin par ni rkyen brtag tu bshad zin la/ rkyen min pa las byung ba yang yod pa min par rgyu med na ni 'bras bu dang / rgyu yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes las brtag par bshad zin pa de'i phyir las kyi byed pa po yang rang bzhin gyis med do/ /

It has been explained in the chapter on the examination of conditions that this action does not exist essentially, in virtue of being arisen from the four conditions, such things as the efficient condition. Nor is it arisen from that which is not a condition as is explained by: Without a cause The effect and the cause will not be possible [VIII: 4ab] in the examination of agent and action. Therefore, the agent of action also does not exist essentially.
gal te las dang byed med na/ / las skyes 'bras bu ga la yod/ / ci ste 'bras bu yod min na/ / za ba po lta ga la yod/ /
30. If there is no action and agent, Where could the effect arisen from action be? If there is no effect, Where could the experiencer be?

gal te las dang byed pa po ngo bo nyid kyis med na las las skyes pa'i 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ga la yod de med do/ / ci ste las kyi 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min na de'i za ba po yang ngo bo nyid kyis lta ga la yod de 'di dag thams cad rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin pa kho na'o zhes shes par bya'o/ /

If the action and agent do not exist inherently, how could the effect which is arisen from the action exist inherently? It could not! If the effect of the action does not exist inherently, how could the experiencer exist inherently? So it should be understood that all of these things are absolutely essenceless.
gsum pa [rang bzhin med pas bya ba byed pa dpes bstan pa] ni/
1.2.3 Demonstrating by examples that, because of essencelessness, things can perform functions

gal te khyod kyis dngos po rnams rang bzhin med par bzhag na ston pas rang gis byas pa'i las kyi rnam par smin pa rang nyid kyis myong ngo zhes gsungs pa de thams cad tshul 'di bsal bar 'gyur la/ las 'bras la skur pa btab pa'i phyir khyod chad lta ba'i gtso bor gyur pa'o zhe na/ / kho bo cag med pa ba ma yin te yod med gnyis su smra ba bkag nas gnyis su med pa'i lam thar pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba gsal bar byed pa'o/ / de la med par smra ba sel tshul ni kho bo cag las 'bras la sogs pa med par mi smra zhes pa'o/ / 'o na ci zhe na/ 'di dag rang bzhin med do zhes rnam par 'jog go zhes pa ni yod par smra ba sel tshul yin te/ de ltar na las 'bras sogs tha snyad du yod pa la med par smra na med mtha' ba dang / de dag rang bzhin gyis yod par smra na yod mtha' bar bstan gyi yod med tsam du smra ba min no/ / ci ste rang bzhin med pa la bya byed mi 'thad pa'i phyir nyes pa so na 'dug go zhes rtsod pas ni/ med mi zer gyi rang bzhin med ces smra ba yin zhes smras kyang las 'bras mi rung ba'i skyon so na gnas zhes pa'o/ /

Suppose someone argued as follows: Since according to your ontology, things are essenceless, you contradict all of the statements of the Buddha to the effect that one experiences oneself the results of the actions one performs. Since you have deprecated the whole system of karma and the effects of actions, you have become the greatest of nihilists! We are not nihilists, because through refuting both the extremes of reification and nihilism we clear the nondualistic path leading to the city of nirvana. In this context we repudiate the nihilistic view by declaring that according to us [313] actions and effects are not nonexistent. Then what is the point? The statement, “as per our ontology, these things are essenceless” [Prasannapadā 109b], is the way we repudiate reification. Thus, we we have demonstrated that if one denies the conventional existence of action and effect, one falls into the extreme of nihilism, and that if one asserts that they exist essentially, one falls into the extreme of reification; but to assert that they merely exist or merely do not exist is not to succumb to these extremes. The charge that you cannot avoid error in the context of essencelessness, since action and agent would not be tenable, means this: although you claim not to assert that things are nonexistent, but only to assert that they do not exist essentially, you cannot avoid the error of asserting the untenability of action and effect.

de'i lan du rang bzhin dang bcas pa rnams la bya ba ma mthong ba'i phyir dang rang bzhin med pa rnams kho na la bya ba mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar bum pa rang bzhin med par gyur pa dag kho na 'jig rten na rang gi bya ba byed par dmigs pa yin no zhes gsungs pas/ rang bzhin gyis yod na bskyed bya skyed byed la sogs pa'i bya byed thams cad mi 'thad cing rang bzhin gyis med pa kho na la bya byed de dag 'thad par bstan te/ las 'bras la sogs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'gog pa'i rigs pa rnams ni/ rang bzhin med pa la bya byed thams cad 'thad pa'i groT yin gyi bya byed rnams des 'gog pa gtan min pa 'di nyid skabs kun tu go bar bya'o/ /

In response to this Prasannapadā says, Because action is not seen to occur in things with essence, and because action is seen to occur in essenceless things, only an essenceless pot is ordinarily seen to be a functioning thing. [109b] Thus, this shows that if they existed essentially, no actions and agents such as the produced and producers would be tenable; only in the context of essencelessness are action and agent tenable, because the arguments that refute the essential existence of such things as actions and consequences support the tenability of actions and agents in the context of essencelessness; but they do not at all refute their being actions and agents. This argument should be applied quite generally.

ci ltar ston pas sprul pa ni/ / rdzu 'phrul phun tshogs kyis sprul zhing / / sprul pa de yang sprul ba na/ / slar yang gzhan ni sprul pa ltar/ / de bzhin byed po des las gang / / byas pa'ang sprul ba'i rnam pa bzhin/ / dper na sprul pas sprul gzhan zhig / sprul pa mdzad pa de bzhin no/ /

31. Just as when the teacher, Through his miraculous powers, Emanates a body, and that emanation Emanates another emanated body, 32. So is the agent’s performance of the action Just like the process of emanation. It is just like one emanation Emanating another.

gzhan yang rang bzhin med pas bya ba byed pa'i dod 'di nyid dpe gsal po 'di las nges par bya ste/ ji ltar te dper na ston pa'i rdzu 'phrul phun tshogs kyis sprul pa ni sprul zhing sprul pa des kyang slar yang sprul pa gzhan ni sprul pa de la/ sprul pa de gnyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gyis stong zhing rang bzhin med pa ltar de rnams la rang bzhin med pa'i bya ba byed pa dang / las dang byed pa po'i tha snyad byed pa de bzhin du las kyi byed pa po ni sprul pa'i rnam pa bzhin rang bzhin gyis stong pa yin la/ byed pa po des las gang cung zad cig byas pa de'ang dper na sprul pas sprul pa de bzhin du rang bzhin gyis stong ngo / / de yi phyir dbu ma pa gnyis su med par smra ba rnams la ltag chad du log par lta ba ga la yod/ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang / gang tshe bder gshegs gtam rnams ston pa na/ / mgon po srang bzhud mi la thugs brtse'i phyir/ / rgyal bas der ni sprul pa rnams sprul te/ / de dag la yang sangs rgyas chos bzang ston/ / srog chags brgya stong dag gis de thos nas/ / sangs rgyas ye shes mchog la smon lam 'debs/ / nam bdag 'di 'dra'i ye shes thob snyam ste/ / bsam pa mkhyen nas rgyal pos de lung ston/ gang gis rgyal ba mi dbang spyan drangs pa/ / de yi sbyin pa mu mtha' med 'gyur te/ / rnyed mchog bsam gyis mi khyab de rnyed ces/ / la la dag ni de la mos pa skyed/ // ces gsungs pa ltar ro/ /

Moreover, the fact that things function just because they are essenceless can be ascertained through these lucid examples. Consider, for instance, when the teacher, through his miraculous powers, emanates an emanated body, and that emanated body again emanates yet another emanated body. Just as these two emanated bodies are empty of the essence of the Tathāgata and so are essenceless, they perform essenceless actions, and so these are conventionally called action and agent. In the same way, the agent of the action is, [314] like the process of emanation, essentially empty. Even the slightest action performed by the agent is essenceless, just like the emanation of one emanated body by another. Therefore, how could the mādhyamika who subscribes to nonduality hold the wrong views of reification and nihilism? The Samādhirājasūtra says: When the tathāgatas, the protectors, give teachings, Out of compassion for the man on the street The victors emanate emanated bodies; The buddhas even give noble teachings to them! When hundreds of thousands of beings heard that, They prayed for the supreme wisdom of the Buddha. Asking, “When shall I attain wisdom like that?” Being aware of their wish the victors prophesied: He who invokes the victor, the supreme human being, Will develop boundless generosity. Saying that the inconceivable supreme achievement is attained, Some develop aspiration toward it. [m Do sde da 36b]
nyon mongs las dang lus rnams dang / / byed pa po dang 'bras bu dag / dri za'i grong khyer lta bu dang / / smig rgyu rmi lam 'dra ba yin/ /
33. Afflictions, actions, bodies, Agents and effects are Like a city of gandharvas and Like a mirage or a dream.

sprul pa'i dpe tsam du ma zad kyi dpe lhag ma 'di dag kyang rang bzhin med pa la bya byed 'thad pa shes par bya ste/ sems rgyud nyon mongs par byed pa'i nyon mongs chags sogs dang bsod nams dang bsod nams min pa dang mi g.yo ba'i las dang lus khog pa dang byed pa po bdag dang /'bras bu rnam smin dang bdag po dang rgyu mthun rnams te de rnams ni dri za'i grong khyer lta bu dang smig rgyu dang rmi lam dang 'dra bar rang bzhin med pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / de yi phyir dngos po rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par khas ma blangs pas dbu ma pa kho na la rtag chad gnyis su smra ba med par shes par bya'o/ /

One should understand that action and agent are tenable in the context of essencelessness not only through the example of emanations, but also through these other examples. The afflictions are such things as desire, which afflict the mental continuum; the actions are such things as meritorious, nonmeritorious, and unshakable actions; the body is the physical body; the agent is the self; and the fruits are such things as the ripened result, the environmental result, and the concordant result. These, like the city of the gandharvas, the mirage, and the dream, should be understood to be essenceless. Therefore, it should be understood that since they do not maintain that entities exist through their own characteristics, only the mādhyamikas are free from asserting the two extreme positions of reification and nihilism.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar las dang nyon mongs la sogs pa rnams rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong par bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / de ltar bstan pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ dkon mchog brtsegs pa las/ sprul pa'i dge slong gnyis kyis dge slong dmigs pa can lnga brgya btul ba'i byung ba'i mtha' brjod pa lta bu rnams yin no/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the presentation of such things as karma and affliction as empty of inherent existence can also be corroborated by profound scriptures and to demonstrate that all of the sūtras that address this issue are explained by this chapter. The Ratnakūta-sātra says that this is like the story in which two emanated monks subdued five hundred obsessed people. [dkon cha brtsegs 147a].
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

rab byed 'di yi rigs pa rnams kyis byed pa po dang las dang nyon mongs dang de dag gi 'bras bu dang de la longs spyod pa la sogs pa rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pa bkag pas ni/ rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa la de dag gi rnam gzhag gang yang mi 'thad pas/ rmi lam dang sgyu ma dang sprul pa dang dri za'i grong khyer ltar rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pas stong bzhin du der snang ba kho na la byed pa po la sogs pa ches 'thad par rtogs par bya'o// /

These arguments refute the essential existence of agent, action, afflictions, their effects, and the experiencing of those effects, etc. They should be understood as showing that it is not at all tenable to posit them in the context of inherent existence. So such things as agents are tenable only in the following sense: Although they are empty of existence through their own characteristics, they appear to exist in this way: just like dreams, illusions, emanations, and cities of gandharvas.
las 'bras brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu bdun pa'o// //
This is the seventeenth chapter called “the examination of action.”
las brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa so gsum gyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu bdun pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the seventeenth chapter, having thirty-three verses, called “the examination of action.”

d.crumb: *XVIII. Examination of the Self and Phenomena

f.d: CHAPTER XVIII. Examination of the Self and Phenomena
gsum pa bdag med pa'i de kho na nyid la 'jug pa'i tshul
This chapter comprises the third of its five parts: the mode of positing the selflessness of things as they really are.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ / don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la lnga/ de kho na nyid la 'jug pa'i tshul/ de la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba/ de kho na nyid la bkri ba'i rim pa/ de kho na nyid kyi mtshan nyid/ don de nges par bsgrub dgos par bstan pa'o/ /

This section has five parts: the mode of engaging with things as they really are, dispelling the charge that this contradicts sūtras, the process leading to the realization of how things really exist, the characteristics of things as they really are, and showing that one must practice this.
dang po [de kho na nyid la 'jug pa'i tshul]
1.1 The mode of engaging with things as they really are
['di] la gnyis/ de kho na'i lta ba gtan la dbab pa/ de bsgoms pas nyes skyon ldog pa'i rim pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: establishing the view of the way things really are and the method for eliminating faults by meditating on it.
dang po [de kho na'i lta ba gtan la dbab pa] ni/
1.1.1 Establishing the view of the way things really are

'dir smras pa/ gal te nyon mongs pa dang las la sogs pa rnams dri za'i grong khyer la sogs pa ltar de kho na nyid ma yin bzhin du byis pa rnams la de kho na nyid kyi rnam par snang ba yin na/ 'dir de kho na nyid ni gang yin la de kho na nyid la 'jug pa yang ji ltar yin zhe na/ phyi nang gi dngos po ma dmigs pas nang dang phyi la bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa rnam pa thams cad du zad pa ni de kho na nyid do/ // de kho na nyid la 'jug pa'i tshul rgyas pa ni 'jug pa las/nyon mongs skyon rnams ma lus 'jig tshogs la/ / lta las byung bar blo yis mthong gyur cing / / bdag ni 'di yi yul du rtogs byas nas//rnal 'byor pa yis bdag ni 'gog par byed/ / ces sogs kyis bshad pa ltar shes par bya la 'dir ni rtsa bar gnas pa'i phyogs tsam bshad par bya'o/ / 'di la gnyis/ bdag ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag / des bdag gi ba ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa yang khegs par bstan pa'o/ /

Here someone might ask: If such things as the afflictions and actions are like such things as a city of gandharvas, not existing in reality even though they appear to fools to exist in reality, then what is the way that things really are [316] and how does one engage with things as they really are? To completely eliminate all grasping of inner and outer phenomena as the self and as that which belongs to the self, respectively, through not objectifying inner and outer phenomena is to see the way things really are. The details of the mode of engagement with the way things really are should be understood as is explained in Madhyamakāvatāra through statements such as this: Seeing through wisdom that all of the afflictions and faults Arise from the view objectifying the transitory aggregates Realizing that the self is the object of this view, The practitioner rejects such a self. [VI: 120] Here is a brief explanation of this as contained in the root text. This section has two parts: the refutation of the inherent existence of the self and showing that thereby the inherent existence of being mine is refuted.
dang po [bdag ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation of the inherent existence of the self
['di] la gnyis/ thar 'dod kyis dang por dpyod pa byed lugs/ / de nas bdag med pa'i lta ba gtan la 'bebs lugs so/
This section has two parts: the initial mode of analysis of those who aspire to liberation and the subsequent mode of establishing the view of selflessness.
dang po [thar 'dod kyis dang por dpyod pa byed lugs] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 The initial mode of analysis of those who aspire to liberation

sdug bden bden bzhi'i thog mar gsungs pa'i rim pas dang por 'khor ba spyi dang bye brag gi nyes dmigs mang du bsgoms pa na/ rnal 'byor pa de kho na nyid la 'jug par 'dod cing 'khor ba'i skyon skye 'chi la sogs pa dang / nyes pa 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa ma lus pa spong bar 'dod pa 'byung la/ de'i tshe rgyu ma log na 'bras bu mi ldog par mthong nas 'khor ba 'di ci'i rtsa ba can zhig yin snyam du rtog par byed do/ / brtag pa na 'khor ba 'jig lta'i rtsa ba can du mthong zhing de spangs pas nyon mongs pa dang skyon ma lus pa ldog par mthong ngo / / 'o na 'jig lta ji ltar byas pas spong snyam na/ spyir rab tu byed pa thams cad kyis phyin ci log gi blos ji ltar bzung ba'i yul yod pa la gnod byed bstan nas/ / de'i yul can gyi 'dzin pa bzlog la/ khyad par du rab byed 'dir 'jig ltas bzung ba'i bdag de phung po dang gcig tha dad gang du yod brtags te/yul sun phyung ba'i sgo nas bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa bzlog par gsungs shing / brgya pa las kyang / yul la bdag med mthong na ni/ / srid pa'i sa bon 'gag par 'gyur/ / zhes bdag 'dzin gyis ji ltar bzung ba'i bdag med par mthong nas srid pa las grol dgos par gsungs so/ /

Since the truth of suffering was taught as the first of the four noble truths, when one meditates on the many general and particular evils of cyclic existence, the practitioner aspires to engage with the way things really are, aspires to abandon such disadvantages as birth and death in cyclic existence, and aspires to abandon the afflictions such as the fault of desire. While so engaged, seeing that without undoing the cause, the effect cannot be eliminated, he then analyzes, thinking, “What could be the root of this cyclic existence?” On analysis he sees that the view of the transitory aggregates is the root of cyclic existence and sees that by abandoning that all of the afflictions and faults can be eliminated. How, one might then ask, is the view of the transitory aggregates to be abandoned? In general, all of the chapters undermine the existence of the object that is grasped by erroneous conception. Thereby the subject’s grasping is dispelled. This chapter in particular examines the self that is grasped through the view of the transitory aggregates in terms of whether it is identical to or different from the aggregates. [317] Through dispelling the object, the grasping of the self and being mine is said to be eliminated. The CatuḥŚataka says: When selflessness is seen in the object, The seed of cyclic existence is destroyed. [XIV: 24cd] It thus says that seeing the nonexistence of the self that is grasped through self-grasping is necessary for liberation from cyclic existence.

rnam 'grel las kyang / 'di yul sun phyung med par ni/ / de spong bar ni nus ma yin/ / zhes gsungs pas shing rta chen po thams cad tshul 'di la dgongs pa gcig dang dbyangs gcig go / de yi phyir bdag 'dzin gyis bdag ji ltar bzung ba dang bzung ba'i bdag dri ma med pa'i rigs pas legs par sun 'byin pa'i tshul mi shes par/ yid bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa las tshur bsdus pa tsam zhig la goms par byas pas srid pa las thar bar 'dod pa ni mi rigs te/ de ni bdag 'dzin gyi yul bdag la ma zhugs pa yin kyang bdag med kyi don la zhugs pa min pas de goms pas bdag 'dzin la ci yang mi gnod pa'i phyir dang / de lta yin na de kho na nyid kyi don sgom pa la lta ba ma nor ba rnyed kyang mi dgos pas/ de kho na nyid kyi lta ba gtan la 'bebs pa gsung rab dang bstan bcos las gsungs pa thams cad don med par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

And the Pramāṅavārtika says: Without eliminating its object, It cannot be eliminated. [II: 223ab] Thus, in this respect all of the great charioteers have the same idea and speak with the same voice. Therefore, it does not make sense to maintain that one can achieve liberation from cyclic existence by simply becoming accustomed to detaching one’s mind from the self and from being mine, without understanding the way the self is grasped through self-grasping and the proper way to use stainless arguments to eliminate the grasped self. That is because although through that practice one does not engage with the object of self-grasping, one does not engage with the object of selflessness. Therefore, that practice can never undermine self-grasping at all. If it could, then in order to meditate on the way things really are, there would be no need to develop the nonerroneous view. It would follow that all of the explanations of how things really are in the treatises and sūtras would be purposeless and meaningless.

thos bsam gyi dus su de ltar yin kyang sgom pa'i dus su de ltar mi dgos so zhes kyang smra mi nus te/ thos bsam gyis gtan la phab pa nyid sgom pa'i dus su lta thog tu sems 'dris par bya ba'i ched yin pa'i phyir dang*/ rnal 'byor pa yis bdag ni 'gog par byed//ces rnal 'byor sgom pas de ltar bya bar gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / des na 'jig lta spong ba ni des ji ltar bzung ba'i yul rang bzhin med par gtan la phebs pa la rag las par mthong zhing / de'i yul yang bdag yin par mthong nas bdag tu 'dzin pa'i dmigs pa bdag de rang gi ngo bos yod dam med snyam du ches thog mar bdag la rtog par byed do/ /

Nor should it be said that although it is necessary to develop this view at the stage of hearing and contemplation, this is not necessary at the stage of meditation. This is because that very thing which has been established through hearing and contemplation is for the purpose of familiarizing the mind with the view at the stage of meditation and because “the practitioner rejects such a self” [Madhyamakāvatāra VI: 120] means that the practitioner does that through meditation. Thus the practitioner, seeing that the abandonment of the view of the transitory aggregates depends on establishing the essencelessness of the object as grasped by it, and also seeing that [318] its object is the self, at the very beginning, analyzes the self, inquiring as to whether or not the self—the object of self-grasping—exist inherently.
gnyis pa [de nas bdag med pa'i lta ba gtan la 'bebs lugs]
1.1.1.1.2 The subsequent mode of establishing the view of selflessness
['di] la gnyis/ bdag dang phung po rang bzhin gcig pa dgag pa dang / bdag dang phung po rang bzhin tha dad pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: refutation of the self and the aggregates having the same nature and the refutation of the self and the aggregates having different natures.
dang po [bdag dang phung po rang bzhin gcig pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of the self and the aggregates having the same nature
gal te phung po bdag yin na/ / skye dang 'jig pa can du 'gyur/ /
1. If the aggregates were the self, It would have to arise and cease.

de ltar bdag tu 'dzin pa'i yul bdag de rang gi ngo bos yod na yod tshul gnyis las mi 'da' bas/ phung po dang rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i gcig dang tha dad gang yin snyam du brtag par bya ste/ gcig dang gcig ma yin pa ni gcig rnam par bcad na gcig shos yongs su gcod dgos pas phung gsum ldog pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar brtags pa na gal te phung po dang bdag gnyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i ngo bo gcig yin na/ bdag de skad cig so so la skye ba dang 'jig pa can du 'gyur te phung po rnams skye ba dang 'jig pa'i phyir ro/ / bdag ni gzhan sdes de ltar mi 'dod la rang sdes kyang de ltar 'dod du mi rung ste/ nga'o snyam pa gang la skye ba'i gzhi bdag de phung po dang rang mtshan gyis gcig tu grub na/ tshe 'di'i phung po dang yang gcig tu 'gyur la de yi tshe skye bo gzhan du med par 'dir byung ba dang thog ma yod par 'gyur te nyer bdun par 'chad pa ltar ro/ /

If the self—the object of self-grasping—existed inherently, one could not escape two alternatives regarding its mode of existence. Thus we should analyze to determine whether it, through its own characteristic, is identical to or different from the aggregates. Of identity and nonidentity, when one is eliminated, the other is affirmed by that elimination. Thus the third possibility is excluded. According to such an analysis, if the self and the aggregates had the same nature through their own characteristics, the self would have to be arising and ceasing at each moment, because the aggregates arise and cease at each moment. The self is not maintained to be like that by the other schools; nor can our own schools maintain it to be that way, because if the self, which is the basis on which the thought “I am” arises, were identical to the aggregates through its own characteristic, then it would even be identical to the aggregates of this life. In that case, the self would have arisen in this life despite not having existed in other lives, and so life would have a beginning. This will be discussed further in chapter twenty-seven.

gzhan yang skad cig so so la skye 'jig so sor byed na rang gi mtshan nyid kyis so so bar 'gyur la/ de lta na nga rgyal po nga las nu zhes bya bar gyur to zhes skye ba dran par mi 'gyur te/ de'i dus kyi bdag ni lus ltar zhig pa'i phyir dang tshe 'dir de dang rang mtshan tha dad pa'i bdag skyes pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan yang phung po mang po yod pa ltar bdag kyang mang por 'gyur ba rang / / bdag phung po'i rnam grangs tsam du zad pas bdag rdzas yod khas blangs pa don med pa dang nye bar blang bya nyid len pa por 'gyur ba las dang byed pa po gcig tu 'gyur ba'i skyon yod do/ / de ltar rigs pa de dag gis bdag dang phung po gnyis rang gi ngo bos gcig tu ma grub pa la nges pa brtan po bskyed par bya'o/ /

Moreover, if each arising and ceasing were located at a distinct moment, they would be distinct from one another through their own characteristics. In that case it would not be possible to remember, for instance, “I became King Māndhātā,” because the self of that time, just like the body, would be disintegrated, and in this life the self would have arisen as different through its own characteristic. Moreover, since there are many aggregates, there would have to be many selves. Since “self” would be merely a synonym for “aggregates” it would be senseless to assert that the self exists substantially, and the appropriated itself would be the appropriator. [319] One would thus commit the error of asserting that the agent and object are identical. Thus, through these arguments one should develop certainty that the self and the aggregates are not inherently identical.
gnyis pa [bdag dang phung po rang bzhin tha dad pa dgag pa] ni/ /
1.1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of the self and the aggregates having different natures
gal te phung po rnams las gzhan/ / phung po'i mtshan nyid med par 'gyur/ /
1cd. If it were different from the aggregates, It would not have the characteristics of the aggregates.

gal te bdag de phung po rnams las rang gi mtshan nyid kyis gzhan du grub na/ bdag de phung po 'dus byas su mtshon pa'i mtshan nyid skye 'jig gnas pa med pa ste de dang bral bar gyur te rta ba lang gi mtshan nyid dang bral ba bzhin no/ / de lta na bdag tu med par 'gyur te 'dus ma byas yin pa'i phyir mya ngan las 'das pa dang nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ / ngar 'dzin lhan skyes kyi dmigs rnam gnyis kyi nang nas dmigs par yang mi rigs te 'dus ma byas yin pa'i phyir ro/ / yang na phung po lnga'i mtshan nyid gzugs su rung ba dang nyams su myong ba dang mtshan mar 'dzin pa dang / mngon par 'du byed pa dang yul so sor rnam par rig pa las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du grub par 'gyur la/ de 'dod na gzugs las sems gzhan du 'dzin pa bzhin du bdag phung po las ngo bo tha dad par so sor mthong bar 'gyur na de ltar 'dzin pa yang min no/ / gal te gzhan sdes bdag phung po las rdzas gzhan du smra ba la 'di gnod byed ma yin no zhe na/ de dag gis rdzas gzhan du smra mod kyang ji ltar smra ba ltar blo lhan skyes kyis dmigs nas smra ba min no/ / 'o na ci zhe na/ brten nas btags pa'i don ma rtogs par bdag ming du btags pa tsam du smra ba la skrag nas kun rdzob kyi bden pa las kyang nyams te gtan tshigs ltar snang gis bslus nas phung po las rdzas gzhan pa'i bdag gi mtshan nyid rtog cing smra'o/ / las dang byed pa po brtag pa la sogs par bdag dang nye bar len pa gnyis phan tshun ltos pa'i grub pa yin par gsungs pa na de dag gis brtags pa'i bdag kun rdzob tu yang bkag go / de ltar bdag rang gi ngo bos grub na bdag dang phung po gnyis rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa'i gcig dang tha dad gang rung du grub dgos pa dang / de gnyis ka la yang rigs pas gnod par mthong ba na bdag ni rang gi ngo bos grub pa cung zad kyang med do snyam du nges pa rnyed pa ni/ 'jig lta lhan skyes kyi ngar 'dzin pa'i yul rang bzhin med par rtogs pa'i lta ba rnyed pa yin no/ /

If the self were different from the aggregates through its own characteristic, the self would not have (that is, would lack) the characteristics (that is, arising, enduring, and ceasing) which characterize the aggregates as compounded phenomena, just as a horse does not have the characteristics of a cow. In that case, there would be no self because it would not be produced and would be like nirvana or like a sky flower.
