mi gnas dus ni 'dzin mi byed/ / gang zhig gzung ba bya ba'i dus/ / gnas pa yod pa ma yin pas/ / ma bzung dus ni ji ltar gdags/ /
5. A nonenduring time is not grasped. Nothing one could grasp as time Could exist as enduring. If time is not grasped, how it is known?

gal te dus zhes pa skad cig la sogs pa las ngo bo tha dad par gnas pa zhig yod na/ skad cig la sogs pa'i sgo nas tshad dang ldan par 'dzin pa zhig na'ang / dus zhes pa skad cig la sogs pa'i sgo nas gzung bar bya ba ther zug tu gnas pa ni med pas/ ltar mi gnas pa'i phyir dus ni rang las ngo bo tha dad pa'i skad cig la sogs pa'i sgo nas 'dzin par mi byed do/ / ci ste dus rtag pa ni yod la de sogs pa dag gis gsal bar byed de/ dus kyis 'byung ba smin par byed/ / dus kyis skye dgu sdud par byed/ / dus kyis gnyid log sad par byed/ / dus las 'da' bar shin tu dka'/ / zhes 'byung ba de lta bu'i mtshan nyid can ni yod do snyam na/ gang zhig skad cig la sogs pas gsal zhing gzung bar bya ba'i dus ther zug tu gnas pa yod pa ma yin te/ skad cig la sogs pa las ngo bo tha dad par yod na dmigs su rung ba las ma dmiT pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan yang dus 'di 'dus byas sam 'dus ma byas shig rang bzhin gyis yod par rtog grang na de gnyis ka yang / skye dang gnas dang 'jig pa rnams/ // ma grub phyir na 'dus byas med/ / ces sogs kyis sngar bkag zin pa'i phyiraro/ / de 'dra ba'i dus tshad ma gang gis kyang ma dmigs pa yin pas ma bzung ba'i dus de ni skad cig la sogs pa'i tshad kyis ji ltar gdags par nus te mi nus so/ /

If what is called “time” endures as a separate entity from such intervals as seconds, then it would be grasped as being measured in such intervals as seconds. However, what is called “time” is not to be grasped in terms of such intervals as seconds; it does not endure immutably. Therefore, since it does not so endure, time is not grasped through such intervals as seconds, which are different entities from it. Suppose one reasoned as follows: Permanent time exists. It is manifested in such intervals as seconds because, as it is said, Time ripens elements. Time assembles the people. Time awakes the sleeper. It is difficult to transcend time. [Dharmadhātudarśanagīti, rGyud zhi 260a]/4/ [340] So time exists with such characteristics. Time—that which is manifested in such intervals as seconds and is to be grasped—does not endure immutably, because if it existed as a different entity from such things as seconds it would have to be perceptible. But it is not perceptible. Moreover, we can examine whether this time exists essentially as produced or unproduced. Both alternatives have already been refuted by Since arising, enduring, and ceasing Do not exist, there are no produced things. [VII: 33ab] No such time is perceived through any authoritative cognition. So, how could time that is not perceived be posited through being measured in such intervals as seconds? It cannot!
gnyis pa [rang sde dngos por smra bas 'dod pa'i dus dgag pa] ni/
1.2.2 Refutation of our own schools’ presentations of time
gal te dus rtag pa med pa ni bden mod kyang 'du byed gzugs la sogs pa la brten nas btags pa'i dus ni skad cig la sogs pa'i sgra'i brjod byar 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose someone argues as follows: Although it is true that time is not permanent, time, which is designated in dependence on compounded phenomena such as material form, is the referent of terms such as “seconds.”
gal te dus ni dngos rten te/ / dngos med dus ni ga la yod/ / dngos po 'ga' yang yod min na/ / das lta yod par ga la 'gyur/ /
6. If time depends on an entity Then without an entity how could time exist? Since there are no entities at all, How can time exist?

gal te gzugs la sogs pa'i dngos po med pa ste de dag las ngo bo tha dad pa'i dus ni ga la yod de med pas dus ni gzugs la sogs pa'i dngos po la brten nas rnam par 'jog na/ sngar bshad zin pa dang 'chad par 'gyur ba'i rigs pas dngos po 'ga' yang rang bzhin gyis yod pa min na de la btags pa'i dus lta rang bzhin gyis yod par ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

Without the existence of entities such as form—that is, those things from which time is a different entity—how could time exist? It does not. Therefore, time is posited in dependence on entities such as material form. So, since as per the arguments that have been presented earlier and which will be presented later, no entities at all exist essentially, how could time be posited as existing essentially based upon them? It could not!
gsum pa [tha snyad du dus gsum rnam par 'jog pa'i tshul] ni/
1.3 The way to set out the three temporal periods conventionally

'dir dus gsum ni/ brgya pa'i 'grel pa las/ de la ma 'ongs pa ni da ltar byung ba'i dus su ma phyin pa'o/ / 'das pa ni de nyid las 'das pa'o/ / da ltar byung ba ni skyes la ma 'gags pa'o/ / da ltar byung ba ni da ltar dmigs pa'i phyir gtso bo yin gyi der ma 'ongs pa dang rgal ba dag gis ma 'ongs pa dang 'das pa'i dus gnyis rnam par 'jog pa ni gtso bo ma yin no/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar gzhag go / de la gang du ma 'ongs shing gang las 'das pas ma 'ongs pa dang 'das par 'jog pa'i dus ni da ltar ba ste des na da ltar ba ni dus kyi gtso bo yin la gzhan gnyis gtso bo ma yin no/ / da ltar bar ma phyin pa na ni nam mkha' dang ri bong gi rwa la sogs pa'ang yin pas de bcad pa'i phyir mngon pa las rgyu yod kyang ma byung ba dang*/ zhes gsungs te/ dper na myu gu'i rgyu yod kyang da dung myu gur ma skyes pa'ang ma phyin pa ni ma 'ongs pa yin gyi gang zhig da ltar bar ma 'ongs pa'i gzhi de nam yang 'byung ba'i rgyu med pas ma phyin pa ni ma 'ongs pa min no/ / de ltar na gang du ma 'ongs pa ni da ltar ba dang / gang zhig ma 'ongs pa ni myu gu la sogs pa'i 'bras bu rnams yin kyang 'bras bu rnams ma 'ongs pa'i dus su 'jog pa min no/ /

Here the three temporal periods are posited according to the Commentary on the Catuḥśataka as follows: The future is that which has not yet come to be in the present. The past is that which is gone by in the present. The present is that which has arisen but has not ceased. Since the present is now being perceived, it is most important. But positing the two temporal periods—the future and the past, that which has not yet come to presence, and that which passed out of presence—is not as important. [dBu ma ya 171b] [341] That temporal period on the basis of which that which is yet to come to it—the future—and on the basis of which that which has passed from it—the past—are posited is the present. Therefore, the present is the most important temporal period, and the two that are posited on the basis of it are less important. That which has not yet come into presence is like the sky or the horns of a rabbit. In order to exclude those things being the future it is said in the Abhidharma that the future is that which is not yet arisen although it has a cause, just as, for example, although the cause of a sprout exists, the sprout which has yet to arise as a sprout or which not come into presence is in the future. But that which has not come into presence and which never has a cause for arising or coming into presence is not the future. So “yet to come”: Where it is yet to come is to the present./5/ That which is yet to come includes such things as the sprout as effect. But the effects are not posited in the temporal period of the future.

'di la gang ma 'ongs pa'i 'bras bu dang de'i rgyu gnyis ka rang gi bya ba byas nas zhig pa [!] min pas rgyu 'bras gnyis spyad ma zin pa zhes dbus mtha' sogs las gsungs so/ / da ltar ba las log pa tsam la 'das par 'jog na nam mkha' la sogs pa dang ma 'ongs pa yang 'das par 'gyur bas da ltar ba las 'das pa ni da ltar ba zhig pa'o/ / byung la 'gags pa zhes kyang gsungs te dper na myu gu zhig pa 'das par 'jog pa na byung ba zhes pa ni 'das pa la mi byed kyi gang 'das pa'i 'das rgyu myu gu la bya'o/ / myu gu de 'das par song ba na 'bras bu myu gu dang de'i rgyu gnyis kas rang gi bya ba byas nas zhig pas rgyu 'bras gnyis ka spyad zin pa zhes gsungs so/ / da ltar ba ni myu gu la sogs pa rnams skyes la ma 'gags pa'i dus te de'i dus na rang gi rgyu ni 'gags la 'bras bu rang nyid ma 'gags pas rgyu ni spyad zin pa 'bras bu ni spyad ma zin par gsungs so/ / de ltar myu gu zhig pa ni myu gu 'das pa'i dus dang myu gu ma skyes pa ni myu gu ma 'ongs pa'i dus dang myu gu grub nas ma zhig pa ni myu gu da ltar ba'i dus yin pas/ dus gsum char yang myu gu la sogs pa'i dngos po de'i zhig pa dang ma skyes pa dang skyes nas ma zhig pa'i dus gang yin de la rtsi ba yin gyi/ dus kyi tha snyad byed pa pos brjod bzhin pa'i da ltar ba'i dus su med pa la da ltar ba ma yin par smra ba ma yin te de ni brjod pa po de la ltos pa'i da ltar ba yin pa'i phyir ro// des na rgyu snga ma dang 'bras bu phyi ma dang 'das pa zhig pa dang ma 'ongs pa ma skyes par 'dod bzhin du skad cig ma snga ma rnams 'das pa dang skad cig ma phyi ma rnams ma 'ongs par 'dod pa ni mun sprul lo/ /

In this context, since both future effects and their causes have not yet disintegrated after performing their functions, the Madhyāntavibhāga [Madhyāntavibhāga-bhāṣya, Sems tsam bi 14b] and other texts [Sthiramati’s Madhyāntavibhāga-bhāṣya-ṭikkā, Sems tsam bi 266a] describe cause and effects both as not yet having been spent. If the past were posited merely as that which is not present, such as the sky, the future would be also be past. So that which has gone by in the present is disintegrated in the present. The past is also said to be that which has come into existence and then ceased. For example, when a disintegrated sprout is posited as past, that which is said to have come into existence is not referred to as past, but it refers to the sprout which is past. When the sprout is past, both the effect—the sprout—and its cause have performed their respective functions and have disintegrated. Therefore, both cause and effect are said to have been spent. The present is the temporal period in which such things as the sprout have arisen, but have not yet ceased. At that time while its cause has ceased, it itself—the effect—has not yet ceased. Therefore, it is said that the cause is spent, but the effect is not yet spent. So the disintegrated sprout is the past state of the sprout; the sprout which is not yet arisen is the future state [342] of the sprout; the sprout which has come into existence but which has not disintegrated is the present state of the sprout. Therefore the three temporal periods are taken to be the state of disintegration, the state of not having arisen, and the state of having arisen but not having disintegrated of such entities as the sprout, respectively. But that which does not exist in the present when the agent is using temporal language is not therefore said to be nonpresent, because that is a present only in relation to the speaker. So, having asserted that the cause is earlier and that the effect is later, and that the past is the disintegration and that the future is that which is yet to arise, to also assert that the earlier moments are the past and that the later moments are the future would be foolish.

bye brag tu smra ba rnams myu gu la sogs pa re re la dus gsum gsum du 'jog pas myu gu ma 'ongs pa dang 'das pa'i dus su yang myu gur yod par 'dod de dngos po gzhan la yang de ltar 'dod do/ / de yang chos skyob ni myu gu la sogs pa ma 'ongs pa nas da ltar ba dang da ltar ba nas 'das par 'jug pa na ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar ba'i dngos po 'dor gyi de'i dus kyi rdzas mi 'dor te/ dper na gser gyi snod bcom nas snod gzhan byed pa dang 'o ma zhor 'gyur ba na dbyibs dang ro gzhan du 'gyur gyi/ kha dog gzhan du mi 'gyur ba bzhin no zhes smra'o/ dbyangs sgrog ni dus re re yang dus gsum ga'i mtshan nyid dang ldan mod kyang gang shas che bas 'das pa la sogs par 'jog ste/ skyes pa gcig bud med gcig la chags pa shas che yang bud med gzhan la chags bral min pa bzhin no zhes zer ro/ / dbyig gshes ni myu gu la sogs pa'i dngos po gcig kyang ma 'ongs pa la sogs pa'i gnas skabs so so bar phyin pa na ma 'ongs pa la sogs par 'jog ste/ rtsis kyi ril bu zhig gcig dang brgya dang stong gi sho mig tu bzhag na gcig la sogs par 'jog pa bzhin no zhes 'dod do/ / sangs rgyas lha ni dper na bud med gcig ltos sa la ltos nas ma dang bu mor brjod pa bzhin du dngos po gcig kyang snga ma dang phyi ma la ltos nas dus gzhan dang gzhan du 'jog go /

The Vaibhāśikas posit the three temporal periods in relation to each thing, such as the sprout. Therefore, they say that the future sprout as well as the sprout that existed in the past exist as the sprout. They say the same thing about other things. In this context, Dharmatrāta [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 239b] asserts that when things such as the sprout pass from the future to the present and from the present to the past, they give up being future entities and give up being present entities, respectively; but they do not give up their current substance. For example, when a golden pot is destroyed and a new one is made, or when milk becomes yoghurt, the shape and taste change, respectively, but the color does not change. Ghośak [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 239b] actually asserts that although each temporal period has the characteristics of all three temporal periods, their respective predominance determines whether a period is past, etc., just as a man who is more attached to some particular woman may not be free from desire for another woman. Vasumitra [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 240a] says that when a single thing such as a sprout passes through different states such as being future, etc., they are posited as future, etc. This is just as a single counter could stand for one or a hundred depending on the slot on a counting board in which it is placed and therefore it is posited as one and so forth. [343] Buddhadeva [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 240b] says that just as a single woman is called a mother or a daughter depending on the person to whom she is so related, a single thing, depending on whether it is related to something that is prior or posterior is posited as being in one temporal period or another.

de'i dang po ni 'gyur ba smra bas grangs can gyi lugs dang gnyis pa la dus kyi mtshan nyid 'chol ba dang / gsum pa la myu gu la sogs pa'i chos las ngo bo tha dad pa'i bya ba 'dod na 'dus ma byas su 'gyur la ngo bo gcig na bya ba byed mi byed kyi gnas skabs so sor med pa dang / bzhi pa la 'das pa la sogs pa re re la'ang snga phyi dbus gsum dus gsum du smra dgos pas dus re re la dus gsum gsum yod par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang 'das ma 'ongs kyi dus su yang myu gu la sogs par rang gi ngo bor yod na/ myu gu la sogs pa zhig pa dang ma skyes pa zhes ci'i phyir bya zhes mdzod rtsa 'grel las bkag nas dus gsum gyi mtshan nyid sngar bshad pa bzhin du smra zhing / zhig pa dang ma skyes pa'i 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa gnyis dngos med du 'dod de 'di ni dbu ma thal 'gyur ba ma gtogs pa mdo sde pa yan chad kyi rang sde rnams kyis 'dod pa'o/ / dbu ma thal 'gyur bas ni dus gsum ga dngos por bzhed de rab byed bdun pa'i skabs su zhig pa dang ma skyes pa'i dus gnyis dngos por bsgrubs pa bzhin no/ / 'on kyang myu gu la sogs pa re re la dus gsum gsum du byed pa ni mi bzhed pas bye brag tu smra ba dang mi 'dra'o/ /

The first of these, since it asserts that a persisting entity changes, amounts to the Sāṁkhya position. The second jumbles the characteristics of time. According to the third, since the functions of phenomena such as the sprout are asserted to be different entities from them, they would be unproduced phenomena. If they were the same entity, there would not be separate states of performing their functions and not performing their functions. According to the fourth, one would have to say each of the temporal periods, such as the past, comprises all three temporal periods—prior, posterior, and middle. It would follow that each of the temporal periods would comprise three temporal periods. Moreover, according to the Abhidharmakośa and its autocommentary the refutation is as follows: If things such as sprouts existed inherently in temporal periods such as the past and the future, then how could there be such things as the disintegrated sprout and the sprout which is yet to be arisen [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 241a]? The characteristics of the three temporal periods are asserted to be as they have been explained earlier: the disintegrated and the as yet non-arisen—the past and the future—are asserted not to be things. This is asserted by all Buddhist schools from Sautrāntika onward, apart from the prāsaṅgika-mādhyamikas. The prāsaṅgika-mādhyamikas maintain that all three temporal periods are things. As it has been proven in the seventh chapter, the two temporal periods in which something has disintegrated and in which it has yet to arise are things. However, since it is not maintained that each thing such as a sprout has three temporal stages, this is different from the Vaibhāṣika view.

'di'i lugs kyi dus gsum myu gu la mtshon na myu gu ni da ltar ba dang de zhig pa ni 'das pa dang spyir rgyu yod kyang skabs 'gar rgyu rkyen ma tshang bas myu gu ma skyes pa ni ma 'ongs pa'o/ / 'o na myu gu zhig pa'i zhig pa rigs 'dra brgyud mar 'byung ba ni 'dod pas de'i skad cig ma skyes la ma 'gags pa rnams da ltar bar 'gyur la de ltar na da ltar ba dang zhig pa gnyis mi 'gal bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ skyon med de myu gu zhig pa'i skad cig ma dang po ni myu gu zhig pa yin la de'i rigs 'dra'i zhig pa rnams ni snga ma snga ma zhig pa yin zhing zhig pa thams cad 'das pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / myu gu zhig pa de rang dus na kho rang zhig pa min kyang spyir zhig pa yin pas 'das pa kho na'o/ /

The three temporal periods according to this system are as follows: Consider a sprout. The sprout is present. Its disintegration is its past. Although in general there are causes, in certain circumstances, without the complete assemblage of causes and conditions, the sprout is not yet arisen, and that is its future. On the other hand one might argue as follows: Since it has been asserted that the disintegration of the disintegrated sprout constitutes a homogeneous continuum, and since the moment when it has arisen and not yet ceased is its present, [344] it would follow that being present and being disintegrated are not mutually exclusive. We commit no such error, because the first moment of the disintegration of the sprout is the disintegration of the sprout. The disintegrations of its homogeneous stages are the successive disintegrations of its previous moments. And each disintegration is a past. At the time when the disintegration of the sprout exists, it is not disintegrated; but in general, since it is a disintegration it is, as such, in the past.

de ltar 'das pa'i rigs 'dra ji snyed cig byung yang dngos po gzhan zhig zhig pa'i sgo nas rang gi ngo bo gzhag dgos pas dus gzhan gnyis dang khyad par che'o/ / de bzhin du ma 'ongs pa'i rigs 'dra ji snyed cig byung yang dngos po gzhan zhig ma skyes pa kho na'i sgo nas rang gi ngo bo gzhag dgos pas 'das da ltar gnyis dang khyad par shin tu che'o// // de ltar na da ltar ba ni dngos po gzhan zhig zhig pa dang ma skyes pa'i sgo nas gzhag mi dgos pa'i skyes la ma 'gags pa myu gu lta bu yin pas ma 'ongs pa'i skad cig ma skyes la ma 'gags pa rnams dang khyad par che'o/ /

So, the homogeneous continuum of anything in the past must be posited as an entity itself on the grounds of the disintegration of a different thing. Therefore, there is a major difference between the past and the other two temporal periods. Similarly, any homogeneous continuum in the future must be posited as an entity itself just on the basis of some other thing not yet being arisen. Thus there is a major difference between the future and the other two temporal periods. So as far as the present is concerned, it is like an arisen but not yet ceased sprout, which neither needs to be posited on the basis of the disintegration of some other thing, nor on the basis of some other thing not yet arisen. Therefore there is a major difference between it and future moments that are neither arisen nor ceased.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation through Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar dus gsum mtshan nyid kyis yod pas stong par bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / dus gsum rang bzhin med par bshad pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam mtshon pa ni/ glang po'i rtsal gyi mdo las/ gal te chos rnams rang bzhin 'ga' yod na/ / rgyal ba nyan thos bcas pas de mkhyen 'gyur/ / ther zug chos rnams mya ngan 'da' mi 'gyur/ / mkhas rnams nam yang spros pa med mi 'gyur/ / zhes

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the presentation of the three temporal periods as empty of existence through their own characteristics is corroborated by profound scriptures and to demonstrate that all of the sūtras that state that the three temporal periods are essenceless are explained by this chapter. The Hastikakṣya-sūtra says, If there were any essence in phenomena,/6/ The Victors and their disciples would have realized it. Immutable phenomena do not attain nirvana. Even the wise are not without fabrication./7/ [m Do sde da 251b]

dang*/ ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang*/ chos ni stong phrag brgya dag bstan gyur nas/ / sangs rgyas 'bum phrag gang dag 'das gyur kyang / / chos dang yi ge dag la zad med de/ / skye ba yod min des na zad pa med/ / ces pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa 'byung ba'i dus kyi tshe/ / byams pa zhes bya'i rgyal ba 'byung 'gyur zhing*/ / sa 'di gser gyis bdal ba 'byung 'gyur ba/ / de tshe de yi 'byung de ga la yod/ / ces sngar sangs rgyas byon nas 'das pa'i dus la zad pa dang phyis 'byung ba'i dus rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa bkag pas dus rang bzhin med par bstan to/ /

And the Samādhirāja-sūtra says, Even though hundreds of thousands of teachings have been taught. And hundreds of thousands of buddhas have come and gone, The teachings and the words are inexhaustible. There is no arising, and so no exhaustion, [mDo de da 147a] [345] and When the Tathāgata arrives and A Victor named Maitreya also arrives, The Earth will be covered with gold. At that time, where is the arrival? [Vīadatta-sūtra, dKon brtsegs ca 201a] This shows that time is essenceless by refuting the exhaustion of the time of the Buddha’s earlier coming and passing and by refuting the inherent existence of the time of the Buddha’s later arrival.
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

sngar byung nas 'gags pa dang da dung ma byung ba slar 'byung ba dang byung nas ma 'gags pa'i dus gsum ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa la gtan mi rung gi / des stong pa'i rang bzhin med pa la ches 'thad do snyam du bden pa gnyis kyi nges pa brtan par bya'o/ /

It is not at all possible for the three temporal periods to exist through their own characteristics: neither that which has arisen earlier and ceased, nor that which has not yet arisen; nor that which has arisen, earlier and not yet ceased. Nonetheless, one should confirm one’s ascertainment of the two truths through thinking that it is absolutely tenable that they are essenceless—that is, empty of their own characteristics.
dus brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa bcu dgu pa'o// //
This is the nineteenth chapter called “the examination of time.”
dus brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa drug gi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa bcu dgu pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the nineteenth chapter, having six verses, called “the examination of time.”
CHAPTER XX. Examination of Assemblage
gnyis pa dus rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed dgag pa
We now begin the second part: the refutation of the argument for the inherent existence of time.
['di] la gnyis/ dus 'bras bu 'byung ba'i lhan cig byed rkyen yin pa dgag / dus 'bras bu 'byung 'jig gi rgyu yin pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of time as the supporting condition of the arising of the effect and the refutation of time as the cause of the arising and cessation of the effect.
dang po [dus 'bras bu 'byung ba'i lhan cig byed rkyen yin pa dgag]
This chapter constitutes the first of those two parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ //
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ dus ni rang bzhin gyis yod de 'bras bu 'byung ba la lhan cig byed pa'i rkyen yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di na sa bon dang sa dang chu la sogs pa'i rkyen gzhan tshogs kyang dus kyi khyad par mi nye na mi skye la nye na skye ba dang / phyi rol bzhin du nang la yang / / tshogs shing dus la bab pa na/ / 'bras bu nyid du smin par 'gyur/ / zhes 'bras bu skye ba dus la ltos par gsungs so/ / 'di dgag pa la gsum/ rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa las skye ba dgag / rgyu nyid las skye ba dgag / rgyu rkyen tshogs pa las skye ba 'gog pa'i rigs pa gzhan bstan pa'o/ /

Here someone might say, “Time exists essentially because it is the supporting condition of the arising of effects. Although conditions such as the seed, the soil, and the water are assembled, until the right moment occurs, the effect does not arise; when the right moment occurs, it does arise; just as it is in the case of external phenomena, so it is for internal phenomena as the Buddha says: When the assemblage is complete, and the time is right The fruit will ripen. [Vinaya, kṣudra-varga, Phran tshegs ta 153a, 156a, 157a, and Vinaya Vibhanga, ’Dul ba cha 177a] So it is said that the arising of the effect depends on time.” The refutation of this has three parts: the refutation of arising from the assemblage of causes and conditions, the refutation of arising just from causation, and the presentation of further reasons for the refutation of arising from the assemblage of causes and conditions.
dang po [rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa las skye ba dgag]
1.1 Refutation of arising from the assemblage of causes and conditions
['di] la gsum/ tshogs pa snga ma las skye ba dgag / dus mnyam pa'i tshogs pa las skye ba dgag / tshogs pa phyi ma las skye ba dgag pa'o/ /

[346] This section has three parts: the refutation of arising from a previous assemblage, the refutation of arising from a simultaneous assemblage, and the refutation of arising from a subsequent assemblage.
dang po [tshogs pa snga ma las skye ba dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of arising from a previous assemblage
['di] la gnyis/ tshogs pa las dngos su skye ba dgag / tshogs pa las brgyud nas skye ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of arising directly from the assemblage and the refutation of arising indirectly from the assemblage.
dang po [tshogs pa las dngos su skye ba dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation of arising directly from the assemblage
['di] la gnyis/ tshogs pa la yod med skye ba dgag / tshogs pa la yod med nyid dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the arising of existents and nonexistents in the assemblage and the refutation of the existence and nonexistence of the assemblage itself.
dang po [tshogs pa la yod med skye ba dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Refutation of the arising of existents and nonexistents in the assemblage
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs pa nyid las skye 'gyur zhing / / tshogs las 'bras rtsa ba bu yod na ni/ / ci ltar tshogs pa nyid las skye/ /
1. If, arising from the assemblage of Causes and conditions, The effect is in the assemblage, How could it arise from the assemblage?

myu gu sa bon la sogs pa'i rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pa las skye na 'bras bu tshogs pa la gnas pa zhig rang bzhin gyis skye'am/ mi gnas pa zhig rang bzhin gyis skye grang / gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi tshogs pa nyid las 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skye bar 'gyur zhing /rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa la 'bras bu yod na ni ji ltar na rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa nyid las 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skye zhes pa mi skye ste/ 'bras bu dang rten brten pa yin pa'i phyir/ dper na/ 'khar gzhong na yod pa'i zho'i rigs 'khar gzhong gis mi skyed pa bzhin no// gzhan yang yod pa ni grub zin pas mdun gyi bum pa bzhin du slar yang skye ba la ltos pa med do/ / gal te rgyu rkyen la 'bras bu'i rang bzhin gnas pa rkyen gyis gsal bar byed pas yod kyang skye ba don yod do zhe na/

If a sprout arises from an assemblage of causes and conditions, including such things as the seed, does the effect arise existing essentially in the assemblage, or does it arise without existing essentially in them? If the effect were to arise essentially from the assemblage of causes and conditions, and if the effect existed in the assemblage of causes and conditions, then how could the effect arise essentially from the assemblage of causes and conditions itself? It could not, because it would be the basis, and the effect must depend upon it. For example, the bowl containing the yoghurt does not give rise to the yoghurt. Moreover, that which exists has already come into existence, like that pot over there, which does not depend on a further arising. Now, suppose one said that although the essence of the effect is in the causes and conditions, because it must be made manifest by the conditions, there is still a point in its arising.
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs pa nyid las skye 'gyur zhing / / tshogs la nyer dgu 'bras bu med na ni/ / ci ltar tshogs pa nyid las skye/ /
2. If, arising from the assemblage of Causes and conditions, The effect is not in the assemblage, How could it arise from the assemblage?

gsal ba sngar yod na slar yang skye mi dgos la med na sngar med skye ba'i phyogs su 'gyur ro/ / gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi tshogs pa nyid las 'bras bu skye bar 'gyur zhing tshogs pa la 'bras bu gnas pa med na ni/ ji ltar na tshogs pa nyid las 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skye zhes pa mi skye ste/ de na med pa'i phyir/ bye ma las til mar bzhin no/ / mdor na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod na skye mi dgos shing tshogs pa la med na rang bzhin gyis skyed mi nus pa'o/ /

If it were already manifest, it would not have to arise again. If it were not, this would be the position according to which that which does not exist previously arises. If the effect arises from the assemblage of causes and conditions and the effect does not exist just in the assemblage, how could the effect arise essentially just from the assemblage? It could not, because, being nonexistent there, it would be like tahini coming from sand. To summarize, if the effect exists essentially, it does not need to arise; if it is not in the assemblage, it cannot arise essentially.
gnyis pa [tshogs pa la yod med nyid dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2 Refutation of the existence and nonexistence of the assemblage itself
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs la 'bras bu yod na ni/ / tshogs la gzung du yod rigs na/ / tshogs pa nyid la gzung du med/ /
3. If the effect were in the assemblage Of causes and conditions, Then it should be found in the assemblage. But it is not found in the assemblage.

gzhan yang gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi tshogs pa la 'bras bu rten pa'i sgo nas yod na ni/ tshogs pa la tshad ma bzhi gang rung gis gzung du yod dgos na tshogs pa nyid la tshad mas gzung du med pas de la 'khar gzhong na zho ltar med do/ / ci ste yang gang zhig gang na med pa de ni de las mi skye ste bye ma las 'bru mar bzhin no/ / 'bras bu ni tshogs pa las skye ba yin te de'i phyir tshogs pa las 'bras bu yod par ni rjes dpag las grub bo snyam na/ 'o na gang na gang yod pa de ni de las rang bzhin gyis mi skye ste 'khar gzhong las zho'i rigs kyi ngo bo bzhin no zhes pa'i rjes dpag gis tshogs pa la 'bras bu med par 'grub bo zhes ci ste mi gzung / ci ste phyogs gnyis ka'ang rjes dpag dang 'gal bas ji ltar tshogs pa la 'bras bu yod pa mi rigs pa bzhin du tshogs pa la med pa yang mi rigs so snyam na/ / kho bo cag 'bras bu rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa la med pa rang bzhin gyis grub par sgrub pa min gyi tshogs pa la 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod par gzhan gyis brtags pa 'gog go / de bzhin du kho bo cag tshogs pa la 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod par mi sgrub kyi gzhan gyis de la 'bras bu med pa rang bzhin gyis grub par brtags pa sel te/ yod med kyi mtha' gnyis bsal nas dbu ma'i lam sgrub par 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, if the effect existed in virtue of being based in the assemblage of causes and conditions, [347] it would have to be the case that it could be found in the assemblage by one of the four kinds of authoritative cognition. But it is not found in the assemblage itself by authoritative cognition, in the same way that yoghurt is seen in the bowl. That which is not in something does not arise from it just as oil does not arise from sand. But one might think about it like this: The effect does arise from the assemblage because the arising of the effect from the assemblage is established by inference. But in that case, why don’t you accept the inference—that which exists in something else cannot arise from it essentially, just as nothing like yoghurt arises from a bowl—establishes that the effect does not exist in the assemblage? Or one might think about it like this: Since accepting the inference is inconsistent with both positions, just as it makes no sense to say that the effect exists in the assemblage, it makes no sense either to say that the effect is not in the assemblage. We do not argue that the effect is essentially nonexistent in the assemblage of causes and conditions, but we refute the essential existence of the effect in the assemblage as it is fabricated by others. Similarly, we do not argue that the effect exists essentially in the assemblage, but we refute the essential nonexistence of the effect in them as imagined by others, because we aspire to establish the middle path through the elimination of the two extremes of existence and nonexistence.
gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi/ / tshogs la 'bras bu med na ni/ / rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag kyang / / rgyu rkyen ma yin mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
4. If the effect were not in the assemblage Of causes and conditions, Then it would be as though causes and conditions Were not causes and conditions.

gal te rgyu dang rkyen rnams kyi tshogs pa la 'bras bu med na ni myu gu'i rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag kyang rgyu rkyen ma yin pa me dang sol ba sogs dang mtshungs par 'gyur te/ 'bras bu med par mtshungs na myu gu'i rgyu rkyen yin min du ngo bo nyid kyis yod med kyang mtshungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the effect did not exist in the assemblage of causes and conditions, then it would be as though the causes and conditions of the sprout were not causes and conditions, just like fire and charcoal. This is because if they were similar in that they do not have those effects, they would also be similar with respect to whether they inherently exist or do not exist either as the causes and conditions of the sprout or not.
gnyis pa [tshogs pa las brgyud nas skye ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2 Refutation of arising indirectly from the assemblage

rgyu mtshan gang las tshogs pa la 'bras bu yod med dpyod par 'gyur ba rgyu dang rkyen gnyis tshogs pa la ni 'bras bu dngos su skyed pa'i nus pa med do/ / 'on kyang rkyen kyi tshogs pas ni dngos kyi rgyu la phan 'dogs pa tsam zhig byed la rgyu des ni 'bras bu bskyed pa'i phyir du/ rgyu'i nus pa 'ga' zhig 'bras bu la byin nas 'gag cing phyin pa'i rgyu des phan btags pa'i 'bras bu yang skyed do zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: According to the argument through which we conducted the analysis asking whether or not the effect exists in the assemblage, the assemblage of causes and conditions does not have the power to give rise directly to the causes and conditions. However, the assemblage of conditions merely assists the direct cause, [348] and that cause in order to give rise to the effect provides causal power to the effect and then ceases. With the assistance of that causation that has been provided, the effect arises.
gal te rgyus ni 'bras bu la/ / rgyu byin nas ni 'gag 'gyur na/ / gang byin pa dang gang 'gags pa'i/ / rgyu yi dag nyid gnyis su 'gyur/ /
5. If the cause ceases, Having provided causation to the effect, There would be two kinds of cause: The causation that has been provided and the cause that has ceased.

gal te rgyus ni 'bras bu la byed rgyu byin nas 'gag par 'gyur na 'bras bu la gang byin pa'i byed rgyu dang gang zhig 'gas pa'i rgyu yi bdag nyid rdzas so so ba gnyis su 'gyur ro/ // de ni rigs pa ma yin te byin pa'i rgyu ni rang skyes pa'i 'og tu yang gnas pas rtag pa dang 'gags pa'i rgyu ni mi rtag par 'gyur ba'i phyir dang rgyu gcig la rtag mi rtag gnyis 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ /

If the cause ceases after having provided facilitative causation to the effect, then it would follow that the facilitative causation that has been provided to the effect and the cause that has ceased would be two substantially distinct causes. That would not make any sense, because the provided causation endures after it has arisen, and so would be permanent, and the ceased cause would be impermanent, and it would be contradictory for a single cause to be both permanent and impermanent.
gal te rgyus ni 'bras bu la/ / rgyu ma byin par 'gag 'gyur na/ / rgyu 'gag nas ni skyes pa yi/ / 'bras bu de dag rgyu med 'gyur/ /
6. If the cause, not yet having Provided causation to its effect, ceased, Then, having arisen from a ceased cause, The effect would causeless.

gal te rgyu gcig nyid rdzas so so ba gnyis su 'gyur ba spang ba'i phyir du rgyus ni 'bras bu la byed rgyu ma byin par bdag nyid thams cad kyis snga logs na 'gag par 'gyur na ni/ rgyu sa bon lta bu 'gags pa'i rjes nas ni skyes pa'i 'bras bu myu gu lta bu de ni rgyu sa bon las dngos su skye ba med pa kho nar 'gyur bas rgyu med du 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te myu gu'i snga rol du sa bon gyi rgyu ril gyis 'gaT pa dang 'gags ma 'gags cha gnyis gang rung du 'gyur ba'i brtag pa 'di ji ltar yin snyam na/ 'gag pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa ltar na myu gu'i snga rol du sa bon 'gags pa la mngon du phyogs pa'i tshe 'gag pa'i bya ba rdzogs dgos te 'gags pa ni 'gag rgyu'i dngos po de'i chos yin la rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i chos chos can ni dus nam yang mi 'brel ba'i phyir te skye ba bden par 'dod na skye ba la mngon du phyogs pa'i tshe skye rgyu'i dngos po grub dgos pa bzhin no/ /

Suppose that in order to rebut the charge that a single cause would have to be two substantially different entities, someone gave the following argument: The cause, without providing facilitative causation to the effect, completely ceases prior to the occurrence of the effect. It would follow from this that an effect such as a sprout which has arisen after the cessation of a cause such as a seed would not have arisen directly from the seed. Therefore it would be causeless. Suppose someone asks how this analysis is supposed to go, where one contrasts the complete cessation of the seed prior to the existence of the sprout with its having either of two aspects—one ceased and the other unceased. According to those for whom cessation exists through its own characteristic, prior to the existence of the sprout, when the seed is about to cease, it would have to have already completed its activity of cessation. This is because the cessation is the property of that entity which is to cease. And a property of an essentially existent entity is inextricable from it, because this is just like the case of maintaining that something is truly arisen; in that case when it is about to arise, that which is to arise must already exist.
gnyis pa [dus mnyam pa'i tshogs pa las skye ba dgag] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation of arising from a simultaneous assemblage

gal te 'bras bu rang gi snga rol gyi rgyu las skye ba la nyes pa 'dir 'gyur na ni rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa 'bras bu dang lhan cig skyes pa kho na 'bras bu'i skyed byed du 'gyur te/ dper na dus mnyam pa'i sgron mes 'od skyed pa bzhin no zhe na/

Now, suppose someone argued as follows: Since we have seen that it is erroneous to say that an effect arises from a cause prior to it, only an assemblage of causes and conditions simultaneous with the effect can give rise to it. For example, [349] the lamp, which is simultaneous with the light, gives rise to it.
gal te tshogs dang lhan cig tu/ / 'bras bu yang ni skye 'gyur na/ / skyed par byed dang skye ba gang / / dus gcig par ni thal bar 'gyur/ /
7. If the effect were to arise Simultaneously with the assemblage, Then the producer and the produced Would be simultaneous.

gal te rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa dang lhan cig tu 'bras bu yang ni skye bar 'gyur na ni/ skyed par byed pa rgyu dang bskyed bya 'bras bu gang yin pa de gnyis ni dus gcig tu thal bar 'gyur na/ / ba lang gi rwa g.yas g.yon gnyis bskyed bya dang skyed byed du ma mthong bas de ni mi rigs so/ /

If the effect arose simultaneously with the assemblage of causes and conditions the absurd consequence would follow that the cause that gives rise to it—the producer—would be simultaneous with the effect to which it gives rise—the produced. This makes no sense, as the right and left horn of a cow cannot be producer and produced.
gsum pa [tshogs pa phyi ma las skye ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.3 Refutation of arising through a subsequent assemblage

bye brag tu smra ba dag na re dngos po rnams sngar ma byung ba las skye ba ni med de glo bur ba rgyu med par thal ba'i phyir ro/ // de'i phyir 'bras bu ni rgyu rkyen tshogs pa'i snga rol gyi ma 'ongs pa'i skabs su yang gnas pa yin la/ rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pas ni de da lta ba'i gnas skabs su skyed pa yin gyi rdzas ni snga phyir gnas pa nyid do zhes zer ro/ /

According to the Vaibhāṣikas, entities do not arise from things that do not exist prior to them. Otherwise, the absurd consequence would follow that they would arise at random without any cause. Therefore, prior to the existence of the assemblage of causes and conditions, the effect exists in the future. The assemblage of causes and conditions gives rise to its existence in the present. But these substances are said to exist both before and after [Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya V, mNgon pa ku 239a].
gal te tshogs pa'i snga rol tu/ / 'bras bu skyes par gyur na ni/ / rgyu dang rkyen rnams med pa yi/ / 'bras bu rgyu med 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
8. If the effect were to be arisen Prior to the assemblage, Then, without causes and conditions, The effect would have arisen causelessly.

gal te rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa'i snga rol du 'bras bu skyes par te grub zin par gyur na ni/ 'bras bu de rgyu dang rkyen rnams la ltos pa med par 'gyur la de lta na rang gi rgyu med par 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ //

If the effect were already arisen prior to the assemblage of causes and conditions—that is, had already come into existence—it would follow that that effect would be independent of causes and conditions. In that case it would arise without its cause.
gnyis pa [rgyu nyid las skye ba dgag]
1.2 Refutation of arising just from causation
['di] la gnyis/ rgyu 'bras ngo bo gcig pa'i phyogs dgag pa dang / rgyu 'bras ngo bo tha dad pa'i phyogs dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the position that cause and effect have the same nature and the refutation of the position that cause and effect have different natures.
dang po [rgyu 'bras ngo bo gcig pa'i phyogs dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1 Refutation of the position that cause and effect have the same nature

kha cig na re/ 'bras bu ni rgyu kho nas skyed par byed kyi rgyu rkyen tshogs pas ni ma yin la 'bras bu la byed rgyu byin ma byin gyi nyes par yang mi 'gyur te/rgyu nyid 'gags nas 'bras bu'i bdag nyid du rnam par gnas pa'i phyir ro zhes 'dzer to//

Some say that the effect is given rise to simply by the cause, but not by the assemblage of causes and conditions, and that no error is committed whether or not one says that facilitative causation is provided to the effect. This is because they say that, having ceased, the cause itself persists in the form of the effect.
gal te rgyu 'gags 'bras bu na/ / rgyu ni kun tu 'pho bar 'gyur/ / sngon skyes pa mi rgyu yang ni/ / yang skye bar ni thal bar 'gyur/ /
9. If, the cause, having ceased, Passed completely into the effect, Then a previously arisen cause Would, absurdly, arise again.

gal te rgyu 'gags pa na 'bras bu skye la de yang rgyu'i bdag nyid kho nar rtog na ni zlos gar mkhan cha lugs gzhan btang nas gzhan len pa ltar rgyu ni dus kun tu 'pho ba tsam du 'gyur gyi 'bras bu sngar med pa skye ba min par 'gyur ro// // de'i phyir rgyu rtag par 'gyur na de ni mi rigs te/ rtag pa'i dngos po yod pa min pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan yang sngon skyes pa'i rgyu yang ni slar yang skye bar thal bar 'gyur te/ dang po rgyu'i dus dang phyis 'bras bu'i dus gnyis kar skye ba'i phyir ro/ / de yang mi rigs te/ skye mi dgos pa'i phyir dang skye ba thug med du 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

When the cause ceases, the effect arises. Some might think that it has the nature of the cause itself: Just as an actor sheds one costume and puts on another, the cause just keeps passing on and does not give rise to any previously nonexistent effect. In that case, the cause would be permanent. But this does not make any sense because there are no permanent things. [350] Moreover, the absurd consequence would follow that a previously arisen cause would arise again because it would arise first when the cause occurs and then later when the effect occurs. This would not make any sense either, because it would not need to arise, and there would be an infinite regress of arising.
gnyis pa [rgyu 'bras ngo bo tha dad pa'i phyogs dgag pa]
1.2.2 Refutation of the position that cause and effect have different natures
['di] la gnyis/ rgyus 'bras bu skye ba'i bya ba sbyor bar byed pa dgag pa dang / rgyu nyid rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the cause providing the action of giving rise to the effect and the refutation of the essential existence of causality.
dang po [rgyus 'bras bu skye ba'i bya ba sbyor bar byed pa dgag pa]
1.2.2.1 Refutation of the cause providing the action of giving rise to the effect

['di] la bdun/ rgyu 'gags pa dang gnas pas 'bras bu skyed pa dgag / rgyus mthong ba dang ma mthong bar 'bras bu skyed pa dgag / rgyus phrad pa dang ma phrad par 'bras bu skyed pa dgag / 'bras bus stong mi stong gi rgyus 'bras bu skyed pa dgag / 'bras bu stong mi stong rgyus skyed pa dgag / rang bzhin gcig dang tha dad kyi rgyus 'bras bu skyed pa dgag / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod med rgyus skyed pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has seven parts: refutation of both a ceased and an enduring cause giving rise to the effect; the refutation of the cause giving rise to an effect by seeing or not seeing; the refutation of a cause giving rise to an effect through contact or without contact; the refutation of a cause that is empty or nonempty of the effect giving rise to an effect; the refutation of a cause giving rise to an empty or nonempty effect; the refutation of a cause giving rise to an effect that is essentially identical or different; the refutation of a cause giving rise to an inherently existent or an inherently nonexistent effect.
dang po [rgyu 'gags pa dang gnas pas 'bras bu skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.1 Refutation of both a ceased and an enduring cause giving rise to the effect
gzhan yang rgyus 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed na rgyu de 'bras bu'i snga rol du 'gags pa'am ma 'gags pas skyed/ 'bras bu yang skyes zin nam ma skyes pa skyed brtag grang /

Moreover, if the cause gives rise to the effect essentially, does the cause give rise to the effect having ceased or not having ceased prior to the occurrence of the effect? And does it give rise to an effect that has already arisen or to one that is as yet non-arisen?
'gags pa nub par gyur pa yis/ / 'bras bu skyes pa ci ltar skyed/ / 'bras bu dang ni 'brel ba'i rgyu/ / gnas pas kyang ni ci ltar skyed/ /
10. How can a cause, having ceased and dissolved, Give rise to an arisen effect? How can an enduring cause related to its effect Give rise to it?

de la dang po ltar na rgyu 'gags pa nub pa ste zhig par gyur pa yis 'bras bu skyes pa ji ltar skyed ces pa mi skyed de/ rgyu 'gags pa'i tshe na ni rgyu de med la med pa yang rgyur mi 'thad pa'i phyir dang / 'bras bu skyes zin pa slar skye mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste gnyis pa ltar na 'bras bu dang ni 'brel ba'i rgyu gnas pa ste ma zhig pas kyang ni 'bras bu ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed ces pa mi skyed de/ ma 'gags par rang bzhin gyis grub pas skyed na rgyu rnam par ma 'gyur bar 'bras bu mthong dgos la de ni mi rigs te/ brgya pa las/ rgyu ni rnam par 'gyur ba na/ / gzhan gyi rgyu ru 'gyur ba ste/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar 'bras bu skyes pa na rgyu rnam par gyur pa dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste 'bras bu grub zin skyed mi dgos pas rgyu'i dus na 'bras bu dang ma 'brel ba skyed do snyam na/

In the first case how could a cause that has ceased or dissolved—that is, disintegrated—give rise to an arisen effect? It could not, because at the time when the cause has ceased, the cause no longer exists, and it is not tenable that a nonexistent thing can be a cause; and an already arisen effect does not need to arise again. In the second case, how could an enduring cause related to its effect—that is, one that has not disintegrated—essentially give rise to the effect? It could not, because if a cause that is non-ceased and essentially existent gave rise to an effect, then it would have to be the case that the effect would occur without any transformation of the cause. But this does not make any sense because, as Catuḥśataka says, When the cause transforms It becomes the cause of another. [IX: 9ab] When the effect has arisen, the cause must have transformed. [351] One might think that since an already existent effect does not need to be given rise to, at the time when the cause exists it gives rise to an effect to which it is not related.
ci ste rgyu 'bras ma 'brel na/ / 'bras bu gang zhig skyed par byed/ /
11. Moreover, if an effect is not related to its cause, How can it be given rise to?

rgyus 'bras bu gang zhig rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed ces pa mi byed de 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed na rgyu dus su'ang 'brel dgos la der ma 'bral na rang mtshan gyis grub pa la 'brel ba tsam yang med par 'gyur ro/ de ltar 'brel med kyi rgyus 'bras bu skyed na rgyu gcig gis kyang 'bras bu yin no cog thams cad skyed pa'am yang na 'bras bu gang yang mi skyed par 'gyur ro/ /

But the cause cannot essentially give rise to such an effect, because if it gave rise to the effect essentially, then the effect would have to be related to the cause even when it is simultaneous with the cause. Suppose it were not related to it. For that which exists through its own characteristic there cannot be any relation at all. If such an unrelated cause gave rise to an effect, a single cause could give rise to every conceivable effect or it would not give rise to any effect.
gnyis pa [rgyus mthong ba dang ma mthong bar 'bras bu skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.2 Refutation of the cause giving rise to an effect by seeing or not seeing.
gzhan yang rgyus 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed na rgyus 'bras bu mthong nas sam 'on te ma mthong bar skyed/
Moreover, if a cause gives rise to an effect essentially, does it do so by seeing it or by not seeing it?
rgyus ni mthong dang ma mthong bar/ / 'bras bu skyed par mi byed do/ /
11cd. The cause gives rise to the effect Neither by seeing it nor by not seeing it.

dang po ltar na/ rgyus ni rang gi 'bras bu mthong nas skyed par mi byed de/ mthong na ni grub zin pas de slar yang bskyed mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyus rang gi 'bras bu ma mthong bar rang bzhin gyis skyed par yang mi byed de/ de ltar skyed na rgyu gcig gis kyang 'bras bu yin no cog skyed par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / mthong ba 'di ci zhig ce na/ 'di ni 'jig rten na dmigs par grags pa'o/ / gal te sa bon la sogs pa dbang po med pa rnams la 'di mi srid pa ma yin nam zhe na/ srid dam mi srid kyang rung ste kho bo cag la brgal bar bya ba min gyi 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skye bar smra ba la brgal bar bya'o/ / des ni sa bon la sogs pas mthong nas skyed par smra na de dag gis 'bras bu mthong ba 'di 'jig rten ma mthong ngo zhes smra bar bya'o/ / ci ste ma mthong bar rang bzhin gyis skyed par smra na ni sngar bzhin brjod par bya'o/ / skyes bu la sogs pa rgyur smra ba 'gro ba rnams la blo sngon du btang ba'i byed pa po yod par smra ba dang / gcer bu pa sa bon la sogs pa dbang po gcig pa can sems pa dang ldan par smra ba rnams la ni thal ba 'di mi ldog pas nyes pa med do/ / shes rab sgron mar mig la sogs pas rang gi rnam shes skyed na de'i yul gzugs la sogs pa rnams dmigs nas skyed dam ma dmigs par skyed ces rgyu 'bras bye brag pa dgag pa'i phyogs dang sbyar ro/ /

To consider the first case, the cause does not give rise to its effect by seeing it, because if it did see it, since the effect would already exist there would be no need for it to arise again. Nor does the cause essentially give rise to its effect without seeing it, because if it did, then a single cause could give rise to any conceivable effect. What is it to see in this sense? It is to perceive, just as it is for ordinary people. Suppose someone asked, “Is it not impossible for such as things as seeds to have sense faculties?” We are not the ones with whom to argue about whether this is possible or impossible. Instead, argue with those who assert that effects arise essentially! They say that such things as seeds give rise to their effects having seen them! However, one should say to them that no ordinary person sees that causes see their effects! If one were to say that they give rise to their effects essentially, without seeing them, then what we said above still applies. When these absurd consequences are presented to those who say that a supreme being/1/ is the cause—those who say that there is a creator who intentionally creates beings, and those Jains who say that such things as seeds have a single sense faculty and a mind—there is no way for them to rebut them. [352] Therefore, we commit no error. In Prajñāpradīpa, this passage is applied to the refutation of a specific case of causality: When such things as eyes give rise to their own sensory consciousness, do they do so by seeing their objects, such as material form, or by not seeing them [200a]?
gsum pa [rgyus phrad pa dang ma phrad par 'bras bu skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.3 Refutation of a cause giving rise to an effect through contact or without contact
'bras bu 'das pa rgyu 'das dang / / ma skyes pa dang skyes pa dang / / lhan cig phrad par gyur ba ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
12. There is never simultaneous contact Of a past effect With a past, non-arisen, Or arisen cause.

gzhan yang rgyus 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed na de gnyis phrad pa ste lhan cig tshogs pa dgos te de ltar min pa'i snang mun dang 'khor 'das la bskyed bya dang skyed byed ma mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / phrad pa yang rigs shes kyis dpyad pa na dus gsum char la yang rnyed pa ma yin te/ / de la re zhig myu gu la sogs pa'i 'bras bu 'das pa ni sa bon la sogs pa'i rgyu 'das pa dang lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni nam yang yod pa ma yin te/ de gnyis zhig pa'i dus na de gnyis med pa'i phyir dang / sa myug gnyis zhig pa phrad du chug kyang sa myug gi rgyu 'bras phrad pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ // de bzhin du 'bras bu 'das pa ni rgyu ma skyes pa ma 'ongs pa dang phrad pa nam yang yod pa ma yin te 'bras bu zhig nas dang*/ rgyu ma skyes pa nyid kyis de gnyis med pa'i phyir dang dus gnyis tha dad pa'i phyir ro/ / 'bras bu 'das pa ni rgyu skyes pa da ltar ba dang lhan cig phrad pa nam yang yod pa ma yin te dus gnyis so so ba yin pa'i phyir dang*/ 'bras bu zhig pa ni 'bras bu yod pa min pa'i phyir te mo gsham gyi bu dang lhas byin bzhin no/ /

Moreover, if the cause gives rise to the effect essentially, these would have to make contact—that is, they would have to be simultaneous. This is because pairs such as light and darkness or samsara and nirvana, which are not like this, are not regarded as producer and produced. When contact is examined by the rational mind this is not found in any of the three temporal periods. In this connection, any past effect, such as a sprout, is never in contact with a past cause such as a seed, because when they are disintegrated, they do not exist and, although the disintegrated seed and the sprout may have come into contact, there is no contact between the seed and the sprout as cause and effect. Similarly, a past effect does not come into contact with an unarisen cause—that is, one that is yet to come—because neither the disintegrated effect nor the unarisen cause exists, and the two temporal periods are distinct. A past effect does not come into simultaneous contact with a cause in the present because they exist in distinct temporal periods and because the disintegrated effect, just like the son of a barren woman, cannot be in simultaneous contact with Lhejin.
'bras bu skyes pa rgyu ma skyes/ / 'das pa dang ni skyes pa ma cu dang*/ / lhan cig phrad par 'gyur pa ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
13. There is never simultaneous contact Of an arisen effect With a non-arisen, past, Or arisen cause.

'bras bu skyes pa ste da ltar ba dang de'i rgyu ma skyes pa ste ma 'ongs pa dang rgyu 'das pa dang skyes pa ste da ltar ba dang lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni nam yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min te/ rgyu 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa gnyis ni dus tha dad pa'i phyir dang / rgyu 'bras da ltar ba gnyis la phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod na dus snga phyi ba mi rung bas cig car yod dgos na de med pa'i phyir dang / grub zin pa'i 'bras bu rgyus bskyed pa'i don du phrad pa rtog pa yin na de la de mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ /

The arisen effect—that is, one that is in the present—can never inherently come into simultaneous contact with its nonarisen cause—that is, one which is yet to come—nor with the past cause nor with an arisen cause—that is, a present one. This is because the past cause and that which is yet to come are in two distinct temporal periods, and if the present cause and effect contacted each other essentially, it would not be possible for them to be sequential; rather, they would have to be simultaneous, and that cannot be, [353] and because, even though one might think that an effect that has already arisen must come into contact with a cause in order for the cause to give rise to it, in fact that is not necessary.
'bras bu ma skyes rgyu skyes dang / / ma skyes pa dang 'das pa dang*/ / lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni/ / nam yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
14. There is never simultaneous contact Of a non-arisen effect With an arisen, non-arisen, Or a past cause.

'bras bu ma skyes pa ste ma 'ongs pa ni rgyu skyes pa da ltar ba dang ma 'ongs pa dang 'das pa gnyis dang lhan cig phrad par 'gyur ba ni nam yang rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te/ rgyu 'das da ltar dang ni dus tha dad pa'i phyir dang rgyu 'bras gnyis ma 'ongs pa'i dus su de gnyis gang yang med pa'i phyir ro/ /

A non-arisen effect—that is, one that has yet to come—can never essentially come into simultaneous contact with a cause that has presently arisen, or an unarisen future cause, or a past cause. This is because the past cause and that which is in the present exist at distinct times and because neither the cause nor the effect in the future exist.
phrad pa yod pa ma yin na/ / rgyus ni 'bras bu ci ltar skyed/ / phrad pa yod pa yin na yang / / rgyus ni 'bras bu ci ltar skyed/ /
15. Without contact, How can a cause produce an effect? Even where there is contact, How can a cause produce an effect?

de ltar rgyu 'bras gnyis la dpyad pa na phrad pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin na rgyus ni 'bras bu ji ltar na skyed par byed de mi byed do/ / ci ste yang rgyu 'bras gnyis rang bzhin gyis phrad pa yod pa yin na yang rgyus ni 'bras bu ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis skyed de mi skyed de/ 'bras bu dang lhan cig tu ma tshogs na phrad pa mi 'thad cing lhan cig tu tshogs na slar yang skye ba don med pa'i phyir ro//

Thus given this analysis of cause and effect, since contact does not exist essentially, how can a cause give rise to an effect? It cannot! On the other hand, even if cause and effect came into contact essentially, how could the cause essentially give rise to the effect? It could not! This is because if the effect were not simultaneous with it, it would not be tenable for them to be in contact, but if they were simultaneous there would be no point for the effect to arise again.
bzhi pa ['bras bus stong mi stong gi rgyus 'bras bu skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.4 Refutation of a cause that is empty or nonempty of the effect giving rise to an effect
gal te 'bras bus stong ba'i rgyus/ / ci ltar 'bras bu skyed par byed/ / gal te 'bras bus mi stong rgyus/ / ci ltar 'bras bu skyed par byed/ /
16. If a cause is empty of an effect, How can it produce an effect? If a cause is not empty of an effect, How can it produce an effect?

gzhan yang gal te 'bras bus stong pa'i rgyus ji ltar na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed de mi byed de/ gzhan du na chu dang zho la mar med par mtshungs bzhin du zho las mar 'byung la chu las mi 'byung ba'i khyad par mi rnyed pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te rang gi 'bras bus mi stong pa'i rgyus kyang ji ltar na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed de mi byed de/ 'bras bu yod pa slar yang mi skye ba'i phyir te bu yod pa'i lhas byin bzhin no/ //

Moreover, how could a cause that is empty of the effect give rise essentially to the effect? It could not, because even though water and curd are similar in the respect that they are each empty of butter, butter does come from curd but not from water, and this distinction could not be drawn. If, on the other hand, the cause were not empty of its effect, how could it give rise essentially to the effect? It could not, because an existent effect does not arise again, just as it is when Lhejin has a son.
lnga pa ['bras bu stong mi stong rgyus skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.5 Refutation of the cause giving rise to an empty or nonempty effect
'bras bu skye ba de yang rang bzhin gyis yod pas mi stong pa'am stong pa zhig skye grang /
Is that effect that arises empty of essential existence or not empty of essential existence?
'bras bu mi stong skye mi 'gyur/ / mi stong 'gag par mi 'gyur ro/ / mi stong de ni ma 'gags dang / / ma skyes par yang 'gyur ba yin/ /
17. A nonempty effect does not arise. The nonempty would not cease. This nonempty would be The non-ceased and the non-arisen.

de la 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod pas mi stong pa ni skye bar mi 'gyur ba ste rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba ma yin zhing rang bzhin gyis gnas pa yin la/ de 'dra ba'i mi stong pa de ni rang bzhin la ldog pa med pas 'gag par mi 'gyur ro/ / de'i phyir 'bras bu de mi stong par 'dod na ma 'gags pa dang ma skyes par yang 'gyur ba yin na de ltar 'dod pa yang min no/ /

An effect that is not empty of essential existence would not arise—that is, not being dependently originated, it would be essentially existent. Since such a nonempty thing could not lose its essence, it would be unceasing. Therefore, if you maintain that this effect is not empty [354] it would be unceasing and unarisen; but you do not want to maintain this!
stong pa ci ltar skye 'gyur zhing / / stong pa ci ltar 'gags par 'gyur/ / stong pa de yang ma 'gags dang / / mi skyes par yang thal bar 'gyur/ /
18. How can the empty arise? How can the empty cease? The empty would hence also, absurdly, Be the non-ceased and the non-arisen.

'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pa ni je ltar na rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis skye bar 'gyur zhing ji ltar na ngo bos 'gag par 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te nam mkha' bzhin no/ / de'i phyir 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong par 'dod na yang ngo bo nyid kyis ma 'gaT pa dang ma skyes par yang thal bar yang 'gyur na khyed de ltar yang mi 'dod do/ /

How could an effect that is empty of essential existence arise inherently? And how could it inherently cease? It could not, just like space. Therefore, even if you maintain that the effect is empty of essential existence, the absurd consequence would follow that it is unceasing and unarisen, and you do not want to accept this either!
drug pa [rang bzhin gcig dang tha dad kyi rgyus 'bras bu skyed pa dgag] ni/
1.2.2.1.6 Refutation of a cause giving rise to an effect that is essentially identical or different
rgyu dang 'bras bu gcig nyid du/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gzhan nyid du/ / nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
19. The identity of cause and effect Is never tenable. The difference of cause and effect Is never tenable.

gzhan yang rgyus 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed na gnyis las mi 'da' la de yang rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis rang bzhin gyis gcig pa nyid du nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur la/ rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis rang bzhin gyis gzhan pa nyid du yang nam yang 'thad par mi 'gyur ro zhes dam bca' ba tsam zhig gsungs so/ / de'i sgrub byed ni

Moreover, if the cause gave rise to the effect essentially, you could not escape two alternatives. Here the author just asserts the thesis that it is not tenable for these two—the cause and effect—to be essentially identical; nor is it tenable for these two—the cause and effect—to be essentially different. The argument for this thesis is as follows:
rgyu dang 'bras bu gcig nyid na/ / bskyed bya skyed byed gcig tu 'gyur/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gzhan nyid na/ / rgyu dang rgyu min mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
20. If cause and effect were identical, Produced and producer would be identical. If cause and effect were different, Cause and noncause would be alike.

rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis rang bzhin gyis gcig pa nyid yin na bskyed bya bu dang mig gi shes pa dang myu gu dang skyed byed pha dang mig dang sa bon rnams gcig tu 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis rang bzhin gyis gzhan pa nyid yin na rang mtshan gyis gzhan du grub pa la ltos pa med pas rgyu yin pa dang min pa rnams rgyu yin min mtshungs par 'gyur te 'brel med don gzhan la rgyu 'bras yin min dbye bar mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the two—the cause and the effect—were essentially identical, then produced things such as a son, visual consciousness, and a sprout would be identical to their respective producers such as the father, the eye, and the seed. If these two—the cause and effect—were essentially different, then, given that they would be different through their own characteristics, they would not be dependent. Therefore, a cause and non-cause could each just as easily be a cause or a non-cause, because you could not draw a distinction between unrelated entities being and not being cause and effect.
bdun pa ['bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod med rgyus skyed pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2.2.1.7 Refutation of a cause giving rise to an inherently existent or an inherently nonexistent effect
gzhan yang rgyus 'bras bu skyed na 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod dam med pa skyed brtag grang /
Moreover, if the cause gives rise to the effect, then we must inquire as to whether it gives rise to an inherently existent or an inherently nonexistent effect.
'bras bu ngo bo nyid rtsa ba yod na/ / rgyus ni cig zhig bskyed par 'gyur/ / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid med na/ / rgyus ni cig zhig bskyed par 'gyur/ /
21. If an effect is inherently existent, To what could a cause have given rise? If an effect is inherently nonexistent, To what could a cause have given rise?

de la 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod na'ang rgyus ci zhig skyed par byed de mi byed de/ de skyed na grub zin slar skyed dgos la grub zin na slar yang skye mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / 'bras bu rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis med na'ang rgyus ni ci zhig skyed par byed de mi byed do/ / gal te gzugs brnyan rang bzhin gyis med kyang rgyus skyed pas ma nges so zhe na/ de lta yin mod dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis med par grub bo// // de'i phyir rang bzhin gyis yod par smra ba btang nas kho bo cag rang bzhin med pa'i rgyu 'bras smra ba'i rjes su 'brang bar 'gyur ro/ /

If an effect is inherently existent, to what could a cause have given rise? There is nothing to which it could have, because if it gave rise to such a thing, it would have to have given rise to something that already exists. But that which already exists does not need to arise again. If, on the other hand, the effect were inherently nonexistent, to what could a cause have given rise? There is nothing to which it could have. Suppose one said that although a reflection does not exist essentially, it is given rise to by a cause and therefore that there is no such entailment. The example is all right, [355] but it would also establish that all things are essenceless. Therefore, by relinquishing the assertion that that things are essentially existent, you would follow us in asserting that all causes and effects are essenceless.

rang bzhin gyis grub pa 'ga' yang med pas 'gal zla med pa'i phyir dngos po rang bzhin gyis med pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis med pas ma nges par yang ga la 'gyur/ kho bo cag ltar na gzugs brnyan zhes pa'i chos can rang bzhin gyis grub pa med na de'i chos kyang rang bzhin gyis grub pa med pas de ni rang bzhin yod med gang du yang ngo bo nyid kyis grub par mi 'dod do/ / sngar 'bras bu stong mi stong skye ba bkag pa ni 'bras phyogs nas yin la 'dir 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis yod med skye ba bkag pa ni rgyu'i phyogs nas yin pas mi zlos so/ /

There is no essential existence at all. So, since its contrary does not exist, there is no essential nonexistence. How is it that there is no entailment? On our own view, since characterized phenomena such as a reflection lack essential existence, their characteristics also lack inherent existence. Therefore we do not assert that they exist inherently, either as essentially existent or as essentially nonexistent. Previously, we have refuted the arising of an empty or nonempty effect by focusing on the effect. Now the refutation of arising of an effect that does or does not exist inherently will focus on the cause. Therefore it will not be redundant.
gnyis pa [rgyu nyid rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of causality
gal te yang rgyus 'bras bu skye ba'i bya ba sbyor bar byed pa bkag mod kyang rgyu ni rang bzhin gyis yod de ma bkag pas so/ / des na 'bras bu nga rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Now, someone might argue as follows: Although you have refuted the cause providing the action that gives rise to the effect, the cause exists essentially because you have not refuted that. Therefore, the effect also exists essentially.
skyed par byed pa ma yin na/ / rgyu nyid 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ / rgyu nyid 'thad par yod min na/ / 'bras bu gang gi yod par 'gyur/ /
22. If something is not giving rise to an effect, It is not tenable to attribute causality. If it is not tenable to attribute causality, Then of what will the effect be an effect?

rgyus 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed pa ma yin na rgyu nyid kyang rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'thad par mi 'gyur ro//ci ste rgyu rang bzhin gyis yod pa bkag mod kyang 'bras bu ni rang bzhin gyis yod la des na rgyu yang rang bzhin gyis grub par 'gyur ro snyam na/rgyu nyid rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'thad pa min na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod pa de rgyu gang gi yin par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

Since the cause does not give rise to the effect essentially, it is not tenable that causality exists essentially. Suppose someone thought that although we have refuted the essential existence of the cause, the effect must have essential existence, and therefore that the cause also must exist essentially. Since it is not tenable that causality exists essentially, of what cause would the essentially existent effect be an effect? There would not be any!
gsum pa [rgyu rkyen tshogs pa las skye ba 'gog pa'i rigs pa gzhan bstan pa] ni/
1.3 Presentation of further reasons for the refutation of arising through the assemblage of causes and conditions
gal te rgyu 'ba' zhig 'bras bu skye ba'i bya ba'i sbyor ba po min gyi rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pas 'bras bu skyed do zhe na de ni mi rigs te sngar bkag zin pa'i phyir ro/ //

Suppose someone said that while the cause alone is not the active agent of giving rise to the effect, the entire assemblage of causes and conditions does give rise to the effect. This makes no sense, because it has already been previously refuted.
rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag gi / tshogs pa gang yin de yis ni/ / bdag gis bdag nyid mi skyed na/ / 'bras bu ci ltar skyed par byed/ /
23. If the assemblage Of causes and conditions Does not give rise to itself, How does it give rise to an effect?

gzhan yang de ltar rtog na rgyu rnams dang ni rkyen dag gi tshogs pa gang yin pa de yis ni rang gis rang skyed dam mi skyed/ tshogs pa bdag gis bdag nyid ni mi skyed de 'bras bu skye ba don med pa dang rang la byed pa 'gal ba'i phyir dang*/ tshogs pa rdzas su med pas 'bras bu'i skye ba rab tu sbyor ba por ngo bo nyid kyis med pa'i phyir ro/ // de ltar rdzas su med pas rang gi bdag nyid mi skyed na tshogs pa des ji ltar na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed par byed de mi byed de mo gsham gyi bu bzhin no/ / tshogs pas rang dang gzhan ngo bo nyid kyis mi skyed pa de'i phyir rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pas byas pa ste bskyed pa'i 'bras bu ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ /

Moreover, suppose you thought of it that way. Then does that which is the assemblage of causes and conditions produce itself or not? The assemblage cannot give rise to itself because there would be no point in its arising as an effect, [356] and reflexive action is inconsistent. Moreover, since the assemblage does not substantially exist, it cannot inherently exist as an active agent of giving rise to effects. Therefore, since it is not substantially existent, it cannot give rise to itself. Thus how could this assemblage essentially give rise to an effect? It could not do so, just like the son of a barren woman. The assemblage cannot inherently give rise to itself or to anything else. Therefore, that created by—that is, that which is given rise to by—the assemblage of causes and conditions cannot exist inherently.

bud d+ha pA li ta las/ tshogs pas rang gi bdag nyid mi skyed pa'i don ni tshogs pa rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma grub pa la bshad do//ci ste yang rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pas byas pa'i 'bras bu med na 'o na ni rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa ma yin pas byas pa'i 'bras bu yod do zhe na/

Buddhapālita explains that the meaning of the assemblage not giving rise to itself is that the assemblage does not exist inherently [255a]. Now suppose someone argued as follows: Even though there is no effect created by the assemblage of causes and conditions, there is an effect created by something that is not an assemblage of causes and conditions.
de'i phyir tshogs pas byas pa min/ / tshogs min byas pa'i 'bras bu'ang med/ / 'bras bu yod pa ma yin na/ / rkyen gyi tshogs pa ga la yod/ /
24. Therefore, there is no effect, either Created by an assemblage, Or by something that is not an assemblage. If there is no effect, where can there be an assemblage of conditions?

rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa las rang bzhin gyis bskyed pa'i 'bras bu med na shin tu 'gal ba rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa min pas byas pa'i 'bras bu med do/ / ci ste yang 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis med mod kyi rgyu dang rkyen gyi tshogs pa ni rang bzhin gyis yod do/ / de'i phyir 'bras bu yang rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/ ji skad bshad pa'i rigs pas rnam par dpyad pa na 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin na rkyen gyi tshogs pa rang bzhin gyis ga la yod de med do/ /

Since there is no effect that is given rise to essentially by the assemblage of causes and conditions, its diametrical opposite, an effect that is created by something that is not an assemblage of causes and conditions, cannot exist either. Suppose someone said that even though the effect lacks inherent existence, the assemblage of causes and conditions exists inherently and therefore that the effect must exist inherently. Following the analysis presented in the arguments above, if the effect does not exist essentially, how could the assemblage of causes and conditions exist essentially? It could not!
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/ /
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar rgyu rkyen gnyis ka tshogs pa dang so so ba las 'bras bu 'byung ba rang bzhin gyis ma grub par bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang de ltar bstan pa'i gsung rab thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung 'ga' zhig dang sbyar na rgya cher rol pa las/ mchu dang lkog ma rkan la brten nas ni/ / lce bsgyur ba las yi ge'i sgra 'byung yang / / lkog mar brten nas ma yin rkan las min/ / re re la ni yi ge dmigs su med/ / tshogs pa de la brten nas ngag de ni/ / yid kyi blo yi dbang gis 'byung mod kyi/ / yid dang ngag ni mi snang gzugs med de/ / nang dang phyi rol dag na'ang dmigs su med/ / mkhas pas ngag skad sgra dang dbyangs rnams kyi/ / skye dang 'jig la rnam par brtags byas na/ de tshe ngag kun brag cha lta bu dang / / skad cig pa dang snying po med par mthong / / zhes ngag gi sgra rgyu rkyen la brten nas 'byung ba dang dpyad na rang bzhin med pa dang de ltar 'byung ba yang blo'i dbang gis yin par gsungs so/ / shin tu dga' ba'i bstan pa 'di la ni/ / zhes pa sogs sngar drangs pa dang shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las kyang ko'u shi ka byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po go cha chen po bgos pa des gzugs la gnas par mi bya'o zhes dang phung po lhag ma bzhi dang 'bras bu bzhi dang rang sangs rgyas dang rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la gnas par mi bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the demonstration that the arising of the effect from the assemblage of causes and conditions, whether jointly or severally, does not exist inherently can also be corroborated by profound scriptures and to demonstrate that all of the sūtras that address this issue are explained by this chapter. The Lalitavistara-sūtra says, Depending on lips, larynx, and palate, Through the movement of the tongue, speech sounds arise. However, it does not arise from the larynx and palate. Words are not perceived to come from them individually. [357] Depending on the assemblage, Speech is arisen through the power of the introspective consciousness, However,/2/ mind and speech are not observed, and there is no material form Because they can be seen neither internally nor externally. The wise person, upon analyzing the arising and ceasing Of speech, words, and sound Sees all speech as like an echo, Momentary and without substance. [m Do sde kha 89b–90a] This means that the sound of speech arises depending upon causes and conditions, and upon analysis is said to be essenceless, and such arising also occurs through the power of the mind. This is similar to “This beautiful doctrine” Upālipaṛiprcchā-sūtra [dKon brtsegs Ca 130c] quoted earlier./3/ The Aṣṭasāhasrikā-prajñāramitā-sūtra says “Oh, Kousīka, the great Bodhisattva who is clad in great armor should not hold to material form,” and thereafter it says, “Nor should one hold to the remaining four aggregates and the four fruits and pratyekabuddhas or the fully enlightened buddhas” [Sher phyin ka 20a]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

bud d+ha pA li ta las/ gal te dus kyang med rgyu dang 'bras bu dang tshogs pa yang med na gzhan ci zhig yod de de lta bas na de ni med pa bar smra ba nyid yin no/ / bshad pa ma yin te/ ji ltar dus la sogs pa dag ngo bo nyid las yod par yongs su rtog par byed pa de ltar mi 'thad par zad kyi de dag brten nas gdags par ni grub po zhes gsungs pa dus dang rgyu 'bras dang rkyen gyi tshogs pa rnams dngos por smra ba rnams ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'dod pa bzhin du med pas de bkag gi rgyu dang rkyen la brten nas 'byung ba'i rten 'byung yod pa ni ma bkag par shes par bya'o/ /

In the Buddhapālita it says, “If neither time nor cause and effect nor their assemblage exist, what else could exist?” is an assertion of nihilism. But we respond: This is not the case, because the way you have conceptually constructed such things as time as inherently existent is simply not tenable; instead they exist as dependent designations.
