[255b] One should thus understand that while the inherent existence of cause and effect and the assemblage of causes and conditions maintained by the reificationists is refuted, the existence of dependently originated phenomena, originated in dependence on causes and conditions, is not refuted.
tshogs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu pa'o// //
This is the twentieth chapter called the examination of assemblage.
tshogs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa nyer bzhi'i ltar/ bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twentieth chapter, having twenty-four verses, called the examination of assemblage.
CHAPTER XXI. Examination of Becoming and Destruction
gnyis pa dus 'byung 'jig gi rgyu yin pa dgag pa
This chapter constitutes the second of those two parts: the refutation of time as the cause of the arising and cessation of the effect.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
[358] It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ dus ni rang bzhin gyis yod de 'bras bu 'byung ba dang 'jig pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir te/ myu gu dgun gyi dus lta bu la brten nas 'jig pa dang dpyid kyi dus lta bu la brten nas skye bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / gal te 'byung 'jig ngo bo nyid las yod na dus 'byung 'jig gi rgyur rang bzhin gyis 'gyur na'ang de ltar yod pa ni ma yin no/ / 'di la gnyis/ skye 'jig rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / skye 'jig rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dod na rtag chad kyi skyon bstan pa'o/ /

Here someone might say that time does exist essentially because it is the cause of the becoming and cessation of effects. This is because depending on time, such as winter, sprouts disintegrate, and depending on time, such as spring, they arise. If becoming and destruction existed inherently, then time, as the cause of becoming and destruction, would exist essentially. But that it not the case. This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of arising and destruction and showing that the errors of nihilism and reification follow from maintaining the essential existence of arising and destruction.
dang po [skye 'jig rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of arising and destruction
['di] la gnyis/ 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i bsgrub bya dgag / 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed de dgag pa'o/ //
This section has two parts: the refutation of the conclusion that becoming and destruction exist essentially and the refutation of the argument that becoming and destruction exist essentially.
dang po ['byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i bsgrub bya dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of the conclusion that becoming and destruction exist essentially
['di] la gsum/ 'byung 'jig lhan cig yin min brtags nas dgag / 'byung 'jig rten gang la yod brtags la dgag / 'byung 'jig gcig dang tha dad brtags la dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation through examination of whether or not becoming and destruction are simultaneous, the refutation through analysis to determine on what basis becoming and destruction could exist, and the refutation through examination of whether becoming and destruction are identical or different.
dang po ['byung 'jig lhan cig yin min brtags nas dgag]
1.1.1.1 Refutation through examination of whether or not becoming and destruction are simultaneous
['di] la gsum/ dam bca' bzhag pa/ sgrub byed bstan pa/ de dag gi don bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has three parts: asserting the conclusion, presenting the argument, and the summary of these refutations.
dang po [dam bca' bzhag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.1 Asserting the conclusion
'jig pa 'byung ba med par ram/ / lhan cig yod pa nyid ma yin/ / 'byung ba 'jig pa med par ram/ / lhan cig yod pa nyid ma yin/ /
1. Destruction does not occur without becoming. It does not occur simultaneously with it. Becoming does not occur without destruction. It does not occur simultaneously with it.

gal te 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod na 'jig pa 'byung ba ste skye ba med par yod pa'am 'byung ba dang lhan cig tu rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin la/ 'byung ba 'jig pa med par yod pa'am 'jig pa dang lhan cig tu rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no zhes dam bca' ba bzhi'o/ /

Suppose becoming and destruction existed essentially. There are four conclusions: there is no destruction without becoming—that is, arising; destruction could not be essentially simultaneous with becoming; there is no becoming without destruction; nor could becoming be essentially simultaneous with destruction.
gnyis pa [sgrub byed bstan pa]
1.1.1.1.2 Presenting the argument
['di] la gnyis/ 'jig pa 'byung ba dang lhan cig yin min dgag / 'byung ba 'jig pa dang lhan cig yin min dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of destruction being and not being simultaneous with becoming and the refutation of becoming being and not being simultaneous with destruction.
dang po ['jig pa 'byung ba dang lhan cig yin min dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of destruction being and not being simultaneous with becoming
'jig pa 'byung ba med par ni/ / ci ltar bur na yod par 'gyur/ / skye ba med par 'chi bar 'gyur/ / 'jig pa 'byung ba med par med/ /
2. How could there be destruction Without becoming? There would be death without birth. There is no destruction without becoming.

'jig pa ni 'byung ba ste skye ba med par ni yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / ji lta bur na zhes pas ni gtan mi srid par ston no/ / de ltar yod na ni skye ba med par te ma skyes par 'chi bar 'gyur te de ni sus kyang ma mthong ngo*/ // de'i phyir 'jig pa ni 'byung ba med par gnas pa med do/ //

There is no destruction without becoming—that is, arising. The phrase “how could” means that it is absolutely not possible. If there were, without arising—that is, without being born—one could die. But this is never observed. [359] Therefore it is impossible for there to be destruction without becoming.
'jig pa 'byung dang lhan cig tu/ / ci ltar yod pa nyid du 'gyur/ / 'chi ba skye dang dus gcig tu/ / yod pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
3. How could destruction Occur simultaneously with becoming? Death does not occur Simultaneously with birth.

dngos po'i 'jig pa ni 'byung ba dang lhan cig pa ste dus cig car du ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis yod pa nyid du 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ de ltar 'gyur na 'chi ba skye ba dang dus cig car tu rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur na de ni yod pa nyid ni ma yin te phan tshun 'gal ba'i phyir snang mun bzhin no/ / phan tshun 'gal tshul ni sngar rab byed bcu gcig par bshad pa ltar ram yang na myu gu lta bu de skyes pa dang 'gags pa'i dus gnyis snang mun ltar yin la skye 'gag rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa ltar na/ myu gu 'gags pa de myu gu'i chos dang myu gu chos can du 'gyur ba de rang bzhin la ldog pa med pas dus thams cad kyi tshe 'gyur dgos pas skye 'gag dus gcig na skye ba dang 'gags pa gnyis kyang dus gcig tu 'gyur ba'o/ / 'jig pa'i dpyad pa lhag ma ni rab byed bdun pa'i skabs su bshad zin pas yang mi bshad do/ /

How could the destruction of things be essentially simultaneous with—that is, occur at the same time as—their becoming? It could not, because if it were, death would essentially occur at the same time as birth. But that is not the case, because they are mutually inconsistent, just like light and darkness. The respect in which they are mutually inconsistent has been explained previously in the eleventh chapter. Alternatively, in the case of a sprout, the two temporal periods of its arising and cessation are like light and darkness. According to those for whom arising and cessation exist through their own characteristics, the cessation of the sprout is the characteristic of the sprout; and the sprout is the characterized. In that case, there could not be any alteration in its nature. Therefore, it would have to be that way all the time. So, if arising and cessation were simultaneous, the arising and the ceased would also be simultaneous. The remaining analyses of cessation have been explained in the context of the seventh chapter and so are not explained here.

'dir shes rab sgron mar 'jig pa ni rgyu dang bcas pa yin te 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid yin pa'i phyir skye ba bzhin no zhes nyan thos sde pa 'ga' zhig gis bkod pa la/ skyon gnyis bkod pa'i rtags ma nges pa'i skyon ni/ blo dang sgra dang me lce tha ma dang dgra bcom pa'i tha ma'i sems dang sems byung gi 'jig pa rnams ni 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid yin kyang rgyu dang bcas pa min pas ma nges so zhes bshad pa la tshig gsal las/ de rnams kyi 'jig pa yang skye ba'i rkyen can yin pas rgyu dang bcas pa yin pa'i phyir dang / blo la sogs pa'i skad cig ma tha ma'i 'jig pa yang 'jig pa rgyu med du ma grub pa bsgrub dgos pa dang mtshungs par sgrub dgos pa'i phyir ma nges pa med do zhes gsungs te/

Here in response to some śrāvakas who assert that cessation has a cause, because it is the characteristic of produced phenomena just like arising, Prajñāpradīpa says that two errors are committed: One is a failure of entailment in the premise. Since although the cessation of all things—such as consciousness, sound, the final flicker of a flame, or the final mental event of an arhat—is the characteristic of produced phenomena, it has no cause, there is no entailment [205a]. Prasannapadā says that their cessation is also conditioned by their arising. Therefore, they have causes; and the cessation of such things as the final moment of consciousness must also be established as not existing causelessly, in the same way that cessation in general must be established. Therefore there is no failure of entailment [134b].

'di ni sngar zhig pa la 'jig par byas pa de yin la de yang zla ba'i zhabs dngos por bzhed pa'i lugs so/ // shes rab sgron mar yang sngar ltar bshad pa'i 'og nyid du zhig nas med pa la ni rgyu yod pa ma yin te med pa'i phyir/ dper na gtan med pa bzhin no zhes bshad de zhig pa dngos por mi 'dod pa'i lugs so/ / des na zhig pa 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid yin kyang rgyu med ces pa ni pha rol po'i khas blangs kyi dbang du byas kyi rang gi lugs min no/ / skye ba bzhin no zhes pa'i dpe ma grub par bstan pa'i rgyu mtshan ni dngos po'i ngo bo sngar ma byung ba las byung bas de'i bdag nyid thob pa nyid la skye ba zhes bya ba'i phyir ro zhes bshad de/ 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid du gsungs pa'i skye ba ni pha rol pos bum pa la sogs pa'i mtshan gzhi las rdzas tha dad du khas blangs la/ de 'dra ba ma grub pas skye ba de rgyu bcas su ma grub ces pa'i don no/ /

As explained before, disintegration is here regarded as destruction, [360] and this is also the way the great Candrakīrti views it, regarding it as a thing. In Prajñāpradīpa, it says, just after the previous discussion, that that which has already disintegrated and which no longer exists does not have a cause, because it is nonexistent, just like something completely nonexistent. This is because in his system, disintegration is not regarded as a thing. Therefore, the statement that even though disintegration is a characteristic of produced phenomena, it does not have a cause is in accordance with the opponents’ assertions, and not with our own system [205a]. The reason why the example to which the phrase “just like arising” refers is unestablished/1/ is explained as follows: To arise is to attain the status of having come into existence from that which previously had come into existence. This means that the arising that is regarded as the characteristic of produced things is maintained by the opponent to be substantially different from such things as pots. Since such arising does not exist, arising is not established as having a cause.

shes rab sgron mar dpe ma grub pa'i sgrub byed du skye ba rdzas su ma grub pa bkod la/ tshig gsal las rdzas su yod pa rnams skye bar grub pa'i phyir zhes phyogs snga blangs pa gnyis mi 'gal te/ snga ma'i don ni sngar bshad pa ltar yin la phyi ma'i don ni pha rol pos skye ba rdzas su 'dod pa'i lugs bzhag pa tsam yin pa'i phyir ro/ / tshig gsal las/ rgyu mtshan des dpe ma grub par 'chad pa mi 'thad pa'i rgyu mtshan du gzugs brnyan la sogs pa rdzas su med pa rnams rgyu dang bcas pa nyid du khas blangs pa'i phyir ro zhes pa ni/ skye ba rdzas yod khegs kyang skye ba rgyu bcas su mi 'grub pa min pa'i rgyu mtshan no/ /

Prajñāpradīpa uses the fact that arising does not exist substantially as a proof that the example is not established. [Ibid.] Prasannapadā, presenting the opponent’s view, as follows: “since the arising of that which is substantially existent…” [134b]./2/ These two positions are not contradictory, because the meaning of the former is as it has been explained above and the meaning of the latter is merely a presentation of the opponent’s position that arising exists substantially. According to Prasannapadā, the reason for the untenability of saying that the example is not established—“you accept that such things as reflections, which do not substantially exist, have causes”[135a]—is that, although the substantial existence of arising has been refuted, it is not the case that it is not established as having a cause.
gnyis pa ['byung ba 'jig pa dang lhan cig yin min dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of becoming being and not being simultaneous with destruction
'byung ba 'jig pa med pa ni/ / ci ltar yod pa nyid du 'gyur/ / dngos po rnams la mi rtag nyid/ / nam yang med pa ma yin no/ /
4. How could there be becoming Without destruction? For things never Lack impermanence.

'byung ba ni 'jig pa med par ni ji lta bur na yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / gal te de ltar yod na dngos po 'jig pa dang bral ba srid dgos na/ dngos po rnams la mi rtag pa nyid nam yang med pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /
How could there be becoming without destruction? There could not. If things existed that way, it would have to be possible for things to be indestructible. But things never lack impermanence. [361]
'byung ba 'jig dang lhan cig tu/ / ci ltar yod pa nyid du 'gyur/ / skye ba 'chi dang dus gcig tu/ / yod pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
5. How could becoming Be simultaneous with destruction? Birth does not occur Simultaneously with death.

'byung ba ni 'jig pa dang lhan cig tu ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis yod pa nyid du 'gyur te mi 'gyur te/ de ltar 'gyur na skye ba 'chi ba dang dus gcig tu 'gyur na de ni yod pa nyid ni ma yin no/ / 'di ni sngar bshad zin to/ /

How could becoming be essentially simultaneous with destruction? It could not, because if that were the case birth would be simultaneous with death and this is not possible. This has already been explained.
gsum pa [de dag gi don bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.1.1.3 Summary of these refutations
gang dag phan tshun lhan cig gam/ / dngos po yod rtsa ba pa ma yin par/ / 'byung ba 'jig pa yod ma yin/ / 'byung ba 'jig pa yod med par ni/ /
6. How can those things which cannot Be established as existing Simultaneously or not simultaneously with each other Exist at all?

gang dag phan tshun du lhan cig pa dus gcig gam phan tshun lhan cig ma yin pa dus mi gcig par grub pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin pa'i 'byung 'jig de dag rang bzhin gyis grub pa ji ltar yod de zhes pa med de/ rang bzhin gyis grub na yod tshul gnyis po de las mi 'da' ba'i phyir ro/ / gal te lhan cig yin min du rang bzhin gyis ma grub kyang de gnyis su brjod du med pa'i tshul gyis grub bo snyam na/ brjod du med par grub pa gang yin gal te de gnyis 'dres pa'o snyam na/ de gnyis sngar so sor ma grub pas 'dres pa med do/ / ci ste brjod du med pa'i don ni blos nges par gzung du med par snyam na/ delta na mo gsham gyi bu'i sngo bsangs dang dkar sham ltar 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis med pas de dag gi rgyu dus kyang rang bzhin gyis med do/ /

How could the nonessentially existent becoming and destruction of those things which can be established neither as simultaneous with each other—that is, as at the same time—nor as not simultaneous with each other—that is, as not at the same time—exist essentially? It could not, because if they existed essentially, they could not escape two alternatives with respect to their mode of existence. Suppose one thought that although they can exist essentially neither simultaneously nor nonsimultaneously, they could exist inexpressibly in these two ways and that that which exists inexpressibly exists in a mixture of these two ways. To this we respond that since these two do not antecedently exist distinctly, there is no way to mix them. Suppose, on the other hand, that one thought that the very meaning of “inexpressible” is that the mind cannot comprehend it. But if this were the case, then just like the blueness or whiteness of the son of a barren woman, since becoming and destruction are not essentially existent, time as their cause is not essentially existent.
gnyis pa ['byung 'jig rten gang la yod brtags la dgag]
1.1.1.2 Refutation through analysis to determine on what basis becoming and destruction could exist
['di] la gsum/ zad ma zad kyi rten la 'byung 'jig dgag / dngos po'i rten la 'byung 'jig dgag / stong mi stong gi rten la 'byung 'jig dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of becoming and destruction whether or not the basis is exhausted, the refutation of becoming and destruction based on things, and the refutation of becoming and destruction whether or not the basis is empty.
dang po [zad ma zad kyi rten la 'byung 'jig dgag] ni/
1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of becoming and destruction whether or not the basis is exhausted
'byung 'jig 'di rang bzhin gyis yod par 'dod na dngos po zad pa'i chos can dang ma zad pa'i chos can gnyis gang la yod/

If one were to maintain that becoming and destruction exist essentially, in which things do they exist, in those that are characterized by exhaustion or in those that are not characterized by exhaustion?
phan tshun lhan cig ma yin par/ / grub pa yod pa ma yin par/ / de ltar grub pa ci ltar yod/ / zad la 'byung ba yod ma yin/ /

7. There is no becoming of that which is exhausted. Nor is there becoming of that which is not exhausted. There is no destruction of that which is exhausted. Nor is there destruction of that which is not exhausted.

de la dngos po zad pa'i chos can la 'byung ba ste skye ba rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te/ rang bzhin gyis grub pa la skye ba dang zad pa gnyis gcig la 'du ba 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / dngos po ma zad pa la'ang 'byung ba rang bzhin gyis med de/ rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i dngos po zad pa ma yin na dngos po'i mtshan nyid 'jig pa dang mi ldan par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / dngos po zad pa la 'jig pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te/ de ni dgag bya'i dngos po de med pa yin la de la 'jig pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa rten par mi rigs pa'i phyir ro/ / dngos po ma zad pa la'ang 'jig pa rang bzhin gyis med de rgyu mtshan sngar bshad pa bzhin no/

Becoming—arising—cannot be present essentially in a thing that is characterized by exhaustion, because it would be contradictory for arising and exhaustion to be co-present in anything that exists essentially. Nor can becoming be present essentially in that which is not exhausted, because if an essentially existent thing were not exhausted, it could not have destruction as the characteristic of a thing. [362] Destruction cannot be present essentially in an exhausted thing, because that is the nonexistence of the object that is to cease. It would not make sense for destruction to exist essentially in such a basis. Nor can destruction be present essentially in a thing that is not exhausted for the reasons presented above.
gnyis pa [dngos po'i rten la 'byung 'jig dgag] ni/
1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of becoming and destruction based on things
'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod de dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'i phyi ra da nga de ni de gnyis kyi rten yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose someone said that becoming and destruction exist essentially because things exist essentially, and things are the bases of these two.
ma zad pa la'ang 'byung ba med/ / zad la 'jig pa yod ma yin/ / ma zad pa la'ang 'jig pa med/ / dngos po yod pa ma yin no/ /
8. Without the existence of things, There is neither becoming nor destruction. Without becoming and destruction, There is no existence of things.

dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin par 'byung ba dang 'jig pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin no/ / dngos po rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rgyu mtshan ni 'di ltar 'byung ba dang 'jig pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ni sngar bkag zin la de gnyis med par ni/ dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te de gnyis ni dngos po'i mtshan nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / shes rab sgron mar ni yod pa min pa ni dngos po'i chos ma yin te sbal pa'i ze ba bzhin no/ / 'byung 'jig ni dngos po'i chos yin pas bden par yod do zhes pa'i lan du 'byung 'jig don dam par med par ni dngos po don dam par yod pa min te dngos po ni 'byung 'jig gi bdag nyid can yin pa'i phyir gtan tshigs ma grub bo/ / de bzhin du dngos po yod pa ma yin par te rten med pas rten pa 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yang yod pa min no zhes phyed gong ma 'og mar byas nas bshad do// /

Without the essential existence of things, becoming and destruction cannot exist inherently. The reason that things do not exist essentially is as follows: We have previously refuted the essential existence of becoming and destruction. Without these two, things cannot exist essentially, because these two are the characteristics of things. Some say that nonexistence cannot be the characteristic of a thing because it would be like the mane of a frog! Since becoming and destruction are the characteristics of things they truly exist. In response to this, Prajñāpradīpa says that without the ultimate existence of becoming and destruction things would not exist ultimately/3/, because a thing has the nature of becoming and destruction. So the premise is not established./4/ [206a–206b] Similarly, without the existence of things—that is, without the basis—the becoming and destruction that are based on them cannot exist. Thus Bhāvaviveka explains this by reading the first two lines after the second two.
gsum pa [stong mi stong gi rten la 'byung 'jig dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.3 Refutation of becoming and destruction whether or not the basis is empty
'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod na ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong pa la brten nam mi stong pa la brten pa rtag grang /
If becoming and destruction exist essentially, are they based on that which is inherently empty or on that which is inherently nonempty?
stong las 'byung dang 'jig pa dag / 'thad pa nyid ni ma yin no/ / mi stong pa la'ang 'byung 'jig dag / 'thad pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
9. It is not tenable for the empty To become or to be destroyed. Nor is it tenable for the nonempty To become or to be destroyed.

de la rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pa la 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'thad pa nyid ni ma yin te rten med pa'i phyir nam mkha'i me tog bzhin no/ / rang gi mtshan nyid kyis yod pas mi stong pa la'ang 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag yod pa 'thad pa ni ma yin te/ / mi stong pa ni 'byung 'jig mi rung bas de'i rten tu med pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not tenable for that which is empty of essential existence to have essentially existent becoming and destruction, because there would be no basis, just like a sky flower. Nor is it tenable that there is becoming and destruction of that which is not empty of existence through its own characteristics, because [363] it is impossible for the nonempty to become or to be destroyed. Therefore, it cannot be a basis for such things.
gsum pa ['byung 'jig gcig dang tha dad brtags la dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.3 Refutation through examination of whether becoming and destruction are identical or different
'byung ba dag ni 'jig pa dag/ / gcig pa nyid ni mi 'thad do/ / 'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag/ / gzhan pa nyid du'ang mi 'thad do/ /
10. It is not tenable That destruction and becoming are identical. Nor is it tenable That destruction and becoming are different.

'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod na yod tshul gnyis las mi 'da' la de yang 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag ngo bo nyid kyis gcig tuyod pa nyid ni mi 'thad de/ snang mun ltar phan tshun 'gal ba ni gcig tu mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du yod pa nyid du yang mi 'thad de/ rang mtshan gyis gzhan du grub na 'brel med du thal bar 'gyur la de gnyis ni phan tshun mi 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ /

If becoming and destruction existed essentially, they could not escape two alternatives with respect to their mode of existence: The inherent identity of becoming and destruction is not tenable because, just like light and darkness, it is impossible for that which is mutually exclusive to be identical. Nor is the inherent difference of becoming and destruction tenable, because if they were different through their own characteristics, then, without any relation, they would be unconnected, but these two are inextricably related to each other.
gnyis pa ['byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed de dgag pa]
1.1.2 Refutation of the argument that becoming and destruction exist essentially
['di] la gnyis/ mthong ba sgrub byed min pa dang / de'i sgrub byed bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: showing that that they are observed is not an argument for the claim and the presentation of an argument for the conclusion.
dang po [mthong ba sgrub byed min pa] ni/
1.1.2.1 Showing that that they are observed is not an argument for the claim
ci ste zhib mor dpyad pa 'dis ci bya ste ba lang rdzi dang bud med yan chad kyis 'byung 'jig rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par mthong ba'i phyir/ de gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: What is the use of these detailed analyses? Even herdsmen and women can see that becoming and destruction exist through their own characteristics! So these two exist essentially.
'byung ba dag ni 'jig pa dag / mthong ngo snyam du khyod sems na/ / 'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / gti mug nyid kyis mthong ba yin/ /
11. If you think you see both Destruction and becoming, Then you see destruction and becoming In virtue of confusion.

gal te 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag ngo bo nyid kyis grub par mthong ngo snyam du khyod de ltar sems na/ rgyu mtshan des 'byung 'jig rang mtshan gyis yod par sgrub pa ni ma nges te/ ba lang rdzi dang bud med yan chad kyis ni dri za'i grong khyer dang sgyu ma la sogs pa mthong zhing rab rib can gyis skra shad dang sbrang ma la sogs pa mthong ba bzhin du/ 'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag ngo bo nyid kyis grub par snang ba yang gti mug dang des bslad pa nyid kyis mthong ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Even if you think that you see becoming and destruction both existing inherently in this way, this argument does not entail the existence of becoming and destruction through their own characteristics. This is because herdsmen and women even see cities of gandharvas and illusions and people with cataracts see such things as hairs and flies! The inherent existence of becoming and destruction is seen in virtue of confusion.
gnyis pa [de'i sgrub byed bstan pa]
1.1.2.2 Presentation of an argument for that claim
['di] la gnyis/ 'byung 'jig rang dang rigs mthun mi mthun las skye ba dgag / dngos po rang dang gzhan las skye ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of becoming and destruction arising from that which is of a homogeneous or heterogeneous kind and the refutation of things arising from self or other.
dang po ['byung 'jig rang dang rigs mthun mi mthun las skye ba dgag] ni/
1.1.2.2.1 Refutation of becoming and destruction arising from that which is of a homogeneous or heterogeneous kind
ci ste 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis grub par snang ba 'di gti mug gis bslad pas mthong bar cis grub ce na 'di ni rigs pa las so/ / rigs pa gang zhe na/

Now suppose one argued as follows: How is it established that the apparent arising of becoming and destruction are seen to be inherently existent due to pollution by ignorance? This is established through reasoning! What is that reasoning?
dngos po dngos las mi skye ste/ / dngos po dngos med las mi skye/ / dngos med dngos med mi skye ste/ / dngos med dngos las mi skye'o/ /
12. A thing does not arise from a thing. A thing does not arise from a non-thing. A non-thing does not arise from a non-thing. A non-thing does not arise from a thing.

'dir 'byung ba rang bzhin gyis yod na dngos po ste skye ba'am dngos po med pa ste 'jig pa las skye dgos la 'jig pa rang bzhin gyis yod na'ang de ltar skye dgos so/ / re zhig dngos po ste 'byung ba ni dngos po ste 'byung ba rigs 'dra las ngo bo nyid kyis mi skye ste de ltar skye na rgyu 'bras gnyis dus gcig pa dang skyes zin slar yang skye dgos na de gnyis kyang mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / dngos po ste skye ba ni dngos po med pa ste 'jig pa las ngo bo nyid kyis mi skye ste rang bzhin gyis grub pa ltar na 'jig pa'i tshe zhig dgos pas 'jig rgyu'i dngos po log pa las skye na mo gsham gyi bu mos kyang bu skyed par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / dngos po med pa ste 'jig pa ni dngos po med pa 'jig pa las rang bzhin gyis mi skye ste 'jig rgyu'i dngos po log pa la ni 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis skyed pa'i nus pa med pa'i phyir dang zhig pas zhig pa ngo bo nyid kyis skyed na mo gsham gyi bu mos kyang bu skyed par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Here, if becoming existed essentially, then it would have to arise either from a thing—that is, an arisen—or from a non-thing—that is, something destroyed. [364] And if destruction existed essentially, it would have to arise in the same way. A thing—that which has become—does not arise inherently from a thing of the same kind—that which has become—because if it did arise like that, cause and effect would be simultaneous and there would be an additional arising, and these two things are impossible. A thing—an arisen—does not arise inherently from a non-thing—that which is destroyed. According to those who take things to be essentially existent, when something is destroyed, it is disintegrated. So, according to them, since a thing can arise from a nonexistent destroyed thing, the daughter of a barren woman could bear a son! A non-thing—that which is destroyed—does not arise essentially from a non-thing that is a destroyed thing. This is because the disintegrated state of a nonexistent thing does not have the power to give rise essentially to an effect. And if a disintegration gave rise inherently to another disintegration, then the barren woman’s daughter could bear another son!

dngos po med pa ste 'jig pa ni dngos po ste 'byung ba las ngo bo nyid kyis mi skye ste de ltar skye na ni ma zhig pa'i dngos pos rang dang mi mthun pa'i zhig pa skyed pa bzhin du sgron me las kyang mun pa skye bar thal bas so/ / de lta bu'i tshul gyis dpyad na 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis med pas de gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod par mthong ba ni gti mug gis bslad nas mthong ba'o/ / yang na 'byung 'jig rang bzhin gyis yod na dngos po'am dngos med la brten par 'gyur ba zhig na de gnyis ni dpyad pa na rang bzhin gyis med pas rten med pas 'byung 'jig ga la yod de'i phyir de gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod par mthong ba gti mug gis bslad pas mthong ba'o// // dngos po yod med rang bzhin gyis med par ni/ dngos po dngos las mi skye ste/ / zhes sogs kyis bshad do zhes tshig gsal las bshad pa ni bud d+ha pA li ta las bshad pa'o/ /

A non-thing—that which is destroyed—does not arise inherently from a thing—that which has become—because if it did arise like that then a nondisintegrated thing would give rise inherently to a disintegration that is heterogeneous to it. This would be just like the absurd situation of darkness arising from a lamp. Through this kind of analysis one can see that to see becoming and destruction—neither of which is essentially existent—as essentially existent is to be polluted by confusion. There is an alternative reading: If becoming and destruction existed essentially, they would have to be based either on things or on non-things. However, since on analysis these two things do not exist essentially, without any basis, where could becoming and destruction be? Therefore, to see these two as having essences is to see them polluted by confusion. Prasannapadā’s explanation that the essencelessness of things and non-things is explained by “a thing does not arise from a thing [138a]” follows Buddhapālita’s explanation [258a].
gnyis pa [dngos po rang dang gzhan las skye ba dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2.2 Refutation of things arising from self or other

gzhan yang dngos po 'ga' zhig rang bzhin gyis yod na 'byung 'jig kyang rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur na'ang de ni med de rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa'i phyir ro/ / rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa nyid ma grub bo zhe na/

[365] On the other hand, someone might argue as follows: if anything existed essentially, becoming and destruction would also exist essentially. But this is not the case, because things do not arise essentially. But essential non-arising does not exist.
dngos po bdag las mi skye ste/ / gzhan las skye ba nyid ma yin/ / bdag dang gzhan las skye ba ni/ / yod na ji ltar skye bar 'gyur/ /
13. Things do not arise from themselves. Nor do they arise from others. Since they arise neither from self nor from another, How can they arise?

ma grub pa ma yin te 'di ltar dngos po bdag las mi skye ste gzhan las skye ba nyid kyang yod pa ma yin la/ bdag dang gzhan gnyis ka las kyang skye ba ni yod pa min pas ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis skye bar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro// 'di ni rab byed dang por bshad zin to/ /

It is not nonexistent because things do not arise from themselves; they do not arise from others; and since they do not arise from both self and other, how could they arise essentially? They could not! This has been explained in the first chapter.
gnyis pa [skye 'jig rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dod na rtag chad kyi skyon bstan pa]
1.2 Showing that the errors of nihilism and reification follow from maintaining the essential existence of arising and destruction
['di] la gsum/ dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par khas blangs na rtag chad du 'gyur tshul/ de ltar khas blangs kyang skyon de spong ba'i lan dgag pa/ de ltar bkag pa'i don bsdu ba'o/ //

This section has three parts: how reification and nihilism follow from asserting that things exist essentially, refuting the rebuttal and still maintaining those assertions, and the summary of the point of that refutation.
dang po [dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par khas blangs na rtag chad du 'gyur tshul] ni/
1.2.1 How reification and nihilism follow from asserting that things exist essentially
dngos po yod par khas blangs na/ / rtag dang chad par lta bar ni/ / thal bar 'gyur te dngos de ni/ / rtag dang mi rtag 'gyur phyir ro/ /
14. If one accepts the existence of entities, Reificationism and nihilism will follow. For these entities Would have to be both permanent and impermanent.

dngos po rang bzhin gyis skye ba rnam pa thams cad du med do zhes pa 'di ni de ltar gdon mi za bar khas blang bar bya'o/ / de lta min par dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod par khas blangs na gsung rab dang shin tu 'gal ba'i rtag pa dang chad par lta bar ni thal bar 'gyur te/ gang gi phyir dngos po de ni rtag par smra na rtag par lta bar 'gyur la mi rtag par smra na ni nges par te chad par lta bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

One must accept without any reservation that nothing is essentially arisen. If, instead, one asserted that things exist essentially, then one would, contradicting the scriptures, end up with the view of reification or that of nihilism. This is because if one were to say that the things are permanent, one would become a reificationist; and if one were to say that the things are impermanent, one would become a nihilist.

'di ni/ gang zhig rang bzhin gyis yod pa/ / de ni med pa min pas rtag / ces pa'i skabs su bshad pa bzhin du rang bzhin gyis grub pa de nam yang med par mi 'gyur bas rtag lta dang / rang bzhin gyis grub pa dus dang por yod la gnyis par med na chad ltar 'gyur gyi yod pa tsam dang skad cig gis 'jig pa khas blangs pas rtag chad du lta bar ston pa min te/ rtag chad ni rten 'brel khas blangs nas spong la rten 'brel gsung ba na 'di yod na 'di 'byung zhes gsungs pa'i phyir dang / brgya pa'i 'grel pa las kyang / ci chos mngon pa skad cig mar 'jig pa khas mi len nam gal te khas mi len na ni/ de bde bar gshegs pa ma yin pa nyid du 'gyur ro zhes skad cig ma khas mi len na nang pa sangs rgyas pa min par thal ba'i gnod pa gsungs pas so/ /

This has already been explained in the context of “Whatever exists essentially, Cannot be nonexistent” is reification. “It existed before, but doesn’t now” Entails the error of nihilism. [XV: 11]/5/ Thus, to assert that things exist essentially is to assert that they never become nonexistent and is hence reificationism; to assert that while things exist essentially at the first moment they do not exist at all at the second moment is hence nihilism. However, this does not mean that to accept mere existence and momentary impermanence is to succumb to the views of reificationism and nihilism. This is because reificationism and nihilism are abandoned by accepting dependent origination. When teaching dependent origination, it is said, “When this exists, that arises.” As the commentary to Catuḥśataka says, [366] Abhidhārmikas, don’t you accept momentary impermanence? If you do not accept it, then you are not followers of the Sugata! Thus if one does not accept momentariness, it would follow that one is not a Buddhist. [dBu ma ya 180a]
gnyis pa [de ltar khas blangs kyang skyon de spong ba'i lan dgag pa]
1.2.2 Refuting the rebuttal while still maintaining those assertions
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gyis grub pa khas blangs nas rtag chad spong tshul dang / de dgag pa'i lan no/ /
This section has two parts: the way reification and nihilism are rebutted while maintaining that things exist essentially and its refutation.
dang po [rang bzhin gyis grub pa khas blangs nas rtag chad spong tshul] ni/
1.2.2.1 The way reification and nihilism are rebutted while maintaining that things exist essentially
dngos po yod par khas blangs kyang / / chad par mi 'gyur rtag mi 'gyur/ / 'bras bu rgyu yi 'byung 'jig gi / rgyun de srid pa yin phyir ro/ /
15. Even if one accepts the existence of things, Nihilism and reification will not follow. Cyclic existence is the continuous Becoming and destruction of causes and effects.

dngos po rang gi mtshan nyid kyis yod par khas blangs kyang chad par lta ba dang rtag par lta bar mi 'gyur te/ gang gi phyir 'bras bu'i 'byung ba ste skyes pa dang rgyu yi 'jig pa ste zhig pa gnyis rgyun ldan du 'byung ba'i rgyun de srid pa 'khor ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar rgyu 'gags nas de'i 'bras bu mi skye na chad pa dang rgyu mi 'gag par rang gi ngo bos gnas na rtag par 'gyur yang de ltar mi 'dod pas rtag chad kyi skyon med do zhe na/

Here the reificationists argue as follows: Even though we accept the essential existence of things, we do not thereby become reificationists and nihilists. This is because the continuum of the continuous becoming of effects—that is, their arising—and destruction of causes—that is, their disintegration—is cyclic existence. If one said that after the cessation of the cause the effect did not arise, that would be nihilism; and if one said that without the cessation of the cause it maintains its own identity, that would be reification. However, since we do not accept these views, we do not succumb to the errors of reification and nihilism.
gnyis pa [de dgag pa'i lan]
1.2.2.2 Its refutation
['di] la gnyis/ rgyun khas blangs kyang rtag chad spong mi nus pa dang*/ rgyun nyid rang bzhin gyis ma grub par bstan pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: showing that even though they accept a continuum, they cannot avoid reification and nihilism and showing that the continuum itself does not exist essentially.
dang po [rgyun khas blangs kyang rtag chad spong mi nus pa] ni/
1.2.2.2.1 Showing that even though they accept a continuum, they cannot avoid reification and nihilism
gal te 'bras rgyu'i 'byung 'jig gi / rgyu de srid pa yin gyur na/ / 'jig la yang skye med pa'i phyir/ / rgyu ni chad par thal bar 'gyur/ /
16. If cyclic existence were the continuous Becoming and destruction of causes and effects, Since that which is destroyed does not arise again, Causes would, absurdly, be annihilated.

'bras bu'i 'byung ba dang rgyu yi 'jig pa'i rgyun de srid pa yin par gyur na rgyu'i skad cig 'jig pa ste 'bras bu skyed pa'i bya ba byas nas 'gags pa la slar yang skye ba med pa'i phyir rgyu'i rgyun ni chad par thal bar 'gyur ro/ / dngos po rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par 'dod na 'bras bu rgyu la mi ltos pa'i gzhan du 'gyur bas/ 'bras bu skyes kyang rgyu'i rgyun mi 'chad pa la mi phan la rgyu 'gags pa slar yang skye ba'i rgyun med pas rgyu'i rgyun chad par 'gyur ro/ // rang la nyes pa de med de dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par khas mi len pa'i phyir dang / gang la brten te gang 'byung ba/ / zhes pa'i tshul gyis brten nas 'byung ba'i rgyu mtshan nyid kyis rgyu 'bras gnyis rang gi ngo bos gcig dang tha dad gang du yang ma grub par 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Suppose cyclic existence were the continuous becoming of causes and the destruction of effects. Then, since for causes that are destroyed every moment—that is, ones that cease after having given rise to their effects—there is no further arising, nihilism about the continuum of causes would absurdly follow. If one asserted that things exist through their own characteristics, then effects would be irrelevant to and distinct from their causes. Therefore, although the effects arise, this would not save the continuum of causes from annihilation. Without a continuum of causes that arise again after having ceased, the continuum of causes would be annihilated. We do not have this problem, because we not assert that things exist essentially. And through this principle—“Whatever comes into being dependent on another [XVIII: 10a]”—just on the grounds of arising, we assert that cause and effect are neither inherently identical to nor different from one another. [367]
dngos po ngo bo nyid yod na/ / dngos med 'gyur bar mi rigs so/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i dus na chad/ / srid rgyun rab tu zhi phyir ro/ /
17. If things existed inherently, Then their nonexistence would make no sense. At the time of nirvana, because it is complete pacification, The continuum of cyclic existence would be annihilated.

dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par khas len pa la rtag ltar yang 'gyur te/ dngos po ngo bo nyid kyis yod na ni phyis med par mi 'gyur te rang bzhin la ldog pa med pa'i phyir de'i rtag par thal ba so na 'dug go / rigs pa de dag ni dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod na 'bras bu rgyu snga ma las skye ba dang rgyu 'bras bu'i dus su 'gags pa mi rung bas de gnyis kyi sgo nas rtag chad spong mi nus pa'o/

Someone who asserts that things exist essentially will end up as a reificationist, because if things existed inherently they could not become nonexistent later. This is because their essence would be unchangeable. Therefore, one still cannot avoid the absurd position of reificationism. These arguments show that if things existed essentially, then it would not be tenable for an effect to arise from a previous cause, nor would the cause cease at the time the effect occurs. Therefore, these two absurdities show that reificationism and nihilism cannot be avoided.

gzhan yang khyed ltar na phung po lhag med kyi mya ngan las 'das pa'i dus na/ srid pa ste phung po'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis 'jug pa rab tu zhi ba ste chad pas chad par thal bar 'gyur na ston pas chad lta ni spong bar gsungs so/ / gal te de 'dra ba'i rgyun chad par 'dzin pa ni chad lta min no zhe na/ de lta na 'khor ba'i skabs su yang de ltar 'dzin pa chad lta min par 'gyur te rgyu mtshan mtshungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, according to your view, at the time of attaining nirvana with no residual aggregates, cyclic existence—that is, the essentially proceeding continuum of the aggregates—would be completely pacified—that is, annihilated. Therefore, the absurd consequence of nihilism would follow, but the teacher has said that one should abandon nihilism. Here, suppose someone said that maintaining this kind of termination of the continuum is not the view of nihilism. To this we reply, by parity of reasoning, that if that were the case, then even in the context of cyclic existence holding such a view would not be nihilism.
gnyis pa [rgyun nyid rang bzhin gyis ma grub par bstan pa] ni/
1.2.2.2.2 Showing that the continuum itself does not exist essentially
pha rol pos sngar ltar bshad pa'i srid pa'i rgyun de rang bzhin gyis yod pa ni mi 'thad do/ / ji ltar zhe na/
It is not tenable that the continuum as presented by the opponent could exist essentially. How does this go?
tha ma 'gags par gyur pa na/ / srid pa dang po rigs mi 'gyur/ / tha ma 'gags par ma gyur tshe/ / srid pa dang po rigs mi 'gyur/ /
18. If the final moment were to cease, The first moment of life would make no sense. If the final moment were not to cease, The first moment of life would make no sense.

'dir srid pa tha ma ni tshe 'di'i sems tha ma 'chi srid yin la srid pa dang po ni skye ba phyi ma'i nying mtshams sbyor ba'i sems so/ / de'i tha ma 'gag bzhin pa ni rgyur gnas la dang po ni 'bras bur gnas shing srid pa de gnyis la ni 'khor ba zhes bya'o/ / de la srid pa dang po de srid pa tha ma 'gags pa'am ma 'gags pa'am 'gag bzhin pa las skye grang / de la srid pa tha ma 'gags par gyur pa na de las srid pa dang po'i sems skye bar rigs par mi 'gyur te/ rang gi rgyu rang gi snga rol du 'gags na de'i tshe rgyu med pa dang */ sa bon tshig pa las kyang myu gu skye bar 'gyur na de ni 'dod pa yang min no//srid pa tha ma 'gags par ma gyur pa'i tshe zhes pa ni 'gag bzhin pa logs su bshad pas 'chi srid 'gag pa la mngon du ma phyogs pa'o/ / 'di 'dra med kyang brtag pa'i mtha' bzung nas 'gog pa'o/ / de las srid pa dang po skye ba rigs par mi 'gyur te 'gyur na ni nyes pa du ma yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

In this context, the end of life is the final mental state of this life—the state of death. The first moment of life is the entry of consciousness into the embryo. The final moment of that life—that is, its being in the process of ceasing—is already present in the cause; the first moment is in the effect. These two states are called “cyclic existence.” So does that first moment of life arise from that which has finally ceased, from that which has not yet finally ceased, or from that which is in the process of finally ceasing? It does not make sense that when the final moment of life has ceased, the mental states of the first moment of life arise from it. This is because if its cause ceased prior to its occurrence, it would be causeless at the time of its occurrence, and a sprout could arise even from a roasted seed. But nobody maintains that! When “If the final moment were to cease” refers—to the state of dying, which is not about to cease, because the state of dying, which is in the process of cessation, is mentioned separately. [368] There is no such thing, but it is refuted hypothetically. It does not make sense that the first moment of life arises from that, because to say that it did would be to commit many errors./6/

de la rgyu med pa'i nyes pa ni 'chi srid 'gag pa la mngon du ma phyogs pa'i dus su skye ba phyi ma'i sems dang po skye na de gnyis dus gcig tu gnas par 'gyur la de lta na rgyus mi skyed pa'o/ / sems can gcig la ngo bo gnyis yod pa ni tshe 'di'i sems tha ma dang phyi ma'i sems dang po gnyis dus gcig tu yod pa'o/ / sngon med pa'i sems can 'byung ba ni skye bzhin pa'i sems can de'i sngon du rang gi rgyur gyur pa'i sems can sngon du ma song ba'o/ / sems snga ma rtag pa'i nyes pa ni rgyud gcig pa'i sems phyi ma byung gi bar du snga ma gnas pa'o/ / sa bon ma zhig pa las myu gu skye bar 'gyur ba'i skyon gsungs pa ni sa bon rnam par ma 'gyur ba'i skabs su myu gu skyes pa'o/ /

One would commit the error of saying it is causeless by saying that the first mental state of the succeeding life arises when the state of dying is not about to cease, and these two exist simultaneously. In that case the cause would not give rise to it. One would commit the error of saying that a single sentient being is two entities by saying that the final mental state of this life is simultaneous with the first mental state of the next life. One would commit the error of saying that a sentient being comes into existence de novo by saying that prior to that sentient being arising, there is no previous sentient being as its cause. One would commit the error of saying that the previous mental state is permanent by saying that the previous mental state of the continuum endures until the subsequent mental state of that very continuum arises. The error of saying that a sprout could arise from a seed that has not disintegrated [Prasannapadā 139b] means that a sprout would be able to arise from a seed that has not transformed.
gal te tha ma 'gag bzhin na/ / dang po skye bar 'gyur na ni/ / 'gag bzhin pa ni cig 'gyur zhing / / skye bzhin pa yang gzhan du 'gyur/ /
19. If the final moment were ceasing And the prior one were arising, The one ceasing would be one, and The one arising would be another.

gal te srid pa tha ma 'gag bzhin pa ste 'gag pa la mngon du phyogs pa'i dus na skye ba phyi ma'i dang po'i sems rang bzhin gyis skye bar 'gyur na ni/ sems can gcig la srid pa mi mthun pa gnyis sa ci ga ca ra du yo da pa ra 'gyur te mi lta bu shi nas lhar skye ba yin na/ 'gag bzhin pa mi'i srid pa ni gcig tu 'gyur zhing skye bzhin pa lha'i bar do'i srid pa yang srid pa gzhan gcig tu 'gyur la/rang mtshan gyis skye na rgyu 'gag bzhin pa'i dus su skye bzhin pa'i 'bras bu yod par sngar bstan pa'i phyir ro/ /

If when the final state of life is in the process of cessation—that is, when it is about to cease—the first mental state of the succeeding life arose essentially, a single sentient being would simultaneously have two heterogeneous lives. This is because, for instance, when a human being dies and is reborn as a god, the ceasing human life is one life, and the arising divine intermediate state of life is another life. If it arose through its own characteristic, then the arising effect would exist at the time when the cause is ceasing, as has been previously shown.
gsum pa [de ltar bkag pa'i don bsdu ba] ni/
1.2.3 Summary of the point of that refutation
gal te 'gag bzhin skye bzhin dag / lhan cig tu yang rigs min na/ / phung po gang la 'chi 'gyur ba/ / de la skye ba'ang 'byung 'gyur ram/ /
20. It does not even make sense that the one arising And the one ceasing are simultaneous. Whoever is dying with respect to the aggregates Would also be arising with respect to them.

de ltar sngar bshad pa'i tshul gyis gal te 'gag bzhin pa'i 'gag pa po dang skye bzhin pa'i skye ba po dag lhan cig dus gcig tu rigs pa min la/ yang gi sgras bsdus pa srid pa tha ma 'gags pa dang 'gag pa la mngon du ma phyogs pa'i ma 'gags pa las bar 'gyur ba'i phung po de dag nyid la skye ba rang bzhin gyis 'byung bar 'gyur ram ste mi 'gyur te skye bzhin pa'i dus na 'chi bzhin par ni shin tu srid pa dang po skye ba rigs pa min na/ de ci phung po gang la gnas nas 'chi 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ //

So, through the approach that has been explained above, the simultaneous existence of the agent of the cessation of that which is in the process of ceasing and the agent of the arising of that which is in the process of arising does not make sense. “Even” indicates that it does not make sense for the first moment of life to arise either from the ceased final state of life, nor from that which is about to cease but which has not ceased. [369] So does birth occur essentially with respect to those very aggregates with respect to which one dies? It does not, because it would be absolutely inconsistent for something to be dying at the same time that it is being born.
de ltar dus gsum dag tu yang / / srid pa'i rgyun ni mi rigs na/ / dus gsum dag tu gang med pa/ / de ni ci ltar srid pa'i rgyun/ /
21. Since the continuum of life makes no sense In terms of any of the three temporal periods, How could that which does not exist in the three temporal periods Be the continuum of life?

de ltar srid pa tha ma 'gags pa dang ma 'gags pa dang 'gag bzhin pa'i dus gsum dag tu yang srid pa dang po skye ba'i srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis yod pa ni mi rigs na/ gang zhig dus gsum du rang bzhin gyis yod pa min pa de ni ji ltar na bdag nyid gzhan gyis yod par ga la 'gyur/ de'i phyir srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis med pas/ 'bras bu rgyu'i 'byung 'jig gi rgyun de srid pa yin phyir ro/ / zhes srid rgyun Rang bzhin gyis yod par smras pa de mi rigs so/ /

It does not make sense that the continuum following from the first moment of life—the state of birth—exists essentially in any of the three temporal periods: neither in the final moment of life that has ceased, nor in that which has not yet ceased, nor in that which is ceasing. So how could that which does not make sense in terms of the three temporal periods make sense in terms of something else? Therefore, since the continuum of life is essenceless, the statement that since “life is the continuous becoming and destruction of causes and effects [16ab]” the continuum of life exists essentially makes no sense.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar skye 'jig dang skye shi dang srid pa gcig nas gcig tu 'gro 'ong byed pa rang bzhin med par bshad pa 'di nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / de ltar gsungs pa'i mdo sde thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bshad pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ ting 'dzin rgyal po las/ srid gsum rmi lam dang 'dra snying po med/ / myur du 'jig cing mi rtag sgyu ma bzhin//'ong ba med cing 'di nas 'gro ba'ang med/ / rgyun rnams rtag tu stong zhing mtshan ma med/ / ces dang / skye ba dang ni 'chi 'gyur yang / / skye ba med cing 'chi med par/ / gang gis shes par 'gyur ba yis/ / ting 'dzin 'di ni rnyed mi dga'/ / zhes dang*/ gang dag bsam yas chos rnams 'di shes pa/ / mi rnams de dag rtag tu bde ba yin/ / chos dang chos min rnam rtog med pa ste/ / thams cad sems kyis spros pas phye ba yin/ // thams cad bsam yas thams cad 'byung min pas / dngos dang dngos med shes pa rnam par shig / byis pa gang dag sems kyi dbang song ba/ / de dag srid pa bye ba brgyar sdug bsngal/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the explanation of arising and destruction, birth and death, and going from one life to another as empty of inherent existence can also be corroborated by profound scriptures, and to demonstrate that, all of the sūtras that address this issue are explained by this chapter. The Samādhirāja-sūtra says: The three realms, like a dream, are insubstantial; Quickly destroyed, impermanent and illusory; Neither having come here; nor going from here, Continua are perpetually empty and without representation. And then Although there is birth and death, For he who knows that Things are birthless and deathless Samādhi is not difficult to attain. [mDo de da 45b]/7/ And it is said, Whoever knows the inconceivable phenomena— These people will be always blissful, Without conceptualizing good or evil; These all are revealed to be mental fabrications. Since everything is inconceivable and nothing comes into being, [370] Knowledge of things and non-things is destroyed. Any fool who is overpowered by the mind Will suffer for a billion lives. [Upāliparipṛcchā-sūtra, dkon brtsegs ca 128b]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

skye 'jig dang skye 'chi gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i srid rgyun rnams rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa la 'jog pa ni de kho nar grub ma grub dpyod pa'i rigs pas bkag la/ tha snyad de dag mi byar yang mi rung bas rang gi mtshan nyid kyis stong pa la de rnams ches 'thad pa'i tshul la nges pa drang bar bya'o/ /

Arising and destruction, birth and death, and the continuum of life which uninterruptedly goes from one life to another are regarded as existing through their own characteristic; but rational analysis into whether or not they exist in reality has refuted this. One cannot work without these conventions; therefore, one should be led to ascertain the way in which they are completely tenable in the context of their emptiness of their own characteristics.
'byung ba dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gcig pa'o/ /
This is the twenty-first chapter, called the “examination of becoming and destruction.”
'byung ba dang 'jig pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa nyer gcig gi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa gcig pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-first chapter, having twenty-one verses, called the “examination of becoming and destruction.”
CHAPTER XXII. Examination of the Tathāgata
lnga pa srid pa'i rgyun gyi rang bzhin gyis stong par bstan pa
We now begin the fifth section of the extensive explanation of selflessness: the presentation of the essential emptiness of the continuum of life.
['di] la gnyis/ de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / nyon mongs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the Tathāgata; and the refutation of the essential existence of the afflictions.
dang po [de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
This chapter constitutes the first of those two parts.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citation from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ srid pa'i rgyun ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di na bcom ldan 'das bskal pa grangs med pa gsum mam bdun du bar ma chad par tshogs rgya chen po sems can gyi don du bsags nas dus ring mo zhig gis sangs rgyas pa yin la srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis med na de bzhin gshegs pa yod par mi 'gyur te/ srid pa'i skye ba du ma brgyud pa la brten nas 'tshang rgya dgos pa'i phyir ro//gang gi ma rig pa'i mun pa 'thug po rigs pa'i snang ba sna tshogs pas bzlog kyang shin tu yun ring mo nas goms pas/ da dung du yang mi ldog pa khyod mi shes pa shin tu che ba 'di nyid kyis srid pa'i rgyun mi 'chad par ches ring ba go bar byed do/ / gal te de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod na srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis yod na'ang de rang bzhin gyis med do/ / 'di la bzhi/ de bzhin gshegs pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa dgag / de la log lta gzhan gyi'ang gnas med par bstan pa/ log par bzung ba'i nyes dmigs bstan pa/ rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba'o/ /

Here some say that the continuum of life exists essentially because the Tathāgata exists essentially. The Victor, for the benefit of sentient beings, accumulated vast merits for either three or seven countless aeons and attained buddhahood through these long efforts. If the continuum of his life had not existed essentially, the Tathāgata could not exist, because the attainment of buddhahood depends on going through many births in cyclic existence. Efforts have been made through the various lights of reason to dispel the deep darkness of your ignorance. But, because you have been habituated to it for a very long time it has not been dispelled. This shows that because your deep ignorance has not been dispelled, the continuum of cyclic existence has not been terminated [371] and instead has been prolonged. If the Tathāgata existed essentially, the continuum of cyclic existence would exist essentially as well, but he does not. This discussion has four parts: the refutation of the existence of the Tathāgata through his own characteristic, showing that there is no room for others’ false views, the presentation of the deficiencies of those false views, and applying arguments to those other views.
dang po [de bzhin gshegs pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the existence of the Tathāgata through his own characteristic
['di] la gsum/ len pa po rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / blang bya rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / de gnyis ka'i mjug bsdu ba'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the appropriator, the refutation of the inherent existence of that which is appropriated, and drawing conclusions from these two.
dang po [len pa po rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the appropriator
['di] la gsum/ de bzhin gshegs pa rdzas su yod pa dgag / phung po la brten nas btags pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag // de rnams kyi mjug bsdu ba'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the substantial existence of the Tathāgata, the refutation of the essential existence of dependent designations based on the aggregates, and drawing conclusions from these.
dang po [de bzhin gshegs pa rdzas su yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.1.1 Refutation of the substantial existence of the Tathāgata
phung min phung po las gzhan min/ / de la phung med der de med/ / de bzhin gshegs pa phung ldan min/ / de bzhin gshegs pa gang zhig yin/ /
1. Neither the aggregates, nor different from the aggregates, The aggregates are not in him, nor is he in the aggregates. The Tathāgata does not possess the aggregates. What is the Tathāgata?

gal te de bzhin gshegs pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis yod na/ de gzugs dang tshor ba dang 'du shes dang 'du byed dang rnam par shes pa'i phung po dang rang bzhin gyis gcig tu grub pa'am rang bzhin gyis tha dad/ sangs rgyas kyi sar tshul khrims dang ting nge 'dzin dang shes rab dang rnam par grol ba dang rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mthong ba'i phung po lnga yang yod mod kyang / phung po lnga snga ma 'dir gzung gi phyi ma ni min te snga ma ni sems can du gdags pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir dang / phyi ma ni skye 'phags kun la khyab par byed pa min pa'i phyir dang snga ma'i khongs su 'du ba'i phyir ro/ / rang bzhin gyis tha dad na de bzhin gshegs pa la phung po brten pa dang phung po la de bzhin gshegs pa brten pa dang / lhas byin nor dang ldan pa ltar de bzhin gshegs pa phung po dang ldan par 'gyur grang na/ de thams cad 'thad pa ma yin no/ /

If the Tathāgata existed through his own characteristic, then he would have to be either essentially identical to or essentially different from his aggregates: material form, feeling, perception, dispositions, and consciousness. Although in a buddha realm the five aggregates of virtue, samadhi, wisdom, complete liberation, and the wisdom of complete liberation exist, the five aggregates should be taken as the former ones, but not the latter ones. This is because the former ones are the basis for the designation of sentient beings, and the latter ones do not apply both to ordinary and noble beings and are included among the former. If he were essentially different from them, then either the aggregates would depend on the Tathāgata or the Tathāgata would depend on the aggregates; the Tathāgata would possess the aggregates just as Lhejin possesses his wealth. However, none of these are tenable.

'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa ni phung po lnga dang rang gi mtshan nyid kyis gcig min te/ gzhan du na rab byed bcu par bshad pa ltar byed pa po dang las gcig tu 'gyur ba dang / bco brgyad par bshad pa ltar rang mtshan gyis skye ba dang 'jig pa can du 'gyur ro/ / phyi ma 'dod na ni 'jug pa rtsa 'grel du bshad pa ltar nyes pa gsum ste las byed pa'i byed pa po skad cig ma yin pas las kyi 'bras bu'i dus na med pas / rten med pa'i phyir las rnams 'bras bu dang 'brel ba med pa'i phyir las byas pa chud za bar 'gyur ro/ // skad cig snga mas byas pa'i las kyi 'bras bu phyi ma rnams su longs spyod par 'dod na ni/ gzhan gyis bsags pa'i las kyi 'bras bu gzhan gyis longs spyod pas las ma byas pa dang phrad pa'i skyon du 'gyur ro/ / skad cig snga phyi gzhan yin kyang rgyud gcig pas skyon med do zhes kyang smra mi nus te/ rang gi mtshan nyid kyis skad cig so so ba skye na rgyu 'bras mi rung bas rgyud gcig pa mi 'thad pa'i nyes pa sngar brjod pa mi ldog go / ji ltar nga'i lus 'di sngar byung bar gyur to zhes mi dran pa bzhin du nga de'i tshe de'i dus na nga las nu zhes bya bar gyur to zhes kyang gsung bar mi 'gyur te/ de'i dus kyi bdag ni lus ltar zhig pa'i phyir dang 'dir snga ma las rang mtshan gyis gzhan pa'i bdag skye bar khas blangs pa'i phyir ro/

The Tathāgata is not identical to the aggregates through his own characteristics because otherwise [372], as was shown in the tenth chapter, agent and object would be identical; and as we explained in the eighteenth chapter, he would arise and cease through his own characteristic. If one were to maintain that he is, then as the Madhyamakāvatāra and its autocommentary explain [VI: 128, 296b], three problems arise. Since the agent of the action is momentary, at the time the effect of the action occurs it does not exist. Since there would therefore be no basis, there would be no relation between actions and their effects. Therefore, the accumulated karmas would be exhausted. If one were to maintain that one at a later moment enjoys the effect of an action performed at a previous moment, then one would commit the error of saying that one would could encounter the karma of actions one had not performed, because the effect of the action—the karma accumulated by the agent—would be enjoyed by someone else. Nor can one say that this error is not committed because, although the previous and later moments are different, there is only a single continuum. This is because if each of the moments arose distinctly through its own characteristic, cause and effect would not be possible. Thus the error mentioned previously concerning the untenability of a single continuum cannot be avoided. Just as we do not remember “my body came into being long ago,” the Tathāgata would not be able to say, “In that life I was Ngalenu.” This is because the self that existed then would have disintegrated, just like the body, and in this context the opponent accepts that a self that is different through its own characteristic from that previous one has arisen.

de bzhin gshegs pa phung po lnga las rang mtshan gyis gzhan pa min te/ gzhan du na bcu par bshad pa ltar phung po med par yang 'byung ba dang*/ bco brgyad par bshad pa ltar phung po 'dus byas su mtshon pa'i mtshan nyid dam phung po so so'i mtshan nyid las rdzas tha dad du 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin gshegs pa dang phung po rang bzhin gyis tha dad du ma grub pa'i phyir/ de bzhin gshegs pa de la phung po brten pa dang phung po der de bzhin gshegs pa brten par ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / lhas byin gnag dang ldan pa dang rna ba dang ldan pa'i ldan tshul ltar de bzhin gshegs pa phung po dang ldan pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa/ min te/ rim pa bzhin du rang bzhin gyis tha dad pa dang gcig tu ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ / phyogs lhag ma gsum dang po gnyis su ci rigs par 'du bas gcig dang tha dad kyi phyogs gnyis su 'du mod kyang*/ 'jig ltas 'dzin tshul gyi 'jug pa la ltos nas 'di dang bcu par phyogs lnga gsungs so// // de ltar phyogs lnga rang bzhin gyis med pas de bzhin gshegs pa rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa gang zhig yod pa yin te 'ga' yang med pas srid pa'i rgyun yang rang bzhin gyis med do/ /

The Tathāgata is not different from the five aggregates through his own characteristic because, just as it was explained in the tenth chapter, he could come into existence without the aggregates. Moreover, as it was explained in the eighteenth chapter, he would have to be substantially different from either the characteristics characterizing the aggregates as produced phenomena or from the characteristics of each of the aggregates. Since the Tathāgata and the aggregates are not essentially distinct, neither do the aggregates inherently depend upon the Tathāgata, nor does the Tathāgata inherently depend upon the aggregates. [373] The Tathāgata does not inherently possess the aggregates in the way that Lhejin possesses his cattle or his nose, because, respectively, they are neither essentially different, nor are they essentially identical. Since the three remaining alternatives are included in the first two, identity and difference comprise these alternatives. However, considering the way things are taken according to the view of the transitory aggregates, here and in the tenth chapter, all five alternatives are presented. Since the Tathāgata cannot exist essentially in any of these five alternative ways, how could he exist through his own characteristic? Since he does not exist like that, the continuum of life is also empty of essence.
gnyis pa [phung po la brten nas btags pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1.1.2 Refutation of the essential existence of dependent designations based on the aggregates
['di] la gnyis/ phung po la brten nas btags pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag // de bzhin gshegs pa dang phung po len pa po dang blang byar rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the Tathāgata as dependently designated based on the aggregates and the refutation of the essential existence of the Tathāgata and the aggregates as appropriator and appropriated.
dang po [phung po la brten nas btags pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1.1.2.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the Tathāgata as dependently designated based on the aggregates

['di] la bzhi/ phung po la brten nas btags na rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin pa dang / de gnyis mi 'gal ba'i lan dgag pa dang / rang dngos ma grub na gzhan dngos ma grub pa dang des na de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis med par grub pa'o/ /

This section has four parts: if something is designated depending on the aggregates, it does not exist essentially, the refutation of the response that these two are not contradictory, showing that if there is no essence, neither can there be the nature of being other, and showing that thus the Tathāgata is established as lacking essential existence.
dang po [phung po la brten nas btags na rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.1 If something is designated depending on the aggregates, it does not exist essentially

mang pos bkur ba dag na re ji skad bshad pa'i nyes par 'gyur bas de bzhin gshegs pa dang phung po gcig dang gzhan ma yin zhing / ri gangs can la shing ltar de bzhin gshegs pa la phung po dang nags khrod na seng ge ltar phung po la de bzhin gshegs pa dang / 'khor sgyur mtshan dang ldan pa ltar de bzhin gshegs pa phung po dang ldan pa'ang min te gcig dang gzhan du khas mi len pa'i phyir ro/ / 'o na ci zhe na/ phung po las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa phung po la brten nas 'jog pa la/ phyogs snga bkag pa ni kho bo cag la gnod par byed pa min no zhes smra'o/ /

The Sammitīya say that as one would commit the errors presented above, the Tathāgata and the aggregates are neither identical nor different. Neither are there aggregates in the Tathāgata as there are trees on a snow mountain nor is there a Tathāgata in the aggregates as there is a lion in the forest; nor does the Tathāgata possess the aggregates as the Cakravartin emperor possesses the relevant marks. This is because he is maintained to be neither identical to nor different from the aggregates. Then how does it go? The inexpressible Tathāgata who is neither identical to nor different from the aggregates is posited in dependence on the aggregates. Thus [374] the refutation of the five alternatives does not undermine our position.
gal te sangs rgyas phung po la/ / brten nas rang bzhin las yod min/ / rang bzhin las ni gang med pa/ / de gzhan dngos las ga la yod/ /
2. If the Buddha, depending on the aggregates, Does not exist through an essence, How could something that does not exist through its essence Exist through the nature of another?

gal te sangs rgyas phung po la brten nas 'dogs na 'o na ni de rang bzhin las sam rang bzhin gyis yod pa min par 'gyur te brten nas btags pa'i phyir gzugs brnyan bzhin no/ / gang zhig rang bzhin las te rang gi ngo bo nyid las med pa de phung po la brten nas gzhan gyi dngos po las ngo bo nyid kyis ga la yod de med do/ /

If the Buddha were designated in dependence on the aggregates, then he would not exist through an essence, or essentially because of being dependently designated, just like a reflection. How could that which does not exist through an essence—that is, inherently—depending on the aggregates, exist inherently through the nature of another? It could not!
gnyis pa [de gnyis mi 'gal ba'i lan dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.2 Refutation of the response that these two are not contradictory

ci ste gzugs brnyan rang gang du snang ba de'i rang bzhin du ma grub pas rang bzhin las yod pa min yang / byad bzhin dang me long la sogs pa gzhan gyi dngos po la ltos nas yod pa bzhin du/ de bzhin gshegs pa yang rang bzhin las yod pa min yang phung po la brten nas gzhan gyi dngos po las ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose one argued as follows: Since the reflection does not exist with the essence of that which it appears to be, it does not exist through an essence. But just as it exists in dependence on such other things as the face and the mirror, the Tathāgata also, although not existing through an essence, depends on the aggregates and so exists inherently through the nature of another.
gang zhig gzhan gyi dngos brten nas/ / de bdag nyid du mi 'thad do/ / gang zhig bdag nyid med pa de/ / ci ltar de bzhin gshegs par 'gyur/ /
3. Whatever is dependent on the nature of another, Its selfhood is not tenable. How could that which lacks selfhood Be a Tathāgata?

gal te de bzhin gshegs pa gang zhig gzhan gyi dngos po la brten nas gzugs brnyan ltar yod par 'dod na ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa de bdag nyid de rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa'i rang bzhin du mi 'thad de gzugs brnyan bzhin no/ / gang zhig gzugs brnyan ltar bdag nyid de rang bzhin gyis med pa de ji ltar na de bzhin gshegs par rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / tshigs bcad snga mas ngo bo nyid las yod na rang gi ngo bo kho nas gdaT dgos kyi phung po la brten nas gdags pa mi 'thad do zhes gsungs pa la/ gzhan la ma brten pa'i rang gi ngo bos grub pa min gyi gzhan la brten nas rang gi ngo bos grub pa'o zhes pa'i lan du de gnyis 'gal bar tshigs bcad phyi mas bstan to/ /

If one were to maintain that the Tathāgata—that which is dependent on the essence of another—exists like a reflection, then, just as in the case of the reflection, it would not be tenable that that Tathāgata exists with selfhood—that is, with inherently existent essence. Whatever is like a reflection lacks selfhood—that is, is essenceless. So how could such a Tathāgata exist essentially? It could not! The previous verse says that if he existed inherently he would have to be designated as inherently existent; it would not be tenable to designate him in dependence on the aggregates. This following verse responds that it is inconsistent to say that he does not exist inherently in virtue of not depending on another but inherently exists as dependent on another.
gsum pa [rang dngos ma grub na gzhan dngos ma grub pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.3 Showing that if there is no essence, neither can there be the nature of being other
gal te rang bzhin yod min na/ / gzhan dngos yod bar ci ltar 'gyur/ /
4. If there is no essence How could there be the nature of being other?

de bzhin gshegs pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod na de la ltos nas phung po'i ngo bo gzhan du 'gyur la de la brten nas de bzhin gshegs par 'gyur ba zhig na/ gal te de bzhin gshegs pa la ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa'i rang bzhin yod pa min na/ de la ltos nas phung po rnams gzhan gyi dngos por yod par ji ltar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /

If the Tathāgata existed inherently, depending on him, the aggregates would be other entities. The Tathāgata would exist in dependence on them. But if the Tathāgata does not have [375] inherently existent essence, then in virtue of this, how could the aggregates have the nature of being other? They could not.
bzhi pa [des na de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis med par grub pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.1.4 Showing that thus the Tathāgata is established as lacking essential existence
rang bzhin dang ni gzhan dngos dag / ma gtogs de bzhin gshegs de gang / /
4cd Apart from having essence or the nature of another, What could the Tathāgata be?

de ltar rang dngos dang gzhan gyi dngos po dag ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min pa'i phyir rang bzhin dang gzhan dngos dag las ma gtogs pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa de gang zhig yod de med do/ / bstan bcos 'di yi gzhung kun brten nas 'byung ba dang rang gi mtshan nyid kyis yod pa 'gal bar rtogs pa'i phyir du 'jug mod kyang rab byed 'dis don de yang dang yang du gsal bar ston no/ /

Since there is no essence or nature of another existing inherently, apart from having essence or the nature of another, how could there be an essentially existing Tathāgata? There could not be! Nāgārjuna’s approach in this entire treatise is to lead one to realize the mutual inconsistency of dependent origination and existence through one’s own characteristic. However, this chapter repeatedly clarifies that point.
gnyis pa [de bzhin gshegs pa dang phung po len pa po dang blang byar rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.1.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of the Tathāgata and the aggregates as appropriator and appropriated

phung po las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa phung po la brten nas 'dogs so zhes smra ba'i mang pos bkur bas ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa len pa po dang de'i phung po blang byar rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par 'dod do/ /

The Sammitīya, who assert that whether the Tathāgata is the same as or different from the aggregates is inexpressible, say that he is imputed in dependence upon the aggregates. They maintain that the Tathāgata as the appropriator and his aggregates as the appropriated exist through their own characteristics.
gal te phung po ma brten par/ / de bzhin bshegs pa 'ga' yod na/ / de ni da gdod brtan 'gyur zhing / / brten nas de nas 'gyur la lag /
5. If, without depending on the aggregates There could be a Tathāgata at all, He would now depend on them. Through depending on them he would be dependent.

de'i tshe gal te nor gyi sngar grub pa'i lhas byin gyis nor len pa bzhin du/ phung po la ma brten par te phung po'i sngar de bzhin gshegs pa 'ga' zhig yod na/ de ni da gzod phung po dag la brten par 'gyur zhing phung po la brten nas de nas de'i len pa por 'gyur la rag na/ dpyad pa na phung po rnams la ma brten par te de'i sngar de bzhin gshegs pa 'ga' yang med de/ de bzhin gshegs par gdags pa'i rgyu med par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

If—just as Lhejin, who exists prior to his wealth, appropriates his wealth—there could be a Tathāgata at all who, without depending on the aggregates, existed prior to them, he would now be dependent on the aggregates. Through depending on them he would become an appropriator. On analysis, no Tathāgata at all can exist prior to and without depending on the aggregates, because there would be no ground for the designation of “Tathāgata.”
phung po rnams la ma brten par / de bzhin shegs pa 'ga' yang med/ / gang zhig ma brten yod min na/ / des ni ci ltar nyer len 'gyur/ /
6. Inasmuch as there is no Tathāgata Not dependent upon the aggregates, If he does not exist without depending on them, How could he appropriate them?

de bzhin gshegs pa gang zhig phung po la ma brten par te de'i sngar yod pa min na/ de bzhin gshegs pa des ni ji ltar na rang bzhin gyis phung po nye bar len par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar phung po len pa cung zad kyang rang bzhin gyis med pa na/ phung po la brten nas de bzhin gshegs pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'gyur ro zhes pa mi 'thad do/ /

Inasmuch as there is no Tathāgata not dependent on the aggregates—that is, prior to them there is none—how could the Tathāgata essentially appropriate the aggregates? He could not!
