Thus since there is not even the slightest essential appropriation of the aggregates, it is not tenable to say that the Tathāgata exists inherently in dependence upon the aggregates.
nye bar blangs pa ma yin pa/ / nye bar len pa cis mi 'gyur/ / nye bar len pa med pa yi/ / de bzhin gshegs pa ci yang med/ /
7. Without the appropriated, There is no appropriation. Without appropriation, How can there be a Tathāgata?

de bzhin gshegs pa snga rol na med pas nye bar len pa cung zad kyang rang bzhin gyis nye bar blangs pa ma yin pas/ phung po rnams nye bar len par rang bzhin gyis ji ltar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / gang gi tshe de ltar sus kyang rang bzhin gyis ma blangs pa'i phyir nye bar len pa phung po rnams rang bzhin gyis nye bar len par mi 'gyur ba de'i tshe/ rang bzhin gyis nye bar len pa med pa yi de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa ci yang med do/ /

[376] Since without existing previously the Tathāgata did not essentially appropriate that which is to be appropriated even the slightest bit, how could the appropriation of the aggregates exist essentially? It could not! Since nobody appropriates essentially, there can be no appropriation of essentially appropriated aggregates. Thus, with no essentially existing appropriation, the Tathāgata could not exist essentially.
gsum pa [de rnams kyi mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.1.3 Drawing conclusions from these
rnam pa lngas ni btsal byas na/ / gang zhig de nyid gzhan nyid da/ / med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa de/ / nye bar len pas ci ltar gdags/ /
8. Having been sought in the fivefold way, How can that which is neither identical nor different Be designated as the Tathāgata In virtue of appropriating?

ji skad bshad pa'i tshul gyis brtag pa rnam pa lngas ni dpyad cing btsal bar byas pa na/ gang zhig phung po las de nyid de gcig dang gzhan nyid du ngo bo nyid kyis med pas/ rten dang brten pa sogs gsum du yang ngo bo nyid kyis med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa de rang bzhin gyis yod par nye bar len pa phung pos ji ltar gdags par nus te mi nus so/ /

Having been sought analytically through the five modes of examination explained above, the Tathāgata is found to be neither inherently identical to nor inherently different from the aggregates. Therefore, how could that Tathāgata that does not exist inherently in any of these other three ways, including as a basis or as dependent, be designated as existing inherently in virtue of the appropriation of the aggregates? He could not be!
gnyis pa [blang bya rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.2 Refutation of the inherent existence of that which is appropriated

rnam par dpyad pa 'dis de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis ma grub par bstan pa 'ba' zhig tu ma zad kyi 'on kyang gang zhig nye bar blang ba gzuT dang tshor ba la sogs pa phung po lnga po de yang rang bzhin las te rang bzhin gyis yod pa min te/ de ni rten 'brel yin pa'i phyir dang phung po brtag par rang bzhin gyis yod pa rgyas par bkag zin pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste yang nye bar len pa de gzhan la ma ltos pa'i rang bzhin las med kyang rgyu rkyen gzhan gyi dngos po la brten nas rang bzhin gyis yod do zhe na/

These analyses have not only shown that the Tathāgata is essenceless, but also that the five aggregates that are to be appropriated, such as material form and feeling, do not exist through their essence—that is essentially. This is because they are dependently originated, and because their essential existence has already been extensively refuted in the examination of the aggregates. Now, suppose someone argued as follows: Even though that which is to be appropriated does not exist essentially without depending on another, depending on other causes and conditions, it exists essentially.
gang zhig nye bar blang ba de/ / de ni rang bzhin las yod min/ / bdag gi dngos las gang med pa/ / de gzhan dngos las yod re skan/ /
9. Whatever there is to be appropriated Does not exist through essence. And when something does not exist through its own nature, It can never exist through the nature of another.

gzhan la ma brten par bdag gi dngos po las te ngo bo nyid las gang med pa de ni/ rgyu rkyen gzhan gyi dngos po las rang bzhin gyis yod re skan te yod pa mi srid de/ rang gi ngo bo nyid las grub pa dang gzhan la ltos dgos pa gnyis 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / yang na nye bar len pa po la ltos pa'i phyir nye bar blang bya rnams rang gi ngo bos grub pa med do/ / gal te de ltar yin kyang nye bar len pa po la ltos pa dang bcas par 'gyur ro zhe na/ nye bar blang bya gang zhig rang gi ngo bo las ma grub pa de len pa po gzhan gyi dngos po las rang bzhin gyis yod par ji ltar 'gyur/

It is impossible for something that does not depend on another, and that does not exist through its own nature—that is, inherently—to exist essentially through the nature of other causes and conditions. This is because it is inconsistent for something to exist inherently and also to depend upon another. Another way to read this is as follows: Since it depends upon the appropriator, that which is appropriated does not exist inherently./1/ [377] Now suppose someone said that in that case they would depend upon the appropriator. We would respond that whatever is to be appropriated does not exist inherently; for how could it exist essentially through the nature of another—the appropriator?
gsum pa [de gnyis ka'i mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.1.3 Drawing conclusions from these two
de ltarar nyer blang nyer len po/ / rnam pa kun gyis stong pa yin/ / stong pas de bzhin gshegs stong pa/ / ci ltar bar na 'dogs par 'gyur/ /
10. Thus appropriated and appropriator Are empty in every respect. How can an empty Tathāgata Be imputed through the empty?

sngar bshad pa de ltar nye bar blang bar bya ba dang nye bar len pa po gnyis ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pas rnam pa thams cad kyis stong pa yin no/ / de ltar nye bar blang bya rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pa ji lta bur na ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'dogs par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / de'i phyir phung po la brten nas btags pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes pa ni mi rigs so/ /

As it has been explained earlier, both the appropriator and that which is to be appropriated are empty of existence through their own characteristics in every respect. Since that which is to be appropriated is empty of essential existence, how could one impute the Tathāgata, who is empty of essential existence as inherently existent? One could not. Therefore it makes no sense to say that the Tathāgata designated in dependence upon the aggregates exists inherently.
gnyis pa [de la log lta gzhan gyi'ang gnas med par bstan pa] ni/
1.2 Showing that there is no room for others’ false views

e ma kho bo cag ni gzegs zan la sogs pa'i ston pa gzhan spangs nas de bzhin gshegs pa la skyabs su song zhing thar pa don du gnyer na/ de ltar nyer blang nyer len po/ / zhes sogs kyis de rang bzhin gyis med par smras pas kho bo cag gi thar pa'i re thag bcad do/ / de'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa'i rtsi sman gyi ljon shing rtsad nas 'don pa khyod dang brtsad pas da chog go zhe na/

Suppose someone responded: Alas! Having abandoned the teachings of other teachers like Kaṅāda, we have taken refuge in the Tathāgata and aspire to liberation. But, since you have said that the Tathāgata does not exist essentially by saying things like “thus appropriated and appropriator…” [XXII: 10], our aspiration to liberation has been quashed. Therefore, it is time to dispute with you, since you have uprooted the medicinal tree of the Tathāgata!
stong ngo zhes kyang mi brjod de/ / mi stong zhes kyang mi bya zhing / / gnyis dang gnyis min mi bya ste/ / gdags pa'i don du brjod par bya/ /
11. We do not assert “Empty.” Nor do we assert “Nonempty.” We neither assert both nor neither. They are asserted only for the purpose of designation.

'dir khyod 'dra ba'i skye bo la kho bo cag gi thar pa'i re ba chad pa yin te/ thar pa 'dod pas ston pa gzhan gyi lugs dor nas sangs rgyas la skyabs su song yang bdag med pa'i sgra mu stegs thams cad dang thun mong min pa mi bzod pa na/ lam ngan pa 'khor ba'i 'brog dgon pa dang rjes su mthun pa de nyid nas song ba yin no/ kho bo ni skur pa btab pas nyes par 'a gyur ba de bzhin gshegs pa stong pa ste med pa zhes kyang mi brjod do/ / gzhan yang de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin med par ston zhing phyin ci ma log pa'i don brjod par 'dod pas mi stong pa ste ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes kyang mi bya zhing / de gnyis kar yang brjod par mi bya la yod med gnyis ka min pa yang brjod par mi bya ste don dam par de bzhi ka khas mi len pa'o/ / 'on kyang tha snyad du ma brjod na gdul bya rnams kyis mi rtogs pas tha snyad kyi bden pa la gnas nas tha snyad kyi don du/ gdul bya'i skye bo'i ngor blos btags nas stong pa dang mi stong pa dang stong mi stong gnyis ka dang / stong pa yang min la mi stong pa yang min no zhes kyang smra ste de'i phyir de kho na gdags pa'i don du brjod par bya'o/ /

Here, we have no hope for liberation for people like you, because while having abandoned other systems in the hope of attaining liberation, although you have taken refuge in the Buddha, you have not digested his teaching of selflessness, which is not shared by the orthodox schools. Therefore you follow the evil path that leads straight to the wilderness of cyclic existence! We do not say that because the Tathāgata is empty he is nonexistent, which would be to commit the error of deprecating him. Moreover, the Tathāgata has been shown to be essenceless. Because we aspire to present the undistorted meaning, [378] nor do we say that he is nonempty—that is, that he exists inherently. We do not assert both of these; nor do we assert neither that he exists nor does not exist because ultimately none of these four alternatives can be maintained. On the other hand, if we did not assert these conventionally, those to whom we speak would not understand us. So, from the standpoint of the conventional truth and for conventional purposes, we say “empty” and “nonempty,” “both empty and nonempty,” and “neither empty nor nonempty.” We say these having mentally imputed them from the perspective of those people to whom we are speaking. Therefore, we simply say that “they are asserted only for the purpose of designation.”
rtag dang mi rtag la sogs bzhi/ / zhi ba 'di la ga la yod/ mtha' dang mtha' med la sogs bzhi/ / zhi ba 'di la ga la yod/ /
12. How can the tetralemma of permanent, impermanent, etc., Be true of the pacified? How can the tetralemma of finite, infinite, etc., Be true of the pacified?

ston pas dgongs pa gang gis stong pa la sogs pa gsungs pa ni bco brgyad pa las bshad zin to/ / de bzhin gshegs pa la stong pa la sogs pa bzhi po don dam par mi mnga' ba de bzhin du 'jig rten rtag pa dang mi rtag pa dang la sogs pas bsdus pa rtag mi rtag gnyis ka dang / gnyis ka ma yin pa bzhi yi lta ba log pas ji ltar bzung ba yang sangs rgyas ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa zhi ba 'di la ga la yod de med do/ / de bzhin du 'jig rten mtha' dang ldan pa dang mtha' med pa dang la sogs kyis bsdus pa mtha' dang ldan mi ldan gnyis ka dang / gnyis ka ma yin pa'i log par lta ba bzhis bzung ba'i don yang zhi ba 'di la ga la yod de med do/ /

The eighteenth chapter has already explained the teacher’s intent in saying “empty,” etc. Just as the Tathāgata is ultimately free of each of the four alternatives (“empty,” etc.) how could this system, in which the inherent existence of the Buddha has been laid to rest, fall under any of the four alternatives—permanence or impermanence of the world, etc., and those to which “etc.” refers, viz., both permanence and impermanence and neither permanence nor impermanence—that are grasped by those who have distorted views? It could not. Similarly, how could the system in which this has been laid to rest fall under any of the four alternatives—finitude or infinitude of the world, etc., and those to which “etc.” refers, viz, both finitude and infinitude and neither finitude nor infinitude—that are grasped by those who have distorted views? It could not!
gang gis de bzhin gshegs yod ces/ / 'dzin pa stug pos bzung gyur pa/ / de ni mya ngan 'das pa la/ / med ces rnam rtog rtog par byed/ /
13. One who holds firmly That the Tathāgata exists Will have to fabricate his nonexistence After having achieved nirvana.

rgol ba gang gis 'di nyid bden gyi gzhan ni gti mug pa'o snyam du 'dzin pa stug po bzung bar gyur pa de ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa mya ngan las 'das pa la ste 'das nas de bzhin gshegs pa yod do zhe'am med ces pa dang / yod med gnyis ka dang gnyis ka min pa zhes pa'i log par rnam par rtog pa bzhis rnam par rtog par byed do/ / tshig gsal gyi 'gyur gyi rtsa ba la/ gang gis de bzhin gshegs yod ces/ / 'dzin pa stug pos bzung gyur pa/ / des ni mya ngan 'das pa la/ / med ces rnam par rtog par byed/ / ces 'byung zhing de dang mthun pa'i 'grel pa'ang bsgyur mod kyang / bud d+ha pA li ta las/ gang gis 'dzin stug bzung gyur pa/ / de ni mya ngan 'das pa la/ / de bzhin gshegs pa yod ce'am/ med ces rnam rtog rtog par byed/ / ces bsgyur zhing de dang mthun par 'grel pa mdzad pa nyid 'gyur legs par mthong nas de ltar bshad do/ //

Whoever holds firmly that only this is true but all the others are confused will fabricate the existence, nonexistence, both, or neither of the Tathāgata who has achieved nirvana, having passed away, fabricating through one of these four distorted views. The Tibetan translation of Prasannapadā has the translation of the root text as it is quoted here, and the commentary in Prasannapadā accords with that translation. [379] but the Tibetan translation of the Buddhapālita has it as follows: One who is a firm holder That the Tathāgata exists Will have to fabricate his existence or his nonexistence After having achieved nirvana./2/ We have commented according to this translation because it is more felicitous.
rang bzhin gyis ni stong de la/ / sangs rgyas mya ngan 'das nas ni/ / yod do zhe'am med do zhes/ / bsam pa'ang 'thad pa nyid mi 'gyur/ /
14. Since he is essentially empty, Neither the thought that the Buddha exists Nor that he does not exist After having achieved nirvana is tenable.

gang gi ltar na de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin gyis ni grub pas stong pa de la sangs rgyas mya ngan las 'das nas ni sangs rgyas yod do zhe'am med do zhe'am yod med gnyis ka dang gnyis ka min pa zhes sems pa'i bsam pas bzung ba ltar 'thad pa nyid du mi 'gyur ro/ / de 'dra ba'i lta ba bcu gnyis dang lus srog gcig dang tha dad du lta ba gnyis ni lung ma bstan gyi lta ba bcu bzhi zhes gsungs pa yin te/ de thams cad bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa la brtsams nas 'dri bas 'o na lung du ma bstan pa yin pa'i phyir te/ de ltar 'dri ba de dag ni zab mo'i snod min pas bdag med pa'i don ni bshad du mi rung la/ rtag mi rtag la sogs pa bshad pas kyang rtag chad kyi lta ba skyed cing don du yang mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / 'dir 'jig rten ni bdag la zer la de ni de bzhin gshegs pa la yang bya bas 'dir de thams cad sangs rgyas la sbyar la/ lta ba tha ma gnyis skabs 'dir ma gsungs kyang sngar phung po dang gcig tha dad bkag pa la de gnyis mi rung ba'i don tshang ngo / /

On the view according to which the Tathāgata exists as essentially empty, it is not tenable to grasp him by thinking that after having achieved nirvana either the Buddha exists, he does not exist both or neither. These twelve views and the two views that one’s life is either identical to or different from one’s body are said to be the fourteen views to which the Buddha would not assent. This is because since all of these presuppose the inherent existence of the self, these questions receive no answer. Those who asked these questions were not vessels of the profound; therefore, it was inappropriate to explain the meaning of selflessness to them. Even had he explained such things as permanence and impermanence, that would have given rise either to reification or to nihilism and so would have served no purpose. In this context, “the world” refers to the self./3/ And that also refers to the Tathāgata and so all of this applies to the Buddha. Although in this context, the last two views are not explained, the fact that these two are not tenable is entailed by the previous refutation of the aggregates’ identity to and difference from the self.
gsum pa [log par bzung ba'i nyes dmigs bstan pa] ni/
1.3 Presentation of the deficiencies of those false views
gang dag sangs rgyas spros 'dra shing / / zad pa med la spros byed pa/ / spros pas nyams pa de kun gyis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong mi 'gyur/ /
15. Those who develop fabrications with regard to the Buddha— The unextinguished one who has gone beyond all fabrication— And are impaired by those fabrications, Fail to see the Tathāgata.

gang dag blo zhan pa nyid kyis sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'jig rten pa'i spros pa thams cad las yang dag par 'das shing / rang bzhin gyis skye ba med pas rang bzhin gzhan du 'gro ba'i zad pa med pa la/ sngar bshad pa ltar gyi rtag mi rtag la sogs pa'i log par rtog pas spros par byed pa spros pa de dag gis/ ye shes kyi mig nyams par gyur pa de dag kun gyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i de kho na nyid mthong bar mi 'gyur te dmus long gis nyi ma bzhin no/ / de'i phyir sum brgya pa las/ gang dag nga la gzugs su mthong / / gang dag nga la sgrar shes pa/ / log par spong bar zhugs pa ste/ / skye bo de dag nga mi mthong / / sangs rgyas rnams ni chos nyid lta/ / 'dren pa rnams ni chos kyi sku/ / chos nyid shes bya ma yin te/ / de ni rnam par shes mi nus/ / zhes gsungs so/ / tshig de dag gis ni gzugs sgra la sogs pa'i spros pa'i chos su bden par 'dzin pas ni/ sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid la log par zhugs shing spong ba yin pas / des sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid mi mthong bas sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid ni chos nyid du lta bar bya ba dang chos kyi sku'o/ // chos nyid ni sngar ltar bzung ba'i tshul gyis shes par bya ba min te tshul des shes par mi nus pa'i phyir ro zhes bstan te/ spros pas blo mig nyams pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i de nyid mi mthong ba'i shes byed yin pa'i phyir dang / spros pa'i rtog pas blo mig ma bslad na mthong bar don gyis bstan pa'i phyir ro/ /

Those simpletons who, through distorted views explained earlier, fabricate such things as the permanence and impermanence of the victorious Buddha who is free from all mundane fabrications and who, being essentially unarisen, does not extinguish by essentially passing on, [380] thereby have impaired wisdom eyes. None of them will see the Tathāgata as he really is just as the congenitally blind cannot see the sun. Thus the Vajracchedikā-sūtra says: Whoever see me as material form And those who know me as sound— Who discard me through distortions— Such people do not see me. The buddhas should be seen as reality. And the guides should be seen as dharmakāya./4/ Reality is not an object of knowledge. It is impossible to comprehend it. [Sher phyin sNa tshogs ka 131a] These passages show that those who grasp such fabricated phenomena as form and sound as truly existent have thereby, through distorting the way the Buddha really is, discarded him. Thus they do not see the Buddha as he really is. The way the Buddha really is should be seen as reality and is dharmakaya. Reality is not to be known in the way that it has been previously expounded, because it cannot be comprehended in that manner. This is because this confirms that those whose cognitive vision has been impaired by fabrication do not see the Tathāgata, and it implies that if their cognitive vision were not impaired by fabrication, they would see.
bzhi pa [rigs pa de gzhan la'ang sbyar ba] ni/
1.4 Applying arguments to those other views

de bzhin gshegs pa brtags pas sems can gyi 'jig rten yang brtags pa yin la sems can gyi 'jig rten rang bzhin med pa ltar snod la yang rang bzhin med de/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gang yin pa de dang 'dra bar 'gro ba 'di yi rang bzhin yang yin pa'i phyir ro/ // de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gang zhe na/

Through this examination of the Tathāgata the world of sentient beings is also examined. Just as the world of sentient beings is essenceless, the vessel is also essenceless. This is because the essence of the transmigrators is similar to the essence of the Tathāgata. So, one might ask, what is the essence of the Thatlj-gata?
de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gang / / de ni 'gro'i 'di'i rang bzhin yin/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rang bzhin med/ / 'gro ba 'di yi rang bzhin med/ /
16. Whatever is the essence of the Tathāgata, That is the essence of the transmigrator. The Tathāgata has no essence. The transmigrator has no essence.

de bzhin gshegs pa ni phung po la brten nas btags kyi rang gi ngo bo nyid las grub pa med pas rang bzhin gyis grupa pa med do/ / de bzhin du 'gro ba 'di dag kyang ltos sa de dang de dag la brten nas btags kyi rang las rab tu grub pa yi rang bzhin nyid med do/ / 'gro ba ngo bo nyid med par ni rkyen brtag pa sogs las bstan zin to/ /

The Tathāgata is designated in dependence on the aggregates and does not exist inherently, and thus is essenceless. Similarly, the transmigrators are also designated in dependence on their respective bases [381] and lack the essence of existing on their own. The absence of inherent existence of the transmigrators has already been demonstrated in such chapters as the examination of conditions.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dang de'i chos phung po rnams rang bzhin med par bshad pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / de ltar bshad pa thams cad rab tu byed pa 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs mtshon ni/ ye shes snang ba rgyan gyi mdo las/ rtag tu skye med chos ni de bzhin gshegs/ / chos rnams kun kyang bde bar gshegs dang 'dra/ / byis pa'i blo can mtshan mar 'dzin pa rnams/ / 'jig rten na ni med pa'i chos la spyod/ / de bzhin gshegs pa zag pa med pa yi/ / dge ba'i chos kyi gzugs brnyan lta bu yin/ / 'di na de bzhin nyid dang de bzhin gshegs pa med/ / 'jig rten thams cad kyis ni gzugs brnyan mthong / / zhes dang /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the explanation of the Thatāgata and his attributes—his aggregates—as essenceless can also be corroborated by profound sūtras and that all of those discussions are explained by this chapter. The Sarvabuddhaviṣayāvatārajñānālokālaṁkāra-sūtra says: The Tathāgata is an eternally unarisen phenomenon. All phenomena are like the Tathāgata. Fools who are attached to representations Engage with things that do not exist in the world. The Tathāgata is like the reflection of Uncontaminated virtuous phenomena. Here neither reality nor the Tathāgata exists. So the entire world should be seen to be like a reflection. [m Do sde ga 284b]

bcom lngan 'das ma las kyang / 'phags pa rab 'byor sems can de dag sgyu ma lta bu yin gyi sgyu ma ma yin nam de skad ces smras pa dang / tshe dang ldan pa rab 'byor gyis lha'i bu de dag la 'di skad ces smras so/ / lha'i bu dag sems can de dag ni sgyu ma lta bu'o/ / lha'i bu dag sems can de dag ni rmi lam lta bu ste/ lha'i bu dag de ltar na sgyu ma dang sems can de dag ni gnyis su med de gnyis su byar med pa'o/ / de ltar na rmi lam dang sems can de dag ni gnyis su med de gnyis su byar med do/ / lha'i bu dag chos thams cad kyang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes gsungs shing / rgyun du zhugs pa dang lan cig phyir 'ong ba dang / phyir mi 'ong ba dang dgra bcom pa dang de dag gi 'bras bu bzhi yang de ltar gsungs te gang zag dang de'i rgyud kyi 'bras bu rnams rang bzhin med par bstan to/ / de nas rang sangs rgyas dang rang sangs rgyas nyid dang rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas dang sangs rgyas nyid kyang de ltar gsungs pas ni gang zag dang de'i chos gnyis rang bzhin med par ston pa'o/ / de nas 'phags pa rab 'byor yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes smra'am/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid kyang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes smra'am/ rab 'byor gyis smras pa lha'i bu dag mya ngan las 'das pa yang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bur smra na chos gzhan lta ci smos/ lha'i bu dag gis smras pa 'phags pa rab 'byor mya ngan las 'das pa yang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes smra'am/ rab 'byor gyis smras dpa/ lha'i bu dag kho bo ni mya ngan las 'das pa pas ches khyad par du 'phaT pa'i chos 'ga' zhig yod na'ang de yang sgyu ma lta bu rmi lam lta bu'o zhes smra'o/ de lta na rmi lam dang mya ngan las 'das pa 'di ni gnyis su med gnyis su byar med do zhes gsungs so/ /

In the Prajñāpāramitā it also says: “O Noble Subhūti, it is said that sentient beings are like illusions; are they not like illusions?” When the ven Subhūati was addressed like this, he replied to the divine sons as follows: “O, divine sons, sentient beings are like illusions! O divine sons, they are like dreams. O, divine sons, since they are like that, sentient beings and illusions are not distinct, because they cannot be distinguished. Since they are like that, dreams and sentient beings are not distinct, because they cannot be distinguished.” He also said to the divine sons that all phenomena are like dreams and like illusions, and that stream-enterers, once-returners, nonreturners, their four fruits, and the arhats are also said to be like that. Thus, the person and [382] the effects connected with its continuum are shown to be essenceless. Thereafter, pratyekabuddhas, partyekabuddhahood, the completely enlightened one, and complete enlightenment are also said to be like that. Thus it is shown that the person and its attributes are essenceless. Thereafter, the divine ones asked him, “O, noble Subhūti, is it said that the completely enlightened Buddha as well is like an illusion and like a dream, and is it said that complete enlightenment is like an illusion and like a dream?” Subhūgti replied, “O divine sons, when nirvana as well is said to be like an illusion and like a dream, then of course other phenomena are!” Then the divine ones asked, “O, noble Subhūti, is nirvana as well like an illusion and like a dream?” Subhūti replied, “O divine sons, even if there were something superior to nirvana, I would say that that is also like an illusion and like a dream. Thus there is no distinction between nirvana and a dream or an illusion because they cannot be distinguished.” [Aṣṭasāhaśrikā-prajñāpāramitā-sūtra, Sher phyin ka 22b]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

chos rnams rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub na de bzhin gshegs pa dang de'i chos rnams kyi rnam gzhag gtan mi rung zhing / des stong pa'i rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba la rnam gzhag thams cad shin tu 'thad pas de bzhin gshegs pa skyabs gnas sogs su 'jog pa yang lugs 'di kho na la shin tu 'thad pa yin no/ /

If phenomena existed through their own characteristics, the ontological status of the Tathāgata and his attributes would not make any sense. But their ontological status is completely tenable insofar as they are dependently originated and empty of existence through their own characteristics. Thus it is completely tenable in this system, and only in this system, to posit the Tathāgata as a refuge object.
de bzhin gshegs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gnyis pa'o// //
This is the twenty-second chapter called “the examination of the Tathāgata.”
de bzhin gshegs pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu drug gi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa gnyis pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-second chapter, having sixteen verses, called “the examination of the Tathāgata.”
CHAPTER XXIII. Examination of Errors
gnyis pa nyon mongs rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa
This chapter constitutes the second of those two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of afflictions.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three sections: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citation from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

'dir smras pa/ srid pa'i rgyu ni rang bzhin gyis yod de de'i rgyu rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di na nyon mongs pa las ni las 'byung zhing las dang nyon mongs pa'i 'bras bu skye ba dang 'chi ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa yang skye la de yang srid pa'i rgyun no/ / gtso bo'i rgyu ni nyon mongs yin te de spangs na las yod kyang srid rgyun ldog pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te nyon mongs pa rang bzhin gyis yod na srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis yod mod kyang de med do zhes 'gog pa la gnyis/ nyon mongs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag / de'i sgrub byed de spong ba'i thabs rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa'o/ /

[383] Here someone might argue as follows: the cause of cyclic existence exists essentially, because its causes exist essentially. Action arises from the afflictions; the continuous series of birth and death following one another arises as an effect from action and the afflictions, and that is the continuum of cyclic existence. The principal cause is the afflictions, because when they are eliminated, even though there is karma, the continuum of cyclic existence is terminated. If the afflictions existed essentially, the continuum of cyclic existence would exist essentially. However, this is not the case. The refutation of this assertion has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the afflictions and the refutation of the essential existence of the methods of their elimination as arguments for their existence.
dang po [nyon mongs pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag]
1.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the afflictions

['di] la lnga/ rten 'brel gyi rtags kyis dgag / rten rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag / rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag / dmigs pa rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag / rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags gzhan gyis dgag pa'o/ /

This section has five parts: the refutation through the arguments from dependent origination, the refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the basis, the refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the cause, the refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the object, and the refutation through another analysis from the essencelessness of the cause.
dang po [rten 'brel gyi rtags kyis dgag] ni/
1.1.1 Refutation through arguments from dependent origination

mdo sde las/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug rnams tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa las 'byung bar gsungs te/ 'dod pa khyod kyi rtsa ba ni/ / shes te kun tu rtog las byung*/ / zhes mdo sde las 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ / dug gsum tsam zhig smos pa ni nyon mongs pa gzhan thams cad 'di gsum gyi 'bras bu yin pas 'di gsum gtso bo yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

It says in sūtra that desire, aversion, and confusion arise from improper conceptualization. Oh desire, I know your source! You arise entirely from conceptualization. [Ajātaśatrukaukṛtyavinodana-sūtra, mDo sde tsha 233a] The reason why only the three poisons are mentioned here is that all of the others are the effects of these three, and these are the principal afflictions.
'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug rnams/ / kun tu rtog las 'byung bar gsungs/ / sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / brten pa nyid las kun tu 'byung / /
1. Desire, hatred, and confusion Arise completely from conceptualization, it is said. They all arise in dependence on The pleasant, the unpleasant, and errors.

yang sdug pa'i rnam pa la brten pa las 'dod chags dang mi sdug pa'i rnam pa la brten pa las zhe sdang dang / phyin ci log la brten pa nyid las gti mug kun tu 'byung ste kun rtog ni de gsum gyi rgyu thun mong ba'o/ / rten 'brel gyi mdo las/ ma rig pa'i rgyu gang zhe na tshul bzhin ma yin pa yid la byed pa'o zhes dang yid la byed pa rnyog pa can las gti mug skye ba yin no zhes gsungs pa'i phyir gti mug kun rtog las skye bar shes so/ //

Desire arises in dependence on representing things as pleasant, aversion in dependence on representing things as unpleasant, and confusion through errors about things. Conceptualization is the common cause of all of these three. According to the Pratītyasamutpāda-sūtra:/1/ What is the cause of ignorance? Improper thought. Confusion arises from muddy thought. [Bodhisattvapiṭaka, dKon brtsegs kha 187b] [384] Thus it is known that confusion arises from conceptulization.
gang dag sdug dang mi sdug dang / / phyin ci log las brten 'gyur ba/ / de dag rang bzhin las med de/ / de phyir nyong mongs yang dag med/ /
2. Since whatever arises in dependence on the pleasant, the unpleasant, Or error does not exist through an essence, The afflictions Do not exist in reality.

gang dag yul sdug pa dang mi sdug pa dang phyin ci log la brten nas 'byung ba de dag ni rang bzhin las med de/ chags sogs rang bzhin gyis grub na ni rang bzhin ma bcos pa dang rgyu rkyen gzhan la ltos pa med pa'i phyir/ / yul sdug pa sogs la brten nas mi 'byung ba zhig na yul sdug pa sogs la brten nas 'byung ngo / / de'i phyir 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa de dag yang dag par med de de yang don dam par med pa dang rang bzhin gyis med pa'i don no/ / 'dis ni dgag bya la yang dag pa sogs kyis khyad par ma sbyar bar bkag na mi rung bar ston te gzhan la yang 'dra'o/ / gti mug gi rgyu'i kun rtog ni phyin ci log ste 'chad par 'gyur la chags sdang gnyis kyi rgyu'i kun rtog ni sdug pa dang mi sdug pa'i mtshan ma sgro 'dogs pa'i tshul min yid byed do/ slob dpon gzhan gnyis kyis tshigs bcad dang po'i don dug gsum las 'byung bas rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes pa'i lan du tshigs bcad gnyis pas de 'gog par mdzad cing sdug pa dang mi sdug pa'i phyin ci log ces gnyis su 'chad do/ /

Whatever arises in dependence on a pleasant object, an unpleasant object, or an object of error cannot exist essentially. This is because if such things as desire existed essentially, their essence would be uncreated and would not depend on causes and conditions; they would not arise in dependence on such things as pleasant objects; but in fact they do arise in dependence on such things as pleasant objects. Therefore, the afflictions such as desire do not exist in reality. This means that they neither exist ultimately nor essentially. This shows that such a refutation is not possible without applying a modifying term, such as “really” and this is true of other cases. The conceptualization that is the cause of confusion is erroneous and will be explained below. The conceptualization that is the cause of desire and aversion is the improper thought that fabricates representations of objects as pleasant and unpleasant, respectively. The other two masters explain that the second verse refutes the first verse, which, they say, states that since the three poisons arise from conceptualizations, they exist essentially. So, they explain error as twofold: error about the pleasant and error about the unpleasant [Buddhāpalita 267a, Prajñāpradīpa 219b-220a].

'bras bu rgyu las 'byung ba dbu ma pas rang bzhin med pa'i sgrub byed du bzhed la dngos por smra bas rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i sgrub byed du smra bas sgo gnyis ka nas bshad du rung bas mi 'gal la/ stong nyid bdun cu pa'i rang 'grel du sdug pa sogs gsum rim pa bzhin du dug gsum gyi rgyur gsungs so/ rnam rtog gi dbang gis skye ba la rang mtshan gyis yod pas stong pa bsgrub sla bas de nyid de'i sgrub byed du yang gsungs te/ stong nyid bdun cu pa las/ gang phyir der chags der sdang der/ / rmongs pa de phyir de dag ni/ / rnam rtog gis bskyed rnam rtog kyang / / yang dag nyid du yod ma yin/ / zhes gsungs so/

The mādhyamika maintains that the fact that an effect arises from causes is a reason for its essencelessness, while the reificationists maintain that it is a reason for its essential existence. Therefore, since these verses can be interpreted in both ways, there is no contradiction here. The autocommentary to Śūnyatāsaptati says that the pleasant, the unpleasant and error are the causes of desire, aversion and confusion, respectively. Since it is easy to establish that that which arises through the power of conception is empty of existence through its own characteristic, this is presented as the argument for that claim. [dBu ma tsa 119b] Śūnyatāsaptati says, Since one desires that, is averse to that, And is confused with regard to that, Conceptualization gives rise to these. Nor does conceptualization exist in reality. [60]
gnyis pa [rten rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag]
1.1.2 Refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the basis
['di] la gnyis/ bdag rten du med pa'i rtags kyis dgag / sems rten du med pa'i rtags kyis dgag pa'o/ /
[385] This section has two parts: the refutation through arguments that the self is not a basis and the refutation through arguments that the mind is not a basis.
dang po [bdag rten du med pa'i rtags kyis dgag] ni/
1.1.2.1 Refutation through arguments that the self is not a basis

bdag gi yod pa dang med pa nyid ji lta bur yang rang bzhin gyis grub pa med pa ni bdag brtag pa la sogs par bshad zin to/ / de med pa'i phyir na bdag de la brten pa'i nyon mongs pa rnams kyi yod pa nyid dang med pa nyid rang bzhin gyis 'grub pa ji ltar yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ / gal te bdag gis yod pa dang med pa rang bzhin gyis med pas nyon mongs kyi yod pa dang med pa rang bzhin gyis mi 'grub pa'i rgyu mtshan gang yin snyam na/

It has already been explained in such places as the examination of the self that the existence and nonexistence of the self cannot be established essentially in any way. Since the self does not exist, the existence and nonexistence of the afflictions that depend on it cannot be established essentially in any way either. Now, suppose someone thought as follows: Why is the fact that the existence and nonexistence of the self are not established essentially a reason for the fact that the existence and nonexistence of the afflictions are not established essentially?
bdag gi yod nyid med nyid ni/ / ci ltar bur yang 'grub pa med/ / de med nyon mongs rnams kyi ni/ / yod nyid med nyid ci ltar 'grub/ /
3. The self’s existence or nonexistence Has in no way been established. Without that, how could the afflictions’ Existence or nonexistence be established?
nyon mongs rnams ni rtsig ngos kyi ri mo bzhin du bskyed par bya ba rtog pa la ltos pas nyon mongs 'di dag rten gang zhig gi yin par 'gyur gyi rten med par med do/ /
Since, just like murals on a wall, the afflictions depend on the conceptualization that gives rise to them, what could the basis of these afflictions be? Without a basis, they cannot exist.
nyon mongs 'di dag gang gi yin/ / de yang grub pa yod ma yin/ / 'ga' med par ni gang gi yang / / nyon mongs pa dag yod ma yin/ /
4. The one to whom the afflictions belong Has not been established as existent. Without anyone to whom they belong, There are no afflictions of anyone.

rten de yang brtags pa na bdag gam sems can gcig yin na de ni sngar rgyas par bkag zin pas rang bzhin gyis grub pa yod pa ma yin no/ / rten bdag gam gang zag 'ga' yang med par ni rten gang gi yang nyon mongs pa dag rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no/ /

On analysis, the basis must be either a self or a single sentient being. But as previous extensive refutations have shown, they do not exist essentially. Without anyone—the self or the person as a basis—no afflictions exist essentially in any basis.
gnyis pa [sems rten du med pa'i rtags kyis dgag pa] ni/
1.1.2.2 Refutation through arguments that the mind is not a basis

gal te nyon mongs kyi rten sngar grub pa yang khas mi len la rten du gyur pa'i bdag kyang med mod kyang / nyon mongs can gyi sems la brten nas nyon mongs rnams skye bar 'gyur la sems de yang nyon mongs dang lhan cig skye'o zhes zer ro/ /

Suppose someone argued as follows: Although it is not maintained that the basis of the afflictions exists prior to their existence, and although the self does not exist as the basis, since the afflictions arise depending on the afflicted mind, such a mind and the afflictions arise simultaneously.
rang lus lta bzhin nyon mongs rnams/ / nyon mongs can la rnam lngar med/ / rang lus lta bzhin nyon mongs can/ / nyon mongs pa la rnam lngar med/ /
5. Just as one views one’s own body, the afflictions are Not in the afflicted in the fivefold way. Just as one views one’s own body, the afflicted is Not in the afflictions in the fivefold way.

rang gi lus la lta ba'i 'jig ltas bzung ba'i yul gyi bdag de rnam pa lngar dpyad pa na yod pa min pa de bzhin du/ nyon mongs par byed pa'i nyon mongs pa rnams nyon mongs par bya ba'i nyon mongs can la rnam pa lngar med do/ / de la nyon mongs can gyi sems de nyid sems byung nyon mongs pa yin no zhes pa mi rigs te gzhan du na byed pa po dang las gnyis gcig tu 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de gnyis rang mtshan gyis gzhan du yang med de gzhan du ni mi ltos par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / rang bzhin gyis gcig dang tha dad gang du yang med pa'i phyir phan tshun rten dang brten pa dang ldan pa yang ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / rang gi lus la lta ba'i 'jig ltas bzung ba'i bdag rnam pa lngar med pa bzhin du nyon mongs can gyi sems kyang nyon mongs pa la rnam pa lngar med pa sngar bshad pa bzhin du sbyar te 'di ni zhar la byung ba'o/ /

Just as, upon analysis, the self—which is the object grasped when one views one’s own body through the view of the transitory aggregates—does not exist in the fivefold way, the afflictions which afflict those who have afflictions—the afflicted ones—do not exist in the afflicted ones in the fivefold way. Here, to say that the afflicted mind just is the afflicted mental episode does not make sense, because in that case agent and action would be identical. [386] These two, on the other hand, are not different through their own characteristics, because in that case they would be independent. Since they are neither essentially identical nor essentially different, neither can inherently be the basis of the other, be based on the other, or possess the other. Just as the self, which is grasped when one views one’s own body through the view of the transitory aggregates, does not exist in the fivefold way, the afflicted mind does not exist in the afflictions in the fivefold way, as has been previously explained. But this has been a digression.
gsum pa [rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag] ni/
1.1.3 Refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the cause
gal te nyon mongs pa rnams rang bzhin gyis yod de/ de'i rgyu sdug mi sdug phyin ci log rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Suppose one said that the afflictions exist essentially because their causes—the pleasant, the unpleasant, and confusion—exist essentially.
sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / rang bzhin las ni yod min na/ / sdug dang mi sdug phyin ci log / brten nas nyon mongs gang dag yin/ /
6. The pleasant, the unpleasant, and the errors Do not exist through essence. What afflictions could depend On the pleasant, unpleasant, or errors?

yul sdug pa dang mi sdug pa dang phyin ci log rnams ni rang gi rang bzhin las te ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa min te rten 'brel yin pa'i phyir dang de rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'gog par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir sdug mi sdug phyin ci log la brten nas nyon mongs gang dag byung ba de dag ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa min no/ /

Pleasant objects, unpleasant objects, and objects of error do not exist through their own essence—that is, they do not exist inherently, because they are dependently originated. Their essential existence will be refuted below. Therefore, the afflictions that arise in dependence on the pleasant, the unpleasant, and error do not exist essentially.
bzhi pa [dmigs pa rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags kyis dgag] ni/
1.1.4 Refutation through arguments from the essencelessness of the object
nyon mongs pa rnams rang bzhin gyis yod de de dag gi dmigs pa drug rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/
Now, suppose one said that the afflictions exist essentially because their six objects exist essentially.
gzugs sgra ro dang reg pa dang / / dri dang chos dang rnam drug ni/ / gzhi ste 'dod chags zhe sdang dang / / gti mug gi ni yid par brtags/ /
7. Material form, sound, taste, touch, Smell, and phenomena/2/: These six Are thought of as the foundation of Desire, aversion, and confusion.

de la gzugs su rung bas gzugs dang sgrogs shing ston pas sgra dang bro zhing myang bas ro dang brngub cing bsnam par bya bas dri dang reg par bya bas reg bya dang*/ mtshan nyid 'dzin pas sam chos kyi mchog mya ngan las 'das pa 'dzin pas chos te rnam pa drug ni 'dir gnas pas gzhi ste dmigs pa yin no/ / gang gi na sems dga' bar byed pas 'dod chags dang sems sun 'byin par byed pas zhe sdang dang sems gti mug tu byed pas gti mug gi ni gzhi yin te/ de dag la sdug pa'i rnam par sgro btags pas 'dod chags dang mi sdug pa'i rnam par sgro btags pas zhe sdang dang rtag bdag la sogs par sgro btags pas gti mug skye'o/ / de rnams khyod kyis nyon mongs pa'i gzhir btags pa bden mod kyang gzugs dang sgra dang ro dang reg pa dang dri dang chos dag 'ba' zhig ste btags pa tsam tu zad kyi rang bzhin gyis grub pa med do/ /

Here in virtue of being physical, there is material form; in virtue of making noise, there is sound; in virtue of being sniffed, there is smell; in virtue of being savored, there is taste; in virtue of being felt, there is touch; and in virtue of having characteristics, or in virtue of containing the supreme phenomenon—nirvana—something is a phenomenon. Since these six kinds of representation are present here, these are the bases—that is, the objects. Objects of what? That which pleases the mind is the basis of desire, that which displeases the mind is the basis of aversion, and that which confuses the mind is the basis of confusion. That is because when these are imagined to be pleasant, desire arises; when these are imagined to be unpleasant, aversion arises; and when they are imagined to be permanent, to be selves, etc., confusion arises. Suppose someone now argued as follows: Although it is true that you have posited them as the basis of the afflictions, [387] material form, sound, taste, touch, smell, and phenomena exist only—that is, merely—as imputed but they are not essentially existent. If they are essenceless, how could they be perceived?
gzugs sgra ro dang reg pa dang / / dri dang chos dag 'ba' zhig ste/ / dri za'i grong khyer lta ba dang / / smig rgyu rmi lam 'dra ba yin/ /
8. Material form, sound, taste, touch, Smell, and phenomena: These six Are only like a city of gandharvas or Like a mirage or a dream.
gal te rang bzhin med na dmigs pa 'di ji ltar yin zhe na/ rang bzhin med bzhin du dmigs pa ni dri za'i grong khyer lta bu dang smig rgyu dang rmi lam dang 'dra ba yin no/ /
Though they are essenceless, they are perceived, just like a city of gandharvas, a mirage, or a dream.
lnga pa [rgyu rang bzhin gyis med pa'i rtags gzhan gyis dgag pa]
1.1.5 Refutation through another analysis of the essencelessness of the cause
['di] la gnyis/ chags sdang gi rgyu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / gti mug gi rgyu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the cause of attachment and aversion; and the refutation of the essential existence of the cause of confusion.
dang po [chags sdang gi rgyu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the cause of attachment and aversion
sgyu ma'i skyes ba lta bu dang / / gzugs brnyan 'dra ba de dag la / / sdug pa dang ni mi sdug pa/ / 'byung bar yang ni ga la 'gyur/ /
9. How could the Pleasant and unpleasant arise In those that are like an illusory person And like a reflection?

gang gi tshe de dag dri za'i grong khyer la sogs pa ltar phyin ci log las rang bzhin gyis med bzhin du der dmigs pa 'ba' zhig tu zad pa de'i tshe/ yul drug sgyu ma'i skyes bu lta bu dang gzugs brnyan 'dra ba de dag la ste de dag gi sdug pa'i mtshan ma dang / mi sdug pa'i mtshan ma rang bzhin gyis yod pa 'byung bar yang ni ga la 'gyur te mi 'gyur te rten log pa'i dbang gis byung bas so/ / ji skad du/ ngar 'dzin las byung phung po rnams/ / ngar 'dzin de ni don du brdzun/ / gang gi sa bon brdzun pa de'i/ / skye ba bden pa ga la zhig / ces gsungs so/ / de dag ni rten log pa yin pas sdug mi sdug gi mtshan ma brdzun par ston pa'i rigs pa'o/ /

Since, just like such things as the city of gandharvas, although they are essenceless, they are erroneously perceived as having essences, the six objects are just like an illusory person or a reflection. So, how could representations of them as pleasant or as unpleasant arise essentially? They could not, because they arise in dependence on an erroneous basis. As it is said, Self-grasping gives rise to the aggregates. But self-grasping is in fact unreal. How can something real arise The seed of which is unreal? [Ratnāvalī I: 29] These are the arguments that demonstrate the falsity of the representations of the pleasant and the unpleasant because they have erroneous bases.
gang la brten nas sdug pa zhes/ / bdags par bya ba mi sdug pa/ / sdug la ma ltos yod min pas/ / de phyir sdug pa 'thad ma yin/ /
10. The unpleasant, depending on which The pleasant is imputed, Cannot exist without depending on the pleasant. Therefore, the pleasant is not tenable.

de ni phan tshun rten pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis kyang brdzun par bstan par bya ste/ 'di na sdug mi sdug ni ring thung ltar phan tshun ltos nas yod kyi ma ltos par med do/ / de lta na mi sdug pa gang la brten pa ste ltos nas sdug pa zhes gdags pa ste gzhag par bya ba'i ltos sa mi sdug pa ni/ sdug pa la mi ltos par yod pa min pas de'i phyir yul sdug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'thad pa ma yin na ste/ yul mi sdug pa sdug pa la ltos na ngo bo nyid kyis med la/ ltos sa ngo bo nyid kyis med na ltos chos ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ /

Now, they are also shown to be false on the grounds that they are mutually dependent. This is because, like the long and short, the pleasant and unpleasant exist in mutual dependence, but cannot exist independently. Thus the unpleasant, which is the basis of its dependence—that depending on which the pleasant is designated, that is posited—cannot exist without depending on the pleasant. Therefore, it is not tenable that the pleasant object exists inherently. Since the unpleasant object depends on the pleasant object, it cannot exist inherently either. It would be inconsistent for the basis of dependence not to exist inherently and the dependent phenomenon to exist inherently.
gang la brten nas mi sdug par/ / gdags par bya ba sdug pa ni/ / mi sdug ma ltos yod min pas/ / de phyir mi sdug 'thad ma yin/ /
11. The pleasant, depending on which The unpleasant is imputed, Cannot exist without depending on the unpleasant, Therefore, the unpleasant is not tenable.

yul sdug pa gang la brten pa ste ltos nas mi sdug par gdags pa ste gzhag par bya ba'i ltos sa sdug pa ni/ mi sdug pa la mi ltos par yod pa min pas de'i phyir mi sdug pa ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa 'thad pa ma yin no/ /

[388] The pleasant object, which is the basis of its dependence—that depending on which the unpleasant is designated—cannot exist without depending on the unpleasant. Therefore it is untenable that the unpleasant exists inherently.
sdug pa yod pa ma yin na/ / 'dod chags yod par ga la 'gyur/ / mi sdug yod pa ma yin na/ / zhe sdang yod par dag la 'gyur/ /
12. If there is no pleasant, How could there be desire? If there is no unpleasant, How could there be aversion?

de ltar sdug pa'i mtshan ma ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin na de'i rgyu can gyi 'dod chags yod par ga la 'gyur la/ mi sdug pa'i mtshan ma ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin na de'i rgyu can gyi zhe sdang yod par ga la 'gyur te rgyu med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Therefore, since the representation of the pleasant does not exist inherently, how could desire, which is caused by it, exist inherently? And since the representation of the unpleasant does not exist inherently, how could aversion, which is caused by it, exist inherently for it has no cause?
gnyis pa [gti mug gi rgyu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa]
1.1.5.2 Refutation of the essential existence of the cause of confusion

['di] la bzhi/ phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / phyin ci log dang ldan pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag/phyin ci log gi yul yod med brtags la dgag / de ltar 'gog pa don che bar bstan pa'o/ /

This section has four parts: the refutation of the essential existence of error, the refutation of the essential existence of one who has error, the refutation through examination of whether or not the object of error exists, and the demonstration of the great value of these refutations.
dang po [phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag]
1.1.5.2.1 Refutation of the essential existence of error
['di] la gsum/ rtag 'dzin phyin ci log tu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / mi rtag par 'dzin pa phyin ci ma log par rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / 'dzin pa tsam rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa'o/ //

This section has three parts: the refutation of the grasping of permanence as essentially erroneous, the refutation of the grasping of impermanence as essentially nonerroneous, and the refutation of the essential existence of mere grasping.
dang po [rtag 'dzin phyin ci log tu rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.1.1 Refutation of the grasping of permanence as essentially erroneous
gal te mi rtag rtag pa zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la mi rtag yod min pas/ / 'dzin pa'ang ci ltar log pa yin/ /
13. If to grasp onto the view “The impermanent is permanent” were an error, Since that which is empty is not impermanent, How could that grasping be an error?

'dir phyin ci log bzhi ste/ phung po lnga po skad cig re re la 'jig cing mi rtag pa la rtag go snyam pa dang / nyer len gyi phung po sdug bsngal ba la bde'o snyam pa dang*/lus mi gtsang ba la gtsang bar 'dzin pa dang*/ phung po bdag gi mtshan nyid dang mi mthun pa la bdag tu 'dzin pa'o/ / de bzhi ni gti mug gi rgyu yin no/ / de la bdag tu 'dzin pa ni gti mug gi rigs 'dra snga mas phyi ma'i rgyu byed la gzhan gsum ni lhan cig byed pa'i rkyen du'ang 'gyur ro/ / gal te phung po rtag pas stong pa'i mi rtag pa la rtag pa'o zhes de ltar 'dzin pa phyin ci log yin no zhes rnam par 'jog na/ phung po ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong pa la mi rtag par rang gi ngo bos yod pa min pas phung po rtag par 'dzin pa ji ltar na phyin ci log tu rang bzhin gyis grub pa yin te min no/ / de bzhin du lhag ma gsum la'ang sbyar te/ gal te sdug bsngal bde'o zhe/ // de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la sdug bsngal yod min pas/ / 'dzin pa ji ltar log pa yin/ / zhes pa'i tshul gyis so/ / 'grel chen gzhan gnyis su/ gal te mi rtag rtag pa zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la rtag pa yod min pas / / 'dzin pa ji ltar log ma yin/ / zhes 'byung ngo / /

In this context there are four errors: regarding the five impermanent aggregates, which cease to exist every moment, as permanent; regarding the suffering appropriated aggregates as happy; grasping the impure body as pure; and grasping the aggregates, the characteristics of which are heterogeneous with those of self, as the self. These four are the causes of confusion. As far as self-grasping is concerned, earlier similar episodes of ignorance give rise to later episodes. The other three also constitute supporting conditions of confusion. Suppose one asserted that grasping the impermanent aggregates, which are empty of permanence, as permanent is erroneous. Then, since the aggregates, which are empty of inherent existence, are not inherently impermanent, how could grasping them as permanent be essentially erroneous? It could not be! [389] We can treat the other three in the same way, mutatis mutandis: If to grasp onto the view “That which is suffering is happy” were an error, Since that which is empty is not suffering, How could that grasping be an error? The other two great commentaries read this verse as follows: If to grasp onto the view “The impermanent is permanent” were an error, Since that which is empty is not permanent, How could that grasping not be an error? [Buddhapālita 268a, Prajñāpradīpa 223a]/3/
gnyis pa [mi rtag par 'dzin pa phyin ci ma log par rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.1.2 Refutation of the grasping of permanence as essentially nonerroneous
gal te mi rtag rtag go zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la mi rtag pa'o zhes/ / 'dzin pa'ang ci ltar log ma yin/ /
14. If to grasp onto the view “The impermanent is permanent” were an error, Why is grasping onto the view “That which is empty is impermanent” not an error?

gal te mi rtag pa la rtag go zhes de ltar 'dzin pa phyin ci log yin no zhes rnam par 'jog na/ dngos po rang bzhin gyis med pa la mi rtag pa yang rang bzhin gyis med pas rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pa la mi rtag pa'o zhes 'dzin pa'ang ji ltar na phyin ci log ma yin par rang bzhin gyis yod de med do/ // mi rtag par 'dzin pa phyin ci ma log pa'i shes par rang bzhin gyis grub na mi rtag pa shes bya phyin ci ma log par rang bzhin gyis grub dgos pa'i rigs pa'o/ / de ltar phung po la ltos te rtag mi rtag gnyis ka shes bya phyin ci ma log par ngo bo nyid kyis med pa na de gnyis las ma gtogs pa'i shes bya phyin ci ma log pa ngo bo nyid kyis grub pa ci yang med do// // de med pa'i phyir shes bya phyin ci ma log pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa ci la ltos nas phyin ci log tu 'gyur ba gang zhig yod/de bzhin du lhag ma gsum la yang sbyar te/ gal te sdug bsngal bde'o zhes/ / de ltar 'dzin pa log yin na/ / stong la sdug bsngal nyid do zhes/ / 'dzin pa'ang ji ltar log ma yin/ / zhes pa'i tshul gyis so/ / rtag 'dzin phyin ci log tu rang bzhin gyis grub na mi rtag pa phyin ci ma log par rang bzhin gyis grub dgos zhes pa'i rigs pa'o/ /

Suppose one asserted that grasping that which is impermanent as permanent were erroneous. Then, since things that do not exist essentially are not essentially impermanent, how could grasping that which is essentially empty as impermanent be essentially nonerroneous? It could not be! This is an argument according to which if the cognitive process grasping impermanence were essentially nonerroneous, then impermanence would have to be an essentially nonerroneous object of knowledge. So with respect to the aggregates, neither permanence nor impermanence is an inherently nonerroneous object of knowledge; and apart from these two, there are no other inherently nonerroneous objects of knowledge. Since there are none, with respect to what could that essentially nonerroneous object of knowledge be erroneous? We can treat the other three in the same way, mutatis mutandis: If to grasp onto the view “That which is suffering is happy” were an error, Why is grasping onto the view, “That which is empty is suffering” not an error? This is an argument to the effect that if grasping permanence were essentially erroneous, then grasping impermanence would have to be essentially nonerroneous.
gsum pa ['dzin pa tsam rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.5.2.1.3 Refutation of the essential existence of mere grasping

gal te rtag 'dzin phyin ci log tu rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa de lta na'ang re zhig 'dzin pa tsam ni rang bzhin gyis yod do/ / de la 'dzin pa ni bya ba'i rang bzhin no/ / de la yang gdon mi za bar sgrub byed rtag pa la sogs pa'i byed pa dang / bdag gam sems kyi byed pa po dang gzugs la sogs pa'i las kyang yod dgos so/ / de rnams rang bzhin gyis grub na kho bo'i 'dod pa grub bo zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Although grasping permanence is not essentially erroneous, mere grasping exists essentially. [390] In this context, grasping has the nature of being an action. Moreover, it must undoubtedly have an instrument such as permanence, an agent such as the self or the mind, and objects such as material form as the ground of its existence. Since these exist essentially, my assertion has been proven!
gang gis 'dzin dang 'dzin gang dang / / 'dzin pa po dang gang gzung ba/ / thams cad nye bar zhi ba ste/ / de phyir 'dzin pa yod ma yin/ /
15. That by means of which there is grasping, and the grasping, And the grasper, and all that is grasped: All are being alleviated. It follows that there is no grasping.

byed pa gang gis 'dzin pa dang 'dzin pa gang yin pa'i bya ba dang 'dzin par byed pa po dang gang bzung ba'i las thams cad nye bar zhi ba ste rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa de'i phyir 'dzin pa tsam rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin no/ / byed pa med par ni/ gal te mi rtag rtag pa zhes/ / zhes sogs dang

The instrument by means of which there is grasping; the grasping that is the action; the agent of the grasping; and the object that is grasped: All are being completely alleviated. That is, they are essentially non-arisen. Therefore, mere grasping does not exist essentially. The nonexistence of the instrument has already been demonstrated through If to grasp onto the view “The impermanent is permanent” were an error, Since that which is empty is not impermanent, How could that grasping be an error? [13]
byed pa po med par ni/ bdag gi yod nyid med nyid ni/ / zhes sogs dang /

The nonexistence of the agent has already been demonstrated through The self’s existence or nonexistence Has in no way been established. Without that, how could the afflictions’ Existence or nonexistence be established? [3]
gzung bya med par ni/gzugs sgra ro dang reg pa dang*/ / zhes sogs kyis bstan zin to//

The nonexistence of the object of grasping has already been demonstrated through Material form, sound, taste, touch, Smell, and cognitive objects: These six Are thought of as the foundation of Desire, aversion, and confusion. [7]
yang na rab byed dang po la sogs pa rnams kyis byed pa dang dngos po dang byed pa po dang las thams cad ma skyes par bstan pas 'dzin pa med do/ /
Alternately, in such places as the first chapter, instrument, entity, agent, and object have all been shown to be non-arisen; so there is no grasping.
gnyis pa [phyin ci log dang ldan pa rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of one who has error

gal te phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis yod de phyin ci log dang ldan pa'i lhas byin rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ 'di dgag pa la gsum/ ldan chos rang bzhin gyis med pas ldan pa po rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag/phyin ci log gi rten rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag / phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis skyes pa dgag pa'o/ /

Now suppose someone said that error exists essentially, because Lehjin, who commits errors, exists essentially. This refutation has three parts: the refutation of the essential existence of the possessor in virtue of the essencelessness of the possessed phenomena, the refutation of the essential existence of the basis of error, and the refutation of error arising essentially.
dang po [ldan chos rang bzhin gyis med pas ldan pa po rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.2.1 Refutation of the essential existence of the possessor in virtue of the essencelessness of the possessed phenomena
log pa'am yang dag nyid du ni/ / 'dzin pa yod pa ma yin na/ / gang la phyin ci log yod cing / / gang la phyin ci ma log yod/ /
16. Since there is no grasping, Whether erroneous or correct, Who will come to be in error? Who will have no error?

'dzin pa'i yan lag tu gyur pa'i byed pa dang byed pa po dang las su bya ba rnams rang bzhin gyis med par sngar bshad zin pa de'i phyir phyin ci log pa'am yang dag pa nyid du ste phyin ci ma log par 'dzin pa rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin na rten gyi gang zag gang la phyin ci log dang gang la phyin ci ma log pa rang bzhin gyis yod de med do/ /

Since, as has been explained earlier, the components of grasping, including the instrument, the agent, and the object, all lack essence, and since there is no essentially existent grasping, whether erroneous or correct—that is, nonerroneous—who, that is, what person as a basis, could be essentially in error, or who could essentially have no error? There is no one!
gnyis pa [phyin ci log gi rten rang bzhin gyis grub pa dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.2.2 Refutation of the essential existence of the basis of error
phyin ci log tu gyur pa la/ / phyin ci log dag mi srid de/ / phyin ci log tu ma gyur la'ang / / phyin ci log dag mi srid do/ /
17. One who is already in error Cannot commit error. One who is not in error Cannot commit error.

gzhan yang phyin ci log 'di gang zag gi rten la 'dod na phyin ci log tu gyur zin pa sogs gsum las mi 'da' la de yang phyin ci log tu gyur zin pa la phyin ci log dag rang bzhin gyis yod pa mi srid de de srid na phyin ci log tu 'dzin pa por 'jog pa'i phyin ci log las don gzhan pa'i phyin ci log dang ldan dgos na de la phyi ma de mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ / phyin ci log tu ma gyur pa'i gang zag la phyin ci log dag mi srid de/ sangs rgyas la yang phyin ci log yod par thal ba'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, if one maintained that error is in the person as the basis, [391] one could not escape from three alternatives, such as its being in one who has already come to be in error. It is impossible for one who is already in error to commit error, because if that were possible, then the error in virtue of which one is said to be grasping erroneously would have to be different from the error one commits. But this just is not necessary. One who is not in error cannot commit error because the absurd consequence would follow that even a buddha could commit error.
phyin ci log tu 'gyur bzhin la'ang / / phyin ci log dag mi srid do/ / gang la phyin ci log srid pa/ / bdag nyid kyis ni rnam par dpyod/ /
18. One who is committing error Cannot commit error. Who can commit error? Examine this on your own!

phyin ci log tu gyur bzhin pa la phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis grub pa mi srid de/ phyin ci log gi bya ba zhig pa dang ma skyes pa las ma gtogs pa'i phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis med pa'i phyir dang / cha 'ga' zhig phyin ci log dang 'ga' zhig ma log pa'i gyur bzhin pa yang brtag pa snga ma gnyis kyi skyon las mi 'da' ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar phyin ci log gi rten dus gsum po gang la yang phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis med na/ rten gang la phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis srid ces bdag nyid kyis ni gzu bo'i blos rnam par dpyod cig /

It is impossible for one who is committing error to commit error essentially, because apart from the act of committing error that has disintegrated and the act of committing error that is yet to arise, there is no essentially existing error. The one who is committing error would be partly in error and partly not in error, and this is not free of the problems demonstrated in the previous two analyses. Therefore, since error does not exist essentially in a basis in any of the three temporal periods, in what basis is it possible for error to exist essentially? You should analyze this with an impartial mind.
gsum pa [phyin ci log rang bzhin gyis skyes pa dgag pa] ni/
1.1.5.2.2.3 Refutation of error arising essentially
phyin ci log rnams ma skyes na/ / ji ltar bur na yod par 'gyur/ / phyir ci log rnams skye med na/ / phyir ci log can ga la yod/ /
19. If error is not arisen, How could it come to exist? If error has not arisen, How could one be in error?

gzhan yang phyin ci log rnams rang bzhin gyis ma skyes na ji lta bur na rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur te mi 'gyur la/ phyin ci log rnams rang bzhin gyis skye ba med na phyin ci log pa can gyi gang zag rang bzhin gyis grub pa ga la yod de med do/

Moreover, since errors are not essentially arisen, how could they be essentially existent? They could not! Since errors are not essentially arisen, how could a person be one who is essentially in error? One could not be!
dngos po bdag las mi skye ste/ / gzhan las skye ba nyid ma yin/ / bdag dang gzhan las kyang min na/ / phyin ci log can ga la yod/ /
20. Since an entity does not arise from itself, Nor from another, Nor from another and itself, How could one be in error?

rang bzhin gyis mi skye ba'i rgyu mtshan ni/ phyin ci log gi dngos po bdag las mi skye ste gzhan las skye ba nyid kyang ma yin la bdag dang gzhan tshogs pa las kyang skye ba min na/ na ci log rang bzhin gyis med pa'i phyir phyin ci log pa can gyi gang zag rang bzhin gyis grub pa ga la yod de med do/

The reason that they are not essentially arisen is this: Since no entity—such as error—arises from itself or from another or from both self and other, error does not exist essentially. So how could the person who is in error exist essentially? He could not!
gsum pa [phyin ci log gi yul yod med brtags la dgag] ni/
1.1.5.2.3 Refutation through examination of whether or not the object of error exists
gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang / / rtag dang bde ba yod na ni/ / bdag dang gtsang dang rtag pa dang / / bde ba phyin ci log ma yin/ /
21. If the self and the pure, The permanent and happiness existed, The self, the pure, the permanent, And happiness would not be erroneous.
gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang rtag pa dang bde ba rang bzhin gyis yod na ni shes bya phyin ci log ma yin par 'gyur te/ bdag med pa la sogs pa bzhin no/ / zhes gzhan don grub pa tsam gyi dpe'o/ /

If the self, the pure, the permanent, and happiness existed essentially, it would follow that they would not be erroneous objects of knowledge [392] just like such things as selflessness. This example demonstrates the mere existence of the others.
gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang*/ / rtag dang bde ba med na ni/ / bdag med mi gtsang mi rtag dang*/ / sdug bsngal yod pa ma yin no/ /
22. If the self and the pure, The permanent and happiness did not exist, The nonself, the impure, the impermanent, And suffering would not exist.

gal te bdag dang gtsang ba dang rtag pa dang bde ba rang bzhin gyis med na ni bdag med pa dang mi gtsang ba dang mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal yang rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin te/ dgag bya med na de bkag pa bden par mi 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ / de lta yin na bdag med rang gi ngo bos med pa'i phyir bdag med pa la sogs pa bzhi rang bzhin gyis yod pa yang shes bya phyin ci log tu 'gyur te bdag la sogs pa bzhin no/ // de'i phyir thar pa 'dod pas phyin ci log brgyad char spang bar bya'o/ /

If the self, the pure, the permanent, and happiness were essentially nonexistent, the nonself, the impure, the impermanent, and suffering would also be essentially nonexistent, because in the absence an object of negation, its negation cannot be truly existent. Since the selfless does not exist inherently, the essential existences of the four, including selflessness, are also erroneous objects of knowledge, just as such things as the self are. Therefore, those who aspire to liberation should eliminate all eight errors.
bzhi pa [de ltar 'gog pa don che bar bstan pa] ni/
1.1.5.2.4 Demonstration of the great value of these refutations
de ltar phyin ci log 'gags pas/ / ma rig pa ni 'gag par 'gyur/ / ma rig 'gags par gyur na ni/ / 'du byed la sogs 'gag par 'gyur/ /
23. Thus through eliminating the errors Ignorance is eliminated. When ignorance is eliminated, Such things as the actions are eliminated.

sngar bshad pa ltar phyin ci log rang gi ngo bos yod med rigs pas dpyod pa 'di ni don chen po can yin te/ sngar bshad pa de ltar rnal 'byor pas phyin ci log ma dmigs pas phyin ci log 'gag par 'gyur la de 'gags pas de'i rgyu can gyi ma rig pa 'gag par 'gyur ro/ / ma rig 'gags par gyur na ni 'du byed la sogs pa'i srid pa'i yan lag phyi ma thams cad 'gag par 'gyur te de rnams ma rig pa'i rgyu can yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

As we explained earlier, the rational inquiry into whether or not error exists inherently is very important. This, as we have also previously explained, is because the practitioner eliminates the errors through not objectifying them. Through their elimination, the ignorance they cause is also eliminated. When ignorance is eliminated, all of the limbs of cyclic existence, including the actions, are eliminated because they are all caused by ignorance.
gnyis pa [de'i sgrub byed de spong ba'i thabs rang bzhin gyis yod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2 Refutation of the essential existence of the methods of their elimination as arguments for their existence

gal te de lta na ma rig pa la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa spong ba rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i phyir nyon mongs pa rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pas srid pa'i rgyun rang bzhin gyis yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Since the elimination of such things as ignorance exists essentially, the afflictions exist essentially. Therefore, the continuum of cyclic existence exists essentially.
gal te la la'i nyon mongs pa/ / gang dag rang bzhin gyis yod na/ / ci ltar bar na spong bar 'gyur/ / yod pa su zhig spong bar byed/ /
24. If any afflictions of anyone Existed essentially, How could they be relinquished? Who could relinquish the existent?

nyon mongs spong ba rang bzhin gyis yod na de ltar 'gyur yang de ni med de 'di ltar gal te gang zag la la'i nyon mongs pa gang dag rang bzhin gyis yod na ji lta bur na gnyen pos spong bar 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te/ rang bzhin gyis yod pa lam su zhig gis spong bar 'gyur zhes pa bzlog par mi nus pa'i phyir te rang bzhin la ldog pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the elimination of the afflictions existed essentially, this would indeed be the case, but it is not. If any affliction of any person existed essentially, then how could it be eliminated through the antidote? It could not. What path could eliminate that which is essentially existent? That is to say, it could not be eliminated, because essence cannot be changed.
gal te la la'i nyon mongs pa/ / gang dag rang zhin gyis med na/ / ci lta bur na spong bar 'gyur/ / med pa su zhig spong bar byed/ /
25. If any afflictions of anyone Were essentially nonexistent, How could they be relinquished? Who could relinquish the nonexistent?

gal te gang zag la la'i nyon mongs pa gang dag rang bzhin gyis med na ji lta bur na spong bar 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa ltar na rang bzhin ni gtan med pas gtan med ni gnyen po su zhig gis spong bar byed de mi byed pa'i phyir te me la grang ba sus kyang zlog mi nus pa bzhin no/ / rang lugs la rang bzhin gyis med pa la gnyen pos spang bya spong ba ches 'thad par 'dod mod kyang pha rol po la rang bzhin gyis yod pa la spong ba mi 'thad par ston pa'i skabs su ni tshul gnyis te sngar bshad pa dang spong ba rang gi mtshan nyid kyis khas blangs pa'i sgo nas skyon brjod pa'o/ / tshul de dag de 'dra ba'i rigs kun la shes par bya'o/ /

If any afflictions of any person were essentially nonexistent [393], how could they be eliminated? They could not be, because on the view according to which things exist through their own characteristics, if something is essentially nonexistent, then it would be absolutely nonexistent. By what antidote could the absolutely nonexistent be eliminated? Nobody can undo the coldness of fire! Although in our own system, it is completely tenable that an antidote can eliminate that which is to be eliminated in the context of essencelessness, when demonstrating to the opponent that it is not tenable in the context of essential existence for such a thing to be eliminated, they are charged with errors in two ways: the one previously explained and the one according to which they accept elimination through its own characteristic. One should understand that these modes apply in all similar cases.
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar chags sogs kyi nyon mongs rgyu rkyen dang bcas pa dang rtag mi rtag sogs kyi yul yul can rnams rang bzhin med par rigs pas gtan la phab pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / de ltar gsung rab las bshad pa thams cad rab byed 'dis bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam smos na/ lhag pa'i bsam pa brtan pas zhus pa las/ rigs kyi bu 'di ni dge slong dang dge slong ma dang dge bsnyen dang dge bsnyen ma kha cig ma skyes shing ma byung ba'i chos rnams la mi sdug par yid la byed cing / mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba dang stong pa dang bdag med par yid la byed pa gang yin pa de dag kyang de dang 'dra bar blta bar bya'o/ / nga ni mi blun po de dag la lam sgom pa yin no zhes mi smra ste de dag ni log par zhugs pa zhes bya'o/ / zhes sgyu ma'i bud med mthong ba na bud med dngos su 'khrul te 'dod chags skyes pa na bud med de la mi sdug pa sogs su yid la byed pa dper byas nas gsungs shing / yang de nyid las/ rigs kyi bu byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams ni 'dod chags kyi mtha' mi shes nas 'dod chags kyi mtha'i 'jigs pas skrag ste 'dod chags kyi mtha' las nges par 'byung ba 'tshol lo/ / zhe sdang gi mtha' ci yang med pa'i mthar ma shes nas zhe sdang gi mtha'i 'jigs pas skrag cing ci yang med pa'i mtha' las nges par 'byung ba yongs su tshol lo/ / gti mug gi mtha' stong pa nyid kyi mthar ma shes nas gti mug gi mtha'i 'jigs pas skrag ste stong pa nyid kyi mtha' las nges par 'byung ba yongs su tshol bar byed do/ / nga ni mi blun po de dag la lam bsgom pa yin no zhes mi smra ste/ de dag ni yongs su log par zhugs pa zhes bya'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the arguments that establish that the afflictions such as desire have causes and conditions and that objects such as permanence and impermanence as well as their subjects are essenceless can also be corroborated by profound sūtras, and that all of those discussions are explained by this chapter. The Sthirādhyāśāyaparivarta-sūtra says, Son of noble lineage! Certain bikshus, bikshunis upāsakas, and upāsikās consider unarisen phenomena—those which have not come into existence—to be unpleasant. Those who consider them to be impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless also see them in the same way. I do not say that these idiots are meditating on the path. Instead I say that they have fallen completely into error. [m Do sde dza 165b] It then presents the following example: A person sees an illusory woman and mistakes her for a real woman and desire arises. The person then contemplates the unpleasantness of women [ibid.]. Then it says Son of noble lineage: Foolish common people who do not know the end of desire [394] and who fear the end of desire nonetheless search for the end of desire. Not knowing the end of aversion to be endless, fearing the end of aversion, they nonetheless seek the end of endless aversion. Not knowing the end of confusion to be empty of ends, they fear the end of confusion; nonetheless, they seek the end of that which is empty of ends. I do not say that these idiots are meditating on the path. Instead I say that have fallen completely into error. [166a]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

de ltar rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pa la yul sdug pa sogs dang kun tu rtog pa las/ nyon mongs rnams 'byung ba dang rtag sogs su 'dzin pa la phyin ci log ma log gi rnam dbye dang /nyon mongs spong ba la sogs pa gtan mi rung la rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod pas stong pa la de dag thams cad ches 'thad pa'i tshul la nges pa drang bar bya'o/ /

So, according to those who think that things exist through their own characteristics, it is not possible that afflictions arise from such things as pleasant objects and from conceptualizing them; nor can they distinguish between the erroneous and the nonerroneous in the context of grasping things as permanent, etc.; nor can they abandon the afflictions. One should ascertain, however, that for those according to whom things are empty of inherent existence, all of this is completely tenable.
phyin mi ci log brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu gsum pa'o// //
This is the twenty-third chapter called “the examination of errors.”
phyin ci log brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa nyer lnga'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa gsum pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-third chapter, having twenty-five verses, called “the examination of errors.”

d.crumb: *XXIV. Examination of the Four Noble Truths

f.d: CHAPTER XXIV. Examination of the Four Noble Truths
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba
We now begin the second part of the demonstration that the dependently originated is empty by nature: the rebuttal of refutations.
['di] la gnyis/ bden pa brtag pa dang / myang 'das brtag pa'o/ /
