Moreover, if you maintain that things exist essentially, then no person would perform virtuous—that is, morally correct—or nonvirtuous—immoral—actions. This is because if things were not empty of essential existence, what action could there be? Action is not tenable in the context of essential existence.
chos la chos min med par yang / / 'bras bu khyod la yod par 'gyur / / chos dang chos min rgyus byung bas/ / 'bras bu khyod la yod ma yin/ /
34. For you, even without virtuous or nonvirtuous causes, There would be an effect. According to you there is no effect Arisen from virtuous or nonvirtuous causes.

gzhan yang 'bras bu rang bzhin gyis yod par smra na chos dang chos min pa byas pa med par yang / de gnyis kyi rgyu can gyi 'bras bu yid du 'ong ba dang yid du mi 'ong ba khyod la yod par 'gyur ro/ / de lta na 'bras bu de dag gi don du las gnyis byed pa don med par 'gyur bas/ chos dang chos min gyi rgyus 'byung ba'i 'bras bu gnyis las gnyis byas pa med par khyod la yod pa ma yin no/ /

Moreover, if you were to say that their effects exist essentially, then even without one having performed virtuous or nonvirtuous actions you would experience the pleasant and unpleasant effects that are caused by these two. In that case, it would be pointless to perform these two kinds of actions in order to obtain the effects. Therefore, you, without having performed the two kinds of actions, would not experience the two effects that arise from the two causes—the virtuous and nonvirtuous actions.
chos dang chos min rgyus byung bas/ / 'bras bu gal te khyod la yod/ / chos dang chos min las byung ba'i/ / 'bras bu ci phyir stong ma yin/ /
35. If for you, an effect arose From virtuous or nonvirtuous causes, Then, having arisen from virtuous or nonvirtuous causes, How could that effect be nonempty?

gal te 'bras bu gnyis chos dang chos min pa'i rgyus 'byung ba khyod la yod na ni/ 'bras bu gnyis po de ci'i phyir rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa ma yin zhes pa yin te/ chos dang chos min las 'byung ba'i rten 'brel yin pa'i phyir gzugs brnyan bzhin no/ /

If you experienced the two effects that arise from virtuous and nonvirtuous causes, [435] then why would these two effects not be empty of essential existence? They would be empty, because, arising from the virtuous and nonvirtuous, they are dependently originated, like a reflection.
lnga pa ['jig rten pa'i tha snyad mi rung ba] ni/
1.2.3.5 Mundane conventions will make no sense
rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yi/ / stong pa nyid la gnod byed gang / / 'jig rten pa yi tha snyad ni/ / kun la'ang gnod pa byed pa yin/ /
36. Those who deny emptiness, Which is dependent origination, Undermine all of The mundane conventions.

dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par smra ba ni rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yi stong pa nyid la gnod pa byed pa yin la/ de ltar byed pa gang yin pa de ni song zhig byos shig lhogs shig 'dug cig / ces pa la sogs pa 'jig rten pa'i tha snyad ni kun la gnod pa byed pa yin no/ /

If you were to say that things exist essentially, this would be to deny emptiness, which is dependent origination. One who did this would undermine all mundane conventions such as saying “Go!” or “Do this!” or “Stand up!” or “Sit!”
stong pa nyid la gnod byed na/ / bya ba ci yang med 'gyur zhing / / rtsom pa med pa'i bya bar 'gyur/ / mi byed pa yang byed por 'gyur/ /

gzhan yang dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa nyid la gnod pa byed na/ / de'i tshe rang bzhin gyis grub pa ni ma byas kyang yod pas sus kyang bya ba ci yang byed pa med par 'gyur ro/ / rtsom pa med pa ste byed bzhin pa ma yin pa yang bya bar 'gyur la/ bya ba ci yang mi byed pa yang byed pa por 'gyur na de yang mi rigs pas dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pas mi stong pa ma yin no/ /

Moreover, if one rejects the emptiness of essential existence of things, then, since things that exist essentially exist even without being created, nobody could perform any action. There would be action without any effort—that is, without any performance—and there would be agents even though they had not performed any actions. But none of this makes any sense. Therefore, it is not the case that things are not empty of essential existence.
rang bzhin yod na 'gro ba rnams/ / ma skyes pa dang ma 'gags dang / / ther zug tu ni gnas 'gyur zhing / / gnas skabs sna tshogs bral bar 'gyur/ /
38. If there were essence, all beings Would be birthless, deathless, And eternally enduring. They would be void of a variety of states.

gzhan yang chos rnams rang bzhin gyis yod na 'gro ba rnams ma skyes pa dang ma 'gags par 'gyur te/ rang bzhin bcos ma ma yin pa dang nam yang ldog pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / ma skyes shing ma 'gags na 'gro ba rnams ther zug tu ni gnas par 'gyur ba dang / rgyu rkyen la mi ltos pas 'gro ba rnams gnas skabs sna tshogs pa rnams dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / ji skad du bcom ldan 'das kyis/ mi stong cung zhig yod na rgyal ba yis/ / 'ga' yang lung ston mi gsung 'gyur med par/ / rang rang dngos la ther zug gnas de la/ / 'phel bar byed cing yongs su nyams pa med/ // ces dang /

Moreover, if beings existed essentially, then transmigraters would be birthless and deathless because, since they would be by nature ungenerated, they could not change. If they were birthless and deathless, beings would endure eternally, and since they would not depend on causes and conditions, they would not exist in a variety of states. As the Lord has said, If there were even the slightest thing nonempty, the Victor would not make predictions. And without any change, everybody would exist eternally just as they are And there would be neither improvement nor degradation. [Pitāputrasamāgama-sūtra, dKon rtsegs na, 50b]/19/

glang po'i rtsal gyi mdo las kyang*/ gal te chos rnams rang bzhin 'ga' yod na/ / rgyal ba nyan thos bcas pas de mkhyen 'gyur/ / ther zug chos rnams mya ngan 'da' mi 'gyur//mkhas rnams nam yang spros pa med mi 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs te mdo sde 'di ni stong pa rten 'byung gi don du ston pa shin tu gsal lo/ /

And the Hastikakṣya-sūtra says, If phenomena had any essence, The Victor and his disciples would have known about it. No eternal phenomena could achieve nirvana. The wise would never cease their fabrication./20/ [Tathāgatajñānamudrāsaṁādhi-sūtra, m Do sde da 251b] [436] It is clear that these sūtras present “emptiness” as meaning dependent origination.
drug pa ['jig rten las 'das pa'i tha snyad mi rung ba] ni/
1.2.3.6 Transcendental conventions will make no sense
gal te stong pa yod min na/ / ma thob 'thob par bya ba dang*/ / sdug bsngal mthar byed las dang ni/ / nyon mongs thams cad spong ba'ang med/ /

gal te rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa yod pa min na sngar 'bras bu ma thob pa phyis thob par bya ba dang / sngar sdug bsngal zad pa'i mthar ma byas pa phyis sdug bsngal zad pa'i mthar byed pa dang / / sngar las dang nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs par ma gyur pa phyis spong ba'ang med par 'gyur bas/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i tha snyad thams cad kyang mi 'thad par 'gyur ro/ /

If things were not empty of essential existence, then there would neither be the achievement later of that which was not previously achieved, nor the final exhaustion of suffering that had not been exhausted earlier, nor the abandonment of all of the defilements and actions that had not been abandoned earlier. Thus none of the transcendental conventions would make sense.
bzhi pa [rten 'byung gi de nyid mthong na bden bzhi'i de nyid mthong bar 'gyur ba] ni/
1.2.4 Showing that to see the reality of dependent arising is to see the reality of the Four Noble Truths
gang gis rten cing 'brel bar 'byung / / mthong ba des ni sdug bsngal dang / / kun 'byung dang ni 'gog pa dang / / lam nyid de dag mthong ba yin/ /
40. Whoever sees dependent arising Also sees suffering, And its origin, And its cessation, as well as the path.

gang gi phyir dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub par khas blangs na rnam gzhag thams cad mi 'thad pa de'i phyir/ rnal 'byor pa gang gis stong pa nyid rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i mtshan nyid can mthong ba des ni/ sdug bsngal dang kun 'byung dang 'gog pa dang ste bden pa bzhi po de dag gi de kho na nyid mthong ba yin no/ // ji skad du 'phags pa bsam gtan pa'i dpe mkhyud kyi mdo las/ bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi po rnams la ji ltar khums par bgyi/bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal gang gis 'du byed thams cad ma skyes par mthong ba des ni sdug bsngal yongs su shes pa yin no//gang gis chos thams cad 'byung ba med par mthong ba des ni kun 'byung ba spangs pa yin no/ / gang zhig chos thams cad gtan mya ngan las 'das par mthong ba des ni 'gog pa mngon du byas pa yin no/ / gang gis chos thams cad shin tu ma skyes par mthong ba des ni lam bsgoms pa yin no/ / 'jam dpal gang gis de ltar 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi mthong ba de ni chos 'di dag ni dge ba'o/ / chos 'di dag ni mi dge ba/ / chos 'di dag ni spang bar bya'o/ / chos 'di dag ni mngon du bya'o/ / sdug bsngal yongs su shes par bya kun 'byung spang bar bya 'gog pa mngon du bya lam bsgom par bya'o zhes mi rtog rnam par rtog par mi byed do/ / 'di ltar gang brtag par bya ba'i chos de des ma mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

Therefore, if one maintains that things exist essentially, this entire system would be untenable. Therefore, the practitioner who has seen emptiness to have the characteristic of dependent origination sees the reality of the Four Noble Truths: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. The Āryadhyāyitamuṣṭi-sūtra says. O Transcendental Lord, how should one understand the Four Noble Truths? The Transcendental Lord replied: O, Mañjuśrī, whoever has seen compounded phenomena to be unarisen has completely understood suffering. Whoever has seen all phenomena to be unarisen has abandoned the sources of suffering. Whoever has seen all phenomena to be completely liberated has realized cessation. Whoever has seen all phenomena to be completely unarisen has practiced the path. O, Mañjuśrī, whoever has seen the Four Noble Truths this way does not conceptualize that which is nonconceptual, saying, “These phenomena are virtuous; these phenomena are nonvirtuous; these phenomena are to be abandoned; these phenomena are to be realized. [437] Suffering should be completely understood, the origins of suffering should be abandoned, cessation should be realized, and the path should be practiced.” Thus he does not see imaginary phenomena.

byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams ni chos de dag mngon du rtog pa na chags par 'gyur ro/ / sdang bar 'gyur ro/ / rmongs par 'gyur ro/ / de chos 'ga' yang mi len mi 'dor de ltar mi len mi 'dor ba de ni khams gsum la sems chags par mi 'gyur ro/ / khams gsum thams cad ma skyes pa dang sgyu ma lta bu dang rmi lam lta bu dang brag cha lta bur mthong ngo / / chos thams cad de lta bu'i rang bzhin du mthong bas sems can thams cad la rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ /

Foolish ordinary beings, when they conceptualize these phenomena, develop desire, aversion, and confusion. But he neither accepts nor rejects any phenomenon, and the one who neither accepts nor rejects does not develop attachment to the three realms. He sees the three realms as unarisen, and as like illusions, like dreams, and like echoes. In virtue of seeing all phenomena as having that nature, he becomes free from attachment and aversion towards all sentient beings.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar des gang la rjes su chags pa dang khong khro bar 'gyur ba'i chos de ma dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ // des sems nam mkha' dang mnyam pas sangs rgyas kyang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong ngo / / chos kyang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong dge 'dun yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong zhing chos thams cad stong pa'o zhes bya bar mthong bas chos gang la yang som nyi skyed par mi byed do/ / som nyi med pas nye bar len pa med par 'gyur ro/ / nye bar len pa med pas len pa med par yongs su mya ngan las 'da'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Why is that so? Because he does not objectify the phenomena toward which one might develop attachment and aversion. With his skylike mind, he does not see even the Buddha to be real. Nor does he see the Dharma to be real, nor does he see the Sangha to be real. And thus, because he sees all phenomena as empty, he does not develop doubt. Without doubt, there is no appropriation. Being unappropriated, and without appropriating, he attains nirvana. [Sarvadharmāpravṛttinirdeśa-sūtra, mDo sde ma 276b]/21/
gnyis pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
2. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

dbu ma pas 'khor 'das kyi chos rnams la rang bzhin gyis grub pa cung zad kyang med par bstan pa na/ pha rol pos lugs de la 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i rnam gzhag gang yang byar med par 'gyur ro zhes rtsod pa yin la/ de'i lan du rnam par dpyad nas de ltar 'gog pa'i rigs pas dpyad bzod pa rdul tsam yang med pas/gzhan lugs la 'di yin dang 'di ma yin gyi rnam gzhag gang yang byar med pa'i skyon yod pa dang / rang lugs la skyon de dag med par ma zad rnam gzhag thams cad ches shin tu 'thad par ni rab byed 'dis gtso bor ston no/ / de yang stong pa'i don rten 'byung gi don yin gyi bya byed kyi dngos po bkag pa stong pa'i don min pa la thug pas/ dbu ma'i tshul la mos pa'i rnam dpyod can yin na ni tshul de ltar du smra bar bya yi/ dngos por smra ba rnams kyis 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i rnam gzhag gang yang khyod kyi lugs 'di la byar mi rung ngo zhes nan gyis 'phul ba la/ kho bo cag gi ltar na gang la yang 'di yin dang 'di ma yin gyi ngos gzung gi rnam gzhag byar mi rung ngo zhes/ gzhan gyis 'phul mi dgos par dang po nas rang nyid de'i gseb tu 'jug par mi bya'o/ /

When the mādhyamika shows that not even the slightest phenomenon related to samsara or nirvana exists essentially, our opponents argue that according to our system the entire framework of mundane and transcendental phenomena makes no sense. In response to this, the present chapter explains things as follows: There is not even the slightest particle that withstands analysis through the arguments that examine and reject true existence. Therefore, while the opponent’s system contains errors that make it impossible for him to assert [438] “this exists and this does not,” not only do we not commit those errors in our own system, but this entire framework makes perfect sense. The main point is that the meaning of “emptiness” is dependent origination, but emptiness does not mean the negation of things such as action and agent. Thus, one who is discerning and aspires to subscribe to the Madhyamaka system should think in that manner. The reificationists press us hard, saying, “According to your system, the entire framework of the mundane and the transcendental makes no sense.” One should not rush into a place in advance before the other one pushes, by saying that according to our system we cannot say that we cannot set out any framework within which one could say “this exists and this does not exist.”/22/
'phags pa'i bden pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu bzhi pa'o//
This is the twenty-fourth chapter called “the examination of the four noble truths.”
'phags pa'i bden pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bzhi bcu'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa bzhi pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-fourth chapter, having forty verses, called “the examination of the four noble truths.”
CHAPTER XXV. Examination of Nirvana
gnyis pa myang 'das brtag pa
This chapter constitutes the second part—the examination of nirvana.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
It has three parts: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa]
1. Explanation of the Chapter
['di] la gnyis/ rtsod pa dang / lan no/ /
This section has two parts: the objection and the reply.
dang po [rtsod pa] ni/
1.1 The objection
gal te 'di dag kun stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / gang zhig spong dang 'gag pa las/ / mya ngan 'das par 'gyur bar 'dod/ /
1. If all this is empty. Then there is neither arising nor passing away. Through the abandonment or cessation of what Does one aspire to nirvana?

'dir smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis thar 'dod rnams la phung po lhag ma dang bcas pa dang lhag ma med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa rnam pa gnyis gsungs te/ de la dang po ni chom rkun pa kun bsad nas grong tsam zhig lus pa ltar 'jig lta la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa zad par spangs nas sngon gyi las nyon gyis 'phangs pa'i phung po tsam zhig lus pa'i 'gog pa ste mdo sde las/

Here it is said that the Transcendent Lord has said that there are two kinds of nirvana: nirvana with residual aggregates and nirvana without residual aggregates. The first is just like killing all of the bandits but leaving their camp intact. In the same way, this is a cessation in which, though one has completely abandoned the afflictions, the residual aggregates projected by past actions and afflictions remain. As it says in sūtra,
ma zhum pa yi sems kyis ni/ / tshor ba dang du len pa na/ / de yi sems ni rnam par grol/ / mar me shi bar gyur pa bzhin/ / zhes so/ /

When the undiscouraged mind Voluntarily accepts feeling, His mind achieves liberation Like the extinguishment of a butterlamp./1/ [Theragāthā, Visatinipāta section, Anuruddha theragāthā IX, verse 906]

gnyis pa ni/ chom rkun pa kun bsad nas grong yang bcom pa ltar nyon mongs pa kun spangs par ma zad nyer len gyi phung po'i lhag ma dang yang bral ba'i 'gog pa ste mdo sde las/ gang na lus zhig 'du shes 'gags/ / tshor ba thams cad bral gyur cing / / 'du byed nye bar zhi ba dang / / rnam par shes pa nub gyur pa/ / zhes so/ /

The second one is [439] just like killing all of the bandits and destroying their camp as well. In the same way this is a cessation in which, once one has not only completely abandoned the afflictions, but all residual aggregates are eliminated as well. As it says in sūtra, When the body disintegrates and perception ceases, One is freed from all feeling. The compounded phenomena are completely pacified and Consciousness disappears. [Udāna, Khuddakanikāya section, IX: 21]

gal te phyi nang gi chos 'di dag kun rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong na 'byung ba ste skye ba dang 'jig pa cung zad kyang med pas/nyon mongs pa gang zhig spong ba ste spangs pa dang nyer len gyi phung po gang zhig 'gags pa las myang 'das gnyis kyi sgo nas mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur bar 'dod ces pa de ltar 'dod par mi rigs te/ phung po dang nyon mongs rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ / de yi phyir dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes 'dzer to/ /

If all of these internal and external phenomena were empty of essential existence, it would follow that not the slightest thing could come into being—arise—or pass away. Therefore, it would not make sense to maintain that one could achieve liberation by successively achieving the two nirvanas through abandonment—that is, abandoning the afflictions—and through the cessation of the appropriation of the aggregates. This is because the aggregates and the afflictions would not exist essentially. Thus, they say, things must exist essentially.
gnyis pa [lan]
1.2 The reply

['di] la bzhi/ dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i phyogs la myang 'das mi 'thad pa dang / rang gi lugs kyis myang 'das ngos gzung ba dang / de las tshul gzhan du smra ba dgag pa dang / de ltar bkag pa la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba'o/ /

This section has four parts: showing that, given the position that things exist essentially, nirvana is not tenable; demonstrating our own account of nirvana; the refutation of contrary positions; and rebutting the charge that this refutation contradicts sūtra.
dang po [dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i phyogs la myang 'das mi 'thad pa] ni/
1.2.1 Showing that, given the position that things exist essentially, nirvana is not tenable
gal te 'di kun mi stong na/ / 'byung ba med cing 'jig pa med/ / gang zhig spong dang 'gags pa las/ / mya ngan 'das par 'gyur bar 'dod/ /
2. If all this is nonempty, Then there is neither arising nor passing away. Through the abandonment or cessation of what Does one aspire to nirvana?

gal te phyi nang gi chos 'di dag kun rang bzhin gyis yod pas mi stong na/ rang bzhin gyis grub pa la sngar med gsar du 'byung ba dang sngar yod gsar du 'jig pa med pas nyon mongs dang phung po gang zhig spong ba dang 'gags pa las mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur bar 'dod pa mi rigs te/ nyon mongs dang phung po rang bzhin gyis gnas pa rnams ldog par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ de 'dra ba'i rang bzhin la ldog pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Suppose all of the internal and external phenomena were not empty of essential existence. For something that exists essentially, it is impossible for it to arise anew having been nonexistent previously, and it is impossible for it to cease anew having been previously existent. Therefore, it would not make any sense to maintain that nirvana arises from the abandonment of the afflictions and the cessation of the aggregates. This is because essentially existent afflictions and aggregates could not be eliminated, because such essence is immutable.
gnyis pa [rang gi lugs kyis myang 'das ngos gzung ba] ni/
1.2.2 Demonstrating our own account of nirvana
spangs pa med pa thob med pa/ / chad pa med pa rtag med pa/ / 'gag pa med pa skye med pa/ / de ni mya ngan 'das par brjod/ /
3. Unrelinquished, unattained, Unannihilated, impermanent, Unarisen, unceased: This is how nirvana is described.

stong pa nyid du smra ba rnams kyis ni nyon mongs pa dang phung po rang bzhin gyis sngar grub pa phyis ldog pa'i myang 'das mi 'dod pas 'byung 'jig med pas myang 'das mi rung ba'i skyon med do/ / 'o na de dag gis myang 'das mtshan nyid gang dang ldan par 'dod ce na/ gang zhig chags sogs ltar spangs pa dang dge sbyong gi 'bras bu ltar thob pa dang nyer len gyi phung po la sogs pa ltar chad pa dang mi stong pa ltar rtag pa ste de bzhir rang bzhin gyis ma grub cing / rang bzhin gyis bkag pa dang skye ba med pa spros pa thams cad nye bar zhi ba'i mtshan nyid can de ni mya ngan las 'das par brjod do/ / de'i phyir de la nyon mongs spangs shing phung po 'gags pas mya ngan las 'da' bar 'dod pa'i nyon mongs dang phung po rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dzin pa'i rtog pa ga la yod/ ji srid du rtog pa de gnyis yod pa de srid du myang 'das thob pa min te spros pa de dag thams cad zad pa las de 'thob pa'i phyir ro/ //

Those who assert the doctrine of emptiness do not maintain that nirvana is the subsequent elimination of previously essentially existing afflictions and aggregates. Therefore, they do not commit the error of saying that because there is neither arising nor ceasing, nirvana is impossible. [440] “Well, then,” one might ask, “what characteristics do they maintain nirvana has?” We describe nirvana as having the following characteristics: It does not exist essentially as any of these four things: desire, which has been relinquished; the fruits of the spiritual practitioner, which have been attained; the appropriation of the aggregates, which has been annihilated; or the nonempty, which would be permanent. It is neither essentially ceased nor essentially arisen, and is the complete pacification of all fabrication. So how could we, who aspire to the nirvana that is the abandonment of afflictions and the cessation of the aggregates, have a conception of the aggregates and afflictions as existing essentially? So long as one has these two conceptions, nirvana cannot be attained, because it is attained through the complete elimination of all such fabrications.

ci ste mya ngan las 'das pa'i dus na nyon mongs sam phung po med mod kyang de thob pa'i snga rol na de rnams rang bzhin gyis yod pas de dag gi spros pa zad pa las mya ngan las 'das par 'gyur ro snyam na/ myang 'das kyi snga rol na rang bzhin gyis yod na phyis zad par bya bar mi nus pas thar 'dod kyis rtog pa 'di dor bar bya ste/ mya ngan 'das mtha' gang yin pa/ / zhes sogs 'chad par 'gyur ba'i phyir dang*/ ting 'dzin rgyal po las kyang / mya ngan 'das la chos rnams yod nyid med/ / chos gang der med de dag gzhar yang med/ / yod dang med ces rtog pa dang ldan zhing*/ / de ltar spyod rnams sdug bsngal nyer mi zhi/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de'i don ni phung po lhag med kyi myang 'das kyi dbyings na las dang nyon mongs dang de'i 'bras bu skye ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi phung po'i chos rnams dang bral bas/ de rnams yod pa min pa ni rgol ba thams cad kyis 'dod pa yin no/ /

Now, suppose one thought that, although when nirvana is attained neither the afflictions nor the aggregates exist, since they existed inherently prior to its attainment, nirvana is attained through the elimination of their fabrications. But if they existed essentially prior to the attainment of nirvana, they could not be eliminated later. Therefore, those who aspire to nirvana should reject this view. Statements such as Whatever is the limit of nirvana, That is the limit of cyclic existence, [XXV: 19ab] that will be found below, and those in the Samādhirāja-sūtra, such as In nirvana there is no existence of phenomena. Phenomena that do not exist there never exist. Those who have conceptions of existence or nonexistence And act accordingly never pacify their suffering. [mDo sde da 26b]/2/ mean that the realm of nirvana without residual aggregates is free from the phenomena of aggregates characterized by action, afflictions, and the arising of their effects. Therefore, their nonexistence is maintained by all parties to the debate.

der med pa'i chos de dag gzhar yang ste nam yang med ces gsungs pas ni 'khor ba'i skabs su yang de kho na nyid du yod pa min par bstan to/ / 'o na ji ltar 'khor snyam na/ rab rib can la skra shad la sogs par snang ba ltar byis pa bdag dang bdag gi bar 'dzin pa'i phyin ci log gi gdon gyis bzung ba rnams la bden par snang ba ni rkang pa tha ma gnyis kyis gsungs so/ / de yang yod par rtog pa ni rgyal dpog dang gzegs zan dang ser skya la sogs pa bye brag tu smra ba la thug pa dang / med par rtog pa ni rgyang pan pa dang 'das ma 'ongs dang rig min dang ldan min rdzas su med cing de las gzhan yod par smra ba rnams dang kun brtags rang gi mtshan nyid kyis med cing ngo bo nyid gzhan gnyis ngo bos yod par smra ba'o/ /

By saying that the phenomena are never there—that is, that they are not ever there—[441] these statements show that nor do they exist in reality even in the context of cyclic existence. Then how does one wander in cyclic existence? The second two lines of this last verse state that just as such things as hairs appear to the person with cataracts, they appear as truly existent to fools who are in the grasp of the demons of false views—who grasp the self and being mine. The reificationists include such people as the Jaiminī, Kāṅāda, and Kāpila, right up to the Vaibhāsikas; and the nihilists include such people as the Cārvāka, and others who maintain that the past and future, nonindicative form, and non-psychophysical aggregates are nonsubstantial, and who maintain that things other than these are substantial, as well as those who maintain that the imagined nature does not exist through its own characteristics, but that the other two natures exist inherently.

gal te rkang pa dang po'i don lhag med kyi myang 'das kyi dbyings na sdug kun gyi chos rnams med pa yin na/ theg dman gyi dgra bcom pa tshe'i 'du byed btang ba na rig pa'i rgyun log pa 'dod pas de ltar smra mod kyang / rang gi lugs kyis ni de dag kyang mthar 'tshang rgya bar bzhed pas de'i myang 'das la phung po'i lhag ma yod med ji ltar bzhed ce na/ rigs pa drug cu pa'i 'grel pa las/ mdo las ni gang phung po 'di ma lus par spangs pa nges par spangs pa byang bar gyur pa zad pa 'dod chags dang bral ba 'gog pa nye bar zhi ba nub pa/ sdug bsngal gzhan gyi mtshams mi sbyor zhing mi skye ba 'di ni zhi ba 'di ni gya nom pa ste/ 'di lta ste/ phung po thams cad nges par spangs pa srid pa zad pa 'dod chags dang bral ba 'gog pa mya ngan las 'das pa'o zhes phung po po 'gags pa las mya ngan las 'das par rnam par bzhag go/ zhes gsungs shing /

Suppose someone wondered, “The meaning of the first line of this last verse is that in the realm of nirvana without remainder, phenomena such as suffering and the sources of suffering do not exist. So, given that those who maintain that when a śrāvaka arhat gives up his life, the continuum of his consciousness is terminated assert that as well, while, according to our view, all of those arhats are maintained to attain enlightenment eventually, what is our view with regard to whether or not there are residual aggregates in their nirvana?” Here the Yuktiṣaṣṭikāvṛtti says, According to sūtra, when all of the aggregates are completely abandoned, thoroughly abandoned, completely eliminated, and exhausted, free from desire, and terminated and pacified, and when they have disappeared and do not connect to further suffering or give rise to further suffering, that is peace; that is sublime. That is, the complete abandonment of all of the aggregates and the exhaustion of craving and freedom from desire is cessation—that is, nirvana. Thus the cessation of the aggregates is theorised to be nirvana. [slight paraphrase from 10a]

phung po zad pa'i don phung po'i phyogs gcig nyon mongs zad pa la 'chad pa bkag nas sdug bsngal gyi phung po spyi zad pa la phung po zad par bya dgos par gsungs so/ / de yang phung po'i rgyun zad pa la byas na phung po ma zad pa'i tshe thob bya myang 'das med la phung po zad pa'i tshe thob mkhan med pas myang 'das thob pa mi srid pa'i skyon bstan nas/ gal te sdug bsngal gyi rang bzhin skye ba med par mthong na ni de'i tshe gnas skabs der yang skye ba de mi dmigs pa'i phyir sdug bsngal de zad pa kho nar 'gyur na/ zhes phung po lnga char rang bzhin gyis skye ba med par mngon sum du mthong ba'i tshe de'i ngo na phung po med pa phung po 'di ma lus par spangs pa zhes gsungs pa'i don du bzhed do/ // des na theg dman gyis nyon mongs zad par spangs pa'i tshe mnyam gzhag gi ngo na phung po'i snang ba lhag ma med par nub pa'i 'gog pa ni de'i lhag med kyi myang 'das dang*/ de'i snang ba ma nub pa'i rjes thob kyi tshe de'i lhag bcas kyi myang 'das su 'jog pa yin no/ /

Refuting the assertion that the meaning of “exhaustion” is the exhaustion of the afflictions that are part of the aggregates, it says that the exhaustion of the aggregates must be the exhaustion of the aggregates in general. If one maintained that this [442] is the exhaustion of the continuum of the aggregates, Candrakīrti shows that one would commit the following error: When the aggregates are not exhausted, the nirvana to be attained does not yet exist. When the aggregates are exhausted, the one who attains the nirvana does not exist. Thus it would be impossible to attain nirvana [Yuktiṣaṣṭikāvrtti, dBu ma ya 9b]. Since at the time when one sees the essentially unarisen nature of suffering, that arising is not perceived, the suffering is simply eliminated. At the time when the five aggregates are directly perceived to be essentially nonarisen, the absence of the aggregates in that perspective is maintained to be the complete abandonment of the aggregates. This is how Candrakīrti explains it. Thus, when the śrāvakas have completely abandoned the afflictions, from the perspective of equipoise, the vanishing—that is, the cessation—of the appearance of the aggregates, without any residue, is the nirvana without residual aggregates. At the time of the postmeditative state when the appearance has not vanished, there is nirvana with residual aggregates.
gsum pa [de las tshul gzhan du smra ba dgag pa]
1.2.3 Refutation of contrary positions
['di] la gsum/ myang 'das mtha' bzhir grub pa dgag / myang 'das thugs su chud pa po mtha' bzhir ma grub par bstan/ des grub pa'i don no/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of the four extremes with respect to the existence of nirvana, showing that one who realizes nirvana does not exist in any of the four extreme ways, and drawing conclusions from this.
dang po [myang 'das mtha' bzhir grub pa dgag]
1.2.3.1 Refutation of the four extremes with respect to the existence of nirvana
['di] la gsum/ myang 'das dngos por yod med so so ba'i mthar 'dod pa dgag / de gnyis ka'i mthar 'dod pa dgag / gnyis ka ma yin pa'i mthar 'dod pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has three parts: the refutation of each of the extreme assertions that nirvana is an existent or nonexistent thing, the refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is both, and the refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is neither.
dang po [myang 'das dngos por yod med so so ba'i mthar 'dod pa dgag]
1.2.3.1.1 Refutation of each of the extreme assertions that nirvana is an existent or nonexistent thing

['di] la bzhi/ myang 'das dngos po'i mthar 'dod pa dgag / dngos po med pa'i mthar 'dod pa dgag / mtha' gnyis spangs pa'i myang 'das gang la 'jog pa/ mtha' gnyis su lta ba ston pas smad pa'i tshul lo/ /

This section has four parts: the refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is a thing, the refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is a non-thing, presenting nirvana as free from the two extremes, and showing how the teacher has condemned these two extreme views.
dang po [myang 'das dngos po'i mthar 'dod pa dgag] ni/
1.2.3.1.1.1 Refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is a thing

bye brag tu smra ba rnams na re myang 'das ni las nyon dang skye ba'i rgyun phyi ma 'jug pa'i 'gog byed chu'i rgyun 'gog pa'i chu lon lta bu yin pas dngos po yin te/ dngos med kyis don byed mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te mdo las dga' ba'i 'dod chags dang lhan cig tu gyur pa'i sred pa zad cing 'dod chags dang bral ba 'gog pa gang yin pa ni mya ngan las 'das pa'o/ / zhes sred pa zad pa tsam du gsungs shing / mar me shi bar gyur pa ltar/ / de yi sems ni rnam par thar/ / zhes gsungs pas mar me shi ba dang nyon mongs zad pa tsam ni dngos med yin pas dngos por mi rigs so zhe na/ sred pa zad pa zhes gsungs pas sred pa zad tsam myang 'das su mi ston gyi myang 'das de yod na de'i mthus sred pa zad par 'gyur ba ni sred pa zad pa zhes pa'i don no/ / mar me shi ba ni nyon mongs zad pa'i dpe tsam yin la de yang myang 'das gang yod na sems thar pa'am grol bar 'gyur ba yin no zhes ston pas dngos med du ston pa'i khungs min no zhes zer ro/ /

The Vaibhāṣikas say that that nirvana is that which stops the further continuation of action, affliction, and birth. It like a dam that stops the flow of water. Therefore it is a thing, because a non-thing cannot perform a function. Now, suppose someone else argued as follows: Since it is said in sūtra that nirvana is the exhaustion of the craving that is concomitant with the desire for pleasure and is the freedom from desire—that is, cessation—it [443] is said to be the mere exhaustion of craving, Just as a butterlamp is extinguished, His mind is completely liberated. [Vinayakṣudrakavastu, ‘Dul ba Phran tshegs tha 291b] Thus the mere extinguishment of the butterlamp and the mere exhaustion of the afflictions are non-things. Therefore it makes no sense that they are things. They reply that saying “the exhaustion of craving” does not mean that the mere exhaustion of craving is nirvana. Instead, “the exhaustion of craving” means the exhaustion of craving that occurs through the power of the attainment of nirvana. Here, they say, the extinguishment of the butterlamp is a mere example that illustrates that when nirvana is achieved, the mind is freed or liberated. Therefore, they say that it is not presented in support of the claim that it is a non-thing.
re shig mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / rga shi'i mtshan nyid thal bar 'gyur/ / rga dang 'chi ba med pa yi/ / dngos po yod pa ma yin no/ /
4. Nirvana is not a thing. It would then have the characteristics of aging and death. No thing exists Without aging and death.

re zhig mya ngan las 'das pa ni nyon mongs dang skye ba'i rigs 'dra phyi ma 'gog pa'i dngos po min te/ dngos po yin na rga ba ste gzhan du 'gyur ba dang shi ba ste 'jig pa'i mtshan nyid can du thal bar 'gyur te/ dngos po ni de 'dra ba'i rga shi la mi 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ // gzhan 'gyur gyi rga ba dang 'jig pa'i 'chi ba med pa'i dngos po ni yod pa ma yin no/ / zhes pa ni dngos po rga shi la mi 'khrul ba gsal bar byed pa'o/ // rga shi'i mtshan nyid can yin na ni myang 'das su yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

Nirvana is not a thing that stops the further continuation of birth and affliction, because if it were a thing it would follow absurdly that it would have the characteristics of aging—that is, turning into something else—and death—that is, cessation. That is because having the characteristics of aging and death are inextricable from being a thing. Nothing exists without turning into something else (aging) and ceasing (dying). By saying this, it shows clearly that aging and death are inextricable from things. If something has the characteristics of aging and death, it could not be nirvana.
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos na/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'dus byas 'gyur/ / dngos po 'dus byas ma yin pa/ / 'ga' yang gang na'ang yod ma yin/ /
5. If nirvana were a thing, Nirvana would be compounded. A non-compounded thing Does not exist anywhere.

gzhan yang gal te mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po yin na mya ngan las 'das pa 'dus byas su 'gyur ro/ / de'i ldog pa ni 'dus byas ma yin pa'i phyi'am nang gi dngos po rten pa 'ga' yang yul dus grub pa'i mtha'i rten gang na'ang yod pa ma yin no zhes pas bshad do/ /

Moreover, if nirvana were a thing, nirvana would be a compounded phenomenon. This presents the contrapositive: Neither internal nor external noncompounded phenomena, which must be dependent, exist at any place or time—on which they would depend—according to any view.
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos na/ / ji ltar mya 'das de brten min/ / dngos po brten nas ma yin pa/ / 'ga' yang gang na'ang yod ma yin/ /
6. If nirvana were a thing, How could nirvana be nondependent? A nondependent thing Does not exist anywhere.

gzhan yang gal te mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po yin na ji ltar na myang 'das de rang gi rgyu'i tshogs pa la brten nas skye ba min te yin no/ / de'i ldog pa ni rang gi rgyu'i tshogs pa la brten nas mi skye ba'i dngos po ni 'ga' yang yod pa ma yin no/ zhes pas bshad do/ / de ltar thal ba dang po dang gsum pas 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid skye 'jig gzhan 'gyur gsum dang ldan pa dang / thal ba gnyis pas mtshan gzhi 'du byas kyis dngos po la khyab par bsgrubs nas khyab byed bkag pa'i sgo nas khyab bya dngos po yin pa 'gog go /

Moreover, if nirvana were a thing, how could nirvana not arise in dependence on its own assemblage of causes? It would have to arise like that. This presents the contraspositive by saying that there is nothing that does not arise in dependence on its own assemblage of causes. [444] So, by the first and third reductios, it would have the characteristics of compounded phenomena such as arising, ceasing, and changing into something else; having shown by the second reductio that its being a compounded phenomenon—a basis of characteristics—would entail its being a thing, he refutes its being in the subordinate category of thing by refuting its being in the superordinate category of compounded phenomenon.
gnyis pa [dngos po med pa'i mthar 'dod pa dgag] ni/
1.2.3.1.1.2 Refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is a non-thing

mdo sde pa la sogs pa rnams na re ji skad bshad pa'i skyon du 'gyur bas myang 'das dngos po min pa bden mod kyang*/ nyon mongs pa dang skye ba log pa tsam yin pas myang 'das ni dngos po med pa yin no zhes 'dzer to/ / 'di dgag bya'i nyon mongs dang skye ba log tsam gyi dngos med du 'dod pa mi 'gog mod/ 'on kyang dngos med der yod pa yang tha snyad kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam min par rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis yod par 'dod pas de 'gog pa yin no//

The Sautrāntikas and others say that although it is true that nirvana is not a thing—as it has been shown above that this would be erroneous—since it is the mere termination of birth and the afflictions, nirvana is a non-thing. They do not reject the assertion that the mere termination of the afflictions and birth—which are the objects to be rejected—is a non-thing. However, the nonthing that exists in their sense is not merely posited through nominal conventions, but rather is asserted to exist inherently. Therefore we reject it.
gal te myang 'das dngos min na/ / dngos med ci ltar rang bar 'gyur/ / gang la mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / de la dngos med yod ma yin/ /
7. If nirvana were a non-thing, How could it make sense for it not to be a thing? Where nirvana is not a thing, It cannot be a non-thing.

gal te mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po min na dngos med du rang gi ngo bos yod pa yang ji ltar rung bar 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur ro/ / 'di ltar phyogs gang la bstan zin pa'i nyes pas mya ngan las 'ad dngos po min pa'i phyogs de la ste des mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po med par rang gi ngo bos yod pa'ang khas blang bar rigs pa ma yin te/ dngos po gzhan 'gyur la dngos med du smra ba'i phyir dang dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa bkag zin pas dngos po rang bzhin gyis yod pa gzhan du 'gyur ba mi rigs pa'i phyir ro/ /

If nirvana were a non-thing, how could it, not being a thing, exist inherently as a non-thing? It could not! Because of the errors shown to attach to the position according to which nirvana is a thing, it does not make sense to assert that nirvana exists inherently as a non-thing. This is because when that which is a thing becomes something other than that, it is called a non-thing. Since we have already refuted the essential existence of things, it would not make sense for an essentially existent thing to change into something else.

gal te dngos med la dngos po'i khyad par zhig gzhan du 'gyur bas khyab na de ltar yin kyang de min pa'i dngos med du ma yod pas rgyu mtshan des myang 'das dngos med du rang gi ngo bos yod pa ji ltar khegs snyam na/ dngos med thams cad la de ltar ma khyab kyang dngos med rang gi ngo bos yod na dngos po yin dgos la/ de'i tshe dngos po 'di 'dra zhig med pa'i dngos med ces 'jog pa'i tshul de dngos po gcig gzhan du 'gyur ba'i sgo nas 'dod dgos pa'i phyir skyon med do/ / gal te myang 'das ni nyon mongs zad pa dang las nyon gyi dbang gis slar yang skye ba med pa tsam yin pas dngos med do snyam na/ de lta na nyon mongs dang skye ba'i mi rtag pa nyid myang 'das su 'gyur te nyon mongs dang skye ba med pa ni de nyid yin gyi de las gzhan min pa'i phyir ro/ / des na de gnyis kyi mi rtag pa nyid mya ngan las 'das par 'gyur na de ltar 'dod pa yang min te 'dod na bsgrim mi dgos par grol bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / 'grel pas de ltar bshad pa la 'di snyam du myang 'das nyon mongs dang lus len pa'i skye ba slar mi 'byung ba tsam du 'dod pa la nyon mongs dang skye ba gnyis kyi mi rtag pa myang 'das su thal ba brjod pa 'di ma 'brel lo zhe na/ gang thob phyin chad slar yang nyon mongs pa 'byung mi srid pa'i nyon mongs sngar yod dus gnyis par zhig pa'i mi rtag pa min mod kyang / yod dus gnyis par zhig pa'i mi rtag pa min mod kyang*/ ma 'ongs pa na nyon mongs mi skye ba de rang gi ngo bos yod na nyon mongs sngar yod dus gnyis par zhig pa dang / de gnyis don gzhan yin pa khegs pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis de gnyis gcig tu 'gyur bar bstan pa na de ltar khas blang dgos pa skyon med do/ /

Suppose someone argued as follows: For something to become a nonentity, if some particular thing would have to become something else, this would be the case. But there are many non-things other than that particular thing. So, how has this argument refuted the claim that nirvana exists inherently as a non-thing? We respond as follows: Although this does not apply to all non-things, if the non-thing exists inherently, it still must be a thing. [445] We do not commit an error, because to be a non-thing is to be a mode of cessation, that is, to be a non-thing-of-a-particular-kind. That is, one must maintain that it is something that has transformed into something else. Now suppose someone thought that nirvana is the mere exhaustion of the afflictions and the nonexistence of rebirth that occurs through the power of actions, and therefore that it is a non-thing. We respond as follows: If that were the case, the impermanence of the afflictions and birth would itself be nirvana. This is because the non-existence of afflictions and birth itself is nirvana, and it is not something other than that. Therefore, the impermanence of these two would be nirvana, but nobody maintains this. To maintain this would be to maintain that one could be liberated without effort. Although the Commentary explains it like this, [176b], suppose someone argued as follows: when someone maintains that nirvana is merely the exhaustion of further rebirth and the afflictions, the alleged absurd consequence—viz., that the impermanence of the afflictions and rebirth would be nirvana—is irrelevant. We respond as follows: Once nirvana has been attained, the afflictions cannot possibly arise again. That kind of non-arising of the afflictions is not impermanence—that is, the disintegration at the second moment of the affliction that existed earlier. However, if the non-arising of afflictions in the future existed inherently, the affliction that existed earlier and disintegrated in the second moment would be shown not to be different objects, and therefore these two would be shown to be identical. One must accept that this argument shows that they would be the same entity. Therefore Candrakīrti does not commit that error.
gal te mya ngan 'das dngos min/ / ci ltar myang 'das de brten min/ / gang zhig brten nas ma yin pa'i/ / dngos med yod pa ma yin no/ /
8. If nirvana were a non-thing, How could nirvana be nondependent? Whatever is nondependent Is not a non-thing.

gzhan yang gal te mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po min pa ste dngos med du rang gi ngo bos yod na/ dper na sngon po zhig pa'i mi rtag pa sngon po'i dngos po med pa de sngon po la brten nas 'jog pa bzhin du mya ngan las 'das pa yang ji ltar na rang gi dgag bya'i dngos po zhig pa la brten nas 'dogs pa min te yin no/ / gal te dngos po la ma brten pa'i dngos med med na 'o na mo gsham gyi bu la sogs pa dngos po gang la brten nas dngos med du 'gyur snyam na/ rab byed lnga par gal te dngos po ma grub na zhes sogs bshad pa bzhin du dngos po gzhan 'gyur la dngos med du 'jig rten na smra bas mo gsham gyi bu la sogs pa 'di 'dra ba'i dngos med du sus smras/ 'o na/ nam mkha' ri bong rwa dag dang*/ / mo gsham gyi ni bu dag kyang / / med bzhin tshig tu brjod pa ltar/ / dngos la brten pa'ang de bzhin no/ / zhes lung las de rnams dngos por med par gsungs pa dang 'gal lo zhe na der ni dngos po bkag tsam la dngos med du gsungs kyi dngos med du ngo bos yod par ston pa ni min te/ dngos po nyid ngo bos ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, suppose that nirvana were not a thing—that is, that it existed inherently as a non-thing. Just as as the impermanence—the disintegration—of a patch of blue, which is the patch of blue’s being a non-thing—is posited in dependence on that patch of blue, why could not nirvana exist in the same way? It would be posited in dependence upon the disintegration of the thing whose cessation it is, and that is how it is! Now, suppose that one asked, “Since there are no non-things that do not depend on things, then, in dependence on what thing is such a thing as the son of a barren woman a non-thing?” [446] In the fifteenth chapter, it says: Since entity does not exist, Nonentity does not exist. [XV: 5ab] Since ordinary people say that to change that which is a thing into something else is to make it a non-thing, who would say that the son of a barren woman is like a non-thing in that sense? But would this not contradict the following statement in the Laṅkāvatāra-sūtra that these are such non-things? The sky, a rabbit’s horns, The son of a barren woman: Although none of these exist, they are referred to by words. Those that depend on things are similar. [m Do sde ca 175b]

'dir ri bong gi rwa la sogs pa'i gzhi ma grub rnams dngos med min zhes gsungs pa ni/ dngos po zhig pa'i dngos med dang rang gi ngo bos grub pa'i da ngo sa me da 'a go ga gi da ngo sa med tsam zhig min par ba zhe da pa min te/ dngos po'i rtog pa bkaka pa tsam zhig yin gyi zhes gsungs pa'i phyir dang skabs gzhan du yang dngos po med par lan du mar bshad pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir gang zhig dngos po la brten nas 'dogs pa ma yin pa'i dngos med rang gi ngo bos yod pa min no zhes pa 'di ni gnas so/ /

Here, the mere negation of any thing is said to be a non-thing, but it does not say that these non-things exist inherently, because the things themselves do not exist inherently. Here, the statement that such things as a rabbit’s horns, which do not exist, are not non-things refutes the disintegration of a thing being an inherently existent non-thing, but does not mean that they are not mere non-things. This is because they are merely the negations of concepts of things, as it has been said, and it has been explained many times in different contexts that they are non-things. Therefore, the claim stands that no non-thing that is not designated in dependence on a thing exists inherently.
gsum pa [mtha' gnyis spangs pa'i myang 'das gang la 'jog pa] ni/
1.2.3.1.1.3 Presenting nirvana as free from the two extremes
gal te myang 'das de dngos po dang dngos med kyi ngo bos yod pa min na 'o na de gang yin zhe na/
Supposed someone asked, “If nirvana does not have the nature of being a thing or a non-thing, then what is it?”
'ong ba dang ni 'gro ba'i dngos/ / brten nam rgyur byas gang yin pa/ / de ni brten min rgyur byas min/ / mya ngan 'das pa yin par bstan/ /
9. A thing that comes and goes Is dependent and produced by causes. That which is not dependent and not produced by causes Is taught to be nirvana.

'jig rten snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba dang 'di nas 'jig rten phyi mar 'gro ba'i skye 'chi gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i dngos po ring thung ltar rang gi rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa la brten nas 'doT pa'am/ mar me las 'od skye ba ltar rang gi rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa rgyur byas nas 'dogs pa gang yin pa de ni/ rang gi rgyu rkyen gyi tshogs pa la brten pa min pa dang rgyur byas nas 'jug pa min par nyon mongs dang phung po'i spros pa sngar bshad pa ltar rab tu zhi ba tsam de ni mya ngan las 'das pa yin par bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan la/ de tsam ni dngos po yang min la dngos med du ngo bos grub pa'ang min no/ / yang na brten nas 'khor bar 'jug pa ni sngar bshad pa ltar 'du byed 'khor ba dang / nyer len gyi phung po rgyur byas nas 'jug pa ni sngar bshad pa'i gang zag 'khor ba'o/ / 'dir nyon mongs kyi sa bon spangs pa dang nyer len gyi phung po'i snang ba nub pa'i gzhir gyur pa'i sems kyi chos nyid myang 'das su bya'i/ nyon mongs la sogs pa'i rgyu rkyen rgyun chad pa las phyi ma'i rigs 'dra ma skyes pa ni myang 'das su mi bya ste/ / de ni rgyu snga ma zad pas bskyed pa'i ma 'ongs par bshad zin pa'i phyir ro/ /

The sentient being comes from the previous life to this life and goes from this life to the next, and thus continues from one birth and death to another, like long and short, which are posited in dependence on the assemblage of their causes and conditions, or like the light of the butterlamp, which is posited as caused by the assemblage of its causes and conditions. Neither depending on the assemblage of its causes and conditions, nor caused by the assemblage of its causes and conditions, the mere pacification of the proliferation of these aggregates and the afflictions is taught by the Transcendent Lord to be nirvana. [447] Just that is neither a thing nor an inherently existent non-thing. “Being involved in cyclic existence through dependence” means, as has been previously explained, the wandering of such things as the compounded phenomena in cyclic existence, and “being caused to be involved in cyclic existence by the appropriation of the aggregates” means, as has been previously explained, the wandering of the person in cyclic existence. Here, nirvana is regarded as the real nature of the mind, which is the basis of the abandonment of the seeds of affliction and the vanishing of the appearance of the appropriated aggregates; but nirvana is not regarded as the non-arising of homogeneous afflictions after the exhaustion of the continuum of their causes and conditions. This is because it has already been explained to be a future that is given rise to by the exhaustion of previous causes.
bzhi pa [mtha' gnyis su lta ba ston pas smad pa'i tshul] ni/
1.2.3.1.1.4 Showing how the teacher has condemned these two extreme views
'byung ba dang ni 'jig pa dag / spang bar ston pas bka' stsal to/ / de phyir mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos min dngos med min par rigs/ /
10. The teacher has spoken of relinquishing Becoming and passing away. Therefore it makes sense that Nirvana is neither a thing nor a non-thing.

gzhan yang mdo las/ dge slong dag gang dag 'byung ba'am 'jig pas srid pa las nges par 'byung ba 'tshol ba de dag gi yongs su mi shes pa yin no zhes byung ba'i sred pa dang ni 'jig pa'i sred pa dag spang bar ston pas bka' stsal zhing / myang 'das ni spang bya min par bka' stsal to/ / de'i phyir mya ngan las 'das pa ni dngos po min zhing dngos med kyi ngo bos yod pa min par rigs so/ / gal te de gnyis kyi ngo bos yod na ni myang 'das kyang dor bar bya ba kho nar 'gyur la/ 'byung ba dngos po dang 'jig pa dngos po med pa la rang bzhin gyis grub par zhen cing chags pa'i sred pas 'khor ba las nges par 'byung 'dod pa la smad pa yang mi 'thad par 'gyur ro/ /

Moreover, it is said in sūtra: Oh monks! Those who seek renunciation from cyclic existence through becoming and passing away are completely ignorant. [Udāna III, Nandavaggo section X, Lokasutta, 69] Thus the teacher says that the craving of becoming and the craving of passing away are to be abandoned. But he said that nirvana is not to be abandoned. Therefore, it follows that nirvana is neither a thing, nor does it exist inherently as a non-thing. If it existed inherently in either of those two ways, nirvana would also definitely be something to be discarded. But it would be unreasonable to condemn anyone who aspires to renounce wandering in cyclic existence through craving, which is the attachment to and fixation on becoming—that is, things—and passing away—that is, non-things—as essentially existent.
gnyis pa [de gnyis ka'i mthar 'dod pa dgag] ni/
1.2.3.1.2 Refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is both

rgol ba gang gi ltar na nyon mongs pa dang skye ba len pa gnyis kyi dngos po med pas myang 'das dngos med dang rang nyid dngos po'i ngo bo yin pas de gnyis kar rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dod pa la de gnyis re re ba la bkod pa'i skyon gyis mi gnod do snyam na/ 'di ni mu stegs 'os pa pas 'dod par shes rab sgron ma'i 'grel bshad las bshad de thar pa ni 'jig rten 'dus pa zhes pa grub pa'i zhing gi mtshan nyid yin pa dang srog gi tshig gi don gnas pas dngos po dang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal rgyun chad pas dngos po med pa yang yin no/ // de yang / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i thar pa 'tsho byed pa/ / rgya spos dri ma med pa'i mdog dang ni/ / 'o ma mu tig ba mo'i mdog 'dra zhing / dbyibs ni gdugs zlum bkan pa lta bu yin/ / zhes bshad pa 'dra ba zhig 'jig rten thams cad kyi steng na gnas par smra'o/ /

An opponent might argue as follows: Because it is is not a thing—that is, affliction and taking rebirth—nirvana is a non-thing; and because it itself has the nature of a thing, it is a thing. Therefore, the errors that have been shown to attach to each of these positions do not undermine the assertion that it exists essentially as both. According to Avalokitavrata’s commentary to the Prajñāpradīpa, The Jain philosophers maintain this. [448] According to them, moksha, which has the characteristic of “a compound universe,”/3/ has the meaning of “life.”/4/ Thus nirvana is a thing. And since it is the termination of the suffering of cyclic existence, it is a non-thing as well. As it is said, The Victor has said that at the time nirvana is achieved It has the color of the scentless joss stick, Milk, pearl, or frost, And has the shape of an open umbrella. [vol. 3, 257a–257b] Thus they say that nirvana is situated above the entire world.
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yin na/ / dngos dang dngos po med pa dag/ / thar bar 'gyur na de mi rigs/ /
11. If nirvana were both A thing and a non-thing, Then things and non-things would both be nirvana. But that makes no sense.

gal te mya ngan las 'das pa thar pa ni dngos po dang dngos med gnyis kar rang bzhin gyis de'i tshe dngos po dang dngos po med pa dag thar par 'gyur ro/ de'i phyir 'du byed rang gi bdag nyid gsar du skad cig dang por thob pa dang de'i dus gnyis par de dang bral ba thams cad thar par gnas pa yin na// 'di ni me du lta bu gcig la 'gyur na de dag ni thar par mi rigs so/ rang gi ngo bos gzhan du grub pa'i rgyu 'bras 'dod na gzhan gang yin thams cad kyang rgyu 'bras su thal ba brjod pa bzhin du/ dngos po dang dngos med kyi khyad par la rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i thar pa 'dod pa la'ang de ltar na de gnyis thams cad kyang thar par 'gyur ro zhes rgyu mtshan mtshungs pa'i mgo snyoms byed pa'o/ /

If nirvana existed essentially as both a thing and a non-thing, then both a thing and a non-thing would be nirvana. In that case, compounded phenomena that have newly attained their own status in the first moment and that are absent in the second moment would be nirvana, but it makes no sense for them to be nirvana. This is just like the case of fire and smoke: If they are regarded as existing essentially different from each other and as cause and effect, the absurd consequence follows that any two things could be cause and effect. By parity of reasoning, if a particular thing and non-thing are regarded as existing essentially as nirvana, the absurd consequence would follow that all things and non-things would be nirvana.
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yin na/ / mya ngan 'das pa ma brten min/ / de gnyis brten nas yin phyir ro/ /
12. If nirvana were both A thing and a non-thing, Nirvana would not be independent Because those two are dependent.

gzhan yang gal te mya ngan las 'das pa ni dngos po dang dngos med gnyis su rang bzhin gyis grub pa yin na/ de'i tshe mya ngan las 'das pa rgyu rkyen la ma brten pa min par brten nas skye bar 'gyur te/ dngos po dang dngos med rang bzhin gyis grub pa de gnyis ni rgyu rkyen la brten nas skye ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / myang 'das dngos med du rang gi ngo bos yod na gang gi dngos po med rgyu 'khor ba'i dngos po zhig pa'i mi rtag pa la 'dod dgos la de lta na de dngos po la brten nas skye ba'i rigs pa'o/ /

Moreover, if nirvana existed essentially both as a thing and a non-thing, then nirvana would not be independent of causes and conditions, but would arise dependently, because both things and non-things that exist essentially depend upon causes and conditions. This argument shows that in that case it would arise in dependence on a thing: If nirvana existed inherently as a nonthing, one would have to assert that it is an impermanence—the disintegration of a thing—that is, cyclic existence, which is the absence of that entity. [449]
ci ltar mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yin te/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'dus ma byas/ / dngos dang dngos med 'dus byas min/ /
13. How could nirvana Be both a thing and a non-thing? Nirvana is uncompounded. Both things and non-things are compounded.

gzhan yang ji ltar na mya ngan las 'das pa ni dngos po dang dngos med gnyis su rang gi ngo bos yod pa yin zhes pa min te/ yin na mya ngan las 'das pa 'dus ma byas ma yin par 'dus byas su 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar dngos po dang 'khor ba'i dngos po zad pa'i dngos med du rang gi ngo bos grub pa gnyis ka'ang 'dus byas yin pa'i phyir te/ de ni dngos po de'i zhig pa yin la skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes shi ba'i zhig pa yang skye ba'i rkyen las skye bar gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ //

Moreover, how could one say that nirvana could exist inherently as both a thing and a non-thing? One could not, because if it did, it would not be a noncompounded phenomenon; instead it would be a compounded phenomenon. Both the thing, and the non-thing—the exhaustion of cyclic existence—that exist inherently would both be compounded phenomena. This is because the non-thing is the disintegration of a thing. When it is said that aging and death arise from birth as a condition, this means that death—that is, disintegration—arises from birth as a condition.
ci ste myang 'das dngos po dang dngos med kyi rang bzhin du mi 'dod kyi de la de gnyis yod par 'dod do zhe na/
Suppose someone said that we do not maintain that nirvana is essentially both a thing and a non-thing, but that it has these two properties.
ci ltar mya ngan 'das pa la/ / dngos dang dngos med gnyis yod de/ / de gnyis gcig la yod min te/ / snang ba dang ni mun pa bzhin/ /
14. How could nirvana Be both a thing and a non-thing? These two cannot be in the same place, Like light and darkness.

mya ngan las 'das pa la ji ltar na dngos po dang dngos med gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod de med do/ // 'di ltar gzhi gcig la de gnyis rang gi ngo bos yod pa ni min te phan tshun 'gal ba'i phyir snang ba dang mun pa bzhin no/ / gal te gzhi de la bum pa'i dngos po yod pa dang snam bu'i dngos med yod pa gnyis/ mi 'gal ba bzhin du myang 'das la'ang 'khor ba'i dngos med yod pa dang thar pa'i dngos po yod pa gnyis mi 'gal lo zhe na/ dngos po dang dngos med rang mtshan gyis grub na gcig gi dngos po yod na dngos po kun yod pa dang / gcig gi dngos po med na dngos po kun med pa dgos pas mthar gzhi gcig la dngos po gcig yod med gnyis kar khas blang dgos so/ /

How could nirvana have both the property of being a thing and that of being a non-thing essentially? It could not! These two cannot be present inherently in the same basis because they are mutually inconsistent, like light and darkness. But suppose someone argued that it is more like the following case: Just as the existence of a pot—a thing—and the nonexistence of a cloth—a nonthing—in the same basis are not inconsistent, the existence of the non-thing—the absence of cyclic of existence—and the existence of the thing—nirvana—are not inconsistent. We reply that if the thing and the non-thing existed through their own characteristics, then if a thing—any one of these—could exist, any thing could exist; and if a non-thing—any one of these—could exist, than any thing could not exist. Consequently, one would have to accept the existence and non-existence of a single thing in a single basis.
gsum pa [gnyis ka ma yin pa'i mthar 'dod pa dgag pa] ni/
1.2.3.1.3 Refutation of the extreme assertion that nirvana is neither
dngos min dngos po med min pa/ / mya ngan 'das par gang ston pa/ / dngos po med dang dngos po dag / grub na de ni 'grub par 'gyur/ /
15. Nirvana is said to be Neither a thing nor a non-thing. If things or non-things could exist, It would exist.

gal te mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po yang min la dngos po med pa yang min par rang bzhin gyis yod par gang ston pa de'i ltar na'ang mi rigs te/ shes bya la dngos po med pa dang dngos po dag rang bzhin gyis grub na de dag gi khyad par bkag pa'i sgo nas dngos po'i khyad par dang dngos med kyi khyad par 'ga' zhig rang bzhin gyis 'grub par 'gyur na'ang / de gnyis gang yang rang bzhin gyis grub pa mi srid pas re re bkag pa'i cig shos kyang rang bzhin gyis 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / dper na ri bong dang rwa mi srid na ri bong gi rwa bkag pa dang mo gsham dang bu mi srid na mo gsham gyi bu bkag pa mi srid pa bzhin no/ /

Nor would it make sense to present nirvana as essentially neither a thing nor a non-thing. This is because with respect to objects of knowledge, if things and non-things existed essentially, despite the refutation of some of their instances, the existence of some other instances of things or non-things might exist essentially. [450] However, since neither of these can exist essentially, when the existence of either one is refuted, neither of them can exist essentially. For instance, if rabbits and horns were not possible, it would not be possible for there to be a rabbit’s horn whose existence could be refuted, and if sons and a barren women were not possible, it would not possible for there to be a son of a barren woman whose existence could be refuted.
gal te mya ngan 'das pa ni/ / dngos min dngos po med min na/ / dngos min dngos po med min zhes/ / gang zhig gis ni de mngon byed/ /
16. If nirvana is Neither a thing nor a non-thing, Then by whom is it expounded as “Neither a thing nor a non-thing?”

gzhan yang gal te mya ngan las 'das pa ni dngos po dang dngos med min pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis grub na/ de 'dra ba de dngos po min zhing dngos po med pa min pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes gang zhig gis ni myang 'das de mngon par te 'dzin pa dang gsal bar byed/ ci lhag med kyi tshe de yod na ni de'i dus su bdag yod par 'gyur na/ de ltar khyed kyis mi 'dod de nye bar len pa'i phung po med pa'i bdag yod par mi 'dod pa'i phyir dang / lhag med kyi tshe phung po rgyun chad par 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste de'i dus su 'dzin mkhan de med na ni myang 'das de 'dra'o ngo bor yod par gang gis shes par 'gyur/ gal te 'khor ba na gnas pas yongs su gcod do zhe na/ de ci rnam shes kyis sam ye shes kyis gcod grang / dang po ni mi rigs te rnam shes ni spros pa'i mtshan ma la dmigs pa yin la/ mya ngan las 'das pa mngon sum du byed pa'i ngo na spros pa'i mtshan ma cung zad kyang med pa'i phyir dang / 'dir yongs su gcod par byed pa ni mngon sum du gcod par byed pa'i skabs yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de kho na nyid kyi don mngon sum du rtogs pa'i ye shes kyis gcod par 'dod na'ang mi rigs te/ ye shes de ni rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa'i stong nyid dang ro mnyam du zhugs pa yin pas rang bzhin gyis yod pa ma yin la/ des ni rang bzhin gyis yod pa'i myang 'das gcod par mi byed pa'i phyir te/ ye shes ni spros pa'i mtshan ma thams cad las 'das pa yin pa'i phyir dang myang 'das rang bzhin gyis yod par 'dzin na mtshan 'dzin gyi 'chi ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dir rnam shes dang ye shes gnyis su phye ba ni spros pa'i snang ba nub ma nub kyi dbang du byas kyi phung po lnga'i rnam shes kyi phung po'i dbang du byas pa min no//

Moreover, if nirvana existed inherently as neither a thing nor a non-thing, then by whom would that nirvana be expounded as existing essentially neither as a thing nor a non-thing? Who would expound—that is, clarify and cause others to grasp—it? If, when nirvana without residual aggregates is attained, he existed, there would be a self. But you do not say this, because you do not maintain that there is a self without the appropriated aggregates, and you maintain that the continuum of aggregates is terminated when nirvana without residual aggregates is attained. Since there is no agent, then who would know that nirvana exists in that way? But suppose someone asked, “Does someone in cyclic existence know that?” By what means could this be known? Either through an ordinary cognitive process or through wisdom? The first case makes no sense, because ordinary cognitive processes objectify the representations of elaboration, but the meaning of “direct perception of nirvana” is the absence of even the slightest representation of fabrication. In this context, to know is to perceive directly. Nor does it make sense that it is known through the wisdom of the direct perception of reality. This is because, since this wisdom and the emptiness—the emptiness of essence—in which it is absorbed are completely congruent in nature, it does not exist essentially. Thus that could not be the means by which one knows any essentially existent nirvana. [451] This is because that wisdom is free from all representations of fabrication; and to grasp nirvana as essentially existent is to be bound by the grasping of representations. This distinction between ordinary consciousness and wisdom is drawn in terms of whether or not the appearance of fabrication has disappeared, but it is not drawn with reference to consciousness as understood in terms of the five aggregates.
gnyis pa [myang 'das thugs su chud pa po mtha' bzhir ma grub par bstan] ni/
1.2.3.2 Showing that one who realizes nirvana does not exist in any of the four extreme ways
bcom ldan mya ngan 'das gyur nas/ / yod par mi mngon de bzhin du/ / med do zhe 'am gnyi ga dang / / gnyis min zhes kyang mi mngon no/ /
17. Having passed into nirvana, the Transcendent Lord Is neither perceived to be existent Nor perceived to be nonexistent. He is neither perceived to be both nor to be neither.

ji ltar mya ngan las 'das pa la dngos po la sogs par rtog pa'i rtog pa bzhis bzung ba ltar med pa de bzhin du/ myang 'das thugs su chud pa po bcom ldan 'das mya ngan las 'das par gyur nas rang bzhin gyis yod par mi mngon pa ste gzung du med la/ de bzhin du mya ngan gang las 'das pa'i dngos po de med do zhes par yang rang bzhin gyis grub pa med do/ / de gnyis med pas yod med de gnyis ka tshogs par yod pa dang gnyis ka tshogs pa med pas/ yod med de gnyis ka min pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes kyang mi mngon pa ste gzung du med do/ /

Just as nirvana cannot be conceptualized as falling under any of the four concepts such as being a thing, etc., he who has achieved nirvana—the Transcendent Lord—after having achieved nirvana cannot be perceived to be—that is, be grasped as—existing essentially. In the same way, the absence of the thing from which he has achieved liberation is also essentially nonexistent. Since it exists in neither of these two ways, it is not perceived to be both, and since it is not perceived to be both, it is not perceived—that is, grasped—to be essentially neither.
bcom ldan bzhugs par gyur na yang / / yod pa mi mngon de bzhin du/ / med do zhe 'am gnyi ga dang / / gnyis min zhes kyang mi mngon na/ /
18. So, when the Transcendent Lord was alive, he Was neither perceived to be existent Nor perceived to be nonexistent. He was neither perceived to be both nor to be neither.

gzhan yang bcom ldan 'das bzhugs par gyur pa'i dus na yang rang bzhin gyis yod par mi mngon la de bzhin du med do zhe'am/ yod med gnyis ka tshogs pa dang gnyis ka min par rang bzhin gyis yod do zhes kyang mi mngon te 'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa brtag par bshad zin to/ /

Moreover, when the Transcendent Lord was alive, he was not seen to exist essentially nor, in the same way, to be nonexistent, nor was he seen to be both existent and nonexistent, nor was he seen to be essentially neither existent nor nonexistent. This has been explained in the chapter called “The Examination of the Tathāgata.”
gsum pa [des grub pa'i don]
1.2.3.3 Drawing conclusions from this
['di] la gnyis/ srid zhi mnyam nyid du grub pa dang / lung ma bstan gyi lta ba dgag pa grub pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the congruence of cyclic existence and nirvana and establishing that the undiscussed views are rejected.
dang po [srid zhi mnyam nyid du grub pa] ni/
1.2.3.3.1 The congruence of cyclic existence and nirvana
'khor ba mya ngan 'das pa las/ / khyad par cung zad yod ma yin/ / mya ngan 'das pa 'khor ba las/ / khyad par cung zad yod pa yin/ /
19. Cyclic existence is not the slightest bit Different from nirvana. Nirvana is not the slightest bit Different from cyclic existence.

ston pa bzhugs dus dang mya ngan las 'das dus gnyis la mtha' bzhi dang bral ma bral gyi khyad par med pa de'i phyir 'khor ba mya ngan las 'das pa las dang / mya ngan las 'das pa 'khor ba las phan tshun du bden brdzun gyi khyad par cung zad kyang yod pa ma yin te/ rigs pas sngar ltar rnam par dpyad na rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa'i rang bzhin kun nas mtshungs pa'i phyir ro/ //

Since there is no difference between the teacher when he was alive and when he passed into nirvana in terms of whether or not he was free from the four extremes, nirvana is no different from cyclic existence; nor is cyclic existence the slightest bit different from nirvana, in terms of whether either is real or unreal. This is because if they are analytically examined, as we have seen previously, [452] they are absolutely identical in terms of their nature as completely empty of essence.
mya ngan 'das mtha' gang yin pa/ / de ni 'khor ba'i mtha' yin te/ / de gnyis khyad par cung zad ni/ / shin tu phra ba'ang yod ma yin/ /
20. Whatever is the limit of nirvana, That is the limit of cyclic existence. There is not even the slightest difference between them, Or even the subtlest thing.

de yi phyir dge slong dag skye ba dang rga shi'i 'khor ba ni thog ma dang tha ma med pa yin no zhes gsungs pa yang tshul 'di nyid la 'thad de/ dang po'i 'khor ba dang phyis kyi myang 'das gnyis ka rang bzhin mtshungs pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar mya ngan las 'das pa'i yang dag pa'i mtha' stong nyid kyi stong tshul gang yin pa de ni 'khor ba'i yang dag pa'i mtha' stong nyid kyi stong tshul yin te/ de gnyis la ni khyad par cung zad kyang yod pa ma yin no/ /

Therefore this statement is relevant to this context: O monks! Cyclic existence—birth, aging, and death—is beginningless and endless. [Indirect quotation from Hastikakṣya-sūtra, mDo sde tsha loga cited in Prasannapadā 180a] The former—cyclic existence—and the latter—nirvana—are the same in nature. Whatever is nirvana’s ultimate limit—that is, its mode of emptiness—is cyclic existence’s ultimate limit—that is, its mode of emptiness. This is because there is not even the slightest difference between these two.
gnyis pa [lung ma bstan gyi lta ba dgag pa grub pa] ni/
1.2.3.3.2 Establishing that the undiscussed views are rejected
gang 'das phan chad mtha' sogs dang / / rtag la sogs par lta ba dag / mya ngan 'das dang phyi mtha' dang / / sngon gyi mtha' la rten pa yin/ /
21. Views regarding his status after his passing; extremes, etc., And views regarding the permanent, etc., Are grounded upon nirvana, the final limit, And the prior limit.

srid zhi rang bzhin khyad par med pas sngon dang phyi ma'i mthar rtog pa mi rung bar ma zad kyi de bzhin gshegs pa gang mya ngan las 'das pa'am grongs phan chad yod pa dang med pa dang gnyis ka dang / gnyis ka ma yin pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis yod par lta ba dag ni mya ngan las 'das pa la brten nas mchog tu 'dzin par zhugs pa'o/ / 'jig rten mtha' dang ldan pa dang la sogs kyis bsdus pa mtha' dang mi ldan pa dang / gnyis ka dang / gnyis ka min pa'i ngo bo rang bzhin gyis yod par lta ba dag ni phyi ma'i mtha' la brten nas 'jug pa'o/ / de la bdag dang 'jig rten la ma 'ongs pa'i skye ba ma mthong ba na mtha' dang ldan pa dang skye ba mthong ba na mtha' dang mi ldan pa dang / 'ga' zhig la mthong zhing 'ga' zhig la ma mthong ba na gnyis ka dang gnyis ka bkag pas ni gnyis ka ma yin par rtog pa skye'o// 'jig rten rtag pa dang la sogs kyis bsdus pa 'jig rten mi rtag pa dang rtag mi rtag gnyis ka dang gnyis ka ma yin pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis yod par lta ba dag ni sngon gyi mtha' la brten nas 'jug pa'o/ / de la bdag dang 'jig rten la sngon 'das pa'i dus su skye ba mthong ba dang ma mthong ba dang cha 'ga' zhig mthong zhing cha 'ga' zhig la ma mthong bas dang de gnyis ka bkag pas ni rtag pa la sogs par rtog pa skye'o/ /

Since there is no difference between cyclic existence and nirvana in terms of their nature, it is not only irrational to conceive of the extremes of beginning and end, but to view the Tathāgata as essentially existing, not existing, both, or neither after his passing into nirvana is also mistakenly to regard one’s own view as superior grounded on nirvana. To view the world as existing essentially with the nature of having limits, etc., and with the nature of those indicated by “etc.,”—including having no limits, both having and not having limits, and neither—is to engage with the world grounded on the final limit. When the self and the world are seen not to be arising in the future, one develops the idea that they have an end. When they are seen to be arising in the future, one develops the idea that they have no end. When some are seen to have ends and some are seen not to have ends, one develops the idea that they have both. When both are rejected, one develops the idea that they have neither. To view the world as existing essentially as permanent and in the ways indicated by “etc.”—including viewing it as impermanent, both, and neither—is to engage with the world grounded on the prior limit. When the self and the world are seen to have arisen in the past, one develops the idea that they are permanent. When the self and the world are seen not to have arisen in the past, one develops the idea that they are impermanent. When the self and the world are seen to be partly arisen in the past and partly not, one develops the idea that they are both permanent and impermanent. [453] And when are both are rejected, one develops the view that they are neither.

dngos po thams cad stong pa la/ / mtha' yod ci zhig mtha' med ci/ / mtha' dang mtha' med ci zhig yin/ / mtha' dang mtha' med min pa'ang ci/ / de nyid ci zhig gzhan ci zhig / rtag pa ci zhig mi rtag ni/ / rtag dang mi rtag gnyi ga ci/ / gnyi ga min pa'ang ci zhig yin/ /

22. Since all existents are empty, What is finite or infinite? What is finite and infinite? What is neither finite nor infinite? 23. What is identical and what is different? What is permanent and what is impermanent? What is both permanent and impermanent? What is neither?

lta ba 'di rnams ni dngos po rang bzhin gyis grub pa yod na 'thad mod kyang dngos po thams cad rang bzhin gyis yod pas stong pa la/ mthar yod pa dang mtha' med pa dang mtha' yod pa dang mtha' med pa gnyis ka dang mtha' yod dang mtha' med min par lta ba dang / lus gang yin pa de nyid srog dang lus kyang gzhan la srog kyang gzhan no zhes pa dang / rtag pa dang mi rtag pa dang rtag mi rtag gnyis ka dang gnyis ka min par lta ba'i lta bas bzung ba ltar gyi don ci zhig yod de med do/ / dngos po la rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i rang gi ngo bo sgro btags nas de dang bral ba dang ma bral ba las lta ba 'di dag bskyed nas mngon par zhen pa 'dis ni/ thar pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba'i lam 'gog cing 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal la sbyor bar byed pa shes par bya'o/ /

All of these views would be tenable if things existed essentially. But since all things are empty of essential existence, what things could there be to view through the extreme of existence, through the extreme of nonexistence, through the extreme of both existence and nonexistence, or through the extreme of neither? How could one view the body as life, or view the body and life as different? What things could exist as they are grasped through the views of permanence, impermanence, both permanence and impermanence, or through the view according to which there is neither? There could be none! One should understand that those who imagine that the nature of things is to exist essentially develop these views on the basis of whether or not things are free of that nature and hence develop fixations. These fixations are obstacles on the road that leads to the city of liberation, and lead one instead to the sufferings of cyclic existence.
bzhi pa [de ltar bkag pa la lung dang 'gal ba spang ba] ni/
1.2.4 Rebutting the charge that this refutation contradicts sūtra

khyod kyis myang 'das rang bzhin gyis grub pa bkag na ston pas sems can mya ngan las 'das pa thob pa'i don du nyon mongs la spyod pa'i gnyen por de dang rjes su mthun pa'i chos bstan pa don med par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: Since you have refuted the essential existence of nirvana, there would be no point in the teacher teaching the Dharma as an antidote to the afflictions so that sentient beings can attain liberation.
dmigs pa thams cad nyer zhi zhing / / spros pa nyer zhi zhi ba ste/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis gang du yang / / su la'ang chos 'ga' ma bstan to/ /
24. The pacification of all objectification And the pacification of all fabrication is peace. No Dharma was taught by the Buddha At any time, in any place, to any person.
