gal te bshad bya'i chos dang nyan pa po dang ston pa po rang bzhin gyis grub pa 'ga' zhig yod na de ltar yin kyang / gang gi tshe ngang pa'i rgyal po nam mkha' la rang gi gshog pa brdabs pa'i rlung la gnas pa'am rlung nam mkha' la gnas pa ltar/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mya ngan las 'das pa spros pa thams cad nye bar zhi zhing zhi ba'i ngo bo la mtshan mar mi gnas pa'i tshul gyis gnas pa de'i tshe/ mtshan mar 'dzin pa'i dmigs pa thams cad nye bar zhi zhing ma dmigs pa'i phyir de'i dbang du byas na sangs rgyas kyis ni/ lha yul lam mi yul gang du yang lha'am mi su la'ang kun nas nyon mongs sam rnam byang gi chos 'ga' yang ma bstan to/ / spros pa nyer zhi dang zhi ba gnyis ni rim pa bzhin du myang 'das la mtshan ma rnams mi 'jug pa dang rang bzhin gyis nye bar zhi ba'am tshig dang sems mi 'jug pa'am nyon mongs dang skye ba mi 'byung ba'am/ nyon mongs dang bag chags ma lus par spangs pa'am shes bya dang shes pa ma dmigs pa'o/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las/ zhi ba'i blo gros gang gi nub mo de bzhin gshegs pas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa dang / gang gi nub mo len pa mi mnga' bar yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur ba de'i bar du de bzhin gshegs pas tha na yig 'bru gcig kyang ma gsungs so/ / gsung bar mi 'gyur ro/ /

If any of the Dharma that is to be taught, the disciples, or the teacher existed essentially, this would be correct. However, just as when the king of the swans takes to the sky by flapping his wings, he flies relying on the air, and the air relies on space, so the Buddha—the Transcendent Lord who has attained nirvana and who has pacified all fabrications—remains in that peaceful state without relying on representations. In that state, all objectification—the grasping of representations—is pacified. In a context where there is no objectification, the Buddha did not teach any Dharma, either concerning cyclic existence or concerning nirvana, to anyone—whether divine or human—anywhere, [454] whether in the realm of the gods or in the human realm. These two phrases, “the pacification of fabrication” and “peace” mean, respectively, the absence of engagement with representations in nirvana and peace by virtue of its very nature, or, respectively, the nonengagement with words and thoughts and the non-arising of the afflictions and birth, or the abandonment of all afflictions and their latent potentials and the absence of the objectification of objects of knowledge and knowledge. The Tathāgatācintyaguhyanirdeśa-sūtra says, Oh, Śāntamati! From the night when the Transcendent Lord attained the unparalleled, complete enlightenment until the night when, without appropriation, he will pass into parinirvana, the Transcendent Lord did not utter even a single syllable. Nor will he say anything. [dKon brtsegs ka 144a]

zhes dang / ting 'dzin rgyal po las/ thams cad tshig med yi ge med/ / gdod nas zhi zhing dri med de/ / chos rnams de ltar sus shes pa/ / de ni gzhon nu sangs rgyas brjod/ / ces gsungs so/ / sangs rgyas kyis su la'ang chos ma bstan na gsung rab kyi tha snyad sna tshogs pa 'di dag mngon par ji ltar 'gyur zhe na/ston pas kho bo cag la chos bstan to zhes pa 'di ni gdul bya ma rig pa'i gnyid dang ldan pa'i rmi lam rmi bzhin pa rnams kyi rang gi rnam rtog las byung ba yin no/ / de ltar yang ye shes snang ba rgyan las/ / de bzhin gshegs pa zag pa med pa yi/ / dge ba'i chos kyi gzugs brnyan lta bu yin/ / 'di na de bzhin nyid dang de bzhin gshegs pa med/ / 'jig rten thams cad kyis ni gzugs brnyan mthong / / zhes gsungs pa ltar ro/ / de'i phyir myang 'das kyi don du chos bstan pa de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i rigs ngor med kyi tha snyad pa'i shes pa'i ngor yod pa tsam yin pas de las myang 'das rang bzhin gyis yod par ga la 'gyur/ /

And the Samādhirāja-sūtra says, Since everything is primordially pacified, stainless, And without words or letters, He who knows things that way Is called the youthful Buddha. [mDo sde da 22b] Now somebody might ask, “If the Buddha did not teach the Dharma to anyone, how could all of these scriptures have emerged?” To say that the teacher taught the Dharma to us means that it has arisen from the conceptual thought of the addressees who sleep in ignorance and who are dreaming. The Sarvabuddhaviṣayāvatārajñānālokālaṁkāra-sūtra says, The Tathāgata is like the reflection of Uncontaminated virtuous phenomena. Here neither reality nor the Tathāgata exist. The entire world sees only the reflections. [mDo sde ga 284b] Therefore, since the teachings that are presented for the purpose of attaining the goal of nirvana do not exist from the perspective of a rational realization of reality, but merely exist from the perspective of conventional cognition, [455] how could nirvana exist essentially?
gnyis pa [nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba] ni/
2. Confirmation by Citations from Definitive Sūtras

de ltar myang 'das rang bzhin gyis ma grub par bstan pa de nyid zab mo'i lung gis kyang grub pa dang / rab tu byed pa 'dis mya ngan las 'das pa bden pa med cing sgyu ma lta bur bstan pa thams cad bshad par bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir du nges don gyi lung dang sbyor ba'i phyogs tsam bstan pa ni/ theg chen gyi mdo sde'i mtha' las/ mya ngan 'das med myang 'das su/ 'jig rten mgon gyis bstan pa ste/ / nam mkha' mdud pa bor ba ni/ / nam mkha' nyid kyis bkrol ba yin/ / zhes skud pa ring pos 'drubs kyi las byed pa'i skud pa de nam mkha' la 'jur mdud 'cha' ba na nam mkha' nyid las 'grol ba bzhin du/ bcom ldan 'das mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pas kyang mya ngan las 'das pa la sogs pa bden par ma grub pa ste kun rdzob kyi tha snyad du yod par ston zhing rang bzhin med par yang ston no/ / tshangs pas zhus pa las kyang / bcom ldan 'das gang dag chos 'ga' zhig skye ba'am 'gag par 'tshal ba de dag la ni sangs rgyas 'byung ba ma lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das gang dag 'khor ba dngos por 'tshol ba de dag ni 'khor ba las 'da' ba ma lags so/ / de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bgyi ba ni gang mtshan ma thams cad rab tu zhi ba rnam par rtog pa thams cad 'gags pa lags na/ bcom ldan 'das skyes bu blun po legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu byung nas mu stegs kyi lta bar lhung ba de dag ni 'di lta ste/ til las til mar dang 'o ma las mar gsar ltar mya ngan las 'das pa dngos po las tshol bar bgyid do/ / bcom ldan 'das gang dag chos thams cad shin tu mya ngan las 'das pa la mya ngan las 'das pa 'tshol ba mngon pa'i nga rgyal can de dag ni mu stegs can yin no/ / zhes kho bo gleng ste/ bcom ldan 'das rnal 'byor spyod pa yang dag par zhugs pa ni chos gang yang ba'am 'gag par mi bgyid la chos gang yang thob pa'am mngon par rtogs par mi 'tshal lo/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

A brief indication that this can be confirmed by citations from definitive sūtras is presented in order to show that the presentation in this chapter of nirvana as not existing essentially is corroborated by profound sūtras, and to show that this chapter represents the teachings of all of the sūtras that present nirvana as not truly existent and as illusionlike. A Mahāyāna sūtra says: The non-nirvana is taught to be nirvana By the teacher, the patron of the world. The knot tied by the sky Is untied by the sky itself. [Avaivartacakra-sūtra, mDo sde sha 271a] Just as those who sew with a long thread undo knots by shaking them in the air, the Transcendent Lord, who is a fully enlightened Buddha, has taught that things such as nirvana are not truly existent; they are taught to exist only by nominal convention, to be essenceless. The Brahmaviśeṣacintiparipṛcchā-sūtra says, O Transcendent Lord: Some phenomena that have arising and ceasing are not arisen, Buddha! O Transcendent Lord: Those who seek cyclic existence/5/ in things are not freed from cyclic existence! Why is that so? O Transcendent Lord: That which is called nirvana is free of all representations, and there all conceptualizations cease! O Transcendent Lord: Those fools who have ordained according to the discipline you have so eloquently set out in the Dharma, but have fallen into heretical views, expect nirvana to come from things, just as tahini comes from sesame seeds and butter comes from milk. O Transcendent Lord: I call those arrogant people who seek nirvana in all phenomena, [456] which are completely liberated, “heretics.” O Transcendent Lord: Yogis and those who engage in the perfect practices neither give rise to nor terminate anything. Nor do they aspire to achieve any realization. [mDo sde ba 33b]
gsum pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
3. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

chos rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pa la ni spang bya spangs pa dang myang 'das thob pa sogs mi rung ba dang rang bzhin gyis grub pas stong pa'i phyogs la de rnams thams cad 'thad pa'i tshul nges par bya'o/ /

One should ascertain that if things existed essentially, such things as the abandonment of that which is to be abandoned and the attainment of nirvana would not be possible, but they are completely tenable according to the position that everything is empty of essential existence.
mya ngan las 'das pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu lnga pa'o// //
This is the twenty-fifth chapter called the examination of nirvana.
mya ngan las 'das pa brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa nyer bzhi'i bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa lnga pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-fifth chapter, having twenty-four verses, called the examination of nirvana.

d.crumb: *XXVI. Examination of the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination

f.d: CHAPTER XXVI. Examination of the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination
gnyis pa rten 'byung rtogs ma rtogs las 'khor ba'i 'jug ldog byed lugs

This chapter constitutes the second part of that section—the presentation of the fact that whether one remains engaged in cyclic existence or frees oneself from it depends on whether or not one realizes that.
['di] la gnyis/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ /
This chapter has two parts: the explanation of the chapter and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba gang*/ / de ni stong pa nyid du bshad/ // ces pa'i rten 'byung de gang yin zhes pa'am/ gang gis rten cing 'brel bar 'byung //mthong ba des ni sdug bsngal dang / / zhes rten 'byung mthong na bden bzhi'i de nyid mthong bar gsungs pa'i rten 'byung de gang zhe na/ 'di ston pa la gnyis/ lugs 'byung gi rten 'brel dang / lugs bzlog gi rten 'brel lo/ /

Here one might ask: What is that dependent origination to which he refers in these lines? Whatever is dependently arisen. That is explained to be emptiness. [XXIV: 18ab] And what is that dependent origination by seeing which he says in these lines that the reality of the Four Noble Truths is seen? Whoever sees dependent arising Also sees suffering. [XXIV: 40ab] The explanation of this has two parts: the order of dependent origination and the reverse order of dependent origination.
dang po [lugs 'byung gi rten 'brel]
1.1 The order of dependent origination
['di] la gnyis/ 'phen byed kyi rgyu 'bras dang / 'grub byed kyi rgyu 'bras so/ /
This section has two parts: the causes and effects that propel one into life and the resultant causes and effects.
dang po ['phen byed kyi rgyu 'bras] ni/
1.1.1 The causes and effect that propel one into life
ma rig bsgribs pas yang srid phyir/ / 'du byed rnam pa gsum po dag / mngon par 'du byed gang yin pa'i/ / las de dag gis 'gro bar 'gro/ /
1. The three kinds of actions that lead to rebirth, Performed by one obscured by ignorance, Are the karma that impel one To further transmigration.

ma rig pa ni de kho na nyid rig pa bkag tsam dang de las gzhan pa tsam min gyi rig pa de'i 'gal ba mi mthun phyogs gang zag gam chos la dmigs nas rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub par 'dzin pa'o// // des yang dag pa'i don bsgribs pa'i gang zag gis yang srid mngon par 'du byed pa'i 'du byed bsod nams dang bsod nams min pa dang mi g.yo ba'am/ lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las rnam pa gsum po dag mngon par 'du byed pa ste skyed par byed do/ / de ni yang srid pa ste skye ba phyi ma'i phung po 'byung ba'i phyir du 'du byed de gang zag des de thob pa'i phyir du dmigs nas 'du byed par ma nges kyang las de 'bras bu de'i don du 'jug pa'o/ / de ltar bskyed pa gang yin pa'i las de dag gi dbang gis ni 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ /

Ignorance is not just the absence of insight into the way things really are, nor just something different from it. Instead, it is the very opposite of that knowledge, and is completely heterogeneous with it. That is, it is the grasping of the person and phenomena as truly existent by objectifying them. In virtue of the real facts being obscured by ignorance, the person performs—that is, gives rise to—meritorious, nonmeritorious, and unshakable action—or actions of body, speech, and mind—that [457] lead to rebirth. He performs actions that lead to rebirth, but this does not entail that the person performs the action with that aim, but that action issues in that result. Through the power of the actions that have been given rise to in this way, beings proceed through transmigration.
'du byed rkyen can rnam par shes/ / 'gro ba rnams su 'jug par 'gyur/ / rnam par shes pa zhugs gyur na/ / ming dang gzugs ni 'chags par 'gyur/ /
2. Having action as its conditions, Consciousness enters transmigration. Once consciousness has entered transmigration, Name and form come to be.

de nas 'du byed bsags pa'i gang zag de'i rnam par shes pa 'du byed kyi rkyen can 'khor ba'i sa bon du gyur pa ni 'du byed dang mthun pa'i 'gro ba lha la sogs pa rnams su 'jug pa ste skye bar 'gyur te/ de yang 'chi srid 'gags pa na skad cig gcig kho na la srang mda'i mtho dman gyi tshul du skye srid kyi phung po rnams las kyis ji ltar 'phags pa bzhin skye'o/ / de'i phyir de ltar ma'i mngal du rnam par shes pa zhugs nas brgyal bar gyur pa na de'i rkyen can gyi ming gzhi'i phung po dang gzugs kyi phung po chags par 'gyur ro/ / ming ni phung po lhag ma bzhi yin la de la ming zhes pa ni/las nyon gyis bsgos pas skye ba'i gnas de dang der bkri bas sam don rnams la 'du shes kyi dbang gis rgyug pas na ming ngo* / / gzugs ni skabs de'i mer mer po la sogs pa'o/ //

Thereafter, the consciousness of the person who has accumulated the dispositions, is conditioned by action, and is the seed of existence, enters transmigrations such as that of—that is, takes birth as—a god, for instance, according to his actions. And at the very moment when the state of death ceases, just like the arms of a balance, the aggregates arise in the state of birth, as they are propelled by karma. Thereafter, when the consciousness enters the mother’s womb, and when it sinks into oblivion, with the consciousness as a condition, the four name aggregates—and the form aggregate—come to be./1/ The other four aggregates—the name aggregates—are referred to as “name” because the consciousness, through being stained by karma and afflictions, is led by these aggregates to its appropriate realm of rebirth or because through discrimination they engage consciousness with the object./2/ Form includes such things as the embryo in this context.
ming dang gzugs ni 'chags 'gyur na/ / skye mched drug ni 'byung bar 'gyur / skye mched drug la brten nas ni/ / reg pa yang dag 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
3. Once name and form come to be, The six senses come into being. Depending on the six senses, Contact comes into being.

de ltar ming bzhi dang mer mer po la sogs pa'i gzugs ni chags par gyur na sdug bsngal 'byung ba'i skye sgor gyur pas skye mched de/ mig dang rna ba dang sna dang lce dang lus dang yid kyi skye mched drug ming dang gzugs kyi rkyen las 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / lus dang yid kyi dbang po de'i sngon nas yod kyang drug tshogs pa 'di nas byung ba'i dbang du mdzad do/ / de nas skye mched drug la brten nas ni reg pa yang dag par 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ // reg pa de ji ltar skye ba dang ngo bo gang yin snyam na/

When the four name aggregates and such things as the embryo—form—come into being, then the senses, which are the doors to the arising of suffering, come into being. They are the six senses: the eyes, the ears, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the introspective sense, which arise from name and form as conditions. Although the physical and mental organs exist prior to this, the collection of the six arises at this point, and that is why they are mentioned at this stage. Thereafter, depending on the six senses, contact arises. How does contact arise, and what is its nature?

ming dang gzugs dang dran byed la/ / brten nas skye ba kho na ste/ / de ltar mig dang gzugs brten nas/ / rnam par shes pa skye bar 'gyur/ / mig dang gzugs dang rnam par shes/ / gsum po 'dus pa gang yin pa/ / de ni reg pa'o reg de las/ / tshor ba kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

4. That is only dependent On eye and form and retention. Thus depending on name and form, Consciousness arises. 5. That which is assembled from the three— Eye and form and consciousness— Is contact. From contact Feeling comes to be.

bdag rkyen mig dang dmigs rkyen gzugs dang de ma thag rkyen dran byed de yid la byed pa la brten nas mig gi rnam par shes pa skye ba kho na'o/ // de ltar dran byed kyis mtshon pa'i de ma thag rkyen gyis ni tshor ba la sogs pa phung po bzhi'i ming dang rkyen dang po gnyis kyi gzugs la brten nas ni/ mig gi rnam par shes pa skye bar 'gyur ba'i mig dang gzugs dang rnam par shes pa gsum po 'dus pa gang yin pa de ni reg pa'i mtshan nyid yin la skye tshul yang rnam shes ltar ro/ / yul dbang rnam shes gsum 'dus pa'i mig gi 'dus te reg pas ni reg pa gzhan lnga yang shes par bya'o/ / de yang gsum po 'dus pa'i skabs su yul yid du 'ong mi 'ong bar ma gsum yongs su gcod pa'o/ / de nas reg pa de las yid du 'ong mi 'ong sogs bcad pa dang mthun par tshor ba bde sdug btang snyoms gsum kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur la/ mig gi 'dus te reg pa'i rkyen gyi tshor bas ni tshor ba lhag ma lnga yang shes par bya'o// de ltar na gang 'phangs pa ni ming gzugs dang skye mched drug dang reg pa dang tshor ba ste bzhir kun las btus las gsungs te 'bras dus kyi rnam shes kyang ngo / // gang gis 'phangs na ma rig pa la brten pa'i 'du byed kyis so/ / ji ltar 'phangs na rgyu dus kyi rnam shes la las kyi bag chags bsgos pa'i tshul gyis so/ / 'phangs pa'i don ni sred pa sogs kyi 'grub byed yod na 'bras bu de dag 'grub rung du byas pa'o/ /

The visual consciousness arises just depending on the eye, the dominant condition; the material form, the objective condition; and retention—holding in the [458] mind—the immediate condition. The immediate cause—retention, for example—gives rise to visual consciousness depending on the four name aggregates—feeling, etc.,—and the first two conditions, such as material form. Their condition is the joining of the three—name, form, and consciousness—and this is the characteristic of contact; it arises in the same way that consciousness does. The other five kinds of contact should be understood in terms of the joining of the three—the object, the sense faculty, and consciousness—in contact through the visual assemblage. When the three join, the three kinds of objects—pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral—are discerned. Thereafter, through contact, in accord with the discernment of the pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral objects, respectively, these three—pleasure, suffering, or indifference, respectively—arise. The other five sets of feelings should be understood in terms of the feeling conditioned by contact through the visual assemblage. Thus, sūatrasamuccaya says that those that are propelled are four: name and form, the six senses, contact, and feeling [Sems tsam ri 65b]. This includes the resultant consciousness. What propels them? Action that depends on ignorance! How are they propelled? By consciousness—the causally efficacious cognitive process pervaded by latent potentials. The meaning of “propelled” is as follows: If there are causal bases, such as craving, they make the effects possible.
gnyis pa ['grub byed kyi rgyu 'bras] ni/
1.1.2 The resultant causes and effects
tshor ba'i rkyen gyis sred pa ste/ / tshor ba'i don du sred par 'gyur/ / sred par gyur nas nye bar len/ / rnam pa bzhi po nyer len 'gyur/ /
6. Conditioned by feeling is craving. Craving arises for feeling. When one craves, The four objects of appropriation will be appropriated.

de nas tshor ba'i rkyen gyis sred pa skye bar 'gyur te sred pa ni tshor ba'i yul can no/ ci'i phyir sred na sred pa can de tshor ba'i don du sred par 'gyur te mngon par 'dod pa skyed do/ / de yang tshor ba bde ba la ni 'bral ba'i phyir dang sdug bsngal la ni 'bral ba'i phyir dang btang snyoms la mi nyams pa'i phyir du sred do/ / de ltar sred par gyur na sred pa'i rkyen can las 'phen pa'i rgyu 'dod pa dang lta ba dang tshul khrims dang brtul zhugs dang / bdag tu smra ba nye bar len pa rnam pa bzhi po sred ldan des nye bar len par 'gyur ro/ /

Thereafter, conditioned by feeling, craving arises, because to crave is to crave to be the subject of feelings. Why does one crave? The craver craves in order to experience feeling, because he is desirous of that. He craves the pleasant in order not to be away from it, he craves being away from suffering, and he craves the nondiminution of the neutral. When there is craving [459], conditioned by craving, these four objects of appropriation, which are the causes of the propelling karma, will be appropriated: desire, views, arrogance in one’s own propriety and in one’s own conduct, and self-grasping.
nyer len yod na len pa po'i/ / srid pa kun tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ / gal te nye bar len med na/ / grol bar 'gyur te srid mi 'gyur/ /
7. When there is appropriation, The existence of the appropriator arises. If he did not appropriate, Then being freed, he would not come into existence.

nye bar len pa bzhi po de yod na de bzhi nye bar len pa po ste skyed pa po de'i len pa'i rkyen gyis srid pa rab tu 'byung ba ste skye bar 'gyur la/ gal te nye bar len pa po gang gis de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i so sor rtogs pa'i shes rab kyi stobs kyis tshor ba la sred pa bdag gir ma byas par/ gnyis su med pa'i ye shes mngon du byas pa las nye bar len pa med par gyur na ni/ de grol bar 'gyur te de'i tshe yang srid yod par mi 'gyur ro/ /

When there are the four objects of appropriation, the existence of the appropriator of these four—that is, he who takes birth—arises, conditioned by the appropriation. If the appropriator, through the power of the discriminative insight which realizes the way things really are, did not entertain the craving of feelings, and if through the realization of nondualistic wisdom he ceased appropriating, then he would be liberated. This is because thereafter there would be no rebirth.
srid pa de yang phung po lnga / / srid pa las ni skye ba 'byung / / rga shi dang ni mya ngan dang / / smre sngags 'don bcas sdug bsngal dang / /
8. This existence is also the five aggregates. From existence comes birth, Old age, and death and misery and Suffering and lamentation and….

len pa'i rkyen gyis 'byung ba'i srid pa de yang phung po lnga'i rang bzhin du rig par bya ste/ lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las dge mi dge gsum char yang ma 'ongs pa'i phung po lnga'i srid pa 'byung bas rgyu la 'bras bu'i ming gis btags nas srid pa zhes bya'o/ / de la lus dang ngag gi las ni gzugs kyi phung po yin la yid kyi las ni phung po bzhi'i rang bzhin no/ // de la gzhung gzhan las bye brag tu smra bas lus ngag gi las gzugs can du 'dod pa bkag nas/ lus ngag bya ba la 'jug dus kyi sems pa la bshad mod kyang zla bas gzugs can du bzhed do/ / yid kyi las ni sems pa yin mod kyang sems pa dang mtshungs ldan gyi sems sems byung gzhan rnams de dang ngo bo gcig pas yid las phung po bzhi'i rang bzhin du bshad do/ / sred len gyis gsos btab pas yang srid 'grub pa'i las nus pa mthu can du song ba'i srid pa de las ni tshe phyi ma'i phung po'i skye ba len pa 'byung la/

One should know that the existence that is conditioned by appropriation has the nature of being the five aggregates. The virtuous and nonvirtuous actions of body, speech, and mind give rise to the existence of the five aggregates in the future. Therefore, the cause is named after its effect, and so is called “existence.” Of these, the actions of body and speech belong to the material form aggregate. Mental actions by nature belong to the other four aggregates. Other treatises/3/ reject the Vaibhāsikas’ claim that the actions of body and mind should both be regarded as belonging to the form aggregate, explaining that action is mental occurring when one engages in physical or verbal activity. But Candrakīrti maintains that the actions of body belong to the material form aggregate. Although mental actions are intentional, other mental processes and mental episodes that are concomitant with that intention are said to be of the same entity. Therefore, mental action is said to belong to the four nonphysical aggregates. Having been activated by craving and appropriation, the birth of the aggregates of the later life arises from the existence in which potent karma gives rise to rebirth.
yid mi bde dang 'khrug pa rnams/ / de dag skye las rab tu 'byung / / de ltar sdug bsngal phung po ni/ / 'ba' zhig po 'di 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
9. Unhappiness and agitation. All these arise as a consequence of birth. Thus what comes into being Is only a mass of suffering.

phung po smin pa'i rga ba dang phung po 'jig pa'i shi ba dang / 'chi bzhin pa'i kun tu rmongs pa'i chags pa dang bcas pa'i snying gi gdung ba mya ngan dang*/ mya ngan des kun nas bslang ba'i ngag gis smre sngags 'don pa dang dbang po lnga la gnod pa'i sdug bsngal dang / yid kyi shes pa la gnod pa'i yid mi bde ba dang sdug bsngal dang yid mi bde las byung ba'i lus dang sems kyi 'khrug pa rnams te de dag ni skye ba las rab tu 'byung ngo*/ / sngar ji skad bshad pa'i tshul gyis de ltar te rang gi rgyu dang rkyen tsam gyi mthus sdug bsngal gyi phung po dang tshogs dang khyu ste sdug bsngal spangs pa'o/ / bdag dang bdag gi ba'i rang bzhin dang bral ba dang byis pas btags pa tsam sdug bsngal gyi bdag nyid bde ba dang ma 'dres pas/ 'ba' zhig pa 'di 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes 'khor bar lugs su 'jug pa gsungs so/ / de la gang 'grub na skye ba dang rga shi'o/ / gang gis 'grub par byed na sred pa'i rkyen can gyi len pas so/ / ji ltar 'grub par byed na 'du byed kyis rnam shes la bsgos pa'i las kyi bag chags de nus pa mthu can du byas pa las kyi srid par byas pa'i tshul gyis so/ / 'dis ni ma rig pa dang 'du byed kyis 'phangs pa de nyid 'grub par byed pas/ 'phen byed dang 'grub byed kyi rgyu 'bras ni skye ba len thebs gcig gi rgyu 'bras yin gyi skye ba so so ba'i dbang du byas pa min no/ / 'on kyang so sor bstan pa ni 'phangs pa'i sdug bsngal dang grub pa'i sdug bsngal gyi khyad par dang / 'phen byed dang 'grub byed kyi rgyu'i mi 'dra ba'i khyad par bstan pa'i phyir yin te/ sa yi dngos gzhi las/ rnam par shes pa la sogs pa nas tshor ba la thug pa dag dang skye ba dang rga shi rnams 'dres pa'i mtshan nyid yin na ci'i phyir rnam pa gnyis su bstan ce na/ sdug ba sngal ba 'i da ngo sa po 'i mtshan nyid tha dad par bstan pa'i phyir dang / 'phen pa dang mngon par 'grub pa'i rab tu dbye ba yongs su bstan pa'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar ro/ /

From birth arises the aging—the ripening—of the aggregates, death—the cessation of the aggregates, misery—heartache that comes with the deluded attachment to the one who is dying and [460] the lamentation caused by that misery, the suffering of assault to the five senses, unhappiness—assault to the mind, and agitation—the mental and physical agitation that arises from unhappiness and suffering. Just as we explained earlier, just through the power of its own causes and conditions, the whole mass—that is, the whole array or heap—of suffering arises. Since it is essentially free from self and being mine, is merely imputed by fools, is suffering by its very nature, and is not even mixed with pleasure, it is said that “only a mass of suffering arises.” Thus, this explains the order in which one engages with cyclic existence. What would arise? Birth, aging, and death! What would give rise to them? The appropriation that is conditioned by craving! How does that give rise to them? When the latent potentials that the dispositions have caused to pervade consciousness are raised to potency, they give rise to existence. This shows that what comes into being is propelled by ignorance and the dispositions. Therefore, “the cause that propels and comes to fruition” refers both to the cause and effect of a single life, but does not refer to an individual life. However, the reasons that these two causes are presented separately is to distinguish between propelled suffering and the suffering to which it in turn gives rise, and to distinguish between the cause that propels and the cause that comes to fruition in the next life. The Bhūmivastu says: Since everything from consciousness to feeling, and birth, aging, and death, have interrelated characteristics, why are they presented in two different ways? That is done in order to show the distinct characteristics of suffering phenomena and in order to distinguish between that which propels and that which comes to fruition. [Yogācārabhūmi, Sems tsam tshi 112b]
gnyis pa [lugs bzlog gi rten 'brel] ni/
1.2 The reverse order of dependent origination
'khor ba'i rtsa ba 'du byed de/ / de phyir mkhas rnams 'du mi byed/ / de phyir mi mkhas byed po yin/ / mkhas pas de nyid mthong phyir ro/ /
10. The root of cyclic existence is action. Therefore, the wise one does not act. Therefore the unwise is the agent. The wise one is not, because he sees reality.

ma rig pa la sogs pa las srid pa'i yan lag rnams 'byung bas 'khor ba rnam shes nying mtshams sbyor ba la sogs pa'i rtsa ba ste rgyu'i gtso bo ni 'du byed yin te/ de'i phyir mkhas pa rten 'byung gi de kho na nyid mngon sum du mthong ba rnams 'phen byed kyi las 'du mi byed pa de yi phyir/ mi mkhas pa de kho na nyid mngon sum du ma mthong ba ni 'du byed kyi byed pa po yin te/ mdo sde las/ dge slong dag ma rig pa dang rjes su 'brel ba'i skyes bu gang zag 'di ni bsod nams mngon par 'du bya ba yang mngon par 'du byed do/ / bsod nams ma yin pa bya mngon par 'du bya ba yang mngon par 'du byed do/ / mi g.yo ba mngon par 'du bya ba yang mngon par 'du byed do/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ // de ltar mi mkhas pa byed pa po yin pas ma rig pa dang ldan pa kho na 'du byed kyi byed pa por 'gyur gyi/ mkhas pa de nyid mthong ba ma rig pa spangs pa ni byed pa po min te de kho na nyid mngon sum du mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

[461] The limbs of cyclic existence arise from such things as ignorance. Therefore, the primary root of cyclic existence—of such things as the entry of consciousness into the embryo—is action. Therefore, those who directly perceive the reality of dependent origination do not perform any action that would propel suffering. So the unwise, who do not directly perceive reality, are the agents of action. As it says in sūtra, O monks! This person, who is completely bound up with ignorance, performs meritorious actions. He also performs nonmeritorious actions. He performs unshakable actions as well. [Śālistambha-sūatra, mDo sde tsha 120a] Thus the unwise are the agents, so only those who are bound up with ignorance are the agents of action, and the wise ones, who have seen reality and who have abandoned ignorance, are not agents because they see reality.
ma rig 'gags par gyur na ni/ / 'du byed rnams kun 'byung mi 'gyur/ / ma rig 'gags par 'gyur ba ni/ / shes pas de nyid bsgoms pas so/ /
11. With the cessation of ignorance, Action will not arise. The cessation of ignorance occurs through Exercising wisdom in meditating on this.

de ltar ma rig pa yod na 'du byed 'byung ba med na mi 'byung ba'i phyir ma rig 'gags pa ste spangs par gyur na ni 'du byed rnams kyang 'byung bar mi 'gyur te rgyu ma tshang ba'i phyir ro/ / ma rig pa de gang gis 'gog par 'gyur zhe na/ ma rigs 'gags pa ste zad par 'gyur ba ni rten 'byung gi de nyid phyin ci ma log par shes pas/ de kho na nyid kyi don bsgoms pa la brten nas de kho na nyid mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur la de nyid mthong ba'i rnal 'byor pas ni ma rig pa nges par spong ngo*/ /

Therefore, where there is ignorance, action arises and where is not, it does not. When ignorance ceases—that is, when it is abandoned—actions will not arise, because of the nonconsummation of their causes. What would cause that ignorance to cease? The cessation of ignorance—its exhaustion—is achieved through the wisdom by means of which one nonerroneously realizes the reality of dependent origination. Reality can be perceived directly by employing that wisdom in meditation on reality. The practitioner who perceives reality most certainly eliminates ignorance.
de dang de ni 'gags gyur pas/ / de dang de ni mngon mi 'byung*/ / sdug bsngal phung po 'ba' zhig po/ / de ni de ltar yang dag dgag /
12. Through the cessation of this and that, This and that will not be manifest. That which is only a mass of suffering Will thus completely cease.

ma rig pa spangs pas ni 'du byed 'gag par 'gyur la de bzhin du 'du byed sogs pa'i yan lag snga ma de dang de dag 'gags par gyur pas yan lag phyi ma de dang de ni mngon par mi 'byung ngo / / rim pa 'di dag ni rnal 'byor pa'i sdug bsngal gyi phung po bdag dang bdag gi ba rang gi mtshan nyid kyis grub pas stong zhing / bde ba dang ma 'dres pas 'ba' zhig pa de ni slar yang mi 'byung bas de ltar yang dag par 'gag pa ste zad par 'gyur ro/ / rab byed gzhan thams cad du chos rnams rang bzhin gyis grub pa rigs pas bkag nas rab byed 'dir ma bkag pa ni/ gang zag dang chos kyi rten 'brel la rang bzhin gyis grub pa'i rang bzhin bkag pa der yan lag 'di dag thams cad kyang rang bzhin med par bshad zin cing / 'dir ni de ltar gtan la phab pa'i de kho na nyid bsgoms na ma rig pa ldog la/ de'i dbang gis srid pa'i yan lag lhag ma thams cad log nas thar pa 'thob pa dang /de 'dra ba'i lta ba ma rnyed na ma rig pa mi ldog pas de'i dbang gis yan lag phyi ma rnams 'jug pas 'khor ba'i 'khor lo bskor bar 'chad pa yin no/ /

Having abandoning ignorance, action will have ceased. Similarly, through the cessation of the earlier limbs—the “this and that”—the later limbs—“this and that”—will not arise. These arguments show that the practitioner’s suffering aggregates [462] are empty of existence through their own characteristic as self or as being mine. That which is only a mass of suffering and not at all mixed with pleasure will not arise again, and thus will completely cease—that is, be completely exhausted. The reason that the essential existence of phenomena that has been refuted in all of the other chapters is not refuted in this chapter is that when the essential existence of the dependently originated person and phenomena are refuted, all of these limbs are also shown not to be essentially existent. Here it is shown that ignorance can be eliminated by meditation on reality as it has been presented. Thereby, through eliminating all of the remaining limbs of cyclic existence, liberation is achieved. Without adopting that view, since ignorance cannot be eliminated, the remaining limbs will thus arise, and the wheel of cyclic existence will continue to turn.
gnyis pa [don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa] ni/
2. Summary of the Chapter and Its Name

gang zag dang chos kyi rten 'brel la dmigs nas bdag tu 'dzin pa'i ma rig pa gnyis kyis bdag gnyis ji ltar bzung ba'i lhan skyes kyi ma rig pa'i 'dzin stangs nges par byas nas/ rigs pa ji snyed cig gsungs pa thams cad de gnyis kyis ji ltar bzung ba'i bdag gnyis bkag nas/ de'i gnyen po bdag med gnyis rtogs pa'i lta ba skyed pa'i yan lag tu shes par byas la/ bdag med rtogs pa'i lta ba rnam par dag pa phu thag chod par byas nas thos pa dang bsam pa dang bsgom pa gsum kyis rten 'brel lugs bzlog gi phyogs su ci 'gyur la 'bad par bya'o/ /

One should ascertain the mode of grasping of the two selves through innate ignorance—that is, the way that they are grasped through two kinds of ignorance, which grasp them as selves when perceiving the dependent origination of the person and phenomena. Thereafter, one should understand that all of these arguments are presented in order to refute the two selves as grasped by the two kinds of ignorance, and in order to develop the view through which one can realize the two kinds of selflessness as their respective antidotes. Having developed a complete understanding of the perfect view through which one can realize the two selflessnesses, through hearing, contemplation, and meditation, one should strive by all means to practice in accordance with the reverse order of dependent origination.
srid pa'i yan lag bcu gnyis pa brtag pa zhes bya ba ste rab tu byed pa nyi shu drug pa'o/ /
This is the twenty-sixth chapter called “the examination of the twelve limbs of cyclic existence.”
srid pa'i yan lag bcu gnyis brtag pa zhes bya ba tshigs su bcad pa bcu gnyis kyi bdag nyid rab tu byed pa nyi shu rtsa drug pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This is the commentary on the twenty-sixth chapter, having twelve verses, called “the examination of the twelve limbs of cyclic existence.”
CHAPTER XXVII. Examination of Views
gsum pa rten 'byung rtogs na lta ba ngan pa ldog tshul

This chapter constitutes the third and final part of the section explaining the meanings of the individual chapters: the demonstration of how, once one understands dependent origination, the erroneous views are abandoned.
['di] la gsum/ rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa/ nges don gyi lung dang sbyar ba/ don bsdus te mtshan bstan pa'o/ //
This chapter has three parts: the explanation of the chapter, the confirmation by citations from definitive sūtras, and the summary of the chapter and its name.
dang po [rab byed kyi gzhung bshad pa] ni/
1. Explanation of the Chapter

sa lu ljang ba'i mdo las/ gang gis de lta bu'i rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba ji lta bur yang dag par mthong ba de ni/ sngon gyi mtha' la rten par mi byed phyi ma'i mtha' la rten par mi byed do zhes gsungs pa yin na sngon dang phyi ma'i mtha' ni gang zhig yin la de la rten par mi byed pa'i tshul yang ji ltar yin zhe na/ 'di bshad pa la gnyis/ lta ba ngan pa bcu drug ngos bzung ba dang / rten 'brel rtogs pas de la mi gnas pa'i tshul lo/ /

Suppose one asked, “Since the Śālistambha-sūtra says that whoever has seen dependent origination perfectly does not rely on the extreme view that there is a beginning or the extreme view that there is an end [m Do sde tsha 123a], what are the extreme views that there is a beginning and that there is an end, and how is it that one should not rely on these?” This answer to this has two parts: identifying the sixteen false views and how to show that one who understands dependent origination does not rely on them.
dang po [lta ba ngan pa bcu drug ngos bzung ba] ni/
1.1 Identifying the sixteen false views
'das dus byung ma byung zhes dang / / 'jig rten rtag pa la sogs par/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa yin/ /
1. The views “in the past I was” or “I was not” And the view that the world is permanent, etc.,: All of these views Depend on a prior limit.

ci bdag 'das pa'i dus na byung ba dang ma byung ba dang / / gnyis ka dang gnyis ka ma yin pa'o zhes lta ba bzhi dang / 'jig rten rtag pa dang la sogs kyis bsdus pa 'jig rten mi rtag pa dang gnyis ka dang gnyis ka min par lta ba bzhi ste brgyad po gang yin pa de dag ni/ / da ltar gyi lus la ltos nas 'das pa'i lus la sngon gyi zhes bya ste mtha' ni skye ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i cha snga ma dang de la brten pa ni dmigs pa'i don yin no/ / byung ma byung gnyis kar dang rtag mi rtag gnyis kar lta ba ni gcer bu pas tshe snga phyi'i srog ni gcig dang phung po ni so sor 'dod pa lta bu yin la/ gnyis ka min pa ni snga ma de nyid rnam grangs las gnyis ka min pa'i phyogs su bshad pa bzhin dang / mang pos bkur bas gang zag rtag mi rtag gang du yang brjod du med par 'dod pa lta bu dang brtag pa'i mtha' bzung nas bkag pa yang yod de/ de dag gis phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa rnams kyi mu gnyis kyang shes par bya'o/ / de la byung ma byung gnyis smos pa ni lta ba gzhan gnyis kyi mtshon byed yin la byung sogs bzhi ni bdag kho na la dmigs nas zhugs shing 'jig rten rtag pa la sogs par lta ba bzhi ni spyir sngon gyi mtha' la dmigs nas 'jug pas khyad par yod do/ /

These eight views include the following four: I existed in the past, I did not exist in the past, I both existed and did not exist in the past, and I neither existed nor did not exist in the past, as well as the following four: the world is permanent, and the others referred to by “etc.,” viz., the world is impermanent, the world is both permanent and impermanent, and the world is neither permanent nor impermanent. These views are called “prior” because they refer to the bodies of lives prior to the existence of the present body. “Limit” means the earlier part of the continuum proceeding from one birth to another arises. To depend on this means to objectify it. The views according to which I existed and did not exist and according to which the world is permanent and impermanent are like the view of the Jains, who maintain that the being of the previous and later lives is identical and that only the aggregates of those lives are distinct. To assert the view that neither is the case is just to assert the previous view in a different way, by saying that they are neither, and is like the assertion of the Sammitīya that the person cannot be said either to be permanent or impermanent. To maintain the imagined extremes has also been refuted. Through these one should understand the two alternatives that rely on the posterior limit as well. The phrases “I was” and “I was not” refer to the two other alternatives. All of these four arise just from objectifying the self. The four views, including the view that the world is permanent [464] arise from focusing on the prior limit in general, and so there are differences in the way these views arise.
ma 'ongs dus gzhan 'byung 'gyur dang / / mi 'byung 'jig rten mtha' sogs par/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa yin/ /
2. The view “in the future I will exist at another time” or “I will not do so” And that the world is limited, etc.: All of these views Depend on a posterior limit.

bdag ma 'ongs pa'i dus gzhan na 'byung bar 'gyur ba dang mi 'byung ba dang de gnyis ni mtshon pa tsam yin pas/ ma 'ongs pa'i dus na bdag 'byung mi 'byung gnyis ka dang gnyis ka ma yin par lta ba bzhi dang / 'jig rten mtha' dang ldan pa dang sogs kyis bsdus pa 'jig rten mtha' dang mi ldan pa dang gnyis ka dang gnyis ka min par lta ba bzhi gang yin pa de dag ni/ da ltar gyi bdag la ltos nas 'byung 'gyur gyi lus la phyi ma zhes bya ste skye ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i cha phyi ma ni de'i mtha' yin la de la dmigs pas na de la brten pa yin no/ lta ba bzhi tshan de gnyis kyi khyad par yang snga ma bzhin no/ /

The two views that in the future I will exist at another time and that I will not do so are mere examples. The view that in the future both will occur and the view that in the future neither will occur complete the four. The view that the world is limited, and those included under “etc.,” viz., that it is not limited, that it is both limited and not limited, and that it is neither are another four. In relation to the present self, the future body is called “posterior” because the later part of the continuum of proceeding from one birth to another is a limit. To depend on this means to objectify it. The differences between these two groups of four views are just as they are in the previous case.
gnyis pa [rten 'brel rtogs pas de la mi gnas pa'i tshul]
1.2 How to show that one who understands dependent origination does not rely on them
['di] la gnyis/ tha snyad du gzugs brnyan lta bu'i rten 'brel gyi dbang du byas nas lta ba de dag la gnas pa dgag / don dam par spros pa thams cad zhi bas lta ba de dag la gnas pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: refutation of these views on the ground that conventional dependently arisen phenomena are like reflections and the refutation of these views on the ground of the pacification of all fabrication in the ultimate.
dang po [tha snyad du gzugs brnyan lta bu'i rten 'brel gyi dbang du byas nas lta ba de dag la gnas pa dgag]
1.2.1 Refutation of these views on the ground that conventional dependently arisen phenomena are like reflections

['di] la bzhi/ sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan dang po dgag / des phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan dang po khegs par bstan/ sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan gnyis pa dgag / phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan gnyis pa dgag pa'o/ /

This section has four parts: the refutation of the first set of four views depending on the prior limit, showing that thereby the first set of four views depending on the posterior is refuted, the refutation of the second set of four views depending on the prior limit, and the refutation of the second set of four views depending on the posterior limit.
dang po [sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan dang po dgag]
1.2.1.1 Refutation of the first set of four views depending on the prior limit
['di] la gnyis/ 'das dus su byung ma byung du lta ba gnyis dgag / mjug bsdus te lta ba gzhan gnyis kyang mi 'thad par bstan pa'o/ /

This section has two parts: the refutation of the two views regarding its arising or not arising in the past and drawing the conclusion that the two views regarding the other two temporal periods are also not tenable.
dang po ['das dus su byung ma byung du lta ba gnyis dgag]
1.2.1.1.1 Refutation of the two views regarding its arising or not arising in the past
['di] la gnyis/ 'das dus su byung bar lta ba dgag / 'das dus su ma byung bar lta ba dgag pa'o/ /
This section has two parts: the refutation of the view that it arises in the past and the refutation of the view that it does not arise in the past.
dang po ['das dus su byung bar lta ba dgag]
1.2.1.1.1.1 Refutation of the view that it arises in the past
['di] la gnyis/ dgag pa dngos dang / bkag pa'i mjug bsdu ba'o/ /
This section has two parts: the principal refutation and the conclusion of the refutation.
dang po [dgag pa dngos] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1.1 Principal refutation
'das pa'i dus na byung gyur ces/ / bya ba de ni mi 'thad do/ / sngon tshe rnams su gang byung ba/ / de nyid 'di ni ma yin no/ /
3. To say “I was in the past” Is not tenable. What existed in the past Is not identical to this one.

bdag sngar 'das pa'i tshe rabs su byung bar gyur to zhes bya bar lta ba de ni 'dzin stangs don dang mthun par 'thad pa ma yin no/ / dmigs pa bdag la dmigs nas rnam pa sngon gyi dus na 'di 'dra zhig tu gyur zhes gang du gyur pa de'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis gyur pa'am byung bar 'dzin pa'o/ / des ji ltar bzung ba'i don de yod na/ da lta bdag sngar 'di 'drar gyur to zhes dran pa dang smra ba'i dus kyi bdag 'di dang tshe rabs snga ma'i dus kyi bdag de gnyis gcig yin dgos pa las/ sngon gyi tshe rabs rnams kyi dus su gang byung ba'i bdag de nyid tshe 'di'i bdag 'di ni ma yin pa'i phyir de ltar lta ba de ni 'thad pa min no/ / bdag sngon gyi dus na 'dir gyur to zhes dmigs pa'i bdag de rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis grub na tshe snga phyi'i dus kyi bdag gnyis gcig tu 'gyur ba'i rgyu mtshan ni/ bdag gnyis rang bzhin gyis grub na ngo bo nyid kyis gcig dang tha dad gang rung du grub pa las mi 'da' la/ ngo bo nyid kyis tha dad pa'ang 'chad par 'gyur ba ltar 'gog pas gcig tu 'gyur ro/ / tshe snga phyi'i dus kyi bdag gnyis gcig yin na rtag par 'gyur la de lta na rim gyis 'khor ba na/ 'gro ba gcig kyang dus gcig tu mi dang dmyal ba la sogs pa 'gro ba du mar 'gyur ro/ / 'o na mdo las/ nga nyid de'i tshe de'i dus na 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal po mang pos bkur ba zhes bya bar gyur to/ / zhes ston pa shAka thub kyis de ltar gsung ba mi rigs te/ mang pos bkur ba'i bdag dang shAka thub kyi bdag gnyis gcig ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ lung 'dis ni de gnyis rgyud gzhan yin pa bkag nas rgyud gcig tu ston gyi de gnyis kyi bdag gnyis gcig tu ston pa min no/ / de ltar yin par yang mdo sde rnams las sngon gyi byung ba brjod nas de nas ming 'di zhes bya ba de gzhan zhig yin nam snyam na de ni de ltar mi blta ste/ nga nyid de'i tshe de'i dus na der gyur to zhes rgyud gzhan 'gog pa gtso bor mdzad nas gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / nga zhes gsungs pa'i bdag tha snyad kyi gzhir gyur pa'i gang zag kyang dus snga phyi so sor ma phye ba'i spyi tsam pa la byed pa'i rnam gzhag ni sngar bshad zin to/ / gal te tshe snga phyi'i bdag de gnyis gcig tu gyur na skyon ci yod ce na

The view that I existed in past lives is not tenable, as this way of seeing things is not consistent with the facts. [465] Having focused on the self as an object, qua that as which one existed in the past, one grasps oneself in the form in which one existed either as essentially existent or as essentially arisen. If that object existed as it is grasped, the two selves—the present self, when it remembers and says “I existed in that way previously,” and the self that existed in the past—would be identical. But since that very self that existed in previous lives is not the self of this very life, this view is not tenable. If the self on which one focuses when says, “I existed in the past as that one” existed inherently, the selves of the previous and subsequent lives would have to be identical. The reason is that if these two selves existed essentially, they could not escape from being either inherently identical or inherently different. Their being inherently different will be refuted later. So they would have to be identical. If the two selves of the prior and subsequent lives were identical, the self would be permanent. In that case, when a being wanders in cyclic existence, a single transmigrator would be simultaneously in many realms, such as the human and hell realms. So, suppose one argued as follows: It says in sūtra, “At that time, in that life, I became the Cakravarti emperor Samati” [Prasannapadā 191a]./1/ And it would not make sense for the Buddha himself to make such a statement; because the two selves—the self who earlier was Samati and the self who was then the Buddha—are not identical. This sūtra refutes those two selves belonging to different continua, but shows them to belong to the same continuum. But it does not show that those two selves are identical. This is because the sūtra, having presented the story, says that one might think that the person with that name was another one, but that is not the right the way to see this, because saying, “I myself at that time became that person,” primarily [466] denies their belonging to different continua. It has been explained earlier that by saying ‘I,’ which refers to the self, which is the person, the basis of the convention, one uses a general term that does not distinguish between particular successive temporal stages. What is wrong with saying the two selves of the successive lives are identical?
de nyid bdag tu 'gyur snyam na/ / nye par len pa tha dad 'gyur/ / nye bar len pa ma gtogs par/ / khyod kyi bdag ni gang zhig yin/ /
4. If, according to you, that is the self, Then the appropriator would be different. Apart from the appropriator, What is your self?

de la rtag par thal ba'i nyes pa brjod zin to/ / skyon gzhan yang brjod par bya ste/ gal te tshe snga ma'i dus kyi bdag de nyid tshe 'di'i dus kyi bdag tu 'gyur ro snyam na/ de'i tshe nye bar len pa po'i bdag gcig yin pas gnas skabs de gnyis kyi nye bar len pa phung po gnyis kyang gcig yin par 'gyur na/ nye bar len pa phung po gnyis ni so so ba kho na ste de'i rgyu dang dus tha dad pa'i phyir ro/ / ci ste nye bar len pa so so ba yin pa dang gnas skabs de gnyis kyi bdag gnyis gcig yin pa mi 'gal bas bdag 'das pa'i dus na rang bzhin gyis byung bar lta ba 'thad do snyam na/ nye bar len pa dang bdag gnyis rang mtshan gyis so so bar grub na de gnyis mi 'gal yang / nye bar len pa ma gtogs par te de las rang bzhin gyis tha dad pa'i khyod kyi bdag ni gang zhig yod pa yin te med pas lan de mi rigs so/ /

We have already said that the absurd consequence would follow that it would be permanent. Here is another error: Suppose one thought that the very self of the previous life is the very self of this life. In that case, since there would be a single appropriator, the two appropriated sets of aggregates would be identical. But the two sets of aggregates are distinct. Their times and causes are distinct. Now, suppose one thought that since it is not contradictory for two sets of aggregates to be distinct and the selves of the two distinct lives to be identical, the view that the self existed essentially in the past is tenable. If that which is to be appropriated and the self existed distinctly through their own characteristics, this would not be contradictory. But, apart from that which is to be appropriated, how could your self exist as essentially distinct from them? It could not! So this response does not make sense.
nye bar len la ma gtogs pa'i/ / bdag yod ma yin byas pa'i tshe/ / nye bar len nyid bdag yin na/ / khyod kyi bdag ni med pa yin/ /
5. Having shown that there is no self Apart from the appropriated, If the appropriated is the self, Your self does not exist.
gal te nye bar len pa phung po ma gtogs pa'i bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod pa ma yin no zhes byas pa'i tshe/ nye bar len pa phung po nyid bdag tu rang bzhin gyis yod do snyam na/

We say that the self does not exist inherently apart from the aggregates. Now, suppose one thought that those appropriated aggregates exist essentially as the self. If that were the case, the self that you maintain to exist inherently could not exist. Because it is merely a synonym of “the aggregates,” this term would not refer to the self.
nye bar len nyid bdag ma yin/ / de 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yin/ / nye bar blang pa ci lta bar/ / nye bar len po yin par 'gyur/ /
6. The appropriated is not the self. It arises and ceases. How can the appropriated Be the appropriator?

de lta na khyod kyis bdag ngo bo nyid kyis yod do zhes bdag khas blangs pa de med pa yin te/ phung po'i rnam grangs tsam du zad pas bdag gi don med pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te nye bar len pa'i phung po nyid bdag dang rang bzhin gyis gcig pa nyid ma yin te/ yin na ni nye bar len pa'i phung po de skad cig re re la 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yin pa bzhin du bdag kyang de ltar 'gyur na de ni mi rigs so/ / mi rigs pa'i rgyu mtshan ni bdag mi rtag par smra na chad par 'gyur te/ rang bzhin gyis grub na snga ma las phyi ma skye ba'i rgyun ma chad pa mi rigs te/ rang mtshan gyis snga phyi so so ba la ltos pa mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / mi 'jig na ni bdag rtag par smra ba nyid du 'gyur ro/ / gzhan yang nye bar blang bar bya ba de ji lta bur na nye bar len po'i bdag yin par 'gyur zhes pa mi 'gyur te/ las dang byed pa po gcig tu 'gyur bas bum pa dang rdza mkhan sogs kyang gcig tu 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Nor does it make sense to say that the appropriated aggregates themselves are essentially identical to the self. For if they were, just as the appropriated aggregates arise and cease at each moment, the self would have to do so. [467] The reason that this makes no sense is that, if one asserted that the self is impermanent, this would be nihilism. This is because if it existed essentially, the uninterrupted continuum of rebirth from earlier to later lives would not make sense, because it would not be possible for successive lives that are distinct from one another through their own characteristics to be dependent. If it did not cease, you would have to assert the self to be permanent. Moreover, how could that which is to be appropriated be the self—that is, the appropriator? It could not be, because since the agent and the object would be identical, it would follow that such things as the potter and pot could be identical.
bdag ni nye bar len pa las/ / gzhan du 'thad pa nyid ma yin/ / gal te gzhan na len med par/ / gzung yod rigs na gzung du med/ /
7. It is not tenable that the self is different From the appropriated. If it were different, then without the appropriated It should be observed. But it is not.

gal te nye bar len pa'i phung po tsam zhig bdag min pa bden mod kyang bdag ni nye bar len pa las rang bzhin tha dad do snyam na/ len pa po'i bdag ni blang bya nye bar len pa las rang bzhin gyis gzhan du yod pa 'thad pa nyid ma yin te/ gal te de gnyis rang gi ngo bos gzhan du grub na nye bar len pa phung po med par bdag de gzung du yod par rigs na de ltar gzung du med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di yang rang mtshan gyis gzhan du grub na ltos pa mi rung bas 'brel ba 'gog nus la/ 'brel med don gzhan ni ya bral du dmigs dgos pa las de ltar ma dmigs pa'i phyir rang bzhin gyis gzhan du grub pa med par ston pa'i rigs pa'o/ /

Suppose one thought that it is true that the mere appropriated aggregates are not the self, but the self is essentially distinct from the appropriated aggregates. It is not tenable that the appropriating self is essentially distinct from that which is to be appropriated, because, if these two existed as inherently distinct, then it would make sense that the self would be observed without the appropriated aggregates, but this is not observed. This argument also shows that they could not be essentially different because, if they existed as different through their own characteristics, it would not be possible for them to be dependent, and their being related would be thereby refuted; if they were unrelated and disconnected, they would have to be observed to be so. But they are not so observed.
gnyis pa [bkag pa'i mjug bsdu ba] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.1.2 Conclusion of the refutation
de ltar len las gzhan ma yin/ / de ni nyer len nyid kyang min/ / bdag ni nye bar len med min/ / med pa nyid du'ang de ma nges/ /
8. So it is neither different from the appropriated Nor identical to the appropriated. There is no self without appropriation. But it is not ascertained that it does not exist.

sngar bshad pa de ltar phung po la ma ltos par gzung du yod par 'gyur bas bdag ni nye bar len pa las rang bzhin gyis gzhan pa'ang ma yin la/ las dang byed pa po gcig tu 'gyur ba dang mi rtag par smra na chad par 'gyur bas bdag de ni nye bar len pa phung po nyid kyang min no/ / bdag tu gdaT pa rgyu med par thal ba'i phyir bdag ni nye bar len pa la ltos pa med par yod pa'ang min no/ / de lta na bdag med do snyam na/ bdag de ni med pa nyid du'ang ma nges te phung po la brten nas 'dogs pa'i phyir te med pa mo gsham gyi bu la sogs pa ni phung po la brten nas 'dogs pa min no/

As it has been said earlier, since in that case the self would have to be observed without depending on the appropriated aggregates, the self does not exist essentially as distinct from that which is to be appropriated. Since to maintain that the agent and object are identical and are impermanent would be nihilism, the self is not the appropriated aggregates. The absurd consequence would follow that there would be no ground on which to posit the self. Thus, the self does not exist without depending on the aggregates. Now suppose someone argued that, if that is the case, the self does not exist. But it is not ascertained that there is no self at all, [468] because it is posited depending on the basis of the aggregates. Such things as the son of a barren woman are not posited depending on the basis of the aggregates!
gnyis pa ['das dus su ma byung bar lta ba dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.1.2 Refutation of the view that it does not arise in the past
'das pa'i dus na ma byung zhes/ / bya ba de yang mi 'thad do/ / sngon tshe rnams sa gang byung ba/ / de las 'di gzhan ma yin no/ /
9. To say “in the past I did not exist” Would not be tenable. This person is not different From whoever existed in previous lives.

'das pa'i tshe rabs kyi dus su sngon ma byung ba'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis gnas so zhes bya bar lta ba de yang mi 'thad de/ da ltar gyi tshe 'di'i bdag 'di tshe sngon ma'i bdag las rang bzhin gyis gzhan du grub na/ de'i tshe bdag 'das pa'i dus na ma byung bar rang bzhin gyis grub par 'dzin pa 'thad na'ang de ni mi srid do/ / gal te tshe snga phyi'i bdag gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du grub na nyes pa ci yod ce na/

Nor is the view, “in past lives I existed essentially in a form in which I existed earlier” tenable. This is because if the self of this life existed essentially as distinct from the self of the past lives, it would have to be tenable that the self that did not exist in the past could be grasped as essentially existent. But this is not possible. Suppose one asked, “What would be wrong with saying that the selves of the two successive lives existed inherently as different?”
gal te 'di ni gzhan 'gyur na/ / de med par yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin de ni gnas 'gyur zhing / / der ma shi bar skye bar 'gyur/ /
10. If this one were different, Then I would exist even without it having existed. If this were so, Without that one dying, this one would be born.

gal te tshe 'di'i bdag 'di ni tshe snga ma'i bdag las ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du gyur na sngar gyi bdag de la ltos pa med par yang 'byung bar 'gyur ba dang / bdag snga ma de ni rang gi dus de bzhin du phyi ma skyes pa na'ang ma 'gags par gnas par 'gyur zhing tshe snga ma der ma shi bar yang tshe 'dir skye bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te sngar gyi bdag de la ltos pa med par 'dir bdag 'byung na nyes pa cir 'gyur zhe na/

If the self of this life were inherently different from the self of the previous life, then it would arise without depending on the self of the previous life, and the self of the previous life would continue to exist without cessation even though the later one is born. And thus the present being would be born without the past being having died. Suppose someone asked, “What would be wrong with saying that the self of the present life was born without depending on the self of the past life?”
chad dang las rnams chud za dang / / gzhan gyis byas pa'i las rnams ni/ / gzhan gyis so sor myong ba dang / / de la sogs par thal bar 'gyur/ /
11. The cutting of the continuum and the nullification of karma would follow; The karma accumulated by some Would be experienced by others. This and other such absurdities would follow.

nyes pa mang por 'gyur te 'di ltar sngar gyi bdag de dus der zhig pa'i phyir dang / tshe 'dir de las rang bzhin gyis gzhan du gyur pa zhig kho na skyes pa'i phyir sngar gyi bdag de rgyun chad par 'gyur te/ bdag snga ma las phyi ma 'byung ba mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / bdag snga ma de rgyun chad na ni de'i mjug tu 'byung ba'i las kyi 'bras bu rnams rten chad pas rnam par chad pa'i phyir dang / de'i za ba po yang med pa'i phyir las rnams kyi 'bras bu chud za bar 'gyur ro/ / ci ste sngar gyi bdag gis byas pa'i las kyi 'bras bu bdag phyi mas longs spyod par 'dod na/ de lta na yang rgyud gzhan gyis byas pa'i las rnams kyi 'bras bu rgyud gzhan gyis so sor myong ba dang / de la sogs pa ni rab byed brgyad par/ ci ste las ni ma byas na/ / ma byas pa dang phrad 'jigs 'gyur/ / zhes bshad pa de lta bu la sogs pa'i skyon du thal bar 'gyur ro/ /

There would be lots of errors! Since the previous self would have already disintegrated in that life, and since the self that is essentially different from it would be born in this life, the continuum of the self of the previous life would be broken. This is because it would not be tenable for the later self to arise from the previous self. If the continuum of the previous self were broken, then the karmic connection to the effect would be broken, since its basis would no longer exist. Without the experiencer of the karma, the effects of the karma would be nullified. Suppose someone maintained that the effect of the karma generated by the earlier self is experienced by the later self. Even in that case, absurd consequences would follow. For instance, the effect of the karma generated by someone’s continuum would be experienced by another continuum. This problem and other similar ones are discussed in the seventeenth chapter: If action were not produced, [469] One would have to fear encountering something not engendered. [XVII: 23ab]
ma byung ba las 'byung min te/ / 'di la skyon du thal bar 'gyur/ / bdag ni byas par 'gyur ba dang / / 'byung ba'ang rgyu med can du 'gyur/ /
12. Nothing comes to exist from something that did not exist. Absurd consequences would follow from this: The self would be produced, Would arise anew, or be without a cause.

gzhan yang tshe 'di'i bdag 'di sngar gyi bdag las rang bzhin gyis gzhan du gyur pa zhig 'dir skyes na ni/ nga'o snyam pa'i tha snyad kyi gzhi'i bdag de sngar ma byung ba las phyis 'byung bar 'gyur na sngar ma byung ba las phyis 'byung ba ni min te/ de ltar 'dod pa 'di la mi 'dod pa'i skyon du thal bar 'gyur te/ 'di ltar bdag sngar ma byung ba las phyis 'byung na ni bdag rgyus byas par 'gyur na/ bdag rdzas su yod par 'dod pa rnams kyis ni rtag pa dang rtag mi rtag gang du yang brjod du med par 'dod la byas na ni mi rtag par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, if the self that is born in this life were essentially different from the self of the previous life, then the self that is the basis of the conventional thought ‘I’ would arise from that which did not exist earlier. But that which is later cannot arise from that which did not exist earlier, because, if you maintain this, unacceptable consequences will follow: If the self arises from that which did not exist earlier, the self would be produced by a cause. But those who maintain that the self is a substantial existent assert that it is inexpressible whether the self is permanent or impermanent. If it is produced, it must be impermanent.

gzhan yang bdag de sgrub par byed pa de las tha dad pa'i byed pa po med pa'i phyir bdag byas pa nyid du ga la rigs/ bdag byas par rtog na 'khor ba'i thog ma yod pa dang sngon med pa'i sems can gsar du 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i skyon 'grel par gsungs so/ / skyon 'di dag 'jug tshul ni tshe snga phyi'i bdag gnyis ngo bo nyid kyis gzhan du smra na/ tshe snga phyi la sogs pa'i dus kyis khyad par du ma byas pa lhas byin gyis gang la dmigs nas nga'o snyam pa skye ba'i bdag spyi tsam pa de/ gang zag de'i tshe 'di'i dus kyi bdag dang rang bzhin gyis tha dad pa mi 'thad pas rang bzhin gyis gcig tu 'dod dgos so/ / de lta na tshe 'di'i dus kyi bdag skye ba snga ma rnams su med par gsar du 'dir 'byung ba bzhin du/ bdag tsam po de yang de bzhin du 'byung bas bdag tsam po de la thog ma yod pa dang de 'dra ba'i bdag gam sems can tsam de/ tshe snga mar ma byung bar gsar du 'dir 'byung ba'i skyon du 'gyur zhing bdag tsam de tshe 'dir gsar du byung na/ de'i sngon du de sgrub pa'i bdag gzhan zhig 'gro dgos na de yang med pa'i phyir bdag tsam de tshe 'dir gsar du byas par yang mi rigs pa'o/ / lhas byin gyi bdag tsam de tshe 'dir gsar du byung ba yin na de ltar 'byung ba de rgyu med pa can du 'gyur te/ de'i sngar lhas byin dang rgyud gcig pa'i bdag ma song ba'i phyir dang tshe 'di'i bdag la de byed pa po bdag cig sngon du 'gro dgos pa'i phyir ro/ // 'am zhes pa ni rnam par brtag pa'i don yin te/ yang na bdag byas par 'gyur yang na bdag 'das dus su ma byung bar khas mi blang zhes pa dang / yang na bdag 'byung ba rgyu med du 'gyur yang na bdag 'das dus su ma byung bar khas mi blang zhes pa'i don no/ /

Moreover, if the self is not different from the agent that produces it, how could it make sense that it is produced? If one thought the self were produced, then, as the Commentary says, the following errors would ensue: There would be a beginning to cyclic existence and new sentient beings would come into existence [193b–194a]. How would these errors ensue? Suppose one said that the selves of the sequential lives are inherently different from one another. Then it would not be tenable, without specifying the selves in terms of such things as the temporal periods of sequential lives, that his general self, on which he focuses when the thought ‘I’ occurs to Lhejin, is essentially different from the self of this life of that person. Thus, one would have to say that they are essentially identical. But in that case, just as the self of this life is born anew without having existed earlier, the mere self would also be arisen in that way./2/ Therefore, the erroneous consequence would follow that the mere self would have a beginning and that the self of a sentient being would arise anew without having existed in a previous life. If the mere self were to arise anew in this life, there would have to be another self preceding it that produces it. [470] But since there is not, it does not make sense to say that the mere self arises anew in this life. If Lhejin’s mere self arose anew in this life, it would thus arise causelessly, because prior to it the continuum with which Lhejin’s self is identical would not have existed and because the self of this life must be preceded by the self that produces it. “Or” means alternatively. Thus one would have to say on the one hand, either that the self is produced or that “I do not assert that the self did not exist in the past,” or on the other hand, either that the self arises causelessly, or that “I do not assert that the self did not exist in the past.”
gnyis pa [mjug bsdus te lta ba gzhan gnyis kyang mi 'thad par bstan pa] ni/
1.2.1.1.2 Drawing the conclusion that the two views regarding the other two temporal periods are also not tenable
de ltar bdag byung bdag ma byung / / gnyi ga gnyi ga ma yin par/ / 'das la lta ba gang yin pa/ / de ni 'thad pa ma yin no/ /
13. So, the views “I existed,” “I didn’t exist,” Both, or neither In the past Are untenable.

de ltar sngar ji skad bshad pa'i tshul du bdag 'das pa'i dus na byung ba dang bdag 'das pa'i dus su ma byung ba'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis gnas par lta ba gnyis mi 'thad la/ so so ba mi 'thad pa'i phyir bdag 'das dus su byung ma byung gnyis ka tshogs par lta ba yang mi 'thad do/ / de ltar gnyis ka tshogs pa mi 'thad pa'i phyir de gnyis bkag pa'i sgo nas 'das pa'i dus su byung ma byung gnyis ka ma yin pa'i ngo bor rang bzhin gyis gnas par lta ba yang mi 'thad do/ / de ltar na rten 'byung ji bzhin du mthong ba ni sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba de rnams la rten par mi byed de/ de rnams ni dngos po rnam pa gzhan du gnas pa la de las rnam pa gzhan du 'dzin pa yin la rten 'byung rtogs pa la ni de ltar zhen pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar na nga 'das pa'i dus na 'dir gyur to zhes pa'i don tha snyad pa'i nga ni de skad smra ba'i dus kyi gang zag de la mi byed kyi/ dus snga phyi la sogs pas khyad par du ma byas par de rnams la rjes su 'gro ba'i gang zag tsam zhig la bya ba yin no/ / tshul de rtogs na ni mdo sde las/ nga sngon tshe 'dir gyur zhes mang po gsungs pa'i don de skad smra dus kyi sangs rgyas de/ tshe rabs snga ma'i dus su byung ba'i gang zag rnams dang dngos po gcig tu yod do/ / zhes smra ba'i sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba ngan pa rnams ldog ste phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba ngan pa rnams kyang ldog go /

As was discussed previously, neither the view that I existed essentially in a previous form earlier, nor the view that I was essentially nonexistent in a previous form is tenable. Since neither of them is individually tenable, the view that I both existed earlier and did not exist earlier is not tenable either. Since neither is tenable, on the ground of their refutation, neither the view that I essentially existed, nor that I did not exist in a previous form nor neither is tenable. Thus, those who see dependent origination as it is do not rely on views that depend on the prior limit. While those who do not see reality see things differently from the way they in fact exist, those who understand dependent origination do not have such fixations. Thus the conventional ‘I’ which is the referent of the statement “I existed in that form earlier” is not the person at the time he is speaking, but it refers to the mere person, which is spread over many lives without specifying particular sequential lives. If one understands this approach, [471] then one will eliminate wrong views relying on the prior limit such as the view that the meaning of the many statements by the Buddha, “I existed earlier in that form” mean that the Buddha is identical to the persons who existed in those previous lives. Thus through eliminating wrong views depending on the prior limit, one will also eliminate wrong views relying on the posterior limit as well.
gnyis pa [des phyi ma'i mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan dang po khegs par bstan] ni/
1.2.1.2 Showing that thereby the first set of four views depending on the posterior is refuted
ma 'ongs dus gzhan 'byung 'gyur dang / / 'byung bar mi 'gyur zhes bya bar/ / lta ba gang yin de dag ni/ / 'das pa'i dus dang mtshungs pa yin/ /
14. To say “in the future I will exist” or “I will not exist”: Such views are like Those involving the past.

bdag ma 'ongs pa'i dus gzhan na 'byung bar 'gyur ba dang bdag dus der 'byung bar mi 'gyur zhes bya bar rang bzhin gyis gnas par lta ba gang yin pa de dag dgag pa ni/ 'das pa'i dus su byung ma byung du lta ba dgag pa dang mtshungs pa yin pas de'i 'don pa bsgyur la dgag go / de yang*/ ma 'ongs dus na 'byung 'gyur zhes/ / bya ba de ni mi 'thad de/ / ma 'ongs tshe la gang 'byung ba/ / de nyid 'di ni ma yin no/ / zhes sogs kyis tshe snga phyi'i bdag gnyis gcig pa dgag pa dang*/ ma 'ongs dus na mi 'byung zhes/ / bya ba de yang mi 'thad de/ / ma 'ongs tshe la gang 'byung ba/ / de las 'di gzhan ma yin no/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pas bdag gnyis gzhan yin pa 'gog pa rnams mtshungs par sbyar ro/ /

The refutation of the views that there is essential existence in the context of the fact that I will exist in some future time and that I will essentially not exist in some future time follows the refutation of the views that I existed in the past and that I did not exist in the past. Therefore they can be refuted by rearranging several verses of the text, such as the following: To say “I will exist in the future” Is not tenable. What will exist in the future Is not identical to this one./3/ These verses refute the identity of the selves of sequential lives. To say “in the future I will exist” Would not be tenable. This person is not different From whoever will exist in future lives./4/ These verses refute the two selves being different from each other. Thus they should be applied similarly.
gsum pa [sngon gyi mtha' la brten pa'i lta ba bzhi tshan gnyis pa dgag]
1.2.1.3 Refutation of the second set of four views depending on the prior limit
['di] la gnyis/ rtag mi rtag gi mthar lta ba dang po gnyis dgag / mthar lta ba phyi ma gnyis dgag pa'o/ //
This section has two parts: the refutation of the first two extreme views of permanence and impermanence and the refutation of the final two extreme views.
dang po [rtag mi rtag gi mthar lta ba dang po gnyis dgag] ni/
1.2.1.3.1 Refutation of the first two extreme views of permanence and impermanence
gal te lha de mi de na/ / de lta na ni rtag par 'gyur/ / lha ni ma skyes nyid 'gyur te/ / rtag la skye ba med phyir ro/ /
15. If a god were a human, Then it would be permanent. The god would be unborn. For that which is permanent is unborn.

'di na mi'i 'gro ba kha cig dge ba'i las byas nas lha'i 'gro bar 'gro'o/ / de la de gnyis rang bzhin gyis yod na ngo bo nyid kyis gcig pa'am tha dad pa gang yin/ gal te dang po ltar na lha de nyid mi de nyid do zhes bya bar 'gyur la de lta na ni mi de rtag par 'gyur te mi'i dngos po ma dor bar lha'i skye ba len pa'i phyir ro/ / mi de lhar ni ma skyes pa nyid du yang 'gyur te rtag pa la skye ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir sngon gyi mtha' la dmigs nas 'jig rten rtag go zhes lta ba 'thad pa ma yin no/ /

Here, consider a human transmigrator who, because of his virtuous actions, transmigrates to a divine realm. In this case, if both the human and the god exist essentially, are they inherently identical or are they inherently different? In the first case, one would have to say that this very god is a man. And in that case, this man would be permanent, because without giving up his human identity he takes birth as a god. Or, on the other hand, it would follow that the man does not take birth as a god, because that which is permanent is birthless. Therefore the view that the world is permanent, focusing on the prior limit, [472] is not tenable.
gal te lha las mi gzhan na/ / de lta na ni mi rtag 'gyur/ / gal te lha mi gzhan yin na/ / rgyud ni 'thad par mi 'gyur ro/ /
16. If a human were different from a god, Then it would be impermanent. If the human and the god were different, Their continuum would not be tenable.

gal te lha las mi rang bzhin gyis gzhan yin na de lta yin na ni a mra'i shing nim pa'i shing dang rgyud mi gcig pa bzhin du/ lha mi gnyis kyang rgyud gcig tu gtogs par mi 'gyur te rang mtshan gyis so so ba la rgyu 'bras mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir sngar gyi mi'i rgyun mi rtag pa ste chad par 'gyur ro/ / gal te lha las mi rang bzhin gyis gzhan yin na de gnyis rgyud gcig ni 'thad par mi 'gyur na snga ma'i rgyud rjes su 'jug pa'i rgyud gcig ni yod do/ / de'i phyir sngon gyi mtha' la dmigs nas 'jig rten mi rtag go zhes rang bzhin gyis gnas par lta ba yang mi 'thad do/ /

If the man were essentially different from the god, then, just as the mango tree and the neem tree do not belong to the same continuum, the man and the god cannot be regarded as belonging to the same continuum. This is because those that are different in virtue of their own characteristics cannot be cause and effect. Therefore, the previous continuum of the man, which is impermanent, would be broken. If the man were essentially different from the god, then it would not be tenable for both of them to belong to the same continuum, but the later continuum is a continuation of the previous continuum. Therefore, the view that the world exists essentially impermanently, focusing on the prior limit, is also untenable.
gnyis pa [mthar lta ba phyi ma gnyis dgag pa] ni/
1.2.1.3.2 Refutation of the final two extreme views
gal te mi 'di phyogs gcig gis mi'i lus btang nas phyogs gcig gis lha'i lus len pas ril po rtag pa dang mi rtag pa'i skyon med do zhe na/

Suppose someone argued as follows: This man partly gives up his human body and partly takes up a divine body. Therefore neither the error of saying that he is entirely permanent nor that of saying that he is entirely impermanent is committed.
gal te phyogs gcig lha yin la/ / phyogs gcig mi ni yin gyur na/ / rtag dang mi rtag 'gyur ba yin/ / de yang rigs pa ma yin no/ /
17. If he were partly divine And partly human, He would be both permanent and impermanent. That would make no sense.

'di ni skye ba snga phyi'i lha mi gnyis srog gam bdag gi cha nas gcig dang lus kyi cha nas so sor 'dod pa lta bu'o/ / gal te mi 'di phyogs gcig ste bdag gi ngos nas lha yin la phyogs gcig pa ste lus kyi ngos nas mi ni yin par gyur na/ de'i tshe lha'i phyogs gcig mi'i dus su yang gnas pas rtag pa dang / mi'i phyogs gcig lha'i dus su zhig pas mi rtag par 'gyur ba yin na/ mi'i 'gro ba'i cha gcig lhas bsdus la cha gcig mis bsdus pa de yang rigs pa ma yin no/ / de'i phyir sngon gyi mtha' la dmigs nas rtag mi rtag gnyis kar lta ba yang mi 'thad do/ / gal te rtag pa dang mi rtag pa gnyis ka ngo bos grub par gyur na ni rtag pa yang ma yin mi rtag pa yang min pa ngo bos grub par 'gyur ba 'dod la rag na/ de gnyis ngo bos grub pa sngar bkag pas mi 'grub bo/ 'dir 'grel pas rtag pa cung zad cig yod na de phyis mi rtag par mthong ba las rtag pa min pa dang ma rtag pa cung zad cig yod na ni/ de phyis rtag par 'gyur ba las mi rtag pa min pa 'grub na'ang zhes gsungs pa'i rigs pa de'i don ji ltar yin snyam na/ mi lhar skye ba lta bu de la mi'i bdag rtag pa zhig yod na des lha'i lus blangs pa'i tshe mi'i phung po 'dor bas/ cha de nas rtag pa min pa dang mi'i phung po 'dor rgyu mi rtag pa zhig rang bzhin gyis yod na/ lha'i lus blangs pa'i tshe phung po de zhig kyang 'dor ba po rtag par yod pas/ cha de nas mi rtag pa yang min pa'i gnyis min gyi mthar lta ba de rigs na'ang de gnyis med ces pa'i don no/ /

This is like the view according to which the man and the god of successive lives are identical in terms of their being or self and distinct in terms of their bodies.
